column5: Poured an amber body with thin head. Aroma is grainy with a similarity to cereal - frosted mini wheats?. Flavor is bitter and dry with a sweet malty feel. Light mouthfeel with a fruity feeling that I couldn’t recognize

Draught sample at the restaurant. Slightly hazy copper color with a foamy white head. Classic lager aroma with a hint of caramely sweetness. Pretty tasty for a pale lager. A little sweet at first but finishes with some crisp bitterness.
Clear dark yellow with no head. Grainy biscuit aroma and a sweet vanilla malt taste with citrus notes to the finish.
Nose is light honey, maybe some diacetyl. Flavor is pretty held back - some light malt, some hop, nothing you can really put a finger on.
On tap at the brewery. Came an almost clear gold. Average white head. Aroma of wheat with a little floral hops. Tastes a bit sweet, again just a bit of hops. Not bad, not good.

Date: February 25, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy gold, fine dirty white head, heavy lace Aroma: light sweet cereal aroma with light floral hops Flavor: light sweet cereal flavor, light balancing bitterness Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 5/20 Rating: 1.7/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: 4

Sampler @ brewpub. I wasn’t going to rate this but I was actually surprised by this brew. Its not that is a well made beer but they were able to make it bad while having it come out nice enough to drink. Color is hazy clear dark straw. Its a weirdly lightly sweet lager. Has just a bit of lemon zing to it. Again, not well made to style but works for me enough.

4 oz sampler at the brewpub. Pour is almost all clear golden, some carbonation. Smallish white head. Aroma of not much, maybe some soft malt. Taste is clean, sweet fruit (almost banana) a touch of malt and OK hop bitterness to the back. Palate is slightly on the thick side for a lager, but gave it a nice body without hurting how it drank. Small diacetyl as it warmed, giving some buttery notes. Overall, nice beer.
Tasted at the High Noon Saloon in Leavenworth, KS. Pours a golden color. light fruity/floral aroma. Taste is hoppy with a slightly sweet berry flavor. I was really surprised by this lager

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy gold with a thin, wispy, white head. The nose is a fairly muted light grain with not a whole lot else going on here, but it has nothing offensive or distracting in it like so many other adjunct-laden lagers. Light-bodied and thin with a tight but mild carbonation and a clean finish. Sweet and clean with just a touch of a floral hop note at the finish. Not too shabby. I’d drink this any day over BMC lagers.

A strange brew. Pours a nearly clear, nearly pink-amber with only a thin layer of head. Interesting, strong aroma almost exactly like those Jolly Rancher watermelon candies. So far so good. Didn’t care for the taste. Tasted more like a canteloupe than a watermelon. I don’t really care for canteloupe very much. If you do, you will like this beer more than I did. Light body, light carbonation. Well made, to be sure, just not for me.

Sampled this beer at the Great Taste of the Midwest in Madison WI. Even though my scores on this are accurate and well researched, Da Man wants me to say more about the beer, so I will. Over the last 3 months or so, I've grown to live watermellon brews, I think this one is quite possibly my new best friend.
Kind of a dark pink color with no head. Watermelon and more watermelon... it kind of tastes like a Jolly Rancher, very sweet. The wheat kicks in at the end. Pretty tasty!
This Has Something of a Glowing Red/Orange Coloring. Medium Head. Smells of Watermelon. Watermelon Flavor Hits you Right Away and Then The Wheat Jumps in For the Finale... Pretty Decent Offering.

Strange combination - but surprisingly good together. The flavor was not as artificial as one might expect and was very refreshing. Just the right amount of cloudiness. The Brewhouse itself was quite impressive as well.

On tap at the brewpub. It poured a copper color with a white head. The aroma was of caramel, toffee, nuts and citrus. The taste was similar to the aroma with more caramel, toffee, nuts, citrus and mild carbonation with a semi-sweet aftertaste. Decent.

Keg at the Water Street location. Clear amber, no head. Aroma of sweet caramel. Taste is watery caramel. Trying to live up to the name? Thin, watery. Not much here and considering the other beers that's a positive.
Tap at brewery. Yellow with thin head. Smells a little like play doh and grainy. Assertive aroma. Flavor is off with way too much sweetness.
Too Light in flavor. Nice color, deep orange. Low carbonation. Aroma was good, caramel and malt. Tap
No hop aromaand good malt aroma showing some oxidation. Head does not linger like the real deal. Malt flavor is not complex enough and has papery notes. A little astringency.
Draft at the downtown brewery in Milwaukee. Reddish-copper color. Caramel aroma. Caramel flavor. Mouthfeel is of watered-down syrup. Sweet, cloying finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. From notes. Bready with grains and light caramel. Drinkable, but not great.

On tap at the Grafton location, and dispensed to a dimpled mug, displaying a clear, coppery color with a decent layer of off white/light tan head foam that lasted a bit, and clingy spots & streaks of lacing. The nose was simply light toast and some caramel sweetness. Light to medium bodied, with moderate carbonation, moderate hop bitterness, and fair maltiness. Basically sessionable.
On tap @ the brewery in Milwuakee. Medium brown with a minuscule head. Sweet caramel, too sweet, and nothing else. Dirty earthy aftertaste.
Tasted on tap at Water Street Brewery. A clear light brown with very little head. A light malt aroma and taste. Not much else happening with the taste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at brewery. Amber color with thin head. Damp dog smell. A bit of a dirty aims amd flavor.
Not my gig, but easy for an amber. Light in every aspect except for the deeper orange red color. Close to what an amber should be. Tap
Minimal noble hop aroma. Head does not linger. Taste is caramelized Malty with oxidation. Semi sweet finish.
Draft at the downtown brewery in Milwaukee (as "Victory Amber"). Toasted biscuit aroma. Copper color. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at the source. From notes. Pretty standard amber, malty with a decent backbone. Good, but not great.
Pours a clear copper color with off-white head. Caramel and roasted malts on the nose; follows onto the palate. Pretty basic amber.

On tap at Water Street Brewery, Grafton, Wisconsin. Sweet caramel detected in this slightly darker than average amber. Light malts and moderately hopped. This is good, but nothing outstanding. Head died pretty quick and left no indication of it’s previous existence. No lacing or foam floaters. This was alright on tap, but nothing I would buy to bring home. 2.8 out of 5 is a gift. It did go well with the jalapeno pretzels I was eating at the bar.
Tasted on tap at Water Street Brewery. Clear amber with a frothy white head. Almost no aroma and a bland, one dimensional taste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Water Street. Pours amber with a yellowish head. Nose shows some faint citrus and caramel. Dusty notes and earth. Not much going on. On tasting, more of the same. Moderate sweetness, medium bitterness. Caramel and bitter. Bland. Probably my least favorite.
An odd amber. Dark amber color. Earthy, caramel, dark fruit(?). Flavor follows nose. Not alot of character.
On tap @ the brewery. Hazy dull gold-amber. Aroma is weak peachy hops, light sweet malts. The palate delivers the same, with an earthy unpleasant undertone. Just not very good.

On tap at Water Street Brewery, Grafton, Wisconsin. Caramel pour with some nuts in the background. Malty, light bakery, slightly nutty, fruity, and a tad floral. Hoppy as hell. This is more like an amber ale to me, but they can call it what they wish. Water Streets best brew in my opinion.
Draft at the brew pub. Murky, rusty orange. Presents a nice, fruity aroma. Drinks with an almost smoky malt swirl right up front and then comes the sweet, melon-fruity salad. (#5144, 7/5/2013)
Tasted on tap at Water Street Brewery. A light cloudy amber with a thin white head and a bit of lacing. A nice little hop bite, but not much flavor otherwise. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Water Street. pours a paler color than the amber, more gold. Sticky white head. Nose is light citrus, toasty malts, faint caramel. Light nose. On tasting, well balanced. Bitterness is moderate, light citrusy notes on the palate. Clean and crisp but somewhat uninspired.
Medium yellow, some head and lacing. Mild hop, citrus aroma. Flavor has lots of hop, some mild citrus, pine. More balanced than most of the other Water Street beers. Lacks impact.

On tap at the downtown brewery. Pours a clear golden orange with a white head. Aroma has pine with some malty hints. Taste is of sweet pine, some bread, grassy hops and some caramel back. Finishes a bit sweet, with light bitterness. Nothing bad or offputting. A solid drinker. Nothing to stand it out, though, either - almost macro-ish.
Sample. Rating #53. Clear and kinda of a dark amber, seems unusual for a pale ale. Nice little pine hop aroma, very familiar, columbus maybe. Real nice hop bite and really tasty. (2423)

On tap at the Delafield location. Pours a clear gold with the slightest orange hue and a near white head that dissipates to the edges and laces slightly. Aroma has some earthy grassy hops with backing grains and a bit of sweetness in the finish. Flavor begins with some earthy grains but also hs some earthy pine and grassy hops.
A nice hoppy session ale and pretty damn flavorful relative to the rest of their lineup.

On tap at the brewpub. It poured a hazy yellow color with a white head. The aroma was of citrus, hay and fruits. The taste was similar to the aroma with more citrus, hay, fruits, lemon and medium carbonation with a sweet aftertaste. Hmmmm.
Keg at the Water Street location. Hazy orange, no head. Aroma of clove and wheat. Taste is wheat, citrus, spice. Thin, flavors all over the place. Dirty. Lingering spice. What a mess.
Tap at brewery in Milwaukee during glbtq. Hazy gold orange with thick white head. Aroma is a weaker version of typical of style. Coriander spice, fruit. Typical but below average.
Tap at brewery. Hazy yellow with thin head. Light aroma of lemon and bubblegum with the impression of heat on the nose. Flavor is a little off.
Sour scent. Some bite but the American chair flavor is higher than the Belgium. Yellow hazy. Tap

Draft at the downtown brewery in Milwaukee. Cloudy, light brown color. Old banana and cloves in the nose; a hint of smoke as well. Old, black bananas and clove notes. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at the source. From notes. Pretty standard hefe with wheat, banana and clove. Decent.
On tap at Wisconsin state fair. Solid weiss, hazy golden color, aroma and taste citrus and light banana.

On tap @ the brewery in Milwuakee. Murky dull golden amber with very scant head formation (for a wheat beer, this is a poor showing). Aroma is wheaty with a touch of both banana and citrus. The palate is a little thin, with light banana and spice, finishing with a citric tanginess. The best of the brews we tried here, bu not a great hefe.

On tap @ Water Street Brewery, Grafton, Wisconsin. Caramel and malted milk pour. Aroma of rotting bananas. Flavor of a banana malted milkshake. Many wheat beers have a banana taste to them and it sucks. This is no different though I have had worse.
Very light, well carbonated, not much to it for flavor or aroma, but certainly not a bad beer.

On tap at Water Street - Delafield. Poured a pale, almost urine yellow with a medium cap of white head. Aroma was of dish soap first and foremost.. muted pils malts and some biscuits in there deeper down. The flavor was just a hair better.. the soap was there, but sweet bready malts and mild bitterness were more pronounced and somewhat tasty. Light-bodied and slick on the palate with a thankfully short finish.
On tap at the Water Street in Delafield location. Poured a light to medium golden color with a smaller sized white head. Aromas and tastes of light grass and some citrus. Thinner body.

Dark yellow/light amber in color with virtually no head. There was a slightly smokey malt note in the nose and taste. The grassy, slightly lemony hops comes through clearly. This is a hot weather quencher, but not outstanding.
On tap. Rather still-looking, not very heavily carbonated for a pils; burnt/smoky notes in the nose and flavor, hoppiness really comes through at the end in a long, bitter finish.

9/17/18 (Milwaukee): $6.37 .4L mug draft pour at Water Street Brewery. Light golden pour with nice carbonation and light white head, faint malt with light honey aroma. Light honey taste, carbonation holds, clean crisp. Overall OK pour.

On tap at the brewpub. It poured a clear golden color with a white head. The aroma was of florals, hops, hay and honey. The taste was similar to the aroma with more florals, hops, hay, honey and with light carbonation and a sweet aftertaste. Not sure about this one.
Keg at the brewpub. Clear amber, large creamy offwhite head, good retention. Aroma of doughy malt, honey. Taste is citrus, honey, pale malt. Thin, boring.
Tap at brewery. Yellow with thin head. Smells like honey and cereal. Has a hint of sour and light bitterness with a honey aftertaste.
It’s exactly what it says, again, not my thing, but I rate on style and descriptions. Aroma is pleasant. Taste is slightly sweet with honey, clovers, and malty. Tap
Not my style, this one is brewed for the masses. Brewed to style , no faults found.
Draft at the downtown brewery in Milwaukee. Honey and apple aroma. Fizzy carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at the brewpub. Honey with citrus. Pretty grainy. Meh, not awful but not too special either.
Pours a clear golden color with white head. Cereal grain and honey on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with just little sweetness.
On tap @ Water Street Brewery, Grafton, Wisconsin. Crisp nose of light citrus malts. Pale golden soda water. Very lightly hopped. Honey is detected and that’s bad: I don’t like honey!
Cloudy white. Thin head. Yeasty. Pretty standard belgian wit. Surprised no coriander.....maybe I’m too used to blue moon.

Tap. Pours a hazy light straw yellow color. Foamy white head. Aroma is coriander, orange peel. Yeast, and wood. Flavor is dry, wood shavings, light soapy and floral notes. Light finish. Fairly refreshing. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at brewpub. Pours a clear gold, although this advertises itself as a witbier. Aroma is some weird banana mix. Tastes like cough syrup with a sour citrus finish. The mouthfeel’s rapid evanescence only deteriorates the experience. Terrible and witless.

Pleasant looking, coming with an orange slice, which I found odd. Sweet tasting beer, with a hint of orange and coriander. Cloudy reddish-brown color, this is a beer that people who like Blue Moon Belgium White would like.

Slight head and effervescence. Faint but insistent aroma of orangeade and coriander. Light, hazy golden amber color. Some wheat malt present in the flavor, along with some sweet-tart spiciness and definite orange peel. This sounds like it would be good, but the flavorings are almost artificial tasting, and the palate is very fizzy indeed. Aftertaste is more of the same. Not complex. It's hard for me to say exactly what makes this beer taste the way it does, but either way it needs less of it IMHO.

My bottle looks like the picture with Kerst not winter so this may be a bit old. Pour is a murky dirty river water brown. Aroma is dark fruit and fig pudding. Flavor is some dark fruit and lots of tootsie roll like sweetness. No alcohol is felt but it is getting a bit warmer in here. This is a big malty, dark fruit flavored strong ale. Not much spices are felt this is all about the dark fruit malt and sugar.

Bottled, 2006 vintage, sampled in 2016. Brown colored, small mostly disappearing beige head, still some pressure upon opening. Aged nose, malts, caramel, molasses, ethanol, not bad. Malty flavor, sharp alcohol, caramel, together with some cardboard. Ten years was way too long, but still it’s quite reasonable.
Kobber klar skum hvid Chokolade vinøs Sherry træ gær Bitter modrate sød Cremet flad @home Mindst 6 år over salg

11.2 oz. bottle picked up locally and discovered in the back of my fridge recently. Pours a hazy deep amber brown color with a medium plus sized beige head. The aroma and flavor have sweet malts, caramel, brown sugar, ripe dark fruits, dates, fig, some berries, spices, coriander, some oxidation as this wasn’t a fresh bottle, but still pretty tasty, alcohol was warming, but blended nicely with the beer.

As: Kerst Smiske Vintage 2010 tasted in Nov. 2015. Aroma: fruity sweet with dark berries and notes of cognac. Flavour: sweet dark berries and a dry finish. A creamy mouthfeel and a warm alcoholic finish. Colour: reddish brown with an offwhite head.

330ml bottle at the Hoppy Pub, Thessaloniki, courtesy of skullgeorge. Hazy dark amber almost brown color with off white to beige head. Aroma is yeasty light funky, spicy, citrusy fruity, caramel malty. Sweet and light bitter, lot of caramel - burnt sugar, fruity, light wineous. Medium oily body with soft to flat carbonation.

Appearance: It is a hazy murky iced tea brown color with a thin dirty-white head that fades instantly. As usual head retention is not something to hold against a beer that is 12%. Aroma: There is a strong caramel scent along with dates. It has a very rich aroma to it, that completely consumes all olfactory senses. If aroma had a "mouthfeel" it would be syrupy. Taste: It has quite a lot of flavor. At first there is this rich candy caramel flavor, then it is followed by this nutty pecan flavor, which has a biscuit aftertaste, and a popcorn-like ending. I like it. Mouthfeel: Despite the collection of flavors and ABV of the beer, it comes across as a fairly medium bodied beer, and a lighter shade of medium to boot. It has a touch of effervescence which seems to further the lightness of the body. I would like to see a larger beer like this have more of a coating quality. Overall: I didn’t pick up any coriander or grains of paradise, but the flavor qualities were still there to make this an interesting beer. It didn’t blow me away but it was a good beer. Try it if you like large Belgian beers, but you’re not missing anything if you can’t get it.

It pours a very hazy/cloudy dark honey colour, 1 finger head of foam with the usual Belgian quality re retention and lacing. The smell is of dark fruits, black cherries amongst them?, yeasty, some light spiciness. The taste is stronger than the nose but not as impressive to me. Dark pitted fruits, yeasty, orange peel bitterness, has some woody notes and light Port(more of that please), vanilla,..to me, a tad over complex and not everything comes together in total harmony. Top end of medium bodied, medium carbo, very good mouthfeel. So, in the end analysis, I reckon, despite what I said about the complexity above, this IS a very good brew.
Bottle@home with Erik. No head. Muddied. Very low carbonation. Dry fruity figs dates prune. Rather prominent heavy sweetness. The spices drown in the sweet flavours.

Pours a dull mahogany color with two fingers of aggressive white foam. Aromas of sweet date, burnt sugar, peppered yeast, clove and walnut. Palate follows with nice balance between sweet burnt sugar and date flavors with spiced bitter walnut and some lingering yeast esters.
according to the label, this is a new recipe - clear dark bronw colour, almost no foam, some maltiness in the nose, slightly toasted, flat and watery flavour, absence of aftertaste - what a pity ...
Draft @ the brewpub. Pours an amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel hoppy aroma. Fruity malty caramel hoppy flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel hoppy finish.
Pours fully murky and brownish murky. Aroma is very mild, some hoppy notes. Taste is very mild, quickly builds up sour body but also quickly dissipates. Lasting slightly sour taste. An ok amber.

Bomber from Bottles N Bins in Monterey, CA. Pours dark copper with a beige head. Aroma is floral with a chocolate note. Med minus body. Flavor is a bit spicy, somewhat roasty malt, a touch of nut, and a hint of chocolate. Better than many ambers, but incredible amounts of hop would help it IMHO.
Tap at the brewpub in Monterey. Clear deep orange amber pour with a small dense ring head. Bread. Sweet caramel. Bit of raisin. Some mild hop poking through.

[2/16/15] Draught at Peter B’s Brewpub in Monterey. As Inclusion Amber. Clear amber. Aroma of malt, caramel and vegetables. Sweetish flavor with malt, caramel, a vegetal hint and a bitterish finish. Medium-bodied.
Light retention and light lacing. Smells of rich malt and floral. Tastes of toasted malt, slight hops and sweet bread. No aftertaste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This rich amber colored beer has the aroma of caramel. It also comes through in the flavor and tasted like its roasted in a fire. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Light amber coloured beer with almost no carbonation and a very short white head. Light honey sweet hinted aroma with a short hoppy hint. Medium palate. Finish is light butter, sweet bitter and malty hinted. Medium.

On-tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy amber with a moderate white head, good lace. Smells caramelly maltywith some hops. Tastes sweet and sugary caramelly malty with a touch of sweet hops. Medium body, subdued carbonation.

On tap. Interesting amber ale. Pours a clear amber body with a decent off-white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of caramel and light berries. Taste is creamy and toasted with slight fruits (odd for an amber). Nice, water like mouthfeel with lively bubbles.

4oz sampler - This was brought to me as the Blonde Ale, so it will be rated as such although this was really hoppy for a Blonde. The appearance was a golden yellow body, zero carbonation with a scant white head. Aroma had light pine hops with a lighter lemony juice twist. Flavor had some pine hops, straw and lemons. Refreshing and quite tasty with the hops.

Clear golden blond coloured beer with some very light carbonation and a very short white head. Ligth buttery hinted aroma with some short hoppy hints. Medium palate. Finish is hoppy and buttery (infected?) with a short fruity yeasty hinted ending.
On tap at the brewpub. Pours dark yellow with a fluffy white head and a floral aroma. Not much taste other than a little banana ester and a slightly bitter finish.
On tap. Pours with a long lasting, thick white head, covering a clear golden body. Light, grassy aroma. Very little taste, but clean. Watery mouthfeel, with lively bubbles.
Draft. Golden-amber beer with an off-white head. LIght grass and light hay aroma. Light malt, light grass, light hay flavors. Medium body. LIght grass and grain linger.
Bland pilsner, not much of anything and not very clear, Just a drink toi drink conversation and no drunkerd brew
Cloudy yellow, light grain and musty aroma, flavor isn’t much different... thin, sour, lactic, not good at all.
Very faint hops nose. Rather thin bland pils with faint brief ending........
Hoppier than your average pilsner, but otherwise it doesn't stand out.......
Bottle. Poured an amber color with a small sized head. On the malty side with nothing really standing out.
Taster at source - pine and light bread. Light and poundable. Bitter finish with resin flavors.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a hazy copper with small off white head that lasts. The aroma is pine and citrus. Medium body, grass, grapefruit, bitter finish, decent.
Draught at Fest of Ales. Malty red almost APA with some heavy notes. Ok overall.

Old rating. Tap at the brewpub. Hazy amber with a modest off-white head. Nice light aromas of caramel, pine and citrus with some light spice as well. Fairly well balanced. A bit boring but solid enough.

on tap @ Cumberland / Louisville KY --- Clear medium amber, off-white head cover, broken bands of lace. Taste is bracing bitter malt that adds a burst of hops on the swallow, slowly drifting through a long finish. It works reasonably well because the hops, while assertive, aren’t overwhelming.
Draft sampler pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of malts, caramel and floral. Taste is malts and resin.
ホップはあんまり感じない 変な香り 甘さ控えめ、あんまりかな
Draft to taster. Looks decent; malty though. A transparent copper with thin eggshell lacing. Smells and tastes of malt and mild hops. Average on the palate. Not bad.
Good shit. Clear amber pour with thick whick head and lots of lacing. Aroma is floral and hops. Taste is floral and hops. Had a lot of beer today. This is stl pretty good.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Tap @ Firehouse. Clear, light orange-amber pour with a short white head leaving moderate fine lace. Nose is neutral. Light toasty body, no hops detectable due to strong butterscotch flavor. This is my second off ale of two from Firehosue and I have to believe they have a problem. Infected lines would be my guess. I’m done here & would recommend avoiding this place until they sort themselves out.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On tap currently at the brewpub. Golden orange appearance which is notably dark. Aroma of cream candies, cotton candy, apricot, and floral, earthy hops. Some biscuit and honey; really clean, comfortable, and relaxed. Flavor is soft and smooth with crisp grassy hops, lavender, and crystal malt; no intonations of bitter minerals or metallics that tend to drag down these brewpub renditions of european blonde ales, just a wholesome, polished canvas of czech hops and doughy, honey-sweet pale malt. Palate tepid and watery. Solid example for refreshment without any real drawbacks.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: This brew pub is just a few blocks from home, but I recently visted for the first time. Tried this on tap and was pretty happy with it...it's a bit overpriced if you ask me unless you make it to happy hour. No head...I mean none...fair smell and decent taste. If you're in Rapid City, it's worth a try (at happy Hour).

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Very fresh tasting ale on tap at the brewery. Nice golden color and hoppy aroma, with a smooth mouthfeel.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Had this beer a few years back so don't remember it very well other than I remember everything we tasted we liked. So I would have to say it was really good

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On tap in a flight at the brewery. Pours dark brown, with no head, but some lacing. Good aromas of toast and roasted malts, with some earthiness and rye. Malty and sweet, with just a touch of bitterness. Light body, with a grainy and malty mouthfeel. Pretty nice Irish red ale.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draught at the Firehouse Brewing Co, Rapid City, SD. Clear mahogany color with a small off-white head. Sweetness, caramel malt and some dryness in the aroma. Caramel malt, sweetness and some cardboard in the flavor. Not bad for an Irish Red but I just don't get the magic in that style. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: No idea where I had this, or whether it was bottled or draught. Malty, Brit style amber, not a hoppy Yank. No distinguishing features.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: aromas of cereal, caramel and toffee. red, minimal head - would have liked more on this beer medium sweetness, medium bitterness with herbal hop medium body, oily feel, could use more carbonation

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: ちょっと奈良漬け、とくに特徴ない.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a gentle hazy red color with a light transparency about it. Bar pour yields a film of a white head that dissipated within less than a minute. The smell had some bitter citrus-like hops with a light underscore of sweet caramel malts. The taste was sweet, balanced between the malts and hops, and came across somewhat crisp. On the palate, this was about a light in body. There was a slight sessionable aspect about it. Overall, decent red ale worthy of having again.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On draft at the brewery. The beer has an amber body (go figure) with a small ringlet of beige head. Spotty lacing. Aromas of pale malt, apple, grain. Light earth notes and floral hops with a malty body. A touch of fruity sweetness. Light bodied, even a tad watery, and quaffable. At just over 4% abv, this is refreshing and drinkable, albeit uneventful for the palate.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draft at brewpub. Pours reddish with a khaki head. Leaves a bit of lacing in the glass. Slight malt on the nose and tongue. 0 for 3.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Growler poured a clear reddish amber with a lingering ring of amber foam. Aromas of carmel and light fruittiness. Palate was medium bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of carmel, earthiness and light fruittiness with a crisp dry lingering carmel finish.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Dang, I thought this was going to be smoked. Pours black with tan foam. Tastes roasty, dry, lightly sweet. Flavors of ash, chocolate, vanilla, cola, dark bread. A tad thin. Not bad.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Pours a deep brown with off white head. Roasty, burnt, approaching smoked with a strong tannin finish. Notes: on tap at the brew pub, June ’17

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On tap at the Brewpub with Chris and Erica. Dark brown with an nicecreamy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate roasted coffee aroma. Medium body with a dry sticky texture. Medium sweet roasted coffee flavor with a medium bitter finish of average duration.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Drank from tap at the brewhouse/restaurant -- This stout was super thin. Did not like. First beer since I can’t remember when that I didn’t finish (and it was only a 3oz pour).

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a gentle dark brown close to black color with a thin white to off white foamy head that dissipated within less than a minute. Some light stringy lacing slid into the body. The smell had a dry roasted coffee bean with a super light underscore of chocolate. The taste was dry, light chocolate with a lighter dose of the coffee bean. On the palate, this one came across right at a medium on the body. Sessionable? Maybe... Overall, this was a pretty good Irish Dry Stout worthy of having again.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: On draft at the pub. Roasted malts dominate the aroma. The flavor consists of chocolate, roasted malts, caramel, floral/fruity/spicy hop character. This is the best beer they had on draft.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: on tap-pours black with a brown head. Aroma is dark roasty malt-molasses, bacon. Taste is dark roasty malt-peat/molasses/chocolate, 2nd earthy hops.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Draft. Murky dark brown color, solid lacing. Aroma of dark milk chocolate. Taste is roasted coffee grounds. OK.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Tap @ Brewpub: Dark brown pour with a modest tan head. The aroma is a blend of roasty malts and dark chocolate. Hints of coffee. Tastes balanced with light smoke, roast, bittersweet chocolate, and espresso. Retains a sneaky amount of sweetness for a dry stout. Nice.

column2: Rapid City, South Dakota, United States
column5: Probably the stand-out beer here - black pour - frothy, lasting tan head - pretty dang sweet for a dry stout - bittersweet aroma with some vanilla cream, chocolate, anise, roast - creamy mouthfeel - a little bitter black malt up front - quite a bit of cream sweetness through the middle and finish - a light bit of roast and anise - lingering, bittersweet finish - a decent stout.

column1: Ginga Kogen Ko Mugi no Beer
column5: Can from the supermarket . Cloudy, light orange white head. Clove, a hint of banana. Relatively dry, spicy, not as heavy as the Bavarian versions. One of the better Weizen I have had.

column1: Ginga Kogen Ko Mugi no Beer
column5: Bottle from an online Asian supermarket. Extra marks for the attractive blue bottle. Cloves to the forefront alongside citrus. A banana aroma lurks in the background. Cloudy gold. Frothy translucent white head soon shrunk away. Initial citrus sourness - quite tart. There's an underlying sweetness. Medium bodied. Slick verging on creamy. Low key fizzy carbonation. Dty finish with an edge of astringency. This as been sat forgotten at work so thought it may have faded but a refreshing Hefe which I could easily have downed on this hot summer day.

column1: Ginga Kogen Ko Mugi no Beer
column5: The Silver Bottle version. Pours cloudy with little white head. Tastes little cloves and spices. A fine but not impressive hefe.

column1: Ginga Kogen Ko Mugi no Beer
column5: Bottle, 300ml, as Silver Bottle. A cloudy yellow colour with a small head. Aroma of plum, coriander, white chocolate, elderflower. Unusual. Flavour has soft citrus and wheat. Light carbonation. Smooth and tasty, a respectable hefe.

column1: Ginga Kogen Ko Mugi no Beer
column5: Can. Hazy yellow color. Thick white head, but falls quickly. Typical aroma, maybe not that prominent. Taste is good, but palate could be better. Too carbonated for me. Overall nice and drinkable beer.

column1: Ginga Kogen Ko Mugi no Beer
column5: Weird 33cl blue glass bottle at Haikan in DC. Drank from the bottle, so who knows. Nose is medium esters, what you expect, bubblegum and clove, some orange and grass too. Flavor is tpale grist and dough, orange, clove, banana, chewed bubblegum. Finishes off dry. Fine.

column1: Ginga Kogen Ko Mugi no Beer
column5: Bought the Silver Bottle version (which is actually in a nice blue bottle) at Shilla, a Japanese/Korean grocery in Amsterdam. Opaque. Light peach colour. Thin head. Aroma is yeast and tangerines. Taste is cloves, orange, and a tin bit of spice.

column1: Ginga Kogen Ko Mugi no Beer
column5: Beautiful 300ml blue bottle with a blue and silver label from Fukuoka. It has a 11-2018 BB date stamp. This is a Belgian White ale, I guess, with moderate strength for style. above average balance, complexity and harmony, and relatively lively carbonation. Tropical fruit notes and bready malts dominate with banana and clove most noticeable.

column1: Ginga Kogen Ko Mugi no Beer
column5: Can sample at a tasting at troubles' place. Thanks Lior D. Cloudy yellow. Fruity esters, bread, some phenolic spiciness, sweet, lots of bubblegum, light sourish note, bitterish hint in the finish, light to medium-bodied. OK. Easy-drinking.

column1: Ginga Kogen Ko Mugi no Beer
column5: At Dror's place, pours hazy yellow with a small head, aroma of fruits, banana, bubblegum, flavor of banana, bubblegum, sweet, medium bodied
Fairly skunky aroma. Sweet malt, hay, mildly creamy, fairly empty finish. Light and boring beer substitute, still fairly quaffable overall.
Best of the happoshu variety without doubt. Keep in mind this is meant as a mega-refreshing beverage along with your meal.

350 ml can bought at YATA in Grand Century Place, Mong Kok. Piss golden yellow colour; Three-quarter finger head and white foam which fades in 40 seconds; Moderate sticky lacing and active carbonation; Very pungent smell of malt, with soaked urinal, strong grains, light burnt rubber, thick bread, light lemon and smelly pissy grass; Light sweet taste of thin malt, with strong grains, wet cardboard, chemicals, soda water, bread, thin lemon and faint bitter grassy hops; Light body, watery palate; Mouth feel is Happoshu-level very thin malt water, soaked with slightly sickening cold medicines, cardboard, strong grainy notes and stale bread. Doh!... Hoppiness is piss grass and light lemon nose and taste. Faint bitterness for chemical non-finish;Dry after taste, easy but awkward to mouth. Comments: Yes, this is a lowly Happoshu - it stinks in my nose, taste like near water and quite chemical-ish, but this is not the worst offender, at least it has some light malt and grain palate, and I managed to finish half a can before I poured it down the drain.

Pour from a can is clear yellow with slight white head. Aromas of grains, a little grassy, some sweat. Taste is grains, slightly sweet. Thin mouthfeel. Full carbonation. Very easy to drink and refreshing, but without much character.
~This review was made some time ago via another application, and thus the specific details (beyond numerical scores) are no longer available~

Can. Good Lord! No one has rated this for two-and-a-half years. Well, guess what? It hasn’t got any better. Some fruitiness in the aroma, also hair perm chemical, and maybe elephant piss. Typical pale yellow, thick 1-2 cm. head. Harsh grassy initial; cardboard emerges in the mid palate -- but it is very clean cardboard; the finish goes off into the fourth dimension... and I could not follow. Thin palate, with a strange sharp whole mouth feel, like a sort of mild mouthwash. Yuck! Warning: this happoshu should be consumed for research purposes only.
Can. Clear, bright gold. Scant head. Dirty socks and hot electronics aroma. Harsh rubbing alcohol and acetone in the palate and flavors. Finishes dry and does have some malt character.
Golden-straw. No head. A little bit biscuity, bready nose. Relatively full body. Slightly toasty, but also a bit taart in the finish. Fairly bland.

Can. Comes as “Sapporo Hokkaido Namashibori”. Clear yellow, short bubbly white head. Bit malty aroma with somethin grassy. Thin mouthfeel. Mild flavour of some malt, bit of grains and grass. Brewed with Ryofu barley grown in Hokkaido only. Sapporo claims that you get a "sense of nature" with this beer…. Hmmm.

Painful stuff - very light, thin and watery. There is no English on the can, not even the word Sapporo, except for "namashibori.com" in real small text on the side. A typical asian brew, though not as dry as most Sapporos. For tax reasons, Japanese brewers create these "happoshu" (low-malt) beers which are made with rice, I guess, instead of barley. Lots of water flavor.
Certainly wasn't impresed with this offering from Orion. But then again, Orion isn't my favorite Japanese beer either. Had a funky, rather unbalanced taste and not much Aroma, despite the name.

oh, orion, you’re like my little island pabst blue ribbon :o) anyway... yeaup, just another "yellow fizzy." / a decently high ABV in regards to macros, it’s appropriate to drink it one of the many, pretty beaches in okinawa... / i wonder what an Extreme and Smooth! might be like!

12 Aug 02-Similar to the regular Orion but with less carbination. Just another Japanese 'Yellow Fizzy'. Wonder why they all seem to be 5.5%, like it's a magic number or something. Re-rate- 6/24/04, Even more boring than I remembered. Knocked it down a few points.....just because.

column1: Padre Island Poncho Villa Brown Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Much better than the stout. Color of coca cola. Roasted, sweet fruitiness in the nose and taste. Well rounded finish, good but unoriginal.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Tap at brewpub. Black with lasting light brown head. Strong malty aroma, with minerals, burnt coffee and some of off-taste characteristics of the tap water here in the island. Has a dry, slightly bitter coffee flavor. Smooth feel with fine carbonation.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Draft at the restaurant on SPI. Black, opaque, with light beige head. Chocolatey aroma a little hint of coffee. More coffee flavor at the finish. Pretty good. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Again just an OK beer without a lot of standout character. No strong aroma here, maybe some roasted notes. The color was very dark with a creamy head. The mouthfeel was light. Tasted of roasted malts and maybe some chocolate. There was not much of a hops presence and a somewhat dry finish. It was fresh and easy to drink.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Black with a fizzy tan head. Chalky chocolate caramel and roasted grain aroma and taste with a coffee syrup finish.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: (Draught) Pours a black body with a small creamy beige head. Aroma of lactose, roasted malt, coffee, and some lightly charred grain. Flavor of coffee, roasted malt, and minerals with a dry finish.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Black in color with cola colored head. Decent burnt toast aroma. Bold mocha flavors; roasted coffee & dark chocolate. Overall, I like it. Probably PIB’s best offering.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Poured black with a slowly dissipating medium brown head. Aroma had notes of roasted malts and coffee. Flavor had quite an acidic coffee note to it with a dark grain undertone.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: The wife enjoyed this beer along with me. Starts off a little creamy, and then has a finish of coffee flavors and small smatterings of hops. Farily well done, not too complex but a good brew on the whole.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: A decent stout -- probably the best beer they make. Has a nice chocolate/coffee taste to it, goes down easy. Goes well with the excellent ribs they make.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Typical brewpub stout....weak, watery, and lacking flavor a stout should have.

column1: Padre Island South Padre Island Blonde Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Draft at the restaurant on SPI. Golden, slightly hazy with a thin white head. Light, malty aroma. Smooth, malty flavor. Not bad. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Padre Island South Padre Island Blonde Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Tap - fair size foamy head, light golden color, light sweet malty aroma and flavor, very mild hops - pretty basic but still refreshing. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Padre Island South Padre Island Blonde Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Decent at best. It seems as if this is a tough beer to screw up and make unique. Aroma was grainy with a small malt presence. Clear golden color with small fizzy head. Light palate with carbonation; nothing exciting here. The taste was like a pilsner. Malty presence with little to no hops presence. Good with a pizza.

column1: Padre Island South Padre Island Blonde Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Clear golden with a fizzy white head. Nice malty bready aroma and taste with a doughy finish. Not bad.

column1: Padre Island South Padre Island Blonde Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Not a whole lot of flavor here but the mouthful feels nice. Velvety and smooth

column1: Padre Island South Padre Island Blonde Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: (Draught) Pours a clear yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of biscuit, minerals, and hay. Flavor of grass, dough, and minerals.

column1: Padre Island South Padre Island Blonde Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Looks like your typical Macro brew. Slight hops aroma, nothing else to it really. Sweet malt flavor profile, other than that no real flavor going on here. Overall, there’s not much to it. I’ll probably not drink again... at least its not offensive.

column1: Padre Island South Padre Island Blonde Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Poured a very pale clear gold with a small white head. Aroma was a bit weak but notes of hay and grass. Flavor has a nice balance of sweet hay and grassy notes.

column1: Padre Island South Padre Island Blonde Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: I haven’t been much of a fan of lighter beers like this, but I was surprised by this beer. Light and crisp, but with a nice mix of hoppy finish that actually stays with you. Good if this is your style.

column1: Padre Island South Padre Island Blonde Ale
column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Very good for the style, but it is still girlie. Crisp and refreshing, sweet, fruity finish.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Piney hops. Clear dark Amber. Light bodied. Pine. Earth. Bitter finish. Not bad. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Draft at brewpub. Amber color with no head. Resiny, pineapple and pine tree hop aromas with a light caramel note. Mild sweetness with a strong resiny bitter aftertaste. Lighter body with a foamy feel.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Draft at the restaurant on SPI. Copper-Amber color with an off-white head. Not a strong aroma, mostly malty, with some light hops. Taste is malty and even a little wheaty. Hop character in the finish, a little citrusy. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: growler from charles .. . pours out copper .. . mild foam and mouth feel .. . pine and pinesol .. . decent pale but it’s a little too island, for me .. . . please don’t embarrass me at the butt plug shop!

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Drinkable Pale Ale but not unique and very safe. I found it nearly odorless with a faint malt sense. Golden amber color with medium head in a 10 oz pilsner. Flavor was watery with some grassy malts and a mild hops presence that was a bit overbitter. Didn’t completely balance. Easy to drink with a light palate and average carbonation. Good with the food they serve.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Clear golden orange with a fizzy white head. Citrus and lemon grass aroma and taste with some lime notes and a moderate bitterness.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Coppery brown color. Perfumey aroma. Sweet floral flavor notes followed by some spicy hops bitterness. Overall, it’s rather good. Easy drinking with some complexity. I would drink again...

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: growler thanks to swalden28. poured gold with a white head. aroma was caramel and butterscotch. flavor was pine, floral, and grassy??? body was light with low carbonation.

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: Growler, thanks to swalden28, a good orange pour with a dry hoppy pine aroma and a pale metallic flavor, short to finish

column2: South Padre Island, Texas, United States
column5: (Draught and Growler samples) Pours a clear copper body with a medium white head. Aroma of earth, caramel, grain,orange, and grass. Flavor of soap, grass, some pine,minerals, and earthiness with a dry, bitter finish.

Thankfully someone found who made this beer! On tap at Blackwoods in Duluth with RobertsReality. Dark brown color with a thin head. Pretty medium aroma and flavor with notes of malt and hops in each. Average, but not plain. Don’t look for anything special.

Porter Pounder I love you!! I’ve been looking for this brew on the site for a bit... Had at Blackwoods in Duluth With a Bloody Buddy.. As Memory Serves..Brown Coloring with Good White Head. Medium Body..Malt Foundation with Hoppy Notes Keeping This Crisp and Dry. Not too Bad, Definitly an Average Brew.
Good, full bodied ale. Quite hoppy with subtle fruity undertones. .........

Dark Brown Coloring with White Head. Sweet Malt, Coffee Roast Aroma. Initial Hit of Carbonation, Almost a Stale Sweet Malt Note , Followed by Semi-Sweet Coffee Roasts. Possibly Too Sweet to Savor the Coffee Notes. More Coffee Yet On the Aftertaste. Smooth, Drinkable..Thin Mouthfeel..Simplistic Porter.
Good solid porter - no gritty aftertaste. Detect a hint of chocolate and coffee. Good thick, creamy head. Great restaurant as well.
Gold Coloring with White Ring. Wheaty Aroma. Sweet, Honey and Wheat Notes. Very Sweet Overall. Wheat Flavored Pretty Subdued.
Not bad for a local wheat - appearance not very cloudy though - tto clear for a true wheat. Good compliment to the walleye at the restaurant.

column1: Sports City Cafe American Barley Wine
column5: aroma was malty enough to still be able to withstand the hop bombardment..the color gleamed a dark golden with a thin layer of froth.. No fruit..No cream..No carbination..Yet still sticky, hoppy, and alcoholic..but how hard is that to do..
Amber coloured. Very flat beer. Weak bitters and touches of caramel. Found it moe like a alcohol lemonade.

Keg at Seaforth, Ullapool. Whaele slayin fo sho. It pours clear deep amber with a thick, creamy head. The nose is toasted grain, brown bread, cereal and stewed apple. The taste is bitter-sweet, brown bread, caramel, grainy, cereal, light toasty, nut and mild astringency with a dry finish. Medium body, moderate carbonation and creamy mouth-feel. Good mouth-feel. Not much to say. Nothing wrong with it, just fairly uneventful.
Keg in Station Hotel, Thurso. Pours clear dark amber with a tiny creamy head. Aroma is weak malty. Creamy mouthfeel. Taste is moderate sweet, light roasted caramel, nice company to a light meal.

Draft, Hilton Strathclyde, Scotland. Medium reddish amber. Very faint aroma, some caramel sweetness. Very light flavour, again some caramel, slight hint of hops but very light. Poor man Boddingtons. Which is not saying much.
Pours cloudy light brown, minimal head, Tastes like Tennents with a splash of brown added to it. Like drinking smooth brown water.
Can, in Scotland 2011. Poured a darkish amber with a whitish head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, earth/herbs? Flavor was ok for the style and overall. Touch of sweetness and caramel/toffee.

Draught at McCaig’s Return, Oban, Scotland. Clear amber colour with small creamy off-white head. Weak aroma with oxygen notes. Caramel sweetness, mild malt and mild hoppy bitterness in flavour. Very smooth. Nicely balanced. Not totally hopeless.
A - honey and a touch of a caramel A - mid amber with dense head T - sweet P - mid and creamy O - alright
On tap. Well balanced ale. Aromas of caramel and cola. Taste is sweet with a mild background, and average length. Palate is oily, with a thin-to-medium body. Amber, with a frothy head.

AROMA: caramel, toffy APPEARANCE: brown, clear, minimal head TASTE: very bitter, heavy cloying sweetness aftertaste BODY: light body, thin feel, soft carbonation, long OVERALL: not for me, sickly sweetness and intense bitternes are not balanced. Not one to repeat.

Cask at Moulin Inn. It pours clear rich golden with a medium white head. The aroma is malt driven, cereal, toasty grain, rivita and spice. The taste is dry, bitter, bready malts, biscuit, cereal and some toasty grass. Light body and soft carbonation. Easy going light ale. Sessionable.
Cask @The Moulin Inn. Pours golden, hazy, white head. Nose is toffee, biscuit, slight hop. Taste is more of the same, with some slight lemon on the aftertaste. Thin.
Cask at the Moulin inn. Pours clear pale amber, nose is sweet toffee, cereal, taste is similar, dry, floral.

[6461-20140706] Cask. Strange mushy pea yeast aroma. Clear, orange body with a quick foamy white head. Grainy yeast flavour has a long soft peat aftertaste. Medium body. Good. (6/3/7/3/13) 3.2+ (@ Moulin Inn, Moulin, Scotland)

2014-07-06. Dark yellow body with a small off white head and nice lace. 3+ Aroma is mild, light malt, muted floral grassy hops. Flavour is mild, lightly bitter and fairly floral hop character. Average bodied palate, low carbonation. Okay. On cask at Moulin Hotel, Moulin

Had a taste from fresh produced badge at the brewery during our holidays. Cloudy yellow collor with no head. Smell of fruits like oranges. Refreshing taste of flowers/spring forrest. Bitter after-taste.
Amber colour witch almost no head. Light fruity hop notes. Taste is light with hops dominating. I think it has just the right name.
Cask by handpump at Troon Beer Festival - clear deep golden, lively off-white head, sweet malty aroma, no lacing, fruity, malty, cereal, refreshing, easy to drink

Cask @ Moulin Inn, Pitlochry [280213] Golden amber, clear, thin white head, good lacing Aroma of light fruits, light pale malt Taste of light pale malts, dab of wet hay, soft bitter citrus hop, light soft fruits, light flavour Palate - light body, bit oily texture. Finish a bit dry, slight zesty but a tad of an astringent linger Overall - Fairly ordinary, quite watery, it’s drinkable but spoiled by the finish
Cask @ Moulin. Golden orange colour, reasonable head. Dry grassy malt aroma. Cereal resin malt flavour. Smooth but insipid. Dry aftertaste.
Moulin Brewery Ale of Atholl 4.5%. Cloudy red, rye malt aroma, medium bodied, wheat and barley malt, rye, red berries, biscuit in the finish. Pleasant Scottish Ale from Pitlochry 🏴󠁧󠁢󠁳󠁣󠁴󠁿
Tried at the moulin hotel. Deep ruby colour with a tan head. Light malty and toffee aroma bitter taste thin body.
Cask @The Moulin Inn. Pours dark brown, beige head. Nose is chocolate, toffee, slight smoke. Taste is more of the same, big toffee also quite fruity.

Bottled 500ml. -3pack from the brewery (Braveheart, Atholl and Old Remedial). Amber/brown coloured, medium sized off-white head, whiff of caramel in the nose. Toasted malt, caramel, dried fruits and hint of chocolate with again not so pleasant acidity in the finish. Unfortunately all three beers were infected more or less.

Bottle picked up in Pitlochry. It pours deep red - brown with a decent beige head. The aroma is toasted brown bread, wood, leather, dried fruits, malt loaf and earth. The taste is dry, pretty fruity, dried berry, juniper, jam, fruit compote, toasted brown bread, Dandelion & Burdock and malt loaf with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. A rather decent fruity ale.

On Cask on the Battle of Killiecrankie battle field at the annual reenactment, from the Moulin beer tent. Pours a lovely deep dark brown. Aromas of chocolate and dark fruits. Taste is more of the same. This is a quite delicious, balanced and very fresh tasting dark ale.

Deep copper-red/brown colour with a light beige head and good lacings. Aromas of grassy, light nutty and floral notes develop. Bit lively, watery texture and a light-medium body. Light sweetness with grassy bitterness and a short finish.
Cask at Congress, Longton. Pours dark ruby with an off white head. Quite a nutty beer, felt more like a mild to me. Good stuff.

[6463-20140706] Cask. Mild grainy yeast aroma. Clear, dark amber body with a medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Bitter grainy toast flavour. Medium-full body. Good. (7/3/7/3/14) 3.4 (@ Moulin Inn, Moulin, Scotland) Overheard: "The fundamental difference between our politicians... Our politicians all own semi-automatic weapons -- yours don’t."

2014-07-06. Brown body nice tan head and great lace. Aroma is mild, malty. Whisper of fruit. Flavour is mild, lightly bitter throughout, slightly nutty, muted toasty touches. 6++ Average bodied palate, low carbonation. On cask at Moulin Hotel, Moulin Overheard: "You’re a dick. Nobody feckin liked you anyway." (Which just sounds better with a Scottish brogue :).
al probar esta cerveza me pareció algo interesante, con un buen cuerpo y una leve espuma, aroma y mucho sabor a caramelo lo que me gusto bastante, algo distinto, recomendable
At the beach straight from a cold can. Sweet malts, stale bitter budget lager. Moderate sweet and bitter. Thin body and soft carbonation. For ticks and fatherland!
Prakticky tady přidávám tento komentář, jen aby tady něco bylo, protože zpětně dopisuji 900 piv z mého seznamu a asi bych se musel u toho zbláznit.

From old tasting notes. Deep gold color with a creamy white head. Good malt aroma with a floral hop nose. Crisp malt flavor with plenty of hops. Good balance and a pleasant dry finish make this a tasty lager. Long bitter aftertaste.
33cl can in Nicaragua wow this is not very good. Tickers gonna tick. I’d buy a 30 pack for camping in no time.
500ml can BB 25/10/16 Aroma is fruity, grainy. Poured golden straw with OK head. The (very mild) bitterness gave way to a thin slightly grainy finish and a solid dose of wet cardboard. Meh.
Can shared. Pale golden. Light sweet grains and some chemical bitterness with soft grass and rotten leaves. Light bodied. As expected.
Nice artwork, yeah! Bright yellow color. Anything else? Seems to be Lager, if I’m right....
Sugary water with a hint of hops thrown in, otherwise tasteless sweet water that was cold. A disaster of a beer.

250ml bottle. Tiny bottle contains a golden color with high carbonation lager. Sweet smell. Very flat cheap supermarket taste. The other comments that say that this is such a very bad beer, haven’t buy some beer in the supermarket lately, because this is definitely not that bad.

8/18/2007 2:59:41 AM On tap at Beer Palace, Oslo. This was quite a boring beer I thought. Not much taste too it. It has an amber body and was quite smooth. Some sweet taste, of caramel. Slight bitter finish. Didn’t finish.

On tap @ Patricks, Kristiansand. Well now, a Norwegian previously retired bayer? This is a clear copper beer with a small thin just off-white head. The aroma has tones of both caramel, ripe fruits and candy. Not to horrible actually. The flavor on this one is not extreme in any way. Hints of thin butter, caramel and again some fruity-ripe candy-thingy. It’s actually a bit tasty. It has a average+ carbonation level with a somewhat thin and watery mouthfeel. Easy to drink and it actually has some flavor. A bit sweet and quite low on the bitterness if anything. 30.03.2012
Bottle. Reddishbrown colour with a tan head. Moderate roasted malt nose. Weak sweetness with notes of roasted malt

Draught at Haandverkeren, Kristiansand. Pours clear reddish brown with small offwhite diminishing head. Aroma is caramel, hay, bread. Taste is light to medium sweet, light bitter. Light to medium body, thin to oily, soft to average carbonation. Not bad for a Norwegian macro brew. 20110311
Light brown with tan head. Caramel and malt in the aroma. Malty taste and lightly sour, it gets a bit watery and flat after. Average carbonation, short finish.
On tap @ Patricks, Kristiansand. Taps clear brown with a small off-white head. Roasted sweet caramel aroma dominates. Flavour is the same, but weaker

On tap @ Christiania Pub, Oslo. Clear, light brown body. Thin, mostely lasting off-white head. Mild and moderately sweet aroma of caramel. Taste is well rounded with quite dry toasted malt, a slight acidulous fruitness and hints of yeast. Light to medium body. Gentle hopbitterness in the aftertaste, Dry and slight hopbitter finish.
500ml draught at Beer Palace in Oslo-Norway. Amber colour with a flat borring foam. Aroma of caramel, grain. Sweet maltynes and a anonymius bitter finsih.Light body.

500 ml draught. Copper coloured with a reddish hue. Small white head. Roasted caramel aromas with a slight sweetness in the nose. Flavour is gentle with sweet roasted malt flavours throughout. Medium-bodied. Slightly drying in the mouth even though there clearly is a sweetness to this beer. Finish is lightly hoppy.
On tap at the beer palace , Oslo. Red brown beer with an off-white head.Light roasted caramel aroma. The flavour is the same.
Bright, clear golden color. Lots of slowly rising bubbles. Smells like corn. Tastes like all kinds of cereal mash. There’s no need to macro the micro.

12 ounce bottle. Served in a pint glass, the beer pours a clear dark gold color with a small off-white head. The head didn’t stick around for long, and there isn’t much lacing. It smells mostly like grainy/bready malt, along with a bit of a vegetal aroma. The taste is pretty much the same as the aroma, it’s mostly grainy/sweet malt and not much else. Not bad, but not really good either. Mouthfeel/body is light, it’s thin and watery but is also easy to drink. I’ve had worse, I really wasn’t expecting much when I bought a single of this for 99 cents. Nice to try, but I wouldn’t buy it again.

1988 Bengals Collectors Can. Given to me by 1_2many after finding a few that had been sitting in his family’s fridge for 20 years. My can had survived a bit more successfully than the one he first drank. Actually had some decent carbonation and with a thin white head that tried it’s best to stick around. Has absolutely no aroma, or taste for that matter. I can’t even say it had much in the way as negative flavors, because it really had none at all. It only scores a "2" for aroma and flavor due to it’s actual lack thereof. It was fun to at least try it....I think.

1988 collectors can just opened twenty years later to celebrate my 100th rating! My dad has had three of these tucked back in his refrigerator for twenty years! I can’t believe I’m about to drink this it looks aweful. Clear golden yellow. This has a ridiculous amount of carbonation and the head disappeared in literally two seconds leaving nothing at all except for a few lonely bubbles around the edge. Pouring this is like pouring a Pepsi or Coke. The aroma is surprising however in that it doesn’t smell entirely of rotten corn or rice. It actually has some toffee malt aroma. The hops are gone... completely...I stopped trying to smell the hops ten minutes ago. The flavor is sweet with almost zero bitterness. This beer is very light with a thin oily texture to it and a lot of carbonation. I will not finish this just because it kind of scares me. The beer didn’t go bad really but it probably wasn’t good in the first place and definitely wasn’t made to age for twenty years. Twenty year old Hudepohl 14-K Premium special collector’s edition. This can has the 1988 Cincinnati Bengals schedule on the back. I can’t believe I just tried this. Oh man...I just poured out the remaining contents of the can and the sediment ring on the bottom just broke up and came out...oh that’s horrible. I think I’ll go throw up those few sips now. Well I went back and opened another can with Bigmmartin and this one was a lot better but not by much. Carbonation was better and the head actually stayed around for a little bit. Same aroma and bland flavor but the appearance improved quite a bit. That’s about all I can say about it. Still don’t know what possessed me to drink this.

It’s so sad to see this one retired. This was my high school beer. $1.10 for a gallon jug at the brickyard lake tavern (in the ’ 60’s). One of the several Cincinnati local beers that have been bought out and closed by the Macros. Crisp, clean and light on the palate. A nice session lager.
very smooth, ballpark beer. not sweet but not bitter. classical beer taste. Looks healthy and full from what i can remember.
hudepohl has to be one of the worst tasting beers, and i’ve drank plenty of beers.
This is just one notch below Hudy Delight. I had this once after a softball game. It was on tap, and I was surprised. It was a very smooth, crisp beer. No bad aftertaste, just a very good beer.
Its not as good as its Hudepohl counterpart, Hudy Delight, but it is still very drinkable.

Not my typical style, but looking for something different to introduce to my macro-consuming friends. Had some on draft at the brew tour in Frederick. Quite refreshing, which would be good if it weren't 20 degrees outside with more snow on the way. A good quality lager, not too dry, not too bitter, just a solid mouthfeel and no watered-down taste. I bet it's great with hotdogs and burgers in the stadium parking lot.
The best thing about this pale bock to me, is that unlike so many other strong pale bocks, the alcohol is never overwhelming, in the aroma or flavor. One of the better of this style to me.

On tap @ Tenaya Creek poured a clear gold with a small diminishing off white head. Aromas of sweet malt, and light fruit. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of cereal and light fruits with a mildly bitter finish.
Superior beer. Solid color. Excellent smooth caramel malt taste. Strong beer (don’t know the ABV) but without the alcohol sting, just a hint in the sweet flavor. Recommended!

Pours a cloudy copper color with a very little head. Scent is that of strong grassy wheat. Very awkward taste here. It starts off rather bold, but quickly diminishes on the pallet. Overall it’s very grassy and grainy with slight hints of citrus and maybe some caramel? Could be a little more bold and a better 2nd half of the taste. Taste is very similar to that of Organic wheat beers. Nothing too special here, but better than the cheap beers!
Fairly subdued nose of bubble gum, bananas and bread. Lightly sweet with a light bitterness for refreshment and balance. Lively. A nice drinking beer with some estery personality.
From old notes. pleasant fruit notes and a crisp, clean taste. Nice wheat and refreshing.
bottle. pours hazy amber with a sudsy white head. aroma of creamy wheat, mild fruit notes and malt. tastes of wheat, banana and cloves. definitely enjoyable!

Pours hazy amber with a small white head. The aroma has big smooth sweet creamy wheat, some banana notes and light tobacco. Medium / full body with gentle, yet sharp, carbonation. The flavor starts sharper than the aroma with a toasted wheat flavor and some spice. The finish is clean and snappy. Nice hefe.

pours light amber/dark gold with a medium white head aroma is banana and clove wheat. some lemon as well. flavour is bready wheat, banana and light spice as well.Not as much lemon as in the aroma. Slightly grassy hop finish. Body is a little thin.
Tap. Hazy orange pour with a white head. Mild nose and taste - mostly earthy and grassy. Not spectacular.
Bottle bought at rileys in madison pours golden and clear with hefty white head aromas of wheat and floral hops same in taste with a slighty floral finish that is sweet and smooth
Bottle. Pours a hazy dark orange with a white head. Kind of odd earth, bread, grass, clove, spice, banana notes. Some off flavors. Not my favorite but could have been worse.

Poured from bottle to pint glass. 2 finger head at best, whichi quickly dissolved. Watery, but malty with no hint of banana or bubble gum as prior reviews have stated. Just watery inside-of-a-can taste. No spice as promoted in the description either. Take a pass on this middling brew.
Can. In airplane. So metallic aroma and metallic taste also. I didnt feel malts or hops. Watery.

Bottled. This is one of the worst beers in Serbia, if not the worst.It’s quite hazy, looks almost like a lighter Weizen. There are some nice malty and yeasty tones but the overall taste is simply horrible- sour and acidic. Used to be better, but now this is the worst Serbia has to offer when it comes to beer.
Bottle from Boris, just back from Zagreb. The best beer we tasted tonight. Creamy yellow colour. Malty and sweet. Nuanced. Slight bitter finish to it. Refreshing and would drink again.

1.5l bottle found at a Žabac store in Zagreb Whoa. This is bottle conditioned. A bottle conditioned pale lager in a 1.5l plastic bottle. Never thought I’d see the day. There was a big yeasty stain on the bottom of the bottle. Was it a mistake, or was it intentional? Who knows. Anyway, poured a hazy yellow colour with a medium sized firm white head that went away at a medium pace. The nose is weak, but still quite nice... agrumes, malt and a touch of honey. The taste is quite... empty. Bit yeasty, malty notes, the hops are missing in general but emerge from time to time to give some weak lemony and/or metallic flavours. Completely lacks bitterness. Easy drinking, but...
Canned(500ml). -Awful beer, when you drink it from can it tastes like a metal, when you put it in a glass, it still tastes like a can
Bottled. Pale amber. Spicy, yeasty nose. Malty, fruity and gently rounded with mild, lightly bitter finish.

Poured a clear pale golden colour with a thick, six-finger (half the height of the 500ml glass) white foamy head that partially collapsed then quickly dissipated. Poor lacing. Moderate to high carbonation as evidenced by lots of trails formed by large bubbles. Aroma sweet, sour and metallic. Taste of sweet grain and malt – bland. Very light body (bordering on watery). Short sort of "sweet and sour" finish. Not for me.
Not the worst drain pourer, but not fantastic. Sweet corn aroma with a coarse palate and slightly sweet finish.

Medium coarse offwhite head shrinks quickly. Yellow body with carbonation. Unbalanced alcohol and corn aroma with chemical notes. Dry lightly chalky apple taste with chemical aftertaste. Nice grassy hop background. Not bad for a happoshu. (0.35l can.)

Heavy, soda-like carbonation. Large foamy head. Yellow color. Funky, sour, sweet, and mildly offensive aroma. Thin flavors of corn, malt, water, and nothingness. Watery, and indeed dry. Pretty horrendous stuff, but very cheap.
Can. Yellow colour. Short lasting white head. Aaroma of sweet malt and hops. The flavour is quite hoppy and dry. Thin aftertaste.

This beer is absolutely disgusting! I usually have no problem downing a beer because I dont believe in wasting beer, but this stuff was insulting. I drank it in Shibuya, on the Subway, then somewhere near Tokyo tower......same can.....it took me that long to choke it down.
Can bought in Kyoto, Japan. Clear yellow with a white head. Slight beer aroma, weak, watery taste with medium carbonation.

8/13/02-2.5 This is in my opinion, the best Japanese Macro. It has a mildly sweet malt nose & taste and a nice crisp finish. *Re-rate*- Yikes, not in any way, shape or form the best Macro in Japan. My tastes sure have changed in the past few years. This is adjunct charged macro swill, not a decent beer.
On tap. Offwhite-yellow/gold. A-Slight sour fruit. T-pine hop with some bite, lt/med malt-maybe some caramel.

"i just wasn’t getting the same thing as the previous three...light bodied AND a tad watery. no hop balance at all, just some nutty toasted malt. perfect example of what i’s expect of a decent macro attempt at an amber, but not good from a micro. passable."

Thanks to Haley for this one. Can was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a nice semi-dark red color with a one finger white foamy that dissipated within about a minute. Light messy lacing falls all over the glass. The smell was a deep roasty caramel to nutty aroma. The taste was sweet and roasty through the previously noted aromas. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the palate. It’s got a fairly decent sessionability about it. Carbonation was appropriate. Overall, I’d have it again.
This one poured a medium orange color with an off white head. Aroa was of caramel malt and grassy hops. Flavor was similar, moderate bitterness to keep it balanced but nothing stands out.
Thanks Robertdale. Light amber pour with a light tan head. Caramel malt and a little spiciness in the taste. OK beer. OK lacing..
heavier broomastraw malt and used cigar with some scratchy light pine and light citrus hop. light sweetness with a full body. nice real amber color with light beige head. full suds, good beer.

Location: 12 oz can (as pictured) from Buy Rite, 3/7/13 Aroma: The nose is buttery, with some caramel malts, a little wet paper, and some metallic notes Appearance: It pours a hazed reddish color with a small off-white head and medium-plus lace Flavor: The taste is pretty much the same as the nose, which is to say, not very good at all Palate: The body is light-medium, it starts off okay, but the mid and late palates both feel unpleasant Overall Impression: This one is a total stay away for me. It didn’t work at all. Way way too many of the components of it seems like mistakes/flaws. Don’t bother...
Hops & malt nicely balanced. I always start my visit to High Noon with a pint of Annie’s before moving on to another style.

Poured from a 12 ounce can. Aroma: fruity, toasted malts, bready Appearance: this is golden/ down right yellow, not amber Taste: astringent/ husky, fruity, roasted malts Palate: thin a little dry/ astringent Overall: this needs some refinement, watch the astringency and this would be a nice beer.
From a can poured an amber color with a good amount of head. Light malty flavor with an almost tart lingering finish.

Mixed malt is the perfect beverage and should be enjoyed with friends. Perfect body. Perfect Mixture between sour and sweet and perfect color. Rich, almost earthy flavours and a fine mouthfeel. I have stored 2 bottles for the future in my winecellar.
Great refreshing taste of peaches. Felt rich and full on the tongue. Only downside is that i only had one.

Can. Pale pink colour with no head. Aroma of chemical peaches. Flavour is sweet, chemical. With some imagination it could be described as peaches. Not a beer. Not a cider. Something completely different and not worth of brewing and putting into a can for sale.
Chemical as can be, sickenly sweet, smells like a cider and tastes like one as well, Only more artificial.
Orange with a low head. Aroma of peach, additives and soda pop. The flavour is cloying and fruity - BUT in an artificial way.
Can Very light blond color. Sweet aroma of peach syrup. Very sweet (saccharin too), with strong artificial peach character. Soda.
An orange beer with a lazing off-white head. The aroma is artificially peachy - very much like a sodapop. The flavor is sweet malty with strong notes of peaches.
Can. Clear golden coloured with a small head. Aroma of peaches and fruits. Flavour of peaches and fruits.

Very sweet candy-like peach aroma offers no sense that this is actually a malt beverage. Pink tinged transparent liquor is topped by a fizzy white fully diminishing head. Sweet peach candy flavour is wholly unappealing. Watery body with very strong, gassy carbonation. This is not beer. It’s alco-pop. Can (Ireland, May-06).
[Canned] very pale pink, soda-like absence of a head. Artificial aroma of peach. Cloyingly sweet with candyish horribly artificial peach flavour. Dear god. People drink this?

Funny they call this a Bohemian pilsener...I thought it tasted a lot like Gosser, which is Austrian. *shrug* Pretty decent choice for people who weren’t sure about stouts and cream ales at this brewery, which unfortunately went belly-up a couple years ago.
Light color and a good pils. Straw flavors with some mild hops. Perhaps could have been kicked up a bit, but good for a style that I'm not particularly fond of.
Nice! Closest thing I've had to enjoying a fresh tap pils in Eastern Europe since I was there 10 years ago. Grassy and a bit grainy, crisp and refreshing.
Apple juice body with small white head. Aroma is grassy. Taste is medium grassy, mild sweet. Finishes acidic but not dry.
Really more of a German Pils. Blond colored. Nicely hopped................
an acceptable rendition of the style, but nothing to write home about.......
This was a light-bodied and flavorful stout from a brewery I’m sorry to have seen go belly-up. I drank many a pint of these during football season -- Stout Bros. did an AYCD for $10 special.

Near black with a typical nitro light tan head. Light aromas of mocha and cola. Coffee and caramel flavors with a peat and light malt finish. Somewhat thin but enough oats to hold it together. Very dry in the finish.
Light bodied and a little darker than the porter. Vanilla nose. Slightly bitter. Bland, watery, without any variation.
Black, light bodied stout with a superb nose of milk chocolate and sweetened roasted coffee. Thin bodied but still creamy.

Completely opaque. hints of brown at very edges, a tight, tan head. Really Roastey, notes of espresso, cocoa and coffee, lots of coffee. Lacks just a bit in body. Nice chocolate flavor, finishes strongly espresso-like with a bit of milk chocolate as well.
Ruby black with small beige head. Aroma is faintly roasty. Taste is minimal sweet, cola, finishing peaty malty bitterness at finish. Medium/light body.
Very dark. Creamy white head. Coffee and caramel are prevalent............
nice coffee notes, smooth mouth feel........................................

Where are the hops? This is a brewery that I was sad to see close, although this was NOT an IPA and not even a PA; more of something along the lines of a strong ale. Decent taste, but the missing hops kept this from being a favorite.
Tarnished copper color. Good head. Seemed to be more of a strong ale than an IPA -- not many strong hops. Some citrus and floral flavors. Also a tad straw, and grass.

Very hoppy nose with citrus notes and a slight nuttiness. Light bodied with an overall grainy feel in the mouth. Biting hops at the end, very quick, dry finish. A strong IPA that need a bit more malt to balance it better.

Orange/amber body with little carbonation. Nice white frothy head. Sweet fruity, floral: Where's all the hops? Mildly bitter, definitely an english style IPA. Finishes fruity and sweet as well. nice body front to back, mildly acidic, not bad for a midwesterner IPA.

Clear light copper body with medium off-white head. Aroma is pine/grapefruit. Taste is medium pine, light grapefruit, medium sweet. Medium body. Clearly there's a lot of medium in this beer, and my rating reflects the same.
Aroma is very hoppy but the flavor somewhat disappoints. Light brown color, frothy brown head.
hop bitterness, but not flavor or aroma... slightly sweet caramel...........

column1: Stout Bros. The Yank Cream Ale
column5: I miss this brewery, and I miss this beer more. Very smooth and creamy, and a great session ale. They used to have AYCD for $10 during Monday Night Football. This was perfect for that.

column1: Stout Bros. The Yank Cream Ale
column5: Nitro - golden brown/apricot color. Quite nice. Heavy yeast and malt nose. Has the smooth nitro feel, which might be expected for the style. Strong yeast, malt, toffee flavors.

column1: Stout Bros. The Yank Cream Ale
column5: Amber/orange with a thick fluffy head. How does a combination of two lagers make an ale? LOL! Grassy and thin without much taste. Dry finish. Not much going on in this one.

column1: Stout Bros. The Yank Cream Ale
column5: Medium creamy off-white head topping clear amber body. Aroma is light grassy bitter. Taste is mild sweet, with light grassy/herbal bitter that begins a mid-tongue and remains through the swallow. Creamy light/medium body with pleasant accessible beer.

column1: Stout Bros. The Yank Cream Ale
column5: I'm liking the cream ales more and more lately. Creamy head, brownish blond color. Very smooth. Good session brew.

column1: Stout Bros. The Yank Cream Ale
column5: lightly toasted malt flavor... almost no hops, very pleasing though ........
Very sour, like a cup full of sour. Tasted like lemon juice. Couldn't taste the banana, clove, or wheat malts through the artifical sour lemon flavors.
Banana and clove nose is pleasant. Some graininess mixes with some sour notes in the middle, finishes biscuity and dry, leaving clove and wheaty tastes lingering.
