Cloudy light yellow with small white head. Aroma is strong banana and mild clove with tough of wheat, medium sweet. Taste is banana up top, lemon (complete with moderate sourness) brings it home. Light body.
Bubble gum/Banana nose. Not filtered but looks as though it may be. Cloudy blond. Not a bad Weiss, just not a great one.

Light hazy straw with a nice head. Light aroma of banana. Very light flavored, light malt, light banana, light clove. Just very light, not a lot to chew on. A hefe brewed for the masses. Just a quencher.
by far the best beer I had at this pub, very authentic weisse...............

column1: Stout Bros. Taverner Nut Brown Ale
column5: Uh, it's brown. Smells like the water that I pour out of the garbage cans at work. No nuttiness. No flavors.

column1: Stout Bros. Taverner Nut Brown Ale
column5: Reddish brown. Tangy, roasty, caramel nose. Sweet taste just doesn't go anywhere or do anything for me. Some strange nutty aftertaste.

column1: Stout Bros. Taverner Nut Brown Ale
column5: Medium tan head atop a clear copper body. Aroma is nutty/toffee, moderately sweet. Taste is medium sweet, toffee, toasty. Light watery body.

column1: Stout Bros. Taverner Nut Brown Ale
column5: Actually I think this is as good as Newcastle. I really don't like Newcastle all that much, however. Cloudy brown color. Slightly bitter with good balance.

column1: Stout Bros. Taverner Nut Brown Ale
column5: breweries in wisconsin can't seem to make a good british style ale..........

They brew some fine good beer in Colorado. To me, this is better than the average IPA. Not in the top tier by any means, but I would classify as 2nd tier-ish. Mostly about the flavor and smooth mouthfeel here. They do not skimp on the bitterness either, which lives up to it's name. Citrus-grapefruit hops is the theme, but balanced well with the caramel malts, etc. Appearance is semi-cloudy medium orange...not a pale/clear IPA. Only grabbed a single in a mix-and-match to sample, but will look for more so I can taste test with some of my favorites in this style.

From Oct 2006 Poured from 22oz bottle a clear amber gold with a smallish head of foam that pretty much maintains its size for the entire session. Btw, they have a year and month bottled on the label but nothing was notched. The smell is on the subtle side with faint whiffs of grassy and citrusy hops. The taste is really grassy and it has some good citrus flavour as well..mainly lemon, with a really faint malt presence but... I *like* what the hops are doing in this IPA and it's making for some really good drinkability so being weak in the malt isn't going to hurt my review of this American IPA at all. Good stuff! Bottom line: A nice American IPA from a small brewery in Boulder Colorado. Give it a chance if you find some.

12oz bottle. Hazy orange color with an off white head. Grain hops aroma. Strong hops flavor up front with a hops malt finish. Medium heavy body with a bitter finish. Definitely a hops focused beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hazy orange amber with thinck bubbly foamy white head; aroma is sweet woody floral malt hop balance; flava malt roast molasses notes then some hop bitters; feels light to medium and lively fizzy; finishes dry bitter with woody notes

[Bottle (12oz)] Pours a cloudy golden-orange with an average size lasting frothy off-white head. Minimal lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, bread, citrus hops, citrus peel and finally, earthy and herbal notes. Flavour of caramel malt, resiny hops, citrus, light vegetal notes and a long bitter finish -- hops mostly come through in the finish. Medium bodied. Something doesn’t quite gel here, it’s just decent.

Hotel room breakfast tasting with Jack & Leighton, Hilton Tampa, 22/02/15. Golden orange with a moderate off white covering. Nose is caramel malt, light pine, bitter citric peel. Taste is caramel malt forward, orange, light pine, toasted malt. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. So so - generic old skook brew pub malt driven IPA affair.
Pours a light coppery color with off-white head. Caramel malt, light citrus, and funky pine notes on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with more malt than hop.

Bottle at home. Pours a copper color, white head, dissipates into a thin laced film. Aroma is caramel malts, orange and citrusy hops. Taste is slightly earthy, citrusy hops, lots of cracker and caramel malts. Malts overpower the hops, finishes with an underwhelming bitterness. Palate is medium body, high carbonation. Malts wash out some good favors in this one. Below average IPA.

Bottle shared during RBWG 2015. Pours clear orange gold with a frothy white head. Pale bread in the aroma, rindy orange. Medium sweet flavor with crackery pale malts, old pine needles, citrus peel, metal. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Boring finish, perhaps a bit aged, with dusty pine, leaves, dry citrus, more crackers. So so.

Not your prototypical ipa but I kind of enjoyed it. Soft but passable hop aroma w/ a clear golden pour & thin white head. The taste has an underlying bitterness but isn’t dry & is quite drinkable. I understand the low scores for the style but found it to be a decent beer overall!
Pours a clear yellow body with a small white head. Aroma of wheat, florals, some raspberry, and cereal. Flavor of raspberry syrup and wheat with a thin, somewhat fizzy mouthfeel.

Pours hazy orange with a thin white head, low retention. Strong raspberry aroma, maybe additional notes of biscuit, caramel, and grass, but so faint, it’s hard to be sure. Light body, somewhat watery, light carbonation. Medium sweet, lightly tart, light bitter finish. Reminds me of an Izze soda, only a touch more bitter.

Thin golden pour w/ a tiny white head & minimal lacing. The aroma is almost nonexistent for a fruit beer. The taste is fairly heavy in raspberry upfront but finishes kind of dry & uneventful. Nothing to write home about!
"Pretty boring in all regards even for the style. Light raspberry nose with some rather generic sweet malt. Flavor identical. Really really boring. Want more something!"

Bottle. A- Cloying sweetness, artificial raspberry syrup, wheat, berries. A- Golden color, slightly hazy liquid, white head. T- Sweet, raspberry syrup, subtle berries, artificial, slightly tart, sticky. P- Light body, average texture, average carbonation, sweet finish. O- No offense to Twisted Pines but they have some of the worst bottle artwork I have ever seen. So generic and reminds me of a cheap novelty soda. Sadly, the taste isn’t much better. artificial syrupy tasting and overly sweet. Just not very well done.

12 oz bottle from Evergreen Discount. Golden yellow and clear appearance with a small white head. Aroma is mostly raspberry fruitiness with pale malts and light bread. Similar flavor, fruity and mildly sweet. Light body, pretty thin and easy to drink. Simple and refreshing, as described.

Hazy yellow gold pour with a thin, soapy white head. Aroma is raspberry, lemon and a hint of doughy yeast. Flavor is seedy raspberry, floury wheat and old tap water. Light body with a water feel, and light, blanketing and quite sharp carbonation. Nothing too offensive here, but there really just isn’t much here at all.
INteresting. Refreshing and easy to drink. thin but just good enough in all the features was.
On tap at Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours clear blonde with a modest white head and a Raspberry aroma. There is a watery light malt flavor with a bit of raspberry. Not muchthere.
12oz bottle picked up at North Boulder Liquor Cloudy amber with a small white head, light lacing. Aroma of raspberry and wheat. Flavors of raspberry syrup and straw OK
Clear amber color with fine white head. Malty, honey aroma. Flavor has a very sweet sticky honey taste.
Bottle. Pours a brown/amber colour with off-white head. Both aroma and flavor is mostly all about honey. Taste is sweet and also has come grass/citrus notes, but very dominated by honey. Decent.
Bottle at Chris_o birthday bash 08. Amber colour with thin beige head. Honey aroma. Just actually a rather nice beer. Good honey. Like a crunchie with honeycomb. It’s got better as it went on.

Bottle. Pours a clear, golden amber with an off-white head. Small lacing. Sweet honey aroma with malt and wooden notes in the background. Flavour is sweet with honey dominating. Some bitterness. Slight metallic notes and a sharp acidic touch. Dry finish with a lingering honey sweetness. The honey is nice in itself but it produces a strange off-note which is not wholly to my liking. Still, not too bad overall though. 21-06-08.
Bottle 0.66 l. Bought Kvickly Hilleroed. Aroma filled with pure honey. Beautiful red-brown colour - small beige head. Taste quite dominated by the honey. Low carbonation.

A Mes rate: Bottle at the Oi Oi Saveloy tasting at Chris O’s. Amber with a thin off white film. Heavy corn in the aroma. Slight sweetness from the honey and clear malt. Flavour is more of the same but slightly better but there is just too much honey for me.
Nice amber apperance, with a fine white head. Aroma is nothing but honey. Very sweet taste with a lot of honey in it. Ok carbonation, very sweet finish.

Orange-chestnut coloured beer under a cream-coloured, small, but persistent head. Extremely powerful nose of dark liquid honey, to the exclusion of anything else. Leafy flavour, autumn leaves, nuts and honey in the finish only. Not too sweet, in spite of the nose. Hint of alcohol, and herbs. Very slick, pappy MF, impression of alcoholwarming, despite the low ABV, but medium bodied at best. It certainly deserves its name. Many thanks to Dirk and Leen
Bottled. Amber color with small head. Strong sweet flowery honey aroma. Dryer flavor with flowery honey, fruity tartness and hint of nutty maltiness. Mostly honey in the aroma and flavor.

Dark amber colored with little yellow head. Honey dominates this overly sweet aroma, mild grains also here. Medium bodied. Flavor is the same with nothing but sweet honey, aftertaste has mild cardboard. No good.

Hazy yellow-orange. Nearly no head. There’s some weird leaves or blades of grass or something in the bottom of the glass. I’ll assume it’s the bog myrtle or whatever crazy spice they’re using in this stuff. Personally, I’m leaning toward bog myrtle because bog myrtle is super cool and it drives the ladies crazy. Nose is dusty with a hint of floral honey and some sort of herbal oddness that I can’t quite place. Once again, I am forced to assume it’s bog myrtle. Mouthfeel is smooth and a tad undercarbonated. I don’t know what a gooseberry tastes like but I don’t think I taste anything fruity or berry-like here. There is an interesting earthy character that comes across as almost chocolaty, undoubtedly due to the bog myrtle. Like many of this brewers other beers, this Gooseberry Wheat is more interesting than it is good, aside from the bog myrtle which is awesome.

Martin Barry, the Salopian brewer, was a chef before founding his own brewery in Shropshire. Many of his beers experiment interestingly with spices, and this is no exception. The careful mix of three different malts, four different hops, and god knows how many spices, result in a light, modern ale with a rich complexity. Flavours include cabbage, mushrooms, ginger, coriander, oranges, Chinese spice, nettles, and something quite familiar that I couln't quite pin down: gooseberries? Pleasing though all that is, I didn't find it that satisfying or exciting an ale. Barry's intention is to produce a range of ales that can also be used in cooking, and there is a recipe for gooseberry fool included on the bottle. Interesting, but not highly recommended.

Bottled. Doesn`t say on the label that it contains gooseberries but has such an unusual aroma that it must have. Amber gold in colour with a good head and condition. Aroma with the glass at a distance is of peardrops, but close up it is like crushed garden weeds like nettle or dandelion. Body has a sweet maltiness to balance the harsh earthy bitterness and the finish is soft and dry. Weird.
Tasty Scottish Ale. The hops are there from start to finish. Probably be better if not brewed at sea level.

After straightening out the tap situation at Mac & Marti in Guam, I realized this was a pretty good Scottish ale and not a very good Irish Red ale. Poured a cloudy butterscotch color with a medium off white head. Hoppy, somewhat skunky aroma. Earthy hop flavor. The smokiness is light up front but after a few sips, it becomes more pronounced in the finish. Good.

Wonderful hop hop and more hops! A beauty, dark amber with a nice thick head, great flavor from this well balanced brew. Hands down the best offering from this small microbrewery (the only one I know of in Guam!) I've had many a pint of this delicious ale. Great food, nice folks, awesome brew! Stop by if your in the neighborhood!
500ml bottle at RIO, courtesy of Phillip. Aroma is light malt. Appearance is yellow with a small white foam. Taste is light bitter. Watery. Ok.

Unremarkable beer from the design, but certainly a good Export or Dortmunder type beer. This underrated style deserves a renaissance, and Erharting Export is a good example of this moderately drinkable Export type.

(bottle) clear golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of sugar icing and cashew nuts, with a light hint of nettles, some overripe pears and green apple. flavour is mostly metallic hops and starchy pale malts, slightly earthy, with a touch of ethanol, dried apricots and a semi-dry finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Herber, leicht süßer Beginn. Helle Malznoten, moderat bitter, süffig. Trocken, einfach aber fehlerfrei. Spritzig, trock herb, der Hopfen ist nur angedeutet. Nett. 9/8/9/9/7/9
0,5 l bottle BB 26. Aug 14 bread, hay, cereal, grass, citrus, herbs, golden, clear, minimal head, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, oily feel, lively,
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, getreidig, leicht fruchtig. Geschmack malzig würzig, getreidig, leicht fruchtig.
Daft in Munich. Nice crisp helles, more of a pilsener, but don’t tell anyone. Fine bitterness, liquid bread.

It’s golden, ever so slightly hazy, with a creamy and lasting white head. The aroma has notes of malt, dusty grain and straw. The flavor has a light sweetness and a slightly harsh light bitterness with notes of malt, straw and grain, and the finish is dry and slightly bitter.

Bottle at the bar on Heiligenstatt banhof platform - 14/07/12. Clear light golden to yellow with a medium slightly off-white head. Grassy aroma with pale malt background. Grainy taste with pale malts and a little caramel backbone. Fair amount of carbonation - average at best.
Tap at Leiberheim Biergarten, Munchen. Pale golden, big white head. Sweet bready aroma. Sweet flavours initially with good spicy bitterness. Nice.
so good bear, one of the best bears I have ever tried, surprisingly good aroma and also nice dark coulor similary like guinness.What can I say else, except you must try it.
Bottled(500ml). -I was very surprised when I tried this beer... there is great chocolate aroma, nice very dark color, one last thing: EXCELLENT
Mørk, let i farve og konsistens, med groft skum. Duft af jord og cola. Kaffe og chokolade og meget begrænset bitterhed. CO2 gør den lidt let i det. Lidt for let
Tried at the Moulin Hotel. Off black colour with a tan head. Malty and floral honey aroma with treacle hints. Taste light honey sweet. Full smooth body.
Cask @The Moulin Inn. Pours brown/red, off white head. Nose is malty, caramel, chocolate, slight honey. Nose toffee, caramel, biscuits. Sweet.

Bottled 500ml. -3pack from the brewery (Braveheart, Atholl and Old Remedial). Dark brown coloured, medium sized pale beige head, acidity in the nose. Toasted malt, fruits, caramel, and again acidity. Unfortunately all three beers were infected more or less.

Bottle picked up in Pitlochry. It pours darkest red - brown with a medium beige head. The aroma is rich, malt - driven, dried fruits, fruit cake, malt loaf, jammy and earth. The taste is initially dry, very fruity, tangy dark fruits aplenty, plum, fig, jam, raspberry pip, vinous and wood with a dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Old style fruity tang ale. I sort of like it.

Chestnut broan, clear, dark white light beige small head with good lacings. Aromas with notes of nuts, fresh butter, biscuity malts with a subtle chocolate flower-honey note develop. Just enough CO2 to lift the palate, light velvety smooth texture and medium body .Light sweet with a soft lingering bitterness as finish. Well balanced.

[6464-20140706] Cask. Sweet toasted caramel fruit aroma. Clear, dark amber brown body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Caramel toasted grains flavour. Medium body. Good. (7/3/7/3/14) 3.4 (@ Moulin Inn, Moulin, Scotland) Overheard: "That’s Amy’s kind of tennis: full frontal nudity tennis."
Pours a ruby brown, nose is sweet toffee, caramel, chocolate, taste is dry, sticky, caramel, chocolate, a little sour.

2014-07-06. Dark brown body with a nice beige head. 3++ Aroma is malty, sort of fruity and tangy. 6+ Flavour is quite malty, some dark fruit, lightly toasty malt accents. Smooth average bodied palate, soft carbonation. Nice. On cask at Moulin Hotel, Moulin Overheard: "Full frontal nudity tennis?"
Dark brown/color with off-white creamy collar. Smell of fruits in the hay. Refreshing and sweet taste. Bit watery after-taste.
On tap at the moulin hotel. Pale amber colour with an off white head. Aroma and taste fruity and light sweet. Medium body
Cask @The Moulin Inn. Pours orange/amber, white head. Nose is caramel, malty, toffee. Taste is more of the same, quite sweet.

Bottled 500ml. -3pack from the brewery (Braveheart, Atholl and Old Remedial). Darker golden coloured, medium sized off-white head, slightly acidic nose. Sweetish malty, light caramel, touch of apples and sharp acidity in the finish. Unfortunately all three beers were infected more or less.

7th September 2016 Tower 42 bottleshare on me birfday! Thanks to Paul. Light haze on this gold beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is smooth and light, decent carbonation. Sweet malts, mild creamy sweetness. Floral bitterness. Touches of pith and soap. Dry crisp finish. Okay.

September 2016 - Bottle share at Canary Wharf, with thanks to Paul. As ’Moulin Braveheart’, 4.0%, BB Aug 2017. Amber orange, hazy, lightly sparkling, foamy off-white head. Aroma has some soured sweetcorn, salad with balsamic, tangerine. Hmmm. Body is smooth with tingly carbonation. Taste is watery, sweetcorn, thin malt, paper and card. An uninspiring but inoffensive flavour. Alright. (2.8)

Bottle shared at the level 42 tasting 7/9/2016. Many thanks to Paul for this one. A hazed golden amber coloured pour with a lasting thin white head. Aroma is semi sweet nutty malts with a little green apple, slight stale malts. Slightly grassy bramble on the nose. Flavour is composed of light raw grainy, nutty malts, grassy hop, and slightly tangy finish. Palate is airy, semi sweet, grainy. Tangy finish.

Bottle split at Level 42, thanks to Bropey, 07/09/16. Lightly hazed golden orange with a decent off white head. Nose is pale malts, straw, light orange peel, bread. Taste comprises orange, straw, light spice, bread dough, grains, crackers. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, semi drying close with a light bitter rinse. Decent enough bitter.

Bottle shared in London - many thanks to Paul. Pours clear gold with a creamy white topping. The nose holds light citric hops, grainy pale malts, faint leaves. Light sweet flavour with plenty of dry bread, light dough, melon, orange rind. Light bodied with average carbonation. Finishes with light astringency, more grainy malts, leaves, faint cereal. So so.

Bottle shared on Level 42. It pours golden - amber with a medium white head. The aroma is toasted grain, rich tea biscuit, cereal, bread and hay. The taste is crisp, dry, fresh bitterness, lemon peel, grapefruit, biscuit, hay, bread, grass and pepper with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Tastes mighty fresh. Pretty ok for an old school bitter.
Bottle shared with Mr_H Grassy Toffee aroma flavour is grassy hop malty herbal flavour grassy bitter finish fairly bog standard
Weak malty aroma. Small durable head. Clear golden body. Weak watery taste. Not too sweet with some alcohol bitterness.
Wypite przed kilkoma laty, nie jest już produkowane… Ocena przepisana z notatek.
Charackterloser Antrunk mit leicht süßer Getreidigkeit in einem wässrigen Umfeld. Mild herb im Mittelteil mit süßer hell-Malzigkeit. Insgesamt weiter wässrig und leicht plörrig wirkend. 8/5/5/4/6/4

No 281 Rated:19.12.2007 Can, 500 ml Appearance: Pours bright and shiny, clear, well filtered golden body, carbonation of body is medium, head is white, foamy, quite quickly disappearing, rather no hints of lacing, what lasts is a small, thin froth on the surface of the body. Aroma: Wet fur, some unfreshness, no distinctive hoppy nose, neither grainy nor hoppy, accidic, some notes of rust, metallic, can, slightly milky, chalk, rather faint aroma,nothing special or worth interest, tap water with a water supply pipe accent, the wormer the beer is the more chalky and unfresh the aroma becomes. Not inviting. Flavour: No sugar, like a poor quality Pilsener, water, accidity, rust, watered grains, a bit crispy, later on barley malts on palate and quite tolerable water quality, but in fact dominating over the flavour. Finish duration is short. Palate: Body is light, texture is wattery, carbonation is soft to medium on palate. Finish feel is wattery, accidic, grainy and crispy but dominated by water.
Can. Clear golden colour with a medium mostly diminsihing white head. Malty aroma and taste with only notes of hops.

Can, from High Spirits in Cleethorpes. Gold, thin shortlived white head and low condition. Vague sweet cereal notes in the nose with a little fruitiness, quite smooth and refined in the mouth but quite muted. Some gentle malty sweetness balanced by a modicum of hop bitternesss and a warming background alcoholic note. Warmth extends to the finish but little else can be bothered to make the short trip.

Slightly disappointing lager from Koszalin breweries, whose Brok beers I like. Straw colour, medium bubbly head. No particular aroma; acidic taste with not much hops and bitterness. Refreshing, but a bit too light.

Canned. An orange coloured lager with a big head on pouring, but that disappears in no time. The aroma is grassy hops. The taste is on the sweet and floral side and is like a strong Bohemian pils. Acceptable.
Bottle from my local Indian supermarket. A strong lager with a firm, sweet body and moderate hops and carbonation. Quite drinkable with no off flavours. Some pleasant fruit notes. A nice beer.
Head initially big but vanished quick. Light goldish look. Average polish pilsner with nice refreshing taste.
(cask) Cloudy light orange with a semi-thick head..citrus mango-hops in aroma with grainy but fruit flavors..kinda soapy tasting at times..

I'm thinking this is their warrior pale ale but if it isnt most wont care cuase it sucks anyways. A very strange orange aromoa to it, not normal. Boring, yeasty, with little hops, back to work chicken fuckers.

I was very dissapointed with this beer. Little to no aroma and the flavor was just bland. For a pale ale it was lacking in hops. Seemed more like a cheap golden ale or lager, but the bartender insisted that it was the pale ale.
En meget stærk guldøl. Den har varme og en sødme fra malten, der gør at den ikke er helt udrikkelig, tvært imod.

Can from Systembolaget. Oddly funky smell, like someones old underwear, sweaty and with a slight toilette aroma. Also boozy. The taste is different. Sweet without bitterness and an artificial malty taste. The taste isn’t as boozy. However it isn’t nice to drink.
Can. Pours a pale yellow color with a longlasting white head. Has a fruity grainy aroma. Malty grainy weak bitter flavor. Has a sweetish malty grainy finish with watery hints.

Clear golden color with a thin head that disappear quick. Aroma of sugar and alcohol. Taste even more alcohol, mixed with sweet fruits. Medium + body. Very sweet and a mild bitterness. Average carbonation. Beer for those with a flu, and who want to get drunk fast. [Can from Systembolaget in in Strömstad, Sweden.]

Can shared at The Wellington during the final stop of the RateBeer Black Country Bus Bash. Massive thanks to tommann for hooking this up. The beer pours perfectly clear yellow with a creamy white head. Honestly, you cannot really knock this beer on appearance; it looks better than most of its peers. Smells mostly like cleaning detergent, real industrial grade stuff, enit. There is some dry, lightly bitter lemon in the snout as well, harkening to mind Pine-Sol or something of that ilk. The flavor is massively sweet, terribly astringent, with lots of alcohol heat and tons of simple, sugary cereal grains. I would imagine if you used toilet cleaner on your corn flakes in the morning instead of the usual milk you might arrive at a flavor profile approaching that which I am experiencing right now. This malt liquor is full bodied with medium to high carbonation. The finish contains some odd, unexpected fruit notes but also plenty of expected notes of intense alcohol and grainy cereal. Overall it is a pretty poor beverage. Although, in all fairness, we had this on the last stop of a long day of pub crawling and the beer may not have been served at an optimal temperature. Still, not a great specimen of the tricky-to-make-well style we know as Malt Liquor.

6th July 2013 Black Country Beano. Not sure where this can was split. Light haze on this pale gold beer. Light palate, semi dry. Mild minerals. Light and sweet pale malt. Mild paper. Not much else going on other than a little paint thinner in the dry finish.
7/13/13. Can thanks to blomster, I guess... apples, grape, hay, and fusel and corn. Meh.
String apple and corn aroma and flavor. Sweet all the way thru the finish. Thanks to Dr. Owl at his likka fest ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Courtesy of Blomster Overripe apples/ See through like test cadaver/ Smells the same as well

Can split by Tomman. Cheers for landing this top want. The pour’s light gold with no head. Pretty nasty, cheap looking. The nose is newspaper covered in garbage juice. Frankly, the taste is pretty similar. Nice hot boozy kick on the finish. Rough and ready mouthfeel. Unnecessarily fizzy, full on the palate. Overall, a proper bus station malt liquor. Not completely without merit, but still pretty terrible.

column1: New Amsterdam Light New York Amber Lager
column5: 12oz bottle (Old Notes)-Pours a medium amber with a decent head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Taste of the same. This light bodied brew is not their best but still tasty.

column1: New Amsterdam Light New York Amber Lager
column5: Light amber with some finings. Sticky, compacted white head. Very light carbonation. Healthy toasted caramel aroma, oxidation and soft hops. Decent body with a dose of toasted caramel, wet paper and slightly citric hops. Would never guess this for a light (95 calories, fat free) beer. Although the flavor seems a bit stripped it is still moderately tasty. Medium body. Clean and smooth. Fresh water taste. Hints of minerals. Seems stale at the finish. Why don't these guys use dated packaging? Decent, if fresh.
Dark blond colour with fluffy head. Aroma and flavour are malty and toasty with the toastiness bringing in a hint of coffee beans.
Cask at Northwich Beer Festival 2019. Pours an amber colour. Taste is quite toffee like. Quite a nice beer
0.5 l bottle from K-Citymarket Ruoholahti, Helsinki. A very much bitter-like ale. I expected more malt flavours. Don't get me wrong, though, this is a good one.
500ml bottle in Bier Halle. Copper colour with a good white head. Aroma is caramel and soft fruit, flavour is broadly similar, a little metallic to begin with. Not bad
Pours a golden color with white head. Sweet malty aroma and taste with a toasted earthy character. Notes: on cask at the Oban Inn, Scotland Jun ‘19
In good condition. Some soft toffee fills the palate out; classic ale notes; fruity finish. One of the better cash basics I've had on this trip.
copper with no real head. fruity sweet malt aroma. taste is sweet, caramel and red fruits. easy drinking
Bottle from ocado Chestnut good lasting head taste smooth caramel nutty good esb
Cask at Abbotsford. Clear amber. Nose is red fruits, light caramel. Tastes light bitter, fruits, hint of dried fruits and nuts. Ok.
Cask at the brewery, clear bronze colour, smallish creamy head, aroma of candy and cakey maltiness with a hint of light aromatic coffee, sweetish malty cakey, yeasty flavour, light bitterness. Nice,

Can thanks to Scopey. A clear amber brown coloured pour with a fine off white head. Aroma is simple nutty malts stewed veg, toast, some bread brown. Flavour is composed of simple nutty malts some dried fruits, chalky, baking powder. Palate is semi sweet, dry chalky, highish carbonation. Simple. .

Can from Tesco as Tennents Special. It pours clear brown with a foamy white head. The aroma is sweet, malt - driven, brown bread, malt, loaf, light ginger bread and wet cardboard. The taste is dry, sweet caramel, brown bread mostly, malt loaf, wet cardboard and toasty grain with a drying finish. Light body and average carbonation. Pretty bland stuff, but to be honest there is a lot worse out there. Brown summaries this beer.

Jan 2018 - Keg at the historic Horse Shoe pub, Glasgow. As 'Tennent's Special 70/-'. Pours an orange brown, translucent and still with a creamy white head that leaves thick lacing. Aroma is airy, faintly malty. Body is light and smooth with tingly carbonation. Taste is watery, little character to it - a bit like drinking vaguely malty dish water or the water vegetables have been boiled in. Nothing much to it so it's not offensive. The old boys here are loving it as an accompaniment to chatting up waitresses 40 years younger than them. (4-4-4-3-10=2.5)

Nice copper color with a fine thick white head. God lacing down the glass. Typical malty and toffee dominated British bitter. But quite balanced and ok. Also a decent carbonation that made it quite fresh. Absolutely ok. Decent 3,5% ale. [On tap at Tolbooth Bar in Glasgow, Scotland]
Can from Tesco, Corby. Copper with a red tint, although practically no head. With a low carbonation, this is a sweetened bitter. Passable but unexciting.

Draught at The Griffin, Glasgow 150419. Clear golden brown with firm lacing white head. Malty aroma with hints of liccorhize. Slightly roasted malty taste with a coffee twist. Nice. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Keg in some dive bar in Glasgow. Pours deep amber,nose is dull malty toffee, taste is sweet toffee.
500ml can. Not too bad but not too good either. More enjoyable than boddingtons and the like IMO. Not by much though. Metallic, cereal aroma. Malty flavour.

500ml can from Scotmid. Pours clear copper with a fast-vanishing of-white head. Aromas of dark sugar and butterscotch. Taste is sweet with a light herbal note. Thin body, medium carbonation. Astringent finish. Meh.
Not very tasty. Better than lager, and more drinkable than many other mass produced beers. Quite thin, kinda brown. "Sweet" malts, no sign of a hop for miles.
Cask in the amber rose. Pours pale amber, nose is fruity, toffee, taste is sweet, floral, light toffee.

Tasted this in Gabriels, Paisley in November 2000. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear pale straw in colour with a thin white head. Slight floral note to the short hopped aroma. Thin resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt base gives a digestive biscuit flavour with a hint of golden syrup and grapefruit peel. Dusty hop resins give an astringent dry hoppy aftertaste which builds in intensity. Finish is citrusy and dry with moisture sucking pithy notes, long in intensity. A popular bitter from the extensive portfolio.

From cask at Counting House. Pours clear and golden orange with a small off white head. Aroma is malty and slight breadish. Dark roasted malt, bitter and medium dry breadish roasted. Bitter and mild fruity into a malty finish. Simple and elegant.
Cask @ Bon Accord. Dark golden colour, off-white head. Aroma is malty, hint of vegetables. Flavour is malty, some caramel. Not much to it.
Cask @ Bon Accord. Grassy aroma. Medium dark brown colour. Distinctive lemon and mild coffee flavour. Interesting one.

Cask in Blue Blazer ... light amber with big foam head ... light fruity hop ... basic fruity hop with a light malt base. Ok but soso Earlier Rating: 4/1/2007 Total Score: 2.5 a ruby coloured ale, thats was fruity with a balanced bitter hop fruity finnish. an ok ale.

On gravity at Swindon BF 30/10/08. Deep amber with next to no head. Aroma of red fruit, floral hops and a touch of roastiness. Flavour was sweetish, with more fruit and citrus hops, before a long, dry finish. Good.
Gravity at Swindon Beerex08. A lovely combination of light coffee and floral hops on the nose and palate. great balance and a nice surprise.
Cask @ Castle Tavern, Inverness 1/8/08. Good darkish golden body. Nice lacing. Roasty tasting. Not a bad brew.

A nice dark blonde pint, good bitter flavour and nice hoppy taste. Is this an american brew? If so it’s a good version of an english pint. If it’s a scottish brew then that’s cheating! Either way very drinkable.
*Old rating. Best before 05/2012. Nice round and smooth Bitter. Nuts. Biscuits, malt. Round and fresh. Nice Ale round aftertaste.

500ml bottle poured into an Abbot Ale glass tankard at home on 22nd June 2015. Hazy golden body with a full, deep and lasting off-white foam blanket for a head. The aroma was both fruity and biscuit: anyone like Garibaldi biscuits, but sweeter and not just currents. The taste is also a sweet blend with the malts winning the flavour stakes throughout the brew. Tasty and robust in nature the body feel is just right and suits the alcohol level nicely. A very pleasant early evening pint.
Cask at the standing order. Pours clear golden, nose is floral, toffee, lemon, taste is sweet, fruity, ok.
Cask at The Standing Order. Pours hazy gold, thin to no head. Light aromas of caramel. Little else. Taste is watery. Not great.
Cask at The Crystal Palace (JDW) in Glasgow. Light brown. Not too much head. Medium consistency.

On tap at Berts bar Appearance -amber with a nice haze. No head for some reason. Nose - malt and apples slightly sour grape. Taste - more apples and grapes wirh nslt background. Palate - light to medium bodied with a similar texture. The finish is fairly refreshing. Overall - had a lot better from Houston.

Bottle shared on the train from Inverness to Plockton, from Tomlinsons, 19/10/13. Very lightly hazed golden with a moderate off white covering that retains well. Nose is toasted malts, orange, grass, citric tang. Taste comprises pale malts, cereal, light citrus, summer fruits, orange sherbet. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, dry finish with a little bitterness. A whelming affair, didn’t have this down as a bitter, more Golden Blond for me.
Bottle from Aldi a hazy orange beer sweet pale malts carmel and orange taste light bitterness on the finish but generally very nice
Golden with a medium white head. Aroma of cereals, toffee, malt. Sweet taste. Oily texture, light carbonation. A bit too cornflakey and a bit bland.

Cask @ Standing Order, Edinburgh [070913] Blonde, hazy, thin white head Aroma - almost nothing on the nose Taste - soft fruits, sweet pale malts background, apricot Palate - Medium body, fairly oily, sweet sourish palate, rather dry Overall - Not great...prob needs a re-rate as condition suspect

1. Cask Stillage at the Town Hall, Stockport 31/05/2001 Sweet and pale with a hoppy finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 14/08/2001 Golden coloured sweet and hoppy. Bitter fruity finish.

Sampled cask conditioned at the Stein Inn, Waternish, Isle of Skye. Pale golden. Herbal nose (I think of heather, but that's probably only imagining). Light bodied, soft and dryish. Notes of vanilla. herbal, sweetish, and only lightly bitter finish.

column1: Isle of Skye The Reeling Deck
column5: Sampled cask conditioned at the Stein Inn, Waternish, Isle of Skye. Dark nut brown. Strong roasty coffeea roma. Malty, dryish and peaty. Rock solid. Slightly grassy and salty, but coffe is dominating all the way through to the finish. Medium bitterness.
12oz can (Old Notes)-Pours a light golden with a small white head. Aroma of nothing. Taste of nothing. Another light pale lager.
There is no reason for this beer to exist except to provide a little more variety for your everyday schmo in his list of "light" beers. At least it has a pretty mountain on the can.
Pours a light golden yellow. Aromas of minor hops, corn, grains. Flavor is light, crisp, watery with a little hop and not much else.

Guam SwillFest 2004: Pours a very pale yellow with a quickly dissipating white head. Moderately fruity aroma-grapes with a hint of hops. The flavor is almost nonexistent. Very carbonated and almost tasting like club soda. There just ain’t anything in this one.

Baisically it's like Bud Light et al. It really makes me angry that Rainier sold out to Miller and closed the brewery in south Seattle. I used to enjoy the aroma of the brewery, it was the highlight of an otherwise awful commute to work. I don’t live in Seattle anymore, but it still bugs me. It used to only be sold in Washington, but I don't think that Miller gives a rat's a$$ about tradition and the beer is making its way across the country now, I suppose.
Rasta Rex brought this with him on his way to Moab. Although it was a Rainier Light its always good to drink a beer with an old friend in your driveway.
Certainly looks like a light. Yea, tastes very light too. Nothing impressive but what would you expect for a generic light beer?

Ale fajniutkie piwo. Piana biala jak balwan na sniegu i tak dlugo stoji jak on prze 40 stopniowym mrozie. Metniste w odcieniu moreli piwo. Pachnie superowo morelami suszonymi i swiezymi, gruszkami i mirabelkami. W smaku nie czuc alkoholu bardzo owocowe morele i brzoskwinie a na wykonczeniu wyglodzony smak przecieru z mango i jablek. Chmielnosc niewielka ale ta owocowosc przypadla mi do gustu, Jest super dziwia az tak niskie oceny.
Medium white sticky head, clear golden colour, sweet citrus fruity apple like and malty smell, medium carbonation and bitter, apple like and spicy taste

750ml bottle (One Pint Pub, Helsinki) Messy petfood aroma, bran, some tinned tomato. Clear orange, ephemeral head. Messy grains in taste. Some wheatiness, again the tinned tomatoes. watery and a bit fizzy. Not good. Does at lest have some real full hops in it. But that can’t save a watery incipid ale.
Bottle 0.75l at One Pint Pub, Helsinki. Colour is clear orange with very small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, spices, ginger and biscuits, sweetness and malts.

(Bottle, 0.75 l - BBE 21.09.13 (the year was more or less unreadable), at One Pint Pub, 20130913) The beer poured golden and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had fruitiness, caramell and molasses. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, molasses, mildly Belgian style yeast, fruitiness, hops and bitterness. Aftertaste was fruity, malty and bitter. A decent malty bière de garde.

Fast gone head over pale clear-golden beer, very fine pearling. Vanilla extract and caramel, liqueur, as something to add to dessert dough, suggesting excessive sweetness. Sweet-nutty beer, some raw grains; much less sweet as suggested by the nose, and much less alcoholic as well. Feels more spritzy than the visual; slick, medium bodied, and a certain fery, burning feel backthroat. Not very distinctive taste, unsettling nose; clashing instead of balance.
Light hazy amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity and yeasty. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish. 160512

Bottle @ DØE meeting. Pours hazy pale golden with a small white head. Aroma of bready malt, yeast, grass, hints of chocolate. Taste is malt, yeast, chocolate, light fruity, grass. Medium body, soft carbonation. Think this bottle is abit old. 160512
Bottle @ DØE Syd. Unclear amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, yeast, fruit, phenols and oxidized. Flavour is malt, yeast, hops, phenols, medium sweet, caramel, little toffee and bread.
Clear golden color with fine head. poor and alcohol strong beer which tastes like old beer and smells like bread.
Surprisingly tasty, bad aftertaste. Objective- keep drinking. VERY filling. Overall- worth a look.
Stale hoppy aroma, pours without much of a head, slightly bitter. Perhaps this was an old bottle?
Deep amber colour, with a buckwheat nose and a slightly whiskeyish malt notes, and caramelized pears.
Light golden color. Sugary, faint sweet malty presence, smooth, slightly bitter hop finish. Not much going on, and I don't taste any hemp, but maybe I'm looking for something different.
Doesn't have any cherry to it. The body is thin, with light, beany coffee notes and a remarkably quick finish.

Suffers from being based on a rather lousy, grainy lager. The flavours do not come together especially well, and the balance is a little off as a result. Will work as a patio refresher, though, and is better than the cavity-inducing 'hard lemonades' out there.
Draught: This is a really lovely bitter with lots of malt and biscuit flavors. Worth a trip to Skye and McNabbs for a pint.

Bottle at some hotel- pours cola-esque dark brown, hazy, dark orange, grayish head. nose is cola cubes. sea air like uig, seaweed, roasted malt, taste is light, strong saltyness light roast flavour. Like a lighter version of the oyster stout.

Any first impressions? -Great foam lingers atop the reddish brown. -Fruit jam and caramel are invitingly spread on toast. -The aroma had said it all apparently, as the flavor profile repeats everything announced. -Quite full-bodied due to rich maltiness and comfy carbonation. What if you dig deeper? -Subtle supporting hoppiness almost balances the flavor profile. -Strawberries and cherries make up fun fruit flavors. -The bready character is sustaining. -This is purportedly a blend of Red Cuillin and Black Cuillin, and I wouldn’t be surprised this were true after having a pint of each over a few days in Portree. Whatever it is, it remains a complex and flavorful pint of scottish ale. On cask at MacNab’s Inn, part of the Royal Hotel, in Portree.
Sampled cask conditioned at The Royal Hotel, Portree, Isle of Skye. Dark ruby/mahogany. Creamy and lightly roasty. Medium bodied, fruity and softly malty. Salty finish. Solid, but unexceptional.

Sample at the brewpub: Clear dark gold color with a minimal white head and sparse lacing. Wheat aroma is difficult to detect but it is there, along with a bit of bubblegum. Light and clean mouthfeel with wheat and hops flavors, along with a fair amount of malt backbone. The finish is wheaty and lingering. Actually pretty good.

draft - The aroma is virtually nonexistent. I think I smelled a trace of malt. The flavor is malty and very light. The mouthfeel is thin and the finish is clean. That’s about all I can say for it. This is not an impressive American Wheat.
Editorial, Ok I just don't get this style. Light straw color with a wispy, foamy white head. Mild malt and wheat sweetness. Light dry, honeylike, finish. Seems like a waste of yeast to me.

Dark amber colour, hazy, big head, fine perlage. Characteristic aroma of oak cask, tart, black fruits, old hop. Pretty malty, some sweetness, not enough sour; good body, smooth, a hint of liquorice; halfway between a Dubbel and a Oud Bruin. Ordinary palate. A hidden complexity, a great potential, but definitely not ready; must try after a few years of cellar.

Can from the brewpub. Straw orange, bit dirty and some foam on top. Quite malty nose, bready biscuits, quite clear. Taste malty, crisp and biscuity. Quite clean and with some modest bitterness underneath. Finish is relatively short but pleasant. Drinks well, clean crisp taste.
Can from Le Petit in Shimokita. Light fruit aromas with some lemon. Easy drinking with a soft, slightly minerally mouthfeel. Refreshing on a hot day and pretty good in the can.

Can from souvenir shop in Nagano Station. Gentle fruit nose: peach, apricot, also some powdered extract. Cloudy, thick honey color, little head. Bread, baby cookies, light grass, tiny it of citrus, and light final bitterness. Thin body. Okay. Seems a touch muddled, as a kolsch. But tasty enough.
Can in Matsumoto - shared with Mette. Clear yellow/golden - white head. Breadisd. Hay. Straw. Light bitterness. Dryness. Light hoppy. Ok - light but pleasant and clean.

citrus, floral, golden, hazy, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, lively, astringent. Primarily citrus nose, slight grassy field notes. Golden, hazy and lazy in appearance. Very pleasantly bready with hints of honey. Quick and sharp bitter finish. Refreshing is the key word here.
Mild tropical aroma and flavor, pretty mild overall. Quite a light kolsch attempt, but still quite refreshing and drinkable.

Can from Le Collier. Straight from the can. Lightly creamy, bit of lemon, very kolsch like. Always easy drinking. Bit tea like, earl grey element and decent fruitiness. Quite nice. Very soft in the mouth.

Bottle. Hazy pale golden with a white head. Surprising lemony hop aroma. Grassy and lemony hop flavours in abundance. Almost chewy texture. A very tasty beer that makes most other Kölsch beers pale in comparison.

Can. Fruity, sweet aroma with a bit of cream. Some esters and a touch of citrus (grapefruit and lemon). Nice but not authentic. Light to medium gold color with a medium, frothy head. Rich golden malt flavor, sweet, grainy, creamy. Fruit including a bit of citrus noticeable. Rather typical Japanese Kolsch: too sweet, thick and creamy for the style, but pleasant nonetheless.
0,35 l can. Fruity aroma. Taste of apricots and mango. Very fruity, and there are aroma hops hat contribute to the full flavour. Decent.

Draft at Shepherd and Knucklehead, Hoboken. Darker reddish color with a thin beige head. Sticky caramel and booze with some go notes. Heavy, cloying malty flavor. Kinda reminds me of all the bad barleywines that use to be everywhere in the early 2010s. Not sure how you can possible call this an Imperial IPA in 2017.

Pours a hazy rust orange-amber with light head. A string malt and dark fruit aroma. A strong malt forward taste with caramel and dark fruits and light hops. A lingering caramel malt and light hop aftertaste.

Bottle. Nose gorgeous PNW fruit salad, typical citrus blend but with really nice cookie dough and a little spice, also stronger malt than usual. Just a touch of nut. Very inviting! Pour a deep but still clear burnished orange with red highlights and a creamy beige head. Taste strongly sweet (too sweet) and strongly bitter, a big mash up of resin and sugar, berry and light citrus squeaking through, meaty malt and spice, lighter vegetal, medium and increasing alcohol numbing and warmth. Aftertaste picks up a little mint and structure without astringency. It’s bold but boozy and a little flabby; still, I welcome more traditional, maltier IIPAs that are actually pulled off, and this one is, more or less. [3.3]. Second go: naaah, way too sweet. [2016.06.17: 3.0]

Sampled at Mile, this disgusting brew pours hazy brown with small ring of white head. Notes are so fucking gross: shampoo, commerce bank lollipop, caramel pie, shit malt, shit grain and shit hops. So much booze heat, pushed back the 1 ounce sample after a sip or two. Horrifying

12 ounce bottle. Amber orange pour. Large creamy beige head. Sweet fruity malt nose has notes of sweet orange and caramel. Flavor follows the nose with additional notes of tropical fruit hops and dried apricots. Noticeable alcohol notes in middle. Chewy, sticky hops in finish. Interesting.
ACBF 2016. Poured a clear amber color with a small foamy tan head. Aroma and taste of caramel malt, citrus, grass, and booze.

12 oz bottle from a trade though I didn’t write down who. Pours a clear amber color with a medium sized, creamy beige head. The aroma and flavor have sweet malts, caramel, some candied fruit, a mishmash of faded hops, citrus, some herbal notes, mild bitterness, seems old.

Sampled on draft at the brewpub this beer poured a red-amber color with a large creamy orange-beige head that lingered and left great lacing. The aroma was bitter, perfumey hops and a bit of sweet fruitiness. The flavor was bitter and boozy with fruity hops, some perfume, an herbal presence, underlying sweetness and then more perfume. Very long perfume and herbal hop finish. Moderately full bodied. Booziness grows. Meh.

Strange beer- Tons of malt and hops but not bitter at all. The sweetness covers up the alcohol well. I enjoyed it. Good in it own right but different from other Imperial IPAs. Pseudo aged 120 min if I had to compare.

12 oz. bottle, sent from wilco (thanks a lot, Mike), pours a clear bright orange amber with a small white head. Aroma is pretty sweet, with caramel malts, big resinous hops, and a syrupy quality. Flavour is certainly on the sweet malty side for a IIPA, bordering on cloying sweetness, with lots of resinous hops underneath. Not at all my kind of IIPA - just way too sweet for me. It’s not bad though.
Pours brown with white top. Aroma is nut, toffee and grain. Taste is faint nut and residual sweetness from the malt. Basic and good.
I don’t remember much about this one. Had on tap at the brewery. Most of their beer was pretty decent.

Ob tap at the brewpub w Ronnee. Medium to dark brown pour, nothing out of the ordinary. Nose is nutty and a little coffee. Palate is loaded w vanilla bean and hazelnut. Some hop bitterness and a hint of roasted coffee. Enjoyed.
Draft. Pours amber brown with a beige head. Sweet malty aroma with notes of coffee. The flavor has coffee, roasted malts, and sweet toffee. Pretty good.

On Tap at the Brew Pub. A translucent brown pour. Aroma of roasted malts. Flavor of roasted malts with nuts and some sweetness. The alcohol was hidden well. (or maybe I had too much by now and did not notice) Decent
Brown with a decent head. Has a roasted, slight earth hop aroma. Flavor has a deeper roasted malt note, light chocolate, some oak, toffee, and light herbal hops. A decent brown that went down easy.

On tap @ Ithaca BrewFest Amber brown with a bit of white head. Aroma is mostly malty, caramel, bit of coffee, hint of hops. Somewhat bitter, medium to lighter bodied, hops come out more on the palate.

Part of a sampler at brewpub. I found all the brews to be better than average though I don’t remember specifics for most of them. It is worth mentioning that the sampler here is very generous with glasses that are big enough to really give you enough to form an opinion.

Cask at Pony Bar. Cloudy brown pour with a thick sticky tan head. The aroma is lightly toffeeish with a kiss of cold coffee as well. The coffee character is really quite pronounced and as it warms it sticks around. Lightly hoppy with a fairly assertive bitterness on the back of the palate that works pretty well. A fairly complex malt bill… toffee and brown malt with a touch of herbal cocoa sweetness, but it is well balanced by the hops. Lingering herbal/hoppy finish. For a style that I’m not typically a fan of, I enjoyed this a lot.

Sampled at the brewpub. AU15/08. App.: Medium ruby, clear, remnants of a light tan head. Aroma: Nice burnt sugar and light molasses, hints of warm spices, coffee, treacle, slightly nutty, somewhat fruity, a bit of alcohol. Palate: Medium-ish body and fairly soft carbonation. Flav.: Much like the nose, full and lovely; dry with a nice amount of bitterness. I really enjoyed this.

From 2002: Lots of ginger apparent in the nose and taste. I thought this beer was way too sweet, but not too gingery. Pull back on the honey or maybe add some more hops and this beer would have been much better.

Didnt kill you with ginger, so that was nice. It was more sweet than it was gingery. Would have benefited from some more hops. Dont think they will be brewing this one again, though it wasnt a bad experiment. Certainly on a better quality level than its honey brown neighbor at high falls.

LIght yellow and, for me at least, scary looking.. GInger spice aroma with some adjuncty vibes.. Ginger flavor subtle at first but grows and grows as the beer travels through your mouth...Gingerness stays on palate for an eternity..Honey sweetness lingers around in the background throughout..Kinda sweet..But not overly so
375ml can. Amber in colour with a medium white foam cap. Clear with no real aroma or taste. Typical of mass produced pale lagers. Very unisnpiring.

This used to be a great beer produced by an independent brewery in competition with the big brewers. Carlton United Breweries (Fosters) took them over and gradually denatured the brew until nobody wanted to drink it, which gave them the pretext to axe the brand. (Typical big brewery tactic). I have not seen this beer on sale here for a couple of years. Fosters still have rights to the Powers name and put out a feeble Powers Gold at Holiday times as a cheap ’opportunistic’ special.

(Can 37,5 cl) Pours a clear, golden with a white head leaving some laces. Sweetish aroma of malt and corn. Medium body with sweetish notes of chicken fodder. No bitterness. Classic Aussie swill. 230108

Light gold colour, poured a good head,this beer was very gassy on the stomach.Aroma was very hoppy slight fruity and sweet like.Flavour, bitter tended to be sour,hoppy flavour .Finish,bitter a beer I grew tired of,very boring.
(375 ml can from a friend from Australia) Pungent sweet scent. Clear golden color with a white head. Acidic mouthfeel and taste. Medium bitterness.

In the can from a sampler pack at the Sydney Airport Duty free shop. Yellow color, white head of vanishing presentation. Aroma of grains and metal. Thin and watery. Bitterness is limited and harsh, not flavorful.

Is there a scarier phrase in the Australian brewing world than the one on the label of this beer: "Queensland brewed"? The Sunshine State has a great deal going for it, but the beer... Ah well. Despite the name, this is another pale gold lager. The aroma has that wonderful Pride of Ringwood metallic ring with some wet grass and butter. Typical CUB lager burp-inducing soda-water carbonation. A hint of honey and peachy fruitiness in the mid-palate before the curse of POR washes it all away in a metallic finish. (375ml bottle)

Big, fat, toffee, earthy crystal malt aroma with diacetyl and mushrooms. Quite interesting. Crystal malt flavour isn’t so dominant but it’s there, light acidity and metallic bitterness. A bit watery, some pineapple. It’s actually not that far off a real bitter, which is a bit of a surprise.

Pale gold, coarse carbonation to form a thin head which drops to nothing within a minute. Carbonation finished in a similar time. Pleasenet, sweet malt/honey aroma, but not well balanced. thin body, drying with a harsh metallic bitterness, and still a notable sweetness. Sounds like it should be nicely balanced but somehow misses out.
This beer was alot better than I expected, but it is still not good, it looks like an average lager but with a nice head. Average, average, average, pretty poor. cheers

On tap at the brewpub. It poured a hazy purple color with a white head. The aroma was of raspberry, hay and bread. The taste was similar to the aroma with more raspberry, hay, bread and mild carbonation with a sweet aftertaste. Ok.
Keg at the Water Street location. Hazy orange, no head. Weak aroma of berries and not much else. Taste is tart berries, hints of wheat. Thin.
Tap at brewery. Hazy light Brown with moderate head. Smells like "berries." Taste is fake berries and wheat. Not cloying though

On tap @ WSB, Oak Creek. Pinkish purple pour. No head whatsoever. Nose of raspberry Kool Aid. Weak, sickly sweet, and lacking in any natural fruit flavor. Tasted more like a flat generic soda than any kind of beer. This is really sub-par for this genre.
Smells sweet citrus but wouldn’t call it raspberry. Pink color. The wheat flavor is lost to the sugars. The touch of fruit is a little like fruit stripe gum before it goes to pot. Tap
Light red pour with small off white head. Standard wheat beer aroma. The amount of raspberries is perfect (not cloy). Not my favorite but I would drink again

On-tap, this pours a reddish color with pink head. The aroma is tart with raspberries and hints of wheat. The taste is sweet and tart, the raspberries really come through. A decent brew, much better than the rating would suggest.

Draft at the downtown brewery in Milwaukee. Cloudy, reddish color. Raspberry aroma. Tart, raspberry flavor. Watery mouthfeel. Dry finish. Seems to be a brew that is caught between being a traditional beer with a hint of fruit and a full-fledged fruit beer; this doesn't quite work. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at the source. From notes. Sweet and tart with loads of raspberry. Not exactly my style, but very good.

On tap and dispensed to a weizen glass at the Grafton location, showing a cloudy, reddish amber color, with white head foam that quickly diminished to a thin ring, and spots of lacing. The aroma was light grain/wheat, some acidity, subtle spice, but no noticeable phenols due to a dominant raspberry puree scent. The taste was similar notes, with a light body, effervescence that seemed to wane by mid serving, but tartness & fruit that remained to the finish.

Perched upon a bar stool supporting my ’Gunner’s’ in the FA Cup 2003, I quaffed a good eight or nine pints of this, before passing out ( not a normal thing for me ) during the trophy ceremony. Spent weeks afterwards searching for the ( I thought? ) British Ale ’Midland Fettler’s’ only to find it non-existent... Until now! Inchant brewery in Guildford, West Australia, sadly,went out of business just before I downed these pints and what a glum chain of globalist events ensued, for a revolutionary Australian Craft Brewer like ’Bullant’. From a vague memory, the palate ( On draught ) was medium bodied, light carbonation with a spritzy effervescence. Aroma was slightly dank, with yeasty highlights. Taste was overly sweet, but not cloying and ginger hit midway through. Short malty aftertaste, caramel sweetness and little hop tone gave me the impression of a Midland Mild ( hence the short story ), now to find out it’s strength and heritage somehow saddens me. :( Seemed a decent Traditional ’Gruit’ Ale, just sad to see a craft brewer go under.

Tawny brown colour with a short lasting head. Aroma of slight yeast (broth), cinnamon then honey. Flavour was ginger followed once again by honey as well as some spices. It is not a full bodied beer (thankfully I think) but it was wet.
cucumber salad aroma - the stuff with vinegar. old bottle, quite dark, dunno about the bottle conditioning. notice the alcohol. i think i'd still prefer it to my baby ginger olde

like morocco spiced ale with extra compost. sweaty rotting pawpaw esters and thin brown sugar tang spoil what might otherwise be a drinkable powdery-malty ginger "old". motelpogo's h.b. on the same theme wins on a head to head, even at the ripe old age of 3 days out of the barrel.

Poured amber-brown, quite thin with basically no head. Spicey pudding-like aroma with hints of ginger. Quite sweet flavour, no hop prominance. Hints of ginger, caramel and a slightly smokey aftertaste. Medium body.

Deep red brown clear with a small short lasting fine bubbled cream coloured head. Unusual light roasted malt and spice aroma (as indicated in the commercial description) plus interesting hints of sherbert, fibreglass resin and marzipan. Medium thin body with flat watery soft drink style palate. Sweet perfumed light roasted malt sweet and the ginger and cinamon are a bit more evident in the flavour than aroma. A touch more bitter woudl really help liven up thsi beer. Soft sweetish quick fading finish. Normally I don't like ginger flavours in beer but this one sufficiently subdued to make it OK.

Well, it definitely is sweet, perhaps a little too sweet, very spicy cinamon in both the nose and palate, and a very honey like sweetness from the start to the finish. I actually didn't mind it that much, but my only real complaint was the sweetness, and probably the lack of bitterness or even roastiness to balance it out a bit. still, its good to see an Aussie brewer experimenting a bit, even if it isn't so great.

Dark brown with tawny tinges and a short head. Yeasty and dusty aroma, more bonox than vegemite flavour with a honey aftertaste, medium texture with a mild carbonation throughout. Enjoyable beer made in WA.

Deep ruby red clear with a medium size shortish lasting mid-beige head. Complex aroma and flavours but not quite as polished or as well blended as one might expect. Quite yeasty (vegemite), faint soapy hops and honey aroma, some treacle and acetone on glass swirling. Medium thin low carbonated body. Medium mild hoppy bitter with fainter nutty, coffee and sweet roasted malt flavours. Soft sweetish finish and mild bittersweet aftertaste. Quite interesting and if the brewers polished it up a little could easily rate a 4/5.

Deep brown, and slightly red around the edges. Little lasting head, but OK lace. Sweetish and roasted, and slightly hoppy, not insanely flavoured, but pretty tasty. Brown Ales are never a favourite of mine, but this one was OK, tasted like somethin between a porter and a brown ale (IMHO). A very surprisingly OK brew.

Deep brown nearly black in colour with a brown short but almost lasting head. Aroma is lots of things, rich dark chocolate liquorice toffee and malt. Flavour is milky coffee, sweet, caramel and medium bodied. Enjoyable but slightly different for a porter.

Deep opaque brown with a larger than average and relatively long lasting dark brown head. Aroma begins with strong roasted malt intertwined with coffee and hints of port wine, someting yeasty & chocolate. Medium thinnish typical porter body with medium malt and hint of cough medicine start. Reasonably strong bitter and roasted flavours dominate the middle and thereafter. Finish also has hints of caramel sweet malt before going back to a dryish bitter. Quite a surprise for a small local brewery in the middle of nowhere to make such an interesting brew. One to follow up.

Not too bad at all. Deep brown to black in colour with a tan head. Roasty nose, with perhaps a bit of fruit. Sweetish on the palate, but the finish is a tad more drier, and a tad bitter. Lots of roasty coffee and caramel flavours, not insane, but pretty good for an Aussie beer, quite full-flavoured, slight molasses flavour, which didn't quite agree with me, but i think this beer was more good than bad, another surprise from this brewer.

27-Apr-14 (22-oz bottle) I like Oatmeal Stouts that develop a hint sourness over time. This one has an entry of dark chocolate, dark toast, sour dough, and perhaps some tart cherry, finishing with a nice earthy, smoky, tobacco flavor. The aromas show cacao nib, toast, oatmeal, sour dough, tobacco, shiitake mushroom, and tart berry and cherry. The beer is medium in weight, medium in carbonation, lightly acidic, and generally dry on the palate. It’s dark-brown in color with a medium-brown rim and a small, tan head fading to a thin ring. Overall, this is a pleasant, complex Oatmeal Stout that’s cellared quite nice over the years, although I don’t know exactly how old this one is. Maybe 8 years?

Transparent dark brown, minimal beige head. Decent aroma of chocolate, licorice and coffee, light hop character in background. As it warms more and more coffee coming through. Coffee dominates flavor, not much else going on. Mouthfeel lacks a bit, body thins out a bit as it warms.

Vintage 2005 Pours opaque black with a dense, thick, dark tan head. The batter-like foam rose to over an inch, and fell slowly to the surface. Remnants of clingy froth failed to stay on the walls of the glass, and only a trace of lacework remained as a result. Aromatics are a nice blend of coffee and dark chocolate. Slightly acrid and heavily roasted, with a mild creamy note. Drizzeled caramel and chocolate syrup come forward in the end. The mouthfeel is a bit spritzy and some overcarbonation keeps the brew from having any creaminess. Not a thick as I had hoped. The pallet is laden with dark chocolate and burnt caramel. A strong espresso note follows through along with a generous dose of roasted malts and a hint of smoke. Finishes slightly warming with a lingering bitter chocolate bite. Lacking a lot of character that is eluded to by the moniker "breakfast stout".

Bomber pours a big brown expansive foam ball with dark dark body and spotty lacing. It smells like a hand full of steel cut oats mixed with faint roasted malts. The over bubbly carbonation causes the beer to explode and punctuate the initial burnt malt, astringent malt and roasted malt notes. As the mushroom cloud of carbonation subsides the oatmeal twang, burnt malts and coffee all ride the flavor to the finish. The beer leaves burnt malts and oats into the after taste.

Meh. A very boring sweet stout. Thanks hopdog for sending it my way though! It is not bad by any means, but it does not differentiate itself from the loads of other stouts out there either in quality or innovation. Typical thin head, dark near-black color, roasted coffee, chocolate aroma. Taste is very much coffee and bitter chocolate; finishes slightly creamy, but the hoppiness of the beer really cuts into the creaminess of the beer, making the cream seem like a worthless pursuit. The flavors just do not all come together to create a great beer. Decent beer, but just decent.

22 oz. bottle- color of black , with a dark tan head - light nose of chocolate , anis , and vanilla – taste of chocolate , anis , and malts - body is medium , sweet , and with medium carbonation – aftertaste of chewy , and dark baking chocolate
On tap at Stone. Dark brown with a fizzy white head. Chocolate, roasty, and grainy aroma. Creamy palate. Bitter-sweet chocolate taste, dark roasted coffee, and a milk chocolate taste to the finish.
Poured black with a big creamy head. Aroma of chocolate, malt coffee. Chocolate malt flavor. Slightly bitter finish.

22oz Bomber My God a deep dark black nectar from the gods above. Thanks you beer gods. This was deep dark amlts chocolate with great smooth mouthfeel. I loved the flavor this was not your mamas breakfast beer thsi was for the those who can aprecate the deep dark thick crude stuff. AWESOME!!!

22oz bottle aquired in trade. Poured a dark, deep brown (almost black) with red edges and an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of milk chocolate, roast, light vanilla, oats and very light coffee. Tastes of roast, vanilla lighter chocolate, and a light bitter coffee finish.

column1: Side Pocket High Gravity Malt Liquor
column5: 40 oz. bottle, with moderate particular buildup in the bottom. Pours a medium, rapidly collapsing white head, over an effervescent, light gold (SRM 4) body......nose is mild malts, sweet corn, minimal hop tones.....taste is mild malt, corn tones, sweet fruit tones, minimal ho finish.....mouth feel, light watery body, high alcohol, moderate carbonation. This is a very simple beer in both aroma and flavor and is very high in alcohol. It is dangerous. BJCP 4/1/7/2/3

column1: Side Pocket High Gravity Malt Liquor
column5: This shit is fucking amazing. There are very few beers where I’d rather not drink anything than drink that beer and this is one of them. It’s sweet and sticky, heavy w/ loads of weird nutty and overripe berry notes from oxidized malt. This is pretty much disgusting across the board.

column1: Side Pocket High Gravity Malt Liquor
column5: 40 at Adnielsens pre-wedding bash. Pour is clear orange with a big white head and good lacing. Corny, doughy, grassy, green apple, and grapes in the aroma. Taste is ethanol, corn, green apples, and dough with a lot of alcohol on the backend. So fucken good.

column1: Side Pocket High Gravity Malt Liquor
column5: Classy clear glass 40 pours with a thin clear pale gold body that supports a tiny white head. The aroma offers up an estery mess of sweet apples and pears and then a sliver or two of corn flowing into boozy table sugar. The taste is similar and it gets harder and harder to drink the deeper you go into that 40. So it’s all sweet with honey covered apple wedges and pear like juiciness that’s balanced off by a slight corn flake sort of cereal sensation and then modestly sharp booziness. All in all not bad for a 10.5% boost vehicle.

column1: Side Pocket High Gravity Malt Liquor
column5: Gold pour, white head. Thanks(or no thanks?)to ibrew2or3. Sweet, corn, grain, artificial crap. Bleh.

column1: Side Pocket High Gravity Malt Liquor
column5: 40 from DrewFace. Pours golden yellow. Aroma if corn and water. Taste is crap water. No byeno.

column1: Side Pocket High Gravity Malt Liquor
column5: 40 into snifter. Bottle thanks to sooner. Brilliantly clear pale golden orange, no head. Sweet, malty, corn adjuncts, no notable skunk. Sweet, lightly boozy, some light malt character but overall too sweet.

column1: Side Pocket High Gravity Malt Liquor
column5: Fo’Ty shared by AndrewCat. Pours a very clear yellow with a white head that dies immediately. Aroma a like sugar water with some fruit. Like a jolly rancher. Taste is just as sickening sweet. Lots of fruitiness too but no significant alcohol presence.

column1: Side Pocket High Gravity Malt Liquor
column5: Can. Pours a clear yellow with a gold hue and a white head that dissipates quickly to the edges. Aroma has lots of sweet grains and corn with an odd light fruit note. Flavor is similar with sweet grains and corn up front with sweet light fruits in the finish.

column1: Side Pocket High Gravity Malt Liquor
column5: Bottle. Clear gold with a small white head. When the pour is fast and vigorous you get some soapy and floral yeast esters which settle quickly out into a corn and alcohol and red apple malt stew. Super sweet and sticky corn syrup / candy corn / pale malt extract syrup / other ingredients. surprisingly not hot or fusel or alcoholic or gross, not in that way. the malt is disgustingly cloying and syrupy and the red apple flavor / smell lingers for far too long.

8/V/14 - 75cl bottle @ De Manedans (Kruishoutem) - BB: n/a (2014-487) Clear dark orange beer, huge creamy solid off-white head, pretty stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: orange peel, caramel, spices, some cardboard, overripe banana, sweet. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: pretty sweet start, overripe banana, caramel, spicy touch, speculoos (ginger bread of some kind), cinnamon, sugary. Aftertaste: orange peel, little sourish, citrus touch, caramel, some cardboard.
Red golden colour, white head. Malty aroma, yeast, some fruit and spices. Very tripel like. Sweet malty flavour, sweet malty finish. Quite unremarkable. (From 75cL bottle @ DRBM, courtesy of joes)
Bottle @ DRBM. A clear golden colored beer, with a thick white head. The aroma of malts with notes of fruits. The taste is malty sweet, with a little bitter. The aftertaste is bittersweet.
75cl Bottle at DRBM. Clear golden colour, white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity. Flavour is sweet, fruity, yeast. Lots of carbonation. Medium bodied. Very mediocre.
Tripel, unremarkable, fruity peach and citrus. Light bitter, too fizzy. Alcohol shines through. (DRbM 2011)
Bottle at UDRBM. Hazy golden pour, thin white head. Aroma and flavor are spicy malts. Quite boring average belgian ale.

bottle shared with Tomaz. pours cloudy golden, thick white head. aroma had something unique not typical to most Belgian strong ales, something of fermented white grapes with a blossom hops and yeast. Found it to be sweet and reminiscent to the Bloemenbiek beer. Flavors, yeasty, some caramel malts, honey like palate, sweet with some raisins, hay/attic flavors. Tasty and surely doesn’t feel like 8.3%

This was a great beer. Very nice brown-orange a bit trouble. Spicy and vanilla on the back ground. Medium body with a nice enjoyable sweet finish. Even the beer reach 8.3, the alcohol is not too much intense. Very well balanced. Last long in the month, remembers me caramelized pear. It was a really one of the nicest beer.
Between amber and red-gold colored beer with a small off-white head. Malty aroma. Rather malty sweetish taste. A bit of caramel, fruits and some peaches.

(Bottle) Amber colour, slightly hazy, with a frothy, off-white head. Sourish nose with green apples, yeast and a touch of vinegar. Malty, fruity taste with notes of dried fruit, apricots and a spicy finish. Balanced sweetness. Possibly a bit too old, but still drinkable.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours black with a thin tan head. Aroma of smoked meats, roasted malt. Flavor of light roasted malt, light smoked meats, bitter chocolate. The smokiness could be a little more powerful, as the flavor is somewhat bland when compared to other smoked porters. The palate is nice and smooth though. 6/4/6/4/14 (3.4/5)

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Looks beautiful in the glass dark with a slight tinge of amber. Ample head that leaves a nice trace along the edges of the glass. Taste is a little sweeter and bitter than I prefer, lacking the full bodied smoke I prefer, almost burnt. The arome has more of the meaty, leathery character of the classic Schlenkerla Rauchbiers. On tap at Davidson.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Not my favorite porter out there. It was moderately smokey, some nice malts to complement, but nothing earth-shattering. It was solid, just not outstanding.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: A - Served a dark black color with a finger of super creamy tan head. The retention on the head was very good and left behind some nice lacing. S - Aroma has some nice smoky notes with some sweet caramel/chocolate malts. Bit subtle and could have used a bit more punch. T - Starts off with sweet roasted caramel malts and just a hint of smoke. The smoke flavor builds a bit through the middle and some chocolate malt flavors blends in. The finish is a mix of the malt flavors and some smoke that lingers. M - Medium bodied with moderate-low amount of carbonation. Feels really smooth and creamy and the finish really fills the mouth. D - Very drinkable. Was expecting a bit more of a flavor punch from a smoked porter, but what was there was fairly good. The mouthfeel was very nice.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Deep brown-black pour. The nose has a touch of briny smokiness. A touch peaty but it’s not overpowering. Soft licorice on the back of the palate. Slightly watery palate but has an assertive bitterness. Kind of light-bodied despite having a fairly silky finish. Odd, but pretty nice.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Dark brown with nice dense off-white head. Coffee nose with a hint of roastiness. Flavor matches nose, coffee and roasty but alcohol is somewhat promninent. Full palate. Nice mild porter with well balanced flavor. On tap at Dive 96 NYC

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: &#40draft&#41 Creamy brown head that leaves nice lacing, atop clear red-black body. Aroma is medium sweet, roast, some smoke, light anise, floral. Taste is medium sweet, roast, some coffee, smoke, light earthy, chocolate. Light-medium body, light resin, somewhat watery.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a deep brown with ruby highlights with a medium tanned head. Aromas of smoke, malt, and caramel. Medium to thick body and creamy. Thins out a little as it warms. Finishes with a light bitterness and nice smoke.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Pours dark brown with a than head. Smells of liquid smoke, chocolate, roasted malt. Tastes roasty and smoky with a nice spicy finish. Full developed mouthfeel.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Clear brown pour with a medium, creamy, tan head. Aroma and flavor of weak smoked and roasted malt, a bland and boring smoked porter, oh well... The body is light and waterty.
Pale straw in color,cloudy with a small white head. Mellow banana/clove aroma and flavor.Refreshingly clean/dry finish.
Light amber with lasting off white head. Flowery nose and taste with decent body for a wheat beer.

Light amber colored and darker towards the top. Made with a special kind of german yeast, this beer exudes a boquet of lilac and lavender--pleasantly perfumey with a flavor that is similarly painted. Would love to try this again--have not had anything else like it to date.
Cloudy tan color.Malt taste with mild alcohol heat..........................

Hazy tan-amber color approximating a wheat/IPA. Scotch aroma with a fair scotch flavor and the presence of alcohol just seeping through the the cover--indeed it is superbly masked. Another well crafted Hales ale.
Sample Brewery (Old Notes)-Pours golden with a small head. Aroma of citrus and sweetness. Taste of the same with a bit of grass coming in. This light bodied brew is well balanced.

Cloudy golden pour with a thin white head. Aroma and flavor of honey and hops. The body is light to medium with an oily texture and moderate carbonation. It’s not a badly done beer, it’s just that it fails to interest me.

Hazy, pale straw yellow. Grassy and faintly swett nose. Light to medium body is nicely carbonated. Grassy with a touch of honey and fruit, very farmhouse-like. Reminded me of the golden Jolly Pumkin beer minus the barrel touches. Interesting.

Hazy, very pale yellow color, very little pale white head. Light citrus/lemon in the nose. Fruity with a sweetish, almost pinapple hint. Sugar a light touch of grass in the end of the nose. The body is lightly bitter and somewhat roasty. Light citrus notes, fruity and spritzy. Grassy and organic in the end.
pale golden-yellow colour. Dry, fairly crips and hoppy. Not bad. ........
malt balanced, slght sweetness, very light with a minimal hop taste. Somewhat yeasty. The beer would fit the Italian food nicely at this Italian Brew Pub.
Draft Brewery (Old Notes)-Pours copperish with a small head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and hops. Taste of the same. This light to medium bodied brew is not too shabby.

Pours a cloudy amber color with a thin white head. Mild aroma of citrusy hops. Decent flavor of biscuity malt and Cascade hops with a bitter finish. The body is light and the carbonation is gentle. Not bad at all but I would have liked more hops and malt in there.
Clear copper color with a thin snow white head. Toasted caramel nose, hints of cascade hops lurking underneath. Malt heavy and rich, but the hops were so muted and weak.
Citrusy hop aroma. Crisp hoppy bite to start with some weird late flavours that I can't quite place, but still good.
cascade aroma and a very citrusy charecter. This and D'Oro are the brewpubs staple beers, less interesting then the others I had.
Caramel/butterscotch aroma and similar flavour, hoppy finish. .............
earthy hop aroma. a solid caramel charecter. spicey with a robust bitterness. Interesting, I've never had Simcoe hops before though.
Toffe aroma/chocolate flavour. I like. ...................................
brown sugar mixed with the grapefruity cascades is inteesting. roasty. unsweetend chocolate. Brown bordering on the verge of Black in color. My favorite yet.
