Did not know they mage this. Found randomly on a lower shelf in a FNQ bottle shop. Corn, lurid yellow, very low carbonation and put me to sleep on a hot FNQ day.

Poured a light golden amber with a three-finger white foamy head that collapsed more than diminished. Laced poorly. Moderate carbonation. Aroma of malt with a strange slightly metallic tint. Taste bit bland up front but has a nice hops bitter after taste. Light (watery) body (3% ABV). Finish is pretty bland with a hint of bitterness.

375ml can. Dull amber colour with a reasonabley nice head of soft foam that stayed around. Mild carbonation and a heavy malt aroma - skumky. Bitter and tart on thye palate with a long aftertaste. Light and dry texture.

In Australia it is common for breweries to run a special batch of beer to be sold on special, packed in 30-can ’blocks’ and sold quite cheaply compared to the normal can or bottle 24 ’slabs’ as they are known here. Powers Gold is only ever sold as a 30-can block and tends to be issued at major selling times like Christmas or Easter. It is usually very cheap indeed, less than $AUD 1 per can and tastes like it. Originally it was 3.5% ABV but has been watered down to 3% recently.

Little brother of powers bitter and not too nice,pours out a darkish gold weak head some lace,aroma is malty but metallic,the flavour green and metallic some fruit like but finish bittery sour,I gave it away quick.
Bronze gold colour with big white head. Malty corn aroma. Metalic flavour with hint of oxo cube.

In the can. Pours pale gold with a medium-sized fluffy white head. Smells like a cross between apple juice and urine. Mild residual bitter finish. Weak and watery. Not sure that this has any sugar-donating adjuncts as it only reaches 3% ABV. Boiled vegetable flavors abount. Yuck.

One of six from the "Beer down under" six pack brought back from Australia. This offering from Carlton pours a pale yellow with a thin white lace. There is a metallic pale hop presence, the carbonation is high it almost burns the throat. There is a small bitter grapefruit quality in the finish but overall it is really weak.

Can. My Uncle Don brought this one over from Sydney in a pack of 6 different Aussie beers. Can says that it’s good until April 06. OK. I didn’t get to try this one in Australia, so here we go. Pours with a fluffy head, and that head leaves quickly, but surprisingly leaves some decent lace. Golden color, a little darker than I anticipated. Nose is like a lot of domestic macros, but not unpleasant, just corn and hops. I glanced at the can and .... what?.... 3 percent?.... Is this near beer for Aussies? Lots of flavor from the hops when I take a slurp. Pride of Ringwood hops I’m guessing because it tastes a lot like the other Australian lagers that I have had. Not bad. Highly carbonated. I think that I could easily drink 15 of these. Pretty tasty actually.

Damn, bugger and all those really bad words. I looked at the ratings of some of my colleagues and I noticed I hadn’t rated this. So, being in close proximity to the Australian Hotel in the Rocks I wander in and find, to my dismay, that this was available. Yup, typical Queensland description of a mid strength beer with all that such a style promises. Too grainy, corny adjuncty to be a real light and not enough guts to be a heavy. These beers are a bit like a transvestite, they technically have balls but they just can’t use them to any real extent. And they certainly are trying to be something they aren’t.
[Canned] Clear golden, no head. No aroma. Paper diluted in loads of water. No malt nor hops, perhaps the vaguest trace of maize can be noted before it fizzes out in an empty finish.
Very thin, no taste or aroma. Golden and a little white top. The cheapest beer is in fact also the worst. As it turned out.
Canned. Pale olden, chemical aroma and flavour. Is this skunky water? No the label says beer, but I doubt it...
Yellow, with a head that actually was ok. No aroma, and this is probably one of the thiinest beers I have tried. Skunky finish, thats all except water.
I wanted this to be good, but it wasn't. Musty pils nose, decent golden color, foamy head. Sweet malt body with some honey (maybe) and a gritty bitter end. Oily mouth feel. You can do without this...
Sweet rice nose. Pee yellow, soft carbonation. No head. Light water - nothing with a spritz of hops.
Bland, tasteless, pale-colored, very boring. The foam is dying very fast. There are no many words to describe this beer.
Light, uninteresting, some bitterness in the flavour, cheap.................
A very delicious ale with a smooth taste. Fine head and a long taste with a fine bitterness. Only on draft.

A very good English style ale. Some Danish homebrewer won a competition with this ale and Allan of Brøckhouse decided to brew a small amount of it. You can taste that it is handcrafted. It is full of taste but still very smooth and pleasant.

column1: Boulder Beer Hazed Hoppy Session Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery, a nice one to start the flight. A pale that tastes like an ipa.

column1: Boulder Beer Hazed Hoppy Session Ale
column5: LemonRadlerCrush🐯Love it or hate it🦁SessionCrispy too🙂...direkt aus der 355ml Dose weggeschnattert :)....vor dem Bill Graham Civic Auditorium in SF...After PHISH TWO Beer :)...

column1: Boulder Beer Hazed Hoppy Session Ale
column5: Aroma of light grains, grapefruit, pine and guava. Taste is malt, orange and light hoppiness.

column1: Boulder Beer Hazed Hoppy Session Ale
column5: 12oz bottle at home, pours a clear amber with a thin white head. It smells like bread and it tastes like a pretzel. It's a good beer, not too hoppy though like the bottle says

column1: Boulder Beer Hazed Hoppy Session Ale
column5: A-. Pours a hazy amber color with white head. Hoppy but not bitter. Nice amber beer flavor balances nicely with the hops

column1: Boulder Beer Hazed Hoppy Session Ale
column5: From Feb 2006 Poured from bottle a cloudy reddish gold with a medium sized head of foam that dissipated quickly.. The smell is quite hoppy with lemony notes, The taste is very hoppy with strong citrus tones that make for a very bitter attack on my palate but that's not a complaint from me. ;^) Solid APA. Bottom line: Here's a very flavourful APA that only tips the scales at 4.85%abv thus making it a good candidate for a session beer. I recommend it.

column1: Boulder Beer Hazed Hoppy Session Ale
column5: 12 ounce can from the remainder shelf at Liberty Beer in Pittsburgh. Nice and clean and unpretentious. Seems appropriately named for Colorado.

column1: Boulder Beer Hazed Hoppy Session Ale
column5: This beer had a lot going on. The hop flavors were really unique and I got the Colorado vibe while drinking it. Just a nice solid ale.

column1: Boulder Beer Hazed Hoppy Session Ale
column5: Can at Cafe Nero, september 28th 2016. Light copperish body with a fingerthick white head. Aroma of caramel malt, mild earthy and floral hops. taste is light, mild fruity, biscuit, strong bitterness.

column1: Boulder Beer Hazed Hoppy Session Ale
column5: I got this from a beer club sampler. Appearance is pretty fine, I see a dark amber with a lingering, almost white foam. The nose contains a woody, lemony scent. For taste I find a slightly hoppy edge along with some citrus and meadow, a metallic ending. A session beer so that kick is just not there.

For its price tag of $1.25 plus deposit, I am rating this beer purely on its price to quality ratio which is great. At 120 calories, it is great for those who are calorie conscience as well. Its quite difficult to find but if you can, stock up as much as possible.
341ml bottle. $1.10. Clear body, uneven white head. As is tradition. Lots of bubbles. No aroma. Not bad, just non-existent. The taste is fresh.
Tap, light pour, aroma is light and taste is crisp, a bit grassy but overall nice and refreshing
Pale gold pour, almost no head. Aroma of wet paper, wet grass. Musty hops, cooked veggie finish. Nothing but macro swill.

MIni keg brought to my house so figured what the heck I would try it. When really cold it was drinkable...not so much once it became just plain cold. Yellow with a copper hue, white head, smells of stale caramel, grainy, corn adjunct with an unpleasant aftertaste.

355ml bottle pours a pale straw color with a small white head which leves no lacing. Aroma is light grains and faint hops. Taste is light malt sweetness and moderate hop bitterness. Average macro lager and nothing more.
tastes like piss. same as all the other macro crap. dont know what else to say...even on tap.
pours pale yellow with a small disappearing white head. malt lacking, corn, light herbal hops. don’t you get fooled by "best north american lager in ontario"... it’s the usual macro brew.

Comes in a 4-pack for $5 at the LCBO. One of three beers being pushed there nowadays. Had a few at the jam, kind of warm and it was not that good. Now, from the cold fridge to the glass, it actually is better. Pale yellow-golden colour, small white head and decent lacing. Malty start to the aromas, but then, corn comes out and then later, adjuncts. Refreshing wet mouthfeel with a little stickiness, but with a light dry finish. Not many flavours, quite mild with a little malt start and a little hop at the end. Probably would be appreciated by Labatt Blue lovers.
Pours a thin straw yellow with a quickly disappearing white head. Aroma is grain and corn. Taste is nothing. I mean literally nothing. Well some grain and shitty wet newspapers.
Just a normal amber, maybe a bit sweeter than usual. Very drinkable, enjoyable, but very simple beer. Thanks Ron.
It's a smooth wheat beer and it fortunately doesnt taste anything like cannibis.
Can, Ann Arbor, MI via Mulmur. Clear dark amber. Metallic caramel aroma. Sweet. Caramel flavor. Balanced.

This is a clear amber beer w/ a big head. It’s interesting more so than good but it’s still a reasonable thing to drink, I suppose. It’s got a sort of caramel, vanilla, tobacco thing going on. It’s sort of creamy in texture w/ medium carbonation. With some tweaking, this recipe could actually be legitimately good.
355ml slim can. Dark amber pour with a frothy creamy long-sticking off-white head. It is a bit carmaally and toasty very light roast. Unnofensive but gimmicky.
Pours red amber with a very fizzy and quick fading off white head. Small malt aroma. Taste of malts, grain and straw. Not an impressive beer.

Comes in a cheap 4 pack. Has a foamy off-white head with a dark amber appearance. Malty aromas, wheats. Watery mouthfeel. Flavours are of weak citrus notes, light malts, some mild spices. If it’s made with hemp, I can’t tell. Nothing too special, but for the price, well worth trying again.

I’m not a lager man. I tried Buzz largely because I was curious about what a hemp beer would taste like. The answer: hay. That’s about it. A thoroughly forgettable beer kept aloft only by the gimmick of putting a marijuana leaf on the can.

On tap at the Arrow and Loon. Appearance: Pours a clear copper colour with little head. Aroma: Malt Flavours: Malt, rye, cereal, yeast. Mouthfeel: Thinner with low carbonation. Overall: Lots of malt and I’m getting some rye. An okay beer but not one of my favourites.
Amber clear body with a quickly dissipating head. Bready euro-lager aroma. Some hop bite, reminiscent of a pilsner in character minus the color. Very thin.

This beer is by far the best Ithaca has ever made. The co,or is nice and dark. The smell is of floral hops. The taste is balanced with sweet smooth caramel malts and then nice bitter, but not overwhelming hops. Overall exquisite beer. Amazing this comes from the same brewery as the scotch ale, pale ale, and amber. Outstanding.

Draft: Poured a light clear burgundy color ale with a small off-site foamy head with light retention and lacing. Aroma of light caramelized notes with subtle toffee notes. Taste is a mix of caramelized malt with light residual sugar. Body is light with good carbonation. Nice seasonable scotch ale with limited amount of complexities.
Can at in-laws. Chestnut pour lovely beige head. Nose is faint nitty and Carmel. Tastes of red fruit, toast, caramel, nutty, and red wine. Some alcohol on finish. Smooth and slick palate.
16 oz. can. Aroma is old leather, yeast. Flavor is a reflection. Old English toffee. No thanks.

Can @ the Railroad Street location. Pours clear reddish brown with small creamy beige head, sweet caramel aroma, low carbonation, medium bitter caramel malt taste, smooth body, long medium bitter caramel finish. Very smooth and drinkable.

Served on tap at the Radio Social Bowling Alley in Rochester NY. It is a clear, warm amber color with a slight beige head. Aroma: sweet and nutty, molasses. Tastes like it smells, sweet bready caramel;. Mouthfeel: medium-bodied. Finish was sweet and stayed sweet. This is a good beer, but a bit too much on the sweet side.
Tap @ BOT. Copper, off-white. Caramel, dark fruits, some bitterness. A bit alcoholic.
Very smooth scotch ale with a still very strong abv. Dark color, sweet delicious. One of my favorite scotch’s. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Legends Bar in the Radisson hotel in downtown Rochester, N.Y., while in town to see a Bob Seger concert. Pours clear amber-brown with spritz of light tan head and lacing. Aroma: nuts, molasses. Flavor: the above, along with black pepper, brown bread, caramel; very much malt-forward. Mouthfeel: medium-bodied. Too sweet, even for the style.
Aroma is a lot of caramel and roast. The flavor is sweet, with a nice finish.

Hazy rustic Amber/copper with a foamy ivory head. Malty toast-filled nose that’s rustic and slightly dark and wheaty and slightly sweet. Semisweet and smooth dark malty flavor that’s a bit bready and wheaty. Lightly sweet and toasty. Meh.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee Honey Creek Pale Ale
column5: On tap at Milwaukee location, pours a clear golden with a thin head, aroma and flavor were both of slight grain with some lemon mixed in and a finish of hops, very light and drinkable just nothing impressive.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee Honey Creek Pale Ale
column5: hazy gold, not much head, lacy. wheaty nose, trace of banana. flavor og grain and banana. medium bodied, banana finish. the banana definitely fades as the beer warms, but overall, not an impressive beer. sampled at rockfest 2010.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee Honey Creek Pale Ale
column5: 1 of 45 beers at Rock Bottom Brewery’s Rockfest. Pours an Amber color with a medium white head. Smells of honey and caramel malt. finished bitter with a lemon twist.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee Honey Creek Pale Ale
column5: On draught at the Rock Bottom brewpub in downtown Milwaukee, WI as White Tail Pale Ale. Pours a clear light copper colored brew with a creamy off-white head that has some nice retention and lacing. Aroma of both citrus and floral hops, golden and caramel malt, a hint of grapefruit and toffee. Taste is medium bodied with flavors of caramel malt, citrus and floral hops with a hint of dark pitted fruit. Finish is semi-dry and has a mild bitterness that quickly disappears.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee Honey Creek Pale Ale
column5: Had on tap at the place. Decent, but lacking the citrus they claim, and not much of a pale ale, even for the American style.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee Honey Creek Pale Ale
column5: On tap. Poured a clear gold with a small white head. Aroma of malt and a slight hop note. Flavor of malt, lemon and grapefruit with a very slight hop bite at the end. Average.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee Honey Creek Pale Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear golden yellow with a thin white head. Very little aroma of pale malts and barely a floral hop note. Lemon citrus, pale malt flavors that are lightly sweet with a floral hop poking out in the finish. Nothing bad, but pretty mediocre. I’ll be trying something else next time.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee Honey Creek Pale Ale
column5: Amber color, with a white head, light honeyed pale malt, with a mild floral hop leafy note, wiht a hint of citrusy in the aroma follows through on a light-bodied palate, with a sharp citrus, limoney flowery hop character, with a faint toasted, caramel malt accent leading towards a lingering hop bitterness finish

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee Honey Creek Pale Ale
column5: Cloudy dark amber with a frothy head. Aroma is almost un-noticable but a hint of citrus can be detected. Flavor is a nice balance of grapefruit and light caramel malt. Very thin, light palate.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee Honey Creek Pale Ale
column5: Date: 06/25/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Milwaukee clear amber, wispy dirty white head, spidery lace, light citrus aroma, cirtus hop flavor with a robuts bitter following, a touch of sweetness from some caramel malts, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20 Rating: 3.1/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Subtle popcorn nose. Cloudy ochre, thin head, good lace. Milk chocolate, wood. Dried leaves are dominant. Medium body, easy carbonation.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Tasted at RB in Arlington. Color is opaque brownish red. Aroma is fruityy, sweet, malty. Taste is sweet malt, honey, touch of bitter hops on the finish. Not a bad intro craft beer, but that is all it is.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Draught at the campbell location. 5.8%abv, and they call it an ESB. The character is definitely English leaning (caramel, toffee, earthy) but American ESBs are pretty much ambers anyway. I’m wondering if other locations are hopping this in a more American fashion, because I didn’t get any of the American hop character, or much at all, that other raters seem to notice at other locations. The color is an amber-red, topped by lasting white foam with small bubbles. The aroma has a touch of dark, roasted caramel, sweeter caramel, and an earthy touch. Malty-sweet flavor with caramel and toffee, and just a touch of earthy hop flavor and bitterness that doesn’t quite balance. Medium bodied with smooth carbonation. Sweet, relatively clean, and displaying a pretty English malt and hop profile, though the yeast seems pretty neutral. A few more IBUs or a few less finishing gravity points would really make this a more balanced, drinkable package. Well-brewed, but the recipe just isn’t what I would want.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Clear orange pour with a thin white head. Mild piny hop aroma. Sweet malty flavor with touch of citrus and some hops. Mostly bland and watery.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Amber with thin head that disappated quickly. Little to no aroma. Toasty sweet with a bit of a hop bite and slightly astringent. Palate is average. On tap at RB, Indianapolis.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Location: I venture into the Rock Bottom Bethesda every now and again because it is so close, this is one of their standard offerings, and I’ve had it a few times on tap Overall Impression: I actually think that this one is the best of their standard offerings. For it’s style it’s at lease a solid C, while the rest of the Rock Bottom Bethesda always available beers , in my opinion, are at best D+ beers. It is a little thin though.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Tap at Bethesda location. Amber color, caramel malt on the aroma, caramel malt and mild English-style hops on the flavor. Body a little light. Nothing special, just an amber/red ale.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: draft at the downtown Indy brewpub - Pours amber and laces well. It has a light caramel malt aroma. The flavor is sweet caramel malt with some mild hops. It has a light body and light carbonation. It’s an average session brew, no more.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: From draught sample at Bethesda. Light hoppy aroma with just a bit of dull herbal hops. Not very aromatic. Medium amber with light haze and small off-white head. Medium-light watery body with medium carbonation. Starts with carbonic acidity an a bit of pale malt. Neutral fruity character before a heavy hit of hop bitterness. Bitter is too harsh in the finish and is not balanced. Astringent after.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: A nicely refreshing amber, tasting of caramel with nuts and dark fruit. Good side to a burger.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Charlotte NC Prospector’s Pilsner-on tap-pours a creamy white head with yellow color. Aroma is sweet grain, faint hops. Taste is sweet grain, faint hops, dry, distinct biting hop finish. Nice.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: On tap at Arlington location, 11/17/05, listed at 6.0% abv. Light golden, short head, good lacing. Aroma is sweet with a warm hop. Not much detectable Saaz hop in this version - just lots and lots of Hallertau. Taste was sugary sweet malts and a warm bitter finish. I was hoping for something more exciting on this one.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Not bad for a pils, this was one was very light, but sweet, creamy and sweet, and refreshing.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: light gold color. large head. has a slightly malty flavor with a bitter aftertaste. it's aight.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Yellow appearance with a large head. Flavor is slightly bitter with a citrus flavor. Pretty good for a pilsner.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Draft, Chicago At the downtown Rock Bottom, they named it “Rooftop Pilsner” for its rooftop dining area (with a fine view of all the much taller yuppie condos surrounding it). They had to brew this in a hurry following the May windstorm that blew their rooftop taps open, draining all of their serving tanks! Pretty good for a style which we've all had bad examples of. Have to give a "5" for appearance, it looks just right. Fizzy head leaves a golden yellow color underneath. No off-flaveors to speak of. Nice citrsy hop aroma which I found to be a little stronger after a scoop of salsa. As the Milwaukee corrspondent notes, a decent session beer.

12oz bottle. Clear dark brown with a full beige head. Nice coffee and chocolate nose. Smooth texture. More dark chocolate flavors, roasted malt, black coffee. Light-medium bodied, lingering smooth finish.
Bottle. Aroma of roasted grain coffee. Nicely malty toasted grain, coffee, clean finish. Fine porter.

Draft at Palmetto, May 2015. Head is mostly diminishing. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma is moderately malty (Oreo cookie, chocolate, roasted grain), with a note of vanilla. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation. Quite a tasty stout/porter...one of the better of four brews I tried here.
Only had 2oz worth at world beer festival January 2013 Columbia,SC,, smells like coffee, ok... but a bit heavy

Originally reviewed: 8/27/09. Poured into my pint glass a deep charcoal black with a thin tan head on top. This doesn’t stick around very long, but it leaves some sticky lace rings in its wake. Smells very roasty, with a big presence of chocolate and hints of coffee. This smells warming and pleasant. The mouth is little too carbonated than my liking for the style, but it’s decent enough. There’s a subtle twang at the first sip. Slightly acrid and, some might say, sour. This washes away though and is replaced by a big black coffee-like bitterness that hits the spot. Finishes with a nice toasted flavor on the mouth. This is a pretty good porter. I’m glad I had the opportunity to try it!
From Charleston Beer Exchange. Light brown with little head. Aroma is coco and roasted nuts. Flavor is chocolate and coffee. Toasty finish. Really great. Blows their other beers out of the water!
I like porters but this one was lacking. The malts are okay. The hops are lacking. The aromas are not too strong. This is a good local brew but not my cup of tea.
Black pour with tan head. Unique scent, lot going on in here, smoke, coffee, burning wood.....Roasted malt taste is very good and like the scent...unique.....tasty brew.

12oz bottle brought back by a friend. Dark brown pour with a medium tan head. Malty aroma with chocolate and roasty coffee. Coffee flavor up front with sweet malt, chocolate and a roasty finish. Light colored pour made me think it would be weak, but it’s a solid porter.

Pours a deep very dark chestnut brown almosr black color with dark mahognay edges when held to a light source and a 1.5 finger foamy beige head thar quickly dissipates into a lasting ring and cap leaving minimal lacing. Smokey roasted malt aroma with chocolate, caramel, hazelnut, oatmeal, toffee, coffee bean and burnt toast notes. Medium body with a huge smoked/roasty malt presence. Chocolate malt, oatmeal, toffee, espresso beans are all very prominent in the flavor with subtle hops and a nice hazelnut and lactic caramel taste. This is a pretty complex beer for the style and is very well balanced. Roasty and sweet with a nice bitter dry finish. Extremely quaffable.
THIS is the only beer i actually dumped down the drain. And I drink crap like Ol’English all the time.
EEWY EEWY yuck sicky woo-woo! grodyyyyy!!!!!! Notes of barley, and dispair.

Yeah, this isn’t really a real rating, but I can remember enough about this one to make some comments. Used to drink Rainier from time to time, and at a party we had Rainier Ice once, and it make everyone absolutely sick who drank it... has the worst rotting broccoli and fuel smell and taste ever. Completely disgusting.
A light corney lager, highly carbonated, sick as it warms, but actually drinkable cold. suck a few down, and you can be in trouble! lol
Pours a light golden yellow. Aromas of minor hops, corn, grains. Flavor is light, crisp, watery with a little hop and not much else.
The hotter the day and the colder your RI, the more you will appreciate it.

This is the beer of choice for those of us here in the Northwest that are short on cash and ready to partake in a night of drinking games. The "Ren-Wah" Ice is truly a beer you need to drink cold. At low temperatures it is simply thin grains, corn, alchohol, and water. As it warms the corn turns into a funky rotten conglomeration and it is just no good anymore (no not-so-good anymore). Better than the Ale, worse than the regular.

A poor attempt at the popular ice beer process. The one I had in the US on the week end was 6%ABV not 5.8%. Still this beer bore no resemblance to a Rainier that had been but in the ice filter...this is a distinctly different recipe from Rainer....and not a particularly good one. Poured a pale straw color (for an ice beer) and had a small cap that went away fast to reveal carbonation that puts that distinctly cheap sweetness of adjuncts in your nostrils. The beer was smooth but I had a time determining any character to it....sweetly malty with no proper hop balance. I’ll give this one a pass.
Not to great of a taste, its an ok beer wouldn't get it again, its only 5.6 which is low for an ice beer. not my first choice.
Looks like a Safeway brand soda! It's cheap and drinkable!..................

column1: Lake Tahoe Meeks Bay Blonde Ale
column5: If you like light beer, you'll like this one. Smooth easy to drink, session beer. Not bad.

column1: Lake Tahoe Meeks Bay Blonde Ale
column5: This beer is a nice thirst quencher after skiing on the lake or hiking in the mountains. Not much of an aroma, even in the bland desert air. The color is a very, very pale straw (looks like a filtered hefe weizen). The flavor was just slightly malty and barely hopped. Pretty thin. The finish was crisp and clean, like a good pilsener. Lawnmower beer.

column1: Lake Tahoe Emerald Bay Pale Ale
column5: I got a bomber of this while in Reno, July of 2008. The body is dark bronze orange with a thick, lightly off white head. The aroma has some grapefruit and almonds. There is also a nice bread crust note. The taste has some rich grapefruit and bread crust. There is also a nice grassy note that is pleasant in the finsh. Not that Lake Tahoe Brewing made great stuff, but I enjoyed the little bit that I tried. I hope that the brewers and quipment have gone on to bigger and better things.

column1: Lake Tahoe Emerald Bay Pale Ale
column5: Resiney and grapefruity in the aroma. Pours blonde with no head. Much less hoppy than the aroma, very mild flavor. great session pale ale, with some pine and citrus flavors.

column1: Lake Tahoe Emerald Bay Pale Ale
column5: Bottle, with label as pictured, but from Citrus Hts CA. Very light amber with a big ol’ head. Quite the citrusy aroma. But it drinks with more of a tilt toward earthy grassiness, with just a twinge of the citric bite. Relatively light body. OK. (#3393, 4/9/2008)

column1: Lake Tahoe Emerald Bay Pale Ale
column5: Brewed in Citrus Heights, CA. Perhaps at the Sac Brew Oasis? "Tahoe’s backyard, bar-b-que, skateboarding beer" on the label. Very strong aroma of pine. Amber golden color with a very frothy white head. A bit thin in body with smooth, but sharpish carbonation. Flavor is roasted malt with a mixed citrus/pine aspect for hop. Pretty hoppy in a soft way. Finish is almost sweet with floral aspects. It drinks very well.

column1: Lake Tahoe Emerald Bay Pale Ale
column5: (Draft. 03.2006). Light, malty aroma with a hint of grassy and citrus hoppiness. Small white head. Orange. Relatively malty with a citrusy hop note in the background. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Very smooth in the end.

column1: Lake Tahoe Emerald Bay Pale Ale
column5: On tap. Smallish head, pancake ready to turn. White. Fair lacing, golden, clear slighltly darker than golden body. Light aroma(hard to pick out at bar) of sweetish hops with citrus and yeast being dominant. Front is lightly sweet with strong pine-yeast hops like pine nuts and a smoothe, semi-bitter aftertaste, balanced by nice hops. Nice body, smoothish carbonation, fairly typical of the style. Characteristic of the bremasters preferences: strong yeast, well balanced hops and very unique flavor. Easy drinking.

column1: Lake Tahoe Emerald Bay Pale Ale
column5: A very light pale ale, and a very good one. Almost a sweet tasting hoppy beer. Not much aroma, but still very good.

column1: Lake Tahoe Emerald Bay Pale Ale
column5: ATTENTION HOPHEADS!! Nice beer. Very well-hopped. The commercial description suffices except that a "well-balanced hop finish" seems like an oxymoron. This beer is wonderfully unbalanced. It’s an IPA in my book. ’Nuff said.

column1: Lake Tahoe Summer India Pale Ale
column5: This beer rocks. A lovely, clear copper hue. I wanted to hold my pint glass up to the sun and take a picture. This beer is wonderfully unbalanced. The front is slightly sweet and then... BANG... the hops hit you right in the face (and nose). This ale cleared my sinuses. Very complex flavor and finish. First sweet, then bitter, then it sucks all moisture right out of your mouth. This ale is a HopHeads wet dream. I love it.
Rating from memory. Pretty typical honey brown ale, sweet with some light malt flavours.

Mousse consistante de couleur caramel, et breuvage cuivré qui semble pétiller de façon régulière. Mi-mince. Nez de bois, caramel, sucre cuit et quelques épices douces. Assez odorante et invitante. Bien sucrée, miel très présent mais agréable. Houblon, malt grillé. Piquante par effervescence. Agréable, sans être une boisson effarante, la Honey Brown présente de belles qualités dans une catégorie saturée et souvent décevante. Belle couleur, goût intéressant ; un côté plus fonceur, moins « lager + miel » pourrait la remonter encore d’un cran.

bread, toast, hay, grass, red, brown, clear, minimal head, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, creamy, average carbonation, bitter A reddish brown pour with very little foam. A nutty/sweet aroma with some grass. More on the sweet side with mildly bitter toast/nutty lingering. Quite thin in body with medium carbonation and a light bitterness that lingers.
Goût de miel peu présent et peu sucrée. Arôme de miel. Une bière se buvant bien et probablement la meilleure de la famille Rickard’s.

Originally rated July 2005. This honey brown from Rickard’s pours a brown colour with orange highlights. The head does not last as long as their pale and red. Lacing is not bad. The scent is of caramel malt with some floral notes. The taste though, is very smooth... almost missing. Ah... found it ! It’s in the background. Not much there, slight bitterness and sweetness. Hardly any aftertaste. Close of being refreshing.

341ml bottle pours a light brown color white a 2 finger white head that leaves a few specks of lacing. Aroma is light caramel malts and faint hops. Taste is light caramel malty sweetness with a clean hoppy bitter finish. Slightly below average for the style.
341ml bottle. Clear light brown. Not much honey taste, but still decent. I see why they replaced this with the Dark in the variety packs.
Bottle. Brown, not very sweet. An attempt to tap into the Sleeman’s market. Bland but drinkable.
Bouteille 341 ml. En fût. Belle couleur brune miel. Arôme légèrement sucrée. Elle est une bonne variante douce à la Rickard’s Red. Très bonne bière de soif.

Light brown body, with a pretty good light caramel head. Smells of sour dough, some slight roastiness and honey. Tastes pretty good, with a balanced sweetness and some caramel notes. There is some unpleasant sourness to it, though. Pretty soft on the palate; light-to-medium body to it. Overall, this WAS the best of the Rickard’s line-up, so it’s somewhat sad that they discontinued it...
Draft - Very light caramel malts. Clear amber with a thin head. Light malty caramel and a light toffee finish. Very light and easy drinking.

Where and how: on tap at brewpub Aroma sweet malty, worty feel ith slight grassy hop elements. Appearance : Top: lighter white top. Base: clear amber. Palate : straight, soft bodied, almost oily, soft carbonation. Taste: malty feel, touch of berry like sweetness. Mild notch of honey other notes decent.

Pale amber pour with a tight white head. The nose is fairly hoppy. Goldings type aroma. Spicy and a little bit earthy. Some lingering bitterness. Crackery malts and a little bit of light toasted malt. Lovely really. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Barley Works. Clear deep amber, with a thin head. Mild aroma of caramel, with some slight hops. The taste starts sweet and fruity, gets bready and creamy, and has a clean, slightly metallic finish. Smooth mouthfeel. Not bad, as the ratebeer score would lead me to believe.

Pour copper orange with white head. Aroma heavy grain, bread, adjunct, honey, fruitiness, sweet. Taste fruity, sweet, adjunct, grain. MF thin to medium body highly over carbed. Meh better then some I guess. Would’ve never guessed this to be a English pale ale.
On tap at the Heuther Hotel. Pours light brown in colour, not much head. Thin body. Aroma and taste are moderately malty, not much bitterness here. Not bad at all.

On tap at the brewpub, amber-copper color, with a beige head, light toasty, caramel, biscuity malt, buttery nose with some fruity hints of honeyed caramelized stewed apples and faint nuttiness in the aroma follows through on a light-bodied palate with toasted, biscuity malt, fruity character of stewed apples, and with a faint flowery hop leafy accent, leading towards a malty, fruity, lingering hop bitterness finish.

Draught. Pours a watery coppery brown. Fairly sweet with a little bit of malts.. very thin mouth feel with the malt dominatign the hops.. a little bit of nutty favour in the finish. decent while there, but not retail quality

Draught at the brewpub. Pours a clear golden-orange with a small lasting creamy white head. Aroma’s quite mild, malty along with some grain, Flavour: Not bad, it’s malty with a good amount of hops and some fruit. Decent light bitter finish. Average bodied. A pleasant Ale and a nice surprise.

Draught. At the brewpub. Clear light amber with an average white draught head. Herbal/grainy aroma, light alcohol - clean. The taste is pleasingly bitter, decent roast caramel malt and more than enough dry herbal bitterness to balance it. Slick, lively mouthfeel - decent carbonation and a reasonably long bitter finish - not overpowering, or memorable, but of all the beers I tried (8) during my visit, this is the only one I would bother to have a pint of.

Not really a distinct brew but a metered blend done at the taps of 2 ales and a light lager. This tap head blend had the effect of approximating a cream ale in appearance and flavor. I’m told by brewers that mixing 3 penny pale ales with a lager at colonial taverns was how this style got started before it was brewed as a discrete style. Malty, lightly hopped, light and mild. Good sessioner with no "off" tastes as some early reviews note.

(Draught) I was assured by our server that this was not the Raspberry Cream Ale even throught the flavour was very berry flavoured. Little aroma. High carbonation, thin white head and a gold body. Cream soda flavour with a berry finish.
Jan 2001: I enjoyed this one. Not much aroma, small head. Body on the thinnish side, but not bad. Compared favourably to Sleeman's Cream ale, one of the few I had had at the time.
Very smooth and creamy.....nice tasting.....................................
Pale straw yellow w/ slight head.Hardly any aroma. Thin body. Flavorless and watery. Slight graininess w/ little bitterness.
Light, perfumy tasting. Presence of the vile weed detected.................
Draft - Light grains and light skunk. Clear gold with a rich beige head. Light malts and some grain. Not too sweet which is nice with enough malt for flavor.

Where and how: on tap at brewpub Aroma soft, mild , mellow golden malt. Lacking hints of noble hops. Appearance : Top: lighter short lived. Base: amber gold, tad too dark for style. Palate : soft mid , proper level of carbonation. Taste: toasty grainy front, proper malt feel but felt tad too thin, washed-out. other notes it would benefit if it had heavier bend on Munich malt as it has good basics to be very nice.
Full bodied lager. Had many a good time drinking it. A solid choice for any season. The best from the Lion Brewery.
Pours a murky brown colour, nose is sweet and malty. Flavour is malty but muddled. Odd beer ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Fairly clean golden pour. The aroma is malty and clean. Bready Vienna-style malt aroma and a little bit of light herbal malt as well. Clean finish with a lingering breadiness. Light but not watery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pour golden yellow with white fizzy head. Super sweet smell grain and sugar. Taste malt forward slightly grassy bitterness. Medium body medium carb. Meh aside from smell alright.
On tap. Pours clear golden yellow. Slightly darker than the lion lager. OK. Kind of flat.

On tap at the brewpub, honey blonde color, with a frothy white head, leaving some laces, mild honeyed pale, toasted, biscuity malt nose, with a note of diacetyl, and some light grainy sweetness in the aroma follows through on a light-bodied palate with a nice grainy honeyed pale, toasty malt, buttery character with a wet flowery hop leafy, grassy note, leading towards a malty, fruity, buttery finish.

Draught at the brewpub. Pours a clear gold with an average size creamy white head. Aroma’s quite mild, with some sweetness, very light grassy hops and perhaps some fruit -- it’s hard to gauge. Flavour’s clean and there’s nothing bad but there’s not much going on either: Watery with some grain and very light hops. Average bodied. A just O.K. Lager.

Draught. At the brewpub. Clear, slightly oily-looking gold with a small white creamy head. Some alcohol in the aroma, solidly grassy-bitter, fresh grain. Taste of dry, almost harsh grain - straw-like - with a decent amount of grassy bitterness - not sweet, but chewy; decently carbonated, with a solid malty fninsh - sure isn’t a pale lager, quite decent.
Draft - Light grains and pale malts. Clear copper with a rich white head. Pale malts, light toasted grains and not much else.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a darkish-but-not-really amber with a small white head. Aroma is the characteristic malty sweetness of this brewery. Flavour has some nice richness to it from the honey, which is not overly-sweet or cloying. Along with the worty grainy malt character in all of their beers. Crisp, fairly well carbonated palate that at times seemed a little rough. Not my favourite from this place but still pretty decent. Surprised I hadn’t tried it until now.

On tap at the brewpub, Copper color, with a creamy beige head, yeasty, fruity, honeyed, grainy toasted, pale, biscuity malt nose, with some hints of spongetoffee and cookie dough, with a faint honey coated apple note in the aroma follows through on a light-bodied palate with a smooth, yeasty, spicy, honeyed toasted, caramel malt character with a fruity flavour of ripe apples, leading towards a fruity, toasty, lingering hop bitterness finish.

Draught. Caramel candy, artificial honey and sweet malt are in the faint nose. Pours an amber color. Like their other beers its thin and a little watery. More hops then I would have expected in a honey brown. Not a good example of the style, like a generic with honey forced into it.

On tap at the brewpub. Looks nice - amber, good sized white head. Aroma of honey and some malt. Taste is right on style if Honey brown was a style - it is malty (for a lager) with lots of honey. Unfortunately, I’ve never found it a a particularly good combination in any beer. Light body. Ok at best, will not have it again.

Tap at the hotel- Pours an amber liquid. Head is thin and short lived, leaving no real lace. Malty nose, with grains and a bit of burnt sugars, followed by some cookie dough. Tastes of sweet honey (perhaps too much so) some cereal, burnt sugars and wood. A bit too sweet on the finish, but this is ok made and better than I expected.

Dark golden colour. Head is white and disapates to a little bit of nothing. No real fancy lacing just tiny little bubbles that one by one go away. Aroma might be honey then again it might be malt. Flavour is sweet malty and clean. Palate is clean with nothing to syrupy. But there is a nagging cloying sweetness to this.

[360-20070623] Tap @ Lion Restaurant (Waterloo, ON). Some yeast, some sweetness in the aroma. Clear, honey brown body with no lasting head. Honey-esque lager sweetness in the flavour has some yeast. Medium body. Not bad for a honey brown.

Tapped a light copper-amber color, smallish head leaves soon, leaves light lace on the glass. Aroma of grains, hay and a light whisp of honey...no sweet tones. Light body, slick mouth feel, fluid chracter. Strange flavor profile for a honey lager: You’re hit up front with caramel sweetness and can just taste the honey when a sourish woodsy tang kicks in as the abundent hops take over. Hops continue to dominate the flavor through to the quick clean finish where it turns softly bitter....a different honey beer to be sure, no flaws just too well hopped to enjoy the honey
One of the worst honey browns I have ever tasted. Tried it once thought it must be skunky, since I had heard good things. Tried it a second time a few months later, still terrible.

Pale straw colour with a thick white head. The nose is bready and fairly herbal as well. Pretty fresh pils malt base along with a clean hop finish. Much cleaner and better than the previous ratings would suggest. Solid Helles lager actually. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught. At the brewpub. Light gold with a small white head. Weak floral/grassy aroma, vaguely yeasty and sweet - not much there, really. Taste is decent enough - clean, grassy, grainy-sweet; light. Light body, not much carbonation, quick-finishing - not much to say, nothing wrong with it, just boring.

[1913-20081220] Tap. Yeasty bread crumbs aroma. Clear, light orange yellow body with a medium-lasting creamy white head. Creamy yeast bread continues in the flavour with a soft doughiness and mild bitterness. Medium body. Quite yeasty. (@ the Huether; Waterloo, ON)

On tap at the brewpub. Medium yellow, small white head, lots of streaming bubbles. House yeast aroma, light malt. Taste has a decent amount of malt, very light and well carbonated mouthfeel and more of the house taste - which is a very fresh, clean if slightly bland taste. Some hops in the finish. A fine clean lager without much to really write about.
Served in a chilled glass at the brewpub. Hit the spot on a hot day but im sure anything would have. Light yellow with a light frothy head. A little bitter but overall not a bad beer

on tap at the brewpub. served pale yellow with a small everlasting white head. served in a frozen glass at near sub-zero temprature so my aroma rating might but a little low. very similar to the other lager from this brewer. malt driven with some hop bitterness. good stuff after a round off golf. thx to chops for buying me a pint!

On tap at the brewpub on my 20th birthday. Pale golden colour with a medium sized white head. Meh, not a standout lager by any means, but still enjoyable. On par with every other generic lager made in Ontario right now. Almost a decent hoppy finish, slightly peppery. Well worth the money but probably nothing I’ll go nuts for in the future.

Pours a sparkling gold, with almost a bit of a haze. Head is foamy and full. Grassy hoppy nose with good floral presence and fruity malts. Sweet grainy flavour with fruity malts and a floral hop bite. Spritzy, assertive finish. Decent lager, though I’m not sure why some of the others are better than the "premium".
Poured with a decent size head. Maltier than their macro lager and about as unsatisfying. Faint hop. Watery.Some carbonation. Bland

Tapped a pale clear gold with a small 1 finger cap which does not last too long...some lacing left on glass. Sweet carastan malts and light hay in the nose. Medium bodied. Modest malt spine, peppery clean mouthfeel. Sweetand grainy upfront then a light lemmony decernment from balanced hopping followed by a fast clean finish with little aftertaste. Your basic non-descript all malt commercial lager.

On tap at the brewpub, pale yellow color, with an of-white heaf, light toasted, pale malt, honeyed nose with a subtle floral hop grassy accent in the aroma follows through on a light-bodied palate with a crisp citrusy, light pale malt character with a faint flowery hop lemony, grassy undertones, leading towards a very light lingering hop bitterness finish. So tasteless!!!!

At the brewpub. Yellow pout, small white head. Slightly sweet bready aroma - the first aroma from these guys that was sort of fake corny to be honest. Taste was better - it could have passed for any of their house beers, so that is a credit in terms of flavour to this light lager. Bready not grassy, slight sweetness, medium mouthfeel. It was refreshing enough with brunch but not packing a ton of flavour. Still, in terms of light beers, it was exceptional.

Not really my favorite Lion quaff but as a light ale it was remarkably fresh and malty. Clear straw color, white cap, well carbonated. Light biscuity aroma not much else. Light body biscuity, mild hopping lightly drt and a fast clean finish. One dimensional but fresh tasting.

[1091-20080211] Tap @ Lion brewpub (Waterloo, ON). Light and fresh yeasty bread aroma. Clear, pale yellow body with a long-lasting foamy white head, lots of bubbles throughout and thick white lacing. Nice yeasty bread flavours but otherwise bland. Light body. A surprisingly nice light beer, good blend.

On tap at the Hotel- Pale yellow pour, topped with a thin white cap. Grainy, fruity nose mostly compromised of apples and a touch of pear. The flavour profile is weak but clean. Apples and sweet pale malts with a touch of leafy hops and grass. A bit watery on the finish, but all things considered, pretty well made.
Light pale yellow with a wee head. Creamy, easy to drink, with a toasty aftertaste. Suprisingly, really enjoyed this.
(Draught) Pours a thin, white head and pale gold body. Grassy nose that passes into the flavour. Bitter finish. Not bad for a light beer...

Pale golden yellow. Small white head. Disipated fast. Nothing in aroma but slight malt and grass. Almost a slight grassiness in flavour. More full flavoured then most macro styled American Light beers I've sampled. Sweet malty and bitter.

2008-02-11. Draft at the brewpub. Yellow body with a small white head, excellent lacing. (3+) Mild floral hop aroma is pleasant. Mild bitterness, floral character returns, sweet lightly doughy malt. Average to light smooth palate. Surprisingly full flavoured, I wondered if they had swapped it with the Lion Lager on the sampler! 6+/3/6/3/13 - 3.1 Jan 2001: Don’t expect much from a light beer. It was better than macro lights, but not much. 4/3/4/2/8 - 2.1
Large white head. Clean finish. Ok for a light..............................
Draft - Light toasted malts. Deep mahogany with a rich beige head. Toasted malts and toffee. Really flavorful and easy drinking.

Where and how: on tap at brewpub Aroma mild roast, slightly nutty hints, accented by chocolate and toasted barley. Appearance : Top: neatly contrasting cap. Base: dark brown. Palate : soft bodied, fine carbonation. Taste: mild, easy going pub ale. Quiet old school in approach.
Draught. Deep red colour, no head. Aroma of light malts, some fruit. Taste is light, soft hops, well balanced. Decent beer.

Deep brown pour with a creamy tan head. The nose is cocoaish and chocolatey with a touch of earthiness as well. Nice toasty malt with a touch of herbal/cocoaish malt. A little bit of lingering bitterness. Solid brown ale. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at the restaurant. A deep dark brown. Not much aroma to speak of. Taste is nicely balanced - smooth, creamy, and roasty. Definitely my favourite of their brews.

On tap at the brewpub, dark brown-copper color, with a creamy beige head, mild honeyed toasted, caramelized, roasted malt nose with some faint dark dried fruit accents of rainsins, figs, dates and some cookie dough, mild brown chocoalte notes in the aroma follows through a medium-bodied palate with a sweet biscuity, toasty, roasted malt character, with a mild coffeeish flavour, and some toffee, cookie dough undertones, leading towards a toasty, fruity, raisiny, faint roasty bitterness finish. This is more balanced beer of all their beers

On tap at the Huether. Nice deep dark reddish brown with a medium khaki head. Aroma is of grains, sweet dark malts, tiny hint of mocha. Indistinct. Flavour is quite nice, roasty malts meet the signature grainy sweet flavour of all this brewpub’s beers. Finishes balanced with some lingering barley tastyness. Great session brew. This was very enjoyable and along with the Wuerzburger the best thing they make in my opinion.

Draught at the brewpub. Pours a deep amber with a spare creamy tan head. Aroma’s sweet, a bit sour and lightly roasty. Watery flavour is also a bit sour (is it off?), lightly roasted and with some fruit. Average bodied. Just passable.

Draught. At the brewpub. This is on tap, so it can’t be OLD, but ... read on. Deep clear mahogany pour, with a smallish creamy beige head (4-). Oddly sour caramel malt/grain aroma, a touch herbal, even a hint of dry cocoa. Taste - weirdly sour, grapeseed, dry oak and lemon juice sour, a bit like those oxidized old Gales corked bottles - but this is TAP; some coffee ground acidity and green herbal (almost mint) bitterness under the unpleasant sourness. Average-bodied, astringent/acidic mouthfeel, very weakly carbonated, with a thin, dry lemon-sour aftertaste - it wasn’t horrid, but I think without the dry tartness it might be solid. (not boozy at all, but also, not very roasty either).

Pint at he brewpub. Dark brown, small white head. Mild aroma (as most were here) - some toasty malt, some roast. Taste is nice - lots of solid roast and malt, good light to medium body, very easy to drink. Not complex but a nicely done. A solid brown ale.

A lack luster seasonal...not because of the fruit...which was real...but because of the weak cream ale under it. Cream ale should have some substance to it but the light ale they used as a base on this was weak bodied and watery.

Their current seasonal. Too sweet, from concentrate. Kind of a girlie pink drink, nothing personal to those that like it. Candy artificial raspberry flavouring aroma and taste, watery. A good head. I think there was beer in there, bit it was disguised by the sweet flavouring,
Hazy light yellow appearance. Surprisingly sweet and untart (if you will) even after the waitress politely reassured me that is was in fact made with real fruit and not a concentrated fruit juice.
I think this beer should be in the "bargain beer" catagory. Tastes stale and tinny. Barely passable grade.
Huge bottle. Light brown, small of white head. The aroma is sweet of butter, and the flavor is malty.
Bottle - Caramel and some twiggy bitterness. Clear copper with no head. Caramel and light bitterness. Decent.

680 mL bottle. Pours medium amber with an off white head. Some caramel malt and a possible suggestion of hops. Flavorless and watery. Light bodied with above average carbonation. At least it’s not macro.

Clear copper colour. Malty aroma with some earthy notes that I don’t enjoy, yeasty funky like. Medium to light body and a watery mid palate and a finish that doesn’t have much to offer. Boring brewery and one that is part of the ’ol guard’ providing swill to the few that come by this brewery.
Bottle at CGBD. Pours copper with an off white head. Sweet toffee malts, light grain, light earthy notes, and a faint hoppy finish. Not bad.

Nothing special but it was an ok pint of beer, was better then all the other Macro beers that was on tap at the pub. Nothing bad about it but nothing great either. As far as craft beers go however the brewery is lacking compared to what many other micro brewery’s in the Ontario region are brewing, they need some new beers once and a while, brewery is a bit boring.
On tap. Light amber with a creamy biege head. Inofensive light malt and hop aroma, bit of stale caramel, little sweet. Moderate carbonation, mild body, some honey, not great but not terrible.
Not worth your time, like most old credit stuff its below what you’d expect from a craft brewer.
Clear red pour with a thin head that fades quick. Aroma is full of syrupy caramel. Taste is mild. Hints of caramel and sugar. Slightly estery. Very light mouth. Slightly astringent.

Bottle from LCBO at Royal Winter Fair in Toronto. This was the only beer -- plus a couple of ciders -- from their sample Ontario selection that I hadn’t tried. Wish I hadn’t bought it. This is a sweet corn water pale lager of the most banal kind. It’s a farce to call this a pilsner. Tastes like watery apple juice, water from a can of sweet peas & melted margarine. Shudder.
Pours golden with quickly dissipating head. Clean pilsner malty taste with appropriate hoppiness. Nice smooth aged flavour.
Not sure why this is rated so low. Sure it’s not a trendy style but this was a pretty legit pilsner in my opinion.
On tap at Jack & Lois, in Hamilton. Pours a clear golden colour with a small white head. Aroma is malt, bread, straw, some apples. Taste is similar. Refreshing summer beer.

680ml bottle from LCBO. 5% alc./vol. Pours a clear golden colour with a minimal white head which recedes to a small outer ring. Aroma of hay, bread, and some apples. Taste is just like your average Pilsner with light sweet flavour. It's a notch better than your Molson Canadian or Bud.

Bottle. Sweet pilsner malt aroma with light noble hops and a little stone fruit. Clear straw under wisps of large, white bubbles. Sweet pilsner malt flavour with very low zesty noble hops and a little sour grain accent. Medium light body, medium carbonation, almost crisp.
Bottled sample from Ribeye Jacks in Streetsville. Was pleasantly surprised with this one. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, shared with Parksy, Grippitis, JJ. Medium golden, a little hazy, rapidly receding head. Sweet grainy aroma and flavour, a bit of corn, a bit of apple, odd chemical/preservative note in the finish. Not good.
Bottle - Pale malts and light apple. Fizzy yellow with a decent white head. Sweet apple and grains, Sweet and fizzy.

680 mL bottle. Very pale with a thin white cap and no lacing. Mild pilsner malt and the faintest note of hops. Has an odd sweetness. Light bodied and moderate plus carbonation. Not flawed, but painfully boring.
Swillfest ’04: Dark golden-brown. Slightly rocky head. Palate is slightly chalky, very sweet. Awful plastic notes and artificial caramel. Shit, Lakeport really is one of the worst breweries on earth.
Tea color , creamy head . Plain sweet aroma. Light in flavour, especially for dark lager. Slightly mineral finish.
(Bottle) Deep brown body with a thin, almond head. Faint Corn syrup aroma. Thin, sugar water taste. Better than the regular but poor overall.

This is the only good thing on the Brava line up. Dark brown with a very light brown head that didn't disappear. To my surprise. Sweet sugar water. And water on the palet. Not very appealing. A step up from the other Brava products but I would still avoid it.
Clear dark brown w/ slight beige head. Mild corn aroma. Watery feel. Roasted cardboard and corn aroma.
Light brown appearance. Light sweet malty nose, slightly skunked (I wonder why?) Dry, faint malt presence. Maybe a step up from Brava...maybe.

(drain pour and ticks’ night) pours clear straw with a very small white head, no retention. skunky and corny, absent malts, almost absent hops if not some herbal blandness. average carbonation, light body - watery. bad like its big sister.

Father inlaws brother brought some to easter! Yay! "hey Rob, would you like a Brava Light? " "would i, hell yeah!" this was quite the foray into light beer territory. Good god, this is nothing but a mash of corn, and cheapo grains, with some grass included. Well atleast it tasted like slmething. Nice to see they were able to get rid of that pesky aftertase and finish that i know everyone hates. Awesome stuff!

Originally rated June 2009. Well, Lakeport has re-released this Light version of the Brava (they had a few years back). At The Beer Store, it is highly advertised and they are pushing on it for this summer (2009). This info is probably the best thing of this review... ha, ha. Pours a pale golden colour with a white fizzy-foam head that does not stay long and hardly has lacing. Big bubbles are all around the glass, so quite fizzy. Malt piss nose with a little corn taste, but also, this chemical aftertaste of raw sewage. Almost like vegetables gone bad. It is quite yuckie overall.

It’s a light beer, it’s a discount beer and it’s made by a big beer company. You get what you pay for - its not a beer for beer snobs. If you want a light, clean taste, you got it. Not malty, no aftertaste, no skunky flavour. Easy to drink.

[3559-20110119] 341mL clear bottle. Corn and rotting haystacks aroma. Clear, yellow body with a quick foamy white head. Sweet corny yeast flavour. Light body. Not repeatable, not pleasant. (2/2/2/2/3) 1.1 (w/ jerc)

2011-01-19. Sweet grainy aroma has small hints of skunked hops, light touches of lemon both in a good way and a not so good way. Flavour is pretty mild, and mostly inoffensive. Sweet sort of industrial cereal grains, very slight bitterness. Average to light palate. Less bad than expected, but not particularly endearing either. Bottle from the LCBO
bottle. Clear pale straw coloured. Light corn aroma. Watery mouthfeel. Grainy and bland. No aftertaste.
Smells of corn and adjuncts, straw yellow, tiny white head. Taste is muted corn and rice, light bodied and listless.

Clear bottle 341 ml Appearance: plain pale golden look with light fizzy thin white top 2- Nose: Aroma of cardboard with hone and sugary dust, slight off fruity hints. Flavor/Palate : Very thin bodied. Plain, flat almost flavorless malt expose. Very little going in here and what is present is not very welcoming. Hint of honey mid late. Very slight oily finish. This brew would not win against targeted competition Corona and that says plenty.

Sample from the Beer Store. I don’t think I would have really ever bought this so I was thankfull for the sample that was at the store that helped me save some money if I was ever to buy this. When I drank it the lady asked me what I thought. And I said to her, "Do you really want to know?" She was like, "Ya" and I gave it to her... man was she disappointed. I saw her face go from happy to why are you even here in about 1 second. Pale yellow with no head. Aroma is grainy and shallow. Sweet flavour is really bland and very watery. No aftertaste. Not offensive at all.
not too bad. nothing vile, but nothing outstanding. the honey doesnt come through as well as i would l would like but its ok.

(Bottle) One of the quickest dissipating heads I have experienced - remindes me of ginger ale. Amber body. Nose of spoiled milk and apples - smells almost flat thought there is slight carbonation. Thin, honey flavour with a strong dough finish. Gross!
Light honey nose and flavor with too much alcohol heat for this style. Not much else
Really weak in appearance department, bland look. Very boring brew. To much feel of alcohol for a wheat.
Nutty roasted aroma, golden, a small head. Nicely bitter, not too sweet, pleasant mouthfeel, so so.
this beer is quite similar to the draft, only a bit rounder and overal meatier with a slight honey-ish taste. not bad, but still not great.
As bland and tasteless as anything I've had.................................
Yellow appearance. Light, some hop bitterness in the finish. Not much going on.
Straw and slightly hazy. Wheat aroma and flavour. Eas to drink but lacked any real complimentary flavour like citrus or corrianer.
Draught at the breweryVery pale straw. Quite cloudy. Sweaty, with a hint of wheat. Effervescent, sweaty, and with a good bit of wheaty acidity. Low on phenols/esters, though.

This beer is a classic American amber/red ale that is big on hop aromas, flavors, and bitterness, but also has enough malt sweetness to balance that assault of hops. It is brewed with Centennial, Chinook, and Cascade hops, and then dry hopped with another huge dose of Centennials. These locally grown hop varieties make American IPA’s or pale ales, what they are, but with a red ale, lots of malt is key flavor component to the style. Trailhead Red is brewed with 5 malts including pale, ESB, wheat, crystal, and Munich malts, giving the beer the malt backbone it needs to stand up to all those hops. Trailhead Red pours to a beautiful, deep amber to ruby red color with a thick and creamy light tan head, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is so fresh and aromatic with big citrus aromas of grapefruit and lemon rind, with hints of ripe fruit and sweet malt. The palate is firm on the tongue with lots of big pale and sweet malt flavors paired with some plumy estery fruit flavors, and a nice back drop of candied grapefruit hop flavor. Trailhead Red finishes with more sweet malty, and candied fruit flavors up front, then ends with a zesty burst of grapefruit/lemon hop bitterness that cuts the edge of the sweet maltiness and lingers with bitterness. Trailhead Red is a fantastic example of American Red Ale, and is well worth taking the trek out to Pacific Crest to try fresh on draught. The Hole in the Wall Barbecue brings the experience to a higher level, and for me makes it a trip any beer lover visiting the PNW must make.
Reddish amber with short beige head. aroma is light malt. Flavor is also light malt with very weak hop end.
Washington Brewers Festival. Pale color with good head. Citrus taste with nice hop nose. Hops are very forward and then disappear quickly on the finish. Nice.
pale copper colour with decent size head. Aroma was lemon and hops. Nice hop flavouring with good alt balance. Not overpowering like a lot of IPAs. Nice bitter finish.

Draught at the breweryLight copper colour. Soft body, citric hoppiness. Slightly honeyish malts. Despite a little resiny bitterness in the end, this is a fairly restrained example. But it is balanced so you can’t argue with that.
Had on tap at brewery. Pale orange color, fairly light on carbonation and limited lacing. A little light for an IPA, but good hop flavor. Needs more body.
GABF 2003: Clear orange color, deep pine aroma, bitter ending. I also wrote 'baxy', whatever that means.

This was a draught sampled at the brewery taproom A hop monster which is about typical for a northwestern IPA. A little thin, the hops came more into balance as the brew warmed. Strange that they served it so very cold. A beer that should be more popular in the Seattle area
Thin fast fading head. Decent body. Faint malt with good hop profile........

On draught at the taproom. Color is an attractive orange-amber, but with very thin head--decent lace, however. Aroma is very pleasant, floral and hoppy...Prominent hop profile does not immediately overwhelm the senses but overcomes with relentlessness--dominating all the way through the finish--and beyond! This leaves the front of the tongue aquiver and fills the entire oral cavity with hop essence. Malt is faintly detectable in flavor and offers just enough body to ward off the dreaded "thin" label. The comprehensive effects of the hops on the whole palate are impressive, and the fruity edges also add positively. Hop-heads will like this offering--bracing and fresh.
Dark brown colour with huge foam, took about 5 minutes to settle. Aroma was some cocoa and roasted malt. Flavour is nutty and slightly sweet. A little thin but still enjoyable.
Draught at the breweryNut brown colour. Slightly musty, chocolatey, roasty aroma. The flavour is quite nutty, and sweet with occasional floral notes and toastiness.
Light in body and taste. Was rather disappointed in this one .............
To thin, to dry, not enough body to support the hops. But to fair they served this taproom sample much to cold and I was thirsty and drank it before it warmed up. It may be a better cool not frozen

On draught at the taproom...This has an unfiltered look: hazy yellow-gold color that glows in the glass...unusual...head very light but with lingering lace. Aroma is slightly sweet with a spicy herbal-hop quality. This spicy hop countenance defines the top-end of the flavor spectrum. Light malt sweetness supplies secondary support and lingers throughout the tapered finish. Carbonation is moderate and in spirit with spritely demeanor of this brew. However, the flavors aren't quite all in harmony here...Body is a bit thin, even though this is clearly intended to be a thirst-quencher. Overall, this is not a classic pilsener, but certainly captures the spicy Saaz nip successfully. What this brew lacks in refinement it compensates for somewhat with a degree of rustic charm...
Golden body with minimal head. Some malts in the aroma and a little fruit (citrus). Tastes more like a lager due to the lightness. Didn’t notice a lot of hops.
Draught at the breweryGolden-bronze colour. Crisp, slightly biscuity malt accent. Fruity hop notes. Kolsch-like, which is surprising because it’s not lagered and uses American hops.
From a bottle that likely day for a while. Malty , dusty Aroma. Faintest whiff of floral hops. Too much carbonation and very very boring overall. Oh well...

355 ml bottle as Big Easy Imperial Maibock Lager. Mostly clear orange yellow, off-white foam settles and mostly fades. Malty boozy aroma. Stronger sweet fruity lager malty taste, not too big, easy to quaff. Softer carbonation, medium bodied, low hopped. MLF (More Lagerboy Friendly)
Pretty enjoyable. Medium body amber lager. Bready in quality. Fairly boozy on the nose and in the body. Nice balance without being cloying.
Bottle. Pours a hazy orangish color. Aroma and taste are sweet with caramel and biscuit.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a bright golden color with a huge creamy orange-white head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was sweet, tangy and yeasty with notes of sugar and golden fruit. The flavor was sweet, tangy and yeasty with notes of sugar, golden fruit and a hint of pepper. Medium length finish. Moderately full bodied. Well done.
Clear golden color with modest head. Limited aroma. Leans sweet which is appropriate to style.
Bottle shard with Parksy. Deep golden amber. Husky toasty malts, subtly spicy. True to style, and actually quite good.

Bottle. Pours a clear gold with a slight orange hue and a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has lots of bread with underlying notes of hay and sweet grains. Flavor has notes of earthy grains and bread with hay underlying.

12 oz single bottle from Mile High Wine & Spirits. Light golden-orange and clear appearance with a beige head. Aroma of bread, floral notes, light peppery spice, light citrus and other fruity esters. Similar flavor, strong and malty, lightly sweet and bitter and a touch boozy. Medium body. Pretty mild overall, not a lot going on. Kind of hard to drink after a while, a little messy.

That bocktown monaca is a great place to taste beers. Funny on this one its called big easy but its brewed in wisconsin, heheheh. Good co2 from the start. Fairly clear smell about it. Perhaps a hint of candy on the nose. Fairly light at first but then there is this somthing happening. Some mild bandaid thing. What is this trying to tell me? Was it a purposefully beer to that this way or was it an accident? I’m not sure. yes, is this a maibock or is it a heller? Could be a premium lager as well. Could be a mestake that they just wanted to get outtah here. Finish is a bit difficult and unique fer sure. Hides alky well if its over 5%

THOUGHTS: This was a gift from a coworker, who obviously had a beers of the world case sitting around for a few years and didn’t realize beer can go bad and decided he’d give it to the beer guy of the office. Well it was skunked. I normally won’t rate a skunked beer, but since I don’t think it is made anymore, I will never have the chance to rate it again, I think I will rate it. TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a cloudy, medium to dark dirty yellow with virtually no head that somehow left fair lacing. The aroma was mostly vinegar. The flavor started sweet and finished sour acidic and a little acetic with an average to short duration. There was corn, sweet malt, skunk, dust and metal. The light to medium body was like watery syrup with soft to flat carbonation and a metallic and light to moderate astringent finish.

Nah - not good. Cloudy, dirty yellow color and odd taste. It’s spicy, but not in a good way. Definitely not one of my top picks (or one of my mid-range picks, or even a lower level pick). It’s just plan old not good - down there with Bud and Miller.

(bottle - 12 oz) Slightly cloudy peach color with not much of a head to speak of. Some light dashes of white. The light aroma is kind of sweet. Almost like cotton candy with a hint of grass. Sweet taste of apple juice and some sour hops at the beginning with a watery middle and a warming and semi-bitter hop finish. Slightly sour aftertaste and very thin-bodied.
I tried this, to see. Poured very fizzy with huge head. No aroma? tasted like bud, at first. As it wamed some good tones came out. But stil. Nothing great

I have had worse. Big head initially which goes away just as fast. Aroma of something that I can't place but not that great. Flavor is slightly acidic and very thin. Slight hops finish and is quite dry. An ok lager but can't remember the last time I saw Italians drinking beer with their ziti.
Italian makae wine not beer. Nothing good come from Wilkes Barre especially beer. Stay away and save your money.
At first this beer was not that delicious, but I have quickly warmed to it. I enjoy the delicious taste, although it is too expensive.

A bit fizzy, much like the macro-swill it could be mistaken for. However, when it warms, this beer reveals a character that's hidden when it's ice cold. Sadly, few will taste those flavors, but this is a respectable, family-brewed Italian lager with enough flavor to be respectable.

column1: Santa Rosa Bay Thomas Jefferson Brown Ale
column2: Ft Walton Beach, Florida, United States
column5: Cloudy dark redish-brown, malty caremel nose, full bodied, very impressive ale, this brewerys best ale.

column1: Santa Rosa Bay Lion Pilsener Lager
column2: Ft Walton Beach, Florida, United States

column1: Santa Rosa Bay Lion Pilsener Lager
column2: Ft Walton Beach, Florida, United States

column2: Ft Walton Beach, Florida, United States

column1: Santa Rosa Bay Red Head Ale
column2: Ft Walton Beach, Florida, United States
column5: Dark red and sweet aroma. The taste is sweet and bitter all at once, with a nice citrus bite finish. pretty good.

column1: Santa Rosa Bay Red Head Ale
column2: Ft Walton Beach, Florida, United States
column5: Glowing red-amber color, medium bodied, sweet malty flavor with a crisp hop bite,another good brew from this place.

column1: Santa Rosa Bay American Light Wheat
column2: Ft Walton Beach, Florida, United States
column5: Date: 08/31/1996 Source: Brewpub clean yellow, whispy head, slight fruity aroma, hint of spicy clove flavor on top of a sweet malt base, touch of hop bitter finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.6/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

column1: Santa Rosa Bay American Light Wheat
column2: Ft Walton Beach, Florida, United States
column5: Dark yellow color, weak wheat aroma, watery and very light..................
Mahogany colour with little head. Aroma is malty with a light floral hint. Sweet malty flavour with some wood.
Draught at the breweryDark amber colour. Not much nose - some sort of amber malts, perhaps. Fairly malty flavour, with a brown sugar/wood dynamic, and a hint of citrus in the finish.
On tap at brewpub. Pours a light brown/mahogany color. Sort of porterish, but with more hop flavor. As with the IPA from this brewery, needs more body.

lots of malt flavor. healthy amount of wheat - but it doesn't create the sour characteristic it does in a lot of weizenbocks. solid hop presence. you can taste the alchohol - but it's not overwhelming. nice golden color - not hazy. exceptionally well balanced and very easy drinking. this is how a weizenbock should be done. just had two of these at pacific crest's tap room. bought a grizzler of it to take home.
Golden colour, clear, frothy head that does not stay long. Aroma is malt drink, grain, some grassy hops. Light but long bitterness. Acceptable.
Barwa złota, piwo klarowne, piana biała. Całość bardzo brzeczkowa, z kukurydziano-warzywynym wtrąceniem.
Brzeczka, woda, woda z brzeczka, karmel, łodyga, spalona skórka ziemniaków. Niepijalne.

Butelka 0,5 litra. Barwa złota, idealnie klarowna. Wysok, biała piana, opada w dość przeciętnym tempie. Obficie zdobi szkło. Aromat słaby, lekko zbożowy. W smaku troche puste, ale nawet czuć goryczkę.
Jedno z najgorszych bezalkoholowych piw jakie piłem. Trochę słodu i sama brzeczka. Do tego przypieczona skórka od chleba i pustka. Nie polecam.
Draft 500ml. Pours light golden. Really super light, flavorless and tasteless.
Nijakie, zbożowe, puste, szmata mokra w zapachu jak i smaku. nic tu nie ma, jako i alkoholu, chyba za co największy plus.

Aroma; mash, wort, malt, sweet bread. Look; off white head, crystal clear golden body. Taste; wort, grass, mash, bread, fruit, semi dry finish. Feel; semi thin, normal co2. Overall decent non-alco beer. [draught at Macek in Olomouc CZ]

Bottle. Pours clear pale golden with a small, staying frothy white head. Aroma has light metallic, sweet sugary malts. Medium carbonation, light and harshly dry mouthfeel. Flavour has rough sweet sugar, harsh metallic bitterness. Rough.
Wyrób piwopodobny, piana minimalna, złota barwa, klarowne. Dziwny aromat, jakby chrupki kukurydziane. Smak podobny, malo piwny. Cierpkie, zamulające. -- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Light tasting and neutral flavor, light body, very pale yellow color with little foam

Seems like this has been relaunched to mark the opening of the new A Line linking Union Station to the Denver Airport, I didn’t realize it hadn’t been brewed since 2012! It’s now 5.2% and a A pale gold brew that gives off notes of light malts and white grapes. Clean crisp light malts tickle my tastebuds. This is an easy drinking brew with a dried toast malt character while the hops seem to be like a fruit jam spread on top. Simple and tasty.
On draft at Wynkoop. Pours a light yellow with a white head. Nose is some light honey, light malt, and light hops. Flavor is similar with light malt and slight honey. Light in body and not bad.

Poured a pale yellow with a fluffy white head. Smells of bread, biscuit, cereal, and yeast. Taste is very bready, with hints of cereal and biscuit, much like the smell. Mouthfeel is very thin and it ends lightly bitter. The bitterness seems to linger and reminds me of a pale lager. Very forgettable.

Tap @ Wynkoop, Denver. Pours light golden with a small offwhite head. Aroma of light malt, grass, light fruit. Taste is pale malts, light fruit, grass, light buttery fruit juice. Thin body, soft carbonation. 040312
I honestly didn’t get much bitter character in this - just some light corny, grainy smells and flavors, plus some grassy notes in a dryish finish.

On tap at Wynkoop Brewery. Clear see-through gold, like an American macro. Light and fluffy white head. Pale malt and some caramel on the nose. Smell is very faint and hard to pick up on. But the flavor is not! Taste is typical Pale Ale but is pretty full bodied for it’s style. Inoffensive and very no in-your-face, but pleasantly hopped with plenty of Pale malt backbone. Unfortunately the flavor alone is the only thing I can give this beer points for. Everything else about it was a little disappointing.
Tasted at the Wynkoop Brewery in Denver, Colorado. Very light appearance similar to a Bud Light. Sweet aroma with a touch of honey in the flavor. Not too bad.
Tap at the brewpub. Pours llight amber. Aroma is mildly malty, mildly hoppy. Tastes like that - it’s a light ale. Sessionable.
Tap at brewpub. Pours a faint yellow with a weak corn nose. Flavor is corn meal. Watery mouthfeel. Yuck.

column1: Mad Anthony Harry Baals Irish Stout
column5: On tap at the Warsaw taproom. Black pour with a tan head. Aroma and taste of dark roasted malt and milk chocolate.

column1: Mad Anthony Harry Baals Irish Stout
column5: Sample at the Ft. Wayne brewpub. Brown-black color with a medium creamy tan head that diminishes gradually. Patchy lacing on the glass. Roasted malt, coffee and chocolate aroma. Light-bodied with a roasty coffee and malt character with some chocolate and mild hops in the background. The dinish is bittersweet chocolate and malt. Decent overall.
