column1: Mad Anthony Harry Baals Irish Stout
column5: On tap at the Warsaw, in location. On nitro, pours the part with a nice creamy head. Lots of roasted malt and coffee. Body is smooth and creamy. I wanna dip my baals in it! God, remember when "The State" was on MTV. Dos where da days.

column1: Mad Anthony Harry Baals Irish Stout
column5: Draft sampler pours black with a tan head. Aroma of malts, chocolate and coffee. Taste is coffee and roasted malts.

column1: Mad Anthony Harry Baals Irish Stout
column5: Tap at Mad Anthony. A pretty solid Irish Stout. Smooth creamy chocolate, caramel. Bitter balance. Rich cocoa finish, some chocolate syrup, but plenty balanced out by the hops. Well done. Guiness-ish is a lot of ways, but better.

column1: Mad Anthony Harry Baals Irish Stout
column5: Nitro - Roast malts and bittersweet chocolate. Jet black with a decent brown head. Dark roast with some dark chocolate. A bit thin and plain.

column1: Mad Anthony Harry Baals Irish Stout
column5: Nitro. Near black pour with a creamy, khaki colored head of foam. The aroma has a lot of roasty character. Big notes of roasty coffee and bitter dark chocolate. Velvety mouthfeel. Low carbonation and light body.

column1: Mad Anthony Harry Baals Irish Stout
column5: On tap at the pub. Pours black with a dense tan head. Cocoa, espresso, roasted malt notes. Light to medium body with a low level of carbonation. Nice enjoyable stout.

column1: Mad Anthony Harry Baals Irish Stout
column5: Taster on tap at the brewpub. Very dark brown red color, clear. Thin light brown head. Bits of sort of loose lace. Good roast malts, coffee in the nose. Hint of dark chocolate. Nice btiterness, little sweet. Lighter body, creamy lighter smooth carbonation. Good light easy-drinking but flavorful dry stout. Lightly dry finish.

column1: Mad Anthony Harry Baals Irish Stout
column5: Tap at Warsaw location. Earthy coffee and chocolate aroma. Near black with a moderate thick creamy tan head, creamy lacing. Ashy acidic espresso flavor with a roasty bitter finish. Rather light for the style.
Golden with a white head. Light toast and some crisp hop. Thin. Easy drinking. Summer porch beer.

On Tap at the Bellingham BP Slightly hazy dingy yellow color. Thin wispy white head Pale soft light grain aroma. Clean dry and fairly sharp flavors. Some character and bite for a Blonde. Less common for the style I think but good and a bit different

On tap at Ray’s. Pours a clear yellow with a slight orange hue and a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has lots of grains and straw with a slight floral note underlying. Flavor has bread and grains throughout with a light floral note in the finish.

20 July 2015, tap at Boundary Bay. light yellow and mildly hazy. nose is sweet perfume, floral. thin body and mildly fizzy. very nice. some lemon bitterness, floral, slightly sweet, some tart notes. very nice.

Draught at the brewpub Hazy blond color; small creamy head. Light malt aroma and flavor; it’s also a bit buttery (diacetyl); light fruitiness and average bitterness. It’s a simple Ale with minor flaws.

Draft - Grain, hay and citrus/pineapple on the nose. Cloudy yellow with minimal head. Refreshing and light with a celery and resin hop taste with the hay. A light yeast flavour can also be found. Nice on a hot day if you are looking for something light.

6 oz. sample on tap at the brewpub, pours a cloudy blond with a small white head. Aroma is very light, with grains, light Belgian yeast, subtle dry zesty qualities. Flavour is yeasty and spicy, with bready malts, quite spicy hops and some yeast. Decent for the style, but expectedly bland.
Poured a hazy yellow with white head. Aroma is grain. Taste is nice fresh grain that is very refreshing with nice soft hop finish.
On tap at the brewery. Cloudy pale yellow with a thin white head. Light vegetable aroma. Thin body but decent mouthfeel. Taste a little like carrots. Not bad for a light ale.

Sample at the brewpub in Bellingham. A bright golden in the glass with thin white head. Aroma is crisp with decent hops. Taste is surprisingly satisfying. There is depth here to the palate, good hop bite, fresh, larger taste than I expected. All in all a great Vienna style lager.
On Tap @3 Fonteinen lambik-O-droom, Beersel. 16/11/2019 Color ambarino espuma blanca ligera, aromas dulces, ácida, sabor dulce, seguida de acidez moderada, cuerpo sedoso.

7-4-7-4-14 On tap @ Lambikodoom, Lot. Pours opaque, dark yellowy orange, with an enormous rocky head. Aroma is notes of oak, nuts, honey and heather, as well as hay, berries, funky notes and farmhouse. Medium body, with soft carbonation. Flavour is fruity notes of forest berries, musty fruits, earthy notes and minerals, as well as heather, kandi and wooden barrels.
Drucken på 3 Fonteinen lambik-O-droom. Guldfärgad med vitt fluffigt skum som ligger kvar. Mjuk och len kropp, ingen kolsyra. Lätt funk, farinsocker, snäll sockersötma, äpple. Oerhört lättdrucket.
On tap at lambik o droom. Pours a cloudy copper gold with large off white head. The aroma is strong funk, earth, oak. Slick body, funky, earth, dark fruit, sweet, light tartness, very good.
Tap. Pours hazy amber. Aroma and flavor are sweet, sour, bitter, funky. Finish is dry and hoppy. Overall: great

Pulled cask at the Droom on our 2019 Never to be Topped (challenge to forever do better) Belgium trip with Ian, Jason and James. Had to try this! Mostly clear light amber with a huge frothy white head. Sweet but funky, fresh and bright with some light citrus, dough and yeast, light body and moderate+ carbonation.
Tap @ the source. Amber color. Oak, honey and citrus in the aroma and flavor. Sweet but also with a pleasant lemony sourness. Nice.

03.05.2019, tap (through a sparkler) @ 3 Fonteinen lambik-O-droom: Nice bubbly-creamy longlasting head, slightly cloudy. Aroma is strange sour-ish, grape peel, Araldite two-stage glue, minerals, grass, weeds, old hay, oak, bark, yeast, hints of banana. Taste is sweet sour-ish grassy, sugar, old rope, sorrel, berry skin, oak, grass, hay, flowers, bark, grape peel, sour berries, yeast, hints of banana. Medium bitterness, slightly sweet sour-ish fruity mouthfeel. Weird aroma, nice taste...

On cask at 3 Fonteinen Lambik-o-droom, Lot, Belgium. It pours unclear golden, with a small, lasting, white head. Aroma is acidic, lemon, apple. Taste is medium sweet. Body is light, carbonation is low.
@Source, Reddish/golden with a nice off white head at the source, sweet, malty back, some brown sugar, soft, smooth, apples, lemon, peppery, caramel, woody, dry finish, decent

Witbier made with the same ingredients as lambic - not as weird as it may seem, seen the historical link between the two styles. Hazy peach blonde beer with medium cream white head; wheatiness in the nose, bready, peachy esters. Soft, mellow taste, gentle wheaty sourishness, yeasty with a light spiciness, subtle herbal hop bitterishness in the finish. Simple, yet balanced, quite refined and very quenching. A side by side tasting with its organic version would prove interesting.

Bottle (couple of years old I expect) at home. It pours hazy golden with a thick white head. The nose is . The taste is soft, sweetish, doughy, slightly musty, banana and some spice. The taste is bitter-sweet, spice, hay, dough, light candy, banana bread and some sweet apple/pear. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Nothing much exciting going on here. A pretty so-so Witbier.

Blond coloured beer with an avarge white head and some light carbonation. Full yeasty, vanilla light herby hinted aroma. Medium to full palate. Finish is light bitter yeasty hinted. Linger dry yeasty ending with some grainy hints.

Das Bier ist überaus mild und wird im Antrunk sowie Mittelteil von einem bananigen Aroma beherrscht. Auch im Abgang nimmt dieses Aroma wieder den Hauptteil ein. Eigentlich schmeckt es von Anfang bis Ende gleich ohne Aromenwechsel. An einem heißen Sommertag genau das Richtige, ansonsten Durchschnitt. Test vom 31.5.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 9,10,13,11,11,11
(33cl bottle) Pours a clear yellow body with a medium white head. Aroma of wheat, banana, and light citrus. Flavor of wheat, florals, and banana. A rather ordinary witbier.
(33cl bottle thanks to bu11zeye) near still with gold body. Nose of honey, corn flakes, Belgian yeast. Taste of apple, Belgian yeast, sweet corn flakes, lightly sticky body.
bottle, thanks to bu11zeye, clear golden color with no foam, aroma of grainy fruit and flavor of sweet apricot and mangos
bottle thanks to bu11zeye. yellow with a white head. cheese, fruits, slight hops. decent palate, fruity malts, slight tartness, easy finish.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this bottle. The beer pours a yellow color with a white head. The aroma is wheat with some yeast. I don’t get too much spice or fruit in the aroma, which is disappointing. The flavor is also a little bit lacking. I get a lot of wheat, but only a little bit of pepper and coriander and even less fruit. I get a little bit of orange peel, but it is very faint. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Bottle @ Grobbendonk, Belgium. Pours unclear golden with a small white layer of foam on top. Nose is yeast, wheat and cookie dough. Flavor is yeasty and quite bready. Medium bodied.
Sampled cask conditioned at Pot of Beer, Manchester Pale golden. Herbal and heavily spicy nose. Sweet with light body. Slightly watery finish. Wonderful nose, but downhill from there.
Golden; smooth, slight lemon hint; definitely sinkable, but a little light on the palate for my liking.

Cask, Star & Garter, Wigston. Amber with a form off-white head. Aromas are pear and blackberry with biscuit and dusty yeast. Trace banana with cream and mellow lemon. Flavours are caamel and lemon with dry tea and a cloying, nasty sweetness. Quite poor.
A Mes rate: Cask at The Volunteer. A fairly tedious offering from Robinsons, as most of theirs are if I am honest. Mainly malts and just very mellow all round. A tad on the watery side. Boo.

Cask at Bedford BF ’06. Amber sessioner; not much aroma. Watery, refreshing, little bitterness. Bit dull, really. 24.3.07. Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Amber-gold with a small white head. No discernable aroma. Malty taste followed by a very thin, watery second half with hardly any bitterness. Rating 1,4,4,3,11: 2.3.
Nice bitter, not annoying and good foam. Pale colour, not so goldy as other bitters.

Cask conditioned @ Humble Plumb, Soton. Doughy yeast and floral hop aromas with caramel. Very pleasant and slightly unusual fruity tea (like a cold darjeeling or ceylon) flavours. Gentle bitter finish to balance the fruity sweetness. Tasty.

1. Cask Handpump at the Castle Hotel, Manchester 08/06/2001 Amber coloured sweet and slightly pale. 2. Cask Handpump at the Castle Hotel, Manchester 16/11/2001 Amber coloured fruity and slightly bitter. Hop finish. 3. Cask Handpump at the Church Inn, Bramhall 31/01/2004 Mid brown amber coloured and fruity. Slightly dry malt finish. 4. Cask Handpump at the Bulls Head, Stockport 06/06/2009 Some fruit aroma. White head. Amber coloured smooth on the palate and fruity with a little dryness and bitterness in a malt finish.
Medway Beer Festival. A tired session bitter offering up a dry appleness, but nothing genuinely flavoursome or gulpable.

(Cask at Market Porter, London) Crystal clear amber body with off-white head. Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, nutty, spice. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, some floral, apple, light spice. Light body with low carbonation.
Cask at Rose & Crown, Mundy Bois. Copper colour. Lasting white head with nice bitter hops. Bit watery in mouth with hoppy dry finish. Slightly yeasty.

Cask. In good condition, light brown with white head. A good session beer quite full bodied for its strength, a fair amount of flavour a few more hops would not go amiss. I prefer this to the Best Bitter which I find too sweet.

Cask (handpump) at the Castle, Manchester, circa 2001. I’m departing from my normal practice of not entering pre-Ratebeer notes as this beer is retired. Mid-brown, mid-weight, mid-hopped (earthy, subtle), mid-malted (caramel, light) beer. I would describe this beer as middling. Perhaps a bit more body than the average session beer, but a bit less bite too. Like many Robinsons beers, I found it worthy but uninspiring. But a couple of pints slipped down nicely enough.
Cask Handpump at the Castle Hotel, Manchester 20/07/2002 Mid brown coloured fruity and refreshing. Slightly dry lasting finish.

Cask conditioned. Chestnut colour with a good thick lasting head and low natural condition. First aromas are of butterscotch and toffee, with caramel the dominant flavour. However, if you allow it to warm a little, fresh resinous hop aromas develop and hop flavour starts to balance out the caramel. Finish is initially malt but with a delicate lingering hop bitterness.
Dark amber; caramelly, peachy, apples.......................................
Sampled cask conditioned at Castle Inn, Manchester. Pale brown. Nutty aroma. Sweet, medium bodied. Dryish finish with relatively low bitterness.

From old tasting notes. Bright Amber gold color. Creamy white head. Soft fruity malt nose. Zesty sweet malt flavor hints at toffee with a touch of sour malt. Nice balance and flavor. Light citrus hops in finish.
Cask by handpump at Bon Accord, Glasgow - clear amber brown, thin bubbly off-white head, good lacing, very mild sweet malty aroma, caramel, fruity, smooth, prolonged malty aftertaste

First tasted this in Gabriels, Paisley in April 1998. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale russet in colour with a thin white head. Floral hop present in the short aroma. Very thin, resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt base gives a thin digestive biscuit base with weak barley sugar and dilute redcurrant flavours. Spicy prickle of hop resins evident in the dry bitter aftertaste. Weak malty finish is rather disappointing with little body or complexity for a 5%. A poor ESB.

Cask (handpump) at the Castle, Manchester, circa 2001. I’m departing from my normal practice of not entering pre-Ratebeer notes as I’m pretty sure this beer is retired. Quite pale in colour, but fairly traditional in chracter. Medium body. Pale malt and light fruit. Some citric hop but mainly dry, soft bitterness. Fairly well balanced but not very weighty for a 5% beer.

1. Cask Handpump at the Castle Hotel, Manchester 08/06/2001 Golden colour and pale. Strong in alcohol with a hoppy finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 30/07/2001 Golden and pale with a citrussy hop finish. 3. Cask Handpump at the Castle Hotel, Manchester 16/11/2001 Golden and slightly bitter. Full hop finish.

Cask Conditioned at The Hole in th' Wall, Bowness on Windermere, Cumbria. Golden amber beer with middling pale head. Crisp maltiness predominates, with a slight fruity sweetness, maybe apricot. Little hop character gets through the mass of malt.
Amber; malty, slightly confectionary, marshmallowy, peachy..................
Sampled cask conditioned at Castle Inn, Manchester. Pale golden. Lightly flowery aroma. Rather sweet and fruity. Despite containing more alcohol then other Manchester bitters it still feels lighter.
# 184; 12/2015. Svěží bitter s nižší plností. V chuti se nejvíce projevuje slad a hořké pomeranče.
(Unicorn copper ale) Amber color with thin durable foam. Malty and a mildly caramel aroma. Taste is malty, citrus hopped and mildly sweet and sour, but aftertaste gets bitter.
Golden colour with nonlasting white head. Aroma of dried fruits, caramel and grass. A little bit too intense. Taste of bready maltiness quicky evolving into stronger herbal bitterness. Average.
Decent bottle of ale, I have drank it a few times previously and it's really good, it hasn't changed in quality.
Bottle from Booths, Penwortham. Pours clear golden with a thin white head. Aromas of pale malt and caramel. Taste is light sweet, malty biscuits. Sweet finish.
Awful over powering aroma. Lingering after taste that is just as bad. Very average ale.
(bottle 0,5l) Overall: Ok english ale. Aroma: Candy sweet. Appearance: Clear golden. Medium, white head. Taste: Medium sweet, light bitter, light malty. Palate: Medium body. Bitter finish.

0,5 bottle. Tökéletesen aranysárga szín, szép tiszta átlátszó, erős, tartós piszkosfehér hab. Háttérben gyümölcsös, főként élesztős, és egyben komlós-malátás, tökéletes sörillat. Indításnak kicsit savanykás, aztán a Golding komló kiérződik. Alkohol foka ellenére testes, ízletes, nagyon jó iható remek bitter. Nekem a savanyúság volt az, ami egy icipicit lerontotta, de bármikor szívesen innám..
0.5l bottle. Golden color with white head. Aroma is malty, caramel and grassy with light fruity notes. Taste is sweet with some caramel and light bitterness. Overall it's average beer.

Botella de 500ml servida en una pinta nonica. Color dorado con una cabeza de espuma blanca de buena consistencia y estabilidad. Su aroma es dulce, a pan, con notas herbales. Sabor refrescante, con un suave dulzor de la malta y mayor presencia herbal que deja una sensación final seca en el paladar. Cuerpo ligero y de baja carbonatación.

Cask, handpump @ The Powder Monkey JDW, Exmouth, Devon. Produced a yellow gold with a few floaties caught in suspension. Head is short lived, an island of white in the centre keeps for the length. Aroma of rose petals, straw, dusty grains, lemon-grass and lemon candy adding a sweet touch. Similar in the mouth, sourish tinge towards the back with bright floral hops and citric esters. Base of pale grains, straw and dried grass. Very light bodied, almost delicate in mouthfeel. Low bitterness, ends short with just a little residual sweetness of candied lemon to play on the palate. Quite a good thirst quencher, can’t find to much to whinge about at all. A nice Summer refresher.

Cask, The Pub, Leicester. Olden with a thi bubbly head. Aromas are hay with citrus. Jammy fruit with base caramel. Flavours are lemon marmalade with dry biscuit malts. Hoppy and dry on the finish. A decent session ale.

Cask @ Great British Beer Festival, GBBF 2008, Earls Court, London, England SW5. Clear light to medium yellow orange color with a small to average, virtually none, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, dusty, damp stained malt. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. (070808)

Cask@GBBF2008. Golden colour, not much head. Aroma is fruits, some dough and mild notes of grass and green apples. Flavour is grass and wood mixed. Also some grapefruit in it. Aftertaste is mainly grassy bitterness.
A Mes rate: Gravicask at The Junction Tavern. Darkish golden colour. Sweet appley notes with a slight sourness and a delicate bitter finish.

(Handpump at GBBF ’07) Golden with a short head. Hint of malt but mainly lemon in the scent. Not bitter or sweet, quite watery. Very short lasting, just leaving some maltyness. Some hop, but grassy malts predominate. Bland but OK.

Cask-conditioned at the Rake, Borough Market 30/6/07. A golden ale with a slight white head. Aroma of citrus and floral hops with a touch of sweetness. Flavour was a bit fruity with a dry finish. Very easy drinking.
also had at the GBBF. yellowish color with a nice head on it. not such a strong smell on it

I agree with the fellow who said it’s more than the sum of its parts. Very light in colour and a slightly sweet taste. Seemed to get nicer the further I got through the pint. Cask at The Cap in Hand, Hook, Kingston-upon-Thames (JDW) 8/04.
A light pale golden ale. Not much aroma and a little too bland. This beer needs a bit of life. Not unplesant but just too boring.

Cask Half Pint at Cask Pub & Kitchen, Pimlico, London in Sept 2010 - A Real Ginger Beer. Ginger prominent but still definitely a beer. Hazy Amber in colour. Strong aroma of ginger. Spicy; ginger and peppery. Sweet ginger malty throughout. Dry finish. OK if you like ginger (which I do), but I couldn’t drink another. (2010-09)
Sample at All in beer fest 2015. Hazy yellow golden with white head. Fruity, floral with spices and heavy fresh ginger. Semi dry with medium bitterness and medium carbonation.
Cask at the Southampton Arms, London, England. Clear golden, small head. Pretty heavy ginger aroma.
Cask at the brewpub. From old notes. Nose is ginger. Flavor is burning ginger. Can’t really taste much else! Overwhelming, though very interesting as well.

Cask at Knott Bar, Manchester. Clear bright amber shade. Thin head coats the glass. Aroma and taste are suffused with ginger, which is rather mild rather than anything approaching throat-burning. Only one real note, but it’s clearly very well worked.
Cask at Manchester Beer and Cider Festival 22/1/2014 Pours a pale colour with a powerful ginger taste

Cask at the Southampton Arms. Poured a clear medium amber with a thin frothy white head. The aroma is dry crisp ginger. The flavour is spicy veg with a strong ginger burn plate. Medium bodied with flat carbonation. Steer clear if you don’t like ginger!
Cask at the Southampton Arms. Pours clear dark golden with a small off white head. Aroma of ginger. Flavour of ginger. Ginger in the palate. A long ginger finish. A bit of a one hit wonder this one.

August 19, 2013 - handpull cask at Southampton Arms. Hazy deep gold with a minimal off-white head. Aroma of sweet grain and earthy floral bitterness, some alcohol. Taste follows, with initial very mild ginger but it develops a strong and earthy bitterness pretty much all from the ginger root. Light body, astringent and a bit still, medium dry almost gritty finish. Not bad.
Really not for me this one so I’m glad I only had a wee sample. Ginger yes, but not pleasantly so.
Cask Handpump at the Marble Arch Inn, Manchester 08/06/2001 Slightly pale beer which is very clean on the palate. Hoppy.

Cask in Marble, Manchester. The same beer as Lagonda, just a name change and a bit more hops in the recipe! Lovely citrussy orange taste and finish with ample bitterness. The taste lasts for hours! (but Lagonda is even better...)
Sampled cask conditioned at Marble Arch, Manchester. Flowery hop aroma. Medium body. Sweet. Rather hoppy with medium biterness.
Complex pint with fruit (berry, apricot), zesty hops, and clean pale malt notes.
Clear golden body with a thick, foamy and persistent white head. Dusty and citrusy aroma. Taste is crispy, yeasty. Soft, yeasty finish. Medium body soft carbonation smooth texture.

Amber body with white lace. Aroma has light hop fruits. Taste is medium sweet to bitter with a biscuit note. Palate is medium bodied oily texture average carbonation and a bitter finish. They can do better.

Cask conditioned at Beer on the Wye '19, Hereford. Amber with white head. This proved to be a dryish bitter, initially simple but also developing a fruity character with pineapple notes in the background. Easily drinkable, nicely balanced. A good sessionable beer.

Light amber with a slight haze, white head which lasts quite well. Aroma has some caramel but with floral hops underneath. Beautiful moreish taste, with sweet notes of toffee and caramel but underlying bitterness. A most superior bitter.

Cask at Marble Arch. Caramel aroma with some grassy and floral notes. Hazy amber color with medium sized creamy white head. Malty caramel profile, floral, biscuity, mostly sweet with nice note of bitterness behind. Thin bodied, silky and almost flat. Superior drinkability. It's really fascinating how something simple like this leaves you craving for more after every sip, +1 for this. One of the best bitters I've had.
A great can of bitter. Lovely balance of bitterness and freshness. The sort of drink you would love to be served in a pub.
Nice easy drinking bitter. Lighter in colour which is typical for a Manchester bitter. Restrained taste with a nice bitter finish
Bottle @ tasting shared by me. Pale yellow color, average sized white head. Smell and taste malts, hops, hoppy bitter. Good, just good. Nice.
Blik gedeeld door Benzai. Gelig bleek bier, licht troebel bier met stevig schuim. Aroma is hoppig. Smaak is waterig en hoppig.
Blik gedeelt door Benzai, geprobeerd met Inoven. Het is een goudgeel bier met een volle witte schuimkraag. Het heeft een fruitige geur. De smaak is fruitig en wat zurig.

1. Cask Handpump at the Marble Arch Inn, Manchester 08/06/2001 Fruity and bitter with a malt finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Marble Arch Inn, Manchester 12/09/2004 Golden coloured smooth on the palate hoppy and slightly pale. Some bitterness in a creamy finish.
Cask in Marble, Manchester. My least-favourite of the marble beers. A buttery, toasty malt taste with some dry hoppiness - but not much.

Organics has little to do with this ’cover’ version of what Boddies USED to taste like. The brewer does a fine job of this session ale, with intense hops, and perfect ’condition’. N/4 in the S/H (Southern Hemisphere) by any chance?? Pity....!!

Sampled cask conditioned at Marble Arch, Manchester. Named after the northernmost, less touristic, quarter of the Manchester city centre. Golden colour. Sweet. Some flowery hoppiness. Mild finish. A well drinkable bitter, but rather bold.
This is an organic beer; amber, malt accent (crystal malt); toastiness; light body.
Cask Handpump at the Marble Arch Inn, Manchester 08/06/2001 Light coloured with slightly hazy appearance and fruity. Some bitterness in the finish.

Cask in Marble, Manchester. hazy due to being fined with seaweed not swim bladders, this golden bitter has a fruity, flowery hop taste and bitter finish. Possibly the same beer as N4 without the fining...?
Sampled cask conditioned at Marble Arch, Manchester. Deep golden. Spicy, and like the rest of this brewery's beers, flowery hop aroma. Rather sweet with medium body. Salty finish.
Bright (!); malty, with earthy hops and a dry finish. Great pub, too, with friendly staff who love beer and plenty of guest handles.

Bottle @ First Official Randers Tasting. Pours clear copper brown with no head. CLear aroma of honey and barrel. Sweet flavour of honey with clear notes of layering and spicy touches. Sweetish aftertaste. Warming alcohol presence. Decent.
Clear dark amber/brown. Aroma is honey, apples and heather. Taste is honey, wood and apples.
Bottle courtesy of HenrikSoegaard. Clear dark brown without head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, honey, herbal and alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet. Dry finish with warming alcohol. 080313

Bottle @ Home, courtesy of HenrikSoegaard. Pours clear dark amber, no head, heavy lacings. Arom of honey, apples, light acidic, flowers. Flavor is honey, wood, spice, green apples, boozy. Medium body, warming alcoholic finish. Abit to hot from the alcohol, othervise a nice mead. 100213
Ceramic bottle. Pours clear amber. The aroma is apples, honey and is light herbal. The flavour is booze, honey, fruit, apples and herbs. Light acidic finish.
Bottle, kindly given by Plovmand to me :) thx bro.... is pours cognac like.... the aroma is apple, alcoholic, sweet.... the flavor is sweet, apple, honey.... sweet honey, alcohol finish ....
cloudy brown with floaties honey and spices in the aroma flavor is stingy , spicy , a bit watery, some honey. not very balanced actually.
Botella. Clear deep brown colour. Sweet honey herbal fruitish aroma. Good sticky mouthfeel. Sweet honey fruity herbal alco flavour. Sweet honey herbal finsih.
Amber and clear. No head. Spicy aroma, pepper, faint honey, medicine. Flavor is sweet, wine. Port. Syrupy, creamy texture.
Bottle. From Helsekosten Nygade Silkeborg. Heavy vinius aroma. Powerfull moderate sweet and spicey and nutty flavor. Long great finish. Light licorice notes. Good mead.

Cask (4%), 1/3 pint by gravity at Alloa Real Ale Festival 2017, Town Hall, Alloa on 28 Oct 2017: weak malty, grain, cereal aroma, deep golden with a thin short-lived white head and no lacing, fruity, cereal flavour, grainy, sweet, good carbonation.
Fra cask/gravity på Plymouth CAMRA Beer and Cider Festival 24 Sep 16. Varm gylden. 0 skum. Lett ingefæraroma. Smaken ingefær med litt sitron. Kjedelig.

From cask by gravity on the second day at Plymouth Camra Beer Festival 2016. Golden body with a slight haze. Minimal lacing head. The aroma is dominated by ginger. Ginger taste as well,lemon beneath. Drinkable, not by kind of taste (Shared with Finn 24.09.2016).
From cask. Pours straw yellow. Eppery and citrus taste. Not picking up too much going ginger. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at home. Pale orange colour with a large white head. This fades a bit, but the carbonation keeps a good head of foam. Good aroma: peppery hop with citrus notes and spicyness from the ginger. Sweet malt to start, backed up with a firm bitterness. Flavours of citrus and ginger throughout. Lively on the tongue and with a very long dry finish. The lemon and ginger is present from aroma to aftertaste and never overpowers. A very nice beer.
Lukt: Svak Lemon og ingefær duft. Utseende: Gyllen. Skum/kullsyre: Lite skum. Smak: lemon, malt, ingefær. Hvor: 27 th Ealing Beer Festival. Medium: Tapp@175ml, ABV@4%, Når@07.07.2016

On cask at the White Cross, Lancaster. Appearance - golden with a proportionate head. Nose - lemon and pale malt. Taste -lemon barley water. Palate - light to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a fairly good finish. Overall - a solid citizen.
Cask at Ealing. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. Light bitter flavor. Some finger notes. Average light bitter finish. Oily palate.

5th April 2010 Hazy amber beer. Very dry palate. Watery malt with apologetic hints of ginger and a whisper of lemon. Very dry finish. Blandness abounds! Bitter lemon in the aftertaste, Nope, hard work!
On cask at Cloisters. Pours a golden colour with a decent white head. Aroma of lemon, ginger, caramel and barley. Similar flavours with mild carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. OK.
Bottle Stracey arms shop Norfolk broads. Golden good white head. Aroma is grassy Citrius taste same some decent hoppy bitters. Ok stuff.

Cask at the Market Porter, Borough. Vague doughy floral aroma. Bright gold. Good thick bubbly head. Initially a very light bitterness, which peaks in intensity into the finish. Underlying maltyness. The lightness of the body is matched by its softness. Gets slicker. Astringent finish. Another bland bitter.
Bottle at appellation. Pours pale golden orange, nose is light citrus, floral, toffee, taste is sweet, harsh toffee, flowers.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Appearance - golden with a nice fluffy head. Slight haze. Nose - geraniums, a hint of lime. Light biscuit. Taste - light floral, but then caramel biscuit takes over. Palate - close to medium bodied with a tangy finish that could be fresher. Overall - it could be fresher, alright.
500ml bottle shared with Ashton McCobb and Stuu666. Pours hazy gold with a thin white head. Aromas of lemon biscuit. Taste is light sweet biscuit, light lemon. Floral finish.

Bottle. Pale Amber in colour. Fruity; citrus orange. Hoppy; grassy hops. Malty; sweet malts, caramel. Sweet malts and citrus fruity hops. Dry bitter finish. Quite enjoyed this. Easy drinking. Sessionable. (2010-07)

Bottle from local shop. Pours clear yellow colour, small white head. Odd grainy and yeasty aroma, slightly funky. Oily mouthfeel with maltiness, obvious diacetyl and medium hop bitterness. Disappointing.
Clear yellow colour. Not much aroma to speak of but the flavour is deep, hoppy and complex.

Another bottle conditioned beer I managed to grab at a party on 7th June 2014: this bottle had a BBD of Jan 15. Light amber with a small white (ish) head. More malts in the nose than hops, same in the taste. I have struggled in the past with this breweries beers and this didn’t help their cause too greatly either. Not a lot going on really, some caramel notes for sweetness and hints of floral hops in the brew but it lacked oomph and a defining character to get into.
Bottle from Alesbymail. Hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light hoppy - grass. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 080414

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12 oz bottle poured. Pours a bright clear orange color with a lasting fizz head. Earthy hop aroma. Orange fruit, and hop forward flavor with a bitter finish. Orange flavor is a good highlight. Decent IPA.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: From notes. Tasted on 12/23/12 from a bottle. Pours clear orange with a thick white head that slowly recedes to average lace. The nose is citrus and resin hops with some candied orange peel, and a bit of caramel malt. The flavor is a bit more bitter and hop focused with the caramel malt acting as a nice backbone. The body is medium with average carbonation and a long bitter caramelized orange peel finish.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Reviewed from notes. Every time I had this beer, I had it in a pint glass. The appearance was a decent orange brown color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated leaving a decent lacing sticking finely to the sides of the glass. The smell tried to be hoppy bitter, but was basically just bitter to be bitter. The taste was bitter at times and then it showed some sweetness to it as it ran back and forth. There was no aftertaste nor was there any finish. On the palate, it sat a light to medium in body with a decent sessionable quality to it. Overall, this was a basic AIPA and most likely one I probably won’t revisit.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle. Pours a mostly clear amber color with a moderate off-white head on it. Nose is hoppy and with some resin tones to it, but smells old, like it’s been sitting on the shelf for a long time. Taste is bitter and hoppy, but also a tad skunky, like the hops are old and have turned. Not really a good IPA.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bomber from Fred Meyer’s. Hazy amber with off-white creamy head. Piney, grapefruit hops aroma. taste is sharp and finishes fast and bone dry. Seemed nice on pour, but finish kind of ruins it.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle. Amber beer with a cream head. Light grapefruit and pine aroma. Grapefruit and pine flavor with light earth and light caramel. Medium bodied. Good bitterness. Grapefruit and pine linger with light caramel.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12oz bottle. Pours amber/gold with white foam. Smells sweet with hints of pine sap and lemon. Tastes watery, sweet, piney with hints of lemon and wheat.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Hazy light brownish gold with ample head. Aroma is fruity malt. Sweet, fruity, malty with a little caramel. Decent beer. Bitter hops are missing. Would not guess it was an IPA.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12 oz bottle. decent maltier ipa. Not overly hoppy for my IPA preference. Rather sweet and malty. Some lingering bitter. Not bad, but better IPAs out there.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. The aroma is fruity/floral/earthy hops, sweet caramel malts. The flavor is sweet caramel malts, toasted malt, citrus/floral/spicy hops. A malt forward IPA.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle. Pours a mostly clear darker amber color with a moderate light tan head on it. Nose is definitely malty, with some caramel and bread notes coming through. Taste is a little too sweet and malty for me. Not very good.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12oz bottle. Pours amber/red with off-white foam. Smells sweet of hazelnuts. Tastes sweet, nutty with hints of grape.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 12oz bottle thanks to my Summer Secret Santa 2012. Pours amber with about a half finger of white head. Aroma of nutty caramel with just a hint of citrus hops. Taste is light bitter and light sweet. Caramel and light citrus. Medium bodied with lively carbonation and a decently long finish. Overall, I would love to drink it again.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: slight red tinge - malty sweet with some light hopping (not enough for the malt) but it seems to be a somewhat complex hop profile - lingering sugarey sweet taste - again a litle thin on the palate (similar to other Firestation5 beers I guess)

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: accidental purchase. I typically do my food shopping now at fred meyer and never bought beer here. I hit the traditional 22 oz section to find some NW hops, and figured I try this anyway. my ratings say it all. not much taste, tastes like a malty red bud light.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: I’ve had better beers, i’ve had worse beers. This is a mediocre beer for me. Nothing to write home about.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Bottle, shared with parksy. Pours a surprisigly pale amber, honey colored. Aroma and palate are simple sweet barley candy. Too sweet for me.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: Fire Station 5 Brewing Company--Fire Boat Amber Ale--2002 Release--12 oz. Bottle--5.00% ABV? (4.0 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Clear thin bright dark copper amber color. Toasted mild floral hop front. Crisp smooth mild toasted biscuit light fruit sweet caramel malt body. Lingering toasty malt light hop end. Light head & lace. Sampled 7/13/2002. Fire Station 5 Brewing Company--Portland Brewing Company--Pyramid Breweries, Inc.--Fire Boat Amber Ale--2008 Release--22 oz. Bottle--5.50% ABV--21 IBU’s. (3.25 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Lacy creamy mild white head. Clear thin bright dark gold color. Mild hop front. Thin crisp mild CO2 tangy dry sweet light crusty caramel fruit hint body. Refreshing easy dry clean mild hop citrus end. Weak Amberish Brew. Thin but crisp. Sampled 12/11/2008. $2.79 Each. Fire Station 5--Olympia, WA--Fred Meyer. Inc.-Fire Boat Amber Ale--Diligence--ABV On Label--2010 Release--22 oz. Bottle. 5.50% ABV--20 IBU’s? (2.75 / 5.0) Amber Ale. No sediment. Thin fizzy no lace white head disappears rapidly. Clear pretty bright thin amber red color. Weak hop fruit ester front. Mild sweet thin caramel fruit earthy toast hint weak amber ale body. Refreshing clean but bland mild hop fruit end. Disappointing. Sampled 2/14/2010. $2.79 Each.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 22 oz. bottle- No head, malty, not a very good beer. Amber ales are not my style and this one is the worst that i’ve had.

column4: Portland Brewing Company (Cervecería Costa Rica - FIFCO)
column5: 22 oz bottle. Smells of caramel, malt. Pours a medium head which disappears fairly quickly. Pretty hoppy for an amber. The unpleasant metallic flavor I tasted in the blonde is present here as well. Ends poorly with no head and turns watery. Tastes a little like a wet dog. Below average amber.

500 ml can. Dark brown with beige foam. The aroma is vague with pale malty notes and herbaceous hues. In taste, berry-ascorbic acidity, a small maltiness with chocolate-coffee notes. The bitterness is woody, not strong, with light burnt notes.
Mid-range Schwarzbier, fortunately the roasted malt flavors are supported by a hint of hoppy bitterness.
Klare nussbraune Farbe, mittelgroße beige schaumkrone. Geruch leicht metallisch hopfig, karamellig. Geschmack würzig malzig, leicht metallisch hopfig, karamellig.
To piwo to jaka? pora?ka zreszt? jak reszta wynalazków z tego browaru tragedia to ma?o powiedziane nie polecam nie po? tego gówna z Lipska bo to szajs !!! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android
Wässrig malziger, etwas verbrannt röstiger Antrunk. Im Mittelteil ist das Malz harmonischer, mild herb. Dazu kommt eine späte milde Hopfigkeit, die das Malz unterstützt. Kurzer Abgang. 12/8/9/9/6/9

Bottle, 4.9%. Clear dark amber/ brown with small tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, little bread with notes of bread. Flavour is malt, caramel, little bread, medium sweet, little thin, hop and a little bitter.
Bottle from Kaufland. Clear brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and caramel. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 250815
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are roast malt, caramel, hops and water. Thin watery finish. Easy drinkable.
Quite terrible. Now the worst score I have given on RateBeer. The aftertaste is very bad.
Pours ruby-brown, with big white head. Aroma of caramel and malts, sweet. Tastes sweet, some medium bitterness and sour finish. I do not recommend, not very drinkable.

Angemessene Schaumentwicklung mit eher grobkörniger Konsistenz. Farblich durchschnittlich gelb bis goldgelb, klar. Riecht würzig-hopfig, leicht süßlich. Geschmacklich zunächst leicht malzig, würzig, nach und nach herber werdend. Der Abgang ist relativ lang und gut hopfig, dabei macht es Qualitativ durchaus einen soliden Eindruck. Guter Durchschnitt für ein Billigbier.

Das "Sterni" genießt ja nicht den besten Ruf. So habe ich mir 2015, als ich dieses Bier trank, ein richtig mieses Schüttbier erwartet. Aber es ist eher ein stinknormales Helles, das ein paar hopfige Aromen und einen recht vollen getreidigen Körper hat. Nichts besonders, aber auch nicht übel.

Standard/average Pils. Aroma suggests more grainy and fruity elements, reminiscent of a Bohemian Pils. Unfortunately its taste cannot live up to this, lacking intense enough flavours. Even a bit watery at times, low level of bitterness. Drinkable though.
Z jednej strony karmelowa, eurolagerowa baza, z drugiej dość mocne chmielenie i zbyt długo zalegająca goryczka. Nieco powyżej koncernowej średniej.

Aroma; floral fruit, apple, grass, caramel. Look; off white dense head, clear pale golden body. Taste; hops products, floral fruit, caramel, sweet bread, and finishes sweet in bread. Feel; ok body n co2. Overall; just okay, really okay. [bt.50cl abv4.9% xp01.12.17 Tasted@Thanxbeeringparty @PivotekaH7] 5363'11

500ml bottle, thanks to djoeye for sharing. Clear golden body under a remaining snow white head, spotty lacing down the glass. Modest smell of grainy malts. Doughy flavours with a discreet hint of noble hops. Drying finish. Clean in the mouth. Average. (Shared with djoeye and Finn, Thanxbeeringparty at PivotekaH7, Tromsø 23.11.2017).
Flaske 500ml spandert av djoeye. Delt med ham og Rune på Thanxbeeringparty 23 Nov 17. Lys gylden. Høyt tett skum. Litt lacing. Lett maltaroma. Smaken pappaktig. Søt.
Aroma of malts and sulphur. Not good at all. Pale golden colour. Taste is extremely watery, low bitterness. Mediocre.

zapach klasyczny, słodowe, z ziołowymi nutami, w tle odrobina siarki i warzyw. kolor złoty, dość jasny, piana biała, obfita, drobna i raczej trwała. w smaku pełne, słodowe, lekko kukurydziane z piwnicznym posmakiem, ale w dobrym stylu. możliwe lekkie żelaziste nuty. goryczka wysoka, ziołowa, ogonkowa, ciężka u długa. nasycenie średnie.
Butelka 0,5l. Aromat słodowy, warzywa, niezbyt zachęcający. W smaku wodniste, gotowane warzywa.
Sweet malts, mildly roasted, some caramel, chocolate and chocolate. Mild and easy to drink in Reeperbhan.

Kleine, feinporige Schaumkrone eines klaren Schwarzbiers. Geruch nach Karamell. Säuerlich, karamelliger Antrunk. Dann leicht süßlicher, karamelliger und röstmalziger Körper. Gegen Ende leicht herber, langer Nachhall nach Karamell und weichen malzigen Röstaromen. Solides, aber nur durchschnittliches Schwarzbier.

0.5 l bottle from 'REWE' (Wyk), best before July 2020. Clear, dark reddish brown to black with a medium large, frothy, almost stable, beige head. Sweetish-malty, slightly roasty and minimally fruity aroma of caramel, dark chocolate, some coffee and a touch of dark fruits. Moderately sweet, malty, slightly roasty taste of caramel, coffee, dark chocolate and traces of dark fruits, followed by a short, moderately roasty-bitter and a little earthy finish. Medium body, smooth and slightly creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Nice!

Schaum: dicht cremig gut Farbe: schwarz. Nase: röstmalz, nussig. Roggenbrot, sehr gut! Geschmack: prickelt ordentlich, auch bitter, , weniger cremig rund sondern eher reichhaltige röstaromen,Holz, malzig. Nachgeschmack röst-rauchig. Echt gut.
Bottle. Pours black with light beige head. Aroma is malts, fruits, paper, some roast, dust. Taste is fresh, fruity, roast, some sweetness, light toffee, some sourness, citrus. Nice beer!

Das Schwarzbier aus Stralsund ist einmal als solches schön zu erkennen. Kein verunglücktes Porter, sondern ein ordentliches deutsches Schwarzbier mit schönen röstmalzigen Aromen. Was man halt vermisst, ist die Rafinesse anderer Störtebeker-Biere.
(nez fruité (banane-pêche), bouche bien faite (/style), fructose (nez + raisins), cara, jolie last, ultra-nice-agréable)

Bottle from Drankenhandel Leiden. Aroma is roasted malt with dark bread, rye bread, and some caramel. Flavour is moderate to medium sweet with a proper roasty bitterness. Body is medium. Satisfying Schwarz.
Pretty little beer, it's a lot like a mild rauchbier and some fresh hops added. Not great but okay.
Kräftige schwarze Farbe. Malzig, Noten von Kaffee. Im Abgang sehr schwach, fast wässrig.

On tap @ Karoeck, Hamburg. Looks, smells and tastes like a run-of-the-mill Pils from northern Germany. Earthy, grassy, grainy, bready, metallic, bitter. Damp basement. Dry and süffig but not really great.

(bottle) pours a clear yellow colour with a frothy white head. aroma of floral hops, straw and a hint of barnyard, with notes of manure, slightly meaty. flavour is mostly the same, heavy barnyard, powdered sugar and light cinnamon, with a light to medium-bitter finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Pale blond color. Light arma of hay and chestnuts. Very dry mouthfeel, light hay flavor, ordinary bitterness, with a shade of hop. Not convincing.

Bottle at Papsø. Clear golden coloured with a medium sized white head. Malty aroma of hay, caramel, liquorice and hops. Malty flavour of hay, caramel grass and hops with notes of cardboard. Dry hoppy finish.
Clear golden with a medium white head. Malty aroma with grainy and hoppy notes. Flavour had grassy hops, malt and caramel notes. Finished bitter.
50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is roasted and light breadish. Sweet caramelish and roasted malty. Bitter and light cornish finish.

Bottle, 4.9%. Rough aroma, lion cage, predator. Clear golden colour. Small stable white head. The flavour has the same as the aroma with the added joy of cardboard. I wonder if this bottle has been sitting in the sun at some point.

Bottle 50cl. @ home.
[ Trade by Maria ]. Clear light to medium yellow color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, hay, toasted, light hoppy, grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (080908)

It’s golden with a nice, white head. The aroma has notes of straw, malt and light flower. The flavour has a light sweetness, notes of malt, flower and a slightly dry bitterness. It’s both mellow and refreshing, but very quickly forgotten.

Bottled@Fonefan. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is hayish, bready malts as well as quite grassy. Flavour is nutty, hoppy and sweet malty. Finish gets into quite grassy hoppyness and bitterness.
Small beige head. Solid golden color. Full malty aroma and taste. A small residual sweetness that is balanced by a firm bitterness.
Bottle. Frothy White good mostly lasting head, Yellow colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.
500ml Flasche. Goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, würzig, herb. Geschmack malzig würzig, minimale Bitterkeit.

(bottle) pours a clear golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of herbal hops and earth, with a hint of tobacco, powdered sugar and ureum. flavour is mostly the same, though quite meaty and slightly vegetal, with a hint of pale malts and a slightly minerally finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.

50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is grassy and slight metallic. Slight sweet cornish, light toasted malt and bitter grassy. Vague metallic. Bitter and dry grassy finish.

Bottle 50cl. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, hay, straw, light cardboard, light to moderate hoppy, green grass. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20091004]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Clear golden with a firm white head with good retention. Some noble hops in the aroma. Medium body, strange toffee-like maltiness and a little metal. Ends dry. Not really convincing. 041009
Bottle, 5.5%. Vinous and citric aromka. Clear golden colour. Small stable white head. The flavour is cardboardy with some rough hops. Soapy flower notes from the aroma hops.
Bottled@Kahdet Kasvot, Tampere. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is hops, grass and some mild notes of paper. Flavour is hops, caramel, some malts and also very strong breadyness.

(Bottled, BB 03/2009). Pub Kahdet Kasvot, Tampere. Clear golden color, small white head. Grainy, grassy aroma. Dry grassy mouthfeel. A bit sweet malty and grassy hoppy. Also a bit oily. Nice drinkable export, although very simple.
Flip-top bottle (thanks Viil). Clear golden color. Medium size, white head, stays. Malty, acidic hops, sourish, grainy, dry, dusty in aroma/taste. Drinkable brew.

Ein weiteres Ökobier -schön, dass es mehr werden. Zum Rother-Zwickel fällt mir als ersten ein Geschmack aus Schwarzbrot mit Orangenmarmelade ein. Es hat klassiche zwickelige Brot- und Hefearomen, dazu aber ein paar interessante fruchtige Ansätze. Allerdings merke ich auch eine gewisse Muffigkeit, welche an alte Kelelr erinnert. Passt dazu, aber gefällt mir weniger. So hat man am Ende doch nur ein recht durchschnittliches Bier.
50cl bottle. A clear yellow golden beer with a white head. Aroma of spicy hops, grainy pale malt, cereals. Taste of spicy and mild floral hops, pale malt and straw, long bitter finish.
500 ml bottle. Unclear pale orange, small foamy head. Orange, metal, straw, grass, hay, earth. Quite bitter. Light bodied, watery texture, bitter metallic finish. Overall okay.

Light golden with a white head. Aroma is citrus and muggy traces of fermentation. The fruity taste continues along more savory, muggy elements,then followed by a slightly bitter palate. Very interesting, reminiscent of a Belgian Gueuze, but certainly not everybody‘s cup of tea.
Hotel beer from a getrankmarkt in Wandlitz. Clear golden color medium white head. Aroma of flowers, hay. Taste is lightly sweet fruit and cereal. OK

Bottle. Whew, a weird one to say the least. Very lightly hazy pale gold pour with thick foamy white head. Aroma is super dank, grassy, intense hay aromas, pot and hop-leaf, intense, dank, weed. Taste is grainy, mellow, quite sweet, with a somewhat harsh bitter finish. Palate is light bodied with low carb.

0.5l flip-top bottle from denn's biomarkt, charlottenburg, 1.09€. pours a cloudy pale golden with a dense head and some sediment. mild aroma of hay, grass, green apples, later on spicy malts. flavour is rather sweet and bready. mellow.

Pours yellowish with a light haze and leaves a thick, frothy head that lingers amidst sticky lacing. Optically, a nice beer. Aroma is very grassy, a bit herbal. Taste has a light citric bitterness with hints of sweet caramel on a light bodied, empty palate that trends watery. Overall kind of disappointing

Bottle consumed in Nov. 2015, best by Jan. 2016: Hazy yellow. Puffy white halo of foam. Subtle aroma of melon, fennel, lemon, baguette, wet hay, and a hint of metal and sulfur. Soft and prickly bubbles. A sulfurous grip and gritty minerals pave a rustic path for lemony hop succulence which brightly ensues. Pils malt is lightly toasty and baguettelike, with just a touch of wet paper and hay poking through and marring things with some limpness. Smidgeon of claylike yeast coats the palate and reinforces the rustic profile. Assertive herb- and lemon-charged Spalt caps the budding baguette and sweet hay notes in the soft, scratchy hop finish. So many kellerbiers beg for more bitterness, so it’s good to see the brewers weren’t shy with the hops here. A very soft and quaffable rendition, with a touch of Old World mystique.
ホワイトエール 白の香り、ほんのりバナナ

sample from Andy glass, THANKS ANDY! you’re typical orangey coridander wit, dry hoppy finish, very light hop though. Lightly spiced, more of a beer than some of the other wits that have way too much orange and spice flavors.
Pours gold with a white, lasting head. Smells of sweet wheat, some coriander/clovey hints. Tastes of sweet wheat, light citrus on the finish. Easy drinking.
Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Wheaty base, light fruity yeasty notes, hints of spices, light sweetness, and a clean and faintly citric finish. Pretty good.
Tap at the brewpub. Slightly cloudy yellow pour with a foamy white head. Wheat, yeast, and mild lemon zest. Very drinkable. Nice.
on tap-thin white head with trailing lace-cloudy straw. A-soft wheat, lt fruit. T-zest/spice, wheat, lt fruit.
Tap. Hazy straw with small head. Very mild spice for the style. More wheat than anything. Average at best.

On tap at the brewpub. Proper glassware. Cloudy gold, respectable white head with good lace. Nose of orange peel and wheat. Taste is classic Belgian Wit. Plenty of coriander and Belgian spices. Medium body. Refreshing and slightly above average if you like the style.floral,
Light yellow. Tons of bubbles hold a white head. Sweet fermented malt taste with a weak aroma of the same. Musty and sweet.
Pours a hazy pale yellow with a white head. Bubbles rush visciously to the top due to heavy carbonation. Slight orange peel aroma, with grass and earth present. The palate is somewhat watery.

Clear gold. Foamy white head. Light carbonation. Crisp, very hoppy and lightly citric with an anise? hint. Grassy-hay like maltiness. Strong Goldings hop flavor but also strangely licorice like. Very intriguing. Made from malts cultivated from Tim Carson's field.
インペリアルスタウト しっかり濃いスタウト、甘さよわめ、苦味がつよい

On tap in a tumbler (interesting choice). Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of lightly roasted malts with a little chocolate and sweetness plus some light hops. Flavor the same, with hints of coffee and chocolate. Average texture. Tastes and feels more like a normal stout than an imperial stout to me.

Tap at the source - Black, tan creamy head. Nose held notes of black chocolate cream with soft underlying notes of butterscotch and currants. Sweet chocolate and roasty flavors fade in to hints of coffee and warming alcohol (8.5%). Faint hops try to round out the sweetness, but stays on the sweet side throughout. Medium to full bodied and oily, soft carbonation, soft sweet finish. More hops could have really made this one amazing. Still ok though for sippin...
On tap at the brewpub. Sable with a beige head. Somewhat weak chocolate and charcoal nose. Bitter chocolate and coffee flavors, followed by a bitter baking chocolate finish. Pretty dry. Good.
Pours dark brown with a creamy light brown head. Smells of figs, dough, coffee, chocolate and candy. Tastes more subdued than it’s smell suggests with a thinness on the mouthfeel.
on tap-pours a big, creamy brown head with black color. Aroma is dark malt, coffee. Taste is dark malt, coffee, alcohol. Somewhat sweet. Not my taste, nicely done.

On draught at brewry with Clarkvv 8/11/05: Opaque dark black color that almost sticks to the side of the glass when swirled it’s so dark. Atop it sits a large tan head that dies to a small but lasting film and ring around the glass. The aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, licorice, earth, and some grapes or prunes. The taste is a bit sweet, but I didn’t find it to be syrupy or over the top. It starts off with licorice and chocolate, caramel, then roasted malt, near charcoal, and a hint of toffee. Finishes a bit chaulky with sweet sugars lingering on the tongue. Full bodied, medium carbonatoin, creamy chewy body.

On draught at the brewery, 8/11/2005 with Bucknaked. Big tan head recedes quickly to cover, tons of lacing as usual. REALLY dark black and opaque. Aroma of dry, nutty malt, earthiness and light roast. Cigars perhaps. Some prune-like vinousness, but again, low aroma overall (even sticking my face in the glass). Flavor begins with some sticky caramel, a bit of black licorice and some smoky, charred wood. Dry, salty black malts. Sweet toffee and a hint of anise and vanilla. Dark, bitter roast on the end. Retro smoke with some chocolate undertones. Hops and alcohol are up front, before it really gets dark and bitter. Seems it could use a good deal more chewiness. Getting some alcohol apparency in the nose as the beer progresses. Pretty flat, some ashiness lingers along with cola and caramel (kind of an odd mix). Loose and somewhat thinned out, but not overly watery.

On tap at CT Brew Fest. Aroma is mildly sweet with some chocolate and the typical licorice notes that City Steam always has. Opaque dark brown/black with a brown head and nice lacing. Sweet start with lots of sugars turning chocolate and roasty. Finishes very sweet and roasty. Extremely sweet for an Impy Stout. Almost as though it wasn’t fermented enough. Unfortunately, the girl pouring this beer was told by the brewmaster to say it was 20% ABV. Because of this lameness, I have deducted overall points.

Draught: I was a bit disappointed in this one. I expect Imperial stouts to be more full bodied and flavorful than this one was. It was good, but more of an "Imperial Stout Light" than anything else. It was still very drinkable, but just not all I would expect from an Imperial Stout. Re-rate 9-07: Definitely improved from the last time that I had this. Much more body and flavor than before.

Yellow body, small creamy white head. Lightly yeasty aroma with a mild fruity character. Very mild flavour with light sweet fruit. Average to light palate is smooth. Tasted pretty much like you would expect if you have had a cream al at another brewpub. Well executed but a bit dull.

I'm the first ever Ratebeerian to visit P'oro? Wow. Well, I went spelunking at the Warsaw Caves (Warsaw Lunch, for the record, has some fine staff) and made sure to stop at the Olde Stone on the way home. This one was billed as being "like Boddington's". Light bronze colour, lemon, EKG aroma...sweetish and mild. I guess so, although I never did find cask Boddy's in Manchester last year. Anyway, it's useless.
This is my least favorite of the Olde Stone beers. This was watery, and had a candy-wheat flavour to it.
Light gold bock with no head, no aroma, heavy malts in mouth with very german lager hops. Friendly server at booth, but not much else. (July 31 at Indiana Microbrewers Festival)
I’d guess this was 9% abv as there’s considerable burn. Touch of sweetness helps to conceal the alcohol. Typical light golden bock color. Good attempt at the style.

Sweet, fragrant aroma. Opens very hoppy, the middle is sweet and malty. Finishes with hoppy bitterness. A bit overdone on the hops, as they linger a long time on the aftertaste, but all in all, the best American beer I have sampled.
Bevuta in bottiglia da 50. Aspetto molto limpido. Aroma delicato.gusto leggero. Fgr
Bottle. Clear gold with a decent white head. Mild aroma of citrus fruits and just tiny hints of banana and clove. Taste follows aroma. Low bitterness. Medium carbonation. Refreshing. Alright.

500ml bottle, thanks to Kolschtrinker. Pours an expected clear gold, frothy white topping. Aroma has overripe banana, greek yoghurt, brioche. Taste is fairly light with measured, soft weissbier notes, light sweetness, gentle ripened fruits, soft banana and cloves. Fine kristallweizen, but nothing to write home about.
Bottle, thanks romqn. Pours golden. Aroma is sweet, banana, wheat. Flavor is sweet and fruity, banana, wheat, yeast. Overall: ok.

0,5l from bottle shared by Mart. Yellow clear color, small white head. Smells ripe fruits, lights sweetness, peppery, caramel, ok smell. Medium body, soft carbonation, slick mouthfeel. Tastes rather light, spices, peppery, light grassy, some ripe fruits. Finishes lightly sweet with notes of caramel, spices and earthy notes. Decently ok
Bottle, thanks Maart. Pale clear golden. Clove-forward typical upper Bavarian weizen notes, creamy mouthfeel, little stunted on the fruit, otherwise fine.
Street beer, RBVG 2018. I assume it's clear yellow, not sure about the head. Aroma of banana, clove, citrus. Taste has banana bubblegum and clove. This one has it all!
19-08-18 // 500ml bottle from Getränke Stumpf. Clear golden. Foamy white head. Slight Hefeweizen nose. Clean crisp grainy taste. Really starting to appreciate Kristall on a hot day.
Crispy and clean, with light banana note, bit spicy. Light sweet all the way with light tartness. Decent, but boring
Flasche im Hackendahl in Berlin. Goldgelb, klar, eine fingerbreit Schaum.Aroma wegen Zitrone im Glasschlecht einzuschätzen. Geschmack: Hopfen, etwas Zitrus, leichte Süße.
Amber; slight tobacco; light, leafy hops, off-dry finish. No aroma.........
Sampled cask conditioned at The Beer House, Manchester Pale amber. Very sweet and very mild. Sugary finish. Not a medallist in my book.
Cask Handpump at the Cross Keys, Knutsford 10/06/2003 Golden coloured slightly sweet on the palate and hoppy. Lasting malt finish.
Orangey colour; crisp- good hop/malt balance; dry finish; toast, slight wood, candied fruits.
Sampled cask conditioned at The Beer House, Manchester. Deep golden. Rich, flowery hop aroma. Malty with loads of hops. Balanced bitter finish.
Beautiful taste, Very cheap at around £3 a pint and only takes a few to get me drunk all round perfect beer
It's not a bad lager tbh, easy refreshing lager, cheap and cheerful pint. Much better than carling
Decent bottled later. Cost about £1.50 from Morrisons. Refreshing taste, very drinkable.
First pint of a Sunday beer fuelled footballing afternoon. Not the greatest taste, but pretty cheap. An attribute that I am a massive fan of.

Pint on tap at The Railway, Buxton. Clear amber beer with creamy white head. High carbonation. Grainy, malty nose. Fine mouthfeel, like expensive mineral water. Nice lacing. Taste is lightly bitter, finish is malty leading to tinny bitterness. Nice and drinkable in the sunshine today.
Average tasting pale lager. Slightly sweet but quite drinkable. An ok example of the style
On tap at Grove Inn, Ashton New Road - nowt wrong with this one, yellow body, lots of fizzy white head. Nose is grainy, but holds together with a balanced sweetness. Refreshing and that’s it.

An unexpected surprise and I must say, most welcome. Malty undertones, tasted rather good to me. Missed the first half of Metz’s set but may be okay as they said they were supporting Mudhoney on some dates. Thomas, the bass is huge.
Sturdy but ordinary tasting lager with carbonation and maintains a good head.
From tap. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small creamy and white head. Aroma is mild butterish and malty. Flavour is the same. Bitter ad flat malty. Bitter far finish

Bottle. 3.5%. BBD of August 1990. Not sure who provided this one, but it was opened at St Mars of the Desert during a meet Ron Pattinson shindig. Clear, deep brown. No head. Remarkably viscous in the glass. Nose has raisin and date. Fig. Some fudgy chocolate. No off notes at all. Taste is sweet and a little vinous. Light body. Still a hint of carbonation. Silky on the palate. Sweet and vinous finish. Remarkably good condition and really tasty, too.

Not a retired beer as indicated. This was in ample supply at the Ape and Apple in Manchester. Presents well in the glass and has a mild malty hopiness in the aroma. I like the earthy nature of the flavour and consider this to have been the best Holt of the evening.
Dark chestnut; fresh, woody hop nose; dry, toasty with a hint of dark chocolate.
Sampled bottled at Ape & Apple, Manchester. Dark ruby with rich head. Fruity and raisiny, yet dry and surprisingly malty. Dry finish with low bitterness.

500ml bottle in 2015. Really dark ruby with a thin beige head. Aroma of sweet malts, raisins, treacle and caramel. Similar sweet, malty flavours with quite a light body and a bit too much carbonation. Might have been nicer in cask?
Bottle drunk at home. Black appearance with off-white head. Aroma is caramel, chocolate and brown sugar. Flavour is toasted, malty, sweet, liquorice and caramel.
Under appreciated drink.....one of the best around strong roasted notes More of a winter warmer
Strength to it. QUALITY and REFRESHING. Warm you up drinking this. Usually stick to these in the autumn and winter months

Bottles from Morrisons, Birtley, Gateshead and Glenridding Mini-Market. A black-brown beer with a masssive tan head of foam. It has a chocolate, malt and caramel flavour with smooth toffee and chocolate on the creamy nutty finish. Good.

Very dark mahogany beer with ample beige head. Typical notes for a beer of this type. Toasted malts and sweetness. Went down very easy. Nice buzz. Could be dangerous on a session. Bought for a very cheap price too at £1.29. Bargain at that price.

18/IV/17 - 500ml bottle from a trade @ American BBQ Guy Tasting (ElManana+1’s place) - BB: 2/I/18 (2017-462) Thanks to Val and Neill for the trade! Clear dark brown beer, creamy irregular beige to brown head, pretty stable, adhesive. Aroma: malty, grains, bit fruity, some caramel. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: very malty, grains, bitter, bit hoppy, some chocolate. Aftertaste: soft roast, pretty bitter and hoppy, some caramel, bit medicinal, malty finish.

Bottle from Morrisons. Deep dark reddish mahogany in colour, off white head slowly fades. Lightish aroma of malt and spice, medium to full body, slightly sweet, nice spice and zesty undertones, good longish finish. Good stuff!

500ml bottle from Morrisons. Pours very dark clear brown with a creamy head. Aromas of burnt sugar, faint dried herbs, some sweet creaminess, boozy fruitcake. Taste is instant coffee, cream, light chocolate. Thick mouthfeel. Dry finish. Good strong ale.

Smells like cow shit and stale cigarette smoke. Tastes of roasted malts and blackberries. Bitter/sweet finish, quite smoky on the back end. The taste is strong. Feels like I could have a couple of these as a meal replacement.

On cask at the Lass O Gowrie, Manchester, April 2008. This is clearly still being made somewhere but I have no idea where. Rosebridge, who made some of the Lass O Gowrie beers for a while themselves went out of business in 2007 so this remains something of a mystery. Amber, thin white head. Dry malt with touches of earthy hop. Standard UK bitter. PRE-RATE. Vintage rating. On cask (handpump) at the Lass O Gowrie. Its not my intention to put all my pre RB stuff onto the site but, where the brewery has recently closed and the beer was still made up to that point (I’m surprised they kept going as long as they did) I’ll add a few for posterity’s sake. Amber colour. Mellow. Soft malt. Some spicy notes, but not very bitter. Serviceable enough without generating too much excitement. (5/3/6/3/11)
Cask Handpump at the Lass O’ Gowrie, Manchester 06/02/2004 Amber golden coloured and hoppy. Some citrus flavour. Smooth on the palate with a dry finish.
Amber; fuggley aroma; crisp, earthy bitterness, slight orange fruitiness....
Sampled cask conditioned at Lass O'Gowrie, Manchester. Pale amber. Flowery aroma. Medium body, rather sweet. Typical Mancunian bitter.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Druidia Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Deep brown color in the glass with a small head. Roasted aromas greet you as you bring the beer close. Flavor was a little bit of a let down. Some sweetness in it but the beer tasted watery and had a rather light character. I see this schwarz isn’t as big as most.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Druidia Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Burnt taste and aroma. A very dark brown ale with stout like qualities. No head a sweet chocolate with roasted malts in the flavor. A solid one from Rock Bottom in KOP.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Druidia Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Poured a hazy brown color with a small, light tan head that left spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma and taste found notes of sweet chocolate, roast, caramel malts. The mouthfeel was overly thin unfortunately.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Druidia Lager
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Black in color, very nice lacy tan head, a little overly carbonated, way too sweet, tasted almost like my homebrew batch of oatmeal stout that didn't ferment correcly and came out all sugary & sweet

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Prussia's Pride IPA
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Pours light orange. Aroma of citrus and hops. Sweet, almost floral taste upfront with the bitterness at the back. Also some sugar cereal taste at the end that gets kicked back by hops. Full mouthfeel. Fairly standard IPA. Tap at brewery.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Prussia's Pride IPA
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours a lightly cloudy orange with smallish white head and minimal lace. Nose of caramel, citrus, grass. Light to medium body. Decent flavor but tough to drink after the Simcarillo

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Prussia's Pride IPA
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at brew pub. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. There is plenty of carbonation in the glass. The aroma Is floral with a bit of orange citrus. The taste is medium bitter, a little dry, and the bitterness lingers on the tongue. Nice.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Prussia's Pride IPA
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Some floral notes on the nose. Pours with a medium size head that leaves a lot of lacing. A lot of bitterness on the tongue that overshadows the hop flavor. The taste lingers for a while. Could use some more balance. Now if you ever get a chance to taste this stuff on cask its a lot more interesting. The nose is bolder and more articulated. There’s a lot more hop flavor on the tongue and it’s more balanced. My score reflects the cask.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Prussia's Pride IPA
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Allegedly an award winner. Pours a clear copper color with a sweet caramel citrus aroma. Caramel flavor with citrus and floral hops flavor. Decent beer with good lacing.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Prussia's Pride IPA
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On draft at the brewpub. Pours a cloudy yellow orange with a small white head. Aroma of malty grapefruit citrus and sweet sticky hops. Taste of sticky hops, citrus and light pine.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Prussia's Pride IPA
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: A pretty neutral beer. Looked pretty, w/ a great copper color. Didn’t have much taste at all.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Prussia's Pride IPA
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap in King of Prussia. Has an unfiltered look to it. Impressive piney hop aroma. A malty, mellow IPA with a resiny, bitter finish. Good.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Prussia's Pride IPA
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: on tap at the brewery. a light hoppy ipa. very drinkable and one of the better offerings and rock bottom kop. orangish yellow color, with a light head.

column1: Rock Bottom King of Prussia Prussia's Pride IPA
column2: King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft. Pours golden amber with a white head. Sweet and hoppy aroma with some light citric notes. The flavor has citric hops, some light piny hints, and a malty sweetness. Pretty good.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Sample. Medium high fluffy white lasting head. Hazy dark yellow body. Sweet banana aroma and flavor with residues of the yeast. High carbonation, long sweet finish.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Draft. Cloudy yellow color, white head. Aroma of citrus, clove, banana. Taste is mostly citrus, light banana.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: "amidst all their other good brews on the tap, this did nothing to make us take notice. not bad, just another standard entry into the american wheat beer category."

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Cask Stillage from the Jug at the Colorado Convention Center, Denver 12/10/2007 (As Loveland Hefeweizen) Banana fruit aroma. Small white head. Clear golden coloured and hoppy. Smooth and creamy on the palate. Some dryness and bitterness in a malt finish.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Tap @ Denver location. I think this is the proper listing- just called Weizen and appears to be one of their new standard lineup. Mildly hazy/cloudy light orange appearance with a fluffy white head. Very potent banana, clove, spicy yeasty nose. Pretty bready yeasty, moderate bananas and cloves, fairly wheat malty flavor. Bready wheat, banana aftertaste.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Draft. An unclear golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has ntoes of wheat and lighter notes of bananas. The flavor is sweet with notes of wheat and bananas, leading to a dry wheaty finish.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Draught, 4.5% at the Boston brewpub as Brewmaster’s Choice Hefeweizen. Dusty, chalky aroma. Almost clear golden colour. Small white head. Thin malty flavour, hint of chalk and fruit. Not really any banana or spices. Harmless.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: A hazy blonde weizen with a thin white head. A lemony aroma with light cloves, fruity esters. In mouth, a thin weizen with light bananas, dryish, again, not interesting. On tap at Rock Bottom Boston, July 1 2010.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: Had on tap at the Milwaukee Rock Bottom. Full of banana notes - be prepared! Not bad.

column4: CraftWorks Restaurants & Breweries -Rock Bottom Corporate Office
column5: From tap at the brewpub in San Diego. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is light banana and estery fruity. Sweet flavoured with the same accents as in the aroma. Quite sweet and estery base flavoured finish.
On keg at the palintine hadfield. Really nice, citrus and hoppy, very refreshing
Pint@George and Dragon,Beaumaris. Złote ze średnią piana o biała kolorze i kremowej konsystencji. Dominują cytrusy,trawa, zioła,chleb,ziarno. Raczej wodniste

Draught. Reddish golden with an off white head with a very slight haziness. Very good (if peculiar) aroma, the alt and yeast really stand out with a very agreeable turnip-like note. Malty in mouth, like drinking a homemade wholemeal loaf, some very subtle leather flavour and minor treacle/molasses that make it a very palatable bitter. Creamy and (mild to) medium body with a fairly long finish. Another decent bitter.
Cask at the Queens Head, Hawkshead. Pours dark gold with a medium head. Aroma is eggy straw. Taste has straw throughout with eggy sulphur on the finish.
Sample at the Old Market Hall, Thick creamy white head. Clear golden pour. Light malt bitterness.

Tried at the Fox & Pheasant, Armathwait, Cumbria. As Cumbria Way (no brewer mentioned). Pale golden colour with a white head. Aroma has citrus and caramel sweet malt and the taste does too. Light crisp body

From tap at Castle Hotel, Manchester, 30.11.17. Clear golden. Dense and persistent white head and lacing. Arom af moderare American hops, pale malt and succade. Slightly sour. Dry. Not great. More a golden ale than a bitter.
On tap at The Castle Hotel, Manchester. Pours clear orange with medium white head. Malty, caramel, some vague fruit notes. Generally quite bland and watery.
A somewhat uninspiring beer.Not bad but it doesn’t leave you wanting more.Thin,watery with little body.OK,drinkable but boring.
Pint on cask at the healey rochdale. Typical robinsons pint. Dark fruits ok looking in the glass
Hazy amber with a big white head. Aroma of exotic fruit with a floral touch. Dry, fruity and malty flavour

Bottle 500ml. @ ChrisO. [ Vintage BBF 0306 ]. Clear medium orange amber colour with a huge, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, oxidide, toffee, leather, cheese, cardboard. Flavour is moderate sweet with a average to long duration, toffee, sweet malt, chocolate notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110802]

500ml bottle (ChrisO’s post-GBBF2011 Tuesday) Massive lychee aroma, some sourness too. Massive carbontaion. Good roast, some liquorice. Has good light and heavy elements, but they do not integrate well. Rerate 5 days later, post RBESG2011 Sunday. More appley in the aroma, more chocolatey in the finish. Aged quite well for a BB2006. Very rich roast, toasty and nutty. Same score.
Bottle @ Chris O’s. Thanks guys. Pours cloudy golden with a fluffy white head and lacings. Metal, fruit, yeast and corn. A bit of peach. Medium bodied.

Bottled. Amber colour with a small foamy slightly off-white head. Aroma is fruits, wood, some slight earth, herbs and mild honeyish and nutty notes. Flavour is fruits, malts, some floral and wooden notes. Pleasantly balanced, ending in a nice dry bitterness.
Bottle at ChrisO & Ruth’s - Thanks. Cloudy red/brown - offwhite head. Red berries, fruity, spicy, roasted, light flowery, medium malty, thin, ok carbnation.
Bottle. Pretty much no aroma or flavour. Slightly apple fruit flavours and not hell of a lot more. Very watery finish. Stale.
Cask Handpump at the Smithfield Hotel, Manchester 09/08/2001 Mid brown colour strong in alcohol and bitter. Malt finish.
(Cask-conitioned at Oliver Twist, Stockholm) Amber. Sweet aroma of toffee and vegetables. Toffee and coffee in flavour, hints of vegetables. Sweet malty finish.
Cask @ Akkurat, Stockholm Dark amber, firm head. Malty with some dark fruits present. A touch of toffee end this rather refreshing pint.
Cask at the Golden Eagle Beer Festival. Light malty and citrus aroma. Taste light sweet medium body.

Cask. Cavendish, Cartmel. Clear gold. Decent head of white suds. Nose has bready, sourdough like grain. Bit of a nettle leaf hop thing. Taste is dry and a little astringent. Some honey sweetness. Light body. Crisp carbonation. Light bitter finish. Ok. Not sure this is in the best nick.
