Bottle from booths, keswick. Aroma is sweet biscuity malts, notes of darker fruits. Taste is similar but actually reminds me of a not so hot whitbread pale ale.
Bottle at home... Golden orange ... little toffee malt aroma ... fruity malt ... soft ... little smokeyness.
Sampled cask conditioned at Queens Head Inn, Tirril, Cumbria. Deep golden. Fruity and really malty with a hint of figd. Full body, chewy. Salty finish with good bitterness.
Good beer quite a weak taste it's a smooth straw coloured bitter with a weak taste and aroma
Cask @ White Lion Inn, Patterdale. Golden with a smooth head. It's hoppy-floral, but mainly the former in taste, and the latter in its nose.

Cask at the White Lion Inn, Patterdale, Cumbria. Pale, slightly hazy gold with a large white head. Watery in texture with light apple and lemon flavours. A mild, dusty bitterness to finish. It's very, very bland.
500ml bottle from Rheged Services near Penrith. Pours golden with a thin white head. Aroma malt grain, hops citrus. Taste lemon with a dry bitter finish.
Cask in the Red Lion, Hawkshead. Golden with a white head. No aroma. Light citrus flavour. Very bland.
Cask. Golden ale with a slight haze. White thick head. Nose is fruity. Light oranges and lemons. Taste is a nice full fruit too - more oranges and lemon. Just a pleasant, drinkable pint.

On cask at Alexander ’s in Kendal. Appearance - golden amber with a decent head and a slight haze. Nose - lemon and honey. Some cereal. Taste - lemon barley water. Palate - light to medium bodied with a creamy yet tangy texture and a long dry finish. Overall - decent golden ale.

BCA. Pours quite flat, very pleasant clean gold colour. Low aroma, sulphury bitter palate, plenty of biscuit, quite lager-esque in the finish. As with most of HN’s beers, it doesn’t have a lot of body, but is an ideal summer quaffing beer.

Bottle, from the Local, Carlise, on the train from Inverness to Hereford 21/10/13. Lightly hazed golden with little in the way of a head. Nose is orange, grass, toasted malts. Taste comprises toasted, malt, grain, grass, light fruit. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, grassy bitterness in the finish. So so GB - one to forget !

Cask handpull, The Duke of Edinburgh Hotel, Barrow, Cumbria, 16/02/13. Straw piled with fine, foamy white. Nostrils of lime, grass and peanut butter hints. Slight, limey and clean with fennel and curry leaf hints. About the best golden ale I encountered in Cumbria, and in tip top condition.
Cask gravity at Planet Thanet BF 2015. Clear dark brown beer. Not much condition. Some dark toffee some chocolate. ok interpretation of a modern dark mild. Fine. Some malty interest.

Cask @ The London Bar, Llandudno [290115] Very dark brown, dense beige head Aroma of very soft roast, soft malts Taste of soft roast, dab of bitter plain chocolate, soft light bitter hops, bit dry bitter Palate - Thin body. Finish is a bit dry, soft bitter roast Overall - Rather too thin and weak, suffers due to the very low abv

Cask at the Anchor, Digbeth, Birmingham. Poured a clear dark brown with a bubbly off white head. The aroma is malt, yeast and lots of badness. The flavour is light bitter with a light watery malt yeasty, light medicinal palate. Light bodied with soft carbonation. Way too light and lacks body. It was approaching the end of the cask too.

Cask JDW Carlisle. I’m pleased that they persevere with this. Its a watered down version of the brewery’s bitter, with added caramel and you can tell. Nice rich roast aroma and taste, it lacks body, but at 3.1% that isn’t surprising. Not as sweet as it claims to be and I’m sure it had more depth a few years back. Will it survive much longer.....?
Cask at the brewery. Dark brown in colour. Raisins, caramel and some roasted notes in the aroma. Fruity, roasted and slightly sweet taste with raisins, caramel and cocoa detected.
Cask@manor arms, rushall. Dark brown beer with a large head. Aroma of roasted malts and toffee. Taste is toffee, roasted malts and some fruit. Ok beer.
Cask manor arms Walsall. Red brown colour decent beige head lacing. Aroma is fruity toffee malts. Taste is same slight sweetness mild bitterness. Medium body soft carbonated. Decent stuff

Hand-pulled pint in the front bar of Loggerheads, Shrewsbury on 19th Dec 13. Dark brown with a ruby hue, on top an off-white blanket of foam. Malts in the nose and taste: subtle (or weak depending on your stance) rather than strong or powerful. I had to re-visit the pump-clip to check the ABV, it wasn’t a surprise when I saw it was 3.1%. A bit too thin in every aspect/department: it lacks oomph and depth throughout.
Pint at the Loggerheads, Shrewsbury. Pours a coffee colour with a very mild cool taste. Ultimately rather tame with subtle liquorice and a hint of chocolate.

Gravity cask at the Bree Louise - London. Pours deep red-brown with little in the way of a head. Aroma holds mostly ripened dark fruits. Light sweet flavor with more ripe and dark fruit character, some hints of chocolate, a bit of dirty earth bitterness. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Nicely toasted malts to finish, dirt, charry leaves, dried and leathery fruits. Decent mild.

Bottle, from historic notes, sourced not recorded. Poured golden to amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of hops, caramel, light fruit. Moderate sweetness, medium plus bitterness. Moderate body, slight watery texture, soft carbonation.
Copper, slightly hazy with a nice head. The aroma has notes of fruit, caramel/malt. The flavour has notes of caramel, fruit and a hint of citrus in the relatively bitter finish.

pours light amber, fizzy with plenty of suds. nose citrussy and slightly resinous, a little metallic. refreshing piney hops and lightly toasted malt flavours, dry bitter finish. smooth and light on the palate. not bad at all.

Bottle -- Clear yellowy amber with large dense head with good retention and good lacing. Prominant aroma of malt and hops. Next to no carbonation (although my bottle is past its use-by date) and medium palate. The flavour is oh so English, with hops and malt again. Very nice beer.

500 ml bottle. Golden amber colour with a mostly lasting frothy off-white head. Toffee, bread, and fruity aroma. Starts acidic with some light caramel and bready malts, finishing with a lingering fruity and acidic bitterness. Medium bodied, lightly fizzy mouthfeel. Standard bottled English Bitter.
30 June 2006 - Light sweet biscuit malt and floral hop aroma. Brown-amber colour, good head and suds lacing. Big floral hop and lightt sweet flavour. big hop floral finish but too much for me.
Sweet hop malt aroma. Clear red brown colour with good head and lacing. Bitter hop malt flavour. Fizzy palate,

musky hops in the aroma. Very clear brew, yellow with a thin head. Good hoppy, wheat taste with a well balanced bitterness. Pleasant beer indeed. easy to drink, I would definitely drink this after climbing.

oxidised, slight woody hop aroma, slight caramel tone on the nose. Rich toffee and slight caramel taste, full medium bitterness, earthy tones. Not all that exciting. There are better examples of bitter out there.
Bottle. Amber colour with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel and hops
A nice malty flavor with hints of fruit. Good strong aroma of hops and malt. A little watery in texture. Weaker and fruitier beer than most Oktoberfests.

copper color , large foamy head. very hoppy aroma of pine and grapefruit. spicy and astringent taste. lots of hops in this but the malt if enough to moderate the bitterness. arguably the best ale at this brewpub

500 ml bottle. (Maruhn) Darmstadt, Germany. Enjoyed on Aug 9, 2019. Hazy golden color with a small to medium white head. Wheat, yeast, caramel, banana, sweetness and dryness in the aroma. Promising. The flavor is yeast, wheat, malt, mild bitterness, dryness and some banana and caramel sweetness. Very well balanced. Tasty. Rich for a 5.3% Weizen. Fizzy.

Pours hazy orange with a white head. Aroma has notes of bread, banana, clove and a hint of phenolic notes. Taste is bittersweet with bread and banana at first. Finishes with crispy clove, herbal and citrus flavours. Refreshing dryish aftertaste. Lively carbonation. A very tasty weissbier. (Poured from a 0,5 l bottle, bb21.12.19)

500 ml bottle. Hazy amber coloured, big foamy head. Bread, yeast, estery notes, banana, clove, some caramel, citrus. Mild dry bitterness. Medium bodied, milky texture, lively carbonated, dry finish. Good!

Schaum: praktisch keiner. Farbe: trüb orange Nase: leicht erdig, aber eher Richtung fruchtig Orange. Geschmack: Recht sauer im Mund, feinperlig, aber darunter schon die Hefe Breite, hier ziemlich Richtung Bitterorange. Hinten raus dann eher holzig. Eigentlich recht gut aber ohne schaum, gescheite Perlung und Banane muss man sagen, dass die Konkurrenz halt besser ist.

Trübes Orange mit mäßiger Schaumentwicklung. Herb-würziger und dezent fruchtiger Geruch. Zunächst spritzig mit viel lebendiger Kohlensäure, im Verlauf aber zunehmend lascher werdend. Harmloser Bananen-Nelkenmix von Light-Bier ähnlicher Intensität mit schwacher Hopfennote im Abgang. Wenn das das Paradestück des benannten Braumeisters ist, will man den Rest lieber missen...
500ml at home, Munich. Aroma is citrus and light banana. Appearance is cloudy orange with a thick, slightly brown foam. Taste is light sweet. Proper Weisse.
Bottle - pours gold with a white head . Aroma is straw, cloves and apples. Taste is mainly malty with only a little of the clove.
Bottle. Slightly hazy orange with white head. Aroma is DMS, veggies, touch of wheat. Taste is peaches, more DMS, not much wheat there. Fizzy carbonation. Not good.
A soft malty smell, some yeast. The small white fizzy head stays quite long. The body is golden. A malty, light bitter taste, the body is light and lively with a lot of carbonation.

courtesy of Thomas Krüsi - cloudy dark orange beer with a little foam left; solid aroma of cloves and straw, spicy; medium-bodied, solid carbonation, sweet, grainy, earthy and with a long aftertaste of cloves and ripe bananas

(Cask at Baltic Fleet, Liverpool). Dark golden colored, little yellow head. Aroma is rather thin with hops and some lemon, mild cardboard there also. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is as aroma: cardboard comes up, lemony tones in ending with some hoppy dryness. Nothing special.

(Cask at Baltic Fleet, Liverpool, 26 July) Golden colour with little head, Nose is fruity with orange peel, mandarin, apricots and canned peaches. Taste is fruity with peaches, mandarin and a spicy, flowery, a bit metallic, bitterness in the finish. Rather dry. Very nice and summery.
Cask conditioned at Baltic Fleet Liverpool. Badged as Wapping Summer Ale. Golden hoppy citrus beer with astringent acids
Cask @ Baltic Fleet, LiverpoolGold; malt-accented, subtle hop dryness; lightly woody with a delicate fruitiness like apple skins.

Cask. Aroma is chocolate, malt and a hint of caramel, tawny, pours a slim custard head. Flavour is also chocolate, malt a and toffee hints this time. Light bodied, well balanced, mildly sweet but most enjoyable. Very good example.

1/2 pint handpulled cask at The Baltic Fleet, Liverpool. Golden to amber color, white head. Aroma is weak malty, maybe with some hops. Flavor is malty (with hints of smoke?), a bit hops and bitterness. A bit thin bitter.

(Cask at Baltic Fleet, Liverpool). Yellow colored, slightly cloudy appearance. Little, thick white head. Nice bitter aroma with lemon, flowers and crispy hops. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is also crispy bitter with floral, even sour lemony tones. Nice lace in glass.

1. Cask Handpump at the Baltic Fleet, Liverpool 22/11/2001 Amber golden coloured with some wheat flavour. Slightly bitter dry hop finish. (Passageway Wapping Bitter) 2. Cask Handpump at the Baltic Fleet, Liverpool 21/02/2002 Amber coloured with some malt aroma. Dry slightly bitter finish. (Wapping Bitter) 3. Cask Stillage at the Community Centre, Frodsham 25/05/2002 Amber golden coloured with some sour fruit aroma. Hop finish. (Wapping Bitter)
Beer No 5 on the Wilsons’ Road Trip 2005. Cask at The Old Harkers Arms, Chester. Pale golden. Citrus hop aroma with good hoppy kick to finish. Tasty.
Badged simply as Wapping Bitter at Baltic Fleet, Liverpool. Pale yellow session bitter with plentyof hops and citrus fruit. Could be quite astringent unless you like really hoppy acidic beers
[Cask conditioned] Pale amber coloured. A very mild bitter. Not very bitter. Some sourness.

GBBF 2003: Farty, sulfur nose - geez, this can't be good. Light amber color, foamy head. Egg-like malty body. Huge scratchy bitterness in the back of the throat - goes down like sandpaper. Off balance. No likey.
GBBF 2003: Overwhelming skunky nose. Little foamy head, golden colo. Thin - silky and smooth - with a short bitter kick. Goes by fast.

Cask Conditioned at The Baltic Fleet, Liverpool. Now produced by Wapping Brewery at The Baltic Fleet. A light reddy brown beer with a white head. Thin malty flavour, sweet biscuit in character then a lingering ash taste.

Half-pint, cask ale at Flying Horse Hotel. Covering white head, spotty lacing, clear golden body. Aroma of grainy fruits. Bread and dried fruity flavours. Hop fruity ending. Standard Brit blonde. (Watching TV football with Leif, Rochdale 05.05.2018).

Cask conditioned at The Post Office Vaults, Birmingham. Gold with white head. This proved to be quite a malty beer, cereal notes, grainy with a simple, floral hop note. Fairly basic and just okay really.
Cask at JDW. Dark golden shade. White head and lacing. Grassy and waxy hoppy feel. Crisp, fruity and bitter ending. Nothing standout, but a decent quaffer.

Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) A clear golden colour with a medium white head. Aroma of bready malt, grain, slight fruit, a little apricot, a hint of lemon and grapefruit zest, mint and some grassy, floral hops. Taste of bready malt, grain, slight fruit, a little apricot, lemon, a hint of minty freshness and some grassy, floral hops. Light bodied and soft carbonation. A dry, grassy, floral hop bitterness in the finish. Bready and grainy malt up front with the sweetness coming through near the end with the bitter finish. A fruity, slightly minty middle. Different and drinkable.
Cask @ The Three Fishes, Shrewsbury. Pours clear golden amber, white head. Light floral hop aroma. Taste is fairly light, faint fruit a bit of breadiness, but generally rather lacklustre.
Middle of the road taste wise looks look creamy body quaffable on fraught at cask and feather rochdale
Cask @ The Old Horse, Leicester. Deep gold colour. It's a malty pale ale- pretty much a standard middle of the road example. It's ok but nowt special like. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in Jan 2013 - Yellowy Gold in colour. Very Fruity; grapefruit and tangerine. Hoppy; grassy and some pine. Malty; toasty malts. Nicely balanced. Moderately bitter citrus fruity hoppy. Dry bitter finish. Liked this. Very drinkable.
Golden with a bubbly head and a floral berry aroma. Has a small berry taste.

Cask at Town Street Tavern, Horsforth. Pours a very clear pale gold with a good white head and lacing. Grapefruit and floral hops on the nose, following through with light toasted malt flavours on the taste. Very nice.

Gravicask at The Bricklayers Arms Lancashire Fest, 15th Sept 2007. Dark brown with no head. Manages to smell of alcohol despite the low strength. Roasted malt taste but the palate is rather thin. Forgettable.
Cask @ The Bricklayer’s Arms, Lancashire Beer Festival. Deep amber with no head. Some smokey malts, hops and an odd panzarotti (fried calzone) character. Strange.

A Mes rate: Gravicask at The Bricklayers Arms Lancashire Fest. Dark chestnut colour with no head. Roasted malt aroma with slight sulphur and a little sourness. Thin appley flavour with not much body. Nothing special.

Cask conditioned at The Dun Cow Winter Beer Fest ’07. Dark brown with thin tan head. A thin, dry mild with hints of chocolate malts and touches of bitterness. Slightly sharp with a tangy note. Nice little starter to the fest.
Cask Stillage at the Upper Campfield Market Hall, Manchester 24/01/2002 Black slightly fruity and bitter. Earthy aromas and a roast finish.
Dark brown; smokey, slightly sour; toasty...................................

Rediscovered rating found on a scrap of paper. Some time in March 2004 (same time as Barnsley Bitter from the same brewery). Venue unknown. Not that pale. More like mid-amber. Fairly bitter, but tempered by plenty of juicy fruit. More on the palate than in the aroma. A decently balanced best bitter. After going bust for the sixth time it looks like we have finally seen the last of the Barnsley/Blackpool set up as the kit was sold to Acorn.
Cask Handpump at the Helter Skelter, Frodsham 02/09/2001 Amber coloured beer with some pale malt and a bitter hoppy finish.
Cask at Head of Steam, Liverpool Mid brown hoppy, matly flavour leads to dry hop finish. Great balance of fruity malt and dry hoppiness. First Blackpool beer I have tried and I was impressed

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London. Called BPA. Amber, bright and in wonderful condition, with a foaming white head. Hoppy fruity aroma but slightly maltier then others. Fruity, hoppy flavour that many things but mostly refreshing and charming.
Dark amber; fruity, lots of hops, honeydew, guava...nice stuff. Sampled at the Ship & Mitre, Liverpool.
Amber, sweet, slight caramel note. A really slight beer....................
Cask@Shackerstone Family Festival MMV, Leicestershire. Pale beer with a cinnimon bitter aroma and a well hopped flavour with a bitter finish. Overall a nice beer that is more complex than the norm.
Cask at the Swan in the Rushes, Loughborough. Pale, golden looking beer, quite hoppy with fruit flavours. Very drinkable, but a bit thin. I prefer Archer’s Golden.
Golden; minerally; rich hoppiness, lots of fruit flavours as well. Impressive and quenching.
Cask Handpump at the Mill Hotel, Chester 12/08/2002 Golden colour creamy on the palate and slightly pale. Some malt and hops in the finish.
Golden; lightly fruity; minerally, good pale malt character.................
same as Carden’s IPA - not really an IPA, more of a strong pale ale, not enough hop for IPA

i wonder if the name indicates that this is some sort of hybrid between an IPA and an Irish Red? anyway, not a lot of hops in evidence: more like an extra strong fruity bitter. very clear dark red colour. whiff of black bananas, or my old chess set. tastes uncannily like glace pineapple chunks marinated in bovril. spicy brown sugary finish.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On draught at Widmer Gasthaus. Dark amber in color. Smooth alcohol warming with taste of roasted malt, pit fruit, and faint chocolate.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Pours a copper brown color with a big off-white beige head. has a caramel aroma. The beer produces a great malt syrup bolus. The sweetness is then smoothed out by at great bitter hop palate. This has a phenomenal mouth feel. The best beer poured here.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: what is in my mouth? roasted malt thinned with water, whiskey, dark cheries & maybe a stray cigarette butt. aroma of roasted malt, dark syrup (sans maple.) dark brown with ruby highlights, no head. great in the mouth--- numbing the tongue and all around. a good intensity, but hte pieces dont fit together

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: 1/19/08 On draught at the Portland brewhouse. Aroma is smoky, malt-forward, with no hop character and some dark fruit character in the background. Appearance is amber/brown with a very low head. Flavor is rich, sweet and fruity, with malt dominance followed by moderate flora-free bittering and a low alcoholic note. Mouthfeel is medium/high bodied with medium carb texture and good alcoholic warmth. Overall, great complexity, but probably wouldn’t go for more than one.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: tap at the Widmer brew pub... dark ruby color with brown head. presence of alcohol, malt and sweetness maybe from chocolate. very complex but very drinkable.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On Tap At Widmer Brothers brewery/pub in Portland OR. pours out a nice rich brown topped with a tan head. A little bit of sweet of caramel.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On tap at the Widmer Gasthaus, Portland brewhouse.Smells amazing. Tons of malty sweetness that oozes with caramel and raisins. Even the most vigorous pour only produced a thin ring that I wouldn’t even call head. The beer is dark brown in color with a ruby glow. The lack of carbonation in this beer is almost to the point of flat, and it makes for a dissapointly watery mouthfeel. It isn’t as sweet as the aroma suggests, but then that’s not such a bad thing. There is plenty of caramel and toffee flavors up front. Towards the end there is a bit of alcohol and a faint bitterness that is more astringent then hop induced. A decent doppelbock with an amazing aroma.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On tap at the Widmer Gasthaus, Portland brewhouse. Poured a dark chocolate brown, with a good tan head. Coffee and chocolate Great palate, almost like oil. This was by far my favorite, and wish is was available in bottles in my hometown. A real winner.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: This was not bad. Brown with some ruby highlights, and a nice creamy head and some sticky lacing. A little bit of herbaly sweetness right up front followed by some stick chocolate and caramel. Strong oily mouthfeel, not bad, not my favorite, but still well made.

column4: Widmer Brothers Brewing Company (Craft Brew Alliance - AB InBev)
column5: On tap at the tap house. Pours deep cherry red with a fast falling white head. Sweet malt aroma with chocolate and caramel. The first taste I noticed was some cocoa up front followed with a rich caramel body, some nice weight on the palate showed the thicker body of this beer. Very well balanced but fairly mild doppelbock.
Cask Stillage at Lewisham Theatre, Catford 14/06/2001 Amber coloured and malty. Smooth and rich on the palate.
Fresh, Brittania Cafe, Rochester. Crap. Disgusting. Cheap quality. Thin. Soapy. Dreadful. Couldn't finish it. Never will I drink another Old Kent beer. Shudder.

el dodgissimo microbitter. very scarily tangy, lemony hop flavours like lemon detergent drown thin milo flavoured malt. very thin, acidic and unpleasant. but gets an extra impression point for being cricket-related.
Can. Blonde. Citrus, dried fruit and soft floral notes in the aroma and flavor. Sweet, kruidkoek

Keg at the Rake, 06/11/19. Pale yellow with a decent white head. Nose gives off a good bourbon waft, caramel, light fruit esters, alcohol, candied fruits. Taste comprises caramel, stewed fruits, sugar cane, good bourbon rip, prunes, light spice. Medium plus bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with a balanced rising boost. Not a bad sipper ... all comes in well below the hefty ABV but perhaps also lacking depth for a 11% jobbie ?!

Cask conditioned at Harbury Beer Festival '19, Warks. Hazy gold with white head. Boozy alcohol to the fore with this from the off, burning, peachy flavours. Bitter and dry, quite raw in character but it's fine.

Appearance- Hazy light golden colour with weak white foam. Aromas- Sweet and hoppy with notes of pine, resin and tropical fruits such as pineapple and passionfruit with touch of light malts and dust. Palate- Full bodied with thick mouth coating texture leaving warming boozy finish. Taste- Alcohol with hoppy grapefruitiness and pineapple with some more alcohol. Overall- Eh, basically, boozy IPA.

Typical cloudy colour. Aroma is if you imagine melted Haribo sweets. Taste is very tropical with pineapple, mandarine, sweet lemon and fuckloads of barley sugar, Finish is lovely and sweet with a bit of a weird taste like a latex condom (not that I would know). Almost better than eating pussy.
330ml can. Pours hazy gold with a thin head. Aroma is toffee, caramel and mango hop. Taste has sticky toffee and citrus to start. Sherbet and toffee finish. Mango aftertaste. Tangy.
Can from Cotteridge Wines; clear golden yellow pour with a bubbly off white head, aroma has lemon and sweet malts, taste has sweet malts, slight citrus hop action
Golden colour with light haze. Aroma and flavour have a lot of candied sugar. Mega sweet and boozy with candied orange peel and citrus syrup.
Tap @Stoneworks,Peterborough. Burnt orange,slightly hazy. Nose - sweet,citrus/tropical fruit,honey. Taste - sweet,citrus and honey notes.
keg at the hanging... Golden.. Thin white lacing.. Soft sweet caramel toffee fruit.. Light spangles fruits nose... Soft juicy sweet caramel toffee fruit juicy sweet toffee caramelised fruits
the least good of the mediocre haake beck line. I didnt even realize it was wheat beer til i thought about the name.
Draft. Very malty, deep yellow color. Hop presence dominates, with a smooth, hoppy, honeyish finish. I'll stack this one against Pilsner Urquell any day.
Really impressive. Pilsener fans try this beer, and i tell you that you will enjoy it. Golden, smooth, and great flavor I thoroughly enjoyed it
Light golden body, little head. Medium/thin malts were sweet. medium hops created a very nice long dry finish. the only thing lacking was crispness.

Wow! This may be the worst one yet. The nose reeks of cheap alcohol. Pours from tab dishwater brown with a small brown head. Taste has a faint pruniness but doesn’t linger and doesn’t improve as it warms. It’s very thin and it doesn’t wear it’s 10% very well. Recommended only for people you can’t stand to see happy.

Cask at the brewpub. Aroma of toffee and earth, not much else. Flavor of sweet malt, nougat, orange and red fruits with some citrus notes. Only had a bit of this, was hard to tell if the sweetness in it would be wearing over a full glass, but it was pretty good for me.

On cask at the brewpub. Pours brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of sweet malt--medicinally sweet-- and acetone. Flavor is very very sweet with some sourness and booziness too. Not terrible but it’s good good either. Much too sweet. 6/4/6/3/12 (3.1/5)

Tap @ the pub. Poured a very deep chestnut brown color with thin off-white head. Fruity sweet malt aroma. Fruity flavor with notes of grape, cherry, and prunes. Medium bodied. Dry bmoderately bitter finish. Warming but otherwise hidden alcohol.

On tap at the Barley Creek Brew Pub. 2001 Vintage. Poured a deep/dark brown color with a very small sized off white head. Aromas of toffee, dark fruits, lightl smoke and light chocolate. Tastes of chocolate, hard toffee candy, some dark fruits, and tart grapes. Sweet with a ightly tart and sour finish. Alcohol content well hidden.

tulip at the brewpub. Very dark brown in color- almost looks like an English Old Ale, or something similar. Aroma is dark fruit, oxidized malts as well as some wild (sour) notes. Taste is oxidized malts, sour fruits, some nasty funk, and alcohol. I guess this one didn’t age too well, vintage 2001.

on tap-pours a light tan head and brown color. Aroma is dark/medium malt-dark fruit. Taste is dark medium malt- dark fruit/fermented cherry. Comes across as a mild, malty Kriek lambic/Flemish Sour Ale. Mild carbonation.

Revised rating 11/1/2008. On tap at Barley Creek. I’m sorry, but this is not the same beer I loved and enjoyed the last time I had it two years ago. While there is still an ample amount of fruit, this beer lacks the richness and silky mouthfeel that made this beer a standout for me. I don’t know if this is just an old keg or if there were strorage issues, but there is definitely some oxidation present, especially towards the finish. I also noticed some mild oxidation in my wife’s Wanderlust Chocolate Porter, which I know is a very fresh batch that was just released, so perhaps it is a quality control issue. In any event, I was disappointed with this year’s edition and hope future editions are improved.

Original rating 8/29/2006. On tap at Barley Creek. Served in a small brandy glass. Pours a very deep reddish brown with virtually no head. Holding the glass up to the light, there is just enough light passing through to see the color of this brew. Wonderful aroma of plums and raisins. The flavor follows the aroma with lots of plum and raisins. Not at all bitter. The alcohol is very well hidden and there is no bite at all. Very smooth and luxurious beverage. A winner! 8-4-8-5-16.

Draft Pours a clear brown red with very little head. Has a sweet aroma with subtle malts. Taste is sweet with a good flavor and a decent finish. Not much carbonation but not flat either. Has a good duration. Hides the high abv pretty well.

tap at the brewpub, pour is a caramel color with a thick creamy head. body of the beer is viscous as it clings to the walls of the snifter. aroma is full of caramel malts and maple sugar, there are some flowery hops and a slight scotch scent. flavors progress from grassy hops up front, through the malts and end up with the maple/scotch flavors. each mouthfull was smooth and creamy, with no hint of the nearly 10%v abv. if it were a little thicker, it would have been utterly fantastic, but there was a little bit of wateryness in the mouthfeel which knocked off a couple points
Light gold; watery, fizzy, bland. Given that you can't buy it in any serious Okells pub, but you can get it at the ferry terminal, I guess the rating isn't that big a surprise.

Cask pint, hand pulled in my local Wetherspoon's pub on 12th April 2018. Golden body, slight mistiness in my glass, white head. Fairly bitter from start to finish with some earthy hop esters and flavours. Passed it's best I should imagine, so scored it objectively and kindly.

On cask at the very neat Devil's Advocate micropub in Middlesbrough, served by a marvellously welcoming landlady/barlady. A lovely blonde bitter with a smooth texture and well balanced flavour of hops and malt. Went down very well.
Bottle 10 at cropredy 2017 Saturday. Amber.. Thin white lacing...Soft sweet caramel toffee malts nose... Soft caramel cream crystals toffee malts.. Tiny cardboard tones
From cask. Pours dark orange to hazzlenut brown with a small white head. Aroma is toffee, butterish and herbal hoppy. Bitter, butterish and dry malty. Herbal. Bitter and dry into the far finish.
Cask@st matthews hall, walsall. Golden amber beer with small head and patchy lacing. Aroma is faint malts. Taste is malts, biscuit and cereal grain. Not great but ok overall.
Cask - light amber with a thin white head. Aroma of white wine, sweet malts and yeast. Taste of malts, light roasted, a little fruit and smoke. Light body.
Cask. Orange, hazy, very small bubbly white head. Aroma is caramel, orange. Body is light, slightly foamy. Taste is tangy, cheesy malt.

Cask at the Wellington, Birmingham. Poured a clear medium amber with a frothy white head. The aroma is malt, citrus barnyard caramel. The flavour is medium bitter with a big malt, grapefruit citrus hop bitter palate and a short bitter finish. Medium to light bodied with soft carbonation. I’ve never had a bitter quite like this before I must say. Lots of flavour and really refreshing.
Pours a blonde colour, taste is Belgian like, quite like a Belgian white beer, nice, but not really sessionable
Cask @ Fox & Goose, Hebden Bridge. Golden with a bubbly head. It’s a higher bitterness ale with a malt aroma.

12th May 2012 saw me on a pub crawl of Shrewsbury: Mild in May is a CAMRA thing, so I had one every time I saw one (or tried too). Hand pulled pint in ‘The Coach and Horses’: dark brown body with a beige head. The aromas given off were of roasted/toasted malts, caramel and other semi-sweet molasses, almost burnt smell at times. Rich is the wrong word, but this was full of flavour: over cooked malts being the main taste, they in turn reminded me of ground coffee, dark chocolate and malt loaf. Another good beer from a fine brewery
cask at southampton arms ... coffee roast light malt nose ... light coffee roast .... little thin ... dark malts ok
Can’t remember that much about this beer, so might have to revisit and rerate it at somepoint, however what I do remember was a smoked sausage kind of taste which combined with beer is excellent

Cask conditioned handpump Wellington Birmingham. A black beer with an off-white head. I’ve not been impressed by a Slaters beer for many a year, but this was good. A roasty aroma with liquorice and arrowroot. Good bitterness and burnt malts in the mouth with abit of veg for good measure. An impressive mild.

From the barrel, pours a deep brown. Nice burnt caramel & malt on the nose. Palate has nice hit of dark malts, & a light juicy finish. I’m not a massive fan of milds, but this has pleasant flavour & is a refreshing pint. There may be a slight metallic undercurrent, but it’s very light & doesn’t ruin the experience.

cask @ the tap in wim village. delicate dark chocolate, treacle and bread nose. Darkest ruby red in colour, lacy white head. Flavours of malt, coffee and bread, but generally rather dull and thin bodied. salty finish. gentle drinkable bitter.

[i] [b] Cask at the Lamb and Flag, Oxford, 01-06-08 [/i] [/b] Pours dark brown with slim white head a few ruby glints catch in the light of the window. I could smell the caramel as this was being poured so came as no surprise that the main aroma that I could sell was caramel. Some caramel and dark fruits blend together nicely in the mouth but to be honest it was a bit thin, also served slightly too warm which wasn’t so helpful, but ok.

Cask (Peterborough Beer Festival 2004) Dark brown, thin head. Pleasantly hopped for a mild - clearly some cuts through the otherwise caramel malty aroma. A paradox - quite a simple taste but with a complex balance of roasted malt and hops. Very well balanced, and excellent for only 3.4%.
Cask Handpump at the Monkey, Crewe 17/06/2001 Dark colour and smooth on the palate. Fruity blackcurrant flavours.

A notebook audit yields four beers that I hadn’t entered up to now. Can’t say where or when I had them, except that it was some time in 2005. A fairly standard, easy drinking, mild, with a bit of roast malt but not much else. But let’s not forget that it is a mild and that’s what a lot of them are intended to be.

Cask Conditioned handpump Market Porter London. A golden beer with a whitish ring of bubbles. A bit sweet of nose but quite plain. There is a dirty water like taste to this with yeast and bruised fruit. Pretty poor.
Golden with a small white head. Grassy aroma with a hint of malt. Dry and fruity flavour.
Cask at GBBF08. Almost clear golden colour. Nicely nutty flavour, slightly fruity. Not very complicated, but quite enjoyable.

A Mes rate: Gravicask at GBBF. Gold with no head. Sweet and watery bready malt all round. Finishes swiftly with little fuss which in all honesty is a good thing. Very low in flavour and what there is is not good.
Cask. Low and quickly disappearing white fluffy head. Clear golden body. Mild honey barley malt aroma. Watery thin fruity flavor with little hops bitterness, low carbonation and a short aftertaste.
Cask (GBBF 2008) - Golden in colour. Malty and slightly gassy aroma Gassy and malty taste with some grain and citrus. Slightly disappointing.
Clear golden with tiny off white head. Sweet fruity aroma with caramel notes. Flavor is similar. Ends sweet.
Cask at GBBF 2007. A golden beer with no head. The aroma is sweet malty with light notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet malty with a slight artificial fruit note. The body is watery - just not me.

Clear golden ale with close to green reflections. Lasting white cover tops it all. Very strawy malt character meets pretty weak hops and can’t help, but making the ensemble feeling quite watery and kinda bland. Light-bodied. Simply not much to say about it.

Cask @ GBBF 2007, London. Clear medium yellow color with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, bread, light hoppy, thinner (the bad way). Flavor is light to moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat.
Cask at GBBF 2010. A hazy golden beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and lemons. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and elderflowers, leading to a dry bitter finish. Boring.

Cask @ GBBF 2010, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear medium orange color with virtually none head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, fruity, orange - citrus. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20100805]

Cask@GBBF2010. Golden colour, not much head. Aroma is nectar, some wood, mild fruityness as well as some slight honey and quite herbal notes. Flavour is fruits, wood, some mild sweet sugary notes. Ends in a quite wooden and grassy bitterness.
From cask. Pours cloudy orange with a with a small white head. Aroma is mild herbal and grassy. Sweet malty, light caramelish and slight citrusy. Slight herbal from back of the nose.

1. Cask Stillage at the Town Hall, Stockport 31/05/2001 Pale and fruity. Slightly hoppy finish. 2. Cask Stillage at the Victory Hall Mens Club, Mobberley 27/07/2003 Amber golden colour with some wheat flavour. Slightly dry full malt finish. 3. Cask Handpump at the GBBF, Earl’s Court 05/08/2010 Fruity aroma. Golden bronze coloured and fruity with an apple flavour. A hint of dryness in a malt finish.
Sampled cask conditioned at GBBF. Deep golden. Very sweet and lightly fruity. Strange watery finish.

Third of a cask pint at the Scottish Real Ale Festival in Edinburgh’s Corn Exchange on 7th July 2017. Really disappointed with this beer having loved everything else ( I think ) I have had from Traquair House. This was watery and weak in all aspects, nearly took it back! Scored kindly.

1/3 pint Edinburgh real ale festival 2015. Pours medium almond amber with a thin thin white head subsiding slowly. Scent is bitter bitter with nut, almond hints. Resin. Taste is medium caramel and toffee character with bitter and smoky finish. Great.
Cask at SRAF. Clear orange. Aroma is sweet caramel, overripe fruits. Taste is sweetish, a bit boozy, stuffy caramel. Meh.
Cask at SRAF. Pours copper, nose is caramel, apple, taste is sweet, thin, light fruit.

Cask at Cloisters. It pours clear deep amber-brown with a medium yellow-white head. The nose is toasted brown, grainy, mild caramel, earth and wood. The taste is smooth, toasted grain, brown, wood and leather with a dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Simple malt-driven job. OK, but probably their poorest offering.

Cask at Scottish Real Ale Festival 2014. Clear caramel body with a thin off-white head. Light lacing. Aroma of earth, heather and Hobnob biscuits. Flavour of caramel, grass and biscuit. Thin body with an oily mouthfeel. Faint carbonation prickle. Well balanced - quite plain, but very nice.
Cask at The Scottish Real Ale Festival 2014. Pours clear amber, thin off-white head. Aromas of caramel and apples, light sugar. Taste is sweet. Finishes clean enough. Bit boring to be honest.
Cask @ Troon beer Festival. Reddish amber brown, decent head. Dry grain malt aroma. Dry grain flavour. Watery with bitter aftertaste. Bland, just drinkable.
Cask by handpump at Troon Beer Festival - clear dark amber, no head, mild raisin, malty aroma, raisin toffee, very thin texture, peculiar aftertaste

A very simple beer: malty, caramel in front, middle and finish, with a smooth palate and a classic rich golden color. Fine; not fancy or flashy, and it didn’t really appeal much to me. (cask at Scottish Real Ale Festival, Edinburgh, June 2012)
Clear very dark brown, fizzy head, gone in a second. Roasted malt, caramel and coffee aroma. Sourish, roasted flavour, late hints of smoke. Dry. Not good.
Bottle - Glencoe Wild Oat Stout. Dark brown with red finish but little head. Good stout aroma, ok mouthfeel. Slightly smokey tasting, bit sweet finish and some fruit aftertaste. Not a classic stout.
Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.

Bottle. As "Traditional Scottish Ales Glencoe Wild Oat Stout" - Black in colour. Roasty chocolate aroma. Malty; toasty (mildly roasty) oatmeal malts, creamy milky chocolate, coffee, caramel. Sweetish malty chocolate flavour throughout. Full flavoured. Very tasty. Smooth. Mild (not harsh). Sessionable. Very Nice Stout! (2011-10-11)

Bottle. Black body with a thin beige head. Good lacing. Aroma of porridge, coffee and smoke. Flavour of coffee, roasted malt, ash and chocolate. Medium body with a smooth, velvety texture. A tasty, ashy Stout.
Bottle from Cocktail’s, Littleborough as TSA Wild Oat Stout. Black with no head. It’s not quite full, but its roasted malt is more than evident in both aroma and taste.
Dark liquid. Thin light brown foam. Strong charcoal malt scent. A bit thin. Trace of tin noted in nose. Kind of disappointing.
Pours an opaque black with a brown head. Rich coffee aroma with a hint of hops. Taste is a rich coffee malt but with a very mild finish.
Bottle at home. Pours black, nose is oaty, light roast, taste is sweet chocolate.
Looks good. Not so great on the nose. Malty, liquorice, dark chocolate, cloves, smokey. Could have been really good but a bit thin and lacking depth to be truly great. Shame.
On tap @...somewhere in Scotland I really liked this stout. Very drinkable, ashy, some burned wood, light malts

Cask (4.1%), 1/2 pint by hand-pump at Alloa Real Ale Festival 2017, Town Hall, Alloa on 28 Oct 2017: sweet malty aroma, opaque dark chestnut brown with a thin short-lived fawn head and no lacing, earthy, roast malt flavour with a bit of liquorice, oily, earthy malty finish.
Cask at SRAF 2011. Pours black, nose is roasted malts, chocolate, taste is roasted, bitter, dry.
Scotland: Thistly Cross Beer fest. Simple, straightforward, and ultimately boring.

Cask at the Halfway House, Edinburgh - 08/12/12. Dark black with a thin tan head that recedes to the edge of the glass and leaves a film. Nose is a little subdued, cardboard, light malt, metallic tones, touch of the vinegars, not great! Taste comprises light roast malt, touch of chocolate, liqourice, molasses, light dark fruit notes, a little nutty. Medium bodied, softish on the carbonation front, dry finish. Pretty average.
Very nice and robust brown head, the body is black. The taste is soft, a bit roasty coffee-bitter, but also to mild. Aftertaste is roasty-bitter. Overall medium. 12/10/10/9/-/9
At the pub. Traditiona dark stout, large white head. Aroma of muted roast malt, chocolate notes. Full body, flavour of treaclish malt and a dry, smooth finish.
6th August 2009 GBBF Cask. Very dark brown beer, clear. Very light malt with lactose sweetness. Light and semi dry finish. Minerals. A very easy going light stout - well porter really!

First tasted this at the Winter Beer Festival, Glasgow in September 1996. Cask, handpump dispense. Dull black in colour with a dark tan coloured head. Strong roast coffee and vanilla fudge in the long aroma. Very thick mouthfeel and poor lacing. Dark malts deliver a strong treacle sponge base with sweet molasses, chocolate and mocha notes. Slight prickle of dusty hops but this is lost in the thick chewy aftertaste. Malted toffee and liquorice noted in the heavy finish. Surprisingly thick for 4.1% and the solid texture reminded me of Youngers No 3. Maybe not one for a session but still highly recommended.

Cask at GBBF 2010. A pitch black beer with a thin brown head. The aroma has notes of sweet and some roasted malt. The flavor is sweet malty with light notes of roasted malt and soy sauce, leading to a dry finish.
Cask@Criterion, Leicester. Brown beer with a sweet and dry aroma and a sweet and vinous flavour. Overall an average beer.
Cask Stillage at Edgeley Park, Stockport 04/06/2004 Mid brown coloured and smooth on the palate. Slightly dry hoppy malt finish.

A dark brown mild with a dense white head. Aromas are light and floral with chocolate. Flavours are chocolate allied to a fair level of hopping. Floral and fruity - a decent mild. Anglo Dutch are producing some good beers.
Gravity Dispense - White Horse Hedgerley BF. A black beer with the typical fruity mild ale aroma. there is some nice roastiness in the taste but it is all a little bit too thin. Drinkable though.
Sampled cask conditioned at GBBF. Deep ruby. Grapefruity hop aroma. Very dry with lingering orangey flavours leading to a bitter finish. Elegant and tasty.
Cask at the heriot watt beer festival. Pours deep reddish brown, nose is roasted, lemon, toffee, taste is sweet, roasted, fruity, spiced.

Cask. Hazy brown color with creamy beige head. Aroma is lots of exotic spices, coriander, fruity too. Taste is lots of coriander, grains of paradise, chocolate, earthy-herbal. Silky mouthfeel with low carbonation. Lots of character, lots of great exotic spices, and supremely drinkable, I love it! Extra points for character.
Cask taste at GBBF 2018. Pours black brown with an off white head. Aroma of roast malt and vegetables. Sweet taste and finish.
Pendle Beer Festival 2018. Dark ale that's not overly spicy, mainly a mild sweetness for me.
Pint @Bridge Hotel in Newcastle. Dark, but not totally opaque. Little head. Chocolate and spice, coriander. Nice beer ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask at Jerusalem Tavern. Darkest brown in color with a small tan head. Lots of coriander on the aroma, coffee and anise backing it up. Flavor is slightly sweet, slightly bitter, roast and a bit of chocolate, loads of coriander. If you don’t like coriander/bedbug flavor, you shouldn’t have ordered this. And yes, bedbugs are known to smell like coriander. Sorry for ruining coriander for you forever. Medium feel, soft carbonation. Not bad considering what this is supposed to be.
Cask. Dark Brown in colour. Tasty roast malty porter. Chocolate, caramel and coffee notes. Spicy (coriander). Hoppy balance. Nice pint. (2008)

Handpull cask at the Three Horseshoes, Stapleford. Very dark brown with lilting shades of purple. A ring of khaki head. Strong herbal note with some coriander and cress. Lovely taste: milky and chocolately with a gorgeous sweet liquorice note. The coriander adds a bit of balance to what may have otherwise been an overly sweet taste. Old Growler is one of my favourite cask porters, and the herbal note adds an unexpected complexity to it.

On tap at the Cardinals Hat Lincoln. Deep cola almost black colour with a thick cream light tan head. Aroma spicy and light roasted malt. Taste roasted bitter and citrus with a touch of caramel sweet. Medium body.

Very dark with no head. Minerally and malt aroma complemented with coriander, but the flavor is much stronger than the aroma. Rich and slightly burnt, very spicy. Smooth bodied and not too heavy. Quite pleasing.
Sampled cask conditioned at GBBF. Dark black. Dry, extremely roasty and oaty. Medium bodied with bitter, salty finish. Similar to, but by far more flavourful than, another stout with a similar name.

Adriaen Brouwer’s precursor, one of those remnants of a time when every brewery in and around Oudenaarde made this type of beer; basically ’oud bruin’ without the bacterial fermentations which typify the West-Flemish variant. Bronze colour, thin, off-white head, caramelly profile with some candi, dried fruits, dough; earthy and yeasty taste, sweetish, even a bit sugary but in a good way, smooth, but thin mouthfeel. Honest and old-fashioned - who can have anything against that? Doesn’t age very well, though.
Pours clear , dark redbrown . Small white head . Smell is sweet , fruity . Taste is sweet , spices ( coockies ) , oak , fruits , cola-likeherbs taste .
Brown, small head. Aroma of caramel and dried fruit. A bit sweet, a bit sour and a bit metallic.

Bottle @ Delirium Cafe. BB 2006. Clear dark reddish brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dark malts and oxidated. Flavor is quite sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. Shame on Delirium Cafe for serving such an old beer to a customer when it clearly isn’t meant to be cellared. 190712

26/VI/2012 - 25cl bottle from Rotsaert (Zedelgem) @ home - BB: 12/XII/11 (2012-656) Clear ruby red to brown beer, small beige head, unstable, adhesive. Aroma: little sweet, some caramel, bit nutty, toast, some dried fruits. MF: soft carbon, medium to light body. Taste: caramel, a bit sour, little metallic, some dried fruits, slightly hoppy. Aftertaste: chocolate, some caramel, dried fruits, overripe banana.
Pours a nice medium brown color. Aromas of light nut, some vegtable. Flavor is bitter, watery, with light touches of nuts and malts.

(25cl bottle best by 7-18-2011 thanks to bu11zeye) clear ruby/brown with excellent lacing and a fine tan head. Nose of florals, raisins, and herbal. Taste is very sweet, toasty, raisins and some cherry.

Das Bier beginnt mild malzig und leicht cremig, dabei spielt der süßliche Unterton eine große Bedeutung. Diese verschwindet zwischenzeitlich hinter einem malzigen Ton, kehrt aber im Nachgeschmack wieder zurück. Besonders im Nachgeschmack wirkt das Bier dabei aber etwas eintönig, eine auflockernde Fruchtigkeit wäre hier angebracht. So reicht es zum Mittelmaß. Test vom 22.9.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,9,9,8,9,8 - 8,35
(25cl bottle) Pours a clear amber body with a small off-white head. Aroma of candi sugar, yeast, raisins, and caramel. Flavor of raisins, yeast, earth, and brown sugar with a somewhat dry finish.
bottle, clear amber color with a sweet fruit aroma, flavor is wine and fruit punch with a metallic finish
Draft at the brewpub. Pours a cloudy gold. Muddled taste. Light hops, lemon, almost a mushroom taste at times. Not my thing.

Pours a cloudy yellow with a thin white head. Light fruit aroma. Flavor is all hops. Grapefruit, orange, lemon. I don’t know if this is a golden ale or not but it was damn refreshing. Finishes bitter. Good.
It's a decent blonde but their Scottish is so damned good, I seldom bother with this one. A nice herbaceous hoppy bite to it.
Pite w Hagatna w browarze restauracyjnym z kija. Kolor jasny orange, lekko zmętniony, piana niezbyt mocna. Aromat owocowy z przewagą cytrusów. W smaku wyczuwalne drożdże. Lekkie piwo na upały
Leicht dunkles gelb, schöner schaum herb fruchtiger Duft im Geschmack grasig leicht fruchtig malzig , nicht schlecht
Vom Fass. Dunkelgelb, luftiger weisser Schaum. Reif-fruchtige Hopfenaromen. Grasiger Antrunk. Etwas wässerig. Leider auch zu warm.
Part of a flight I had at the brewpub -- A very light beer. Some aromatics of tropical hops, but muted. Flavor was very light. The sessionability of this beer is what made it good.
(tap) clear orange amber colour with a small tan head; aroma of fruit; simple hoppy flavour; very forgettable

Draft at the brewpub. Flavors almost hefe-like. Some sweet malts too. Mouth has a light bitter finish. Resampled at the brewpub. The appearance is a more pale gold with some small white head. The aromas are nice with a bitter earthy hop tone. The flavors are a great medium strength bitter grassy hop. Nice medium malt balance. The mouth is moderately drying. Solid pale ale.

Poured cloudy orange/butterscotch with a thin head. Big hop aroma, slight earth notes, and some citrus. Grapefruit and orange in the flavor. Well hopped and goes down well. Very nice to see this brewery open again in Guam. Good stuff.
A very tasty Pale Ale. If I didn't love their Scottish Ale so much, this one would be my favorite. Nice floral hoppy nose, a good west coast (way way west that is) style Pale.
Dunkles braun schaum Ok, Geruch Kaffee dunkle schoko, nussig Kaffe im Geschmack dunkle schoko dunkles Karamell

Part of a flight I had at the brewpub -- Looked very appealing. Upon tasting I was a little disappointed, it was slightly thin and didn’t have the mouthfeel of most typical oatmeal stouts. Otherwise it was a very good beer.

#800: Poured dark brown with a medium tan head. Moderate aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Taste is lightly sour, malty, thin bodied and has a huge cocoa finish that is somewhat powdery. Pretty good.

Looks great, a deep dark opaque brown. Thick lasting head. Strong coffee flavor but lacks the richness and complexity I like in stouts. A bit thin in the palate too but don't get me wrong, still very drinkable!

Sampled cask conditioned at GBBF. Golden coloured, slightly hazy. Richly malty, filling mouthfeel. Dry, orangey and a bit flowery. The finish is more sweetish and quite bitter. A well balanced and very flavourful ale.
Cask Stillage at the Formby Hall, Atherton 30/01/2003 Dark coloured smooth mild with plenty of roast malt in the finish.
Cask conditioned. Red brown, poor head and moderate condition. Low aromas of chocolate mixed with hops, subdued flavours of hop, chocolate and hazelnut and a nutty dry finish.
Sampled cask conditioned at GBBF. Dark ruby. Dry and really roasty. Salty bitter finish.

Cask at GBBF 2011. Pours a straw colour with a thin white head, some wheat in the aroma, the taste was wheaty with a dry finish. Not sure where the raspberries were in the beer, rather a disappointing beer.
10th July 2008. Chelmsford beer festival. Barest hint of raspberry, a little bubblegum and a little hop. 7th August 2008. GBBF. Sharp fruity start - raspberry sherbet. Slightly watery finish.

Cask Stillage at the Civic Hall, Nantwich Beer Festival 28/09/2007 Fruity aroma. Golden coloured and a little hazy in appearance. Fruity raspberry flavour with some alcohol present. Slightly dry lasting bitter finish.

Bottle Very loose sediment. Looks slightly hazy orange and fizzy. Tart wine-fermenting aroma with crisp yeasty notes. The raspberry flavour is nice and delicate sitting well with the cereal wafts that are also found here. This is actually quite a lovely, delicate beer. Fills the mouth with summer-fruit tingles. Tastes like pink. Delicious pink.
Cask Real Ale 0.25L glass tasted at Gallows Bird. Mild raspberry nose. Small head. Pale golden yellow colour. Raspberry in the taste. Mild hoppiness.
Cask (Gallows Bird, Espoo, Real Ale Festival 2009) Day 0: Milky aroma. Sweet sticky palate. Sickly sweet taste - not doing it for me. Some hop aftertate, but not enough to save it.

(Cask at Gallows Bird, Espoo, on 2009-01-23) Pale copper red and clear. Light (rasp)berry aroma. Medium bodied palate, dryish and litle bit of carbonation. Sweetness, berries, hint of malts and very light bitterness in flavour. Watery and light aftertaste. More juice than a beer.
cask 0,268 at Gallows RAF 2009 light orange transparent. Dash of rasberry dash of wheat dash of hops. fruity sweetness in aftertaste. Easily drinkable

Cask at GBBF 08. Gold, disappearing off white head. Some raspberry. It’s an odd beer. I kept forgetting that it was on the table in front of me, so I couldn’t have liked it that much as it took me so long to drink.
Kingston BF 08. Aroma of raspberry leaves, not fruit. clear straw yellow, big bubbled rim no lace. good, fresh wheatale, quite tart. very drinkable. like.

First tasted this in Gabriels, Paisley in August 1997. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear pale gold in colour with a thick creamy white head. Thin aroma of fresh green apples and dusty hop resins. Thin resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a digestive biscuit note with zesty citric fruit notes of lemon, lime and gooseberry. Resiny hops give a fresh pine note to the long aftertaste. Finish is dry but fruity with grapefruit peel present. A decent session bitter.
Cask Stillage at the Mill At The Pier, Wigan 05/03/2005 Golden coloured hoppy and fruity. Crisp bitter lasting malt finish.
Cask conditioned at Charlbury Beer Festival. Golden amber coloured (Hazed) with slight head. Sweetish light malt bitter, refreshing and fruity, with a prety decent bitter finish. Very pleasant.
Light amber; minerally, with a touch of earthy hops. Simple beer...........
Sampled cask conditioned at GBBF. Amber colour. Malty and fruity, slightly sweetish. Crystal malt flavours leads to a hay finish.

Cask by handpump at Bon Accord, Glasgow as part of the Battle of the Roses Beer Festival (23 Feb 12) - very light floral aroma, perfumy citrus, sharp aftertaste, easy to drink, no significant sweetness or bitterness

On cask (gravity dispense) at Chelmsford Beer Festival on 15 July 2011. Very surprised to find I hadn’t reviewed this before. Extremely pale straw colour. Loose white head. Excellent condition. Clean and citric. Lots of bitterness. Light bodied and very drinkable. Despite the colour this is much more of a bitter than a golden ale. Straightforward but does the job admirably.
Cask @ Millsborough Hotel, Sheffield. Pours a light yellow. Aroma of sweet floral hops. Flavour of biscuit and floral hops with a light, crisp, bitter finish. Decent.
Cask på Hillsborough Hotel, Sheffield 1 Okt 10. Lys gylden med et lavt kremskum. Svakt fruktig aroma. Smaken litt grapefrukt. Svakt syrlig bitter ettersmak.

Cask@Bishops Stortford Beer Festival 2010. Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is fruits, nectar, bready malts and some earth. Flavour is quite similar with also some mild notes of wood and sap. Grassy, herbal and bready finish.

Cask at the Hillsborough Hotel, Sheffield on 7th Feb 2010. Crystal clear pale gold with thin lacing white head. Intensely bitter and hoppy with a rich grassy kick and a satisfyingly bitter aftertaste. Pleasantly textured mouthfeel. Superb.

Cask at The Hilsborough Hotel, Sheffield. A light golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has notes of citrusy hops and light notes of malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of elderflowers and malt, leading to a lightly bitter finsish.

Caask. Slightly hazy yellow with a small white head. Sweet citrusy hoppy nose - delicious. Light body, almost flat with a sweet fruitiness. Lightly hoppy finish with loads of fresh citrus. Damm, this would be a killer quencher if only served cold! 180110
On tap in Sheffield - pours a medium yellow. Flavour is mild hops, citrus, and quite smooth. Very enjoyable.
Cask gravity, Solihull 09. Headless straw. Slight potato aroma, honey, sweet spliffy hop. Biscuit, orange, some vegetable and bile, good dry bite in the finish. So-so.

Cask at the Farmer’s Boy, St Albans on 2nd March 2010. Pale gold with a mostly diminishing white head. Intense hoppy grassiness with a citric "answer" that lasts to a dry bitter finish on a softly textured mouhfeel. Excellent.
Handpulled cask at the Farmers Boy, St. Albans. Pale gold with healthy white head. Plenty of citrus hops in a very well balaced flavour. Refreshing and enjoyable.
Cask conditioned @ Farmers Boy, St Albans. Pale fruity hops with nice leafy bitterness and a bit of sweet maltiness. Quite nice.

Cask handpull at Farmer’s Boy, St Albans. Pale gold, lasting white head. American hop aroma. Good blond session beer. Slightly yeasty on aroma. In the JHB/Hophead arena/ Just hasn;t quite got the quality of those two. Fresh though.

Cask-conditioned at the Farmers Boy, St Albans, 8/6/07. Golden coloured with a slight white head. Aroma of flowers and grapefruit. Flavour started hoppy before a sweet malt finish kicked in. This didn’t hold back - a brash beer which was enjoyable.
Cask at The Farmers Boy St Albans 29 Sep 06. Golden coloured. Hazy. A tiny creamy head. Some fruity flavour but an overall bitter impression.

Half pint on cask. Slightly hazy golden. Small white layer of foam. Quite nice lemon citric aroma. Bitter fruity flavour combined with blend of malt and hops. More than a standard bitter English ale (The Farmers Boy in St Albans 29.09.2006)

Cask conditioned at The Farmers Boy, St Albans, Herts. Pale gold with white bubbly head. Restained light beer bordering on a golden ale, sweetish malt and hops, but these are dispersed with a butterscotch type toffeeness. Average.
Cask Stillage at the GBBF, Kensington Olympia 08/08/2002 Golden coloured with some fruity, pale and wheat aromas. Slightly dry hop finish.
Cask : The Farmers Boy, St Albans. Impressive! Full of hops, bright yellow. An amazing IPA for only 4% ABV.
light pale colour. fruity malty smell. taste is resin earth British hop with sweet malty note throughout. pretty tasty

Cask-conditioned at the Seven Stars, Bristol, October 2016. Deep gold in colour with a slight off-white, head. Aroma of stone fruit with a touch of leafy hop. Flavour had sweetish, biscuity, malts with some more fruit, before a moderately dry finish. Ok.
Goachers Gold Star Cask. Amber, with a solid small white head. Malty, slightly hoppy hints in the aroma. Smooth, bitter hoppy taste, short finish.
Cask conditioned at Banbury Beer Fest ’14. Gold with white head. This had a brown bread maltiness, grainy, some sweetness, hints of peach notes but really pretty average in character. A touch dull.

Handpump (@ The Flower Pot, Maidstone, Kent): Golden, almost clear, lacy smaller white head, moderate to solid fruity and bisquity nose, moderate sweet-bitter flavour, relatively full bodied; ślightly lingering bitter-sweet herbal hoppy finish with an illusion of alcohol in the aftertaste. Solid stuff…
Cask (Gallows Bird, Espoo, Real Ale Festival 2002) Dry peppery hoppy aroma. Smooth palate. Citrussy hoppy bite, also fruity. Finish is hoppy. Rating rediscovered while packing for a move in 2010.

Cask (handpump) @ Great British Beer Festival, GBBF 2008, Earls Court, London, England SW5. Clear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, fruity, moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. (080808)

Handpulled cask at the Black Lion in Lynsted, Kent. Gold with a thin white head. Aroma of apples suggested that it may have been past it’s best. No off tastes and quite smooth and sweet. Would like to try in fresher condition.
Cask@GBBF2008. Golden colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is hops, fruits and mild notes of gerass. Flavour is fruit and wood along with some mild notes of sourness and also mild nuttyness.
Cloudy golden medium white head. Sweet peachy aroma with caramel and hoppy notes. Sweet flavor with caramel and hoppy notes. Ends bitter.

Aroma; pale malts, caramel, grass, herbs, spices. Look; fine good offwhite head, pale clear golden body. Taste; hay hops, grass, minerals, pale malts, spices, and finishes balanced, hops n malts. Feel; ok body n co². Overall; pilsnerish pilsner. [btl @im hauslicher Umgebung] 6373'14
Found it on the bitter side. A bit overboard on the hops, making it hard to get any subtleties.

5 August 2019. 50cl bottle provided by Maarten - many thanks! Best before: 21/5/19. Pours clear golden with a lasting, very thin, foamy, white head. Aroma of citrus, apple, bread, yeast & grain. Taste is medium malty sweet, notes of apple, bread & sweet yeast; soft grainy bitterness & citric sourness leading to a dryish finish that is yeasty & a bit fruity. Light to medium body, oily texture, fizzy carbonation. Decent Pilsener.
Bottle from Rauchbierlover. Clear golden appearance. Aroma is sweet, malt and grassy. Flavour is bitter, herbal, grassy, malt, sweet and hops.

Bottle (BB Sep 21, 2019). Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly diminishing. Body is light to medium yellow. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain / bread), moderately hoppy (honeysuckle flowers, herbs). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. A pretty darn solid rendition...nice aroma hops, clean, tasty. Could use a bit more finishing bitterness and a bit more aromatic pizzazz, but it's an easy-to-like quaffer.

Gold with a frothy to creamy white head that lingers. Herbal aroma with straw and cereal undertones, and a dash of peppercorn. Taste has that usual German pils bitterness, quite herbal, crisper than most though with no jarring notes. Solid malt backbone with bready undertones. Dry at the end. Better than most in the style, but the style is such that even a good example just doesn’t cut a buy again with me.

500 ml bottle poured a clear yellow with a lingering ring of white foam. Aromas of straw, graininess and noble hops. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of straw, noble hops and light graininess with a crisp dry lingering bitter finish.

Shared bottle. Pours a clear, golden color, with a medium, frothy, off-white head. The aroma is caramel, pine, strong floral notes, and resin. Sweet and syrupy, with a mild, pleasant bitterness. Light body, with a sticky, relatively thick palate. Pretty solid pilsener, if a little heavy.
24-04-19 // tap at Kaschk. Clear golden. White head. Classic and clean german Pils. Crispy, mild sweetish grain sweetness. Smooth. Balanced bitterness

Ar: Grassy, steely malt; herbal hoppiness, with minty accents; chalk and a bit of moss. Ap: Straw yellow and clear; medium white head with moderate retention, settling into a solid cap of foam and leaving some dashy lacing along the glass sides. T: Raw dough and grass; herbal and chalky; bitterness is high and clean; hop flavor is mossy and has hints of mint and black pepper; minerals and grainy, sweet malt; very clean fermentation profile, with just the slightest hint of gooseberry; finish is bitters, more chalk, and hay. P: Light body with very high carbonation; finish is bone dry. O: Excellent German pilsner; dry, bitter, and malty.
Poured clear straw with a small off white froth. Aroma of sweet citrus and soft malt. Light body, flavour is lightly sweet, lightly bitter.

On gravity at the Bank, Bristol 08/08/09. Clear gold in colour with a slight white head. Aroma of sweetish malts with a touch of citrus hops. Flavour of biscuits malts, summer fruits and a decent bitter finish. Ok, if not particularly memorable.

Cask Conditioned at Banbury Beer Festival 06. Hazed Gold no head. A tremendous disapointment this one, racked on tuesday, unsaleable until Saturday and only then with a warning as it was still hazed. Thinly flavoured with a cidery note and a touch of farm in the nose. Tart finish, not very popular.
Cask Stillage at the Pacific Road Arts Centre, Birkenhead 23/10/2003 Clear golden coloured with citrussy hop aroma. Slightly bitter lasting finish.
Medium gold color; no head due to cask pour. Boringly mild. Interesting lemon hint all through the mouth.
On cask at the White Horse...light amber; fresh, but light taste; slight apple note.
Sampled cask conditioned at the White Horse, London. Pale golden. Sweet with medium body and some vanilla flavour. The finish is disappointingly watery.
Cask at The Cask And Barrel southside. Golden straw with a white head. Looks great. Flavour and aroma are light citrus. Very thin on the ground.
Cask ay C&B Southside. Pale yellow with a white head. Weak aroma and flavour. This beer is so fucking dull.

Cask at Maltings York 5 May 06. Pale yellow colour. A little white head (for a wheat beer). A cautious fruity aroma and taste leaving you with a bitter aftertaste. Difficult to find any similarity with standard wheat beers.
Very underscorted by some Brittish drinkers, non from this page. But it is excellent one, do not make the Germans or Belgians look too high from it. I like it, specially the colour.
Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 19/07/2003 Clear golden coloured sharp on the palate and bitter. Lasting hop finish.
[Cask conditioned] Pale yellow coloured. Quite thin, but rather hoppy for a wheat beer.
GBBF 2003, tap: Pale yellow color, sulfury nose. Apply juice, man, with a gritty bitterness. Very British, but not good.
GBBF cask cond. 03: Skunky cheese nose. Straw yellow. Grapes flavor not very intense.
Sampled cask conditioned at Black Bull, Haltwhistle, Northumberland. Pale yellow. Citrus and vanilla aroma. Soft and sweet with rounded mouthfeel and low bitterness.
Cask Stillage at the Old Broken Cross, Rudheath 11/07/2002 Dark red coloured and smooth on the palate with fruity aroma and flavour. Some dryness in a roast malt finish.

Cask conditioned at some pub in Richmond, London (sorry i forget the name of it). Dark brown, OK head, dissipates however. Sweetsih malty nose and flavour, a bit sweet and not enough bitterness, no real bite, and too smooth in my opinion. i agree with Per, a bit one dimensional.
Sampled cask conditioned at Blackfriars, Inverness, Scotland. Very dark brown. Roasty and creamy, sweet and rather malty with smooth mouthfeel and some coffee flavour. A bit one-dimensional.

Found this beer alive and well in a deli near New Quay. Pours golden with a white head. Has quite lagery looks and is has quite a lager taste too. Surprisingly sparkling. Very little honey in evidence. Just a bit of a bland golden ale really. Not really bad, just boring.
Hazy amber colour. Not much honey in evidence. Not much of anything in evidence really, except maybe a touch of cardboard/ OK, but bland. Bottled at the London Joet gathering, January 2005.
Shit honey homebrew aroma and flavour. Looks ok, medium bodied but very bland with an astringent taste. Not my thing.
Bottle. Pretty thin. Sweetish, but not too sweet, finishes off dry. Subtle honey flavour. Not muh body or flavour, feels very empty.
Bottle at Chris_o’s place with the rest of the London crew + joet. A totally pointless honey beer thats sweet and lagerish with a little honey.
Cloudy orange beer with white head. Smoky sulphuric aroma. Fruity, a bit smoked flavor.
Light amber; slightly sweet. Bland. Quick finish. .......................
Vigorous big head that looked impressive to me. Aroma of gas with some bitterness. Not to sweet as I expected .Only with some hints of "honey". Low complexity, sadly.
Golden coloured, hazy. Ligh spicy aroma. Sweetish and light bodied. Balsamic with just a hint of the expected honey. Low bitterness.

One of the lesser known examples of its style, with a yellowish white, moussy head, quite stable, and a pale golden blonde colour, cristal clear. Nose gets pale malts, a tad of sourish wheat, apple, cheese and an earthy, leafy hoppiness. Pure and sweetish pale malts in the mouth, minerals, in the end a herbal and leafy hop bitterness, a bit more herbal than I am used to in this genre.

Würzig-süßlicher Geruch. Der Antrunk ist vollmundig-süßlich und angenehm süffig. Zum Hauptteil kommt eine leicht herbe Note zum Vorschein, die sich wunderbar mit der leichten Herbe verbindet. Der Nachgeschmack ist lang anhaltend, angenehm süßlich-feinherb und schön mild. → Ein leckeres Kölsch! 12+12+11+12
Klares goldgelbes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig, grasig, herb. Geschmack malzig, getreidig, minimal herb.
Pale golden color with a small white head that disappear quickly. Aroma is quite sweet and malty. FLavor is the same with a light bitterness, low carbonation e light body. No bitterness..

#1023 Es sieht ja noch halbwegs wie ein Kölsch aus, auch wenn sich die Schaumkrone(?) noch schneller als üblich verabschiedet... das Aroma ist dann etwas hopfig ohne kölschtypische Fruchtigkeit. Im Antrunk dann Kölsch-Wässrigkeit par excellence, gefolgt von einem geschmacklichen Bermuda-Dreieck, das etwas malzig-süss ist. Der absolute Kotzbrocken ist aber der Abgang: Hier kommt eine bissige-metallische Note, die einfach grottig ist und den Billigeindruck zu 100% bestätigt. Never again! Test vom 8.4.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche Noten: 8,6,5,4,6,6 - 5,75
Light white head with a highly carbonated, clear golden body. Nose of grain and tonic water. Flavour of cardboard and mildly metallic.
Bottle. Blonde. Slightly soapy dusty aroma. Soft grassy flavor. Typical kölsch. Not abundant with flavors and aromas, but quite drinkable.

(bottle) pours a clear yellow colour with a frothy white head. aroma of marzipan and paint thinner, quite acrid, with notes of grain, cardboard and herbal hops. flavour is mostly pale malts and floral hops, quite mellow, with only a hint of sweet spices and cardboard. watery body with average carbonation.

Bottle by 23.11.12. Sunny, simple citric malt in the nose but a little lean toward peach/apricot. Clear yellow body with a soapy white head. Taste is rather sweet with little other than slightly floral/grassy malt, very low bitterness and a very faint moist bread in the finish. Soap-slippery herbal butter tones, and something unclean. Medium body and too child-oriented to drink in mass (or during mass).

500 ml bottle. From bierzwerg.de. Clear pale golden colour with minimal head. Lively. Malt and some sweetness in aroma. Mild grassy bitterness, malt and herbs in flavour. Some unpleasantness. Slightly watery.
Bottle in Turkey. It has weak aromas and lover carbonation and pure yellow colour. It is a refresher.
U jingisa. Vona slabsia leziakova. Farba zlatista pena chvilu bola. Chut jemne horka drzi sa.
Plechovka od kolegu. Vôňa pivna leziakova. Farba bledsia zlatista. Chuť celkom pitelne.
Sweet and watery lager. Getting a bit tired of these Bulgarian macros this evening.

Bottle, 360 ml. Wow, the best beer so far this afternoon. Bright golden, almost no foam, but the aromas and the taste are just nice. Smells sweet malt with a bit of caramel inside (or maybe it's not caramel, but they use some interesting malt inside which is sweet). The palate is refreshing, good amount of barley(s) and a nice structure. Faint aftertaste, but very pleasent taste with a nice touch of sweetness. I like it a lot, this is a great value for 1.05€. New favourite! Update: the canned one tastes more intensive for me, great bitterness on the end, this is simply a great lager!

500ml bottle, drunk many times over the years. Review from old notes as this one is now sadly retired. Pours clear with a frothy head, medium retention, some bead. On the nose, a good mix of bread and honey malts with grass and floral hops. In the mouth, medium carbonation, flavours consistent with the aromas, mild bitterness, a crisp short finish. Overall, a refreshing and flavoursome lager, now sadly retired, despite being Bulgaria's best macro. Its "twin", Shumensko Spetsialno happily lives on.
Butelka 500ml. Jasnozloty kolor. Piana biała,o dość dużych pęcherzach,opada szybko. Duzo słodowych akcentów,trochę trawy ,mało chmielu. Bida aż piszczy....
Słomkowe, klarowne. Zapach nie jest zbyt intensywny. Głównie słody, jest nuta chmielowa. W smaku słodkawe. Lekkie w odczuciu. Ma wyraźny słodkawy posmak. Przeciętny lager.
Trockener, mild getreidiger Antrunk. Schnell schwächer werdend, minimal würzig. Trocken herb im Mittelteil, wässrig, kurzer Nachhall. Noch trinkbar. 8/6/6/6/7/6

Lattina Shumensko 1882 ABV 4,8%. L’intensità olfattiva è normale e la persistenza olfattiva è corta. Il gusto al naso rimanda a percezioni di orzo. Il cappello di schiuma ha una scarsa tenuta, con la grandezza delle bollicine che è grossolana, a carbonazione media. La consistenza del liquido è limpida. Le bollicine sono poche e fini. La carbonazione è morbida. Il colore è giallo paglierino. Il corpo è snello. L’amaro è leggero. L’intensità gustativa è leggera e la persistenza gustativa è corta. Il gusto è piacevole. Le sensazioni boccali finali sono di facile beva. Il finale è dissetante e semplice. Il retrogusto è veloce. Al palato arrivano sentori di pane e cereali.
Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 27/04/2001 Smooth on the palate with some bitterness. Caramel malt flavour in the finish.
Bland, malty, little interest at all. This really was a boring beer with no redeeming features, sadly the way Brains are going nowadays.
Cask Conditioned at a Wetherspoons. Brown beer with fluffy white head. Malt crammed welsh beer, going over to boiled caramel and toffee. Very little finish, no lasting bitterness.
Amber; heavy diacetyl on top of caramel notes; again with the signature watery finish of Brains.
Fairly basic raspberry wheat. Somewhat tart. Very nice. No bitterness. No malt.
On tap at Gritty’s in Freeport. Clear light golden color with white head. Sweet Raspberry aroma. Light crisp malt flavor with a sweet raspberry flavor.
Very thin and watery... Over filtered and light with sweet raspberry. Fruity. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Straw colour. Lots of raspberry syrup on the nose. Watery, with vile syrupiness. Bad even for a mailed-in raspberry brew.

Draught @ Freeport outlet. Billed as "Raspberry Light" and is a variation of the Sebago Light, not a wheat beer. Very clear. Raspberry soda children’s drink smell. All manner of fruitiness disappears in the flavors and ends with slight hop reminiscent of a generic light lager. Very thin, lacking any layers or complexity. Some grain flavors simple, but clean. Raspberry is almost an afterthought. Grandma beer.
Draught: Watery, weak flavor, and unexciting. Really light and boring. Give this one a miss.
Very Light Rasberry arome and flavors, light gold in color and just a little bitter at finsh, alittle tart but not lemony, not too sweet at all, refreshing but overall weak.

Date: 04/29/1999 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: seeing the world through rose colored beer with a whispy head, Aroma: sweet raspberry aroma, Flavor: flavor has a lot of up front raspberry twang, some wheat character still shows through, Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
On tap a the pub... Aroma:Light fruity nose... Appearance:Clear gold,light head... Flavor:good raspbery flavor...

On tap at Auburn brewpub location. This is basically what appears to be their light beer with some raspberry flavors thrown in. It was a nice tangy raspberry which made it a little different than the other raspberry wheats i’ve had, although I’m still not a big fan of wheat beers, nor am i a fan of fruit beers. I’ve gotta say you should skip this one.

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in Aug 2010 - Dark Amber in colour. Sulphurous aroma. Malty; grainy malts, caramel. Hoppy; earthy hops. Fruity. Overall bitter; grainy malts meet earthy hops. Dry mouthfeel. Very dry finish. Unique taste. Liked this. Very Drinkable. (2010-08)

Is this still brewed?? I used to drink this when I lived in Edinburgh, many years ago! It seemed to be available in most of the pubs I frequented, I was particularly fond of Bannermans in the Cowgate. I’ve rated it as average all round as I can’t rightly remember the details of it’s character ( it was 30 odd yrs ago!) but it was usually a bloody good pint!
Although I have not drank this beer for several years it is a taste I will never forget. One of my all time favourite beers.

Cask at bretwood, aberdeen.Earthy fuggles nose without the metallic note, creamy texture herbal to taste at first, think weak tea with robust shortbread malt following after with a good dash of bitterness. Touch of nettles. Like it.

First tasted this in the Wee Howf, Paisley in December 1980. Cask, handpump dispense. Danny always kept this in good nick and won an award for this back in the day. Cask, handpump dispense.
