Clear pale copper in colour with a thick creamy white head. Warm yeasty dough in the robust malty aroma. Thin but creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt gives a powerful, fiery digestive biscuit base with some ginger nuts mixed in. Strong tart marmalade flavours also present in the mouth. Dry black pepper flavours present in the spicy hop resins give a fiery aftertaste. Finish is robust and malty with dry leather and oak cask wood notes strong in the palate. An excellent session ESB and a pub with happy memories.

The Baron (JDW). Slightly pondwatery amber with a tight drum of head draping the glass. Hints of spice in the aroma- toasted seeds, curry leaf, maybe. Drab but inoffensive flavour with a faintly peppered Weetabix sogginess, a weak, unidentified jellied fruit hint. Some chalk and caramel. It’s immensely tedious but drinkable.
cask at cambridge ....amber ... thin lacing ... soft mellon fruit ... light smoke light sour tart fruits ... big lemon ... ok but not sure at best
@JDW Playfair, Edinburgh. Spicy and caramelly nose, though it is fairly light. Slightly toasty, slightly tart but generally a fairly standard bitter.

Cask @ Playfair. Amber and clear, served WITHOUT a sparkler and giving a nice natural cask head. Yay! Fresh malty, worty aroma that also has a little fruity perfume, which is strange. Quaffable and easy. Mostly malty. Has fruity, juicy flavors finishing with bread and granola.

On tap at the Kings Head, Monmouth. Clear copper colour. Thin white head, slightly aromatic aroma. Hop fruity flavour. Nice bitterness. Pleasant malt finish. Very enjoyable session beer. Good quality.
Leakaroma, very soapy and skunky. Also leak and cardboard in the slightly malty flavor. Bitter aftertaste. Poor quality, in fact undrinkable.

500ml can from the shop, drunk at home. Pours clear, but almost opaque with a thin frothy pale brown head, plenty of lacing, no bead. Dark brown in colour. Light aroma of toast, caramel and corn. Creamy mouth feel with mid to high carbonation and flavours of toast, cereal and bread. Crisp finish with well-balanced bitterness. Overall, a fairly ordinary dunkel, but nevertheless, a welcome change from the raft of supermarket lagers and pilseners, and refreshing enough to be drunk all year round. Sadly, it remains one of Bulgaria's seasonal dark beers.
Dunkler, wenig herb-malziger Start. Steigende Malzigkeit von geringem Level aus, Getreidenoten, sinkende Süße. Mittellanger, rund schokoladenmalziger Nachgeschmack. Okay. 8/8/8/9/6/8

Canned 500ml. -Dark brown/almost black coloured, big and long-lasting beige head, caramel and cheap honey in the nose. Sweet caramel, light roasted malt and light coffee with notes of corn and alcohol in the finish. A way too sweet and quite strong alcohol notes for 5%ABV.

Bottle in Bulgaria. Pours dark brown with a fast-fading beige head. Malty aroma, some turbinado sugar in there. Flavor is interesting in its first impression: strong notes of lightly charred whole wheat toast. Further taste of light dough and faint dark sugar. Light to medium in body with average carbonation. Lingering toasted bread in the finish, lightly dry, with only subtle malt sugars. Really a quite nice beer. I can’t remember having a beer with a similar flavor profile. Good stuff.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with medium creamy light brown mostly lasting head. Aroma is roasted malt with notes of coffee. Sweet spicy flavor. Bitter finish.

Bottle 500ml. Clear dark red brown color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, light coffee. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration, roasted, sweet malt, licorice - laber laver notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100904]

Can from the last high way gasstation before Varna Airport. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Dark brown colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. Some caramellic notes. Light bitter and sweet flavor. Average light bitter finish. Oily palate.
light malty,smoke and toffee aroma,black, brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation.
Dark, almost black. Has a light-brown head, mostly lasting head. Aroma is light roasted, caramel. Flavor is moderate sweet. light bitter finish. Creamy texture. Soft carbonation.
Can courtesy HenrikSoegaard. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are roast malt, caramel and has notes of licorice.

Surprised ratings are not that high. I personally really enjoyed the pint. Will definitely look out for it in the future when on tap. A good pint. Good pale amber colour, with nice hoppy and slightly caramelly taste.

Cask at the Bay Tree Hotel, Burford. Pours clear orange amber with a beige head. Aroma: sweet malts, toffee. Taste: light sweet & bitter, fruity, toffee, caramel. Medium body, soft carb, semi dry close. Not a fan
Half pint (4%; quarterly ale) by hand-pump on 6 Jun 2017: weak toffee aroma, amber, thin bubbly cream head, thick bubbly lacing, toffee, malty flavour, quite bitter, harsh maltiness in the finish.
Amber appearance. No aroma to mention. Chemical taste. No hit on palate. Overall very disappointing considering appearance.
50cl bottle from B&M Doncaster. Thin white head. Clear amber pour. A bit thin and watery. Ok.

Live rating of a 500 ml bottle from B&M Gateshead, picked up by mistake when I was stocking up on the brewery’s Station Porter which I love: this however, is a different beast. Amber with a white head, so it looks good. Weak lemon barley water in a rusty tin can aroma, which manifests itself in an initially sourish flavour. A bit of muted lemon, a soupcon of toffee malt, a mildly bitter finish, and that’s yer lot. Perhaps it’s about context: perhaps after lashing it back on a night out with a group of raucous mates, I would score this higher. It doesn’t stand up to much scrutiny at home. Not horrible.
Pint at JDW. Pours bright amber with deep bubbly head. Rather too sweet and with somewhat astringent after notes.
Bottle. Amber in colour. Malty; sweet malts, caramel. Fruity; citrus orange, apple. Hoppy; mildly grassy hops. Sweet fruity malty and dry throughout. Ok. Very easy drinking but bland. (2011-08-27)
Bottle Xmas day amber colour thin head standard supermarket bitter reminiscent of a sheperd neame creation
Fra cask/gravity på Plymouth CAMRA Beer and Cider Festival 24 Sep 16. Litt uklar. Filmskum. Aroma av søt frukt. Smaken mango & mørke plommer. Litt tørr etter hvert.

Cask (Kingston Arms, Cambridge) Light golden colour, thin head. Sweet light fruit and crisp hop aroma. Flavour fills out with a sweet but tangy malty almost slightly musky body. Very impressive for a 3.5% beer.

1. Cask Handpump at the Old Harkers Arms, Chester 12/08/2002 A golden smooth beer with some sweetness and slightly dry hoppy finish. 2. 05/08/2005 Cask Handpump at the Head Of Steam, London First drink of the day en route to the GBBF Again the beer was golden and hoppy with some sour fruit and bitterness in the dry malt finish.
A fairly balanced beer erring on the side of sweetness. Has some malt character but the sweetness is too much for me and increases towards the finish. (Cask @ Cornubia, Bristol)
Cask Conditioned at The Stags Head, Swalcliffe. Pale gold coloured with thin head. Dry hoppy beer, tobaco back notes with a smokey character. Thin and nasal on the finish.
(Hand Pump) A straw coloured ale, with a loose head that fails very early. Reasonably hoppy flavour, and drinks above it's weight. It is what it says it is, a refreshing summer beer.

Cask, Frog and Toad, Gillingham. Aroma of rancid nylon. Dull flavour - neither citric sharp nor earthy bitter, but a boggy blend of both. Clinging mouthfeel. Watery finish. Dreadful beer. No wonder Archer's beers rarely travel far beyond Swindon.
Sampled at the Bag O' Nails, Bristol...fruity (blackberry), hoppy, slight leather note, refreshing. Bursts with flavour.

’Leadmill Apocalypse’, 5.2%, The Crown, Nuneaton. Tawny amber and persistent. Resiny hop and dry roasted nose. Peppery hop and bitter yeasty nuttiness beyond, milk choc hints, intriguing full nutty biscuit and hop balance. Dry and nutty with soft chalky bitterness, lingering bread and biscuit. Very decent.
Sampled cask-conditioned at the Bag O' Nails, Bristol...Malty, slight lowland whisky note, bit of toffee, mineral, and resiny hops.
Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 19/08/2001 Mid brown coloured with a fruity aroma. Very bitter in the finish.
Cask Conditioned at The White Lion, Fewcott, Oxon. Gold amber beer, lightly malted, sof fruit flavours with a hoppy punch in the finish. A decent enough bitter.
Amber; hoppy, quite a bit of fruit (peach, pear). Very fresh tasting. Sampled cask-conditioned at the Bag O' Nails, Bristol.

Deep copper colour w/ big head & nice lacing. Fruity aroma w/ hops cutting through nicely. Full bodied, resiny & sticky. Malty & fruity upfront w/ a lingerinig bitter finish. A little harsh & earthy for the style. Considering alcohol content & bitterness, in my opinion, this beer tends more toward an IPA (That being said they do have an IPA that wasn't available when I was there--imagine!)

Tap at the brewpub. It pours darkest brown with a tiny beige head. The nose is bitter-sweet, juicy, milk chocolate, candy, hot chocolate, malt loaf and horlicks. The taste is bitter, earthy roast, some acidity & tangerines, cocoa/dark chocolate, ash, charred wood and a touch of pepper with a lingering dry-roast finish. Medium body and moderate, foamy carbonation. Easy-going stout. Fine.

Quite a fine Dry Stout, I am not sure why it’s under the "Sweet" category. Black/brown with a thin crema-like head adorning the juice. Scents of smoke, roast malts, coffee and nuts hearken me to guzzle. I heed the call, enjoying all of those same smells in the flavour, dry and bitter with strong nutty notes. A nice thick body that finishes bone dry, don’t miss this if you’re at Rogue’s.
Black pour with a thin lace. Roasted malt aroma. Nice roasted malt chocolate flavour. Smooth texture. Very nice bitterness. Nice brew.

Rich inky black with tan head and lacing. Nice looking. Rich coffee aroma. Some cocoa too. Yummy smells. Soft gently caressing mouthfeel. Coffee pervasive throughout with lingering roasty finish. A nice dry stout.
dark black, beige head, not alot on the nose maybe some choc, very dry some nuttyness and choc not bad stout

[034-20060902] Tap @ Rogue’s Roost (Halifax, NS). Roasted malt aroma. Clear, dark dark dark brown/red body with a big creamy light brown head. Tastes like roasted coffee, a little fruity, a little chocolate. Great full mouth, long-lasting aftertaste. Great togetherness (minus the fruity part).
Deep black stout with a moka head. Very honest roasted chocolate malt and light coffee. Nice chocolate malt with light hops. Very lightbodied for a stout. On tap March 2005.

Smallish creamy khaki head dimishes quickly atop a black body. I expect a larger pour in a different glass would have lingered longer. Decent lacing (3+) Aroma is muted, mild dark roast malt and a hint of chocolate. Flavour is fairly dry with just barely enough sweet malt. Dry mild roast with touches of nutty dark chocolate at times. Chocolate comes out a lot more as the glass warms. Medium palate. Decent average stout, not really doing much for me today.
very dark with ruby highlights. No head. Coffee, raisins, nutty aroma. Bitter finish on the dry side with lingering roasted aftertaste. A tad thin for a stout, but very drinkable.

Deep brown/ruby colour. Thick tan but diminshing head. Slight coffee and chocolate aroma. Caramel and chocolate flavours, finishing with coffee and alcohol. Palate is too light, lacking typical stout chewiness and warming mouthfeel.

Bottle at The Situation, served in its own Slaapmutske glass. Pours a brown colour, with oranges tones, big head with medium retention, good lacing. Aroma of candied fruits, green apples, cinnamon, spices, nuts. Medium body, sticky texture, normal carbonation. Nutty finish. Taste follows the aroma. Good, not exceptional.
Mørk brun lett tåkete med fingerhøyt beige skum. Lukter maltekstrakt og nøtter. Middels fylde. Noe maltig sødme. Karamell, nøtter og korn. Kort

Auch als ich dieses Bier getrunken habe, ist schon eine Zeitlang her, aber es ist mir sehr positiv in Erinnerung geblieben. Ich trank es damals in der Vorweihnachtszeit an einem grauslich-verregneten Dezemberabend und dieses Bier konnte mir das Herz erwärmen. Es ist ein süßes Dunkles, dessen Karamellmalzigkeit mit wunderbaren Gewürzaromen nach Zimt, Koriender und Vanille erfreute. Durch den nicht zu hohen Alkohol ein sehr empfehlenswertes Betthupferl.
Aroma: rich malty & banana Appearance: brown, red, tan sheet lacing Flavour: banana cake with malt Palate: medium, heavily carbonated
Flesje gedeeld met H. Roodbruin bier met stevig schuim. Aroma is fruitig (braambos en bessen). Smaak is zacht, zoet en toch een beetje hoppig. Nasmaak is iets bitter.
Sweet aroma, a bit weird tho. Nice malty background combined with sweet caramel notes. Too watery for my preference. One time try.
Decent maltiness, caramel, toffee, candy, dried fruits. Moderate sweetness with light bitternesd. Lovely
Bottled. Pours unclear amber liquid with a tall frothy off-white head. Aroma: walnut, dried apples, caramel, candy, dried banana. Similar taste. Lightly sweet.Medium body. Soft bitterness. Pleasant.

Donkerbruin moutig bier met tonen van gedroogd fruit en karamel. De smaak is vol, zacht en warm en de afdronk is verassend vol met wat zoetigheid en een beetje kruidig. Goede volle smaak en ondanks het lage alcoholpercentage een prima genietbier.

Bottle. Dark gold with amber, yellowish foam. Fruit aroma: apple, malt, lollipops, dried apple and other dried fruits, a little milk. Taste: sweetish, apple, dried fruits, raisins, slightly sour yeast, mild bitterness.

Bottle at The Situation, served in its own Slaapmutske glass. Pours a golden colour, small head and retention, normal lacing. Aroma is fruity, tangerines, peaches, malt, spices. Medium body, sticky texture, normal carbonation. Taste is fruity too, peaches, tangerines, bananas, spices. Refreshing.

Bottle from de Caigny dranken in Essen, Belgium. The beer is hazy golden blonde colored and has a medium white head, with average carbonation. The aroma is malty and very fruity, with notes of grass, citrus, bread, yeast, honey, peaches and spices. The taste is medium bodied and light sweet malty and goes to fruity and light hoppy with notes from the aroma. The finish is a little refreshing, light dry and pretty bitter.
Dunkelgelb, feste weiße Krone. Fruchtig-malzig im Antrunk, passender runder Körper.
Een aangename volmoutsmaak en een mooi afgerond mondgevoel. De afdronk is zeer zacht en aangenaam bitter.
Lekker biertje, beetje richting Duvel. Uit de Belgische bierschuur net over de grens. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Foggy gold. Decent white head. Smells of grassy hops, spicy yeast, minor malts. Light to medium body. Tastes relatively dry, grassy, spicy, light to medium bitterness. Restrained maltiness. Decent. Saisonish feel. Still my favourite Belgian blonds are more malty as a rule.
Fles gedeeld met Roelzie en Koenzie. Het is een geel bier met medium schuimkraag. De geur is wat fruitige. De smaak ik moutig en fruitig met een licht hopbittertje.
Bottle. Straw-golden color, white foam. Aroma: flowers, citrus and fruit, malt. Taste: malt, citrus, fruit, pear, pleasant hop bitterness, slightly grassy.

4/VI/17 - 33cl bottle from Dranken Geers (Oostakker) @ home - BB: 22/XII/18 (2017-705) Clear blond beer, big creamy off-white head, pretty stable, non adhesive. Aroma: pretty fruity, apples, some yeast, bit oxidized, almonds. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: bit oxidized, sweet, almonds, soft bitterness, some orange peel. Aftertaste: some citrus, hoppy touch, bit oxidized, sweet finish.
Bottle @ Pressklubben, Stockholm. Golden body with a medium white head. Fruity, spicy, quite light and descent.
Auch das Tripel aus dem Hause Slaapmutske enttäuscht mich nicht Es gibt schöne Koriander- und Zimtaromen, die im Bettchen vom Malzzucker ruhen. Ein voller Geschmack mit einem dezent röstigen Abgang.

This strange tripel is sort of a wolf in sheep's clothing. The aroma is just delectable with tons of orange, apple, pear, stone fruit, spicy hops and yeasty esthers. If my nose could live inside the glass, I would be eternally grateful. But the flavors here are just muted and underpowered. The beer comes across as old. Fruitiness is there, but past it's prime as are the hops. Not quite stale, just not bright and lively. A bit of a disappointment given the amazing aroma. Not a heavy Tripel, it drinks light with a nice carbonation profile. It died almost everything right... But the flavors just don't pop.
Bouteille 33cl couleur blonde foncée, mousse blanche onctueuse qui tient, gout floral, un peu de grillé, houblon, très bonne

14/XII/18 - 33cl bottle from Geers (Oostakker), shared @ home, BB: 24/XI/19 - (2018-1986) Clear dark blond to orange beer, very big creamy off-white head, stable, adhesive, leaving a nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: bit fruity, stone fruit, pears, honey, pretty oxidized, orange peel, bit spicy. MF: very lively carbon, medium body. Taste: orange peel, soft acidity, oxidized malts, bit acidic, lemony, spicy notes. Aftertaste: some coriander, bit acidic, orange peel, soft bitterness, some almonds, a bit too old I guess.
Bottle, 330 ml in Netherlands. Hazy orange with large white head. Malty, fruity, some ripe fruit, bit spicy. Sweet. Some bitterness in finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Ljus med fint vitt skum. Doftar fruktigt, lite jäst. Smaken fyllig, fruktig, mjuk. Eftersmaken hyggligt lång med lite beska och fruktighet.
Bier met een niet al te interessante etiket. Smaak wel goed. De tripel is bitter met af en toe een zoete smaak. Heeft in de verte iets kruidig. -backlog de BierApp-
Flaska från Belgoklubben. Ljust kopparfärgad med smutsvitt skum. Fint humlad med klassisk tripel som bas i doft och smak.
750 ml bottle from Belgoklubben. Cloudy golden with white head. Fruity, sweet malty with yeast and herbs. Semi sweet with low bitterness and medium carbonation.

Dark straw with small fluffy head. Nose is yeast and som herbal notes. Taste is also herbal with some fresh bitterness and hoppy notes. Palate rather short but the bitter hops remaining for some time.

Objectively speaking: Most likely a different recipe, but drank in July 2008 under the Abbey Single name. I like: Fair bready malts provide a supple medium body. Relatively dry all througout, though not hoppy. I dislike: A bit disorganized yeastiness. Not much freshness involved. Not very challenging esters, barely fruity.
I'll agree with muzzlehatch that this beer is sub par. Deep cloudy golden colour. Strange yeasty flavour. Relatively clean and sweet, and it's fairly light. Nothing great. I wouldn't order it again.

Really liked this pub's dubbel and trippel, so had some hopes for this singel; alas, unfounded. Watery, slightly yeasty, bit smoky; but not malty or hoppy at all, not sweet, dull quick finish and the carbonation seemed artificial. Weak, boring all around.

Pint at the brewpub, February 2006. Deep walnut-bark color, hazy-to-opaque, with very little head atop the murkiness....nose lightly nutty, chocolaty and just a touch peaty-smoky, fairly restrained....served too damn cold, this does offer more as it warms, hints of buttery toffee and anise are noticeable....whoa, it’s a sweet one, lots of brown sugar and perhaps a bit of maple at first, licorice in the center, and as it warms and especially at the end, thick rich toffee, almost too much as there’s little in the way of balancing hops....touches of woody-twiggy character do kill the sweetness just enough to make it drinkable, though it could use a little more body....wasn’t too into this at first, but it does get a bit fuller and more expressive as it warms and is certainly recommendable.
Yellow orange with little head. Mild grapefruit aroma and flavor. Very drinkable, with a pleasant bitter aftertaste.

Straw colored. A fairly weak nose. I really couldn't detect much in it at all. A tiny bit floral. Lightly hopped for a pale ale. A bit thin. A bitter, dry finish. Decent beer. B.A. brews much better beers.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Washoe Wheat Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: "another boring beer. the aroma is slightly enticing, but there’s nothing there of note. not a horrible beer, but average at best. i was really expecting more.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Washoe Wheat Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Poured into a shaker pint at the brewery while sitting outside enjoying the view. From notes, July 27, 2012. A: Bready wheat malt, light-colored fruit and light pepper and clove spices. A: Hazy orangish-golden color with a small white head that fades pretty quickly. T: Taste seems weak in every aspect. Very light clove with some grassy, wheat-like malt and a slight fuit flavor. No flavor is very strong, however. P: Light-bodied with good carbonation, and a mild dryness. O: This beer isn’t bad, but it’s pedestrian. Again, everything is a bit too subdued.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Washoe Wheat Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: A decent yet boring wit. Pours an ugly clear orange. Smells really good, like preaches and tropical fruit, with some orange. Taste starts with citrus, but finishes dry. Had on tap at the brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Washoe Wheat Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Cloudy dark yellow with a fizzy white head. Faint banana bread aroma and a watery banana bread taste with a thin body.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Washoe Wheat Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On draft at the brewery/restaurant. Aroma:citrus, malty/grainy, very clean nose Taste: doughy, cracker, grainy, hint of citrus Overall: A clean beer that lacked complexity.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Washoe Wheat Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Taster @ the brewery. Pours really clear four a wheat. But aroma and flavor are spot on. Thin head. Pretty good except the appearance

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Washoe Wheat Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: [Tap] Pours a cloudy light yellow color with a small amount of white head. Wheat malts and cereal in the nose. Grass, herbal notes, milder amounts of citrus and sweet gum in the taste. Watery mouthfeel. Needs more body to bring out the otherwise decent flavor profile.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Washoe Wheat Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Date: July 04, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: muddy orange, headless Aroma: sweet citrus aroma Flavor: sweet orange flavor, light balancing bitterness from a citrus rind character Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 9/20 Rating: 2.4/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Washoe Wheat Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. The body was dark amber with a khaki head. the aroma was lemons with some bread and cloves. The taste was clove along with a light banana note. There were also some lemon hints.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Washoe Wheat Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Nothing in the aroma. A wheaty beer for sure and American-style, which I don’t like. Grassy thin and too wheaty.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Needle Peak Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Pours gold with a white head. Mild citus aroma with caramel. Flavor is mild toasty malt with light citrus and fruit. Bitter enough. Dry. Hint metallic?

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Needle Peak Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. The body was light amber with an tiny head. The aroma was of light citrus. The taste was the same light citrus along with basic toast notes. Very thin and light.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Needle Peak Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: no way this beer does ANYTHING good to distinguish itself. this is substandard. 6/09: still can’t believe the 4.4! gave it another shot, and it was worst in show, right behind the no-balance porter. thin, bitter, no balance here either. not a blonde, but a pale. crap either way."

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Needle Peak Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Draft. Rich amber beer with a cream head. Light malt and light citrus aroma. Light malt and light grapefruit flavor with light coca. Medium bodied. Light malt and light citrus lingers with light darker malts. Listed at the brewpub as a pale ale.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Needle Peak Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Poured into a shaker pint at the brewery while sitting outside enjoying the view. From notes, July 27, 2012. A: Grapefruit and citrus hop notes with faint sweet malts, wet grains and hay. A: Pours clear copper with a one-finger white head and decent lacing. T: Follows the nose with a dry finish and off-flavors lurking in the background. P: Medium body and low carbonation. O: A decent golden ale that lacks complexity, like all the other beers from The Brewery at Lake Tahoe. I’m starting to think that there is a serious problem with the malts this brewery uses.....

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Needle Peak Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: A decent pale ale. Pours an ok orange color with a white head. Slight smell of tropical fruit and hops. Taste is fruity upfront with a hoppy finish. Had on tap at the brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Needle Peak Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Not that much to the aroma but it looks nice. Great orange red color. The flavor is that of a solid pale ale, some good hops and a decent malt character. I like it.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Needle Peak Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Clear light orange with a fizzy white head. Sweet malty molasses aroma and taste with a clean citrus hops flavored finish.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Needle Peak Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Pretty average pale ale. Slight fizz, not much head. Slight hoppy taste. Drinkable but not outstanding.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Needle Peak Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Pours a golden color, moderate head, some very nice hop aroma here. Flavor is fairly light, as expected for the style, and not a lot happening to impress. Easy to drink, and ok beer.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Prince of Pales
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: "a change of pace, this one had an ok body, but no interesting aroma or flavor to speak of. thoroughly boring, avoidable beer. i can’t believe this place is still kicking, unless it’s gotten better since last i visited."

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Prince of Pales
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub. A white head topped a dark gold body. The aroma was tea and apples. The taste was bitter orange peels with some woody dryness. There was also a little bit of dirt.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Prince of Pales
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: A fine-smelling pale, with a noticeable but light hop character. Flavor was also nice. Like the IPA, not real hoppy but consistent and smooth. A good grainy session beer.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Prince of Pales
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: The 2nd beer of the sampler order. An English style pale ale? Well, it was hoppy a la an American pale. In fact, with the cascade type flavor it reminded of SNPA, but not nearly as refined. Aroma was nearly non-existant, but after some prodding I could get some grapefruity hops. Appearance was clear, light amber in color with an off-white head. Flavor was fairly nicely balanced with hops and malt. Overall, for a beer in made in Lake Tahoe that’s supposed to be an English style pale ale, it’s not that bad.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Prince of Pales
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Poured a clear light orange color. Head was off white and left a bit of lace on the glass. Aroma and flavor were of light malty cereal grain, a touch of caramel, and subdued flowery hops. Not bad.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Prince of Pales
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: There was something seriously wrong with this beer. Tasted like something out of a garden hose. No, the rubber taste was too strong, tasted like it was fermented in a garden hose. No good at all. It was nice and bitter though.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Prince of Pales
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Medium amber color, Medium white/tan head. Aroma is fruity and sweet (took a while to get any aroma). A medium bodied pale ale. Malts are nutty and fairly sweet. Hops are kind of mild, slightly spicy. A pale ale in the English style, so it much maltier than hoppy. It’s a little too sweet, but manageable. Smooth taste. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Prince of Pales
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Tap. Amber color. A decent amount of hops but not powerful. The malt is king in this pale ale.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Prince of Pales
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Good beer. The appearance was hazy and golden. The nose was very floral, hop cone strong. The flavor was very malty, but very very well hopped also to provide balance. The finish was crisp and bitter. HopHead delight.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Alpine Amber Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy amber with a beige head. Malty aroma. Med body. It’s malty with a little hop. Chocolate note I seem to find in ambers. Not my thing.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Alpine Amber Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Pint on tap at the Peppermill’s Bimini Restaurant. Clear copper with a lasting disc of foam. Aroma is toast, toffee and a bit of toasted nut. Tastes of caramel, toasted pecan, spicy citrus and hint of dry cocoa. Light-medium body has a pleasant medium carbonation and a nice balance.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Alpine Amber Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: "as with all their beers, this one was a bit of a letdown. not a whole lot to report on here...slightly substandard malt and hop aromas and flavor. Nothing bad, but really nothing good. re-rate 6/09: 4th best of the 8 they were serving...doesn’t really say a whole lot. not BAD, but not worth the price of a pint. darker than usual."

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Alpine Amber Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Draft. Reddish-amber beer with a cream head. Malt aroma. Malt and light citrus flavor. Medium bodied. Malt sand light citrus lingers.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Alpine Amber Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Simple, but tasty. Pours a very nice red. No smell whatsoever. Taste is simplistic, but a decent amber for warming up after a ski day. Had on tap at the brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Alpine Amber Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Clear dark amber with a fizzy white head. Faint malty aroma. Malty cereal grain taste with light citrus notes. Light bodied palate.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Alpine Amber Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On draft at the brewery/restaurant. Aroma:caramel/roasted malts, low aroma Taste:dyacital, caramel, roasted malts Overall: This was a thick chewy beer. The aroma and flavor were mild so the thick body was really off putting to me.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Alpine Amber Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Sample at the brewery. Aroma has caramel notes. Some hop. Flavor is good, and I usually don’t care for ambers. Palate is thick and finishes mildly dry. Flavor has a sweet maltInnes to it. Overall its a great beer.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Alpine Amber Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: [Tap] Light brown in color with a small white head. Hazelnut and some caramel in the nose. The taste is of caramel, grass, some cocoa, bread and grassy hops. Dry and dusty finish. Nicely balanced. Average carbonation. Mild, but pleasant. This was one of their better beers.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Alpine Amber Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours clear medium amber with nice white head and good lacing. Aroma is mostly malty and caramelly without too much hop presence. Flavor is mainly caramel malt, along with a little roastiness and mild citrusy hops. A little butterscotch. Medium body with average carbonation and a pretty standard non-hoppy amber ale mouthfeel. Overall, meh, pretty average. Drinkable I guess.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Indian Pale Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Bright yellow orange but opaque. Firm but thin top. Same big mouthfeel as the DIPA. Fruited and easier to drink though. Good drink. (#6301, 8/27/2016)

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Indian Pale Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at the brewpub with Kara. The body was deep amber with a tan colored head. The aroma was grapefruit and a little bit toasted malt. The taste was grapefruit with some toasted malt and a bitter ending. Medium body and the 7.4% ABV was noticeable.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Indian Pale Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: "maybe more of a letdown than the others, only in that i expect more from this style. this is a rather weak and unassuming ipa. nothing is loud enough, or flavorful enough. just ok. re-rate 6/09: still under average for an IPA, but one of the semi-enjoyable brews they make at least. Still a bit boring, but not as bad as I remembered."

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Indian Pale Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Pours rather apricot with a white head. Aroma seems earthy and fruity. Med body. Flavor is fruit with a little earthiness. Mild caramel. Bitter, but not strongly so. Bitter enough to make a good drink tho.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Indian Pale Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Draft. Rich amber beer with a cream head. Grapefruit and light pine aroma. Grapefruit and light pine flavor with light caramel. Medium bodied. Decent bitterness. Grapefruit and light pine lingers with light caramel.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Indian Pale Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Poured into a shaker pint at the brewery while sitting outside enjoying the view. From notes, July 27, 2012. A: Spicy, floral, and citrus notes. Slight malt sweetness in background. A: Poured a hazy, orange amber color with a two-finger light tan head that dissipated to wide rings of lacing. T: Follows the nose, slight sweetness from the malt, resiny in the middle with a crescendo bitter in the finish. P: Medium body and moderate carbonation. O: I’m starting to see a trend here with this breweries beer; malts lack complexity and hops like a fresh punch one would expect from the nose. Off-flavors become evident in the after-taste. I won’t be drinking this beer again.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Indian Pale Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: A boring IPA. Pours an orange color with a white head. Not much of any smell. Taste is bitter, but not overly so. Boring. Had on tap at the brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Indian Pale Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Clear dark golden with a fizzy white head. Sweet caramel grapefruit and pine aroma and taste with a sweet earthy finish.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Indian Pale Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Citrus and light pine. Some malty sweetness in the background. Weak in the middle. Finishes with a bitter and dry.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Indian Pale Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On draft at the brewery/restaurant. Aroma: dyacital, butter, citrus Taste:dyacital,caramel, pine, citrus Overall: This beer was flawed, large amounts of dyacital almost made it undrinkable.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Bad Ass Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Rusty red. Nic aroma of a strong beer. Delivers on the promise. Stark bock-like beer with a big malt backbone and a big hop flourish. Props. (#6302, 8/27/2016)

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Bad Ass Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at the Brewpub in LT with Kara. Pours a reddish brown with light tan head. Aroma is malty and some hops. Initially the flavor was caramel, sweet malt, bread and it had a earthiness. Finished with metallic tasting hoppy bitterness. This had the most malt of all it’s beers. There is some alcohol burn.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Bad Ass Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Tap at the brewpub. Pours really dark copper with a beige tan head. Aroma is malty and piney. Full bodied. Flavor is sweet malt, but there’s a lot of hop. It’s earthy, spicy, piney, roasty. Heavy duty ale.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Bad Ass Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Kind of like Arrogant Bastard, but not as intense. Malty and hoppy, nicely balanced and fairly easy to drink considering the ABV.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Bad Ass Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: one of their best, but that really isn’t saying much. it just means this one isn’t quite crap like the rest. nothing new to report. 6/09: still one of their better beers...more on the boozy malty side. come to think of it, none of their beers have enough of a hop presence. ok. i ordered a pint after a race, but i won’t be rushing back anytime soon."

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Bad Ass Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Draft. Rich amber beer with a cream head. Malt and light citrus aroma. Malt and light caramel flavor with light grapefruit. Medium bodied. Light caramel and light grapefruit lingers.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Bad Ass Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Nice red hue pour. Thick creamy tan head. Malt bomb. Hints of caramel, toffee, and a secret ingredient....which I can't place. Reminds me if a double red ale. I like it. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Bad Ass Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Poured into a shaker pint at the brewery while sitting outside enjoying the view. From notes, July 27, 2012. A: Toffee and caramel with hints of alcohol and metallic hops. A: Pours a medium reddish-brown color with an average-sized off-white head that left decent lacing. T: Notably disappointing from the nose, it has a very unbalanced tastes. Initially caramel, sweet malt, and bread notes with a dry earthiness, and finished with metallic tasting hoppy bitterness. P: Medium body and carbonation. O: Lacks balance that would make it easy to drink, it comes off like a bad home-brew with malts that lack complexity, weak hop notes and a slight unfermented yeast flavor and smell.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Bad Ass Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: The best so far from the Brewery at Lake Tahoe. Pours an absolutely beautiful red with a thick white head. Smells like molasses and chocolate. Taste is very creamy, with a sweetness upfront, and a green tea like finish. Has some pepper as well as some squash in the aftertaste. Had on tap at the brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Bad Ass Ale
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Murky medium brown with a fizzy off white head. Molasses and brown sugar aroma and taste with good citrus hops character and a decent bitterness.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Belgian Wit
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: On draft at the brewery/restaurant. Aroma:dyacital, coriander Taste:soapy, coriander, dyacital, solventy Overall: An over spiced mess. looked as though it was filtered as well. Not refreshing, thick and oily.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Belgian Wit
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: [Tap] Bright yellow pour that includes a little bit of haze. About a half inch of dense white head. Grainy aroma of malts and light citrus. Sweet wheat malts, lemon zest, grass and mild spice. Below average to average in body. Not a bad Witbier, but it could be a bit more robust.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Belgian Wit
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Hazy orangish-golden color with a small white head that fades pretty quickly. Aroma is nice with wheat, yeast, orange peel, spice, and a little butter. This is actually pretty flavorful. Wheat, pale malt, orange peel, and spices (mainly coriander). Just a little buttery note in there, but that doesn’t detract too much. This is sort of like what Blue Moon would taste like if Blue Moon wasn’t so terrible. Medium bodied with a somewhat tingly mouthfeel. Overall, despite the Blue Moon-ishness, this is pretty good for the style. Highly drinkable.

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Belgian Wit
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: Date: July 04, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: muddy orange, scant white head Aroma: sweet orange aroma with a light spicyness Flavor: sweet orange flavor, nice spicyness, light ballancing bitterness follows the spicyness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *4

column1: The Brewery At Lake Tahoe Belgian Wit
column2: South Lake Tahoe, California, United States
column5: This beer rocks. The color of bleach. The aroma was very nice... spicy and fruity. The flavor was much the same... spicy (cloves), fruity and pungent (orange, lemon?) and malty. Lingering citris on the tongue. Very nice wit.

Aspecto: Serafijn Blonde es una cerveza rubia que atesora una capa delgada de espuma con buena retención. - Aroma: Agradable aroma que se compone de levadura y lúpulo. - Cuerpo / Sabor: Consta de algunas especias, frutas y un agradable acabado de lúpulo.

Où, Quand, Comment : Bouteille 330ml, dégustée au Saint-Bock à Montréal (été 2007). Visuel : Couleur : jaune-dorée. Apparence : claire. Arôme : Levures fruitées (agrumes, léger de bananes) et épicées (coriandre, notes poivrées), léger de houblon herbeux et de pain. Goût : Entrée de bouche : Levures fruitées (agrumes, notes de bananes) et légèrement épicées. Un léger support de pain avec des traces de sucres est également présent avec une légère amertume asséchante de houblon herbeux aux notes florales. En bouche : Corps : moyen-mince. Effervescence : moyenne. Texture : légèrement crémeuse. Finale : moyenne et un peu sèche, légèrement amère de houblon herbeux aux notes florales avec des notes de levures fruitées et épicées.

Pajiza, nebulosa. Escasa espuma y poco duradera. Aspecto de Witbier. Minimo aroma. Levadura, citrico. Muy bebible y refrescante. Buen punto de gas. En boca buen equilibrio, caracter seco pero algun contrapunto dulce. Citrica y especiada.

Bottle @ home. Clear golden yellow coour with a fairly large white head. Smells malts, some iron, nothing crazy. Tastes malts, slightly weird but I’m not sure what it is and it’s not even that unpleasant. Medium body, nice carbo.
Een heel lekker biertje met een goede zachte smaak. Echt een aanrader om eens te proberen
Helder geel bier met veel schuim. Smaak is fris fruitig met iets van kaneel en anijs. Smaak blijft redelijk lang hangen. Erg goed wat mij betreft.
Blonde légèrement dorée trouble, effervescence moyenne, col blanc moyen. Maltée en entrée, elle développe une amertume houblonnée assez sympathique et légèrement épicée.

Blond session ale with loose, irregular, sticky, somewhat rocky, off-white head and light peach blond colour, cloudy. Strong sweet, ethereal spiciness reminiscent of aniseed, cloves and coriander, pear, melon, pineapple, soap, flowers, cheese, lemon; fruity and spicy onset, dry hoppy finish, a bit unusual and not too well-balanced, the different taste components seem to merge into each other in a somewhat uncontrolled way. Still interesting, though.

Hazy golden color, nice stable and regular white foam. Aroma is quite hidden, some notes of Belgian yeast, dust and bread. Taste is bitter and a bit salty, with some banana notes. Medium body, average carbonation, dry and astringent finish. A decent blond beer.

24/VI/14 - 33cl bottle from Willems (Grobbendonk) @ home - BB: n/a (2014-665) Clear dark blond to beige beer, big creamy white head, very stable, adhesive, leaving a nice lacing. Aroma: pretty spicy, candi sugar, coriander, bit dusty, orange peel, floral notes, banana and yeast. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: grains, sweet malts, citrus, hay, bit spicy, coriander, pretty bitter, floral. Aftertaste: chocolate bitterness, some banana, alcohol, yeast, spicy, dry, bit grassy, alcohol burn, which is weird for this beer, almonds and marzipan on warming up.

Beer sold and labeled by Brouwerij Het Koelschip in Almere. Very dark colored, in fact almost black. Sour apple aroma. Also apple and some chocolate in the flavor with some vinegar sourness. A bit yeasty. Atypical and a bit amateuristically brewed dunkel weizen. Drinkable, but not a good beer.
Bottle, from historic notes. Source not recorded. Poured golden amber with a small white head. Aroma of rotting fruit and veg. Watery texture. Just wasn't very nice.

Not an advert, but at £.80p a bottle if you order 3x24 cases to avoid delivery charge. Very low calorie where all sugar turns to alcohol- so pretty much Carb free (about 2g a bottle) Like others have said, ignore The CAMRA beer snobs who don’t seem to understand that this is brewed this way deliberately to keep the calories down. What on earth do they expect??

Its very easy for the beer snobs to slate this beer but for the thousands of diabetics in the UK it is one of the only beers they can drink without seriously jeopardising their health. Please have a heart and please, please stop trying to get this beer discontinued. If you don't like it don't drink it but please leave those less fortunate than yourselves some pleasures in life. I perhaps wouldn't drink it from choice but I quite like it and at the moment it is the best there is for us, unless perhaps the geeks can suggest something better with less than 2g of carbs per bottle.
Bottle from Darwen gold club. Clear bubbly yellow appearance with big white head. Aroma is malts. Flavour is malt, dry and earthy.
Clear golden beer with small white head. Aroma is weak malty, maybe some citrus. Taste is light sweet and soft. Thin feel. Light body, watery. Overall quite tasteless beer.
275ml bottle present.Golden orange, not much head. Oaty caramel malt aroma. and flavour. Dry and bland.
Golden appearance but overall quite bland. Refreshing if chilled. Low calories a plus

This is an absolutely superb beer. Dozens of guests and friends agree who have tried while visiting. Ignore negative reviews. Buy some and judge for yourself. Low carb too which is a bonus and unbelievable given the taste. Best sourcing direct from Classic Ales.
Butelka 330ml. Złoty kolor. Piana biała,zbita ,o średniej wysokości utrzymuje się całkiem długo. Wodniste o metalicznym posmaku,słód,trawa,lekkie chmielenie,kukurydza,woda,karton i woda....
A great substitute for people who want an easy drink that is low calorie but doesn't want to sacrifice taste.

Bouteille de 25cl. Couleur marron foncé, mousse assez faible et de tenue minime. On reconnait dinstinctement le goût singulier des production de Gayants, hormis celà, les quelques arômes de cacao ou caramel que l’on peut distinguer à la mise en bouché deviennent très rapidement insipides. Il est noté sur l’étiquette : "caractère artisanal" mais j’ai du mal à lui en concéder du caractère! Même la texture est tristounette. Trouvée à l’entrepôt - Courcelles les lens.

25cl bottle at Kasteelhof in Cassel, France. I suspect this is much improved since Joris tasted it. Firm working brune, quite precise in its pitch, a bit of chocolateand some sultana but still not benefitting from bottle-conditioning.

Medium, dense brownish head over dark cola-coloured beer, leaving some fine lace. Very bready nose, dark breadcrust, melanoidins ad sweet-smelling, as well as a faint aroma of spiced beef stock. Average. Sharp peanuts flavour, fatty acids, insectoid flavours, some melanoidins and backthroat sweet maltsyrup flavour. Extremely false impression of body, petering out lamentably watery. Pretty awful beer, rather nasty. Caractère Artisanale - meaning from a homebrewer with an overtime kit and two left hands?
Bottled. Dark brown. Vegetable aroma. Stale and lagerlike with medium body and strong notes of blood and metal. Low bitterness. Distinctly unpleasant.
Draught. Slightly hazy golden coloured beer with a citrus/apple aroma. Light malty flavour with a faint bitter finish.
Cask Handpump at the Marble Arch Inn, Manchester 24/08/2002 Clear golden coloured with some fruit and pale aromas. Smooth on the palate with a slightly bitter finish.

Sweet and fruity aroma, apples and pears, yeasty with a bit of astringent citrus and must. Cloudy pale amber with thick foamy white lacing head. Medium body with medium-high carbonation. Starts with mild malt and light sweetness, mild acidity. There is an off flavor to it, though, reminding me of the smell of burning brakes or clutch. Mild finish with meak after, no bitterness.
On cask at the GBBF...no head, hazy gold; aroma of celery, strange spiciness. Funky, but more like cleaning up after a Parliament show than actually seeing them play.
Cask. Almost black. Roasted malts (caramel and chocolate). Fruity (berries). Subtle hops. Bittersweet with roasty bitter finish. Nice full-flavoured Mild. (2008)

Cask at the Southampton Arms, London on 1st July 2010. Almost black with thin off-white head. Rich malts and slight notes of coffee and vanilla - almost like a mild version of Milton Nero. Zingy mouthfeel and highly quaffable. Very well kept in the pub.

Cask - Market Porter, London. Poured a dark brown with a fine, beige coloured head leaving a watery lacing. Smoke, roasted malts and some dried fruit on the aroma. Dark, sweet/sour fruits, some choc and a dry mid-dark malt bitterness. Soft palate texture, light to medium body with just a hint of carbonation and a mid-length finish.

Cask conditioned handpump Evening Star Brighton. A black beer with a good bubbly beige head. An excellent smoky roasty mild with chocolate licorice and fossil fuel flavours together with a little sweetness. A very competent and tasty mild.

Coarse dark beige froth covers only half the beer. Just barely translucent dark red body. Earthy fruity chocolatey aroma with wooden hoppy notes. Dry-sweetish earthy dusty cocoa taste with fruity notes. Mild mouthfeel. Light body. Dryish earthy wooden resiny aftertaste. Quite nice. Not too pleased with chocolate/fruit clash, but still a good beer. (0.5l bottle, RealAle.com.)

Cask @ GBBF 2009. Pours a clear dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty slightly burnt caramel aroma. Roasted malty caramel and coffee flavor. Has a roasted malty caramel finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.
Cask at GBBF 2009, 4th August 09. Very dark brown. Ultra smooth and soft. Lots of malt flavours. A good mild.

Cask @ GBBF 09, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear dark brown color with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, dark roasted, burnt, light coffee. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090805]
Dark brown with a lasting off-white head. Aroma of fruit and chocolate with a touch of coffee. Sweetish malty flavour with a nice roasted character.

Cask, from the Central Southern Bar at GBBF 09. Jet black body carrying a few floaters on the surface. Mild roasted malty aroma. Vaguely taste of roasted, dark malts. Semi-sweet impression. Not bad for a British mild &#40Earls Court, London 05.08.2009&#41.

Bottle. Hazy Gold in colour. Hoppy; floral & grassy hops, spicy. Fruity; citrus-grapefruit and orange. Malty; toasty malts, caramel. Bitter citrus-fruity hoppy throughout. Dry bitter finish. (2009-05)
Quite pale, slightly hazy. Aromas grass / hay and some caramel. A good level of bitterness leaving a leafy aftertaste.
Bottle. Vintage. Frothy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate malty and heavy hoppy aroma. Grassy notes. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.
Bottle. Medium head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are nuts, caramel, hops, fruits and malt. Formidable bitter.

cloudy orange brown, smooth white head.3 sweet flowery hoppy aroma, caramel, 6. flavor is pretty spicy ,herbs, licorice, bitter hops, a bit chemically. Faint flowery hops. This sample a bit old beer notes, but it is also bbf aug 09 tasted oct 10. Overall a good bitter with lots pf flavor and a good measure of aromatic uk hops

Fløska. Hazy dark amber colour, small but nice creamy off-white head, ok lacing. Aroma of stinging neddles, hops, caramel, herbs, bit soap. OK mouthfeel. Flavour: herbs, caramel, flowery and bit fruity hops, mild liqourice root touch towards the end, dry, ok bitterness. Strange .
500ml Bottle - Amber in colour. Hoppy aroma with grapefruit and tea. Crisp and refreshing taste with hops, biscuity malt and grapefruit.

Cask @ Clarence Tavern, Gosport. Pours a pale amber color with a samll off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty slightly dry caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty caramel finish with some weak hints of hops.
Cask, amber / gold with a crisp white heads. Clean fresh hops with smooth nutty biscuit malt tones.
Caskc conditioned at a Wetherspoons. Amber with white head. Good solid quaffing bitter, dry, with a nutty light malt, some biscuit then a peppery hop. Decent enough.

A bright golden yellow coloured beer with a thick and frothy white head. A light hoppy aroma, grassy and citrusy with a background pale malt. Dry mouthfeel. A mild bitter taste to start, again, grassy and pithy citrus fruit, then a biscuity, slightly caramel malt flavour in the background. The finish is hop led and bitter.
500ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours clear pale gold, massive bubbly white head. Aromas of lemon, sherbet. Taste is very dry, more citrus, light wheat. Bitter, dry finish.
Hazy blonde. Aroma is mainly earthy with a hint of lemon. Taste is earthy, maybe a little bit mushroomy. Dry and w lingering bitterness.

Cask. The pour’s a clear gold with a small white head. The aroma’s of sweet grains, mild caramel, pale malts, honeyed bread. The taste is light floral hops, soft sweet malts backbone. Some white grape. Syrupy. Light body, crisp. Not bad.

Cask at the Guide Dog - St Denys (So’ton) - 09/09/12. Pale golden yellow with a thinnish off-white head. Nose comprises apples, toffee, straw and hops. Tastes of sweet malts, hops, fruit, light caramel, slightly earthy and farmish. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation leading to a dry finish.
Cask at Guide Dog, Southampton Mid-blonde with gentle carbonation and citrus on the nose. Light and bright with a clean citrus character and a slight bitterness in the finish. Expertly balanced.

(Cask at Carpenter’s Arms, Marble Arch, London, 27 Nov 2011) Pale golden colour with creamy, white head. Fruity, hoppy nose with notes of lemon, grapefruit and grassy hops. Fruity, hoppy taste with citrus, lemon peel, biscuity malt and a fairly dry finish with a generous grassy/citric bitterness. Medium body, quite dry and fairly bitter. Very nice and refreshing.
Drucken på Hawkley Inn. Lätt kropp, lätta flyktiga blommiga toner. Friskt lättdrucken men kanske lite väl tunn.

06/09/2011 Brasserie 4:20 (cask). Dorata, viva, abbastanza limpida, con bella schiuma morbida, pannosa, bianca, molto persistente. Al naso sentori di malto, caramello, pane, frutta, note floreali. In bocca è delicata, con una luppolatura morbida e mai aggressiva, corpo medio-basso, leggermente acquosa, ma gradevole. Carbonazione quasi assente. Una ottima session beer, rinfrescante e gradevolissima, al pari della Hole Hearted.

Cask @ Guide Dog Inn, Southampton. Pours a slightly hazy pale golden color with a small whitehead. Has a fruity malty hoppy aroma. Dry malty hoppy bitter flavor with some hints of citrus. Has a fruity malty hoppy bitter finish.
Cask at Ascot Festival 2010. Pours a good amber colour with a thin white head, good aroma of hops, and a hint of caramel. The finish is sweet and fruity.
Cask (Gallows Bird, Espoo, Real Summer Ale Festival 2004) Copper coloured, tiny head. Sweet fruity aroma, marmaladey. Rich nutty malty taste. Very good example of an English bitter.

Cask (handpump), rediscovered notes from March 2004. Venue uncertain. Amber colour. Sweetish and predominantly malty with some underlying spicy hop character. Smooth and mellow without much bitterness. Could maybe use a touch more grip and bite, but pretty decent. An easy drinker.
Cask conditioned. Earthy caramel aroma. Dry bitter flavour with unpleasant nutty crystal malt which fades to leave a long sticky hop finish.

Cask Fresh @ Crown & Thistle, Gravesend - a Freehouse. Slightly dark amber with a slightly foamy head. Good balance of marmalade sweet malt and good tangy bitterness. Quality throughout. [3.4] The Oak, Bank, New Forest. Pleasant fulsome bitter. Decent sweet malt; orange marmalade; tangy hops. Some dust in the finish. Very pleasant. [3.6]
Cask Conditioned at Banbury Beer Festival. Light golden yellow with thin fluffy head. Oily, fresh flavour, a touch of linctus but rich in hops. Nice dry follow through.
Pale straw in colour. This beer lacks malt body but is redeemed by a good level of hops. The hops are oily and pine-like and quite addictive. Squirrels would probably like it.
Light brown colour; thin flavours (nutty), dryish finish....................

Cask at Hants Oktoberfest 2019. Malty spicy marmalade aroma. Light-medium gold. Bubbly white head. Light-medium bitter with a citrus sour edge over a malty core. Light bodied. Thin if slick. Flat carbonation. Long finish. OK gold.
had at on tap at a whetherspoons pub. It was a fruity light golden beer. It just left you wanting something more from the beer It was a let down to be honest

23/8/2019. Cask at the 42nd Peterborough Beer Festival. Pours clear bright gold with a small bubbly off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, fruit, flowers and yeast. Medium plus sweetness and light to moderate bitterness. Medium body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation.

A bit confusing to still have this listed as Oakleaf. Cask half at the Volunteers Arms, GBBF. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of malt, a little buttery. Bitter taste and finish. Not sure it is as good now as it was.

Bottle at home under the new Fallen Acorn label. Pale amber with a rocky white head. Rich aroma of malt, peach and grapefruit and hop. Sweetish start with a gentle but persistent bitterness. Rich, smooth, buttery malt, orange wine gum and marmalade flavours. Rich, smooth, excellent carbonation and a long, dry finish. Excellent. One of those brewers that does bottling properly and not just as an afterthought.

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in May 2010 - Deep gold in colour. Very Hoppy; piney resinous hops. Fruity; grapefruit citrus and tropical fruits. Malty; caramel. Very hoppy citrus fruity throughout. Dry bitter hoppy finish. Nice beer! (2010-05)

Cask @Meat And Barrel, Portsmouth. Clear golden color, small white head. Aroma has strong diacetyl, butterscotch, some fruityness. Light-bodied. Flavor is also dominated by diacetyl, not much of Cadcade to talk about. Dry citrus finish. Something gone wrong.
Clear golden beer, white head. Grapefruity flavour, you get the malt as well. A touch sickly after a couple buy nice. Really nice.

500ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours clear pale gold, thick white head. Big lemon drop aromas, light grapefruit. Something earthy too. Taste is quite sharp, more lemon and light floral notes, touch of white sugar sweetness at the back. Decent beer though.

Bottle from Beers Of Europe [210115] Light golden, clear, frothy bubbly white head, light lacing Aroma - Fresh citrus hops, lemon, soft tropical hops, light sweet malts, soft fruits, clean nose, soft sweet lemon Taste of soft fruity pale malts, dab of soft yeast, plenty of zesty hops, some peppery hops, lemon zest, good soft sweet light malts that don’t get in the way of the hops, gets a bit more bitter with the drinking Palate - Soft carb, medium body, soft sweet, zesty bitter. Finish as main flavour, slightly dry, soft peppery, bitter zest Overall - Very quaffable stuff, easy going, well made

BCA at home. Pours black in colour with hints of brown red through. White head of foam. Aroma of nuts, chocolate and roasted malt. Taste is slightly sweet to start, then bitter. Some fruit, more roast, dry finish. Very smooth mouthfeel, plain but rich and satisfying with a good bitterness throughout. Another good beer from Oakleaf. Recommended.
Cask@ three judges Glasgow Aroma is sweetish grain and a bit of chocolate Taste is sweet malt wit a sweet finish bit thin ok but it,s a drink once and move on beer
Cask by hand-pump at Bon Accord, Glasgow - opaque dark brown near black, good beige head, sweet chocolate, mocha, creamy, good carbonation
Bottle at home, 31st August 14. Aroma is chocolate, malts, a little iron. Pours flat, taste is chocolate, ash, metallic. Palate is too thin, drinks easy. OK, about what I expected
Bottle from Bitter Virtue at home on 8/8/14. Pours black with no head. Aroma of coffee and liquorice. Bitter dry finish.

Bottle, from Hogs Back shop, at JF’s house decoration bash 22/02/14. Light black with a moderate tan covering. Nose is roast malt, cocoa powder, light spice, touch of vanilla. Taste comprises burnt toffee, light roast, cocoa powder, dark fruit twang. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, a little on the watery / thin side. Ok stout, easy drinker, perhaps a little thin for the ABV.

Cask conditioned handpump Seven Stars Rugby 01/02/14. A black beer with a whitish loose head and good lace. A good dry roasty stout. A welcoming nose and great dry flavours. Restrained bitterness. Rich with good chocolate and coffee mélange. Good stuff. Score 3.9 Subsequent rating scored 4.2. Average becomes 4.0

Cask at the Lyric - Soho, London. Pours dirty brown with a large, lasting beige froth head. The nose holds earth, wet tobacco ash and milk chocolate. Light sweet flavor with lots of gritty ash, tobacco, abrasive charred leaf bitterness. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Poor condition. More ashy roast to finish, bitter cocoa, burnt wood, dirt. I fear this might be the end of a cask that has been pouring for a bit. Not much to like here. A pretty unpleasant drink.

Cask at Lyric Soho. It pours deep ruby-brown with a medium beige head. The nose is roasted malt, cocoa, coffee and burnt notes. The taste is roasted malt, pepper, toast, ash, burnt notes, coffee and mild acidity with a very dry finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Not a whole lot going on really. A run of the mill stout.
500ml Bottle - Very dark brown in colour. Liquorice, coffee and roasted malt in the aroma. Very roasted taste with notes of coffee, liquorice and plain chocolate standing out.

Bottle, from historic notes. Source not recorded. Poured slightly hazy dark amber with a creamy off-white head. Aroma of moderate roasted malt, toffee, biscuit, hops and fruit. Moderate sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily texture. Was a pretty decent brew.

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in Oct 2014 - Dark Brown in colour. Malty; roasty malts, smoked malts, toffee/caramel, some coffee, hints of liquorice. Fruity; some dark fruits. Spicy. Hoppy; slightly earthy hops. Sweetish roast malty and smoky, becoming increasingly bitter into the finish. Liked this. Decent. (2014-10-25)

Backlog rating. Cask at JDW CW, London. It pours a rich copper color with a medium tan head. Aroma is rich malty and light sweet and medium crispy, with notes of dried leaves, caramel, toffee and nuts. Taste has light chestnuts, caramel, toffee, earth and dried leaves. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, tasty

Appearance: Dark brown, clear. Nice amount of light tan head. Good head retention. Aroma: Dark malt, toasted. Hint of fruit? Taste: Good amount of dark malt, slightly toasted and some bitterness. Smooth, some caramel sweetness. Bought: Beers of Europe, 500 ml, £2.09 Info: 4/7-2015, 83/300M, BB: 20/10-2015

Draught (Regal (JDW), Cambridge) (7:4+:7:4+:14=3.6++) Deep red. Soft sweet roasty aroma. Soft gently chocolatey malty body. Succulent and sweet palate. Mellow. A top ruby ale. What a start to a morning - delicious!

Cask at The Green Dragon, Leek (JDW) A clear mid brown colour with a fizzy white head. Aroma is nutty with some roasted malts, spicy fruits and earthy hops. Taste of roasted nuts, spicy fruit, earthy hops and some chocolate. Medium bodied and soft carbonation. A malty, fruity finish. A tasty winter ale, enjoyed this.
Good dark brown colour with creamy head. Hazelnuts and chocolate taste malty flavour and hint of black midget gems. Good strength and crisp on palate. All in all a good one.

500ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours very dark brown, but clear, big, pillowy creamy head. Aromas of hazelnuts, high-baked biscuits, light chocolate, raisins. Taste is all this and more, some dried mixed peel, more nuttiness. Medium body, creamy texture. A real treat actually, lovely example of the style.

Handpump at the Moon on the Square JDW, dark brown with a clinging off-white head and aromas of fruity dry malt. Full bodied with dry-sweet malts, peppery hops and faint hints of liquorice, burnt toffee and plain chocolate. Delicious.

Cask @ Bridge House JDW, Belfast [141114] Caramel brown, clear, dense off white head Aroma of caramel, touch of brown bread, dab of spicy English hops Taste of caramel, twiggy hops, spicy hop, no fruits, metallic tinge Palate - Soft bitter. Finish is bitter with some rust. Overall - Wasn’t all that keen this to be honest.

500ml bottle in 2015. Clear deep golden with a white head. Aroma of bitter and resinous hops, with a lot of pine and peal. More piney flavours, quite crisp and with a big dose of bitterness. Just gets a little astringent at the end, but otherwise nice.

Bottle at home. Pours a clear, light bronze colour with a thin head. Pungent aroma of skunky hop, malt and floral orange. Taste is very bitter. Lots of flavour: sweet juicy malt, more orange marmalade and a dry, herbal bitterness. The label suggests aniseed and I do not disagree. Long, rich finish, ending dry. A great beer on lots of levels and recommended.

JDW, Southampton - Admiral. Lovely citric flavours in a malt full of character. If all hoppy beers had such a great malt base it would make all the difference. Bags of flavours, baby of character, lovely drop to drink.
YUM, if you like IPAs that are citrusy and have a lingering taste you’ll certainly enjoy this, I did :)

On cask at the Guildford Arms. Appearance - golden with a proportionate head. Nose - oranges and a touch of mountain herb. Taste - fresh oranges and lemons with a nice sweet fruitcake note in the background. Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a long dry finish. GGood balance. Overall - enjoyable ale.
Huddersfield Beer Festival. Blonde with a small head and a hoppy nose. It’s quite dry with its dominant hop taste that has some very small fruit notes.

Cask-conditioned at the Seven Stars, Bristol 7/7/2014. Golden, with a decent, white, head. Hedgerow fruit, with a touch of apricot and tangerine, biscuity malts and a lingering, bitter, finish. Enjoyable English drinking.

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in Feb 2014 - Pale gold in colour. Decent off-white head. Good lacing. Fruity; grapefruit citrus, lemon, hint of tropical fruits. Hoppy; grassy hops, moderate hop bite. Malty; toasty malts, caramel. Moderately bitter citrus fruity hoppy and dry throughout. Very drinkable.

21st February 2014 Chelmsford Winter Beer Festival. KEGS. Cask. Almost clear paleish gold beer, small bubbly white head. Palate is light and dry and a little crisp. Nice carbonation. Light pale malt, semi sweet. Dry and slightly bitter floralness. Nice citric peel lemon - orange - grapefruit. Light finish. Decent.

Cask at the Michael Bacon JDW, blond with a fine white head anda citrus hoppy nose. Powerfully dry-bitter on the palate, yet with an earthy note and an underlying maltiness, it’s almost like an English take on an American IPA.

Cask Pint at Cask Pub & Kitchen, Pimlico, London in May 2010 - Very dark brown. Roast malty (caramel, some chocolate). Fruity (dark fruits, berries and citrus). Some grassy hops are evident. Bitter hoppy malty throughout with a lingering citrusy bitter finish. Very tasty. Hoppy for a Mild. Super beer! (2010-05)

On cask at the Speaker, Westminster dispensed into a pint glass (Dec ’11). A mid brown colour with a small head that had vanished after 4 or 5 sips. Smelt very hoppy, citrus nose, light malts and nuts, maybe another fruit (of the dried variety) or perhaps mild spices. Smelt a lot like the Hophead! Tastes akin to Hophead but earthier and more emphasis on malt and nut, maybe a smidge of toffee/caramel, but similar hoppy pleasanteries! Mouthfeel was fine. Hophead in a brown winters jacket !

My first ever visit to ‘The Southampton Arms’ (London) and one of the many cask offerings was this beer: my third beer of a slow Saturday afternoon session was a hand-pulled pint of this, poured into an old ‘dimpled pint mug’, like all the cask ales are in this pub. I like a good Dark Mild now and again, this fitted the bill nicely. Dark brown with an off-white wisp of bubbles on top it looked your typical beer of that style. Roast/toasted malts in the nose, coffee and toffee like with some slightly burnt bits in the smells too. The taste is also malts all the way, again roasted/toasted with some dried fruit and malt loaf flavours coming through as well. The finish is fairly dry and the beer is far from sweet, the hops coming into their own towards the end of each gulp (you don’t sip Mild). Not the richest or thickest Dark Mild body wise, but very enjoyable non-the-less.
Cask, The York Tap, York. Medium white head. Black body. Fruity, roast, spicy. Bittersweet. Dry finish. I did not realise this was a mild.
Cask at Euston Tap. Dark red brown colour with small beige head. Aroma is dark fruit, plums, bit roasty. Taste is fruity, malty and nice and hoppy finish. Maybe a touch of spice. Pretty nice.

Very pleasant hoppy/bitter dark ale. Well-balanced without any of its elements out-doing the other. Perhaps a bit too straight-forward for long-lasting rewards, as most of its character is quite immediately apparent.

Half, from cask @Craft Beer Co, London. A cap of beige fisheyes, covering a translucent dark mahogny body. Mild coffee, citrussy hops and English licorice on the nose. Taste has a chalky and dryish malt character. Tones of cocoa. Also a pleasant fruitiy bitterness underneath. Soft and creamy in the mouth. Less than medium full, yet not thin. Soft malty and light fruity-bitter ending. Nicely balanced, lots of taste. Yum!
Cask. Nice easy mild. Dark color, small off-white head. The nose is a bit roasty and fruity. The nose is mostly mild roasted malts. Easy, light body. Very easy to drink. Soft carbonation. Nice mild

A good beer. Described as mild it has all the characteristics you would expect. Dark. Malty. But the great thing with this beer is the balance given by greenish hops, giving a different type of hop flavour compared to most dark molds. Nice.

Dark toffee with ruby highlights. Tan head, thin in size. Lacing. Caramel and malty aromas. Tastes of hops right up front, slightly bitter with malt in the middle and a caramel aftertaste. Slight bitterness on the back, but subdued. Sweet viscous bitterness. Okay. Not a whole lot going on though. Too thin and lacking in flavor.
Cask Handpump at the Head Of Steam, London 11/06/2003 Clear golden coloured sharp and fruity. Some dryness in a creamy hop finish.
June, 2005. Catford Beer Fest. Full and juicy with a good wheaty flavour and a gentle hint of passion fruit and honey.

Cask@Catford Beer Festival. A bit dissapoiting, especially seeing that it comes from one of my favourite English brewers. Quite a thin, spritzy mouthfeel, with subtle hints of coriander and lemon. Some light eggy/sulfuric notes in the aroma, which weren’t too pleasant. Not really up there as far as witbiers go.

Cask at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Pale yellow. Citric, lemony hop aroma. Light bodied with medium sweetness and soapy hoppiness. The mouthfeel is light and rounded and there’s lingering bitterness in the finish. Much more of a blond ale than a witbier.
(sampled cask-conditioned at Akkurat, Stockholm) Light yellow, low firm white head. Vague lemony aroma. Lemon and pale malts in flavour. Notes of grapefruit in the aftertaste. This is not a Wit!

Gravity at Banbury Beer Festival. Sampled with Maeib. Hazed yellow, no head. A bit of a pork inspired Wit. Hints at the requisite chalkiness, and is lemony, but seems like more of a Golden ale to me. Nice dryness in the finish. Very citric, with a lemon smell. Ok.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Banbury BF. A light haze to this yellow-green coloured attempt at a Belgian Wit. The aroma has a tiny amount of spice and some lemony notes. The taste is a bit medicinal with hints of lemon. It is a reasonable beer but not really true to its style.

Presumably intended to be in a Belgian wit bier style, but I don’t think its one of Dark Star’s more successful efforts. Very pale straw colour, only slightly hazy. There some citric edge here - even a little sharpness. However, I didn’t pick up too much in the way of spicing and, overall, I found this a bit dull. Cask (handpump), Head of Steam, Euston.

(Cask conditioned) Slightly hazy golden color with a medium, white head. Quite mild, flowery-hoppy aroma. Sweetish, very flowery and somewhat fruity flavor. Would like even more hopping, though. Medium-bodied, sticky, very soft and smooth, low-carbonated palate. It’s interesting to see a British, cask conditioned wheat beer. It’s just way too mild and flat to be interesting as a witbier.
Cask Conditioned at Banbury Beer Festival. A reasonable attempt at a Witbier, but the spice is a litle over the top, no subtlety. Lemon with a corriander flavour.
Cask Handpump at the Pot Of Beer, Manchester 16/11/2001 Mid brown colour and very fruity. Dry hop finish.

Cask (gravity dispense), Chelmsford Beer Festival, July 2005. I’m not sure I’ve ever seen a British brewer attempt a bock before, so full marks for trying. However, it didn’t succeed entirely. The colour is a deep tawny. Malty aroma but it has a quite raw, stagnant, feel to it. Dull, malty flavour with caramel, hints of licorice and a touch of bitterness. But the flavours were a bit muted and, overall, there wasn’t really a lot happening for me.

Cask@Chelmsford Beer Festival. A bock on cask? Doughy caramel sweetness, touch of soy (only aa very small touch). A little sticky and flat in the mouthfeel. Not the best from thiss brewer, but still nice and soft and as usual from Dark Star, well made.
Cask at The Sportsman, Rickmansworth in 2013. Mid golden with a white head. Aroma of floral hops, orange and peaches. Flavour is malty sweetness, with dried and soft fruit notes and some grassy hops.
Floral aroma. Zesty honey tastes with a marmalade bitter finish. Nice easy drinking. Quite sweet so one was enough.

September 16, 2017 - at Craft (Clerkenwell) - handpull cask. Clear gold with decent smallish rocky off-white head. Floral golden ale aroma with some tree fruit - simple. Taste follows, has a tangy tartness and more floral pungency - airy, dry, medium finish - good shape, solid beer.
On tap at Cask pub & kitchen. Golden colour with small white head. Mild hop aroma. Bitter, malt, slightly sweet taste. Medium body.
Cask, pours clear pale gold, small white head. Aroma is fluffy caramel malts, floral and citrus, butterscotch. Light medium body, oily, creamy texture. Very soft carbonation. Light bitter finish.

Clear pale golden with one finger white head. Aroma is dry malts, cereal, crisp bread, melon, citrus, grass and light floral notes. Taste is melon, citrus, grass, floral hops and slightly burnt crisp bread. Light mouthfeel, minimal carbonation and bitter flowery aftertaste.

Cask at The Roebuck, Leek. A clear golden colour with a medium white head. Aroma of lemon, honey, some orange, subtle pale malts and slight floral hops. Taste of lemon, honey, some orange, slight grass, a little caramel, boiled sweets and subtle floral hops. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. A soft, citrusy hop bitterness in the finish. A good, zesty and fruity golden ale. So sessionable and flavourful like most dark star beers.
Quite bitter tasting with s lovely golden clear appearance. Subtle head and a little fruity. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask at the Stockbridge tap. Pours clear amber, nose is burnt toffee, malty, lemon, taste is zesty lemon, chewy toffee, biscuit.

Cask handpull at The Webb Ellis Twickenham as ’Dark Star Sunburst’, 4.8%. Golden dark yellow, still and clear, small foamy white head. Aroma is sugary biscuit, honey, Danish pastry. Body is smooth with soft carbonation. Taste is lightly woody, a little floral, soft malts in great balance with the woody liquorice stick hops, breathy musty bitterness.
