Not particularly complex but it’s an assertive flavour and I like what’s there a lot. I’d happily drink this all night.

Cask Pint at Edward Rayne (JDW), Raynes Park, London in Dec 2012 - Amber Bronze in colour. Fruity; orange citrus. Spicy, ginger. Malty; toasty malts, caramel. Hoppy; grassy hops. Sweet spicy fruity malty throughout. Very drinkable. (2012-12-06)

Cask at The Congress, Longton. A clear deep amber colour with thin off white head. Aroma of red berries, caramel, some cherry and subtle herbal hops. Taste of red berries, caramel, some cherry, slight brown sugar, subtle ginger and herbal hops. Medium bodied and an oily texture. A dry, malty finish with a slight herbal hop bitterness in the aftertaste. A full bodied malty premium bitter, the ingredients are interesting but the beer doesn’t quite work well enough for me. Ok.

Cask at local bar in Brighton. Clear dark amber with almost no head. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Nice herbal bitterness with some sweet tones. Caramel, clove, brown sugar, malts, flower, spices and herbs. A tasty seasonal. (25/1/2015)

Amber beer with a thin white head and bittersweet smell. Flavour is basically of light fruit but there’s a sickly hit of cinnamon as well and leaves a sort of weird, claggy aftertaste. Not bad but I wouldn’t dash back to it.
Half pint - on tap at Dorking beer fest. pours a clear amber/copper colour with an off white head. aroma is biscuity malts, hops and ginger. taste is malty and earthy with a dry nutty finish.
Cask at Oluttupa Viisi Penniä, Helsinki. Colour is clear dark orange with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Bitterness and malts.

(Cask at Viisi Penniä, 20150109) The beer poured dark brown and clear. Its head was small, white and it lasted long. Aroma had malts, molasses and sulphur. Palate was medium bodied with low carbonation. Flavours were malts, caramel, grass, earth and bitterness. Aftertaste was earthy and bitter. Aroma was a bit weird but the taste was nicely balanced.
Cask@5p. Red amber. Amber yeasty malts, slight raisiny caramels, sort of red berry. Bitterish, slight husky. Bit messy. -- bb
Cask at the Stockbridge tap... Amber... Thin white lacing... Soft dry fruit.. Big spice nose... Soft fruits.. Dry toffee.. Dry roast... Light mellow spice
Poured reddish brown with a small off white head. Aroma of dark fruit and caramel malt. Light to medium body, flavour of nuts and ginger, sweet berries and malt.
Sampled cask conditioned at Akkurat, Stockholm. Amber, creamy head. Light orangey aroma. Clean, firm and rounded maltiness. Dry, yet fruity with lingering grassy bitterness.

Cask pint as Original at the King’s Tun, Kingston. Pours clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of roast malt with treacle and toffee. Sweetish taste and finish. A lot better than the last time I had it.
Tried at the Cardinals Hat, Lincoln. Deep ruby colour with a light tan head. Aroma stone fruit, stewed fruit and malty. taste light sweet to dry finish medium body.

Deep dark color with a small tan head on top. Moderate intensity in the aroma. Medium body and a soft carbonation level. Semi dry texture. Bready, roast and mild fruity flavor. [Cask at Fat Cat in Norwch, England]
Pours a dark brown colour with a small light beige head. A grainy roasted malt and brown bread aroma. Similar roasted grainy taste, moderately sweet and some dryness in the finish. Average.

Cask at the Fat Cat, Pours dark brown with a small off white head. Aroma of light roasted malt, caramel, hop, mild fruit. Light sweetness and medium roasted bitterness. Medium body and slick texture, carbonation is average.
Cask. Appearance is very dark brown, with a small beige head. Treacly malty aroma, with hints of brown bread. Taste- more treacle, burnt malt, brown sugar, toffee.
Cask @ The Fat Cat, Norwich. Medium head with medium duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, fruits and hops. Sweet finish.

Cask @ Fat Cat, Norwich. Clear dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and caramel. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and roasted moderate bitter finish. 180217

Cask @ Fat Cat, as Dark Star Original. Norwich. Pours black with an offwhite head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, light bread. Flavor is light sweet, malt, caramel, bread, liitle dark fruit. Medium body, soft carbonation. Medium body, soft carbonation, sweet finish. 180217

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in July 2011 - Very dark ruby colour. Very Malty; roast malts, coffee, caramel, chocolate, liquorice. Fruity; dark fruits, berries. Hoppy; earthy and grassy hops. Sweet roast malty with a slightly sour hop/fruit edge. Fantastic dark ale. Great pint! (2011-07-28)

Cask (gravity) @ The 18th Reading Beer and Cider Festival 2012, Reading, Berkshire England. Clear medium amber orange colour with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing to lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate hoppy, orange - citrus. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120505]
Zzt bottle. Typical UK golden ale, more prominent in malt than hop flavours. Hint of butter. Very refreshing aftertaste. Seems like a good session beer

Cask at the William Webb Ellis (JDW), Twickenham - 14/04/12. Dark golden brown with a generous dollop of off-white head. Citrus and floral hops on the nose allied to malt. Hoppy taste, zesty citrus, medium bodied, crisp finish.

Hand-pulled pint in ‘The 7 Star’: Carey St London, on 28th April 2012. Struggled to enjoy this to be honest; it looked OK, an orange hue to the light brown body with a fairly good head of off-white bubbles perched on top. The nose was flowery and fruity with lightly baked bread yeast in the mix. The taste was also on the flowery/fruity side with a mini-hop bitterness towards the end of each sip. Medium bodied but lacking something: too floral for my taste buds.
Cask @ Akkurat. Dried apricots... sort of dark fruitiness... flour... fresh grape in the aftertaste... a small touch of tigerbalsam... Refreshing and quite complex.
Cask at Akkurat. Pours golden with a small white head. Fruity sweetness like in califonian raisins, some floralness and honney and orange cest bitterness.

30th April 2012 Euston Tap. Light haze on this gold beer. Tidy white head. Palate is smooth and dry with a little fine carbonation. Light crisp malts supports reasonable hop. A little repressed orange - grapefruit citrus. Minerals. Finishes dry. Nicely balanced.
Cask @ Craft Beer Co. reddish amber brown colour, reasonable head. Resin hop aroma. Fruity hop flavour, bitter sweet smokey aftertaste. Not bad.

Cask handpull, The Salmon, Leicester, 23/05/12. Orange-gold heaped with a fat stable head. Muted, orange-hinting aroma. Wow; pretty intense, deeply stewed, earthy hop character with woodland notes I’m struggling to describe..hawthorn? Softening creaminess, some chalk and Soothers not detracting from the pungently bitter finish. G+T linger. Hopped-up, slightly wonderful, strangely English stuff considering the name.

Cask at Akkurat. Somewhat hazy golden beer with a small but lasting beige head. Fruity, hoppy, grassy, bready aroma, grapes, apples, metal notes. Fresh fruity hoppy flavor, pineapples, citrus, apples, peach, metal, perfume notes. Long bitter fruity finish with pineapples and metal.
Cask. Dark Reddish Brown. Bitter espresso coffee and milk chocolate. Roasted malts. Dark fruits, berries. Full-flavoured. Noticeable hop in the finish. Good balance. Nice Porter! (2008)

August 28, 2013. Hand-pull cask at Southampton Arms. Dark black, small head. Proper oily/toasty aroma, a little treacle and a hint of iodine. Taste follows. Light body, slick, nice acidic oily finish. Well done.

Cask at Victoria station ’Wetherspoons’, London. A dark brown/black coloured pour with a medium beige fluffy head on top. Roasty, malty, chocolate aroma. Tastes similar, roasty, malty, chocolate, hint of coffee. A lovely smooth drinking porter from Dark Star.
On tap @ Craft Beer, Islington. Dark brown with a tiny brown head. Roasted and malty tones. Coffee, malt, chocolate and hops. Medium body with a nice, dry finish.

Cask @ wetherspoons. Deep dark black colour. No carbonation. Not a massive aroma but what you'd expect - deep maltiness. Flavourwise, it's good, though a bit watery in the mouth. Licorice, coffee, treacle and a nice bitter finish. Good. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask at Inn Deep, Glasgow Scotland. Enjoyable, medium bodied porter, quite a light malt aroma, pasteurised milky taste with a light, crisp burnt chocolate finish. Nice session beer.

Cask,hand pulled at The Craft,Clerkenwell.19th february.Dark brown pour with small off white head.Nice aroma of chocolate,malt and coffee.Chocolate,roast malt and coffee flavour too with a little nuttiness in the background making a very drinkable and tasty porter.

Cask (Oliver Twist, Stockholm) - Dark brown in colour. Chocolate, malt, roasted nuts and coffee in the aroma. Smooth and delightful taste with notes of smooth milk chocolate, coffee and roasted malt standing out. Superb.

Cask conditioned at The New Inn, Witney, Oxon. Black with off white head. Darkly roasted malts, bitterness, coffee with a dry black chocolate flavour. Plenty of mouthfeel and depth on the palate. Very decent.
Dark brown coloured beer with small brownish head and no carbonation. Roasted port hinted aroma. Medium sparkling palate. Finish is roasted bit sweet ending dry.

Bottled, 330ml, aged 7.5yrs from the now closed Bellinger’s Garage, Grove, Oxon. Dark chestnut with cream head. This is a big, fruity, smooth beer, prunes in a silky way. The alcohol is well melded into the malt fruitiness, as are the hops. It has aged rather well imo. Late caramel note. Very decent indeed.
Klares dunkles rotbraun mit durchschnittlicher Schaumkrone. Malzig, süßlich, leicht fruchtig, dunkle Beeren, Pflaume, Whisky.
*330ml bottle, 7.4%. Extreme rich beginning. Dried fruits, plums, brown sugar. Not too sweetish, nice strong ale characteristics. Long and intense thick fruity malty aftertaste. Nice!
Bottle. Brown with beige head. Nose is mostly whisky, sweet malts, dark fruits, toffeeish. Taste is mellow but somewhat thin bodied, sweet malts, whisky, dark fruits and berries. A bit unbalanced.
Cask at tapped Leeds. Pours dark brown, thin beige head. Aromas of stone fruit, cooked plums. Taste is rich, sweet, spicy. Sticky finish. Good.
Cask tapped Leeds. Black thin head. Aroma dark fruits malts taste same some sweetness alcohol roasted malts ok bitter finish. Medium body. Decent stuff was expecting more!
Cask at the Harp, Covent Garden. Black, small bubbly tan head. Body is light, smooth, low carbonation. Taste is tangy toffee, plummy, not really bitter at all.
Keg @ Euston Tap. Fairly sweet with caramel and sultanas and an earthy bitter influence. Slick mouthfeel, not bad at all.

Cask at Euston Tap. Lovely dark tan with creamy lacing. Plenty dark fruit and spicing. Good temperature here for cask. Blackcurrant, some alcohol, cherry. Incredibly smooth and rounded. Damn fine in any season!

Aroma: caramel malts, winter spices, some dark berries, hints of alcohol. Appearance: dark brown/black, hardly any head. Taste: medium to heavy sweet. Palate: long dri-ish finish, some alcohol, strong sweet malts, dark berries again, more is hidden. Overall: nice English Strong Ale, palate is quite complex. Pint at Willow Walk, Victoria.

September 7, 2014 - at Craft Beer Co (Islington) * As Dark Star Vice Beer @ 4.5% ABV but confirmed it IS this beer * Clear deep gold, minimal off-white bubbly head. Nice light slightly funky grain and solid fruit with more than a little coriander and mixed spices - pretty decent. Taste follows - more spice, less grain, a bit more alcohol character. Chewy, good body, slightly dry post-spice finish. As almost always, a well-crafted offering from DS.

As an American who regularly visits the UK, it was nice coming across a wheat beer which reminds me of the wheat beers I have back in PA. It does seem a bit too carbonated but it has nice sweet flavor too it. It is a very tasty sweet beer but nothing spectacular. It would do well in the US if it wasn’t so fizzy.

[Keg at The Evening Star, Brighton] A yellow beer with a small white head. The aroma is slightly wheaty. The flavor is sweet spicy with notes of citrus, hints of wheat, and loads of hops in the end, which is dry.

Carbonated keg. Evening Star, Brighton - with joet. Big carbonation. Too big - an invasive and nasty bubble rush. Tonic water bitterness at the back. Honey sweetness on the lips. Vomit aroma. Yeast infection colour. A bad experience which I wouldn’t want to repeat - and my first poor Dark Star beer.

Tap@The Evening Star, Brighton. Pretty bland for a witbier, only a slight suggestion of coriander and a slight lemon tang, reminded me of a few of the blander microbrewed wits/wheats i had in the states, this was pretty boring.

Keg, at the Evening Star, Brighton. Pale golden, larger looking really. Has a persistent fizz that annoys really, given the selection of other beers. Not cloudy, no bubble gum. Nothing, fizzy, bright larger. [After the annual cricket match, Wenlock Arms v Evening Star]

A Mes rate: Keg at The Evening Star. Pale blonde with a thin white rim. Malt & cereal but held together reasonably well with some decent hops and a dry finish. Better than plenty of other lagers but far from special.

On tap at Evening Star, Brighton. Gold colour with thin white head. Not a huge aroma. Quite good aromatic creamy hop on what is basically a thin watery lager. Served too cold. Some pukiness toward the end of the palate. Quite drying, not great.
Keg Handpump at the Head Of Steam, London 18/06/2003 Clear golden coloured crisp and smooth on the palate. Lasting hop finish.
[Draft at Evening Star, Brighton] A yellow beer with a small lasting white head. The aroma is sour wheaty, while the flavor is plain wheaty.
Keg. Evening Star, Brighton - with joet. Tastes cheap and nasty with butterscotch lingering unpleasantly, going into rancid fat. Rotten fruit aroma. Some tin and cabbage. Foul!
Tap@The Evening Star, Brighton. This was just a pretty bland pale lager, very clean and crisp, and very boring, hard to pick out too many flavours, pretty bland, and not very interesting.

Keg, at the Evening Star, Brighton. Golden bright larger. Slightly sweet and definitely a lady pleaser. Not bad larger for a brewery that specialises in ales. [After the annual cricket match, Wenlock Arms versus the Evening Star]
Lekka wędzonka, słodowość. Lekkie, nieco słodkawe. Wysokie wysycenie, średnia goryczka.

500ml bottle from BEER:Shop in St. Albans. Pours clear dark gold with a small white head. Aroma is smokey and bready. Taste is medium sweet, subtle smokiness, malt and spicy hops. Modedrate bitter finish. Excellent.

(Fasche) Es hat eine goldgelbe Farbe, ist klar filtriert mit einer weißen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist schlank, leicht rauchig, leicht getreidig und ein klein bisschen nach Lösungsmitteln im Kopf. Der Geschmack ist schlank, leicht rauchig und auch wieder der leichte Geschmack von Lösungsmitteln.

Color amarillo claro, sin turbiedad, transparente. Espuma blanca, ligeramente jabonosa, de más de dos dedos de espesor y buena retención aunque desaparece de forma un tanto irregular. Aroma escaso a cereal y notas de heno. Sabor igual, algo más intenso y con un final maltoso, levemente dulce y seco, notas ahumadas en posgusto, alcohol imperceptible. Textura acuosa. Carbonatación media.
Bardzo lekkie, orzeźwiające i wędzone piwo ciekawostka! Zadziwiające jak aromaty dymne, którymi przesiakniete jest wszystko w Browarze, subtelnie przeszły do piwa bez dodatków slodów wędzonych!
Pint can. Aromas of light smoke, grain, grass, herbs. Clear gold with a somewhat lasting white head. Dry, smoky, grainy, grassy. Light-medium bodied.

500ml bottle. Clear bright gold with thick frothy white head. Flavors are bready cereals, crackers, caramel and charred wood with herbal, mineral and fruity notes. Medium body, good carbonation, smooth texture.

Bottle. Clear golden color, lasting fine white head. Cereal and smokey ham aroma. Medium sweet taste, moderate bitterness. Aftertaste has also decent smokey ham and light cereal malt aromas. Medium to low carbonation, full body.
Pale gold color, medium white head. Aroma malt and light smoky. Taste malt, grain, smoke, light bitter finish.

On tap at GBBF 2019. Clear bright golden, medium white foam head. Nose is light smokey, clean, crisp, golden grains, cereal, minerals, light wood smoke. Taste is crisp, clean, toasted golden grains, cereal grains, light bacon smoke, light wood smoke.

A deep dark brown pour with a small loose beige head. A soft chocolatey aroma, some coffee and malt notes. A sweetish chocolate and raspberry flavour with a little smoke and a drying bitter finish. Very good mild.
cask scura leggeranota di cioccolato fondente corpo leggero un finale leggermente terroso amaro contenuto un filo fruttato nota quasi affumicata

07Aug2019 Dark chocolate, cacao, toasted bread, sweet coffee. Clear, very dark brown, small, frothy, off-white head. Light bitter. More dark chocolate, cacao, burnt toast, earthy notes, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Nice aroma. Cask at GBBF19.

Cask at GBBF 2019, Olympia, London, Aug 2019 - Dark brown with light tan head. Roasty malts, bready, chocolate. Dark fruit notes. Moderate hop bitterness. Bit dry. Moderately bitter roast chocolate malty throughout. (2019-08)
Cask @ Fox & Goose, Hebden Bridge. Dark red with a creamy-frothy head. Has steady light tasting floral roasted malts in both aroma and taste.

[Cask at the Bell, Waltham St Lawrence.] An opaque tawny brown pour with a thin yellowish cream head; light malty aroma;a thin malty taste with a touch of fruity bitterness; and a dry biscuity finish. A pleasant mild.
Hand-pulled cask @ The Church End Brewery taproom. Rich on the nose, roasted coffee in the mouth and hints of liquorice in the finish. Church End's best, undoubtedly.

Cask at PoW, Farnborough, 16/08/17. Vague sweet malty aroma. Cola brown. Frothy beige head. Light sweet. Malty base. Medium bodied. Creamy. Flat carbonation. Low key finish. Nice. Slips down. If unmemorable.

Cask at GBBF 2016. Day 1. Pours clear brown with reddish highlights and a foamy topping. Pretty good stuff, with notes of brown bread, faint smoke, a bit of cocoa. Light bodied with fine carbonation; good condition. Finishes with soft roast, more chocolatey malts. Nice mild.

Cask at the Great British Beer Festival 2016. Poured dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee and nut. Medium body, soft carbonation. Finish is semi-sweet and somewhat dry. Easy drinker.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Sampled this bitter in the Three Judges, Glasgow in February 2004. CXask, handpump dispense. Clear pale copper red in colour with a thin loose white head. Slight malt in the aroma with a juicy mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malt complexes giving a digestive malt flavour along with a note of redcurrant fruit. Dry hop in the aftertaste giving a faint metallic tang. Finish is malty with dry vinous notes in the mouth. A good session ale.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: golden amber ... Thin white head ... Light lemon nose ... Zezty lemon fruits ... Juicy and soft ... Clean and eaasy ... Refreshing... quite nice

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Cask, South Causey Inn, Stanley, Co Durham. Golden colour with a minimal head. Fragrant, slightly fruity aroma. Flavour malty and slightly sweet, with vague bitterness in the finish. Hugely average and dull like the loud conversation being played out at the bar while I was supping this.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Cask conditioned at Harbury Beer Fest ’07. Orange gold with white head, hazed. Beer with a big dose of caramel in the flavour and a sweetish toffee note with a chalky powdery feeling. Some malty graininess and a little late bitterness, but certainly not a session bitter of class.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Squashtness is at a minimal here, but he must have been on glue here anyway as its one of the palest beers iv ever had. Excellent condition crystal clear. No aroma at all. Taste is honey with pale malts, lightly bittering pale malts. Easily drinkable but somewhat nothing as a beer.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: [Cask at The Three Judges] Clear and golden with a minimal head. Aroma of dried apricot, slightly floral. Body is on the thin side, lightly sweet with a dry finish. I agree with Nekronos here, this one is not squashy at all.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Cask conditioned@ Guide Dog, Soton. Light copper. Some spicy hop and fruit aromas. Lightly sweet with a fruity vinous acidity which although pleasant in darker beers seems slightly misplaced here.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Cask Handpump at the Star Inn, Huddersfield 11/03/2006 Golden coloured with some fruit and wheat flavours. Dry on the palate in the finish.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Very interesting, sweet in some way and not squashy at all. The colour is a little dark. But it is still a bitter.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Although the brewery describes this as a session bitter, the colour is pale yellow and the aroma betrays a very obvious Cascade hop presence, so it is really more like a golden summer ale. Slightly cloudy. Lemon & citrus notes in the aroma as well as aromatic floral elements. However, the palate was very grainy and dull, with murky flavours and just the merest hint of peach in the background. Dull finish. No zing at all. Not in peak condition. Cask (gravity), Cambridge Beer Festival.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Bottle. Traditional stuff. Pours foamy headed amber from the bottle. Soft malty aroma. A bit overcarbonated for me, but it's refreshing, bitter and drinkable. Nutty sweet follow through. Went well with food.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: 50cl bottle from a friend. Clear golden pour. Medium off white head. Subtle bitterness. A little nutty in the aftertaste. Decent

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Bottle. Amber in colour. Malty (biscuity malts, caramel, toffee). Fruity (citrus-orange). Hoppy (floral hops). Full flavoured. Nice malt/fruit/hop balance. Tasty. Very drinkable. (2008)

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: 500ml fles, schenkt helder koperkleurig mengsel met slordige kraag. Smaak is verrassend pittig van de hop, fruit tonen als mandarijn en mineola, met bitters die links en rechts prikken. Ook lange afdronk. Aroma is als premium pils met toffee, steeds binnen het groene bereik en niet vies. Dat voor 5%!

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Bottle, gift from Jim- cheers. Amber with a small white head. Malty malty malty with some blackcurrant. A little dirty hop note in the finish but not enough to spoil a good malty English bitter.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Cask-conditioned at the Three Tuns, Bristol March 2015. Amber in colour, with an off-white head. Sweetish, cereal malts, a touch of hedgerow fruit, honey, and moderately bitter finish. Good.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Cask at the hanging bat. Pours clear golden, nose is toffee, floral, taste is wishy washy, toffee, floral.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: 500ml bottle: drank at home on 14th Mar 2015. Poured into an Abbot Ale badged glass tankard and shared with no one. Lively bit of kit, a huge off-white billowing foam head only allowed me to fill half the glass with beer, copper hue to the clear amber body. Nice blend of flavours and well balanced with neither the hops or malts ruling the brew. Woody, nutty and tasty. Semi-sweet malty molasses vie with the mildly bittering hops for your attention and dance around the mouth in perfect harmony: a great start to my evenings mini rating session.

column2: Newcastle upon Tyne, Tyne & Wear, England
column5: Bottle from Darlington railway station. Appearance -dirty honey colour and decent head. Nose - honey, toffee and hazelnuts. Taste - yep praline again, light biscuit bitterness. Palate - light to medium bodied with a creamy yet tangy texture and a tangy and fairly dry finish. Overall - quite complex but slightly sweeter than I’d have made it.

column1: Sarahs Hop House Hop to It
column5: Cask Handpump at the Railway Hotel, Golborne 13/06/2001 Hoppy with some alcohol present. Hint of lemon flavour in the finish.

column1: Sarahs Hop House Hop to It
column5: Dark amber; caramel nose; dry, toasty, flavourful body. Most of my favourite bitters from England were juicily hoppy, but this is balanced and stylish.

On tap (cask) at Twice Brewed Inn, Northumberland on 28-May-2017. ABV 3.8%. Listed as Twice Brewed Bitter (brewed by Theakston’s)). Golden colour with a thick white head. Aroma of caramel malt and soft fruit. Medium body and soft carbonation. Taste of malt, burnt toffee, fruit and vanilla. Smooth and refreshing.
Cask as Twice Brewed Bitter. Clear golden yellow color. Aroma of light pepper. Taste is lightly toasted caramel.
Cask at the Guildford arms. Pours clear golden, nose is cereal, sweet toffee, floral, taste is similar, far too sweet.
Cask at the Kings Head, Carlisle. Pours clear pale gold with a thin white head. Aromas of light caramel, light lemon. Taste is light sweet. Clean finish, if a bit thin.
on tap dorata lieve citrico discreta secchezza amaro medio un finale discreto luppolato filo terroso media intensita
On tap at Twice Brewed Inn. Pours golden with white head. Malty, caramel, bit fruity and watery.
Cask in the King’s Head, Carlisle. Golden with a white head. Citrus with a little grapefruit. Bitter finish. Pretty watery, but not bad for what it is.
Golden colour white head ,aroma is grainy with little malt,taste is bitter fruity dry bitter finish
Cask Bon Glasgow. Brewers notes very misleading . No discerning hop aroma,palate or taste. Bog standard English bitter bettered by so many new micros. John Smiths in all but name.
Golden ale with a true bitterness, fine tasting with an excellent body to it.

The last beer of my first day at the GBBF. I had to take a class in ancient Sogdian to read my notes, but I figured out that this beer had dark fruit flavours and a creamy body. Anyway, even if I don't know quite what it tasted like, I do know that I liked it.
Cloudy amber-orange ale. Malty flavour with a touch of citrus, no bitterness. Not actually bad just a bit wierd.

for those who wodered what happened to tomahawk brewing. has a nice label with a story about convicts which should challenge foreign notions about australianness. quite thick and with a whiskey maltiness but nothing to back it up
Bière style scotch ale assez sucrée au gouts de cassonade, caramel et levures. Je trouve le gouts des levures choisis pas super pour le style, un peu aqueu et fade. Pour le prix c’est ok.
Couple of bottles from a tasting box. Pours dark brown with white lacing. Roasted and caramel malt, and some woodish aromas. Lots of sweetness. Kind of messy. Not my thing.

Bouteille de 341 ml. Couleur brune avec un joli col beige. Arôme de malte caramélisé et de sucre. Goût de caramel, de cassonade et de céréales grillées. Aucune amertume perceptible. Bonne bière très facile à boire

Nous manquons de BRUNES au Québec alors je ne retiens pas mon (petit) enthousiasme pour celle-ci! Bel exemple de brune caramélisé, avec pointe de sucré et amertume bien dosé, couleur ambrée alléchante, assez d'épices pour intrigué. Bel asssemblage des sucres du caramel, fruit confis, malt, pain d'épice et soupcon d'houblon, facile a boire car le sucre arrondit le tout avec sagesse. Bière sans prétention et pas chérante offrant un rapport qualité prix surprenant comme la plupart des bières offerte par Alchimiste.

Bouteille. Léger gushing. Robe ambrée foncée et claire avec un mince voile de mousse. Arômes de noisettes, caramel grillé, léger sucre d’orge, anis et mélasse. En bouche, caramel fade, sucre d’orge, noisettes âcres, vieux houblons herbacés, fruits séchés, raisins rouges. Texture un peu aqueuse et corps mince à moyen. Bonne brune grand public.

Bière brune foncée aux reflets rubis, plutôt limpide, effervescence moyenne, et surmontée d’un col brunâtre étroit, mais tout de même assez dense et persistant. Arômes bien maltée, principalement sucrée, beaucoup de caramel, cassonade, nuances de sirop d’érable, raisin foncé bien mûr voire confit (raisin sec), compote de prune, pruneau… Effluves également un peu rôti, pain grillé et grain rôti, avec notes fumées, tendance tourbe, terre… Nez agréable, intéressant et appétissant, intensité élevée mais complexité plutôt moyenne. En bouche, pétillement plutôt faible sur la langue, onctuosité moyenne au palais. Au goût, pain grillé, grain rôti, caramel, cassonade et fruits foncés (raisin, mais surtout prune/pruneau). Saveur également un peu terreuse, marron, tourbe… Finale de houblon herbacé et feuillu, menant à une amertume bien légère. Bière significativement moins sucrée que ce que le nez laissait croire, et surtout bien moins riche et intense qu’anticiper, impression aqueuse en bouche, c’est décevant considérant le nez qui était si prometteur. Goût correct, complexité et intensité en bouche plutôt faibles… Bière correcte, sans plus…

341ml bottle. Clear dark amber body, small beige head with average retention, almost no lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, black currant jam, herb liquor, a touch of leather and some metallic tones. Light tone with a strong mineral note: caramel, dried dark berries, toasted malt. Not the best interpretation of the style.
Très bof, peu de corps, très aqueuse. Un arome caramel fumé assez perceptible mais sans longueur ou surprise. Une scotch ale très bas de gamme.

Brune aux reflets rouges, nez malts torrefiés, notes légères café et caramel, manque un peu de consistance sur la longueur, même si petite accroche sèche en finale, sympa. Bouteille 341ml achetée sur un stand québécois au marché de Saint-Gilles-Croix-de-Vie (étrange), France, bue le 03/10/2015.
Pours a dark brown color with a small white head. Nose of caramel, toffee, coffee, dark chocolate. Light to medium body. Medium sweetness, medium roastiness finish. Not too bad.
Pretty standard but with a point of interest towards the end, like a Volvo with a bumper sticker
Couple of bottle from Alchimiste tasting box. Pours dark golden with small white head. Bready and grainy with grassy hops. Nice bitterness. Light sweetness. Pretty good.
Couleur et clareté identique à du jus de pomme. En bouche, caramel, bonne carbonation, un peu sec. Pas très distinctif.
Lager forte, la Bock de Joliette est une bière ambrée au goût chaleureux de pain d'épice, de malt grillé et de fruits rouges.

Bouteille. Robe orangée-ambrée claire et avec un mince cerne de mousse. Arômes de sucre liquide, malt caramélisé, pamplemousse rose, citron confit, Splenda©, gazon humide. En bouche, malt caramélisé, sucre d’orge industriel, confit d’agrumes, houblons nobles, mousse au citron, un peu de saveurs grillées. Fibale plutôt fade. Texture huileuse et corps mince. Une bock très d’entrée de gamme.

Sucre d’orge, caramel, peu de fruits, plutôt mince et surtout, courte en bouche. Une bière qui n’est pas mauvaise, mais qui ne peut remplir les attentes portées par le style et les caractéristiques annoncées. Le corps est trop mince pour le degré d’alcool à mon goût, la finale (inexistante pratiquement) est incapable de balancer un liquide trop sucrée pour ce que le corps est en mesure de soutenir. Du fruit, du houblon, des notes plus grillées; tous des éléments qui auraient pu contribuer à créer un meilleur équilibre.

Bouteille de 341 ml. Couleur cuivré avec un joli col. Arôme de malt, de pain et de caramel brûlé. Le goût est celui des épices, des céréales et du sucre d’orge. Bonne bière mais je suis pas tombé en bas de ma chaise.

Bière orangée un peu brunâtre, moyennement voilée avec quelques particules visibles, effervescence moyenne-bonne, et surmontée d’à peine quelques remous beige en guise de col. Arômes de pain grillé, pâtisserie et sucres mi-foncés (réglisse rouge, sucre d’orge, cassonade, caramel…), avec quelques notes d’érable. Effluves également assez fruité, baies, bleuet, fraise, raisin rouge, prune… mais ça reste «pâteux» comme nez, pâte à fruits… tendance cartonnée même par moment (oxydation?). Enfin, odeurs aussi subtilement herbacé par moment, et même salé… herbes salées… caramel salé… Nez intéressant et agréable, complexité correcte,, intensité plutôt moyenne. En bouche, pétillement assez élevé sur la langue, mais breuvage plutôt mince au palais. Au goût, entrée maltée de pain grillé, pâtisserie st sucres (surtout cassonade), suivi des saveurs fruitées précédemment humées. Même si l’impression pâteuse et cartonnée est moins présente qu’au nez, les saveurs fruitées font tout de même pas mal «pâte à fruits» et «réglisse rouge». Finale plus herbacée, et même feuillue (feuille verte et feuille morte), avec subtil citron, légère acidité, légère amertume… Même si les flaveurs de la bière s’orientent principalement vers le malt et les sucres, le breuvage reste relativement peu sucré et montre un équilibre impressionnant. Complexité correcte, mais, comme au nez, l’intensité en bouche est plutôt moyenne. Bonne bière!
Bière très maltée. De la noix assez présente. Manque de longueur et d’équilibre. Pas 100% convaincu par cette bière.

Merci à Dominique. Un look doré et sucré. Le liquide est clair et paraît rond dans mon verre à vin. Un nez qui malheureusement me rappelle le beurre et le diacétyle. Très orienté sur le malt - un malt gras et peu soigné, le liquide aurait présenté un quelconque houblonnage que ça ne lui aurait pas fait de mal. Enfin. Ça sent la fermentation et le beurre. Un instant. En y laissant traîner mon nez qui qui ne se lasse de chercher, je décèle un légume vert qui me rappelle le poivron. Est-ce une illusion? Non je ne rêve pas. Il y a bien un poivron vert et/ou du concombre. Ça fait du bien! En bouche le corps est moyen. Les saveurs tournent encore une fois autour du malt et d’un miel surgissant! Peu complexe, cette bière pourrait être bien meilleure si un sérieux houblonnage venait équilibrer le tout.
Aroma was a bit skunky. Nice looking white head, bread crust like color. Taste unusual also of rye bread crust, hmmm ... Some bitterness.
Malty aroma, deep golden amber, medium sized vanilla head.Mild maltiness, good bitterness, with a fine malt aftertaste. Well balanced, fair carbonation. A very good lager.
Tan. Nice creamy head. No discernable aroma, maybe a little malt. Very slight roast flavor. Funky graininess. Thin. Bland.

a gruitbeer using larch instead of hops to simulate a celtic beer - blond-orange colour, few head, honey, licorice and larch aroma, the sweetness is well balanced by a medium alcohol presence, dry floral finish - original and very good
Poured a thin red with a white head. Nose was much bigger than the taste. It was of tart berries and spices. Taste was a bit watered down. Not something I would order a second glass of.

(TX) Im surprised no one has made the simpsons reference to this style of beer until now. Smelled promising, very fruity with hints of alcohol and yeast. The taste was disappointing, eerily similar to a redhook ESB....except the annoying aftertaste was spicier and longer.

Tasted as Postel Christmas. Abbey beer with warm bronze colour, creamy head and caramelly and spicy character, with impressions of banana, pear, butterscotch, liquorice, cloves, chocolate, white pepper; malty sweet taste, soft, smooth with mild hop bitterishness and warming alcohol in the finish. Like the other Postel beers, this is actually not bad and well balanced, though very mainstream and stereotypical for its style.
Bona cervesa, és bastant equilibrada i gustosa. Buena cerveza, es bastante equilibrada y sabrosa.
Brune rougeâtre opaque, effervescence moyenne, quasi pas de col. Caramel légèrement rôti, réglisse, fruits foncés, fruits secs (noix), ABV bien présent.

(bottled)From old notes from an October trip to Brussels . Probably the best Christmas beer ive had at 5 am in the morning while intoxicated of my ass !!! My notes say in reflection...Rich of course ...a rather creamy unity of caramel and spicy boozy relentlessness in liquid brown format ...A wave of dry texture slowly breezes in to refresh my palate ... Exactly what I would expect from a Belgian Christmas ale ...

33cl bottle. Deep brown colour, beige head adhesive. Aromas of sweet malts, caramel and brown sugar. Taste is sweet in the beginnig. Some herbs, perhaps some cinnamon. Finish is more bitter with definitely some liquorice. Hevay body. Ok christmas beer, but not a top one in his category

Clear brown amber colour, beige head. Aroma of sweet malts, caramel, red fruits, canned peach, spice and candy sugar. Sweet malty flavour, caramel and candy sugar. Light bitter hops. Light bitter finish, hops and roasted malts, light lingering spices. The one I like most of the Postel beers I’ve tasted to date. Certainly nice with a little age on it. (From 33cL bottle @ Het Brouwershuis, Baarle-Hertog

23/12/2011 33cl bottle from Colruyt @ home - BB: 6/9/13 (2011-725) Clear dark amber to reddish brown beer, creamy, off-white to beige head, pretty stable, adhesive. Aroma: sweet malts, caramel, very fruity, sweet peaches, some strawberries, hops, bit spicy. MF: good carbon, medium body. Taste: sweet start, caramel, malts, bitter hops, some spices, fruity, strawberries, cherries. Aftertaste: bitter hops, some spices (liquorice). Very decent for a Postel beer.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Hazy brown coloured brew with an nice sweet spicy taste and some fine hints of caramel. Nice beer for the Christmas time, easy and good.
slight hints of caramel, nuts, resin, a ’cosy’ beer . brown, light sparkling, small white head. medium sweetness.

Bottled (as Postel Christmas, 9.0%) at Pressklubben, Stockholm. Cloudy mahogany colour, rocky head. Toasty vinous nose with figs and dark bread. Sweet and near full bodied with well rounded mouthfeel. Brown sugar on dried figs with some grassy hops atop. Light spicy bitterness with a bit of warming alcohol. A likeble, rather complex and warming beer, where my sampel alrady had matured a little.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Pours a fairly faint yellow with a thin head and leaves some lacing. Not a lot going on in terms of taste. I was expecting some sort of hop expression but all i got was this astringent thing. Very disapointing!

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Location: Draft at the Brewpub, 10/2/10 Aroma: The nose has caramel/toffee malts along with a bit of hops, a fairly light nose Appearance: This one is a clear orange color-red beer with a head that leaves light lace on the glass Flavor: The taste is fairly balanced, subtle, with a light malty sweetness and some hops as well Palate: The body is light to medium, it has an alright mouthfeel, but it thins out a bit as it goes Overall Impression: Overall this reminded me of a something between a simple, standard ESB and a low hop English style IPA. I didn’t love it, but I found it to be sessionable enough to enjoy with my meal.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Tap. Bitter, but very one dimensional. Aroma was weak and focused only on grassy hoppy. Not complex in flavor, just bitter and bland. Not spicy as some bitters.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: on tap–pours an off white head and amber color. Aroma is sweet light/medium malt, biscuity, some tea/herbal. Taste is sweet light/medium malt, biscuity, tea/herbal hops.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Had this on tap at the Hyde Park Brewing Company. Somewhat bitter with a malt character. Nice aroma with a hops smell to it.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Rerating this one after about a year and a half, as this was one of the reasons I haven’t been to this place in over a year. Pours a clear caramel brown. Nose is all caramel and toffee, no hops. Sweet caramel and bitterness. Still unexciting. Still not fully attenuated and heavy. Cleaned up a little since the last time, but not great. Original rating: 5/3/4/2/9 On tap. Pours a copper to dark brown color without much head. Smells of burnt malt and little else. Smooth in the mouth, but rather flat, leading into a disappointing finish which elicits the first appearance of anything hoppy or bitter, and not much of it at that. I haven’t had this beer in a while, but I recall years ago it being a much more solid choice. Heck, if it didn’t come out of the tap flat and they just hopped it a bit more it would have picked up an extra half a point.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: The beer pours a clear light copper color. Aroma is bark, some sweet apple/rotten fruits, with some hops trying to break through. Taste is mineral and vegetal with a light body.Brewpub sampler.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Umm not the best bitter I have tasted, not very bitter or hoppy, but, nice and smooth with soft carbonation. Not bad

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: I wasn’t going to rate this beer because I believed what I received was not representative of what the brewmaster intended. However, after sending it back as undrinkable I was told by the waitress that 4 other people has tasted it and that 3 of those people made a face while the front end manager said the beer was supposed to taste the way it did. It tasted like it was brewed in a dirty diaper pail. There was a bit of a sour flavor up front and a diaper pail aftertaste. The beer looked nice and there was some lacing from the few sips I had. I feel that there was a problem with the yeast. Beyond that the beer was bitter, but had no flavor from the middle addition of hops nor any hop aroma. A very poor effort that should be poured down the sewer.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Very low, sweet, soapy, floral, lavender aroma. Clear copper coloured body is topped by a fine bubbled white head. Mildly bitter floral, soapy hops with stale notes of cardboard. Medium light body with soft carbonation. Sampled on tap at the brewpub with Olivier_MTL and Rastacouere.
03.01.2004. 0,5l Can. Pale yellow colour. Aroma is sour with thin body. I think Aass, in this case, only focus on the nice designer can and not on the beer.
500 ml can. Golden body with diminishing white head. Weak malt aroma. Flavor is weak malty with fruit and low bitterness. Like a watery pilsner with aggressive carbonation.
Can. Plain golden color with a big head quikcky disappearing. Light malt aroma. Taste is clean and a bit dry with mild flavors of malt. Thin body, short finish and very ordinary.
Can. Weak malty aroma and a sweet malty taste. Light body with a light dry finish. Boring.

(Can 50 cl) Clear, orangey golden with a small, white head. Aroma of malt. Slightly thin body with soft and sweet malty accents. A wee edge of caramel. Discreet fruitiness. Not your typical Pale Lager - refreshing, but thin. 150906
Can. Clear yellow coloured with a white head. Aroma of malts and metal with spicy notes. Flavour of malts and fruits.

Biggish offwhite creamy head with come coarser lace. Clear deep yellow body. Sweetish malty aroma with grassy hop notes and a touch of chalk. Taste is grassy chalky malt sweetness with hoppy aftertaste. Chalky pea taste lingers. Decent, a bit different, nothing too exciting. (0.5l can.)
Canned. Golden colour with a white head. Neutral almost nothing aroma.A little hint of hoppy fruit flavour.

Can. Pale golden with an ok white head. Neutral, next-to-nothing aroma, but not offensive. Flavor is quite thin too, with a hint of hoppy friutiness. Thin, quaffable beer. Quite boring, but not bad-tasting. (060225)
A nice, round pilsner. It will not offend anyone, but it does not reach a high level, either! Nice can!

22.12.12 Uts: mørk rød, litt uklar, tett rosa skum. Duft: solbær, brett og enorm syrlighet. Smak: først tydelig lambic, deretter sødme og intenst solbær, middels fyldig, forfriskende og kort ettersmak preget av syrlighet. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a purple black colour with a very bubbly short lasting puple-reddish head. Aroma of cassis indeed with a good sweetness and sourness. the flavour has planety of cassis, sweetness, nice sourness. Sweet and sour fruity dry finish. Very fruity beer indeed!

Beer #3 at Croydon Draught Belgian Beer Festival. One of the murkiest, muddiest looking beers I’ve ever had on draught. And pink mud is a very odd appearance indeed. The cassis is very pronounced, with cough sweets and pear drops. Maybe something a little clammy in the aroma. Juicy and fruity, but a bit sweet and simple. Like other Liefmans fruit beers, there seems something a little synthetic about the fruit to me. There’s a touch of late sharpness, but not really enough to temper the sweetness. Despite misgivings, I still found myself enjoying this.

Draught@The Belgian Draught Beer Festival, Croydon, London. Sweet cough lolly like sweetness. Obvious cassis characters. Some tart sourness makes this at least bearable to drink. Otherwise this was a little too sweet.

Draught: Cloudy mud brown, with a tan head. Strepsil? Cough lolly aroma. Sweet blackcurrant all the way through. A little dry and slightly tart in the finish. Medium bodied, perfectly drinkable though a bit unbalanced.

500 ml bottle, imported and doubtless left on the shelf awaiting me for a good long while. Nose is like a batch of blackberry's that have set in the cellar too long--a bit musty with an acidic wang on the backend. Nice effervesence and a nice, light purple/pink head of fine bubbles. The first taste is tame for a lambic--the sour pucker is not quite equalled by the fruity berry flavor of the currants. The palate of this lambic isn't fresh and crisp as it should be--perhaps due to too long on the shelf, or perhaps not. In any case, this is a nce sparkling fruit beer that makes for a nice apertif. I prefer Kriek and Framboise at this point.
[Draught at The White Horse, Parson's Green, London] This really gives you suberb refreshment. Very natural and flavourful with a great balance between the sweetness and the acidic notes. I love it.
also at the white horse. sweet fruity and tart all at once. think of ribena & goudenband blend.

the white hoss seems to be the only place you can get this stuff. basically liefmans kriek - cherries +ribena = cassis. the blackcurrant stuff is tasty enough, but the brown ale base is what i really like - beautiful, subtle blend of sourness, wood and malt. good stuff.

Sampled on tap at the White Horse, Parson's Green, London...and I can't believe you missed this Per. Muddy brown with purple highlights; rich currant aroma and flavour, sweet malts and an acidic finish - bursts with flavour. Complex, refreshing, probably my favourite of the Liefmans beers now that the Goudenband is half of what it used to be.

0,5 l bottle. Pours clear amber with white quickly dissipating head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Aroma is stale in general. Body is medium and slick with average carbonation. Taste is sweet and medium bitter. Finish is short, caramel and light bitterness.

Can, 0.5l. Clear amber pour, one finger soapy off-white head. Medium retention, solid lacing on the glass. Malty and grainy nose, a bit roasted, pronounced grassy notes. Thin body, medium carbonation. Light mouthfeel, watery texture. Fizzy. Bittersweet taste, stronger bitterness towards the finish. Aroma of lager malt, caramel, herbs, grains and grass. Mild metal, some peppery notes. Bready. Short to medium finish, herbal, lingering bitterness. Not bad for the price.
A sweet amber beer, surprisingly sweet coming from staropramen. But clean and quite nice. Tir a nog dresden
Amber color , aroma of malt and hops , sweet taste , caramel flavor. Pretty good.

No może i ma barwę soku z granatów. Piana leciutko żółta. Spora i zanikająca. Szamponowa. Aromat słodowo owocowy. W smaku wodniste. Ma cechy piwa ciemnego, ale bardzo stonowane. Jest delikatna goryczka. Nic specjalnego.
Amber color with lacing large off-white head. Aroma has caramel, malt and hay. Taste is malty sweet with long somewhat bitter aftertaste. Flavors of caramel, malt, grass.
Czeski lagerek z karmelowym słodem. Lekki, łatwy, przyjemny, nudny. No, ale jest solidny i pijalny. Może być.

Wygląd: Ciemno miedziany, rdzawy kolor. Przejrzyste. Piana bardzo biedna. Prawie jej nie ma. Aromat: Słodki, karmelowy i lekko cukierkowy. Z tyłu lekkie żelazo, pieniądze. Smak: Tu też słodkie, karmelowe, lekko podpalane słodowe. Niestety wyczuwalne żelazo przeszkadza choć na skórze nie wychodzi. Wysycenie niskie. Ogólnie: Piwo fajne tylko z koloru. W smaku i zapachu karmelowe. Dziwne żelazo przeszkadza.

Bottle. Pours clear amber, quite rich yet rapdily-dissipating head. Aroma of toast, bread, caramel, malt. Taste is semi-sweet, low bitterness. Flavors of toast, malt, caramel, bread. Medium body, crisp texture, average carbonation.
Vahva amber väri. Tuoksu paahteinen. Vaahto katoaa nopeasti. Maussa karvasmanteliöljyä.

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: The head is quickly disappearing. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of fruit, and I sense a light bitterness on the middle of the tongue, that last throughout the finish. OK, but definitely not a beer that will be remembered....

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: Not a bad beer by any means, but not particularly interesting. Poured crystal clear orange-brown with a decent sized head. Initial salty vegemite aroma that, once settled, transformed to a weak caramel and even weaker roasted malt. Fairly bland flavour, with not much bitterness to speak of - that was surprising - just some sugary sweetness. Thin bodied with a good carbonation level, the palate was in thread with the rest of the beer’s characteristics.

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: Attractive gingery colour. Otherwise, its a fairly nondescript beer with gentle, yet insistent bitterness, soft malt and a touch of toffee (once it warmed to room temp). Not much aroma. Worthy, but a bit dull. 500ml bottle from Safeway.

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: Jan 2005 - Some earthy aroma notes with sweet malt and hops. Clear red-brown colour and reasonable head. Easy drinking malt flavour but a bit too simplistic. Tangy bitterness and a bit of a light finish.

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: 50 cl bottle. Dark copper with white head with not too impressive durability. Aroma has caramel and is a bit metallic. Smooth flavor without bitterness, making it a bit boring. The flavor is dominated by caramel with some slight roast. Pleasant carbonation, but watery mouth feel.

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: Tasted a little after it’s use-by date, but it didn’t seem to matter as it turned out to be a very disappointing and undemanding little bitter, that fell into the take-over/profit revolution, sadly seen in a lot of the U.K.’s ’once proud’ breweries. Pours a clear deep amber with a short dense off-white head, that gave reasonable length and lace. Musty, dry and a little earthy in the aroma, faintly hinting at stale hops. Quite dry, also, in the mouth with a light roasted grain and burnt sugar palate and a little caramel sweetness upfront as it warmed. Medium carbonation and medium-light in mouth feel, it started off alright, but became quite boring and one dimensional by the end. Without quoting ’Highlandlad’ too much, it was just another forgettable U.K. Bitter with a proud heritage written on the label and not in the beer itself. Bastard pasteurisation!!!

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: Disappointing pasteurised English bitter. Poured a plummy amber colour with a 1.5cm lacing head. Aroma was initially tart and fruity (sour plums) but developed some caramel malt and nutty notes. Thin in the body, moderately carbonated, with a well balanced finish. Drab pasteurised boiled flavour smothers any subtlety this might have. Mildly fruity. Flavour is mainly caramel malt. A thoroughly forgettable brew. (500ml bottle, Camperdown Cellars)

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: (Bottle 50 cl) Coors calls this a "Premium Ale" on the label, well - it’s really notthing more than a straight bitter. Clear, beautiful, dark amber. Small head. Lightly smoked malt-aroma, high bitterness and some late sweetness. 281204

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: Bottled, Pasteurised, 500ml. Light brown amber with fizzed head. Caramel notes throughout with a fizzed tinny CO2 taste. Underflavoured watery nonsense.

column4: White Shield Brewery / Museum Brewery (Molson Coors)
column5: Very little aroma. Slight hint of spice and hop. Clear dark coca-cola colour with reasonable head. Bitter burnt malt flavour Flat palate.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: The first thing I noticed about this beer was the glass it's served in! It was like a shallow bowl with a horn-like shape coming out of it. Very unusual for a brewer in Kansas City to serve out of obscure glasses. Anyway, this beer reminded me quite a lot of a Belgian witbier. It has a light, wheat-malt aroma, with unmistakable citrus (orange) and coriander. Very nice lacing and head. Medium golden-orange in color, this beer is really quite attractive. Spicy, sweet, orangey and coriander profile, with some light spicy hop flavor. Finishes mostly sweet and malty, aftertaste is all spice and citrus. Very soft palate/body, creamy carbonation. Tasty, but rather one-dimensional.
Pours light golden with a mostly receding off-white head. Notes of lemon, tart wheat and citrus. Thin bodied with aggressive and fizzy carbonation. A bit too tart and overcarbonated for me.
on tap at mishawaka brew pub. standard wheat beer. too bad the brewpub went out of business

Bomber courtesy of stfun. Pours a hazy gold with a white head. Smells of sweet citrus, szome dry malt. Taste is overly sweet and cloying with a lot of lemon and what reminded me of candied fruit. I’ve had better.
Pours a golden color with a white head. Aroma is wheat, clove, bubble gum, and some peppery hops. Flavor is wheat, honey, clove, and a bitter citric finish.

Date: 02/23/2008 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, Cellar Party Appearance: hazy gold, wispy white head, Aroma: sweet malt aroma with a grain character, Flavor: light tart wheat flavor, bit of sweetness, touch of balancing bitterness, Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4

Appearance: Pours a bright yellow body with a small, fizzy white head. Smell: Malted wheat aroma with a small dase of spice and a garnish of lemon. Taste: Sweetish, tart spiced lemon and wheat malt. Mild bitterness. Tangy, sour lemon finish and it’s over! Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Moderate carbonation. Drinkability: It’s hard not to be bearish about this beer investment. Sell! Sell!!

Pours a transparent bright golden with a thin, wispy-lacing white head. Aroma of lightly sweet pale wheat and doughy yeast and light fruity esters. Body start lightly sweet and citric with a thin, fizzy carbonation before a drier, citric finish. An ok American wheat.

Bottle. Wheaten, lightly chalky aroma with yeast and strong lemon overtones. A touch grainy. Pretty pour, golden with a lacing, creamy, rocky white head. Lemon and lemon cleaner taste with light pretzel dough. Medium tartness. Fullish body, crisp and prickly, slightly oily mf with a slightly artificial lemon and wheat finish. No real contribution from the hops. Does not mesh.

Bottle: This looks okay, a golden yellow body with a decently sized head, but it smell like a freshly opened box of Wheaties with some lemon juice squirted in. You can taste the wheat and a little sweet malt, but the lemony flavor increases and gathers at the back of the throat. Rather uninspired rendition of a style that doesn’t thrill me too much to begin with. Pat’s Liquors, Porter, IN

This bottled brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of finely sized white colored bubbles that was long lasting and left behind a transparent softly carbonated orange brown colored body and a good lacing. The mild aroma was wheat and dough. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of tingly wheat and mild malt. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again. This one goes down easily! Very drinkble.
Almindelig pilsner, den er god ved at være knap så skarp i smagen som mange andre billige pilsnere.
2/2/2008 10:29:45 AM Can from IKEA Amsterdam. Golden colour, bigheaded. Skunky nose. Grassy taste. Eggy. Watery but a fair enough lager nonetheless with good texture and chalky finish.

Clear golden color with a fine white head. Malty and herbal aroma. Medium body. Moderate sweet and a moderate bitterness. Malty and herbal flavor. Drinkable, but not something I buy. [Can from Systembolaget in Sweden]

Can, 0.33l. Clear golden color with medium frothy white head and sparkling appearance. Aroma of grainy malt, bread, grass with mild honey note. Taste starts with moderate sweet bready malt, following is grassy with mild sweet floral note, crisp and dry mouthfeel and light bitter finish. Light body, slick texture and lively carbonation in palate. Could be much worse...
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldgelbes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht malzig, getreidig. Geschmack wässrig malzig, getreidig, minimale Bitterkeit.
Fat på Lion. Billigaste fatölen på stället och smakar därefter... Svag doft av havregryn. Smakar metall...
Bottle. Aroma grainy and metallic. Taste is about the same, crappy swedish lager.
Pale gold, white head. Nose is papery malts, some hints at sweetness, corn. Taste is pretty much the same as the nose, but with more corn. Watery body, medium carbonation, weirdly oily palate. Bad.
Tillsammans med en AW på HP. Ingen direkt "Provsmakningsöl", var både hungrig och törstig så fungerade bra till maten.

Pours clear yellow with medium white head. Aroma is typical poor lager with bread, malt and maybe a hint of hay. Taste is bland with just a hint of bitterness in the weak, abrupt finish. Light body with too much carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at the brewery. The whitest weizen i've ever seen so far, a weird very pale milky yellow, thick yeast suspension, foamy white head which collapses after a while but carbonation keeps a layer. It looks like pineapple juice with milk, huh. Taste is super citrusy, lemon everywhere with classic wheat and banana tones, in the finish an unexpected note of almond and nuts comes our. Relatively thick texture, super strong carbonation, watery texture. Taste sour. Finish is lemony, dry, with almond spirit, refreshing, nice. I like the fact weizens develop a citrusy flavour but it can't be this strong, I suspect they added some lemonade... hopefully not. Quite surprised by this, quite original.
Tap at the pub. Cloudy murky orange. Thin white head. Aroma and flavour is super yesty, banana, clove.
En tysk hvedeøl der ikke smager af banan og alle mulige andre nellikker usw. Men ellers en tydelig hvedesmag i den.
Aroma: white bread, bananas. Appearance: yellow hazy beer with stand thick head. Taste: white bread, bananas, a few yeasts. Palate: a few sour with a bit bread.
On tap at the brewpub. Fruity smell with foam banana and the typcal wheat aromas. Similar taste. Better smell then taste. High carbonation.

A cloudy orange yellow coloured beer with a thick white head. The usual wheat beer aromas, banana and tropical fruit, clove and cinnamon spice, plus a perfumed floral element towards the end. Dry mouthfeel. The taste is a fizzy, mild bitterness, tropical fruits lead, banana and passion fruit, then the spice comes through, clove and cinnamon, and finally the floral element comes through with a hint of Parma Violets lingering on into the dry finish. Drought @ Brauhaus Joh. Albrecht, Hamburg.

On tap at the brewpub. Trübes orange goldenes Bier mit einer mittelgroßen weißen schaumkrone. Geruch nach citrusfrüchten, hefig, leicht bananig. Geschmack angenehm hopfig, citrus, leicht hefig fruchtig, gut.

Draft, 0.30l at the brewpub in Hamburg. Hazy amber color with medium creamy off-white head, good lacing and average sparkling appearance. Aroma of wheat, banana and herbs. Taste starts with moderate sweet caramel, follows by wheaty and yeasty sourness without any bitterness at finish. Medium body, slick texture and average carbonation in palate. Although lacks hops, it’s well brewed and good for a dessert...

Draught @ Brauhaus Joh. Albrecht, Hamburg. Pours very cloudy dark yellow with a offwhite head, lacings. Aroma of wheat, yeast, dasty, little sweet fruit, apples. Flavor is light sweet, wheat, yeast, fruit, light soapy. Medium body, lively carbonation. 311014

31.07.2014, tap @ Brauhaus Joh. Albrecht, Hamburg: Big creamy longlasting head, very muddy color. Aroma is slightly fresh yeasty, wheat, sourdough, hay, broth, yeast, weeds, cereal, hints of citrus and banana. Taste is grainy, wheat, grain, yeast, dough, cereal, minerals, hay, hints of banana. Little bitterness, yeasty mouthfeel. Nice, but there’s "a bit" too much yeast sediments in this glass at least...

Tap at the brewpub. Dark copper color with a yellowish head. Looks like a Vienna or märzen. Light sulfur on the nose,flavor of caramel malts and herbs. Taste is grainy with a leftover of wet cereal, light rosted, a bit of citrus. Not really a dunkel, rather an original variarion. Ok

Draught at Joh. Albrecht brewpub in Hamburg. Little hazy dark amber beer with some white head. Aroma is soft mild malty and caramel. Taste is smooth dry malt, bread and little bitter finish. Medium body. Overall descent beer, a little bit raw.
Not very dark, not overly flavourful. Very little roast, quite bland. Joh albrecht hamburg
Draught at the brewpub. Pours dark amber. Aroma of hard rye bread. Drinkable malty sweet lager.

Vom Fass. Hellbraun-rötliches Bier, hellbeiger Schaum. Es riecht nach Butterkaramelbonbons. Werters Echte?? Antrunk nach Brot. Keine Süsse. Leider sehr flach, fast wässerig. Etwas Karamel und Malz. Naja.
En dunkel uden karamelsmag, men med let ristede smag fra malten. Fraværende humlesmag.
Tap at brauhaus. Pours dark amber with fading beige head. Aroma is semi-sweet and malty with biscuit and caramel. Taste is semi-sweet and malty with biscuit and caramel and light hoppy with grass.
Aroma: caramel and burnt malt. Appearance: caramel, small head with small bubbles. Taste: burnt malt, a bit empty.
On tap at the brewpub. Malty smell with caramel and bread. Similar taste. High carbonation. Spritsy. A bit rough.

A dark orange brown coloured beer with a thick off white head. A light roasted malt aroma, bready and nutty and a hint of chocolate in the background. Dry mouthfeel. The taste is a medium dry malt flavour, bready and nutty, cereal and a slightly sweet chocolatey, coffee flavour in the background. The finish is dry and malty. Draught @ Brauhaus Joh. Albrecht, Hamburg.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Light caramel sweet malt aroma, pours dark cola brown, caramel sweetness upfront, bitter malts at the end, medium to full mouth for style, tap at brewery.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Tapped at amerisports. Dark, nutty and sweet. Dont know what to compare it to. Maybe a little fruit flavor going on too

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: This beer could have had a more aggressive flavor. It tastes as if there is just enough malt to add color. Hint of sweetness. Tried at the Parkville Brewfest in 2015.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Tap @ Amerisports KC. Pours a hazy dark orangish brown appearance with a light brown head. Caramel, nutty, mild toffee aroma. Toasted malty, caramel, a bit watery, nutty flavor. Bleh.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: On tap at Amerisports Brewpub. Pours a dark brown color with white head. Roasty, coffee, chocolate flavors. The best beer that I tried at Amerisports.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Dark brown with a creamy off white head. Faint malty aroma. Creamy palate. Light chocolate bread taste with a slight burnt coffee finish.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Growler courtesy of secret santa. Pours dark brown with a lingering, tan to light brown head. Smells of chocolate, sage, earthy, spicy, some tea. Tastes of caramel, a touch of prunes, raisins, figs, some orangey hints, some chocolatey hints, peppery. Complex mouthfeel. Enjoyable and full bodied; almost doppelbock like.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Sampler at the brewpub. Dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Taste is similar. Pleasant. Thought their lighter beers better.

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: growler - thanks bvc!! cola brown with mild roast, tobacco and chocolate; thin, clean and crisp; dry finish with chocolate and mild roast; not a lot going on, but very solid and drinkable; something quite fresh and tasty about it too

column4: Amerisports Brew Pub at Ameristar Casino
column5: Growler. Thanks, Theisti and BVC! Pours mahogany to black. Dark ruby highlights and a thin grayish filmy rim. Nice big dark roasty smoky and salty nose. Creamy medium body with very pleasant medium carb. Smoky, earthy, slightly salty mid-palate. Long earthy finish. This is a very forward, aggressive dunkel, you might say Americanized, with plenty of carb, flavor, and aroma. Drinks very easily and has copious amounts of flavor for 4.5%. Kind of glad I wasn’t prejudiced by walking into a casino and trying this; it’s much better than I might have been inclined to think in such a setting.
Amberkleurig bier met witte schuimkraag. Lichte smaak vaan rood fruit en beetje caramel en zoethout smaak.

Very fruity and interesting beer for the style.. It has one very weird bittersweet taste and leave you some pleasand malty and bitter aftertaste. Also i notice some spicy and caramel notes here.. Overall one decent beer from this great brewery but i have drink better "Belgian Strong dark" beers for sure..
Amber color with lacing off-white head. Aroma has caramel, hay and sweet fruity notes . Taste is malty sweet with long quite sweet aftertaste. Flavors of caramel, strong malt, spices and fruits.
Draft @ Brouwerij het Anker, Mechelen. Clear light amber, creamy offwhite head. Caramel, herbal, bread, grainy, medium hoppy bitter: like a firm special belge. Medium body and carbonation.
Dark amber and hazy with a frothy head. Smell of peaches and yeast. Bitter hoppy taste, medium carbonation.

Bière 33 cl ramenée de chez Vanuxeem à Comines. Ambrée légèrement trouble et surmontée d’une mousse crémeuse et abondante blanc cassée. Nez peu intense sur des arômes de céréales, cerise, caramel. En bouche, malts, grenadine et caramel, petite amertume, notes acidulées. Un peu trop sucrée à mon goût. Pas mauvaise mais elle manque quand même d’un peu d'équilibre.

Doble abrada belga. Roja. espuma media que permanece. Poca carbonatación. Cuerpo medio. Gusto dulce, malta, afrutada, especies. Es parecida a la chimay roja pero algo más dulce y con un sabor más complejo y elaborado. Retrogusto dulce y suave. Buena.
Dark amber and cloudy, heavy creamy head with good retention, raisins and nuts aroma, medium body, raisins flavor
Pours a milky dark beige colour with a big tan head. Mostly sweet malt on the nose. The taste is spicy with pepper and coriander notes, although this is not a wit.
Robe ambrée, mousse abondante. Caramel, fruits, petite pointe d'amertume. Correcte.
Draft at Brewer’s Alley. Dark brownish black with light tan head. Aromas of roast, cream, chocolate. Tastes of licorice, cocoa, roast, light cola. Medium body with a dry finish.
Draft at the source. Brown color, beige head. Nice roasty aroma. Taste is coffee grounds and cocoa powder, dry finish. Tasty.

Tap. Pours deep, dark brown with average, creamy beige head; good retention and spare lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, figs, earthy hops, and light smoke. Flavor is roast malt forward with some supporting dark fruit esters and hops; creamy taste with a dry finish. Medium body, low carbonation, and low warmth.
Draft. Heavy coffee aroma, bllck, tan faomy head. Said to be nitro but seemed standard. Medium body, slight bitterness. Strong coffee stout a little heavy on the carbonation.

Off my few beers at this place, this was my favorite. Finally a bit of aroma. Roasted malt and chocolate. Pours a nice almost black with a very creamy lasting head. The flavor is similar with a nice vanilla highlight. A bit on the thin side but pretty good.
Cola and chocolate, light roast, very dry. Solid effort that worked extremely well on cask, highly drinkable. Brewer’s Alley’s beers were a pleasant surprise at the DuClaw cask fest.
Opaque dark brown pour with a thin light tan head. Roast coffe aroma. bitter roasted flavor with cream. A little watery but a decent stout.

Draft at the brewery. Opaque black-brown with a patchy white head. Smooth roasty chocolate aroma. An easy drinking stout, presumably nitro-poured. Light and watery in some respects, but mossy, smooth, and impressively flavorful. Hits the spot.

Tap (cask conditioned)@Brewer’s Alley in Frederick, MD->mini pilsner glass. Pours a lasting, creamy head that exhibits spare lacing atop a black body. Smokey malt aroma. Medium body, dry and chalky taste. I enjoyed this beer considerably.

Had on cask at the brewpub, served at about room temperature. The beer had a big spicy and roasty aroma of chocolate, coffee, and caramel malt, a bit of grainy and earthy hops too. It was a dark brown-black color with a creamy, dark tan head that had fairly good retention and size. The flavor was pretty sweet, slightly spicy and lively, and the chocolate and coffee tastes were detectable. It had a very creamy palate, and was very wet and full, with a lower amount of carbonation. It’s a good beer, I think if it was chilled a little more it would help with this beer, but it did have a lot of character.
Keg at the Mansfield arms.. Golden amber.. Small white head.. Dry toffee fruit nose.. Sweet caramel fruits.. Lught carbonation
Cask at SRAF 2011. Pours copper amber, nose is grassy toffee, taste is grassy, floral, little nutty.

Cask@GBBF 2011. Orangeish amber colour with a small white foamy head. Aroma is sweet malts, some caramel, mild grassy and floral notes along with some hay too. Flavour is bready and caramel malts along with some mild fruits, some grass, herbs and a bit hayish notes too. Mild bitterness, but at the same time quite tasty and refreshing.
At the pub. Pours amber. small diminishing head. Aroma is floral and slightly citrus. Medium body, flavour of sweet nutty dark fruit and malt. Dry, sweet average finish.

Cask by handpump at Larbert Beer Festival (31 Mar 12) - grassy / fruity aroma, clear pale copper ale, non-existent head, caramel, served at good temperature, prolonged bitter aftertaste spoiled this a bit for me
Cask @ Alloa Real Ale Festival 2011. Dark copper colour, off-white head. Nose is caramel malts, little fruityness. Flavour is light caramel malts, fruity, slight hoppyness. Most average bitter.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2011, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Clear medium to dark amber orange colour with a small, virtually none head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, fruity. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, nut peel bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20110804]
Strange way of pumping it, but the colur was very dark, bubbling head and nice kind of sweet flavor.
Orangey-amber; malty, but slight flavour; touch of caramel & copper. Too light for its own good, as it disappears across the palate.

Draft at the brewpub - MA. Pours clear gold with a creamy, white head. Simple bready pale malt nose, some cereal, ripe orange. Medium sweet flavor, a bit syrupy, with note of grainy cereal, caramel, brown sugar, minimal bitterness. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sweet, sticky finish with more bready malts, caramel, almost no hop presence. Somewhat tasty but lacks balancing bitterness.

Cask at the brewpub. Aroma hinted at isovaleric, cheesy oxidized hops, but it showed really strongly in the flavor. The body of this was clean and put together, but the doggy, old-cheese hops just overran and ruined what should have been a respectable hoppy beer.

Cloudy amber, small head with a bit of sediment floating around in the glass. Almost no lace. Mild carbonation. Taste is medium sweet, caramel, grapefruit. Light-medium body. No bitterness in the finish which is a plus for me. Pleasant and well worth a try. A good representation of this style. I wouldn’t mind drinking this again.

22 oz bottle color hazy amber with light sediment floating around. Small white ring of head. Minimal lacing and lightly carbonated. Aroma of malt and light grapefruit. Taste is the aroma. Not bitterness in the finish. Very nicely done American Pale Ale. Good example of the style. Would drink again.

On tap at brewpub. Appearance : Pale amber Aroma : Sweet malt with light caramel and light hops. Quite earthy. Taste : Earthy hops and a bit citrusy. Malt and light caramel. Finish is hoppy and bitter. Quite earthy and mineral. Overall : Not bad. Quite hoppy and bitter. Maybe a bit too sweet.

Pours a two finger off-white head that fades quickly leaving some lace. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Cloudy amber color. Nose is light grapefruit hops. Flavor is grapefruit hops and hints of caramel. $5.45 for a 22oz bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA.

22oz bomber in a crystal pint glass. No head, makes for easy drinking. Solid tan, gold, copper slight color, a nice pale ale spriti to begin with. Taste is malty sweet as it could only be the malts that transpire this amber rush of greatness. there is a flatness to it though, which had me second guessing the brillance of a good brew. Hops bounce around like chickens on a trampoline and hit the pallate subsideingly like a dump truck going 48 on a freeway. A solid, average pale ale here from good old greenfield. I really need to get to this brew pub to take in all in face to taste to mouth. Word.
My pick as the best beer at this very cool brew pub. Well balanced and exactly the kind of malty goodness that I’m looking for in this genre. Aromas are a specialty here and this is no exception.

My Bottom Line: Amiable leafy hops and biscuity malts for a balanced and accessible pint of American Pale Ale. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam floats atop the hazy amber. -The aroma is weak for what I like in the style. -Orange-like fruitiness comes from the hops. -The body is a tad loose; the carbonation is very soft and the malt structure simple. On tap at the brewpub.
on tap-pours an off white head and hazy amber color. Aroma is medium malt-caramel, some herbal hops. Taste is medium malt-caramel/earthy, some herbal/resin hops. Fairly malty, medium body.
On tap @ Internationales Berliner Bierfestival Clear golden body with a minimal vanishing white head. Crispy and cereals aroma. Crispy finish. Medium body soft carbonation oily texture

Bottle. Hazy golden color with white head. Aroma is light noble hops, cereals, earthy, a touch barn and leather, but overall very clean. Taste is grainy, cereals, minerals, dry. Mineraly, chewy mouthfeel with natural carbonation. Very good one!
Bottle. Hazy Amber to gold color, off-white cream. Dry mineral herbal juicy aroma, medium Body, mellow. Fruity, juicy malt character, good grassy light nettle hop finish, moreish.

caramel, bread, hay, cereal, resin, floral, grass, spruce, citrus, herbs, pale, golden, amber, orange, clear, hazy, cloudy, rocky head, frothy, minimal head, light sweetness, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium sourness, salty,

Aroma; floral scents, fruit, caramel, bread. Look; off white head, misty golden body. Taste; honey, malt, flour, bread, caramel, and finishes floury malted. Feel; ok body n soft co2. Overall; good lagerbier. [swingtop-bt.50cl abv4.9% sp23.11.17 Tasted@Thanxbeeringparty @PivotekaH7] 5364'14

500ml swing-top bottle, thanks to djoeye for sharing. A low white head to a misty golden body, fair lacing. Semi-sweet malty nose, citric hints. Moderate taste profile of bread, biscuit and basement. Subdued malt-fruity ending. Rather refreshing. (Shared with djoeye and Finn, Thanxbeeringparty at PivotekaH7, Tromsø 23.11.2017).

Flaske 500ml spandert av djoeye. Delt med ham og Rune på Thanxbeeringparty 23 Nov 17. Gylden. Litt uklar. Lavt skum. Litt lacing. Forsiktig maltaroma. Smaken malt med spor av fersken. Søt fruktig ettersmak.

(Flasche) Es hat eine goldgelbe Farbe, ist leicht trüb mit einer weißen Schaumkrone. Aromatisch ist es eine Butterbombe, sonst kann ich nichts erkennen. Geschmacklich ist es eindimensional, buttrig, leicht süßlich mit leichtem würzigen Hopfen. Die Karbonisierung ist ok.
Naturtrüb. Malzbetonter Antrunk, weicher würziger Körper begleitet von einer feinen Hopfenbittere.
bottle bb 20/6/17 golden light hazy good head butter bit cereal smooth not bitter oro leggera velata buona schiuma media persistenza diacetile filo cereale morbidaluppolatura contenuta

Another addition to the Graal range, since 2007. Creamy, moussy, light beige head, colour a deep, misty bronze. Sweetish aroma of pear, caramel, chocolate, pepper, yeast, cinnamon, dates, flowers. Sweetish fruity taste, soft caramelly and chocolatey maltiness, bit nutty, typical Graal yeasty spiciness, ending in a mild, herbal, flowery hoppiness with a glow of warming alcohol. Very decent and pretty well-balanced without being world class, like most De Graal beers.

pours a semi-clear maroon with a small beige head that dissipates, and some lacing. smell is of wild yeast, dark fruits, and a touch of caramel. taste is of dark fruits, some caramel, a little cocoa, and wild yeast. ends slightly tart.

14-Mar-12 (750-ml bottle) This dark Belgian ale has an extremely complex, intriguing, and enticing nose. It’s very fruity, malty, and candy-like, with prominent aromas of fig, date, and raisin, but also toffee, brown sugar, caramel candy, treacle, clove, nutmeg, aged wood, leather, nut shells, dust, and old books. Unfortunately, the beer doesn’t taste nearly as complex or enjoyable as the aroma suggests.
