Malts are fruity and sweet, touch of orange and pineapple. Hops are slightly floral and citrusy, Nice carbonation. Beer is somewhat sweet, but its balanced by a good solid hop presence. Good balance. Nice orange highlights throughout. Very drinkable session APA. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
I was going to say, this definitely tasted more EPA than APA, rich and has a heavier maltiness, light bodied mouthfeel, with some crisp citrus hoppiness in the background. Enjoyable.

Tap. Lightly opaque, medium amber in color with a small off-white head. No lacing. Predominantly malty in aroma with a nice citrus background. Light to medium bodied. Decent caramel malt flavor with a fair citrus hop balance. Fair APA.
RBSG 2004, on tap at the brewpub: Cloudy orange, cookie malty aroma, starts and ends lightly sweet. A decebt pale ale.

On tap at Old Market, pours a red-tinged dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma is restrained, with light toasted bready malt. Flavour is more robust, with toasted malt, caramel and a decent hop kick. Nicely constructed and well-balanced. Good porter.

On tap at OMP. Pours a clear brown color with a small white head. A light nutty nose. The flavor is intensely sweet nutty malts, bizzare like a creme brulee. Terrible really in some sense. Tastes like diacetal. Odd.

Keg at the brewpub, 11/11/14. Mahogany brown with a decent beige covering. Nose is light roast, cocoa, dark toffee, hint of cardboard. Taste comprises light roast, cocoa rub, dark toffee. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, semi drying close. So so porter.

On tap. A: Murky, if penetrable, dark brown. Ring of white head. N: Almonds, coffee, coconut, chocolate, and caramel. Peppercorn. T: Sweet with a touch of bitterness. M: Medium body, a little oily. O: Drinkable and sweet. Not a standout from the crowd, but not something to avoid.
On tap at OMP with Jeff. Pours a red/brown with tan foam. Smells sweet and lightly roasty. Tastes lightly roasted with hints of caramel and coffee.

Date: September 22, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: black, fine tan head, dripy lace Aroma: dark chocolate and roasted aroma with a nice espresso note, light caramel sweetness Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, touch of roasted, caramel and butterscotch sweetness add to the richness, light balancing bitterness Overall: was initially disappointed to see the dyactyl and it was the first flaw in a dozen beers but it works really well in this beer and may not be a flaw afterall Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 15/20 Rating: 3.6/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: *** /4 Date: September 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: opaque dark brown, fine tan head, streaks of lace Aroma: sweet dark chocolate aroma, touch of roasted, caramel sweetness Flavor: sweet caramel and chocolate flavor, dark chocolate bitterness, hint of roasted adds an espresso character, light bitterness from the roasted Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4

Draught. Poured black with thick lasting tan head. Aroma of malt and coffee, like a good fresh brewed cup. Full Malty body, with chocolate caramel and coffee notes. Lingering coffee finish, with more malt..
On tap at the Old Market Portland OR. Pours out dark brown topped with a tan head. A nice malt, coffee and sweet. Not a bad porter.

on tap deep lack with a thin dk tan head for 20 min. nice choc roasted aroma. flavoe was very sweet and c0hoclaty. modeete palate and vrt little vitteenwss ttailer. tasty but quite sweet. unintenialy maybe.

[Tap - Old Market Pub] A deep brown color with a little head. This had chcolate and toffee in the aroma and there was a deep toasty maly build to this brew. it was easy to drink and had a great flavor. Semi coffee finish and I really liked that. Not Bad at all.
Draft at Broadway Grill. Lightly cloudy amber, small creamy head. Aroma and taste reflect a well balanced hop- malt mix. Classic NW style IPA.

Not fans of this IPA. Pours a clear orange with a white head. Smells and tastes piney. Classic northwest IPA, more hops then anything else. Had on tap at the brewery. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Old Market, pours a clear copper golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out light piney hops, British malt and an earthy quality. Flavour brings out chiefly British hops that have an earthy bitterness to them. Just enough malt to back. Long bitter finish. Decently made.
On tap at the brew pub pours orange Amber, small off white head that leaves a long cap. Plenty of pine, hop resin, and bitterness. Medium body.
On tap at OMP. Pours a clear copper color with a small white head. A fresh hop nose. Perfume, citrus, oranges, medium bitterness. A pretty solid ipa. Quite bitter.

Keg at the brewpub, Beaverton, 11/11/14. Clear golden amber with a moderate of white swirl. Nose is floral, light pine, bitter orange, tangerine, mineral notes. Taste comprises sweet tunes, chalky minerals, orange pith, hint of tropical fruits. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with a whisper of tropicana. So so IPA, wouldn’t call it British though, too much new world hop and not enough malt to replicate a Burton style IPA.

On tap at Old Market Pub in Portland, OR. Aroma was perfectly floral and hoppy, but had a slight hint of dishwater. Palate was pleasing. Taste was piney, but very bitter. Too bitter even. Not a great balance. Not a favorite, but would drink on occasion.
Nice aroma, appearance was a bit cloudy. Taste had a nice up front grapefruity flavor, which I enjoyed! Finish was nothing special. Overall it was tasty and I would drink again!
Draft at the brewpub. Decent but fairly average. Bitterness really sticks with you. A little bit of a dry finish....kind of wierd.
On tap at OMP with Jeff. Pours gold with white foam. Smells of floral hops. Tastes bitter with floral hops and slight malts to back it up.

On tap at Old Market, pours a clear pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma doesn’t really show much of the hot peppers, with straw and biscuity malt. Flavour is extended intense, with burning hot peppers. The flavour isn’t really of anything other than throat-destroying spiciness. If that’s your thing, you might like it, but this isn’t well-crafted IMO.

On tap at OMP. Holy shit is this hot. Pours a clear straw color with a small white head. A light grainy nose. Man, this is nuts, a smooth lager flavor for 3 seconds then massive burn of Habanero. This is super hot. Couldn’t finish a sampler.

Keg at the brewpub, 11/11/14. Clear pale golden with a moderate off white head. Nose is bland, pale malt, light spice, straw. Taste takes off but in a bad way, big chilli kick, green pepper, chilli heat - 1 trick pony and a shit trick at that. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, semi drying close. Dum de dum de dum ....... WHY ?

Name: Hot Tomale Pepper Ale Date: September 22, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy gold, creamy white head, drippy lace Aroma: sweet feet aroma, hint of buttermilk Flavor: sweet malt flavor is quickly balanced by a hot peppery character, touch of feet lingers from the aroma, long hot pepper finish Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 7/20 Rating: 2.1/5.0 Drinkability: 5/10 Score: *+ /4

On tap at the Old Market Portland OR. Pours out a light amber topped with a very small head. Nothing much going on for aroma. Tast not much going on and them Bam it hits the back of your mouth. Pretty cool beer.
on tap clear litght yelloe amber with snall white hed. plain liht geain aroma and no ecidence of thepepper untill the after tasteNis

For what this is, this was exceptionally tasty. Although it is somewhat vegetal and earthy, with some inherent spiciness, but it never overdoes itself, it is not extremely overpowering. It does however have a couple of levels of spiciness, the first spiciness hits you right in the nose and burns a little bit, and then the second wave rushs over your palate and then fades away.

Tap. Lightly opaque. Medium to light amber in color with a decent white head and fail lacing. Aroma is malty and somewhat vegetal. Light bodied. Flavor is Cave Creek Redux. Not quite as harsh and painful as Crazy Ed’s elixir but still this is a pepper dominated beer in flavor. A very quick malt sweetness is erased quickly by the capsaicin. Long medium hot burn. Fair, but you are better off having food with this one.

On tap at the Old Market. Pours golden with a medium white head. Aroma is sweet, lots of pepper, hint of lime and some other fruitiness. Taste starts quickly sweet, then the pepper burn starts, really hot and long lasting. Quite a nice pepper beer. I think it could use a bit more beer taste to it, but still a great spicy brew.
RBSG 2004, on tap at the brewpub: Amber with a small white head. Flowers and hot green peppers in the aroma, long mellow burn that is followed by a strong pepper burn in the aftertaste.
(En fût à la source): Base malté miellée frôlant le générique avec une couche de verdure craquante. Rien de fou, rien de déplaisant.

Draft at the brewery. Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, fully lasting. Body is medium yellow. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain, cracker), lightly to moderately hoppy (herbs), with notes of minerals and straw/hay. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately bitter, slightly husky. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Well, shucks. I’ve had three draft samples of this now and the quality is all over the place...3.9 at the brewpub on Friday, 2.2 garbage at Beerhive over the weekend, and 3.4 at the brewpub today. This seems to jive with overall impressions from their other beers...e.g., my friend Jeff had a very solid sample of the Dort, but mine (bought at the brewpub) was horrible. As with so many breweries in the world (including Germany), this place just doesn’t have the consistency factor (yet?). You may luck out with a great sample of this, or it might just be ok, or it might be terrible.

From can it’s filtered gold with a lasting white head. Clean, floral-citric noble hop aroma comes across as honeysuckle, lemon, apricot nectar, spicy touches of black fennel; clean fermentation provides clarity for hop and malt (which imparts a baked baguette toastiness), while the yeast imparts a subtle sulfur-mineral quality. Off-dry, hoppy and bitter, light-bodied but fluffy with a fun bounce of carbonation, finishing fruity and juicy with a small bit of pineapple twang that I didn’t get from tap (better carbonation and balance than the cans, going from memory). Canned 6/29/16, so age may be a factor, but even so it’s still in fine shape.
Tap. Pours clear pale golden, large white head, good lacing. Aroma of grass, grain, hint of citrus. Flavors is light sweet, light bitter. Light body, clean.
Can at the Local DC Tasting. Clear pale yellow with off-white head. Aromas of corn, malt, light skunk. Tastes of corn, wheat, malt. Light body with a dry finish.
From a can at the DC tasting July 10, 2016. It is a clear light golden color with a slight head. the aroma is fruity and the taste is a strong bitter flavor
From a can at the DC tasting July 10, 2016. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Bready nose. Flavors of dough and white toast. Clean finish
Can. Crystal clear golden yellow color, white head. Straw aroma. Taste is black pepper and lemon. OK.
Light saaz here and lots of malt. A little bit of an odd tangy finish. Golden pour without much head or lacing. Tangy finish. Can.
[Dec 28 2015] On tap at Snowbird Ski Area. Nice golden body. Maltier nose. Taste of malts and grass. Metallic. Lots of hops in the taste, skunkier too. Pretty well balanced.

Draft. Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, fully lasting. Body is hazy light yellow. Aroma is moderately malty (cracker, light bread), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with a light note of lemon zest. Flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Little to no German Weissbier yeast character, but if they’re still making this with Czech lager yeast, that explains that. And indeed, it is mostly a malty affair (and pretty nice malt at that), with a little yeast and lemony character. Simple and light, but better than usual from this very inconsistent brewery.

Tap. Pours light hazy straw, medium white head, nice lacing. Aroma is wheat, lacking traditional hef esters, citrus. Flavor is light sweet, no bitterness, twinge of tartness. Light body. Let it tart up a bit and call it a Berliner.

On tap @ Bohemian. Mostly clear golden pour with white foam. Somewhat crackery, but a lot of bread, some apple, and an oddly floral and grassy character. Slight grain husk bitterness to the finish. A little watery as well. Not my favorite.
Had on draft at the brewery. Very light straw color, slightly cloudy. Nightshift esters, soft doughy maltiness. This is a restrained beer.
Draft @ brewery. Lemony wheat malt aroma. Hazy yellow with a large white head. Leomony wheat malt and very light grassy flavor. Medium body, lively carbonation.
Nice enough, though if I’m grabbing a hefe, I thin I’d prefer the more fruity and spicy hefe yeast. This was refreshing with hints of lemon and wheat. Easy drinking.
Best weis beer I've had In a long time. The checz yeast makes a real winner. Nice balance very enjoyable. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brewpub pouring pale opaque gold with white head. The modest aroma offers up some grainy malts and echoes of citrus from the lemon wedge that they put in the beer. The taste has a nice yummy grainy maltiness laced with mild sweet fruity esters and a touch of malt or caramel or butterscotch or something sweet into the finish.

on tap 7/22/10... hefe? hazy very pale yellow color... it looks a lot like lemonade with a soft white head. it smells very similar to sprite soda???... lemony refreshing and calcium mixed with wheat, flowers and some grass. the flavor is a mix of wet wheat and a spicy dry finish along with the notes from the aroma. it is crisp, medium bodied and ridiculously quaffable. neat-o. 7/3/7/3/15/3.5
Hazy deep gold pour. Aroma of grain, yeast, spice and citrus. Flavor is lightly tart wheat, spice, banana and lemon peel. Nicely done.
Pours golden/Amber. Earthy aroma with a decent light and yeasty bitter flavor.

Draft at the brewery. Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, fully lasting. Body is medium to dark yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain, cookie), lightly hoppy (flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. At first I thought I was given the wrong beer because the color was so much paler than expected, but that’s partly because this was a sample in a narrow glass. Great head retention, as usual. Whereas the Czech pils aroma leaped from the same sort of glass, this seems to hide and say nothing at all. And just sweet and flabby in the mouth. Not as bad as the Schwarz, but very dull. I’m really pleased they got the pils dialed in, but it sure would be nice if their other brews were closer to that level.

Toast and honey, fall leaves and paper, sweet pastries and artificial apricot hoppiness. Light bodied, sweet with low bitterness, kind of unremarkable and plain but it is clean and the carbonation suits the sweetness and body.
Tap. Pours clear orange, medium off white head, dissipates fairly quickly, good lacing. Aroma is grassy, grain, hint of nuttiness. Flavor is light sweet, light bitter. Light body. Decent.
12oz can pours a clear, dark gold with some creamy, white head. Nose has yeast, grist, honey. Flavor follows, yeast, honey, flowers, orange, dough. Finishes dry. Not terrible.
Some copper and some malt. Amber pour with ok head. Tangy metallic finish. Shared at tasting.

Packaged on 4/14/16, consumed on 5/8/16. Golden orange. Fleeting white head settles into the wispiest collar. Pleasant nose of marmalade-kissed toast, vanilla cookie, creamed coffee, and hay dust. Trace of melanoidins is marred by hints of marzipan and fruit chews. Light tickle of loose-bubbled carbonation. Fluffy malt textures inundate the palate, backed by a gripping contrast of toasted pumpernickel bread and softer tobacco. Hint of sweet pecan accentuates the earthy medley of flavors. Subtle tartness and a slippery orangey fruitiness quickly emerge and hamper the drinkability as the body takes on a distracting limpness and sugary sweetness. A smattering of dusty melanoidins pokes through at times as the malt is thoroughly extracted. Well integrated hops show a fairly high level of oily flowery petal notes as well as an elegant and rustic tealike effect, although the sweetness is unassuaged. Rich, but wet, maltcentric finish is dabbed with an aniseed-like hoppiness and lingering spicy tobacco. I’m a bit surprised by the mediocrity of this, after having consumed several cans of the superlative pils. The malt does boast moderate depth from this having been decocted, but it’s too sweet and unclean to drink much of. Nice aroma, but that’s about it. Okay. Thanks for the can, Sledutah.
On tap at Snowbirds Octoberfest pours a clear amber with a one finger head good malty caramel flavors smooth, very drinkable

On tap @ Bohemian. Light amber pour with a white head. Bready, toasty malts dominate. Some mild floral hops and a bit of fruity ester qualities. Slight caramel to it, too. A bit more bitter than I’d normally expect. Still, really nice malt sweetness and bready character. Nice.
Draft @ brewery. Light caramel malt aroma. Clear copper with a large off-white head. Caramel malt and grassy hops flavor. Body on the light side of medium, soft carbonation.
Pours dark, with subtle toasty caramel aroma. Tastes of roast nuts/coffee. Didn't taste the chocolate.
(En fût à la source): Anis, caramel, mélasse discrète et des notes rôties. Rond, souple et agréable.

Draft at the brewery. Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (malt syrup, wort, roasted grain, husks). Flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter, unclean, husky. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Shockingly poor compared to the wonderful Czech pils. How does the same brewery make both? Raw and dirty and rather sour too...couldn’t even stomach a 2oz sample.

They are calling this a Schwarzbier now on their menu, FWIW. Tap. Pours deep clear Ruby black, medium beige head, good lacing. Aroma is super roasty, lactose, a bit ashy. Flavor has a touch too much sweetness, light bitterness. A bit odd. Stale coffee? Light plus body.

Can from sledutah who helped me gather a bunch of these strange brews I was after. Cherry brownish black pour. Nose is dried fruit light cola. Tastes of flat cola, dried red fruits like cherry and raspberry, some caramel, and bread as well. Light bodied. Yippee 15 dunklers
12oz can pours a murky brown with a ring of white head. Nose has malt, pumpernickel bread, some dried fruit, hints of spice. Flavor is soggy bread, malt, some mild spice. Watery finish.
Can at the July DC tasting. Can. Poured a clear ruby color with a small white head. Aroma was light sweet malt notes. Toasted malts, light cherry notes, touch of roast.
I haven’t had a lot of dunkler bocks but this isn’t quite what I look for in a beer. Tangy odd aroma with copper. Amber pour with good head and lacing. Bottle.
Can. Clear ruby maroon color, tan head. Aroma of brownies and fruitcake. Taste is sweet malty roast. Very nice.

Draft at Taggarts. Pours dark nut brown with a thick, bubbly beige head. Tastes like dry toasted malt, dried dark fruits, earthy, woody, and light booze. Medium body and low carbonation. Smells like dried dark fruits, toasted malt, earthy, woody, and light booze.

A surprisingly decent beer, especially out of a green bottle. No skunkiness to it at all and a crisp, slightly sweet taste. Far and away beter than any of the major American beers. Too bad Ithink you can only get it in Henan Province of China.

OLD NOTES OCT 21, 2003 Very similar to the full strength. Good amount of flavour for a light beer. Sweet malt, probably better that most Aussie macro light beers on offer, and better price. But the fact remains...why?

330ml. bottle. Clear and amber in colour with a large white head that settles quickly. Good carbonation with a grassy aroma that has a hint of soapy water mixed with it. Mlat flavour with a dry texture and light bitter finish.
Deep orange and alot of bitterness for a light beer. I did not think this was too bad for its class. Not much of a head though but alot of bitterness.

I must admit I cringe at even the thought of drinking a ’free’ light beer from a mates house, which played on me when I bought this, myself, from ’Con’s case place’ in Balcatta. Poured a clear pale straw with a thin soapy white head. Aroma of lightly sour grassy hops and husky gritty malt, quickly lost its pizazz as I quaffed my first mouthful. Flavour seemed balanced, malt driven with a light bitterness in the back and feint fruity esters across the palate. Slightly yeasty with a light body and a short dry aftertaste. Little complexity, but not a bad beer overall for a ’Light’.

Pale orange/golden colour witha compact short lasting white head. Slight malt aroma. Pleasant bitterness but a bit watery and a touch of lemon. Overall not a lot flavour but I like the bitterness for a light beer.

I admit I overpraised the full strength version of this because it was sweet and malty and suited my palate at the time. This light also smells sweet but has no flavour at all. A dry finish like club soda. A waste even at 98 cents, like other light beers.
Geez, the full strength version got a 1.5. This is half as good. What's 50% of crap?
This beer has a light yellow body - hue with a bitter initial flavor and a light body.

german style my butt. i'm astonished how many flavours ol_juntan got out of this, he mustve been concentrating very hard. i put this with some 11% grandridge supershine and it improved both beers considerably.
Well, er, imagine regular Haagen and then water it down a bit, sweetish and bland, thats about all i can say.
Strong aroma of cherry compote and jam. Saturated scarlet color, clean almost without foam. The taste of ripe cherries is quite simple. Light body, medium carbonation.

Bottle shared at kulminator. A pinky brown coloured pour with a a lasting pink head. Aroma is weird semi sweet, cherry, musty, cough sweet. Flavour is composed of semi sweet, cherry cough syrup, light must, cherry, raspberry sweets. Palate is semi sweet, light tang,. Decent.

7 3 6 3 12 ‘95 Bottle shared at Kulminator. Hazy purple with a pink head. Aroma of mellow sweet cherries, holding up well for the age. Sweetness is present but toned down with a light sourness behind. Light medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle at the Kulminator, 07/12/18. 1995 bottle. Dark cherry red with a well presented crimson cap. Nose is musty cherries, damp wood, cherry skins, straw. Taste comprises mellow cherries, underlying sugars but not super sweet, musty, light cherry yoghurt, berry compote. Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with a light tarte cherry edge. A nice surprise ... this has aged very well ... no oxidisation and not overly sweet.

*Old rating, best before 08/02/05. Primeur 2004. Aromatisiert mit 10% konzentriertem Fruchtsaft... Sehr süße Angelegenheit, viel Kirsche, vielleicht auch Kirschlolli, kaum Bier. Sehr süffig, ein Hauch von Säure, aber viel zu süß.

Spring version of the regular Belle-Vue Kriek, presented as being made with fresh fruit, but it’s just the same industrial, sugary ’fake lambic’ as the original. I never did a side by side tasting of this with that original, but I remember it as being fruitier, rounder and sweeter, with less acidity. I’m note sure if this is still made, but I for one will not miss it.

Bottle -1994- at kulminator Pours dark red to brown No foam Smells dusty , some cherrts in a sweet way Low carbo Sugary mouthfeel Im a fan of some aged sweet beers ( think of redbach , alexander ) but this is too damn high on sugar

Please note: this review is based on a bottle that has been properly stored for 16 years (vintage 1995) so it might not taste the same as a new one. Clear body, spongy pink/grey head. Amazing aroma, dried plums, cherry. After tasting... this beer makes you happy! Taste like Polish Christmas plum soup. Super!

When fresh even sweeter than the normal Belle-Vue kriek. Clear cherry red colour, pinkish white head. Loads of cherry juice, not much lambic character. Very sweet finish. Haven’t seen it around anymore lately, has it been retired? (from 25cL bottle)

Bottle 25cl. [ Vintage 1994 ]. Clear dark red color with a average, frothy, fair lacing, fully diminishing, white to off-white head. Aroma is oxidid, cherry. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090226]

Aroma; malted scents, alco, herbs. Look; beige head, clear caramel brown body. Taste; malts, caramel sauce, stingy alcohol, some modest herbal influence. Feel; dabooze. Overall; if abv were lowered to 6.4 and booze scents removed, it would be nice. But then it wouldn’t go as a typical ugly sweedish boozy malt liquor anymore.
Brown,smooth brown head, aroma is Malts, synliggjort seedet, Flavor is malts,se det,

(50 cl can from Systembolaget) Clear brown color, big tan head. Aroma is rather sweet mixed with applesauce. Sweet rather mild taste with more than pleasant notes of alcohol. Medium but too spritzy mouthfeel. Low bitterness, sweet and alcohol aftertaste.
Can: red clear colour. Aroma of lots of malt and a balanced hopy nose.Some toffee and dark chocolate notes to bur that all. Flavor is almost the same. thin body, short finish. To sweet for me.

Coppery colored, little light brown head. Surprisingly thin aroma with slight toffee, sweetness, esters and mild alcohol. Medium bodied. More character in flavor than aroma: caramel, sweetness, hops, mild alcohol, some perfumy tones and berries. Weird aftertaste with this perfume and some alcohol.

Can. Clear golden with a small off-white head. Malty and grainy aroma, and a flavor with caramel and some malt. Thin and watery body with a malty finish. It didn’t feel right to call it a bayerskt. (060908)

Clear amber with a large creamy white head, good retention and lacing. Weak aroma of cheese and sweet malts. Bitter mouthful, balanced out to some extent by some sweetish malts. Carries no hop flavour or good malt characteristics, which is hardly suprising. Alcohol is well hidden in the finish, and in all its not too bad to drink.

<!-- i -->can; courtesy of Domtom<!-- /i --> - pours a clear amber colour with a fast collapsing head; very metallic nose, some alcohol and an earthy touch; sweet and a bit oily, medium-bodied; tart corny finish with some astringence; more metallic notes and a touch of caramel maltiness in the aftertaste - I’ve had worse malt liquor
Can. Amber with small, short lasting head. Sweet, syrupy, unpleasent harsh, battery-like finish.
canned. Dark golden colour with a vanishing white head, lacings. There is a sweet malty aroma. The flavour is sweet and malty with hints of alcohol,
Bottle from Aldi. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. No tasting notes kept, just rating.
part of my 2013 backlog Golden colour with a white head. aroma is fruity apricot, malt and biscuits. Nice bitter finaish.
Pours a copper colour with a white head, aroma is floral and light hops, taste is medium bitterness with a dry finish.

Bottle aldi. Pours with white head soon dissapears. Clear light copper colour. Aroma is biscuity malts. Taste is malty with slight orange undertones sweet finish. Thin body strong carbonation. Middle o the road beer.
Bottle from b&m Chester-le-Street. Amber coloured with marzipan, vanilla and toffee flavours and a red fruity finish.

(Bottled) . its not golden ,yet is called a golden ale on the bottle , resembling more an APA - you know customary glowing bronze SNPA lookin kinda resemblance thing , i reckon, resting in the flute . drinking this isn’t as floral or zesty as you expect either for the style . rather malty driven , caramel , mild orange notes , wood, lemon bitterness , some mango ..... but these fruits and the overall character is rather subdued . Not bad though despite my moanng through most of the rating .....

Clear 500ml bottle (4.2%), best before mid July 2008, drank early May 2008. Poured into a Batemans half pint tumbler (twice). It was a light amber colour, clear and sparkling, with a good formed white head which sadly soon fell away to a thin wispy covering. Fairly sweet aroma, toffee apples and malted milk biscuits came to my mind. This is the 13th Batemans beer I have reviewed on this site. I obviously like their beers and this is no exception. It has a sweetish feel to it, although there is a dryness in the finish. I also detected spices (pepper, cumin and tumeric?), but the wife was cooking mushrooms in the room next door. Lovely summer brew and another fine beer from a wonderful brewery set in a smashing part of Great Britain.
4.2% deep gold colour with a thin head, hop aroma, some fruitiness in the taste a reasonable bitter.

(Bottle) Bright coppery golden with good white head. Aroma has notes of biscuit and rice. Light body, well carbonated. Flavor is thin and not very pleasant with seaweed and subtle toffee. Overall a bit bland, thin and not very nice.
Bottle. Over carbonated. Pours a very lively white head. Golden amber body. Biscuity, fruity, nutty. Not too hoppy, despite its colour. Sweetish. Clean dry finish. Average.
Ich weiß gar nicht, ob dieses Bier überhaupt noch produziert wird, aber es ist mir in positiver Erinnerung gelblieben. Es sind doch nicht alle Biere aus der Wieselburger Brauerei mies.

Tap at Krahvogel Innsbruck. Clear yellow-golden color with white head. Aroma is grassy, definitely some hops here, pale malts, a bit herbal, touch of honey, a bit of a bubblegum-like fruitiness. Taste is crackery pale malts, honey, a bit fruity again. Slightly fruity aftertaste. Ample carbonation. Okay.
On tap in Spitz. White-yellow. A-sweet grain. T-sweet grain, second spice hops. Easy.
Relativ ordentlicher und dabei hopfiger Antrunk mit mittlerer Schaumkrone. Einfache Trinkbarkeit mit ein wenig Heu und Hopfen im Nachgeschmack. Simpel, aber ok.

Bottle from local Spar in Austria. The beer pours out in a clear golden colour with steady head and crisp body. Aroma of bitter hops and malt, followed by a taste of medium bitter hops, malt, grass, citrus fruits and grains. Hints of bread , metallic finish and high carbonation. Drinkable.
Drunk from 33cl bottle in Krems, Austria. Fairly bland standard lager. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft in Bier Lagune Wien. Clear, pale golden colour, sparkling, long- life large white head, neutral aroma, from light to medium body, smooth fizziness, very sweet malty taste, slight herbal hoppy palate. Decent well-balanced and easy-drinkable Pilsner style beer.
On tap at the Krahvogel in Innsbruck. Can’t really go wrong with this one. Standard pilsener. Never revolting, never great. Aftertaste is slightly dusty and not the best. Goes down fast.

On tap at Elferhaus Innsbruck. Pours golden clear with large white head. Mild noble hop aroma confused by smoking establishment. Tastes like a hoppy helles, bready malt and noble hops. Finishes dry with subtle bitterness.
On bottle in the last trip in Vienna. It is a little bit hoppy and few malt feelings. A typical golden Austrian pilsner. Nothing very special but refreshing!
butelka 0,33; , kolor jasnożółty, obfita piana choć dość krótka, łagodnie wchodzi, niezbyt gazowane jak lubię, trochę zbyt kwasowe, goryczka w w sam raz trochę powyżej średniej, finisz łagodny
A refreshing no nonsense beer with a good initial taste and a good finish. I really liked this beer.
500ml bottle from Spar Hermagor. It is a good average beer with very nice foam, average co2, average malt, light neutral hop. Touch of yeast feeling. Nice to drink.
Bevuta in bottiglia. Birra bionda per tutte le occasioni. Nulla di particolare.

0,33l bottle. Pours clear deep golden with a finger of white dissipating head. Aroma of malt, cardboard, herbal hop notes. Flavor follows aroma. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is on the light side, slick and carbonation average. Finish is rather short, cardboard, herbal notes and mellow bitterness.

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega piirdun iga õlle juures selle tekstiga.

Many thanks to Mirko & Stefan for bringing this beer back from their vacation. Grainy and malty beginning. Easy to drink, round and refreshing with a grainy back. Not too deep with a grainy malty finish and a slight bitterness.
Just your run of the mill light lager. Drank at some tapas place in Vienna. Nothing else to say
golden, clear, white foam, lightly bitter, medium sweetness, medium body, average carbonation,

Goudgeel, witte schuimkraag, vrij helder. Aroma: Mout, graan, sterk brood/biscuit, beetje citrus. Smaak volgt het aroma.... bitter is vrij zacht... ook niet echt spicy.... dus matig gehopt. Iets zoetig . Lichte body, voller als een pilsener.

On tap at MBC Lansing. Deep translucent red body, medium tight buff head. Sweet nose with brown sugar, berries, toast, and alcohol. Aggressive body dominated by hot alcohol and sweet candy, with notes of brown sugar, caramel, and berries. Hot, dry, and a bit medicinal, with none of the flabby citrus/pine hops or oxidized caramels that I have come to dread in barleywines.

This was an interesting barley wine. Much sweeter than any barley wine I've had. It had a sort of syrupiness too it that I didn't particularly enjoy. It seemed out of place somehow. It was very drinkable, and it tastes quite alright. I don't think they quite hit the mark on this one though.

Expensive 350ml brown bottle at Cruzat in B.A. Labeled 4.5%. Pours a dense dark gold color with a slight head of fime bubbles and perfumy aroma. A full mouthfeel from the big carbonation. slightly sweet flavor balance, slight pale malt flavor and slight hop bitterness. Fruity notes and not very clean.
[bottle from FireWater] Fizzy yellow, quickly diminishing head. Stale, bready aroma. thin, watery body. Barely detectable dryness in the finish.
They told me i wasnt aloud the bottle and had to drink this out a plastic cup. Aroma is skunked cornish. Taste is terrible also, a seriousl rubbish beer, which i struggled to finish.

Had this at Castro’s, another Toronto bar owned by the same people as Sarah’s. Clear golden colour with a creamy white head. Slightly fruity aroma and flavour. Clean, crisp finish with a pleasant bit of hoppiness. A very well-made mainstream lager.

Had it at Castro's Lounge in the Beaches. Not much head on mine, bit of fruit in the aroma and the finish. Nice clean lager with a bit of hops. Not fantastic but at $2.99 a pint it was the best value I have got for my beer money in a while!

This is available at Sarah's Cafe & Bar as their House Draught. Sweet fruit aroma, golden creamy head. Apricot and citrus(lemon?) flavour. Sweet, smooth, clean with a crisp finish. A well done lager, nice draught on their patio.
Little head but good lacing, nice medium golden hue. Good solid deeply flavored pils taste and typical beery/grainy aroma. I was a bit impressed.
Pretty heady. Not quite heady enough to call it a doppelpils, but it is a good pilsener.

This "Special Draft" poured a very light yellow with a non-existant white head, even after a vigorous pour. To the nose it is very much like they’re Stone Hammer Pils. Doughy with very small slioght scent of citrus and a bit of hopps thrown in. It is smoother/ watery and doesn’t have much flavour. It smells much more than it tastes. The palate is doughy like the nose and dissipates quickly.

Just as pootzboy says freshness makes a big difference with this beer just like most F&M beers. Aroma is of light bread, slightly hoppy with floral notes. Appearance needs improvement: small mostly-to-fully diminishing white head with fair lacing, and light yellow colour. Flavour is malty with some sweetness and little bitterness. Body is light to medium with soft carbonation.

Tasted in Toronto. Obtained from LCBO. Tasted in pint glass. Appearance is golden yellow, clear with moderate white head. Aroma is faint, slight hint of bitterness. Taste was similar to very cheap corn syrupy macros.

I disagree with the Canadian raters that put this brew in the Macro fizzy weak category...it’s not. What it is; is a fairly decent drinkable draft lager with better than average malt delivery in it’s smooth dinking character. Bought mine fresh from the brewery....that’s the key sales point on this draft...it's sold fresh and meant to be consumed fresh and that is the fact with most of F&M brews. Age never improves the character as it isn’t pasturized in bottles...they aren’t date coded, so I’m not surprised there are bad reviews from people who buy this at the LCBO out of date. The pour reveals a yellow-gold semi hazy liquid with a small head that reduces quickly to a light ring....carbonation is pronounced..the glass is lively. Light aroma of sweet malts and a musty hay smell. Starts crisp and peppers the tongue with effervescence as the main (light) body comes through with the balance definately on malts, light on the grassy hops... then the finish is nice...full malt departure with a long finish that has a lingering sour biscuit dough after taste. A nice drinkable draft. I will definately look at getting a pony keg for a patio get together with non beer geek friends...a good way to turn them on to fresh beer.

I bought it fresh and it tasted so 10 days later. Crisp with higher than average carbonation. Satisfying all purpose beer. Better than the national brands. Like the fresh brasserie beers I would have at college in Montreal.

Co-rated by Scraff... Very pale, amber lager. Aroma is very light... some straw and hay. No flavor. Not offensive, not good. Canada's version of Rolling Rock Extra Pale. Very thin. Light-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Well-balanced, but so is Evian bottled water. Short, crisp, clean finish.

(Bottle) It appears by the ratings that this beer has been improved for 2003. F&M Special Draft shouldn't be a 1.2 - 1.8 rating; those can be saved for the Mols/batt's. Pours a thin, white head and a amber body. Pleasant nose of sweet malt that tranferred over to the flavour. There is some moss in there as well. Average.

Malty sweet aroma that was really powerful even when still in the bottle. Gold in colour thin head and little carbonation. Flavour is sweet the first few sips were okay but after awhile it got boring. It's interesting though. Creamy in the finish.
Sparkling gold with white head.Faintly sweet nose.A light bodied sweet lager
Golden yellowish, malty, acidic notes. In short NASTY. I have to admit that it was a bit to warm.

Draft at Good Dog. Yellow gold pour. Nice solid white head. Lots of lace. Big carbonation. Feels like a refined honey wheat beer with some fuzzy funky elements. Grassy amber fruits. Lemon pith. Vinyl bananas. Green oranges. Yellow peppers. Juniper berries. Interesting.

Tap at Nodding Head, PHL, 26/11/13. Clear golden with no head. Nose is toasted malt, light citrics, caramel, straw. Taste comprises lemon sherbet, light hop bill, orange peel, straw. Medium bodied, fine carbonationm dry grassy finish with a spike of bitterness, So so GB affair - I came here to escape them !!!
light bodied blonde Ale with soft hop finish in celebration of stuff............. ...

Golden with thick foamy rocky white head very very bubbly as they continually rising through the glass; aroma is grainy and sharp; Flava is crisp grainy slightly tart; feels light and crisp with fizzy bite; finishes dry and slightly bitter with long lasting yet clean flavor

Golden with a white head. Aroma is toasted malts, light hops, a bit sweet. Thin body. Flavor is sweet, bready, light floral hops. Not much in the back end but maybe a hint of hops. Not much going on here but nothing offensive, either.

Pint on tap pours golden with a white head. Aromas of malt straw some bread aromas and slight cereal very slight floral aroma as well. Flavor is sort of sweet and malty cut only by a hoppy finish. Body is light and finish is a bit bitter

On tap at brewpub. Pours a clear light orange with a thick white head. Aroma of sweet light fruits and wheat malt. Flavor of wheat malt and bitter floral hops in the finish. Quite sweet throughout. Light-medium bodied and fairly clean. Very run of the mill.
Draft at nodding head with Linh. Pours a light gold amber body with no head. Aroma is gross metallic malts. Mouthfeel is thin, dry and bitter and flavor is gross.
This is a tribute to the 700 level at old Veterans Stadium. It tastes like the beer they served up there during Eagles games. As close as a small brewer can get to MillerCoorsBud.
on tap. straw colored, light, not much flavor or taste. your classic light craft beer.

column1: F & M Royal City Cream Ale
column5: clear gold, smalkl white head. faux fruit grainy malt and grape(?) aroma. cereal-ish malt and a bit a green apple in the flavour. quite thin. not for me.

column1: F & M Royal City Cream Ale
column5: Pours gold with a thin white head. Not much of an aroma other than a slight citrus scent. Dull carbonation. Thin. Apples and grape flavours. Some bready malts. It has some good flavours but it’s so unpronounced.

column1: F & M Royal City Cream Ale
column5: Bought fresh from the brewery. Poured a pale gold color with a 3 CM white head that reduced fast to a surface covering thin light lace. Medium-low carbonation. Very faint odors of grassy fruity sweetness. Light and thin up front then the light body releases a faint apple/pear fruityness and suble tartness...like a weak malty cider. Finishes fast, thin and cleanly with very little aftertaste (just a slight metallic effect). An average tasting beer...a bit thin and flat for my tastes.

column1: F & M Royal City Cream Ale
column5: there is a bit of cream balanced with hops. A bit sweet. Not offensive but an average beer. Bit of head. Attractive golden yellow colour.

column1: F & M Royal City Cream Ale
column5: (Bottle) Pours a thin, white head and a golden body. Nose of malt. Smooth, sweet doughy flavour. Average brew.

column1: F & M Royal City Cream Ale
column5: Friuty, malty aroma, golden, small white head. Malt and bread flavour, some bitterness, a little sweet, but well balanced, a pretty good beer.

column1: F & M Royal City Cream Ale
column5: Gold color, white head. Intense bead.Nothing bad about this, but nothing good either. Bland
Pale yellow color, very little white head. THe nose is really quite fruity with hints of apple. Spritzy body with a light fruitiness and very light touch of hops towards the end.
Golden colour with a white head. Nothing too impressive with the looks. Malty aroma slight bit of grassiness. Creamy palate. Overall decent but nothing spectacular.
(Bottle) Pale yellow body with a thin, frothy, white head. Tinny nose with some sweet malt flavours. Thin. Average.
Pale straw. Fizzy white head. Sweet aroma w/ some DMS. Highly carbonated feel. Sweet grainy flavour.

It had very average aroma, plain sweet. What it hit me was how sweet this beer it was. It had creamy texture ,yes but lack of other flavours makes this palate boring. Some more complexity would be interesting. Did not appeal to me and I do believe will not appeal to most.

Dark appearance, minimal head. Bad mouthfeel, like wet cardboard. There was a definite off-flavor that made it seem like the hops and malt weren't matched up very well, and there was minimal carbonation. Kind of hard to describe, not one of Bitter End's better selections. But at least they're still experimenting with new beers, even when they already have proven winners.
typical brown ale, yet not as flat as most brown ales. the head was very short lived.
Looked like coke, had a rather weak head. Better than most browns. Sweet aroma, went down very smooth with a crispness that most browns dont match.

This is one of the few beers from the Red Star that I have really not liked. Sampled on draft at the brewery the beer poured a dark brown color with only a trace of a white head. The aroma was sour malt but nothing else. The flavor was sour and tangy. I could not detect any wheat or much flavor of any sort other than the sharp sour and maybe a hint of banana.

This rating is going to be exactly the same for my rating for the Red Star Belgian Dubbel. That said the two beers taste exactly like a weizenbock with good flavors of cider, banana, and smoke. The weizenbock is a good beer and it fits its style.
A good version of a Dubbel. Very nice nose and a lingering pleasant taste.

This rating is going to be exactly the same for my rating for the Red Star Weizenbock. That said the two beers taste exactly like a weizenbock with good flavors of cider, banana, and smoke. The dubbel is a good beer but it doesnt fit its style.
Draft sample at brewpub. Pours dark black with dark khaki head. Sweet, smoky and roasty nose. Flavors of coffee, mild lactose sweetness and mild smokiness. Notes of chocolate and caramel. Tasty
Pretty decent stout. They usually have this. It is a local favorite definately worth trying. not too much aroma and can be unagreeable with the stomache.

Sample at the brewpub. Jet black color with medium and frothy khaki head. Thin, spotty lacing. Roasted coffee aroma, with hints of malt in the background. On the thin side and very smooth-bodied. Coffee and malt flavors are there but not very pronounced. The finish is dry and mildly bitter with a coffee aftertaste. Not bad, but could definitely use some more flavor and maybe a higher ABV.

Chocolate and coffee bitter smokiness. Good dry bitter hop notes, with roasted malts, dry and toasty. Dark black clear with light tan creamy lacing head. Medium to light bodied with smooth carbonation, under nitro. Starts dry and roasty with bittersweet chocolate and burnt coffee. Light sweetness of malt, malted chocolate milk and dry nuttiness. Finish is smooth bitter and mildly sweet. Bit of carbonic acidity but smooth overall, almost milky. Nice dry stout.
Nothing too special for a stoudt. this beer could use more body. It does have a smoothness to it from the nitrogen.

I really tend not to go much for this style of beer, but It mixes well for Black & Tan purposes.Draft only. This is the usual dry Irish stout that is almost always on their menu. It is very typical of the style. Dark black and thick. Large tan head that lasts quite a while. Roasted malt aroma with a hint of chocolate. Dry from start to finish with decent roasted malt and hints of chocolate and coffee.
Good dry stout. Nice choclate and coffee notes to compliement the malts. PLeasant creamy head.
A very good stout. Creamy and malty, just what you expect and want.........
pleasnt dry stout. very Irish in character. smooth wuith a initial sweet malt taste ans a bitter dry aftertaste.
Guinness... it tasted exactly like Guinness... enough said..................
1/2 litre at a restaurant in the Planai resort. Malty aroma, brown with an off white head. Coffee and chocolate flavour, creamy texture. Pleasant
Weak, watery and plain, thats all I can say.................................

I didn''t know the etymology of Tazza Nera when I took my notes...but I noted that the coffee flavors are clearly here. Buttery flavors, too. Caramel head, more of a pitch black body than the Oatmeal Stout, with only bits of brown around the edges. Dusty aroma. My wife preferred this to the Oatmeal, but I don''t agree. Still tasty, partly because I like coffee stouts.

Not really to my taste, but respectable nonetheless. Like a shot of expresso (see if you can find the joke). The coffee flavors just flat out overbear the beer flavors, which is ok if that's what you're into. I like coffee, but... I think I'd have this again but only once in great while.
I liked the brew at first but why would you blend coffee with beer? I'm not going to rehash the previous rating, just keep the whole depressant/caffeine paradox in mind.

Somewhat light aroma, what is there is lightly roasty coffee and malt. Dark brown-black appearance, with a light but persistent head. Flavor is very coffeeish, with some lightly fruity hops (citrus? this doesn't sound like it would work, but it's really an okay blend) and highly roasted malt. Dry, grainy finish. Body is on the light side of medium, mouthfeel is a bit thin as this beer has a more watery consistency than most stouts. Tasty but overall a bit light. Interesting piney-coffee aftertaste.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Starts sweet and keeps getting sweeter. Apple-like English yeast overpowers the bland malts, and the finish is virtually hop-free. Shoulda stuck with the Rocket Red.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap at BRG in Chattanooga. Deep amber colored body with excellent clarity. and very clear body with a semi-durable tan head and a little lacing. Lightly sweet aroma with about equal hops and malts and a hint of caramel Flavor: lightly sweet up front and mildly bitter by the aftertaste; hints of baked bread and faint hops. The medium body is very smooth; near medium carbonation. O: solid but unexceptional.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap. Pours amber with tall, long-lasting, fluffy white head and nice lacing. Aroma is of bready malt and herbal hops. Body is medium and smooth. Herbal hops, caramel and bready malt fill the mouth. Finish is long and semi-dry. On a sweet side but quite tasty.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draft at the source, with injured typing finger. Clear golden amber color. Aroma of light biscuit. Flavor is very light biscuit.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: At a lookouts game in Chattanooga. My rating might be a little inflate since it is so hot. Overall a good beer. Very smooth. Nice finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draft. Light copper with small off white head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Medium/light body with caramel and malt notes and a sweet finish.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draft. Poured pale amber with a medium-sized white head. Aroma and flavor were toasted malt, slightly spicy hops. Fruitiness comes out as it warms slightly (not my intention -- part of a sampler flight). Light to medium body.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Clear copper color with thin white lacing. Thin up front with bold and slightly aspicy lingering finish. Good overall.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draft. Pours amber with a white head. Lightly sweet malty aroma, but relatively clean and grainy. The flavor is malty, with sweet and grainy notes, and not much else. Pretty good.

column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draught at the Hamilton Place location. Pours light copper with sticky off-white head. The aroma is very mild with toasted malt, a tangerine hint, and subtle fruity hops. The flavor is very mellow with toasted malt, a hint of caramel, a little bit of wood. There’s a sweetness that somehow reminds me of the marshmallows in Lucky Charms cereal. Light fruity hops in the finish. The caramel quality sticks around through the aftertaste. It seems to get fruitier after several sips.

column1: Big River Grille Wowzers Summer Wheat
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Pours a light yellow with an aroma of clove and banana. Tatste is spicy with notes of banana in the finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Big River Grille Wowzers Summer Wheat
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap at Big River Grille during the summer, hazy and golden. Aroma of wheat, cloves. Good carbonation. Taste is smooth. Good beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Big River Grille Wowzers Summer Wheat
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap at Big River - Chattanooga. Poured cloudy, paler golden with a sticky whitish head. The aroma picked up sweet banana with cloves and tart wheat.. decent balance, but a bit too sugary. The flavor found chewy, earthy wheat at the core, with semi-sweet banana, cloves, and white pepper around.. finished with prickly carbonation and dry, white spices. Lighter-bodied with tight, sharper carbonation on the palate.. dried out nicely, and the balance somehow came together. Decent brew.

column1: Big River Grille Wowzers Summer Wheat
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Pint on tap. Cloudy pear color, with a small lasting film of bubbles. Aromas of clove, banana, lemon zest, and bread.Taste is the same with a bit less acidic lemon, and a hint of bubblegum. Near-medium body is balanced and has medium carbonation.

column1: Big River Grille Wowzers Summer Wheat
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Clear yellow with a fizzy white head. Bready aroma and a banana bread and clove taste.

column1: Big River Grille Wowzers Summer Wheat
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Had at Disney brewpub .. light whiffs of banana and light clove and some fresh barley .. . great headring .. . light and refreshing and leaves a nice aftertaste .. . pretty good stuff . . pluto!

column1: Big River Grille Wowzers Summer Wheat
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap at the brewery in Nashville. Pours a turbid pils color. Banana/wheat aroma. Taste like an American Hefe - banana/clove/wheat. Light and refreshing, well-crafted.

column1: Big River Grille Wowzers Summer Wheat
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Light clear yellow with a lasting white foam. Aroma is bitter orange, light coriander. Taste is big coriander, orange, light lemon.

column1: Big River Grille Wowzers Summer Wheat
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Cloudy yellow, dense, smooth head. Smells crisp and clean, like a sea breeze (not like Sea Breeze, the facial cleaner). Smooth notes of banana and some hints of a hoppy bate. Goes well with fish tacos.

column1: Big River Grille Wowzers Summer Wheat
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Thin wheat ale. Pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma of wheat and lemongrass. Taste is crisp enough but has no real body.

column1: Big River Grille Imperial 375 Pale Ale
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: 2 Pints on tap. Hazy orange-copper with a half inch of foam. Mild aroma of caramel, citrus and toast. Tastes of pecan, toffee, toasted wheat bread, with a delicate finish of pine resin, citrus and cocoa. Light-medium body is well balanced and has a smooth medium carbonation.

column1: Big River Grille Imperial 375 Pale Ale
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: had this a while a go in Chattanooga. My least favorite of the beers I had that night. aroma some malt, hops, grassy . flavor same as the aroma. nothing special here

column1: Big River Grille Imperial 375 Pale Ale
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Clear golden with a fizzy white head. Grain and citrus aroma and taste with a malty finish.

column1: Big River Grille Imperial 375 Pale Ale
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: 3 oz Sample at the brew works downtown. For an Imperial pale Ale this drops offs way short. 5.5 ABV? Does that even count as an Impeiral? Not in my book. But here it goes. Very dry light golden pour. Almost sour wheaty with a strong barley palet. I can pass on this one also. Big river has yet to impress.

column1: Big River Grille Imperial 375 Pale Ale
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Thin white head, pale golden body. Aroma is pale malt sweetness and little else. Taste is grassy, caramel, strange.

column1: Big River Grille Imperial 375 Pale Ale
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Cloudy orange, foamy, dense head. Cirtusy, grapefruit-like aroma. Very crisp palate at first, then some piney, resiny notes. Crisp finish. Nice session beer.

column1: Big River Grille Imperial 375 Pale Ale
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Malty with a caramel flavor and not much hops to speak about. Light orange color, seems english style and in my opinion it could definitely stand to have the hops kicked up about four notches. Not a bad beer just needs some hops dammit. I’m not sure why they call it imperial as it is nothing of the sort. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 02-13-2009 22:55:46

column1: Big River Grille Imperial 375 Pale Ale
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: on tap-pours a dissipating off white head and copper color. Aroma is mild grain, some herbal hops. Taste is grain/medium malt-caramel, secondary spice hops. Borders on a Vienna Lager with some Tettnang/Hallertau. OK now I had the Vienna Lager which has a bit more malt and a bit less hops.

column1: Big River Grille Imperial 375 Pale Ale
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draft at Downtown Chattanooga location The winner of the 8 different ones I had, this was the one I could have drank all day. Nice citrus aroma, and the flavor was almost perfectly balanced between a great malt character and a crisp hoppiness. Nothing ground breaking but this particular pint was nice.

column1: Big River Grille Imperial 375 Pale Ale
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap at Hamilton Place. The body was deep gold with an off white head. The aroma was earthy and light with some grapefruit. There was also some fresh cut wood. The taste was grapefruit with some bread crust. Decent.

column1: Big River Grille House Brand IPA
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Pours clear amber with a lingering off white head. Nose is a nice blend of piney hops and sweet malts with a little apple. Flavor is fresh and well balanced. A nice, easy drinking IPA.

column1: Big River Grille House Brand IPA
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap at Big River at Disney’s Boardwalk. Clear amber color with an average off-white head. Aroma is of perfume, floral, herbal, and pine. Taste is of herbal, piney hops, grass, and caramel.

column1: Big River Grille House Brand IPA
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap at BRG in Chattanooga while #1 Clemson is beating SC. Appearance: amber colored body with good clarity. Very durable off-white head leaves plenty of sticky lacing. Floral and herbal aroma with citrus notes and ample strength for style. Flavor: moderately bitter at first, but high bitterness by mid-taste; some hints of baked bread but mainly hops and more hops. Medium body is smooth; near medium carbonation. O: solid but too much dominance by bitter grapefruit.

column1: Big River Grille House Brand IPA
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: 12 ounce can poured into a brandy snifter. The beer is a moderately hazy copper color with a white head of foam. The aroma has strong pine resin and some cardboard. Kind of smells like an old beer. The date on the bottom of the can is unreadable unfortunately. The taste is strongly bitter without much to balance it out. There is a moderately sugary nuance to the beer as well, but it is very mich overshadowed by the bitterness. Medium body and lower to medium carbonation.

column1: Big River Grille House Brand IPA
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Can poured a clear golden amber with a small lasting white head. Aromas of biscuit, grapefruit zest and light pine. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of bread, grapefruit zest and light earthiness with a crisp dry lingering bitter finish.

column1: Big River Grille House Brand IPA
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draft at the source, with injured typing finger. Clear golden yellow color. Aroma of light lemon. Taste is watery lemon.

column1: Big River Grille House Brand IPA
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draft. Copper with large white head and nice lacing. Nice aroma of citrus hops. Medium body with citrus hop bitterness upfront and a nice malt body.

column1: Big River Grille House Brand IPA
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap at Big River Grille downtown. This rivals any American-style IPA I’ve tried. Solid malt background, but Cascade hops are at the forefront of this beer.

column1: Big River Grille House Brand IPA
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: On tap near brewery. Aroma is American hops with a decent amount of caramel malt. Nicely dry-hopped aroma remains throughout the drink and keeps enticing me back to the glass. I don’t know that I would call it aggressive, but it is certainly representative of standard American IPA and is of good quality.

column1: Big River Grille House Brand IPA
column4: Big River Grille & Brewing Works Chattanooga (Craftworks)
column5: Draft. Poured deep gold with with a medium-sized off-white head. Aroma and flavor of spicy, resinous, earthy hops and bready malt, caramel. Medium body. Solid IPA.
Draught at Keyaki. Mild wheat character, floral notes, lemon, bit of spice, earthy finish. Not too bad, fairly light and basic.
Tap. Soft egg/wheat nose. Not too expressive, but opens up a little with some aggravation. Wheat, faint spice, orange. Solid if uninspired.
Bottle from the brewery. Hazy golden, white head. Lemony aroma with coriander. Solid lemons flavours, coriander kept in the background. A bit too acidic and simple, but refreshing enough.

Biggish white head. Pale hazy yellow opaque body. Light flour and coriander aroma, a bit like soap, with citric notes. Sweet spicy coriander and fruit aroma with dry, citric flour aftertaste. A very nice wit. (0.3l on tap.)

Well balanced, extremely easy to drink Wit, with oranges and some soapiness. Really refreshing, well made. Perhaps easiest beer to drink I ever had, and I mean that with all respect. A definetely step above.
A nice Witbier. Bubblegum-ish, banana-ish. Cloudy. Quite tasty..............
Had this at the brewery with the brewer last fall then had a Fred Flintstone sized pork chop a cool place even know out of the way in Japan we worth the visit.
Bottle at Grand Tasting RBJG#2. Dark brown with a beige head. Sweet with aromas of of smoked malts and some caramel. Also hints of licoroce. Medium to light bodied Medium carbonation.
Bottle at RBJG#2 - Grand Tasting Ueno Park. Clear brown - offwhite head. Sweetness, nice smokey, amber malts, roasted, nutty, bitterness, wood smokey. Nice.

My Bottom Line: Beechwood smoke and mild hoppiness define this simple but pleasant Rauchbier. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam tops the cloudy pale brown. -There are no ‘ale’ qualities in this one ; I’m happily surprised. -Malt flavors are well polished. -This is not an over-the-top Rauchbier à la Schlenkerla. It’s more of a quencher like Spezial, Hönig or Fischer, to give you an idea. Bottle.
Lightly smoked, a tad more peaty than anything. Smooth but slightly undercarbed body. Pleasant.
RBJG2. Amber brown colour, golden head. Aroma is lightly smokey meat, citrus. Taste is again light smoke, hoppy, malty. Interesting. Would like to try it again.

Bottle at the RBJG 2 Grand Tasting, thanks TimE. Dark brown colour with an off-white head. Chocolate, smoke, wood aroma. Smokey burned flavour with some chocolate. Well rounded and not extremely smokey.
tons of aged smoked Gouda. Moderately smokey mouth. Lightly smoked mouth. Lingering Gouda finish. Pleasent
Bottle at RBJG2. Murky brown color, fluffy beige head. Aroma of chocolate biscuit. Taste is burnt toast.

Bottled. Nice smoky nose, katusbushi, chocolate. Cloudy brown with lace. Nose is a bit faint but nice. Nice smoky, lager-like flavor. Simple but tasty with chocolate and smoke. Very drinkable, Bambergian. Good level of intensity.

“Wittmann Premium Extra Pils“, vom Faß im Weißen Bräuhaus zum Krenkl, Landshut. - Hellgelb, blank. - In der Nase feines helles Malz mit milder Süße. - Antrunk schlank und recht farblos zitrusfruchtig hopfenherb. Durchschnittlich rezent. Im Abgang trockene, kräftige Bittere. - Für ein bayerisches Pilsner untypisch schlank und ordentlich bitter aber aromatisch schmalspurig. Tut was es soll aber kein Deut mehr.
Clear golden. Aroma is lime grape pips a bit pepper. Taste is sour and a bit bitter hop. Clean and prototypical for a german pils.

Tap. Clear pale golden color with white head. Aroma is pale malts, grassy, biscuity. Taste is crackery malts, grassy, biscuity. Grassy bitter finish. Oily mouthfeel with medium carbonation. On point German Pils, though this also makes it kinda boring.
Fruchtiges Aroma, eine gewisse Bittere, helle gold-gelbe Farbe, ordentliches Pils

(bottle) clear pale golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of skunky bittering hops and marzipan, with some notes of straw, dried apricots, sugar icing and grainy pale malts. flavour is more dried fruit and some raisins, slightly sweet, with hints of fresh wort and a light-bitter finish. light- to medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Goldgelbes Bier mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch hopig, blumig, leicht fruchtig. Geschmack fruchtig, grasig, malzig, blumig.
0,33 l bottle BB19. Jun 14 light golden, clear, frothy, white foam, lots of cereal, herbs, basement aromas, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation,
Pours clear golden with a small creamy white head. Flavour is malt, bread and bitter.

It’s hazy golden with a creamy, white head. The aroma has notes of straw, malt, flower and fruit. The flavor is slightly sweet with the same notes as the aroma, and the finish is dry and slightly bitter.

Bottle 330ml. @ home. [ Trade by Maria ]. Clear medium yellow colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, pale malt, moderate hoppy, grass, fresh grass, vegetable and cardboard notes, cardboard - limestone - chalk notes. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, cabbage water, malty, sharp hops. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120209]

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Dieses Bier habe ich vor einigen Jahren bereits getrunken, aber jetzt muss ich zugeben, dass es doch weitaus besser ist, als ich es damals empfand. Es ist ein schön süffiges Bier mit schön fruchtigen Noten nach Banane, Mango und co. Dazu noch bio - ein schönes Bierchen.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Flasche 0,5l: Helles Bernstein, ocker, kräftige Trübung, stabiler feinporiger Schaum; frische + leicht fruchtige Nase, leichte fruchtige Säure, leichte Hopfennoten, sehr kräftige trockene Hefearomen, Malz, Getreide, Karamell, nur leicht bananig, etwas Schokolade; frischer + leicht fruchtiger Körper, malzig-fruchtige Süße, leichte Hopfennoten, sehr kräftige Hefearomen, Malz, Getreide, Karamell, cremig, kräftige Kohlensäure, dezente trockene Zitrusnoten; angenehmer malzig-fruchtiger Nachgang

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottle, ty marduk. Pours hazy golden. Aroma and flavor are sweet, candy, wheat, fruits, banana. Overall: ok.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: 500ml bottle (thanks Viil). Cloudy dark orange color. Medium size, white head, stays. Banana, sweet, caramel, lemon candy, hops in aroma/taste. Drinkable brew.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Opaque yellow-golden with a decent white head. Aroma is grass, hay, distant Taste is a little grassy, a little grain, a little fruit, but overall not very intense. Drinkable.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottle from BioCompany - hazy, dark golden color, (unusual) small white head. string banana notes, high unpleasant carbonation, ome metallic notes. rather watery body. nice aroma, but overall too weak.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottle from Edeka in Rothenburg. Pours hazy yellow with a lasting, thin, foamy, white head; little lacing. Aroma of ripe banana, apple peel, wheat, clove, honey, white bread, kitchen herbs. Taste is medium fruity sweet, very ripe banana mixed with apple cake & some honey; light spicy bitterness brings clove & white pepper, sourish wheat & vague lemon peel bring balance, all supported by a quite 'white' bready & yeasty malty base. Dryish, bit grassy hoppy finish, lingering wheat & ripe banana, rather malty sweet. Medium body, fluffy/oily texture, soft to flat carbonation. Drinkable stuff, if not very impressive.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Top notch German wheat beer, hits all the desired flavours, right on style. Denn’s Dresden

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: 0,5l bottle Nürberg- hazy goldish with a small white head - aromas are intense banana vanilla ? hopfs Fruits ! - Taste is sweet with a bitter end , funny carbonation bananas and hopfs ...one of the most aromatic Weiss I’ve tasted so far!

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Strohgelb, mäßig trüb mit viel schneeweißem Schaum. Herb-würziger, getreidiger und verhalten fruchtiger Geruch. Spritziger Antrunk dank lebendiger Kohlensäure und dezenter Säure. Viel kerniges Malz ohne aufdringliche Süße. Zitrusfrüchte. Schlanker Körper, latent wässrig. Wunderbare, für ein Weißbier außergewöhnliche Hopfennote. Nicht besonders komplex, besser: schnörkellos. Enorm süffig.

Sampled draught at Thembi, Maastricht Mustard yellow, really hazy with brief creamy head. A nose full of vanilla and vinegar. Lightly acidic, well rounded, clean and malty with balsamic finish. Like a strong, blonde Flemish red ale. Tasty and refreshing, but perhaps not very complex.
From tap. Milky flavor with grapefruit and hops. Refreshing and clean palate.
Plain clear golden with a white head. Grainy, sweet lemonfresh aroma. High carbonation and sharp bitterness, with flavours of vegetable. Rotten finish.
Can. Pale golden colour with a white head. Corny aroma and a corny, hay taste. Light body with a dry finish.
Pale golden colour with a white head. Malty and sweet aroma with light note of hay. Malty, quite bland flavor with a vague sweetness.
Can, thanks to Thomas for sharing this gem. Clear yellow coloured with a fast disappearing white head. Aroma of corn and fruits. Flavour of corn, fruits and hops.
(Bottle 33 cl) Golden beer with a decent head. Lovely hoppy nose, soft with sweet malt and not much bitterness. 160800
Canned. Yellow/golden colour, not much head. Weak malty aroma. Malty flavour with dry finish. Mouthdrying. A bit metallic hints also.
Can 500ml (BB 06/2005) Golden color, small white head. Malty, rye-bread aroma, some sweetness too. Medium-bodied, sweet malty with harsh finish. Uninteresting beer with a rough palate.
Canned. Pale golden. Ozon aroma. A bit sourish flavour with non-existing malt tendencies. Clear abv presence. Kind of unpleasant all in all. But then, it’s EURO 2004.

This was my very special favourite when I was younger. Me and my friends drank this every time at the club. We only had to hold two fingers in the air, and the waitress knew we wanted two Guldöl. But I realize now that there are better beers. Many better... Pours pale golden with not much of a head. Rather carbonated. Aroma is grassy, flavor is not much at all. Actually not as thin as I feared, but a very boring beer.
Pale golden. Corn aroma. Thin. Low bitterness. Yawn.........................

This was a special gift from Josh. The can was leaking, gas was out but I was brave enough to sip glass or two. Sweet corn aroma, light yellowish, almost no head. Tasted like stale grape juice .The qualities that it represents do not even compare to the nastiest American standards products.

So I walk in the front door and there's a cooler filled with sixpacks, the brewery hidden in the back and the guy's living room off to the left. I ask what kind of beer he's got, and at least he's honest about it being mainstream lager, unlike many local "microbreweries". It's pale yellow with large bubbles but no head - there's a reason for this which I'll get to in a moment - the aroma of a mix of corn on the cob, herbaceous hops and fusels (I don't think this is high-gravity brewed, so that's a bit odd, really). Light, quick palate, heavy on the corn and cider notes. It's available in cans, which is crazy for such a small brewery. But DO NOT lay them on their side, because they leak (guess who's getting the half-empty can to taste, Paul?)

column4: Beijing Five Star Tsingtao Brewing Co.
column5: very nondescript, clear light yellow and very effervescent, almost tasteless. at least you know it will not give you the green apple two-step.

column4: Beijing Five Star Tsingtao Brewing Co.
column5: Interesting, being from China, but a poor substitute for a real beer. I honestly only tried it because it was cheap and contained alcohol, and it served only a very basic purpose. Kind of a strangely sweet, fruity flavor. Not at all hoppy and not something I particularly cared for. But hey, did I mention it was on sale?

column4: Beijing Five Star Tsingtao Brewing Co.
column5: Hell yeah, brother. "China''s State Banquet Beer". What exactly is a banquet beer? I expected a lite beer flavor, which is a contradiction of terms, but this was pretty tasteful, maybe not really tasty, but it did have flavor. It''s reminiscent of a pilsener, with a decidedly german flavor. I''d bet they used Saaz hops. The beer is a beautiful bright gold color. I was expecting absolutely nothing, and I guess i was pleasantly surprised. Drink out of a pilsen or hefe glass.

column4: Beijing Five Star Tsingtao Brewing Co.
column5: The label says that this is "China's State Banquet Beer" - oh I feel so sorry for them! This stuff is thin, watery, weak, full of sugary fakeness, lacking hops, no head, no lace, and for an extra kick of krappy-ness, it's packaged in a green bottle! It gets a "3" for impression only because I will never forget it!

column1: Rock Bottom Cleveland Dawg Pound Brown
column5: Draft sample at Cleveland brewpub. Poured clear brown color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate toasted nutty malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium roasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met with another solid drinkable beer.

column1: Rock Bottom Cleveland Dawg Pound Brown
column5: Dark brown, small white head. Aroma is coffee. Flavor is subtle coffee followed by chocolate and crystal malts and an almost nutty roasty taste. This was bigger than most brown ales and was pretty good.

column1: Rock Bottom Cleveland Dawg Pound Brown
column5: Nearly opaque dark coffee brown. Milde chocolate cakey aroma. SOme green nut tones on a cocoa spine. Some off flavors at times. Medium light nutty sweetness. Some floral tones in the aftertaste. Finishes off chalky and roasty.

column1: Rock Bottom Cleveland Dawg Pound Brown
column5: (Cleveland) Cola black body topped by a tan head. Aroma is medium sweet, chocolate, some nut. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, chocolate, some nut. Soft medium body.

column1: Rock Bottom Cleveland Dawg Pound Brown
column5: On tap in Cleveland - Poured very dark brown with a mocha head. Aroma is of roasted malts, nuts, caramel, and some coffee. I was impressed with the appearance of this. Looked almost porterlike. Flavor was malty, roasted malts, coffee, nuts, caramel. Palate was a little thin but quite smooth. For a brown I have to say this wasn’t bad. Just not real exciting.

column1: Rock Bottom Cleveland Dawg Pound Brown
column5: Had this at the brewpub while visiting Cleveland last weekend for the Disturbed concert. Light and floral nose, hard to pick up much in a smokey bar. The brew is a dark brown with a creamy brown head that doesn't stick around long. The flavor is bland and mild, the finish is long and slightly bitter. The medium to full body is fizzy and dry. Not much exciting happening here.

column1: Rock Bottom Cleveland Dawg Pound Brown
column5: Named after the Cleveland Browns famous fans (obviously), this nutbrown has a nice nutty sweetness to it that is almost ruined by the watery, thin texture. Now, I'm not expecting motor oil thickness, but this really needed some body to back up the flavors. Tasty, but could ues much improvement.

Draft sample at Cleveland brewpub. Poured clear ruby color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate toasted malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met with a good beer.

Cleveland, Oh. - on tap at the brewpub. Dark copper pour, fluffy white head. Neutral aroma - some fresh lake water notes. Good caramel notes, some nuttiness. Smooth, clean finish. Solid brewpub amber. Part of a sampler.
Couldn’t smell it. Buffered cocoa overa a watery backbone. Medium mahogany. Medium body. Trailing roast bitterness. Grew on me a little.

(Cleveland) Crystal clear copper body with beige head. Aroma is moderately sweet, chocolate/caramel, butterscotch. Taste is sweet, caramel/butterscotch, some chocolate, light earthy. Soft, light-medium body. Much more malty than an American amber.

On tap in Cleveland - Pours deep copper with a short fluffy offwhite head. Aromas of Caramel and roasted malts as well as some floral hops. Flavor is quite malty and sweet. Notes of caramel, brown sugar, and a little fruit. Nice hoppy finish. Palate is medium bodied and very drinkable. A pretty nice amber and one of the better brews there.

Very dark red body with a whispy off-white head. Malty aromas with notes of chocolate and sweet bread. Rich flavors and velvet-soft carbonation. Lots of chewy malts with a chocolate touch and some noble tasting hops. Very nice.
