Very deep red. Medium thick malts, nice fruity hops. This is one of the more memorable brews from this restaurant and one of the better Ambers that I've had.
500ml bottle in 2016. Clear mid golden with a thin white head. Aroma of lager malt, lemongrass and perfumed hops. Fairly standard pale lager flavour. Decent and quite drinkable.
bottle, Markgrafen-Getränke Bischberg. Golden yellow, tall white head. Grainy nose. Grainy malty start, shy but decent hops with a resiny touch. Also a slightly "burnt" flavour.
One of the better festbiers going here. Malty aroma on a white head and a tan body. Full flavour malty with a hop skin. Makes you want to sing.
From old tasting notes. Bright honey gold color. Fluffy white head. Faint malt aroma. Sweetish malt flavor lacks complexity. Brief malty finish is subtle and plain.

Bottle. Amber coloured beer with a good frothy head. The aroma is gently roasted, mildly malty and vinous, with yeastiness. The flavour is rich with maltiness, and gentle roastedness, and yeastiness. Overall a nice gently malty beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle (BB 19th Jul 17), from Beers of Europe and shared with my son on 11th Dec 16. Golden yellow pour, snow white head, that did not last long. Hops just about outplay the light malt content in both the aroma and flavour stakes, decent enough blend with a hay/grassy nature to the whole brew, even though it has a semi-sweetness throughout before the hops produce a slightly bitter and dry finish to each sip or gulp.

Pour golden color that starts with a nice and fluffy white head and last for awhile. Aroma is malty with hints of hops. Flavor is between sweet and bitter, but the sweetness comes up stronger. Medium carbonation and light to medium body with a sweet bitter finish.

Bottle from Getränke Kistner in Forchheim. The beer pours out in a light hazy golden-amber colour with airy head and medium body. Aroma of hops and straw. Taste of hops, straw, wheat, bread, milk and nuts. Fruity finish. Drinkable, yet nothing special.

In der Nase tut sich nicht wirklich nicht viel ausser etwas Getreide. Geschmacklich eher duenn und kaum dem eines Festbieres angemessen.Laff auf der Zunge, ein wenig Roggen, in Festlaune werde ich so sicher nicht kommen.
Bottle on the what the hell was I think ingredients tour of Bavaria. Clear deep gold lasting white head. Cereal aroma. Decent beer. Some malt some alcohol. Ok. D

33cl bottle (6,3%) from Carrefour Market (Chaussée de Boondael) in Brussels. F: huge, tanned, very long lasting. C: dark, opaque. A: malty, caramel, chocolate, dried fruits, bit toffee, coffee, bit spicy. T: medium malty base, bit coffee, dark chocolate, dark caramel, dry on the palate, bit dried fruity, spicy, medium carbonation, ok for the style.
33cl bottle. A dark brown beer with a beige head. Aroma of nuts, caramel, red fruits and raisins. Taste of raisins, caramel, riped fruits, prunes, some yeast.

Bottle from a Carrefour in Ghent. Pours hazy dark brown with a huge, slowly collapsing, frothy, beige head; some lacing. Aroma of coriander, clove, white pepper, licorice, brown bread, toast, caramel, molasses, ripe pear. Taste is medium malty sweet, caramel, molasses & licorice with a fruity hint of ripe pear; light spicy bitter middle has coriander & clove, rendering it a bit soapy, faint toast & coffee in the back, faintly berry-like sour too. Dryish, earthy hoppy finish, bit phenolic, lingering toast, dark fruit & caramel, Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation. Perhaps just too profuse with spices, but all in all agreeable.
Robijnrood tot donkerbruin bier met schuim. Smaak is licht bitter met iets van karamel en rook. Al met al een waterig en licht bier, niet echt bijzonder.

Bottle. Dark brown with a huge wgite/beige head. Aroma of malts, yeast and sugar. Taste is malts, yeast, caramel, raisins and a certain kind of fruitiness (cherries perhaps). Slightly acidic and low level of hops. Low to medium carbonation. Thin and watery mouthfeel. Not the best Dubbel I ever had.

33cl Bottle @ Beer Mania, Brussels, Belgium. Brown colour with a medium size white head. Aroma is yeast, malt, fruits. Taste is yeast, malt, sweet, fruits, nuts, slightly spicy. Medium body, average carbonation.
brown colour, huge, dense beige head; aroma and taste of raisins, dried cherry, toasted rye bread, dark chocolate and some plum jam notes; correct ale...isn't it a dubbel rather than a Belgian ale?

Robe brune, mousse beige moyenne. Nez de pain grillé, café, caramel, toffee. Bouche sur les mêmes saveurs, légères notes de houblons frais. Carbo moyenne, corps moyen, finale sucrée, amertume légère en attaque, mais peu de longueur.

Bottle 33. Brune foncée à mousse beige persistante. Nez sur la levure, l'acidité, l'aigre, la framboise. Bouche douce en entrée, un peu d'acidité, un peu fruitée, peu de corps, peu d'amertume mais plaisante par le fruit.
Bottle. Very dark chocolate brown, offwhite lace. Spicy mole, roast, clay, fruit zest finish. Light body, dry, clay, chocolate, not exiting but ok.
Gold appearance with a slightly clingy sweetness that comes close to but isn't sickly. Not one I would try again but certainly not one to avoid.
This is a great light beer and I can't wait to have another! This a very smooth and pleasently tasting beer.
Too light for me. Bitter water and thats all. ..............................

Long Trail brews this beer for Lui Lui restaurants, which is where I was last night and thought I’d give it a try. Tastes a lot like a typical Long Trail Ale, or maybe closer to their IPA. Pretty good. A dark copper color, pouring a moderate off white head and a pretty good amount of lacing on the glass. Aroma is slightly sweet and hoppy but not overpowering. It’s a good tasting beer but not at all a strong IPA. A strong Pale Ale or a weak IPA if that makes sense. Hoppy and sweet, slightly bitter and pretty smooth. Easy to drink. I’d get it again.

This is does not look like a regular IPA as it has a dark bronze color. It tastes typical with a strong hops flavor. Overall it was an average IPA with a different look. I wish they had it in draft. I figured they would seeing as it is their brand on it...
light golden with a small white head,large loose bubbles that quickly disapate. Sweet malt aroma with a licorice flavor. I did not enjoy this one bit.

Bottle, cloudy light orange with a thin large bubbled white head. Corn-like aroma, with some sweetness. Dry ending. Watery weak mouthfeel. The best part about this beer was when I finished it and didn’t have to drink it anymore.

Good straw color,small foamy white head that managed to stay around for awhile.The aroma was malty and fairly fruity berryish but hard to describe exactly what berry it could be,I guess blueberry is what i'm coming up with.The taste was very diffrent,yah there was a fruit presence But again what kind is hard to put a finger on,it also is coming off as sort of tangy or sourish.Light malt flavor with an after taste that is fruity and very faint hops.It's a fairly smooth and watery brew with a unique flavor but over all nothing special.I wouldn't get in a twist trying to find this brew other then for a one time trial.

Floral, chemical prune aroma, like something rotting in a field of flowers. Standard gold with pithy white head. Lousy label, looks like 70's Celtics socks. Vegetable brothy, somewhat metallic, lightly sweet and tart. Badly hopped. If it were February, and I was stranded in Siberia, and I was out of vodka, I might buy another.
This had quite a hoppy flavor. I'm not accustomed to foreign beers that are this hoppy. Not great, but maybe worth a try.

Upon opening, has a wet paper bag aroma - not pleasant. Soapy, white head with clingy lacing. Very light golden in appearance - almost see though. Alcohol is the the prominent flavor. A cloyingly sweet boiled corn flavor is also prominent. This beer is not.....good. Difficult to finish the whole 500 ml - reminds me of a low-alcohol malt liquor.

Thin head which does not last long. Dissipates into a chunky unappealing foam. Smells like buttery mashed potatoes to me. Who knows. Color is yellow/gold with very little carbonation. Flavor is a little weak and watery with some malt. Finish is a little sour but goes down easy. Not a very good pilsner.

I actualy think this is pretty good. Murky color, medium sized head initally but fades to chunky white lumps. Aroma is somewhat spicey and medicinal. Rarher low carbonation, smooth tastes that is hard to nail down. You could drink a lot of this at a social event as it is refreshing and clean.

You pour yourself a tall pint of mild lager but you carry it into the bathroom cuz you''ve gotta take a leak. Leaving it near the medicine cabinet, you relieve yourself. Suddenly the medicine cabinet comes unhinged, causing lozenges, medicinal herbs, bitter homeopathic roots and assorted cough suppressant tablets to land squarely in your pint. After they dissolve you take a sip of your newly-created Frankenstein brew (thanks to MartinT for the inspiration for this rating).

Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy medium yellow, dense tiny particles, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (grain), lightly hoppy (herbs), with a note of solvent. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately bitter, moderately acidic. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Dull yeasty sourness with an industrial grainy and medicinal aroma.
Cloudy. Sweet fruity, floral nose. Flavor has plenty of hops, some orangey sweetness and a fine balancing malt. I was pretty impressed with the beers here after reading bad comments at pubcrawler.

This beer was bad. It was heavily oxidized. I could hardly finish my glass without wretching. It appeared okay with a hazy light amber body and a nice creamy looking head. I guess I should have sampled this before I bought a growler of it. Harsh cardboard taste dominated this beer's flavor. It was truly a disturbing experience. There were some hops in the background but they didn't do a thing for flavor. This was wretched.

Fruity malt and roastiness very well defined in both flavor and aroma. Nice chocolaty coffee nuances and a well rounded hop citric bitterness make this a first rate stout. Slight sourness just spoils a little in the aftertaste, but doesn''t take away the enjoyment.

Black body with a nice off-white head atop it. Toasted coffee notes in the nose. Chocolate and cocoa on the tongue with a bitterness that is noticable on the sides of the tongue. Some bittersweetness toward the back of the tongue that leaves a bit of dryness. Tasty brew.

What the fuck is this shit and how is it from gilroy when my can says monroe, WI. Tastes horrible, one of the worst, most flat, most skunked flavors ever. And it doesn't even have the wide mouth on the can. Brutal at best.
Straw color, heavy haze. Clean bubble gum malt aroma, faint herb spice. Fizzy palate, sweet, sourness in latter half, grainy dry finish. Bud or Corona alternative.
Picked up a can at Family Mart in Naha. Golden ale color with white head and a bit of lacing. Smooth mouth feel with nice tones of malt and just a touch of hops.
Pale yellow. White head. Slightly malty aroma. Initial taste is sweetish with a bitter modestly hoppy aftertaste From can so highly carbonated. It’s an average beer

350ml can consumed@Beijing China 2018.12.11 canned@2018.08.10 外观 金黄色透明清亮酒身 一指半白色颗粒泡面表面绵密 持续时间中等 香气 淡淡的麦芽香气 和一些saaz酒花的香气 味道 依旧是简单的麦芽的甜和saaz酒花的花香 回味 初期是淡淡的甜在口中 之后浮现出轻微的苦干和极其薄的涩感 尾端又冒出轻微的麦芽的甜 口感 酒体略轻薄 纱口感略弱 酒精感wu

2018, drunk from can. Coarse carb and bitter front before biscuit malt sweetness kicks in. Adjunct grain flavour and feel unbalance what could’ve been a nice malty brew. In the end it’s a fizzy ricey miss that sits somewhere in the middle of macro output.

7-11 Wuxing junction. Light orange in colour. Foamy head that leaves fairly quick. Nose is very feint sweet malt. Perhaps I drank this one too cold but the flavour was cleaner and not as cloying as other efforts. That said often in these seasonals if you leave them the flavour opens up. This one was sharper and cleaner and more like a standard lager. Light grain and corn malt. Dry finish. I like it as a standard lager but don't get why it's an Autumn brew. More like they had a stab at a new beer and thought.....'heck we'll keep that recipe for the future'. Overall clean and refreshing but not a 'speciality' beer.

I drink this every year because I love the can design and I can’t resist. It’s a Japanese macro lager and goes well with food, even fish. A little on the heavy side and if drunk quickly retains a thin head near the finish. Session beer for me, not a sipper and that’s the way I likes this one.

Can bought at Family Mart in Suzhou, CN. Nose has nicely fruity hop notes, even some mild mango or passionfruit - something similar to what i pick up from sorachi ace, but really muted. Flavor is good, but a little less exciting than the nose - some light barley and adjunct (mildly sweet flaked corn). Finish is very good with a good punch of fruity hop resin bitterness that lingers for a few minutes on the palate. Good use of hops elevates an otherwise mundane strong lager.
light aroma, gold pour. light flavor with a hint of citrus. good session beer.

Aroma: 4 skunky ordinary Appearance: 3 good for a pale lager. Not creamy enough Taste: 6 metallic, somehwhat bitter, malty sweetness, flat, not complex Palate: 3 watery Overall: 11 There’s no limit to how beautiful these cans can be. The photo here does no justice to this fabulous presentation. I wish they could be as dedicated to making better beer.
Aroma: malt. Golden with little white head. Flavor of hops and bread. Light body. Dry finish.

Bought it at seven eleven in Taiwan as the end of summer harks the start of seasonal beer. Pours a dark golden orange with a nice head which settles after a few seconds. Nose is sweet with traces of sacharin and boiled candy. It has a fairly strong taste compared to most Suntory and is more apparent the warmer the lager. Given this is an Autumn beer maybe it isnt meant to be drunk ice cold as it changed during my tasting. On first drinking it was mild with a slightly malty edge. There is less carbonation in these autumn brews I think. As the beer grew warmer the malt became more obvious. Finish is light and quick. This beer is 6% yet doesn’t taste overly strong. A nice change from the usual Japanese beer and a success for Suntory in my eyes who often fall behing Asahi and Kirin in the regard to the best beers of Japan.

Pours a clear golden orange. Nose is slightly spicy with hints of candi sugar. Taste is off putting, sweet candi sugar, anise, stale caramel body. I’d drink it only if i had aids and it was the only known cure.

Clear Golden with a medium White head. Corn starch scented. An adjunct flavored treat with some malty sweetness in the middle. At least the 6.5 ABV gives it some character to stand it apart from the dozens of other macros on the shelf.
Can. One of my first beers upon arriving in Kyoto, Japan. A pale yellow with a white head. Crisp and full body with high carbonation and slightly tangy.
Can from Yamaya. Cloudy light gold, big frothy head. Aroma has wheat and corriander with some orange peel. Smooth, almost creamy. The citrus does enough so the corriander isn’t to dominant.

Bottle... Poured cloudy yellow with a thin head. Aroma was citrusy and yeasty with some spices and ginger. Lots of carbonation with sweet spices and baked fruit notes, coriander, and roasted yeast-like flavors.
Tasted @ GJBF Yokohama: Cloudy, nice head and lacing. Nose of light sweet spicy yeast, lots of coriander, light orange, a bit wheaty and some yeast in the tail. Good finish.
Fancy can. Hazy yellow coloured. Wheaty aroma and flavour with rubber notes. Very light and quite bland.
Hazy light golden appearance. Creamy white foam. Lemony and wheaty aroma. Quite thin flavour of sticky wheat malts. Short aftertaste.

Canned, thanks IslandHaole! Hazy yellow, small head. Banana aroma. Esters and sweetness aretoned down. The mouthfeel is soft, and it’s solidly malty. Well made and fairly refreshing authentic hefeweizen.
Has orange peel, smoke and cloves in the nose. Nice light body, slightly sour and yeasty and then a refreshing orange peel finish. Still too watery for me.

12 ounce can. Thanks to IslandHaole for this one. Hazy straw pour with big, white head. Aroma of hopcit, lemongrass, banana, cloves. Tastes hopcity, with a smoothness at the finish and notable complexity. Nice.

Thanks to IslandHaole for the brew! Hazy light gold pour, small head. Light yeasty aroma, light hops. Good light clean flavor, some wheat, yeasty and light fruity tones, light hop bite. Best canned beer I’ve had yet!

A slightly hazy medium gold color with a big foamy head. As Mark says, "another great brew from Ginga Kogen". These folks are right on target, one of the best Japanese breweries! A very nice Weiss. No adjuncts, remarkable for a Japanese beer!
Sample tray. Tasting notes provided by brewery call it Cascade Irish Style Stout. 4.5%. Black. Nice roast. Lighter soft body.

On tap at Raccoon Lodge Portland, Pours out a dark brown almost black topped with a tall cream brown head. Aroma was pretty good a nice roast coffee along with some dark chocolate. Taste was lots of rich and dark roast malts along with the chocolate.

Tap @ Raccoon Lodge: Dark brown, near black pour with a finger of creamy brown head. Aroma is plentiful in roast with some coffee and light cocoa. Flavor retains the heavy roast presence, but adds more chocolate and less coffee. It gets a bit dry in the tail and has a tiny bit of bittersweet amongst the heavy roasty notes.

Draft at Raccoon Lodge. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty coffee and chocolate aroma. Roasted malty chocolate and coffee flavor with a sslightly thin mouthfeel. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish.
On tap at the bewpub. Pours opaque black with a creamy tan head. Medium body, minimal carbonation. Coffee and chocolate nose. Lightly sweet taste of chocolate, nuts, oatmeal. Soft finish.

On tap as "Colosseum Stout" @ Pizza Roma in Portland. Poured deep, dark brown-black, and viscous. Not much of a head after it settles. Chocolaty, with faint toffee and coffee notes. Low carbonation, bitter, and sweet. Very delectable.

draft @ brewpub - dark brown with tan head that collapsed in the middle; strong chocolate aromas mixed slightly with hops; the hops are noticeable in the flavors too as the finish becomes chocolaty; a little thin, but rich and smooth

Sampled on tap at the brewery during ABA Beer Tour ’07. Pours an opaque dark brown brew with a fast dissolving off-white head that diminishes to a fine off-white ring. Aroma of light coffee, dark chocolate, some molasses and toasted nuts. Taste is medium to full bodied, no carbonation with some roasted malt flavors. Finish has a light and smooth bittersweet aftertaste then changes to light coffee flavor.

Very rich chocolate flavor at the start followed by a astringent coffee finish. This stout was a bit watery on the palate, but the flavors with rich and roasty with a good balance to it. I just wish it had a bit more body.

[Tap] A great dark black beer that pours like molasses and taste like honey. This had a great flavor and was so yummy to drink. I really enjoyed this brew. It is very hard to find a good Stout brewed with the right stuff. Good malts and lots of good character. I will drink this again for sure.
On tap, copper color with no head, malty fruit aroma with flavors of metallic bready frui, finish is slightly bitter
on tap. Pours red brown with beige head. Floral hops, toffee, brown sugar smells. Tastes a little dusty, sugary, some toasted nuts, slight pepperyness.

Draught at the brewpub. Dark amber brown with an off-white head. The aroma is malty and pretty expected, with toasted grain, lightly burnt caramel, and a touch of hops. The flavor has a malt profile that follows the aroma with toasty malt and rich dark caramel that borders on roast. Light on the hops and sweet in balance, though not overly so. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. An alright amber ale with a nice rich malt profile that brings a very light roast.

[2949-20100626] Tap. Mild wood plastic tarp aroma has spent grains. Clear, amber orange body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Lightly toasted grains and yeast flavour with a hint of roast aftertaste. Medium body. Boring. (@ Raccoon Lodge, Portland, OR)

2010-06-26. Dark red-brown body, small beige head. 3+ Flavour is malty, light toasty overtones. Aroma is similar, modest toasty character to the simple malty core. Average plus bodied palate. Pretty simple, but a good example of the style. On Tap at Raccoon Lodge, Portland.
I didnt expect to like it, but it really was delicious. Not too caramelly or sweet, nice hop bite, complex but mellow. very good beer.
tap at brewpub. pours a clear copper with a small beige head. doughy bock like malt backing. sweet bread. light coffee. not much going on in the nose. ok, not great.
On tap at Paddy’s as Cascade Copper Celtic. Minimal aroma (due to the plastic cup?). A bit woody tasting. Nice beer.

Date: September 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear dark amber, fine beige head, drippy lace Aroma: light sweet malt aroma Flavor: sweet malt flavor, hint of bready character, light bitterness Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4

On tap at Raccoon Lodge Portland, Pours out a dark amber topepd with a small sand head. Aroma was of sweet caramell roast malt and a nice roast nut aswell. Taste was more of the sweet malts along with a little floral hop. Pretty tasy.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Bad Billy Blond Bock
column5: On tap at Cascade Tasting Room with mcberko. Pours a clear yellow.gold.orange. Aroma of roasted malts, bread, earth, spices and biscuit. Flavour of roasted malts, earth, bread, spices, biscuit and orange peel. Medium bodied. Decent.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Bad Billy Blond Bock
column5: On tap at Cascade Tasting Room, split with Matts_Property, pours clear golden blonde with a small white head. Aroma is earthy and spicy, with light biscuit. Flavour of biscuit, earthy and dry bread - dry, herbally finish. Drinkable.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Bad Billy Blond Bock
column5: Name: Blond Bock Date: September 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy dark yellow, fine off white head, drippy lace Aroma: lightly sweet malt aroma with a nice spicyness Flavor: sweet malt flavor, lots of spicy hops dries it out, light bitterness, long bitter finish Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.9/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4

column1: Raccoon Lodge Bad Billy Blond Bock
column5: On tap at Raccoon Lodge Portland, Pours out a straw yellow topped with a small white head. Aroma was of light floral hops along with some light malt. Taste was more of the light floral notes and some spice.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Bad Billy Blond Bock
column5: Tap @ Raccoon Lodge: Blond in color, medium white head. Aroma is mild of sweet malt, a little spicey, and some floral hops. Flavor gets into some trouble up front and is kind of bland, but it recovers from a malty-watery grave by smoothing out into a spicey and floral finish.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Bad Billy Blond Bock
column5: Draft at Raccoon Lodge. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a sweetish malty grainy caramel aroma. Sweetish malty spicy and grainy flavor with some hints of caramel. Has a slightly sweetish malty grainy finish.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Bad Billy Blond Bock
column5: on tap, clear gold color, sweet bready nose and flavor, medium body, slightly cloying finish

column1: Raccoon Lodge Bad Billy Blond Bock
column5: On tap at Raccoon Lodge. Pours clear gold with a lacy ring of foam. Medium body and light carbonation. Caramel honey nose and taste.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Bad Billy Blond Bock
column5: 22 oz. bottle - gold and crystal clear with big white head upon pouring, 2nd pint becoming slightly cloudy; some lacing; yeasty aromas mixed with sweet malts; flavors are mild and a little sweet; smooth finish, but kind of bland overall

column1: Raccoon Lodge Bad Billy Blond Bock
column5: Burnished tawny-golden body with a rocky sweet, bready off-white head. Silken slippery, smooth creamy bready with nicely balanced spicy Saaz hops. Pretty good beer.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Ring Tail Pale Ale
column5: Date: September 23, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: hazy pale yellow, fine white head Aroma: light malt aroma, light floral hops Flavor: pale malt flavor, touch of cereal, light sweetness, floral hops Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 4/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 7/20 Rating: 2.1/5.0 Drinkability: 6/10 Score: *+ /4

column1: Raccoon Lodge Ring Tail Pale Ale
column5: Wow just like old times. I have a rate that is right next to Jake65. Pretty cool anyhow. On tap at Raccoon Lodge Portland, Pours out a light straw topped with a thin white head. Aroma was of light floral hops and a little sweetness. Taste was more of the light floral hops and some caramell malts.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Ring Tail Pale Ale
column5: Tap at Raccoon Lodge: Light golden colored pour with a small white head. Aroma is mild of malty sweet and floral hops. Flavor is sweet into a grassier/floral malt trainwreck. Pass.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Ring Tail Pale Ale
column5: Draft at Raccoon Lodge. Pours a pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a sweetish malty hoppy aroma. Sweetish malty and slightly hoppy flavor with some hints of caramel. Has a sweetish fruity malty finish.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Ring Tail Pale Ale
column5: On tap at Raccoon Lodge. Pours clear gold with a very lacy white head. Light body and light carbonation. Aroma of fruit and wood. Taste of bread and fruit with an almost crisp finish. Not a lot going on here for an APA.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Ring Tail Pale Ale
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Light malt and hop aroma. Amber golden color with a lacing white head. Medium body with mild carbonation. Floral hop over pale malt for flavor. Mildly bitter finish with floral notes, and perhaps a little wood. Excellent session ale.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Ring Tail Pale Ale
column5: Sampled on tap at the brewery during ABA Beer Tour ’07. Pours a clear golden pale yellow brew with a fast dissolving white head that leaves behind a white ring. Aroma of light piney citrus hops and light caramel malt. Taste is smooth, lightly carbonated, medium bodied with a good balance of bread dough and citrus taste. Finish has a light hop citrus bitterness that lingers around after the finish. Reading some of the earlier ratings, looks like the brewmaster has took notice and improved this pale ale.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Ring Tail Pale Ale
column5: [Oregon Brewers Guild – 2006 Brewers Dinner] A light colored brew with a full flavor. This was a nice beer but not my favorite. I was hoping for more. This was a simple easy to drink beer. The PBR crowd would love this.

column1: Raccoon Lodge Ring Tail Pale Ale
column5: Watered down, zesty herbal notes and some medicinal something or other going on here too. This is a really big disappointment. Left me asking where did it go?

column1: Raccoon Lodge Ring Tail Pale Ale
column5: Tap at Horsebrass. Pale amber to golden colored, sparse white head. Pissy aroma and flavor. Sadly disappointing, certainly nowhere near an APA in character, this would even struggle if classified as a mild. Even the description is hideous, sounding like a BMC ripoff, talking about slow brewed. I would rather have a slow brewed glass of water.
0.33 l bottle in Göteburg... Clear golden color, short head... Nice bitter hop aroma... Average Pilsener taste... No special ending...
Det här är en smaklös öl utan varken humlebeska eller maltighet, dessutom saknar den kropp. Trots det fungerade förvänansvärt bra till ett julbord.
Bottle 33 cl, 2003-03-12, onother of the swedish lagers that are not perfectly interesting! The head is ok for a short time. Malty, hoppy and a bit fruity (undefined sort of...) + wee bitterness.
33 cL bottle. Pours clear and pale yellow with a small white head. Aroma is mild cardboardish and grassy. Grassy and cardboardish faint flavour. Mild bitterness into the finish. Boring.

330 ml bottle. Clear, pale yellow-golden body. Thin, fully diminishing head. Grainy and light sourish malt aroma. Notes of hayish hops and yellow fruits. Grainy, light sweet flavor. Mild bitterness, lacking some freshness. Body is light plus. Quite clean on the palate. Short, sweet, and faintly bitter finish. Not bad, boring only.

Golden with an OK head. The aroma has notes of slightly sour malt, wet grain and hints of grass. The flavour is remarkably weak with weak notes of sourish malt, wet grain and hints of grass. The expected bitterness in the finish never arrives...
Bottle, 33 cl. Pale, clear golden, medium white head. Weak, a bit skunky malt, no hops. Medium bodied and decent mouthfeel. Low bitterness.
Canned. Pale golden with a large and white head. Sweet, slightly bready maltiness. No bitterness to write home about.
(50 cl can from Systembolaget) Pale golden color, fluffy white head. Acidic, milk and yogurt scent. Malty and slight bitter tast, very meaningless. Medium mouthfeel, low bitterness. Sweet aftertaste.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is fruit, malt. Flavour is malt, flower, hint of hop. Thin.
Cask-Conditioned. Dark, ruby in colour – very slight head. Malty aroma. Flavours of malt, some hobby bitterness. Not as full bodied as the colour and alcohol content (around 5%) would suggest.
Cask @ The Vulcan, Huddersfield. Golden with a thick creamy head. It has an ordinary bitter aroma but a surprisingly good nutty taste.

Cask, Kings Head, Leicester. Hazy gold with a thin foam. Aromas are caramel and Weetabix with melliw lemon. Stewed pear with floral notes. Flavours are sweet caramel and thin grain with apple and soft spices. Very boring and an insult at £1.50 for a half pint.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 2012, Great British Beer Festival, London Olympia, Hammersmith Road, London, England W14 8UX. Clear medium to dark amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted - caramel, apple. Flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120808]

Cask @ The Bricklayers Arms, Putney. As ’Clarks Best Bitter 3.8%’. The pour’s light amber with a small head. Bready nose. A bit of caramel and earthy hop. The taste is toffee, more caramel. A bit of red apple skin acidity. Light cider tang on the finish. Light body. Fine carbonation. Overall, a pretty straightforward number. OK.

Cask conditioned handpump Coach & Horses Wellingborough 08/01/13. A slightly hazy amber coloured beer with a whitish head. Tart and fruity with sweet notes too. A bit of vomit late on. An old fashioned dull bitter.

Cask at the Sussex Arms, Twickenham Green - 30/11/12. Hazed golden, thin white head, soon clears to edge and forms a film. Nose is vegetal, peas, malt. Taste follows no more to say! Medium bodied, light carbontation, veggy bitter finish. Classic twig water - meh !!!

8th August 2012 GBBF. Light haze on this amber beer, little white head. Light dry palate - quite flat. Okay balance of mild malts and repressed citrus. Dry finish. Standard stuff and condition is poor.

Two hand-pulled pints of this Traditional Bitter: Swan Hotel, Wellington (Shropshire) on 29th Sept 2012. Mid-amber body, clean and clear: an off-white head sat on top of each pour. The nose was more malty than hoppy: some semi-sweet molasses (toffee and caramel) hid the fruity, nut esters of the hops until the beer began to warm in the glass a little. The taste followed the smells: malts ruling the flavours with the hops just providing a slight bittering towards the end of each sip. It was fairly well balanced and not as malty as I might have described to be honest, lets just say it leads with the malts. An OK session beer but not one I’d seek out.
Cask@GBBF2012. Amber colour, small white head. Aroma is wood, caramel, some fruits, toffee, caramel and mild notes of yeast. Flavour is fruity, caramelly, floral, wooden and quite earthy.
Handpump at the Country Club Sprotbrough. Decent white head. Clear golden blond pour. Nice session beer.

Cask, Crown & Thistle, Gravesend. Lemon colour. Lemon yeasty aroma with a small touch of sulphur. Lemon again in taste with a good dusty handful of hops. Some sweetness up front. An attractive profile, though the dusty hops are just a little too pronounced for my liking.
Cask-Conditioned. Light colour, aromas and flavour. Slight hops & fruit. Dryish finish.
Cask at Wellington Arms, Bedford. Copper colour. Sweet caramel aroma developing. Taste is sweet, fruity and refreshing with a sharp leafy hoppiness. Nice balance here.
Cask Handpump at the Friar Penketh, Warrington (JDW) 03/06/2002 Copper golden colour and malty. Clean slightly bitter dry finish.
Cask conditioned at a Wetherspoons. Dark brown with thin head. This is a roasted malt beer with deep fruity flavours and an overall sweetness. Some bitterness but mostly of the coffee bean type.
Draft at the craft beer festival , beer at the pier in the south street seaport. Light color and easy flavor. Very light beer with little flavor. Good to session in the summer
Bottle from Mousehouse Cheesehouse. Pale gold and flat looking. Odd mild apple and malt likka character. Not good.

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 2-22-13. Soapy, tangy, chemical-y, floral aroma features lime, melon, apple cider, and vinegar scents. Weird, strong smell; I’ve never encountered a smell like it. Pours a clear gold with a small amount of short-lasting, beige head. Low in flavor (bland) but not actively offensive. A weak, champagne-like quality to the taste. Light body; watery. Fizzy and lively in the palate. 4/2/3/2/7=>1.8

Straw yellow with a quickly fading white head. Aroma of skunked grains, pale malt and noble hops. Taste of sweet malt, grains and noble hops. Thin, macroesque and kinda blah. This was my last new beer of 2012 and unbeknownst to me at the time, it was my 1000th Wisconsin beer.

A blonde pils with a thin white head. In aroma, faint malt, with very faint catty notes. In mouth, a rather plain sweetish malt with light buttery fruity esters, boring. On tap at the Istmus Beer and Cheese, Jan 21 2012.

Draft at OF. Filtered yellow-orange. Factory sewage aroma. Soda-like carbonation, thick non-head. Light to medium bodied, somewhat sugary, corny. Too "malt" centered with an extreme shortage of hop character. This is pretty sub par stuff. Watery, unenjoyable, sugary.and thick.

Sampled from a bottle at GTMW 2011. Pours a clear gold with a large frothy white head. Poor head retention and lacing. Aroma of grassy notes and corn. The taste is grain and tortilla chips. Thin bodied.

12 oz twist off bottle. It pours a honey gold with big, bulky bubbles and a soapy white head. The smell is light and clean. It is unoffensive, with noble hops and light biscuit. Th flavor is a bit of a letdown. It has a big buttery diacetyl flavor and it is under carbonated. Other than that there is a mild hop flavor, but it is a buttery, sweet, malty pils. Serving type: bottle Reviewed on: 12-15-2010 00:43:02
citrus, pale, clear, minimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light body, thin feel, flat,
Beer #14 at GTMW. Good clean beer smell. Spritzy with definite spicy hops. Like to say more, but this is just palate cleanser before I head back to the Real ale Tent.
Bottle from Nick, Fruit punch and brett funk. Some candy apple and grain. Not a fan
Uma saisson com notas de frutado e condimentada no aroma, características do estilo.
Bottle shared at the first post-Dean THT. Pours a hazy yellow with a white head. Way too herbal, nope. Medium sweet and bitter. Medium body, low carbonation.

Bottle at February THT. Almost clear golden with small bubbly white head. Massive sage, thyme, rosemary. Basically this is a lot like herb juice that would be good in dinner. Soft malts and sugar but mostly herbs. Medium sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Very herbal but also not too bad.

Sampled from bottle at THT Februari at "De Zuipschuit". Hazy golden with thin white head. Massive herbs, thyme, rosemary, provencial herbs. Light sweet and moderate vegetal bitter. Medium body and soft carbonation. Very herbal. I agree with kermis, this would probably go nice with anything chicken.

Bottle shared at THT. Hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is huge herbal, thyme, rosemary, it’s all about herbs that would work pretty well with chicken. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Would pair well with a kipcorn.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle of one of the recent batches, 2014 I believe. Aroma is malty with toasted bread, nuts and caramel. Some fruity esters with red apple, pear and banana being most prevalent. Light citrus notes. Some phenolic notes with pepper and clove. Slightly woody note as well. Pours a slightly hazy, amber brown with a large, moderately thick and frothy, tan head that recedes fairly quickly. No lacing or legs. Flavor is slightly acidic with a medium light sweetness. Malt notes of toasted bread, caramel and nuts. Medium light fruit notes with pear, red apple and stone fruit as well as some lighter banana and raisin notes. Medium light bitterness. Light woody note. Light pepper and clove phenolic notes. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. Overall, a nice darker saison. Good malt notes balance with nice fruit and phenolic notes. Lighter acidity. I still prefer the lighter Fantome saisons though.

At Fofa. A semi-opaque gold and a massive foamy head. It has a great aroma of orange blossoms and honey. Medium to full bodied with a soft round carbonation. The flavor evoked a tart orange creamsicle, zest, plus light malts. Good shit
Pours murky dark amber color with almost no head. Dark fruit and yeast aroma with some Fantome funk. Sour dark fruit flavor with musty, earthy, and funky notes. Medium body with no carbonation.

750 ml capped and corked bottle, label says best before end 2017. Served in a Prairie Teku, the beer pours a hazy brown color with pretty much no head whatsoever. No lacing, either. Aroma is subtle at first but gets stronger as the beer warms, it smells like red apples, caramel and woodiness. Luckily the flavors are stronger in comparison to the aroma. It tastes like red apple, cherries, caramel, vinegar, stone fruit, earthiness, oak and some light spiciness. The tartness is subtle. Mouthfeel/body is light/medium, with very low carbonation. I thought this was OK overall, it’s not my favorite Fantôme brew but still an interesting one. I’d like to try a different batch of this in the future.

1. Cask Handpump at the Dog Inn, Over Peover 28/07/2002 Amber golden coloured and slightly pale. Fruity with a dry hop finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Beer House, Manchester 24/08/2002 Golden coloured slightly fruity and hoppy. Some bitterness in a dry finish.
This bitter was darker than most others, but also had more flavor than most. An interesting brew served of cask. I would try this one again.
Fruity, hoppy bitter with a yeasty note.....................................

Sampled cask conditioned at the Jolly Angler, Manchester. Deep golden, but a tad darker than their regular Bitter. Neutral, or perhaps vaguely flowery aroma. Slightly watery mouthfeel. Low- to medium bitterness.

Draught pint at the brewery, 11/4/05 with Muzzlehatch. Three Needs beers have a very odd appearance. They’re quite hazy and unfiltered, which is encouraging, but past that there’s a small head that quickly fizzles away to nothing, with no lacing and looking rather still in the glass. This one has a slightly beige-off-white head, with a dull amber to dry-hay colored body. Nose shows lightly fruity yeast (apples, cherries, dates), a round, clean caramel and toffee malt, with some expressive base malts as well. Strong floral/grassiness in the nose, with light chocolate on end. Flavor is lightly sugary dough, with more fruitiness and a touch of raisins and white grapes. Dates and almonds, with lightly grassy, hay-like hops and just a touch of toasted malts. Soft, creamy, low carbonation, no alcohol apparency. Maybe a touch of wateriness, but very minor on the end.
Deep red brown ale with little off-white head. Light burned caramel aroma. Grassy notes in nose. Strong nuttyness with sweet malts, and harsh bitterness in finish. Medium bodied.

Looks like Dr. Pepper pouring out of the tape; no head. Nose weak, slightly malty. Chocolate, slight grapiness in the flavor; excellent creamy/winey mouthfeel; hops very subdued. A caramel sweetness grows with warmth. Not great as barley wines go, and rather low on the ABV I think, but drinkable. Sept 03. Earthier, heavier, richer this time. I like it. Leathery and smoky.
on nitro-pours a creamy light tan head that laces and black color. Aroma is dark malt-coffee. Taste is slightly sweet, dark malt-coffee, secondary bitter hops. Mild carbonation.

Pours rich and opaque with a thick nitro head. Dry roasted malt aroma. Starts sweet with a touch of soy sauce and brown sugar before finishing roasty and dry. Body is a little thin, but still maintains a silky feel. A very nice dry stout.

Sept 02: Pours nice, good thick stout look with a small but everlasting head. Downhill after that I'm afraid; too carbonated, thinnish mouthfeel, flavor very mild with chocolate and wine (white zinfandel most likely) dominating. Very little nose. Why bother? Feb 03: Vastly better 2nd time around. Carbonation at a decent level, roasty effects stronger, incredibly rich and smooth mouthfeel, slight thinness at the end is the only real problem. Not distinctive enough to be great, but delicious enough to have again.
Deep golden. Some grassy hop aroma, reasonably malty but with short flavour. Medium bitterness.

(Bottle 50 cl) Golden beer with a tall, handsome head. Very soft and smooth lager with a delicate hop aroma not leaving much bitterness. All right but really nothing spectacular. According to the back label the Lapps consider the year to have no less than eight seasons - this is a beer for summer. 021200

Golden coloured, much blonder than the winter version. Sweet start with a bitter finish. The aroma is difficult, my wife says it smells "stinging nettle and summer. I have mixed feelings about the aroma. The summer version is not really a good beer.
Pale golden. Slight grassy hop aroma. Light bodied, bordering to thin. Medium bitterness.
Golden colour. Grassy hop aroma. Medium body. Short flavour with harsh finish. Medium bitterness.

330ml Bottle - Golden with a white head. Grain and some faint hints of citrus and honey in the aroma. Moderately sweet taste with honey, grain, lemon peel and lime leaves detected. Some hints of bubblegum can be detected in the finish.

Keg at the Tegernseer Brauhaus, Munich in 2016. Deep golden with an offwhite head. Aroma of dark malt, dried fruit, cloves and fruitcake. Fruity sweetness up front, with a little roasty note at the end.
0,33 l bottle as "Der blaue Page". Clear golden with a two finger frothy white head. Low grainy smell. Taste starts grainy, low caramell, little bit alcoholic with hints of apples. Boring stuff.
18-04-18 // bottle from Getränke Stumpf. Clear golden. Small head. Medium sweet. Grainy malty. Light alcohol in the end. Solid bock.
Der blaue Page 33 CL bottle. Mainstream maibock. Bread and flowers in the taste, as some koriander. Good to drink but not worth a detour.

"Der blaue Page", Flasche (33 cl) von Hopfen & Malz, Berlin-Wedding. - Goldgelb, blank. - In der Nase wenig mehr als breit süßliches, ein wenig schales helles Malz, Anklänge an Honig. - Antrunk zuckrig-süß hellmalzig, Kandiszucker-artig, grundiert mit matter Kräuterbonbon-Herbe (Ricola). Mild rezent aber etwas leer im Körper, im Vergleich zu besseren Böcken beinahe wäßrig. Noch im Abgang behauptet sich die Malzsüße; die kräuterigen Hopfenaromen sind nur Begleitmusik. Schwach herber Nachtrunk. - Sehr malzsüßer Bock ohne Tiefgang und Schwere; eher ein angedicktes Helles. Dennoch rund und gut trinkbar.

Bottle. Pours crystal golden with medium frothy top. Aroma is sweet maltiness, even kinda deep grainy flavor, a bit robust, but interesting. Taste is sweet, minimal bitterness, avg dry finish. Medium body, sirupy texture. One time try thou strong grainy flavor was interesting.

As "Der blaue Page" at Tegernseer near Marienplatz. Golden color with small head Aroma is sweet grains with some extra honey. Taste as well. Honey and sweet grains. Low carbonation, some chewiness. Boring Heller Bock. Nice to drink but really not a good Bock.

A heller Bock from Tegernsee, drank in the "Der blaue Page" varaint. This is quite like its younger brother the Helle only slightly more heavy and more alcoholic. It is a good beer, but the extra strength is not needed. I must drink more helle bock to perhaps understand the nuances.
Rated as Blauer Page. Ins Glas ergießt sich ein goldenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch malzig fruchtig, getreidig, leicht herb. Geschmack sehr malzig getreidig, fruchtig, leicht alkoholisch.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Served on tap in a pint glass Appearance – The beer is served a lightly hazed yellowish amber color with a one finger head of fizzy looking white foam. The head fades very fast leaving a rather tiny bit of lace on the sides of the glass. Smell The aroma is heaviest of a citrus smell of tangerine and grapefruit as well as a strong showing of a wheaty and yeasty smell. Aromas of banana and a bit of a grassy and slightly funky smell are there as well, giving a rather nice sweeter and yeasty wit smell overall. Taste – The taste begins with a nice sweeter citrus and wheat flavor with a good deal of tangerine and orange and some nice wheat bread tastes. Upfront there are also some nice notes of banana and candied sugar which add to the overall sweet flavor of the brew. As the taste advances some of the sweeter candied sugar tastes and fruitiness of banana and tangerine decrease a bit, but all the while are replaced by some more yeasty and slightly sour lemon flavors. The yeasty tastes bring with them some lighter spice flavors of coriander and clove and with a hint of a grassy and hay like taste, one is left with a rather present, moderately sweet lemonade like and very tasty wit taste to linger on the tongue. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is on the thinner to average side with a carbonation level that is rather average. The average body is great for the mix of yeast, fruit and wheat, all while the average carbonation keeps it very easy drinking, but yet does not hide any of the wheat, yeasty, or spiced flavors of the brew. Overall, it is rather well done. Overall – A quite tasty wit overall, with a great level of flavor and balance for a brew of only 5.3 %. A nice one to try if you get a chance.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Hazy lemon-yellow body, thin white head, spotty lacing. Light citrus, banana, coriander and soft grains. Light bodied with moderate carbonation, a touch of sweetness and a clean finish.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Clear golden w minimal head, looks thin.... pretty traditional aroma, some lemon aroma... thin, kind of watery, boring, lemony... leaves a lot to be desired....

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On Tap. Slightly hazy, pear-colored ale with a large, frothy, white head. Grapefruit, lemon and coriander aroma. The flavor is of butterscotch and grapefruit. Light-bodied with some carbonation. Crisp, clean finish. Refreshing!

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: tap, pours hazy yellow, thin white head. Thin wheat aroma. Watered down sweet wheat body, some light spice in the finish. Flavors are too light and boring.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Tap @ Blind Tiger. Golden pour with some white head. Spices and light citrus flavoring. This wasn’t great but not bad either.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft. Pours a golden body with a white head. Coriander and lemon grass sweet and a light tart lemon and more coriander. EH.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On draft at the GL. Pours a cloudy honey yellow gold with a medium white head. Aroma of light spice, coriander, orange peel and hops. Taste of light spicy hops, coriander, orange peel and tang.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Hazy yellow. Aroma was of yeast, banana, and clove. The taste was the same with light refeshing finish.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Date: 07/25/2007 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub, Phoenixville cloudy yellow, wispy white head, drippy lace, light aroma, sweet orange flavor, touch of spices provides some balance, Aroma: 4/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 2.7/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: **/4
Sweet and malty aroma, a bit metallic. Taste is watery and short, the alcohol is prominent and the malt flavor has a sour and bitter aftertaste. Nasty beer!
Bottle. Clear yellow golden with a medium white head. Sweet malty aroma. More of the same in the flavours, maybe a touch of herbs. Medium body. A waste of effort to brew something so boring.
Golden with a nice white foam. Clean, with notes of hops and barley. Medium body with a bitter finish.
(50 cl bottle from Systembolaget) Clear golden color, small white head. Sweet grainy malty aroma, vegetables as well. Malty and wood taste, some metal. Rather dry. Spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.
Bottle, pale yellow with a firm white head. Malty flavour, and I do smell filmjölk too... Flavour is cereals and malt.
Bottle. Clear golden colour, white head. Not much nose, not much taste. I thought this was going to be much better.. but it wasn’t.

[Bottle] Golden colour, creamy foam. Dry-ish, papery nose with small honey notes. Soft mouthfeel with grassy hops and an interesting malt profile that gives fruitiness, a spicey touch and honey? Light, pleasant bitter finish. Hm...this was not that bad???
Bottle. Golden colour with a big white head. Malty, hay aroma and a dry hay, straw taste. Medium body with a dry finish.
Pale yellow beer with a white head. Malty, grainy sweet aroma with notes of hay. Sweet malty flavor with a dry grassy finish.
Bottle. Clear yellow coloured with a white head. Aroma of malts and hops. Flavour of malts and hops. Boring beer.

Flaska från Landbierparadis. Disig gyllengul vätska med stort maffigt vitt skum. En ganska snäll hefe till både doft och smak. Frisk och syrlig men ganska lätt kryddad och inte så jästig. Känns nåogt starkare än genomsnittet. Hög drickbarhet. Gott.
The foam stability is good, the body yellow and cloudy. The Aroma is yeasty, citrussy, malty, wheat. Taste is yeasty, refreshing, fruity, rather citrussy, a little stonefruit. I like it!
Hefig säuerlicher, mild herber Antrunk. Geringe Würzigkeit, wässrig, laff. Langweilig. 9/6/7/7//6
500ml Bottle - Hazy golden with a very foamy head. Banana and toffee in the aroma. Fairly tangy taste with notes of lemon meringue, banana and a hint of spice.
In der Nase Nelke, im Trunk ebenso, süßlich, leicht herb, hohe Drinkability, aber nichts aufregendes.

Hazy golden with medium white fluffy head. Aroma is banana, yoghurt, lacto, yeasty stuff, maybe flour. Taste is fresh yeasty sourness, with a little chalk. Good to drink, nice chalky mouthfeel. Not bad.

Bottle. Hazy yellow color with white head. Aroma is fresh spicy yeasts, bananas, some other exotic fruit. Taste is some banana, dry, mineralic. Silky mouthfeel. Very refreshing (and dry), this is one of the more enjoyable Franconian Weizen.

(bottle) murky golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of black pepper and clove, quite yeasty, with a touch of earthy hops and apricot stones. flavour is mostly caramelized wheat and grass, with a hint of powdered sugar and some floral hops in the rather minerally light-bitter finish. medium-bodied with lively carbonation.
Bottle. Hazy yellow, white lace. Dry spicy nose, citrus, tropical (starfruit?). Medium, dry minerally body, dry spices, light fruit salad, mellow mealy finish.

bottle from pivnzub! Cloudy golden with a tall and creamy white head. Yeasty nose. Wheaty and yeasty with a pleasant fruity touch, not exaggerated. Shy hints of banana. Smooth and velvety carbonation.

column1: Little Apple XX Black Angus Stout
column5: Draft pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malts and coffee. Taste is malts, chocolate, grain and a hint of coffee.

column1: Little Apple XX Black Angus Stout
column5: On nitro. Cascading light brown head -black. A-roast/molasses/anise-dark malt bitter. T-roasty/cocoa-dark malt, lactose, some earthy hops

column1: Little Apple XX Black Angus Stout
column5: Sickeningly sticky beer. An incredible amount of caramel and butter in what should be a beer dominated by its chocolate or coffee roastiness. I had trouble finishing it.

column1: Little Apple XX Black Angus Stout
column5: Has a hint of coffee, after tast was was strong rite after. Would get again

column1: Little Apple XX Black Angus Stout
column5: Had this beer every time I have visited the brewpub and its never been off, which is something very special for this brewery. Looks great off nitro, adds a thickness to the mouthfeel I don’t get much from their other beer. Plenty of roast a unsweetened cocoa and all very drinkable. If you only get one beer here make it this one.

column1: Little Apple XX Black Angus Stout
column5: Pours a deep almost black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of milk chocolate, caramel and honey roasted nuts. Flavor of milk chocolate milkshake, touch of caramel.

column1: Little Apple XX Black Angus Stout
column5: Sampler at the brewpub. Comes almost black with a nice thick tan head. Aroma of malt and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, coffee, and a touch of hops. Rich and creamy. Nice.

column1: Little Apple XX Black Angus Stout
column5: Pours black with frothy tall nitro head. Smell is smooth and slightly sweet. Taste is mild, very light body, light sweet stout with light creamy well blended malt bill. Slightly dry bittering finish with a touch of coffee. Enjoyable overall

column1: Little Apple XX Black Angus Stout
column5: Very dark and very creamy and had a good roasted coffee bean taste. A head on it like ive never seen beer is a most try.

column1: Little Apple XX Black Angus Stout
column5: On tap at little apple, pour and appearance it’s perfect taste is lacking but the smooth and creamy mouthfeel is sweet surprised to find this in kansas

Smells strangely like soap. Typical wheat ale color but a little more hazy. Very easy drinking but weak, much better with a lemon slice thrown in. Thin palate for the style. Average. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap. Thin white-very hazy yellow. A-light fruit, musty grain. T-wheat/musty grain, light fruit/some earthy hops.
Sampler at the brewpub. Clear, dull pale golden color. Light diacetyl with tartness. Flavor thankfully is missing the diacetyl and is mostly a tart and mineral watery beer.
Pours a hazy golden with a small bubbly white head. Aroma of lemon and Cheerios. Flavor is very grainy, some banana and lemon.
On tap at the brewpub. Comes hazy gold with a small white head. Aroma of grain and citrus. Taste is malt, grain, and citrus. Very average.
Cloudy golden brown with a thin white head when poured. Comes with a lemon garnish. Has a sweet taste with minimal after taste.
Sampled at the 2009 Parkville microbrew festival. Pours a clear gold with a thin white head. This is an ok beer but nothing special. It’s very easy to drink. A very flavorless beer for the masses.
Pours hazy golden with the typical wheaty aroma. Little grass, little lemon. Flavor is tart, lemony, thin and watery.
On Tap color of off gold sorta paleish it smelled and tasted like burned butter awful smelled bad tasted bad overall crap.
Tap at Midwest Brewfest. Pours average yellow with an aroma of garbage disposal refuse. Flavor is corn garbage. Watery mouthfeel. This beer sucks.
Smells and looks great. Nice clean hop profile, very well made overall. This place knows what they’re doing. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bu au festival à la brasserie De feniks verre de 15cl. Couleur jaune pâle brillance moyenne. mousse inexistante . Au nez : note floral et houblon frais . en bouche : Sensation houblon frais plutot intense vraiment bien ! note fruitée comme des fruits exotic et un peu de melon . amertume juste et non sèche. bon corps je trouve fin de bouche agrèable .
Draft at Parkville fest. Clear golden color, white head. Citrus aroma. Taste is fruity, just lightly bitter. OK.
On tap. No head-gold. A-caramel, light citrus. T-caramel-light malt, orange/herbal/tea hops.
A middling pale ale. Has some grassy bitterness, but there is a lingering butter problem with this (and most other beers) from this brewery.

Pours a lightly hazy golden amber with a smaller bubbly white head that laced. Aroma of lightly toasted malt with a hint of caramel, some floral and citrusy hop notes. Flavor of tea, bready malt, light caramel and light grapefruit and floral hop notes.

Pours mostly yellow with white head. Smell is light, sweet grain and herbal hops. Taste is earthy and grainy. Mild resinous herbal hop bite with dry finish. Nice sweet fruit, almost a strawberry like, underneath it all. I bit like an over hopped English pale.
On tap at little apple thought I got a pale ale and I was pleasantly surprised with the hoppyness of this , for 3.50 a pint it’s very good
Pint at the brewpub. Comes a light amber with a small white head. Aroma of hops and citrus. Tastes of hops and malt. Some bitterness. Not bad at all.

Sampled at the 2009 Parkville microbrew festival. Pours orange with a thin white head. This is their regular pale ale?!? This beer is thicker than many DIPAs. This is candy-sweet. lots of toffee. Thick and rich with the right level of hops for a big beer.
Draft pours brown with a off white head,. Aroma is nutty, malts and roast. Taste is caramel , nutty and grains.
Pours a deep brown with golden notes and a smaller off white head. Aroma of honey roasted nuts and lightly toasted malt. Flavor of honey dipped milk chocolate.
Sampler at the brewpub. Comes dark brown with a small biege head. Aroma of roast and chocolate. Taste is roast, chocolate, and some coffee. Smooth and easy to drink.

Pours dark brown with of white head. Smells of sweet roasted grain. Taste is big on chocolate, a little coffee, heartier roast than it looks. Kind of a robust porter ish brown. Not bad but bland finish.
Dark brown with a thin white head when poured. Sweet taste with a bitter after taste. Not impressed at all.

Sampled at the 2009 Parkville microbrew festival. Pours dark brown with a thin white head. Has a nice chocolate aroma and a big coffee roasted flavor. This is flavorful enough to be a lesser brewer’s porter.

Loved this beer off tap at the Little Apple Brew Pub. Almost no head, very dark, smooth, not sweet, but with tons of roasted grain, like darkly browned whole wheat bread, smooth and easy to drink, no crimes on the finish. Very enjoyable.
4 oz taster at the brewpub. Pour is brown ruby with a thinnish tan head. Aroma of faint nuttiness and some malt. Taste is thin, watery, featuring some nuttiness and not much else. Meh.
On tap, poured a very nice dark color, foam is sorta a off white color a little lacing can taste the some choclate very easy drinking.
on tap. poured a dark whiskey color. no initial smell. taste if clover, caramel and vanilla with a hint of chocolate. smooth finish.

Sampled on draft the brewpub this beer poured a reddish brown color with a medium sized foamy yellow-white head that left minimal lacing. The aroma was sweet golden fruits and simple syrup. The flavor was toasty with caramel, golden fruits and bread crust. Medium length finish. Moderately full bodied. Well done.

Super hazy amber and copper coloured body with a very nice 2 centimetre tall tan head and some very nice chunky orange tints - beautiful beer. Aroma of a lot of malt, some specialty grains, a bit of toast and some caramelised sugars. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong malt flavours at first dominate with some rye and bitterness along with some toffee, earth and alcohol warmth near the end. Aftertaste shows some of the malt pungency still, but the sugars come through more at the end, along with a bit of grain and alcohol warmth. Overall, a nice and super dense maibock, and in all honesty, a deep beer for any lager, even for doppelbocks or weizenbocks! Nice to sample on draught and to have here in the state of Virginia! I sampled this sixteen ounce pint on draught at Whole Foods in Pentagon City (Arlington), Virginia at the end of my driveway on 14-September-2016 for US$4,00.

raft at Brewer’s Alley. Pours clear gold with a fizzy off white head tastes like doughy malt, some dry citrus hops, lemon, grapefruit, and dried fruit. Light/medium body and carbonation. Smells like doughy and caramel malt, and faint grapefruit hops.
Pours Amber with low head. Aroma is sweet toasted malt and pine. Taste is mainly sweet malt, light body,
This is all about the malt. Aroma of malt, flavor is sweet. A bit too sweet for me, as I tend to reach for savory first. The sweetness does hide the high alcohol content and the beer is in balance.

Taster on tap at Brewers Alley. Labeled 9.5%.. Is that a mistake? Amber color. Minimal ring of off-white head. Fruity aroma, bit of a sweet malt liquor -esque malt bill. Medium-plus body. Kind of crisp, reasonably smooth lighter carbonation. Lightly slick texture. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter. It does have a bit of heat to it, not really any burn though. Pretty interesting maibock. Impressive in how enormous it is - extra point for hiding that reasonably well.
Heavy body with forward malts. Nice balance of candy and dark fruit sweetness with a bit of alcohol bite. Very clean tasting with no noticeable off-flavors.

On tap at a Brewer's Alley Beer Pairing Dinner at a Frederick Keys/Potomac Nationals class A baseball game at Harry Grove Stadium in Frederick, MD. Clear, medium dark red amber with a thin off-white head and good lacing. Aroma of bread, caramel, spice, fruit, floral hops and composting leaves. Taste of brown bread, caramel, yeast, sweet dark fruit and earthy floral hops. Medium body and medium carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft. Caramel color, somewhat thick, high alcohol, a little sweet and malty. Pretty good but not my style choice.

On tap at the brewpub on 7/20/09: Transparent amber copper with a thin, wispy-lacing white head. Aroma of sweet caramely malt with a touch of light fruits. Starts with good fullness and sweet doughy caramel malt with good balance of noble hops before a bittersweet finish. True to style and enjoyable.
Pours clear dark amber with a one finger, off white head. Aroma is light caramel and a hint of roast. Taste is thin caramel, moving to Munich hops. Finish is light roast. An OK Marzen.

I really like this beer, and it reminds me quite a bit of SN’s current oktoberfest. Golden color, nice vinous maltiness, a bit juicy, toffee. Good peppery hoppiness, gives it a small kick and a balanced finish. Shows a little off-fruitiness if you drink it too warm, so put a good chill on it.

The aroma is milt and somewhat non-descript. The texture is very nice, buttery with good balanced hops acidity. The taste is a fine balance of hops and malt. The beer is eminently drinkable and not too heavy.

Tap into glass. Mahogany color, nose of maple? Oddly sweet at any rate. In the mouth malty with a crisp bite. Finishes with a bit more malt,a brief hit of sweet and lingering mild hops. Respectable if relatively unremarkable Americanized take on the style.
12oz in Boston. Warm and rich autumnal beer, heavier malting and sweet earthiness. better than a ’premium’ lager with richer caramel-copper malting and a little spice. Rich and tasty.
Not a lot of fragerance but has a wonderfuly crisp fall taste. A sharp, well balanced, yet wonderfuly light beer.

Bottle from Harvest Market Pours a clear copper color with a smallish off white head that hangs around for a bit. Light toffee and earthy floral hops in the aroma along with a hint of mineral water. The flavor is light toffee and sweet malts with a light fruity twang. Light earthy hop provides some balance. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a slick watery mouthfeel. Nothing horribly exciting here, pretty poor excuse for an Oktoberfest, I wouldn’t buy this again.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle. Brass-amber colored pour with a swiftly fading white head and busy carbonation. Nice aroma of toasted biscuit malts, caramel, butter, and general sweetness. The body is medium. The taste also has an upfront maltiness with a slightly more bitter bite but not in a floral, earthy hopped up fashion. Just a slight lingering finish. I enjoyed it.
Light musty caramel aroma. Copper orange color. Starchy malt flavor, light enough to have some bitter hops evident. Crisp like a pils, overall too light though.

Bottle from Half Time. Pours light copper with a slight, transient beige head. Mild caramel/roast aroma. Flavor starts toffee, moving to a bit bready, picking up some grassy? hop, and ending a little papery. Balanced, but rather bland.

On draft: Nice sweet wheat and herbal aroma. Golden yellow hue. Clean white head. Sweet maltiness and citrus flavors, some spice and clean crisp dry finish. A very enjoyable, quaffable brew. Always love the BBC's.

Draft: Foggy garnet. Microscopic bubbles slowly surface to form a small head. Unrefined aroma of spent hops, tobacco, red berries, and smoky molasses. Condensed carbonation. Heavily dense body, but equally slick. Spent hops prevail in the flavor over a shadow of tealeaves. Gritty with an earthy mulch texture and overbearing mineral and leathery astringency. Masked melon note lends much-needed softness to the body, but only somewhat compensates for its utter lack of finesse. Wet paper abounds, but, interestingly, there’s no sign of oxidation. Harsh, overexerted 2-row pungency runs rampant and compounds the overall wreck of flavors. Softly hoppy finish, but clamorously firm in body, as the more-vivid hop elements fail to blossom. While this showed no signs of overaging, the fact that it was virtually unpalatable, is quite puzzling.

Thanks to Tom Nickel for sharing this stuff with us. This stuff had some age but still had plenty of legs left. Heavy malt aroma and taste up front with flavors of dried fruits, toffee, caramel and sugary sweetness. Still had a nice hop bite to it along with a nice alcohol punch. I think this stuff was on the downside of what was a great life but still very enjoyable.

Pitcher. A poorly balanced beer that may have gone south, considering the lack of carbonation and the meek hop activity. Brown. Hints of caramel, apples, chocolate, resinous hops and a huge scent of wood in the aroma. Caramel and chocolate in the flavor, but above all this was served nearly flat and the flavor was just not there.

This beer was had on tap at the San Diego Strong Ale Festival 2004. This beer poured a dark mahogany and reddish mixture color with a thin tanned head and a good degree of lacing. Ahhhhh, the aroma... you can tell right away that this is a barleywine. Sweet malts, caramels and fruits clash with a sea of centennial hops. Sweet candy, caramel, cinnamon and brown sugar aroma with a hint of citrusy hops. The flavor develops into a long-lasting full bodied array of sweetness upfront followed by a bittering hoppy and cocoa, coffee bean clean finish. Slightly dry brown sugar in the finish as well. Very little alcohol presence, but just enough to pick it up in the finish. Sweet, but very well balanced and extremely full bodied...this could be a scary beer if bottled or aged!

Tasted at the 2004 Pizza Port Strong Ale Fest Amber brown color. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is cinnamon, caramel and malts. A medium to full bodied barley wine. Malts are fruity and sweet, touches of cinnamon and a little oak. There is also some nice spiciness going on here as well. Slightly bitter hops. Very smooth. Touch of molasses. An excellent sipping beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Very nice barley wine! Very rich brown and gold pour w/ a yellowish hue. Great head, and great lacing. Roasty, hazelnuts, and soury fermented fruit w/ hints of coffee in the mouth, and piney, soury fermented fruit and slight gym socks appeal on the nose. Creamy and yet aggresive w/ a full body.

(Draft: 2004 Strong Ale Festival, Pizza Port in Carlsbad, CA. Day 1, Beer 5) The nose is freshly hoppy and quite malty, with an odd woody aroma, perhaps some wild, brown mushrooms. The flavor follows suit, very earthy, woody and mushroomy, and also some moderate smoke. These are all the dominant flavors. It’s also moderately hoppy and malty, but it’s the funky flavors that really draw your attention. Maintains excellent balance from start to finish. Medium body, somewhat dense and coating on the palate, but the hops keeps the palate somewhat clean in the finish. Ruddy, light brown color, fairly cloudy in appearance. Very large tan head shrinks to but retains a thin layer, leaving some patchy lace. Deserves a controlled tasting session out of a real glass, and where the barleywine can warm to room temperature. The nuances are probably lost because the beers are too cold (it’s a cold night here in San Diego).

12/4/04. On draft at Pizza Port Strong Ale Fest in Carlsbad, CA 12/4/04. 2001 Vintage. Dark caramel brown with medium haziness. Deep orange outline on the glass. Awesome lacing. Funky cinnamon nutmeg aroma with a bit of a "foot" character. I’m not a foot fetishist, but I like it. Extremely interesting for a barleywine without completely abandoning the style. Big twigginess and aged malt. Cool mouthfeel with a sharp finish. Big woody flavors and bitter, seltzery soda. Nutty, citrusy with something lime-like beneath all the glory. Strange transformation in your mouth between the initial taste and the very nice finish. The flavor isn’t quite as strong as I’d like, but it’s very drinkable for the size and style. Probably the highlight of the Strong Ale Fest for me. I must’ve told 20-25 people that they HAVE to try the Tricentennial, and not a single one came back to me with a word of disappointment or complaint. I almost feel bad for giving this beer *only* a 4.3, but it was really a lovely, wonderful treat that I went back to time and again over the two days of the insane fest. I don’t know if or when I’ll ever be able to try this beer again, but I anxiously await that glorious day.

This barley wine pours with a deep amber body topped by a thick head with tons of lacing. The aroma is bitter and hoppy with alcohol esters, a strong pine note, some cinamon, and an underlying foot note. The flavor is slightly sweet yet bitter with piney notes, slight caramel notes and a touch of alcohol. Full bodied, tingly on the tongue and slightly dry.

2001 bottle from Tom himself. Yummy... POurs a dark, deep brown in color with aromas of fruit and brown sugar. Flavors of evergreens and brown sugar again, with a slight chocolate feel. Maybe the best barleywine i've had yet.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: September 19th, 2015 - Port's 15 Double Hop is a no frills, no thrills Double IPA. Clean and consistent, this is like the Sierra Nevada Pale Ale of DIPA's, and I love it. The color is a nice orange marmalade shade, with a generic IPA smell, and it's not even especially hoppy. But the flavor is where that brilliant familiarity lies. Balanced, good hops and a clean taste balanced on a comfortable body, this is a great beer to pair with food.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Taste pour from can as part of blind taste test from One Stop Market. Appearance is clear gold with gorgeous lazy sparkle with finger-width foamy off-white head with good retention and no lacing. Aroma is citrus pine and malty. Taste is strong caramel and bready malts with medicine-y alcohol not much hops except bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium side of light-to-medium bodied with smooth texture frothy carbonation and finish as taste. Overall nice mouthfeel but taste is more APA than IPA and IPA mostly for bitterness. High ratings seem to be from when bitter West-coast IPA's were king. Not feeling it in 2019.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Refrigerated 19.2 aluminum can poured into a glass. Clear golden with big white head. Aroma is herbal hops, medium body, well carbonated, and little lacing. Taste is herbal hops, floral hops, and bitter finish.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Intensive aroma of pine, flowers and citrus Taste: flowers, citrus, touch of honey. Bitter aftertaste with pine and citrus zest notes

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: this beer from the can is likely one of the best I have had. So complex, , clear deep golden, even some lacing at this abv.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Gravity cask at GBBF 2019. Orange-amber, clear, bubbly head. Acidic hop nose, citrus, light caramel, boozy. Sweet, smooth, boozy, caramel and sugar, orange, grapefruit, resins, bubble gum. Interesting and fun.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Bursztynowe lekko zamglone piwo z niezłą pianą. Aromat owocowy, leśny dość dużo żywicy, w tle słodowy. W smaku wytrawne dominują akcenty lasu iglaki i żywica, mało owoców, trochę syropowate. Finisz wytrawny. Niestety nie porwało

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Let hazy orange/rød/ravgylden, flot hvid skum som svinder. Umiddelbart lækker delikat lidt sødlig humle, efter lidt tid bliver den lidt mere tung, sprittet og lidt maltet. Smagen er meget fyldig, medium/høj bitter som rundes af af noget malt sødme, forholdsvis meget sprit, efter lidt tid i glasset er der næste lidt Barley Wine over den, lidt sødlig bitter eftersmag. Fin IPA, men måske lidt for sprittet.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Blond, licht troebel, bier met romige witte schuimkraag die redelijk snel inzakt. Volop hop, citrus, hars, steenvrucht. Behoorlijke volle body, medium bittere afdronk. Abv zit goed weggestopt. Drinkt te makkelijk weg. Top ipa.

column4: Port Brewing Company / The Lost Abbey
column5: Delicious double IPA from port here nice lacing and mouthfeel. Honestly can't taste a ton of hip burn and comes in at a whopping 11% abv

column1: Pizza Port Late Harvest 15 Year Anniversary Ale
column5: Thanks Jon! Pours a clear honey brown with very little head. Smells of leather, rich fruit, caramel. The taste is rich fruit, caramel, tangy, strange ending...dry. The body is light/medium without much carbonation.

column1: Pizza Port Late Harvest 15 Year Anniversary Ale
column5: 2002 Bottle at Monks after the cellar dinner. This bottle was totally grimed out from being in Tom’s cellar for the past 10 years. Poured a slightly hazy amber color, with thin off white head and a little bit of lacing. Aromas of wood, vinegar, dark grapes, plum, malts, pine, citrus. Taste was filled with delicious crystal malts and dark fruits, other notes of fig, pinot noir. Lots of vinous notes coming through with soft oak mouthfeel. Warming in the upper chest. Excellent beer, in my top 3 of the night.

column1: Pizza Port Late Harvest 15 Year Anniversary Ale
column5: A fairly old bottle. This beer was killer. Almost clear amber color with an off-white head. The aroma was fairly complex and not too oxidized. The aroma had a good sweetness to it with notes of Chardonnay, wood, and fruity malt. The flavor was malty with some vinous character as well. Hops really weren’t around but there was a bitterness at the finish that could have been from hops, the wood, or even the alcohol. There was enough flavor to cover it and any alcohol taste. Great warmth in the chest. Medium to full bodied. I didn’t even know this stuff existed. Yum

column1: Pizza Port Late Harvest 15 Year Anniversary Ale
column5: Tap @ 2004 Toronado Barley Wine Festival. Hazy amber color with a foamy white head. Light vinous flavors with a tiny bit of fruit in the flavor.

column1: Pizza Port Late Harvest 15 Year Anniversary Ale
column5: 2/21/04. On draft at Toronado Barley Wine Festival ’04 in San Francisco, CA 2/21/04. Dark copper-bronze color, almost like a plum wine. Scarlet edge. Not much head, but it's a rocky, very dark tan with slow and spotty lacing. Looks quite nice. But it isn’t. Not even close. Aroma is vinegary and vinous and holy shit. Flavor is grapey and vinegary, totally off-balance like I thought the beer was spoiled and off. A little leather pokes through, but doesn’t make it go down easier. This guy is a monster. But somehow, the body is surprisingly thin, also silky in texture. Finish is ridiculously hot and darkly malty beneath it all. Big grape flavors into wine with a sharp woodiness and balance like a one-man seesaw. What a disappointment.

column1: Pizza Port Late Harvest 15 Year Anniversary Ale
column5: This brew pours with a cloudy ddep amber body topped by a thin head with little lacing. The aroma is bitter, malty and oakey with lots of alcohol and a touch of fruit. The flavor is sweet yet bitter, woody and malty with a touch of friut and alcohol. Full bodied, smooth and warming.

column1: Pizza Port Late Harvest 15 Year Anniversary Ale
column5: I can't help but think it was not right (Toronado Barley Wine Fest '04) but because I was assured by several people that it was as it was supposed to be, I'll rate it. Where do I start? A dull, unenlightened brown. It is SOUR, but not in that good lambic-y way we're all familiar with. Aroma is actually quite nice--quite reminiscent of a good port, but perhaps a bit more treacly--lots of big fat red grape notes with smooth brown sugar/molasses malts. But flavor is surprisingly uncomplex, and bafflingly thin for such a big beer. Just sour with little or no malt complexity. Fetid. I did not find this complex or enjoyable in any way. Sorry.

column1: Pizza Port Late Harvest 15 Year Anniversary Ale
column5: Murky, no head, burgandy colored. Interesting beer. Reminds me of Levitation by Fish Tales. Wine character to it. Wood comes through quite clear, I'm not sure I pick up any of the hops. Sour finish. Well done and interesting.

column1: Pizza Port Late Harvest 15 Year Anniversary Ale
column5: Dark brown, flecks of red cranberry at the edges. . . Aroma of cherry malt, very good brown ale flavours, kicked up with undertones of the sour cherries, white grapes and green apples. Pretty good flavour, but a bit too 'winey' in the finish. Doesn't linger well for me.

column1: Pizza Port Late Harvest 15 Year Anniversary Ale
column5: Little head, immediately disapearing. Yeast in suspension. Deep brown beer with a reddish shine troughout. Nose: alcoholic - and a lot! Prunes - maybe slivovitch.
