Clear brown body with a small tan head, fading. The nose is light with clean yeast, herbs and caramel. The flavor is dry with light toffee, dough and flowers. Medium/light body is soft with light carbonation.

Now brewed by Otto’s for Kclinger’s in Hanover. Tawny brown colored body, moderately hazy, with a medium to small sized tan head. Sweet bready toffee malt nose, with a mildly starchy bread and cracker flavor, with mild use of hops. Some toasted maple and bread in the finish, and it dries a little bit as well. A good brown ale overall.
Had all the qualities of a nut brown ale. Had a dark brown coloring with a small head and a very slight hop aroma. Taste was smooth, but was a little too watery for my tastes.

Red in colour, as advertised. Quiet, malty aroma could use more punch but seems fairly inviting. Nice, round malt flavour feels good in the mouth and good going down. Some cherry traces add a welcome second dimension to the aroma and flavour. Not stunning by any means, but a nice, average, red-coloured ale.

I think that I must’ve gotten an off pint of this (which doesn’t completely surprise me, as I had it in a less reputable bar than C’est What), ’cause I didn’t like it nearly as much as most of the other raters. It looked OK, with a reddish color and a small white head. But there wasn’t much aroma to it, and the body was watery and not very flavourful. I just got a hint of fruitiness in the finish once it had warned up a bit. Not repulsive, just pretty bland.
Draught at C'est What. Reddish body with a white head. Decent red beer with a lot more hops in the flavour than I remember, almost citrusy in the finish now. Intriguingly pleasant.

Tasted in Toronto at C'est What. Aroma is slightly tart and sour with a hop like bitterness. Red colour, clear with light white head. Taste is slightly sour with tart finish and subtle hoppy bitterness.
reddish brown, small white head. clean, malty fruit flavours with slight notes of peach. hops balance out the finish. nice
Hoppy, thin red ale. It is has a very clean profile........................
Roasted malt aroma, clear ruby, very little head. Malt and nutty flavours, some bitterness, good after taste of malts. Nice tongue tingle, full bodied. Rich texture, a fine hardy amber!

This is a special brew made by Iron City (at least for this Oktoberfest), and I had it on tap at a bar. I've had much better oktoberfests... actually i thought it was fairly similar to the Augustiner Lager. Far superior than IC and IC Light but still nothing special.

I drank this beer in a restaurant in Vienna, Erdbergstrasse 111. After the good meal, this beer is find but there is nothing extraordinary. The body is yellow and gold, thin and white foam. The taste is ok for me, regular, sweet limonade with a side of malt, few hop, simple, drinkable with a meal or during the hot days.
Typical euro radler. Pale yellow, small white head. Lemony citric aroma, malty. Sweet taste, some soury feel from citric lemon. Ok when ice cold. Drinkable if nothing better.
Goldgelbes Radler mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr süß nach Limo. Geschmack startet sehr süß nach Limo, vom Bier keine Spur.
Yellow colour, no head at all, strong citrus aroma. lemon taste. Not very good. Thera are better beer mixes on the market
Can. Clear pale yellow with medium white head. Aroma is malt and artificial lemon. Flavour is malt, sweet, artificial lemon, sugar and a little watery.
Pours pale green with a fully gone head. Aroma is citrusy. Sweet and citrusy flavoured. Sweet and citric finish.
can. better ice cold. taste and palate are very light, no head, soft yellow color.
Can @ Papsø-Grand-Tasting, September 2010. Pours clear pale yellow with no head. Lemon, citrus, dishwasher. Not good. Short end.

Can 500ml. Clear light to medium yellow color with a small, fizzy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, white head. Aroma is light malty, grain, toasted, moderate citrus, lemon. Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration, cardboard, lime. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20100912]
Can at Papsø’s - Thanks. Clear golden - white head. Sweetness, soda-pop, cardboard, candy, artificial, boring.

12 oz bottle purchased at Four Firkins in St Louis Park, Minnesota. Pour is a dirty golden, hazed, with a foamy two inch white head. Some fine carbonation bubbles and floaties appear in the glass. Aroma is cracker grain, and sort of a dull earthiness - not aggressively dirty, but not real clean either. Taste is the malt and grains, along with light lemon sweet citrus, and followed by the earthy dirt of the nose. Nice and refreshing until the finish. Palate is light to medium bodied, active scrubbing carbonation and the unfortunate dirt aftertaste. Overall, still a decent enough beer.

Appearance: Pours a thin, clear yellow body with a small white head. Smell: Lactic, soured wheat aroma. Ugh, everything’s all messed up! Taste: Good grief. Extremely lactic taste overall, a hint of adjuncts here and there, but it’s simply unfinishable. Lord knows I tried! Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Mild carbonation. Drinkability: "White weasel" has since become sort of a colloquial saying around these parts.

Date: 09/08/2007 Mode: Bottle Source: Tasting, Cellar Party Appearance: hazy light yellow, wispy white head, Aroma: lactic aroma of a wet straw weasel bed, Body: thin body, Flavor: tart and lactic malt flavor, Overall: each northwoods is worse than the last Aroma: 2/10; Appearance: 4/10; Flavor: 2/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 3/20 Rating: 1.1/5.0 Drinkability: 2/10 Score: -/4

Pours a transparent pale golden with a thin, spotty-lacing white head. Aroma of grainy adjuncts, sauerkraut and tart infectious bacteria. Starts thin, watery, sour and a pretty much drainpour. Tastes like everything else I’ve had from them.

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle from the brewpub. Pours a very light blonde pale brew with no head. Only a few bubbles on edge of glass. Aroma of multi-grain, steamed rice, with some flowery hops. Taste is highly carbonated, watered down orange peel, some corn flake character and light sweet flowery finish. Palate is too clean and very watered down.
Pours golden yellow with thin white head. Aroma of corn and grains. Flavor is more of the same, but adds some faint sugar and hops.
clear yellow tiny white head. Dry barley and corn bland smell. average palate. Flavor is corn and barley some sweet sugars.. very bud like.

Hazy Yellow Coloring with White Ring. Faint Wheat Aroma. Wheat, Lemon Notes on the Tongue...Faint Hops as Well. Very Drinkable. Agreeably Not a Cream as Much as an American Wheat Style Brew. Actually one of Their Tastier / Non-Offending Brews, if Not the Best So Far.

Yellow color with a thin head. A little wheat for the aroma. The taste is a passable rendition of a wheat with some citrus as well. Disturbingly enough, not a bad little beer. Oh... it’s a cream ale? Um, no... but it’s drinkable.

Actually one of the best brews of the night even though I was rushed out of the bar at 11:00 (slow night). Light hazy straw color with a wispy white head. Light cotton candy aromas. Mild wheat and light citrus flavors. Now I see the description as a cream ale. Seemed more like a a wit. This place really has to decide on its style and how they are going to brew.

The Aromas are toffee, herbal, dark malt and a hint of roast. Flavors are like nose, on the sweet side. Slightly thin body yet strong carbonation. I just cannot imagine how this recipe won an award at gabf

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear copper amber with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma is mild wit light caramel and a hint of sweet grains. Flavor is thin with sweet bread and a hint of caramel.
Stopped in at the brew pub. Really dark brown body for a brown ale. Slight malt aroma. Mild bitter taste with a hint of sweet caramel.
12oz bottle pours a reddish brown with a medium off-white head and nice lacing. Nice Saturday afternoon guzzler.

Bottle. Pours a beautiful clear ruby black witha shall creamy tan head and nice lacing. Aroma is light roasty, a bit of caramel. Flavor is rich roasty, touches of coffee and smoke. Light sweet, little bitterness, light astringence. Medium body.
Had it on tap at Northwoods BrewPub in Eau Claire Wisconsin. What can I say, the score says it all. I will say it is hazy brown in color low hop aroma and slightly sweet.
Tasted at Northwoods Brewpub. Rich clear brown with off white head. A bit sweet with a touch of hop. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured a very dark, reddish brown with a minimal beige head and like lacing. Aroma was of weak sweet malts. Taste was of roasted/burnt malts with a slight hop finish. Palate was OK. Overall, not a bad brown but I have had better.

Bottle from Skyview, thanks! Clear chestnut with a thin tan head. Aroma is faint yet malty with nuts and light breadiness. Taste is meh with nuts, malt, toffee and malt. Thin bodied and par for their course.

Shared 12 oz. bottle at a monthly geek tasting. Poured to a sampler with a ruby highlighted, dark brown color, modest off white/light tan head foam, and light, streaks & spots of lacing. The nose was a very light, uneventful aroma expression of the flavor, which was light nuttiness, and cloying sweetness of caramel, molasses, and toffee. Toasty malt, hop bitterness, and carbonation were soft, the body was fairly light, and the texture was watery. Nice potential in the variety of notes, but basically came off as an average, homebrew entry.

Tasted this in the Saltcot, Saltcoats (JDW) in May 2006. Cask, handpump dispense. Clear pale amber in colour with a thin white head. Floral hops present in the short aroma. Thin resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts gives a slight digestive biscuit flavour in the mouth. Dry hops flowers add an astringent bitterness to the aftertaste. Finish is insipid and slightly malty. Yet another!
cask at clockwork. amber with a light bubbly head. firm texture, some lemon rind aroma, decent citric bitterness, quite pleasant
Cask ... Copper colour ... ligth fruity nose ... mellow hop fruit ... little spice...nothign special but ok
Cask at Abbotsford, Edinburgh. Amber colour. Light bodied with floral hops. Bit dry and fishy.

Cask conditioned at The Guildford Arms, Edinburgh. Deep amber to copper coloured beer, creamy head. Nice hoppy and fruity aroma, nearly vinous. Moderately fruity and malty flavour, moderate bitterness, dusty hops in the finish.

A Mes rate: Cask handpull at the Guildford Arms. Oily golden brown with a creamy off white head. Bitter hop aroma with some light malty balance. Nice distinctive hoppy flavour with a blanced malty finish. Very straight forward but decent all the same.
Cask, Clockwork, Glasgow, RBESG 07. Clear copper, laced white head. Citrus hop, some maltiness. Really fruity mouth. Some toffee malt present, but quite light.

Cask at The Wellington, Birmingham. Dark golden with a short white foamy head. Orange aroma, with taste of fruit berries and grass. Not too sweet or too bitter. Just right: simple, straightforward and refreshing.
[cask from JDW] Flowery, sweet fruit aroma, background malt presence. light body, sweet finish.
Good colour, not goldy not amber at all, foam somewhat thick. NOt annoying, almost bitter, but too sweet for being so.
Sampled cask conditioned at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden. Deep ruby. Chocolatey aroma. Sweet and light bodied, slightly fruity. Short flavour and clean finish.

Tasted this at the Paisley Beer Festival in April 2000. Cask, handpump dispense. Crystal clear pale amber in colour with a thin white head. Fragrant floral aromas present but short in intensity. Thin resiny mouthfeel and good lacing. Pale malts give a strong juicy, fruity peach and lychees flavour full in the mouth. Floral dusty hops compliment the malt well and give a short bitter bite to the aromatic aftertaste. Finish has a slightly sweet edge with a hint of golden syrup in there. An excellent summer session ale.
Cask Handpump at the Baltic Fleet, Liverpool 16/06/2002 Golden amber colour and hoppy. Hint of ginger. Dry finish.

500ml bottle from Fabeers, York. I’m guessing this was pasteurised, but I can’t be 100% certain. Not sure that its made any more and this was a couple of months past its best before date, but I picked it up anyway in case I can’t get it again. Deep red/brown colour with scant head. Cardboard and caramel malt aroma. Very heavy toffee flavour, with more caramel and hints of treacle. Dry malty finish but not a lot of bitterness. Definitely 80/- in style. Didn’t really go a bundle on it, but I’m not a great fan of the style anyway, so I haven’t marked it down too much.
A brown beer with a small beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel and hops. The flavor is of roasted bread, hops, and burnt caramel, leading to a dry roasted end.
Nice hint of malt and a pleasing sweetness.Pleasant without being outstanding.
Cask Conditioned at The Hobgoblin, Oxford. Amber coloured beer, bubbly head. Caramel malts with an orangey undertone. A little thin on the tongue and slightly sweet.
Bottled. Amber with a reddish tinge, stable white head. Roasted malt aroma, amidst good servings of honey and maple syrup. The sweetness transfers to the flavour and stops abruptly on the palate.

Forth Brewery was founded by partners in the Maclay Brewery which stopped brewing in 1999 passing production to Belhaven. Output and range are still limited at the moment, but if this Puffer Ale is an example of what is to come they should do well. This is a good example of an 80/- Ale: rust, blood, pregnant fruit and toffee apples. This was the bottled version and, though fresh up front, did have a metallic, stewed hops finish.
Sampled cask conditioned at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden. Deep ruby. No head. Fruity and somewhat chocolatey. Medium bodied, sweet. Clean finish with low bitterness.

column1: La Barberie Rousse au Miel de Sarrasin
column5: Bouteille 500ml. Nez de céréales terreuses aux petites notes sûres, léger de miel avec des notes de noix. Aqueuse en bouche. Goût de grains de céréales aux notes acides et terreuses avec un léger goût de noix lors de l’entrée en bouche suivi d’un goût sucré de miel avec des traces de pain et de caramel doux et finalement une très légère amertume de houblon herbeux. Post-goût très légèrement amer de houblon herbeux avec une goût de noisettes et quelques traces de de céréales sûres.

column1: La Barberie Rousse au Miel de Sarrasin
column5: Bottle (500ml). Via trade with Lubiere. Reddish-brown, hazy, with a huge tan foamy-fizzy head. Aroma of slightly vegetal malt, honey, light spice, maybe a hint of toffee - a touch sour. Taste is odd - watery sour red table wine, light molasses, a little earthy and a strange almost chemical aftertaste that lingers a long time. Mouthfeel is acidic, watery, harshly ... something, only slightly carbonated. Not my favourite - is it supposed to be sour and peppery like this?

column1: La Barberie Rousse au Miel de Sarrasin
column5: Pas un très bon mélange; miel et sarrasin. Elle est buvable, mais il y mieux.

column1: La Barberie Rousse au Miel de Sarrasin
column5: Deep red copper with a thick creamy white head. Sweet malt with notes of buckwheat flour. Very malty and nutty ale, with a bit of a lactic point and buckwheat in mouth. A bit light bodied.

column1: La Barberie Rousse au Miel de Sarrasin
column5: (5oo ml bottle) Pours a large, almond head and a cloudy mahogany body. Very pretty to look at... but looks can be deceiving! Nose is slight honey and vinegar with undertones of whiskey. Most sour beer EVER. La Barberie and Schoune must have the same brewmaster becase the consistency for spoiled beer is an ALARMING rate!

column1: La Barberie Rousse au Miel de Sarrasin
column5: Cloudy indian red color. The nose is yeasty and fruity. Some tartness in the body, light fruitiness and a light hoppiness. Pretty straighforward.

column1: La Barberie Rousse au Miel de Sarrasin
column5: Hazy dark reddish amber. Slightly medicianl in the nose with honeyish notes and foresty hops. Palate is stale wood, dust and decrepit fences on old farm roads....yeast ferments mildew into a dry fizzy finish. Aroma is a good start but this one got away from the brewer at some point.

column1: La Barberie Rousse au Miel de Sarrasin
column5: Dark murky brown in colour. Aroma was a bit metalic but at the same time still had some citrus notes. Flavour was tart, acidic and a little metallic. Overall, not very interesting.

column1: La Barberie Rousse au Miel de Sarrasin
column5: Sweet fieldberry malt stabbed by a rotten metal dagger...No finish...Death...Silence...A lurid, metallic aroma hovers in the palate...

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Solstice d'Été aux Bleuets
column5: Acid, a bit tart and fruity but I would have liked to taste the blueberries more.

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Solstice d'Été aux Bleuets
column5: Wonderful acidity of a berliner weisse which transforms into a sweet blueberry juice at the halfway point and finishes that way...From one end of the spectrum to the other, this weisse is well-done, but its sweetness gets tiring...I prefer their berliner with raspberries...

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Cuvée de l'Alchimiste 09
column5: For a scottish ale, it could use more "smokeyness". It is really a session ale, light enough on the body, relatively low hopping although the bitterness is somewhat arresting (a common trait amongst DDC beers).

column1: Dieu du Ciel! Cuvée de l'Alchimiste 09
column5: Cousin to their Première Communion, a quaffable caramel sweetness floating on a touch of citrus...Hop bitterness surreptitiously surfaces in the end and balance is attained...Needs a cask...
Nice malty aroma, with an even better mixed malt taste with just a little bit of smoke. A big win for Duclaw with this one!
This beer is amazing, not to much of a smoke flavor, but there is a large caramel sweetness but it is well balanced, pours a deep mahoghany, delicious.

Sweet sassy Jesus! I go on this website to see some beer reviews and I get a bunch of namby pamby pretention about aromas of raisins and boozy aftertastes (with yanni playing in the background). Holy smokes people, this Isnt how you rate beer! I’ll show you how to rate twisted kilt. First, you put on some Amon Amarth. Then you open up your growler and pour a half liter of brown gold into a freezer chilled ceramic 0.5L mug. Appearance? Unnecessary. Give it a sniff, you will find it stinks a little, its probably the only thing that sucks about this beer. Then you tilt er back, and take a nice frosty pull. Its a good smokey red all right, with just a bit too much sugar. They kept off the hops like no one seems to be able to do or understand. DuClaw is usually good at that; laying off the hops. Take that first mug in about 7 swills. Pour out another 0.5L, new mug, just as frozen as the first. Let that tan head overflow a little. This is humanity right here. Letting that tan head overflow, going a bit farther than necessary. Now take another swig. The sugar is starting to get to you. You think: "just a little less sugar and it would be so damn perfect". Oh well, finish this one. People have been tortured to death for multiple days on end, you can handle a second beer with a bit of stink and too much sugar. Pour a third beer. If you are out of frozen mugs, you are a loser. This one starts to teach you. That sugar is still a bit much, but that stink is gone. This is a good pint. Feel free to air guitar. Finish the growler in the last of your pints. Does it matter anymore? Life is great. This is a good beer, and we are free to enjoy it.

Reviewed from notes. Pours a very dark brown with a tan head that recedes fairly quickly. The nose is roasted malt, dark fruits, sweet malt, and a bit of smoke. Taste brings light smoke and some dark malt. A bit of dark fruit. Fairly hefty body with a bit of alcohol. Drinkability i okay, but it’s fairly run of the mill. Serving type: on-tap Reviewed on: 11-10-2010
Pint: poured a copper color with a very thin off white head. Very sweet taste and lasting aftertaste.
on tap-pours an off white head and copper color. Aroma is sweet medium malt-caramel/peat, earthy. Taste is medium malt-caramel/peat/chocolate, earthy, hops bite.

Draft at Bowie location. Arrived at the table a reddish amber color with a thin tan head. A sweet aroma of caramel, vanilla extract, burnt malts, and wet cardboard. Thin to medium-bodied. Very sweet taste throughout. Lots of caramel, burnt maltiness, chocolate, and some vanilla extract upfront. Roasty coffee follows. Some weird smokiness and a touch of alcohol warmth at the end.
Not bad. Im not a fan of scotch ales but this one was pretty good and worth a try. Smokey, caramel, sweet. Good, but not great.

On tap @ Bel Air-Reddish/Mahogany color w/no head but some minimal lacing. Sweet malt aroma. Had a smokey, woodsy flavor: peat, roasted malt, caramel, toffee. Had some bite to it; pretty smooth & easy to drink. Reminded me of the Misfit Red, but a little rougher around the edges. Long sweet finish. Decent brew.

pours a beautiful caramel brown. not much head. aroma of caramel, milk and baking chocloates, and a smoky/peaty character. Flavor was heavy chocolate, malted milkshake (chocolate, of course), toffee, caramel, and peat/ smoke. pretty good. Aftertaste was sweet caramel malt. Easy drinking. nice and viscous.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. A very standard lager beer. How many of this boring lagers with different labels do Aass bother to make?
A not too bad rendition of pale european lager. Not much can be said. Slightly malty. Serving: Can
Can, what can you do when skiing in Norway and finshed the beers the we brought with us? Works in the sauna do.
Pours a nice light golden yellow. Aromas of hops, grass, and maybe corn. Taste is crisp with a nice mellow hop flavor. Still better than Bud/Coors/Miller light products.
(Can 50 cl) Golden with a nice head - yet surprisingly hazy. Fresh, slightly bitter with an odd tartness coming close to Swedish "Färsk-öl". Canned for the American market. 221203

When I sampled this for the first time, 2 years ago, I declared that I could drink it for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Now. I was probably trying to get on the good side of the pretty girl who poured it for me, but I was impressed, though I'm an ale man, and I really coouldn't down too many lagers in a row, unless forced to do so... Thin, white bubbly head forms a small ivory ring over a typical lager hue, pale yellow. Aroma greets the nose happily, with dry, floral, citrusy notes, lots of lemon. Highly aromatic from the moment the can is opened. Mouthfeel is straightforward, unintrusive, clean, pleasant. A sweet and happy finish that walks along your tongue, taking it's time. Light body, very tasty. Just what you need in a lager.Excellent on draft, too

From a can, beer pours (in Chimay glass) a very light applejuice (piss, read 'urine')-golden color with virgin-white, small-bubbled head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is of burned wood citrus with straw. Flavor is a slight citrus coverup to straw, and generally bland tasting liquid. Heard great things about this drainpour of yucky yellow beer. So much for celebrating #50. Sampled at 71 degrees Fahrenheit.

Light yellow/straw color. Tiny white head fizzes away. Almost no aroma. After thourougly enjoying the Aass Classic, I was disappointed by this watered down version. Had some straw flavor with some malt, but was too thin. Not much to write this beer just didnt have enough there (wasnt overly carbonated though!). Get Aass Classic if you want a real treat from this brewery.

Color is clear golden yellow with a creamy-like head that was just over a finger high leaving nice sheets of light lacing as it settled. Smell is faintly of a grainy malt thats a tad sweet and has a floral grassy/hay like hop note in the back. Taste is clean and sweet of a lightly roasted malt, held back, tamed crispness thats balanced in well with a hop thats a floral, bittering, piney dryness. Feels smooth and clean, slightly acidic, light to medium bodied with a good hold of light sweetness and piney tang dryness thats very easy to handle. Everything about this beer states balance, balance between sweet, crisp, dry, with smooth, tart, clean, just about all this beer emcompasses in its flavor and feel just makes it a very easy, smooth, and good drinker.
I tasted a full-alcoholic version, so, I cannot call it "watery". It's rather very ordinary lager but quite drinkable with some hops in the finish.
Malty aroma with a bit of hops which I found unusual. Darker colored oktoberfest. Has a strange sweetness that I enjoy but can’t pinpoint.

Deep amber. Mostly caramel malts and herbal/earthy hops. Brief caramel malt sweetness that is ultimately taken over by the hops. A strange herbal-like hop bitterness that lingers a bit. Not a good match.
Sampler, nice dark amber color, of white head, sweet malt aroma, some hops on the finish, smooth good balance, flavor sweet malts to hops with a bit of toast and honey.

On draught during GTMW 2010 in Madison, Wisconsin. Pours a bright orange amber colored brew with a thin and creamy off-white head that quickly dissipates to a fine film and a thin ring. Aroma of caramel malt, a hint of honey, roasted nuts and a touch of almond marzipan. Taste is medium, bodied, smooth and creamy with flavors of sweet caramel malt, floral hops and a hint of honey. Finish is malty (Bavarian Style) with a caramel and floral hop aftertaste. A solid märzen throughout.

Orange Autumn Coloring with White Ring. Sweet Malt and Light Autumn Spices..Medium Mouthfeel..Sweet Malt, Caramel Notes on the Tongue...Light Hop Ending. Light Alcohol Notes Detected and Overall a Sweet Brew.
Sample; Aroma of malty sweet and spices. Medium bodied with sweet mals and spices as well. Orange body with off white head.

Pint at the brewpub. Deep solid amber with a touch of head...malty, sweet, a bit raisiny in the body, just a hint of toastiness, and a fairly large smack of alcohol...body reminds me of caramel-apples, but with rum injected into them..syrupy, a bit too boozy, some nice toasty malts are present but for me the alcohol is just too much for this session style. Rather harsh finish.

Magnifying bright orange in color with a thin and creamy peach colored head. Squeezable plastic toys register first for aroma, anteceded by honey roasted almonds, fading Nutella, caramel, butterscotch and autumnal potpourri. Nice sweet and nutty flavor profile. A delectable mix of brown sugar sprinkled pecans and pistachio, complimented by a maple and honey one-two combo. Carbonation levels are nearly perfect, and the oaken and nutty sweetness derived from patience in lagering is greatly appreciated. Just enough spiciness to seal the deal, protruding with pepper and rye. Therein lies the finish, along with a sweetened brand flake cereal aftertaste. Very well done.
Amber color with no head. Sweet alcohol aroma. Light malt flavor with some honey to sweeten the mix. Very drinkable and a nice example for the style.

On tap at the Brewhaus. Very light, very short-lived head. Yes, it looks like the amber, maybe a little deeper red. The alcohol this year is 6.9, and it is noticeable but not in your face. Very malty and sweet, but not cloyingly so, this is dangerously drinkable. Similar in style, but bolder in flavor, than the Pschorr Brau Octoberfest.
(En fût à la source): Encore une fois des traces de diacétyl mais ce n’est pas un désastre. Minéral et assez neutre mis à part l’agrume et la touche miellée.

Sampled at GABF 2015. In the tasting glass was a golden amber with an off white head. Nose of caramel malts. Some citrus. Medium body. Flavor is malts and hops in good balance. Some bitterness which makes it taste more like an English Bitter to me. Quite good.

Pint at the brewpub/casino. Pours a crystalline, pretty red hue with a tall off white head. No surprises in the aroma, unpleasant or otherwise. Clean citrus hops, biscuity malts. A hint of toffee. Clean drinking and well balanced amber ale. Palate is medium. Nice accessible American hoppiness in the flavor with a sturdy malt base. Finish is like biscuits and grapefruit juice. I’m sure beer snobs will crush this one for being boring, which it is. Still a well made, good drinkin’ brew though.
On tap at the brewpub. Comes golden brown with a small beige head. Aroma of malt, citrus, and caramel. Taste is similar. Decent, nothing bad, nothing good.

On tap at the brewery. Golden amber and clear appearance with a small white head. Not much aroma, toasted grains and light hops. Flavor is similar, a bit bland, not too much going on. Light, thin body. My least favorite of the four I tried.

From a kegerator at Voss Farms, Arvada. Poured a clear amber with a small lingering white head. Aromas of toffee, biscuit, and a hint of fruittiness. Pretty light/medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of straw, toffee, a light touch of caramel fruitiness...not bad, just a little plain and thin.

tap, this beer was described as a bitter. Pours a gold brown with creamy white head. Mild aroma malt dominated but with some hops too. Overaly carbonated mouth, medium bodied. Bland copper hay flavor, a bad bitter.
Amber gold/foamy off-white head. Mild floral/malty aromas. Flavor same with an interesting citrus touch. Wife thought it excellent. And she tends to avoid beer.

On tap at Dostal Alley poured a clear amber with a small lingering off white head. Aromas of carmel and a hint of fruittiness. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, straw and light fruittiness with a smooth malty finish.

English Pub Ale Dostals Best Bitter–on tap-pours a creamy light tan head that laces and gold/orange color. Aroma is sweet malt-caramel, secondary citrus hops. Taste is sweet malt-caramel, secondary citrus hops, mellow, maybe too mellow. Mild carbonation. A good Bitter, a less than average taste if it is an APA.
Sampled at Great American Beer Festival 2019 in Denver, Colorado. Roasty, coffee, dry.
(En fût à la source): Un liquide mince et très porté sur le cendrier. Des résidus de mélasse faible et de pain brulé reste sur la langue, sinon c’est assez tranquille.

Sampled at GABF 2015. In the sample glass was dark almost black with a tan cap of foam. Nose of coffee and roasted malts. Body is medium. Flavor is dark roasted malts and the finish shows coffee and some hops. Pretty nice.
Tap at Dostal Alley. Pours black with tan head. Aroma of tobacco, espresso, chocolate. Taste is very dry, medium bodied, medium carbonation, a bit thin for style. Overall, eh.
Sample at GABF 2014. Comes black with a small tan head. Aroma of malt and chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, and coffee. Enjoyable.

Draft. Black color, caramel color head, smoke and toasted almond aroma, surprisingly light bodied, goes down real easy, smooth and nice overall light experience. That said I prefer a more hardy stout.
Tap at the brewpub. Black/3 finger creamy dark tan head - really dark roast aroma - suggests BA - some coffee. Flavor is burnt malt and hoppy - passing on to strong coffee. Really has character.

Draught at Dostal Alley. Pours opaque with a medium, creamy tan head, good retention. Aroma is dark malt (chocolate, coffee), with leathery yeast, dark fruit, and light hops. Flavor is moderate bitter dark malt, lightly bitter hops, leather, earth and peat. Medium bodied, medium carbonation, and a creamy texture with a dry finish.
One of the best Classic Dry Irish Stouts I’ve had. Tastes like Guiness when it was actually brewed at St. James Gate.

On tap at Dostal Alley poured a clear dark brown nearly black with a small lingering brown head. Aromas of roasted malt, charcoal, coffee and dark chocolate. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roasted malt, dark chocolate, light coffee and a hint of vanilla with a smooth lingering roasty finish.

column1: Dostal Alley Jacob Macks Mild Ale
column5: (En fût à la source): Un léger glissement de diacétyl dans une Mild très caramélisée avec une touche noble.

column1: Dostal Alley Jacob Macks Mild Ale
column5: Sampled at GABF 2015. In the sample glass amber brown with an off white head. Nose of caramel malts and some floral hop;s. Medium body. Flavor is roasted malts, some floral hops, and a nutty bitter finish. Quite nice.

column1: Dostal Alley Jacob Macks Mild Ale
column5: On tap at the brewery. Amber and clear appearance with a white head. Aroma of toasted grains and light caramel. The flavor adds a light smokiness and peated malts. Light body with a smooth finish. Not bad.

column1: Dostal Alley Jacob Macks Mild Ale
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Comes golden amber with a decent tan head. Aroma of malt, grain, and grass. Taste is caramel malt, grain, and grass. Easy to drink.

column1: Dostal Alley Jacob Macks Mild Ale
column5: tap. Pours dark brown with creamy white head. Aroma sweet and malty, caramel. Medium bodied and medium to low carbonation. Flavor of caramel, some hay malt, and more hoppy than expected, although not "hoppy" per se with a slight coppery aspect, and a crispness. Overall my favorite beer of the 4 I tried at dostal alley, not bad at all.

column1: Dostal Alley Jacob Macks Mild Ale
column5: Tap at casino. Pour was a light brownish color with a cream colored head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, earth and some very light hops (which I was told were grown by the locals). The taste was malty, slightly sweet, with a minute hop presence. Not even enough to create any bitterness. It had a creamy, medium body that would have made it extremely easy to drink several. Nothing fancy here, but enjoyable stuff.

column1: Dostal Alley Jacob Macks Mild Ale
column5: Brown/creamy beige head. Creamy roast malt aroma - typical brown. Smooth brown malt flavor with some light chocolate. Very smooth and tasty. Mild ale? Seems more of a brown. But the bar guy was firm, and the tap handle backed him up.

column1: Dostal Alley Jacob Macks Mild Ale
column5: (Draught) Pours a hazy deep amber body with a medium cream head. Aroma of earth, grass, caramel, and grain. Flavor of roasted grain, caramel, earth, and nuts.

column1: Dostal Alley Jacob Macks Mild Ale
column5: On tap at Dostal Alley poured a clear reddish brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of carmel, graininess, earthiness and light butterscotch. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of carmel, earthiness and light graininess with a smooth dry malty finish.

column1: Dostal Alley Jacob Macks Mild Ale
column5: on tap-pours a tan head and brown color. Aroma is sweet malt-caramel. Taste is sweet malt-caramel, secondary hops with slight bite. OK carbonation.

Keg at the brewpub, 8/16/16. Clear copper, large creamy off-white head, good retention. Aroma of citrus, lemongrass, pale malt. The taste is lemongrass, lemon, lime, pale malt. Medium bodied, mild lingering bitterness, well balanced.

Tap pour - orangey-gold body, minimal white head. Aroma showcases the citra hops...I know they’re used in everything now, and I’m still okay with this. Flavor is moderately bitter, but turns sweet mid-sip...finishes with the bitter hop character. Good mouthfeel - mildly creamy. Not a bad beer by any means, though not a whole lot to make it stand out in a crowd...

Draft at the Delafield Brewhaus. Copper color with substantial lacing. Pine and brown sugar aroma. Pine and sweet malt flavors; sweet and not overly hoppy. Later bodied. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Sampled at great taste. Deep golden and hazy. A nice bitterbite to it. Flavor as big as some doubles. Earthy. Fruit is complex.

Draft at brewpub. Clear medium amber. Medium creamy white head, fairly lasting with good lace. Biscuits. Caramel. Pine. Grapefruit. Citrus. Finish. Resin pine earth. Md body. Moderate drying. Medium bitter. Medium sweet. Touch oily. Not too complex. Balanced. Good drinkability. Pleasant.

Draft at the brewery. Filtered orange-tan. Big, steady off-white/beige head. A fairly reasonable IPA. Pretty well balanced with some nice citrus hop characteristics. Toasty, some fruity butterscotch tones. Not world class by any means, but captures the style. One dimensional and somewhat soapy.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a hazy orange with no carbonation. Aroma is fresh fruit, pine with some floralness. Taste is much maltier than the aroma, but also nice bitter fruit and syrupy resin. Nice flavor. Great hoppy burp. Finishes medium strong and quite bitter. Nice effort!

Draught at the BrewPub: Aroma of malt, caramel, Earth, leaves, and hops. Poured amber in color with a medium-sized, creamy, dense, off-white head diminished but lasted throughout. A few small and medium-sized particles. Clear. Lightly sparkling. Very good lacing. Flavor is medium sweet and light to medium bitter. Tastes of caramel, light hops, light Earth, and leaves. Medium body. Average, lightly dry texture. Average carbonation. Medium sweet, lightly bitter, caramel, malt, light hop, and light Earth finish is slightly dry.

On tap at brewpub, pours a clear copper with a thin head and some spotty lacing, the aroma has a light hoppy kick with some tropical fruit mixed in, the flavor isn’t as intense I was hoping for but still had some citrus in the finish, kind of a thin overall, not bad.

On tap at the Delafield Brewhaus. Amber with a thin tan head. Aroma of pine, caramel and grapefruit. Taste of pine, grapefruit and sweet malt with a piney resinous finish. Mildly abrasive and some vegetal qualities come through.
Keg at the brewpub, 8/16/16. Clear amber, large creamy off-white head, good retention. Aroma of toasted caramel malt, mild fruitiness. The taste is caramel and bready malt. Thin.
Pours hazy copper color with malty aroma. Toffee with orange notes for taste. Easy drinker.
Draft at the Delafield Brewhaus. Copper color. Sweet multi flavor with orange citrus notes. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Smells like chocolate the appearance is dark amber color tastes like malty Coco. Sits well on the palate. Another descent amber ale.
Tap. Pours deep orange with white head. Aroma is a bit dirty, nutty. Taste is very malty, flat, a bit boring, malt forward. Needs something more. Meh.
Draft at the brewpub. Pretty standard American amber. Textbook color, middle of the road caramel malt ambiance. Easy drinker. (#5092, 7/2/2013)
Dark amber, little carbonation. Slightly sweet. Funky flavor and aroma. Somewhat wild ale character. slight dry finish

Sampled from the tap at the brewpub. Pours a near clear amber with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a strong malt note of hay, bread and grain without much else. Flavor has a bit of earthy grass up front, but mainly has notes of hay and bread.

Draft at the brewery. Filtered orange-tan with a thin, steady off-white head. I’m not really an Amber fan in the first place, but this is pretty sub-par stuff. Dull malt tones, somewhat rancid and butterscotchy. Off flavors galore, no hop presence. Belongs at Calumet. Gross.
Tap at the brewpub. Orange pour with a thin white head. Sweet caramel malt nose. Medium palate. Really nice sweet caramel malt flavor - good stuff.

Bottle at MBC after band concert brewing. Dark amber color with a moderate white head that diminished slowly with small lacing. Moderate sweet hop aroma. Medium body with creamy texture. Medium flavor with small bitter finish.
They really went wrong with this beer. I believe it is one of the other beer lines with just a slight variation of flavoring added.

I thought I was drinking plastic for a moment. Something must have gone astray in the fermenter, because the off-flavors were not acceptable. Perhaps it is the hops, but these hops taste like they were grown in my asshole. A good bargain...

Picked up two cases for $30 at the brewery. Tastes a bit cidery and uses hops to cover the higher than average alcohol content. It goes down smooth, but the flavors don't mesh together all that well. An average beer, but definitely worth it at that price.

Bottled version. Unimpressive, cloudy golden body and an instantly fading head. There's a definite citrus aroma, orange, some pinapple and hop resin. I'm not quite sure what they were aiming for here. I think it's supposed to be an APA, but the result is sort of twisted. This beer reminds me of the not-quite-premium from concentrate orange juice, which tastes a little stale and has an awkward bitterness to it. MBC's Lake Effect Pale Ale is much better.

330 ml can. (Joker) Bjerkvik, Norway. Enjoyed on Oct 6, 2019. Clear dark golden color with a medium size white head. Bready and malty aroma. The flavor is bready malt, mild bitterness and cardboard. Quite typical non-alcoholic.
Can 330ml (Kirkenes) Golden colour, small white head. Light sweetish aroma of malts. Light to medium-bodied. Quite dry for NA. Light worts and breadyness. Aftertaste has more sweetness. Harmless.
Lys gulbrun klar med høyt hvitt skum. Lukter honning og maltekstrakt. Lett. Vannete. Kort

Aroma eple, malt. Utseende lys gul med hvitt skum. Smak eple, malt, humle. Lett fruktig, smak av eplemarmelade. Det er faktisk noe bitterhet i ettersmaken Boks kjøpt på Joker Engenes Nord-Lenangen. 33cl 0.7% 221017
Lyst strågult med lavt hvitt skum. Ufrisk duft av vått høy og kokte grønnsaker. Smaken ikke mye bedre. Veldig tynn.
Can by Magne. Pours clear golden. Aroma is light, bread, sweet. Taste is light, but not bad.

Off white foam, climbing inside bottleneck. Clear pale straw body. Sweet pale malts and dusty lemon to the nose. Tastes sweet lemony malts and fragments of dusty hops. Pale finish. Soft on palate. Soso. [33cl btl, BB.08.05.16 B@supermarket]
Boks. Lys gylden, klar, moderat karbonert med hvit skumtopp smaker malt, gress og metall. Ikke spesielt god
Pale golden with a white head - Some malt and wort in the aroma - Malt and wort flavours - The malt goes into a short finish - This was just boring
Flaske 330ml fra Eurospar, Tomasjord. Skittengul. Svakt uklar. Høyt kritthvitt skum som varer en god stund. Kniplingslacing. Aroma av gress & litt mais. Tynn smak. Mest malt. Uvariert.
Søtlig duft av humle og malt. Klar lys gyllen farge. Tynt lag skum, ring langs kant. Friskt lettdrukket med en sursøtlig ettersmak.

0.33L brown bottle, abv 2.5, b@Eurospar. Bright golden (a bit beige) body, with a bit creamy white head, some lacings. Scents; hops, hay, grass, grassy malts. Taste; hops, grains, mild grapefruit, maybe strawberry, mild malts. Light thin on palate. Fresh. Ends with mild malty grains. Alright, fresh thirstquencher.
Flott utseende.. gulbrun med medium hvitt skum. Korn, søtt. Smakløs, hint av noe søtt....
Bottle. Golden, white head. Smells of cooked corn, grain. Moderate sweet, unpleasent avis hints. Moderate bitter
Pours clear straw coloured with a tiny head. Aroma of sweet grain, a whiff of grass. Taste is moderate sweet corn, watery palate, extreme low bitterness at the end.
Not so great. Tiny hints of pilsner and malts, and the beer itself is thin and quite tasteless.

Bottle 330ml @ home Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, grain and wort. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long cooked vegetables finish. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.
Yellow colour with a white head. A bit sweet malty and grassy nose. Light waterish and grassy flavour . Bottle from Varnaveien Mineralvann in Moss, Norway
De botella. Bit unclear yellow colour, short white head. Mild maltish aroma with grain. Thin mouthfeel. Flavour is grainy with a bit malt, grass and a light short bitterness. Thin.

Bottle 330ml. [ Trade by yngwie ]. Clear light to medium yellow color with a small to average, frothy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, grain, toasted, vegetables, cardboard. Flavor is light moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. [20110218]
Bottled. Golden colour, rich head. Aroma of grass and raisin. Sweet with clean mouthfeel and drier, grassy finish.

Norwegian "light" beer always means low alcohol (<2,5% ABV). This is another "draught" (actually bottled) beer which means that it's marginally darker than an ordinary pils or light beer. It is, after all, not the worst example of this lousy style. Still, avoid it if you don't have to drive!
03.01.2004, 0,5l Can. Standard vare. Gyllen farge. Det mest positive må være ettersmaken.

500 ml can. Clear golden with a medium white head. Weak malty and a bit fruity aroma with a hint of caramel. Flavor is mild malty, caramel, low bitterness and quite short finish. Yet another pilsner/lager from Aass with just a marginal difference from they’re standard pilsner. Perhaps just a hint of extra caramel flavor, but the focus is obvious on the packing.

(500 ml can). This beer is named after the founder of Aass, Norway's oldest working brewery. Typical pilsener colour and aroma, good head, quite refreshing, nice bitterness. A decent pils, no more, no less.

Bottle. Yellow colour with a white head. A very standard cheap lager beer. Light malty and hoppy aroma and flavour. Why do Aass produce all this s...? when they allready have a standard good lager beer.
330ml bottle. Special beer to remember the silver mines in Kongsberg. Might as well be the aas pilsner in a special label...

330 ml bottle. Golden body with a medium white head. There is some malt and a grassy aroma here, not strong but clearly existing. Flavor is relatively sweet malty compared with the average Norwegian pilsners and a pronounced bitterness. Frankly it’s hard to taste any difference compared with the ordinary Aass Pilsner, it might just be marginally sweeter.

330 ml bottle. Clear dark amber body with a fine beige head. Aroma of light burnt malt, caramel and a hint of spices. Traces of roasted malt in flavor as well and sweet caramel. Thin body, not very bitter and short finish. Totally drinkable but not very exiting.

This "klasse D" Christmas brew has the colour of a brown ale, but is of course bottom fermented. Decent aroma of oak and some spices. Drinkable with a meal, on its own it''s just too watery to bring about any Christmas joy. Weak aftertaste. This style just calls for a higher ABV!
On 33 cl bottle from Meny Vollebekk. Amber color, good foam. MAlty aromas, dried fruits; medium arma intensity. medium body & complexity. Well balanced. Enjoyable
Rødbrun med lavt skum. Mild aroma av tørket frukt, malt og gjær. Smak av malt og noe humle. Ikke så halvgærent, spesielt aromaen er ok. Tynn konsistens og lite å hente i munnfølelelsen.

Bottle from Vaaland, Bryne. Pours clear dark copper with a big creamy beige head. Musty malty aroma, weak raisins. Taste is moderate sweet, caramel and grains. Light oily mouthfeel. Short sweet aftertaste.
Duft av humle, malt, krydder og nøtter. Fin kastanjebrun farge. Lite skum. Smak av krydder og karamell.

33 cl brown bottle, abv 4.7% D, supermarket. Deep red-brown body, light beige fluffy head, making lacings. Scents of hops, hints of caramel, cream, pee. Tastes malts, hints of butter caramel, soap. A bit stingy carbonation sometimes. Ending short, slippery, malty. I must admit that some non-alcoholic beers are better than this.
Fyldig ettersmak. Litt tam i starten. Helt midt på treet.................................... ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Klar mørk kobberfarve med lys beige skum som forsvinner raskt. Lukt av malt og karamell. Smak av malt og karamell. Supermarked.
Nose : Some wheat Appearanse : Dark brownish red / brownish red Taste : Well...... Maybee slightly sweet and malty. Drinking beer that are lacking something in the taste.

Appearance: Amber color with a creamy tan head. Nice lacing. Aroma: Mild roasted caramel malt. Palate: Medium body. Slightly sweet with some bitterness. Average carbonation. Taste: Mild roasted caramel malt. And light hoppy. Overall impression: The ususal boring Norwegian grocery store Christmas beer. I use it in preparing of food. Personal stats: Bottle from Varnaveien Mineralvann in Moss, Norway

33cl bottle from Meny Løren. Pours clear copper with an off-white head. Aroma of malt and caramel with hints of raisins and hops with some roasty notes. Quite sweet and not so much flavour, but some bitterness in the finish. Drinkable, but quite boring.
New label and now 6.4% alcohol. The taste is standard, maybe a little old. Would probably taste best on tap.
This pours amber with a whitebhead. Nose of spice Medium body. Flavor is malt with fmkm Finishes with bitterness

Sampled from a bottle this beer poured a very dark amber color with a medium sized foamy white head that left a bit of lacing. The aroma was sweet with almost maple syrup. The flavor was earthy, sweetish and perfumy with a definite cumin presence. Long finish. Medium body. Odd.

Draft. Amber beer with a cream colored head. Light malt and light spice aroma. Spice, yeast, and light malt flavor. Medium bodied. Yeast, earth, and spice lingers with light malt. Light Indian spices throughout.

draft @ brewpub. Clear amber. Very thick, lasting head. Lots of flowers but also has diacetyl. Ugh. Slick palate. Buttery :( Some smokiness in the palate. Soapiness. Clashing flavors. Finishes with overwhelming butterscotch. Too bad about that.

Saison Elysee--2001 22 oz. Bottle. 7.50% ABV. (3.0 / 5.0) Saison--Clear bright golden color with hints of amber red. Crisp light Belgian floral yeast front. Thin malty Belgian body. Medium sediment hazes and mellows brew. Big.Dry Belgian spice end. Needs aging. Sampled 8/31/2001. Saison Elysee--2002 22 oz. Bottle. 7.00% ABV. (4.0 / 5.0) Saison--Big foamy light lace head. Floral estery yeast mild hop front. Crisp very citrus mild spice astringent dry sweet body mellowed by mild sediment. Clean smooth rich citrus end. Tasty with good malt base. Sampled 1/1/2003. Saison Elysee’ Belgian-Style Farmhouse Ale--2005 22 oz. Bottle. 5.80% ABV--15 IBU’s.? (4.0 / 5.0) Saison--Foamy lacy head. Cloudy dark orange color. Rich estery wild floral mild hop front. Crisp sweet fruity citrus wheat ester Belgian body. Big mellowing sediment. Dry citrus mildly creamy smooth mild hop end. Sampled 1/5/2005. Saison Elysee’ Belgian-Style Farmhouse Ale--2006 22 oz. Bottle. 5.80% ABV--10 IBU’s.? (4.0 / 5.0) Saison--Huge tight pellicle. Rich bright golden orange color hazes creamy lemon white. Tangy fruit ester start. Mild creamy sweet fruit dry estery wheat body. Clean refreshing tart Belgian citrus ester end. Sampled 4/12/2006.
on tap at sodo laocation. lots of bubblegum and some yeast in the nose. orange red with cream lace. honey clove peppery hop and cumin in the taste.

Draft@ Elysian Feilds. Clear amber with an off white head. Yeasty, spicy, pale grainy malt aromas. Medium body with a rich smooth mouthfeel. Lightly sweet pale grainy malt flavors with spices, peppercorn, earthy cucumber, Enjoyed this one.
Pours copper with a nice white head. Smells of floral hops, dry malt, some funky hints. Tastes funky and dry with a ice perfumy finish. Straight forward and very enjoyable.
On Tap At Elysian Fields Seattle. Pours out a dark copper/gold topped with a sand head. Aroma was of spice, belg yeast and sweetness. Taste was of fruit sweetness along with some floral notes.
Clear light copper. Watery body. Light caramel accents with heaps of bitter English hops. Not very well balanced. Tasted like it was made on a homebrew kit, no offense.

Dark iced tea appearance. Foamy off white head. Thin bodied, light and watery. Very hoppy. Minty, woody with strong Fuggles notes. Nice roasted chocolate aftertaste. Has makings of a solid brew, but not quite.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Draught @ Brewery: This one pours a clear, light golden color. There was a very small white head and almost no lacing. The aroma is mild. Some malts, maybe some floral hops. The taste was definitely light. Some malts, floral hops, and an aftertaste I couldn’t quite figure out.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Draft. Pours gold with a white head. Clean grainy malts, with grassy and earthy hops. Simple, well balanced, and very drinkable. Good stuff.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Sample at the brewpub. Pours gold with a white head. Smells of light noble hops, a touch of dry malt, some grainy elements. Tastes of dry malt, some bitterness, some sage and grass elements on the finish. Enjoyable.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: a bit better than the big easy blonde. Not much aroma here. Taste is a bit cleaner but not terribly hoppy which is too bad. Finishes fairly clean. Could make a decent lawnmower beer. Of course I don’t own a lawnmower.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Location: Draft at the Brewpub, 10/2/10 Aroma: A light and dull aroma of grains and corn, fairly typical of a boring pale lager Appearance: The pour of this one is clear, golden in color, and with no head Flavor: It has a malty sweetness up-front with a finish of hoppy bitterness and something quite off Palate: It is fairly light of body, and feel that lasts on the tongue just doesn’t quite work for me Overall Impression: This one is not exciting at all, probably my least favorite thing that I tried at the Brewpub. It is rather dull and typical of the mediocre examples of the style, and it has a rather odd aftertaste. This just really isn’t very good.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the Hyde Park Brewery. Pours a clear golden yellow, thin white head remnants, but mostly still looking. Empty for the most part but what aromas exist are mostly grain. Holy sweetness batman. . Decent body at least, but this is just sweet and empty. Big abrasive and unrefined bitter finish. Ugh.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: on tap–pours a white head and yellow/gold color. Aroma is perfumy, grain. Taste is perfumy/herbal hops, grain/light malt-sweet.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: A Bohemian Pilsener that uses Czech hops. A slightly sour aroma. Not very impressive.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: The beer pours a completely lucid macro yellow. Aroma is slightly sour and lemon. I do not think it is intended to be so but heck it works well enough. Taste is similar with light biscuit malt sweetness. Very light and quaffable.Brewpub sampler.

column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Golden lager-like pour with a pretty good white head. decient bitterness with a nice light body. Not bad

column1: Hyde Park Von Schtupps Dark Lager
column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Draught @ Brewpub: This one pours an opaque, very dark brown color. There was a very small tan head, and almost no lacing. It has a lighter aroma. Chocolate malt and earthy notes. The taste is decent enough, but a little light. Roasted chocolate malts and a hint of bitterness. Decent enough.

column1: Hyde Park Von Schtupps Dark Lager
column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub yesterday with lunch. Nose of light cocoa. Slick and shimmering black in the glass. I sent it back due to the overwhelming decay and funky rotten vegetable taste that overtook the second half of the mouthfeel. I nearly spit it out. I asked the waiter if they had cleaned their lines lately. He looked at me strangely. I stated that I thought that it was off a bit. He stated that it wasn’t. My first thought was then..."so you regularly serve sub par beer" I asked for the Oktoberfest.....While they didn’t blink when I asked to exchange the beer. They did come back and ask if I liked the Oktoberfest. I stated that it was "OK", and the waiter replied "yes it is truly excellent isn’t it?" I nearly threw a fork at his face.

column1: Hyde Park Von Schtupps Dark Lager
column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: On draught at the brewpub. Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Some hints of coffee and roasted malt give way to a subtle tartness and an earthiness. Tastes earthy and tarte with a malty sweet finish.

column1: Hyde Park Von Schtupps Dark Lager
column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Location: Draft at the Brewpub, 10/2/10 Aroma: The nose is fairly sweet, toffee, roasted malts, and a touch of fruit Appearance: It pours a fairly dark brown-black color with a bit of tan head Flavor: The taste is fairly sweet up-front flowing into a roasted malt finish Palate: It has a fairly light body, but isn’t watery at all, it has a smooth feel, and low carbonation Overall Impression: This was probably my favorite thing that I tried here, a fairly enjoyable and well-made brew. I thought it was a solid Schwarz, and I enjoyed drinking it.

column1: Hyde Park Von Schtupps Dark Lager
column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: On tap at the Hyde Park Brewery. Pours a deep black with a medium sized beige head. Metal and chocolate on the nose. Toast and light grain. Toast and coffee in the body, thin and watery. Grainy and a bit of chocolate and some light cereal flavors. Sightly off plastic and vegetal flavors that are standard for HP’s beers. Not as bad as the rest of them though, it seems the darker malts often cover up some of the more glaring flaws in many of their lighter offerings. Soft sweet finish. Drinkable at least.

column1: Hyde Park Von Schtupps Dark Lager
column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Tap. Pleasant malt aroma. Smooth texture. Smokey malt, bready flavor. Malty bready nutty finish. Very nice.

column1: Hyde Park Von Schtupps Dark Lager
column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: on tap–pours a light tan head and mahogany color. Aroma is dark malt-chocolate/licorice, roasty, some hops. Taste is dark malt-chocolate/licorice, roasty, some hops. Some dusty on mouth feel. Soft carbonation.

column1: Hyde Park Von Schtupps Dark Lager
column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Nice and sweet with dark pour with a ncie off white head, very light bitterness toward the end, nice and smooth

column1: Hyde Park Von Schtupps Dark Lager
column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Mild, sweet, lightly vegetal aroma. Clear, dark brown coloured body with a low but lasting, fine bubbled, off white head that leaves some lacing. Chick peas, sweet malts, creamed corn and herbal notes with light bitterness in the mouth. Medium light body with soft carbonation. Sampled on tap at the brewpub with Olivier_MTL and Rastacouere.

column1: Hyde Park Von Schtupps Dark Lager
column2: Hyde Park, New York, United States
column5: Couleur brune aux reflets rouge foncé, bonne quantité de mousse beige pale. Grains hautement torréfié…se dirigeant dangereusement vers le brûlé. Sucré en bouche et semble en effet oxydé. Sensation aqueuse, corps mince, étalement très court. Plutôt maladroit. Évidemment pas le même calibre de produit que ceux qui sont décrits par d’autres membres au bas de cette page. En fût à la brasserie, N.Y., Septembre 2005.

column1: Du Bocq Cuvee Li Crochon Blonde
column5: Robe blonde, fine mousse peu persistante. Nez assez banal, malt, céréales, houblon. Bouche tout aussi banale, légère, pointe de malt, bulle discrète, finale courte.

column1: Du Bocq Cuvee Li Crochon Blonde
column5: 25 cl. bottle @ the bungalow in Vencimont, bought @ Carrefour, Dinant. Hazy golden with a big white head. Fruity sweet aroma. Sweet taste with some hopbitterness. Nice blonde

column1: Du Bocq Cuvee Li Crochon Blonde
column5: Commissioned by Fosca, Hainaut ale with straw blonde colour and malty character with spicy notes, not too much body, finishing a bit phenolic. Not for me.

column1: Du Bocq Cuvee Li Crochon Blonde
column5: Een blond biertje zonder veel smaak aan, net als het bruine broertje hiervan.

column1: Du Bocq Cuvee Li Crochon Blonde
column5: Bottle (25 cl) from biergusto.be. Hazy golden, medium white head. Duponts yeast aromas, spicy, oranges, tropical fruit, some shale, along with floral hops. Meidum bodied, medium carbonation. Dry with medium bitterness.

column1: Du Bocq Cuvee Li Crochon Blonde
column5: 1/IV/13 - 25cl bottle from Comptoir des Fagnes (Couvin, BE) @ home - BB: 20/XII/13 (2013-293) Clear pale yellow beer, white head, unstable, adhesive, leaving an nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: orange peel, apple skin, bit sugary, artificial lemon. MF: lots of carbon, light to medium body. Taste: some citrus, lemony, artificial, bit sugary, pretty bitter touch. Aftertaste: bit chemical, bitter, lemony. Bleh.

column1: Du Bocq Cuvee Li Crochon Blonde
column5: Bottle, bought @ Belgianshop.com. [vintage 2006] Pours pale, muddy yellow with a fine, large, creamy, white head. Yeasty aroma, some bready and biscuity malts, light spicy and citric. Medium carbonation, okay mouthfeel. Flavour is lightly metallic, some malty sweetness, good yeast. Light notes of banana, honey and green apples. Not overly impressive.

column1: Du Bocq Cuvee Li Crochon Blonde
column5: bottle in Li Crochon glass. pours light hazy golden, white head. Aroma, yeasty, hoppy with some sweet elements, wheat/hay, spices, almost minty and some green tea leaves freshness. Taste, malty, light hops with some citrus notes, yeasty giving the beer a liverly/sparkly palate, some fruits, grains and mid sweet honey notes. Def. a preference for the brune version.

column1: Du Bocq Cuvee Li Crochon Blonde
column5: Bottle 25cl. @ home. Unclear medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, fruity, caramel notes, citrus notes, moderate yeasty, spicy. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20081022]

column1: Du Bocq Cuvee Li Crochon Blonde
column5: 25cl, from De Bierloods Adegem, not complex, balanced, hazy, good head, nice brew
Deep chestnut. Creamy head. Medium body. Tart, lemony with notes of clove and faint roasted caramel. Gentle hint of fizzyness. Solid example.

Poured from tap at Berkeley Pyramid ale house, labeled as Belgian style white, a cloudy blonde with small white head. The nose was very soft with a little citrus and something like corriander and cinnamon. Flavor was mostly sweet honey, light spice of cinnamon, and sweet citrus. Very little carbonation, tang or malt-feel to this one. Palate is mostly sweet with a very small tartness, and the spice is very subdued. Overall the flavor is ok but the beer lack spiciness and carbonation as well as being too sweet. I would skip this one next time.
Orange and slightly hazy. Subtle aroma of corriander. Very citric. Slight bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel. Slightly off.
Hazy gold.Spicy grainy nose and flavor with a tart yeasty finish............
Tap. Hazy yellow. A spicy, orange, and a little tangy. A grainy texture.

The menu card said this was a Belgian style white that included spices like coriander. Fine, I thought, so this is supposed to taste like Hoegaarden. I took a sniff and sip and said: apricots?!?!?!, a Belgian wit isn't supposed to taste like apricots! Then my dinner companion pointed out that I had also ordered Pyramid apricot ale and the ditzy waitress probably put the tasters on improper places on the laminated beer menu. Sure enough, that's what happened. Cloudy, light orange color. Citrusy smell with a hint of yeast. Bitter, watery, with a hit of wit yeastyness. Some spice, but without strong coriander flavor or fullness of most wits.

Bottle from Swedish "Systembolaget" in November 2005.Clear golden color, white head. Mix of hops and malt in the scent and flavor. Quite nice for being an october fest beer, better than the Spaten I tried.

(Bottled) Golden color with a medium, foamy and quite tight head. Very metallic, slightly acidic aroma with some malt hints. Strongly acidic, slightly buttery-malty and sweetish flavor with a strong metallic feel. Light to medium-bodied palate with medium carbonation. There can be no excuse for a beer as metallic as this one. A hint for the brewer: An oktoberfest should be sweetish-malty - not acidic-metallic.

Pours golden with a thick diminishing white head. Malty, slight hoppy nose with a spicy touch. Smooth, somewhat metallic flavour with some hints of toffee. A little saltyness is sensible in finish. Drinkable, but not overwhelming.
Bottled. Golden colour, huge creamy white head. Malt and cooked vegetables in aroma. Flavour is very boring, vegetably and malty with small hoppy bitterness and dryness in finish. Lagerish...

Bottled (BB 02/2006) Golden color, huge creamy white head. Harsh malty, lemony dish water nose. Medium-bodied. Quite watery, sweet malty. Not much oktoberfest-style found here, more like a bulk lager.
(Bottle 50 cl) Beautiful full golden colour without much head. Not much body and not really that different to a standard lager. 280803
Pours a thin white head on a hazy yellow body. Herb, citrus and hop aroma with cheesy tones. Also hops and herbs in the flavor. Foamy mouthfull.
Bottled: Light golden coloured. White fluffy head. Malty and fruity beer with a somewhat sour undertone. Is light citric and ends rather dry and light hoppy.
A cloudy pale yellow beer with a fine though disappearing head. The aroma is sour malty while the flavor is boring malty with notes of metal and a dry hoppy end with a touch of citrus.
golden with thick white medium head. Weak aroma with some malt and spices. Flat flavour and body. Not much malt in here. Quite metallic bitter finish.

Tasted at Pyramid’s Berkeley brewpub as a taster set w/5 other beers. Beautiful in the glass- Cappucino-like thick head contrasting with dark brew below. Scent, though was of instant coffee-thin, unpleasant, almost medicinal. best part of the beer is how it feels in the mouth- as smooth as cream, with tiny nitogen bubbles accentuating the deep roasts. The beer then goes downhill. Sour at the end, with no more depth. A quick flavor. I kept sipping just for the wondrously smooth mouthfeel.
(Draught) Brown bubbly head with an opaque body. Coffee and caramel nose. Very roasted maltiness in flavour with keen coffee notes. The cocoa powder makes an appearance shortly in the finish. Good.

on draft at berkeley: pours with a nice thick creamy head, maybe a little darker then guinness and head a little darker. coffee notes in the nose. taste somewhat the same choc malt and slight bittering hops....not nearly as big as i had hopped. thougtht by the nose it was going to be something special but fell short of my expectations.
A dark creamy stout with a thick head. Coffee and chocolate aroma and flavor.
had this at the berkeley alehouse, it was decent, nice dark, huge tight head, lots of coffee and choco flavor

Black and creamy. Aroma of roasted malt. Slightly bitter. Roasted flavor. A touch of sourness. Very creamy mouthfeel. Bigger than most dry stouts. Fairly nice although something here is a little off. Yeast funk?
Tap: Chocolate and coffee, lightly roasted. Creamy and smooth as per the nitro
On tap - Berkeley. Ok, but not somewhat weak. Mostly coffee, roasty flavors.
Nitro, chocolate and coffee flavors. Mildly bitter. Pretty basic. Could use a drier finish.
Tap. Solid black with a nice brown head. Aroma is roasted malty and chocolate. The nitro makes it smooth and creamy.

Tried this recently in a beer bar in Berlin, typical of the style, but very intense cherry flavour, and pleasant hint of almondy bitterness from the stones. Rich and fruity ( we ordered it instead of dessert) and perhaps rather too sweet to drink in large quantities but lovely with food . Liked this more than some of the other Kriek lambic beers have tried
Mørk rød klar med lavt rosa skum. Lukter mandelkjærnepudding med rød saus. Søt. Uten bitterhet. Smaker lett syrlig kirsebær. Kort
Very sweet, surprisingly so for a lambic with a just a hint of sourness. Deep cherry flavours. I would re purchase. A very easy drink low in abv.
Restrained aroma in a murky purple pour. Tart taste to start with a sweeter fruit body body and clean finish.
Najmniej lambikowy i najbardziej słodki Kriek, jakiego piłem. Dobry, słodko-kwaśny, ale to już nie piwo raczej.
It pours a pink color and has a sweet taste with a smooth cherry , sugar aroma.

Ich finde dieses Kriek, das doch recht verbreitet ist, eigentlich ganz gut. Mit klassischem Bier hat das Getränk natürlich wenig zu tun. Aber es hat den klassischen Kriek-Geschmack, auch wenn es ein bisschen zu süß erscheint.

Slušný sladký kriek, chutnající jako třešňová limonáda. Neříkám podle hodnocení, že průměrné nebo tak, ale víc jsem si oblíbil lambiky čisté, kyselé a bez přidaného cukru. Na posezení, či do horkých letních dnů ale toto pivo určitě sedne.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours clear cherry red with a pink-tinged head. Aromas of cherry and almond. Taste is sweet, marzipan and cherry. Lots of flavour, and a light sharp finish.
Sweet Jesus that's good. Perfectly balanced, velvety, sweet, tart, delicious, in short. Slightly lower abv and a smidgeon too thin for 5.0 but am struggling to criticize here
Black color with a medium head. Coffee and mildly burnt roasts permeate the aroma and flavor. It’s better than average, but not outstanding.
Black Coloring with Tan Head. Coffee Aroma. Almost Stale Coffee Roast Taste. Malt...Dry Bitter Aftertaste.
Tapper at the pub. Pitch black, small head fragrant roasted malt aroma with chocolate teasers, taste was pretty much the same, not as smooth as I thought it would be

Festival tap:Massive cascade, deep black with tan head, very sweet and strong malt nose, big chocolatey taste, very rich and thick. Dry coffee notes at the finish, peaty and sweet aftertaste. This is a rich one!

Black body, wispy tan head. Nice strong flavor on this one. Starts with a deep dark fruit flavor, like a "gourmet" chocolate filled with a sweet, syrupy cherry filling. Also, it has a rice krispie dryness. Dark chocolate and light coffee aroma. A satisfying oatmeal stout! Could have used a bit more mouthfeel, however.

Glass at the brewpub. Deep dark charcoal...light smoky-roasty chocolate-grape nose. Gorgeous milky chocolate initial flavor, cafe latte in the middle/end. Could be a bit fuller, but really just a terrific flavor...leaves massive, intricate lacing. Nice little finishing bite.
Black body with brown head. Aroma is roasty, medium sweet, caramel. Flavor is mild -- coffee/roasty, slightly sweet. Medium/full body. Pleasant, but that's the best you can say.
This was a dark black beer with a tan head. It had a subtle coffee malt scent. It tasted of coffee, only slightly sweeter. Pleasamt aftertaste.

ehhh...this is strictly a minor sin, say undertipping at a restaurant, as opposed to something big like murder. A beer that plays it too safe and has little character beyond a hint of smokiness and a pretty head.
Dark brown, near opaque with a small bubbled tan head. Aroma of sweet malt with a touch of mild roasted barley. Very smooth in mouthfeel. Light malt flavors. A very mild stout.
Amber Coloring. Not a Bad Ale Per Se, but Not Much to Offer the Tastebuds. Sweet, Easy Going Down.. Slightly Malty. Boring.
Dark amber color with minimal head. Slightly sweet all around with a bit of malt. Eh, just not much to offer.

I'm one of the few people on here who likes looking for a good red, and unfortunately, I was dissapointed by this one. It had a sweet scent, but a touch of caramel was the only noticable flavor. Balanced to the point of being bland.
Leinie''s Red with a bit of a hop bite. Pretty bland.......................
Ambered color ale. A full, malty mouthfeel which leads to a crisp hop bitter finish. Nice!
On tap. Nice, deep brown nose. Roasted malts with nuts are present. Slight alcohol tastes with caramel malt. Smooth finish. easy-drinking and decent.
This smoky beer is one of the best scotch ale’s in Madison. It hits your nose as you tip your glass to drink and the flavor rocks!

Pretty garnet in color, like a glowing rose. Oily, web-cast head and similar lacing tracts. We’ve still got some laundromat aroma, along with some wafts of sweet caramel and grenadine syrup. Sweet, bing cherry flavor couple with rye. Some caramel, butterscotch and cedar. I’m beginning to believe that their beers are very conservative so they don’t offend. I think they could make the flavor leap and go all out, but I have yet to see a committed effort from these guys. Indistinguishable malt monster clusterf*ck finish.
Brown Coloring with White Skin. Malty Aroma. Sweet Taste...Malty and a Bit Stale as Well. Tart and Dry Ending.

Dark copper color with a thin head. Mutty malt aroma. Sweet malt taste with a bit of an alcohol zing. Some kind of nut is lurking in the background; walnut? Very smooth. Tasty, but if it’s going to be a 99 shilling brew it should land a knockout punch.
Festival tap: Very creamy and thick bodied beer with big notes of scotch malts and a nice firey alcoholic finish. A bit over the top, but the malts do make their presence known.

Yes, it looks the part, but if you’re in Madison, I’d recommend the Great Dane’s Scottish Ale over Angelic’s. Hell, just go to the Great Dane instead of Angelic. RERATE: I’ve had this beer three or four times and every time it has been of decent quality. I gave it an overall rate of "3" before. Last night, however, I had a pint that was awful. There was a big taste of grape cough syrup, insipid aroma, drank like a soda pop...I’m not sure if it was the batch or the lines, but I’ve never had a beer that tasted like this before. Because of this, I _have_ to rate it down a few notches.
deep ruby body, sweet ripe and a bit fruity. carmel, noticeable alcohol content. somewhat scotchy

Dark brown with a tan thin head. Aroma of heavy malt, light peat and alcohol. Heavy malt sweetness starts the sip with roasted malt and light peat later. The darker malt and alcohol dominate in the finish. I do prefer the balance of a good 80.
It looks the part sure, but the aroma is awfully faint and the beer itself is pretty insipid - sweet, but not enough nuttiness.

column1: Eel River Raven's Eye Imperial Stout
column5: Bomber from Hops and Bottles. Black body, small head disappears. Aroma is roasted malts and light chocolate. More roast in the taste, ashy bitterness. Hint of sweetness.

column1: Eel River Raven's Eye Imperial Stout
column5: Copenhagen 6/6 2019. 65 cl bottle from Høkeren, Ravnsborggade, Kbh N. Print directly on the bottle. Silhouette of a Raven flapping it's wings. Pours opaque dark brown with medium-sized beige head. Settles as thin layer of foam struggling to cover the surface of the beer. Moderate lacing. Aroma is intense, sweet and with a notable alcoholic presence. Brown sugar, molasses, chocolate of the bitter variety, vanilla. A little boozy brandy odor. Light carbonation. Medium thick, oily, soft sticky texture. Flavor has a heavy sweetness followed by a more moderate cofffee bitterness. Aftertaste has a stronger bitterness - but still with a prominent underlying sweetness. Lingering. What use you have for beer who holds the cold Russian winters in mind in California, I can't say. But it is a an fine concentration of sugar, coffee and alcohol.

column1: Eel River Raven's Eye Imperial Stout
column5: Bottle from BevMo! in Willow Glen, CA. Aroma is vanilla, caramel, chocolate, anise, some leather / tobacco. Taste is tangy dark fruit, vanilla extract, tobacco. A tad bit sweet and some fake vanilla in there, otherwise very drinkable and nice tobacco port side bits.

column1: Eel River Raven's Eye Imperial Stout
column5: From a bottle at home. Pours with a minimal tan coloured head. Slight aroma of coffee and nuts. Tastes fizzy with a smooth finish. Slight bourbon finish. (K)

column1: Eel River Raven's Eye Imperial Stout
column5: Big and brash, Ravens Eye packs some alcohol heat, but remains very creamy, and then ends light. Packed with chocolate flavor and a a bit of leather in ess. Outstanding.

column1: Eel River Raven's Eye Imperial Stout
column5: Dried fruits, liqourice, prunes, tobacco. A little sweet but balanced and sober

column1: Eel River Raven's Eye Imperial Stout
column5: Earlier Rating: 9/13/2016 Total Score: 3.8 Fra flaske på Mi2 Cardinal sep-16: nesten helt svart med beige skum. Saftig aroma og smak i en perfekt balansert kombo med kaffe, sjokolade, røde bær. Rund, fyldig, og med lett delikat bitterhet som gjør det til en fornøyelse å helle den innenfor snippen. Saftig og passe tørr på samme tid. En vennlig avslutning på en super aften. Tnx Sigmund!

column1: Eel River Raven's Eye Imperial Stout
column5: Et typisk imperial Stout. Meget bitter og stor smag af lakrids og en fed smag af mørke malte. Heldigvis også en del sødme.

column1: Eel River Raven's Eye Imperial Stout
column5: Tap@ Hugos w DØE Hane. Appearance: pours clear dark brown with good beige creamy head and lacing. aroma/taste notes: caramel, chocolate, coffee, alcohol and light wood. palette: strong roasted malty aroma, average carbonation, medium to full body, medium to notable sweetness, somewhat balanced by an average bitterness, medium duration and an oily texture. Overall: tasteful and smooth

column1: Eel River Raven's Eye Imperial Stout
column5: Pitch black, sweetish aroma. Slightly boozey sweetness, coffee, sugary notes.

Kentucky Fried Charleston Trip Beer #131. Draft at the brewpub. Pours a Clear dark brown color with a thin tan head. Poor head retention. Aroma of brown malts and clay. The taste is sweet malts, mild nuts. More like a brown ale than a schwarzbier.
On tap. Sample pour is black with an off white top. Scent is malty with chocolate Taste is sweet malts with chocolate.

Pint at Tribeca Tavern Cary. Aroma, yeast and malts. Not an overwhelming scent. Little cardboard/ paper. Minor chocolate. Clean orange brown color. No head or lace. Sweet flavor. Light body, thin mouthfeel, dry finish. Meh, nothing of note here.

on tap-pours an off white head and brown color with red tint. Aroma is faint medium/dark malt-caramel. Taste is medium/dark malt-smoky/roasty/caramel/chocolate. Faint/secondary hops bite. OK carbonation. Occasional.

draught. Pours a dark brown, a little reddish, with a fading white head akin to that on a glass of cola. The aroma is mild and malty, non-descript. Flavor is of a little chocolate, flat hops which are almost papery, small chalk. This is semi-thin and kind of boring, but drinkable.

Draught. Pours a clear dark burnt red with off-white head. The aroma is clean and, erm, lager-y, with sweet malt, some chocolate, a faint leafy note, and some pepper. The flavor is bitter chocolate, some moderately bitter roastiness, and an ashy finish. A little bit of cardboard comes out in the aftertaste. It gets nuttier as I get down the glass. The body is thinner than I would like.

Balck, or really dark brown. Virtually no head. Peppery, faintly coffee-ish aroma, with maybe a touch of honey, perhaps? Palate seems rather rich at first, but kind of disappears as you finish it. Flavor is coffee, and Oreo cookies with a mildly hoppy finish. Draft at Barley’s Knoxville

Draught at the brewpub. Clear dark brown color with foamy white head. No lace. Roasty brown sugar nose with brown sugar again in the flavor along with subtle chocolate. Roasty finish. Not a big fan of Schwarzbiers, in general, but this one is decent.

Slightly off-white head with good retention. Black color lets a little ruby through. Not much aroma-what is there is faint malty, chocolate. Flavor is malty with smoke and caramel-chocolate. Medium body with soft finish and not nearly as dry as the standard German counterpart.

A nice head over an appropriately dark body, but the head dissipates a bit too quickly. The aroma is satisfyingly smoky. Nothing really to note about the mouth-feel.
