Flavor-wise, this was a pleasant beer, not ruined with hops (especially Cascade) the way so many recent beers are. Overall, this was a nice drinkable beer, but not really much above average.
Orangish in color. Not much head at all. Fairly malty color. Malt, caramel flavor. Not bad. Just put it on tap yesterday.
Clear amber pour. Toasted malt and caramel on the nose. Fruity flavor with a nice balance of hops. This was a nice surprise.
BJCP Training: Categories 3&4. Clear dark golden body with a medium white head. Light toasted malt aroma. Sweet malty flavor with some light toastiness.

Thanks to William for bringing a growler of this back for the BJCP training session. Clear light orange, head comes up quick, but has zero retention. Light toasty malt aroma. Toasty flavors, a very faint roast note, and a malty, dry finish. Not rich. Not exciting, but not bad.

Sampled at Asheville Brewgrass 2005. Copper, with a beige head. Nice toffee and caramel aroma. Tas is malty smooth, with he same notes of caramel and toffee, but also a hint of cardboard. Gently sweet finish.

Huge, blossoming white head--imagine an albino mushroom cloud!--stands over a dark orange brew. Intensely aromatic from far-off: principally citrus, flowers and honey. Perfectly fits the Bavarian wheat style as I understand it, but where does the "winter" part come in? The brewery specializes in wheats, or should I say "weisbier specialitaten", as it says on the label, but no further information is given about this "winter wheat" business, or what the heck a "Schneewalter" is. Thirst-quenching, delicious, substantial, and sweet. Quite good, but I can’t find what ought to set it apart from other Bavarian wheats.
Aracauna pretty much nails this one. Nothing exciting, too bland for an Oktoberfest. I did find the hops a hair too strong for an Oktoberfest, and the head dissipated entirely too quickly.
Pale spice in the aroma and flavor with some caramel. This isn't one of the overhopped O'fests, but like the other two beers from the Mash House I tried, it's thin and bland.

341ml bottle sampled many years ago poured a pale amber color with a finger and a half of white head that left a few spots of lacing. Aroma is light caramel and cereal grains with some pleasant hop notes. Taste is malty sweetness and hop bitterness in a nice balance with a nice clean finish. A nice refreshing lager without the harshness of the many macros out there.
I like the idea of bears indicating the colour of the beer. This was a nice light beer with noticeable hops and barley, Better than most macros but nothing overly special.
Slight hoppy aroma. Pours a golden brown, carbonation low with a thin head. Decent palate with a slight maltiness. Hops are present but low. A mildly satisfying beer but not a standout.
A little dark for a lager with a slight haze. Light head with big bubbles. Hoppy for a lager. Thin body, light on malt.
Dark gold with short white head.Decent malt with a few finishing hops. Not bad, but nothing special either

I'm surprised I'm only the second person to rate this beer. Nice rendition of a narwhal on the label (about to be devoured by a polar bear). Darker than most lagers. Quite flavorful and hoppy for a lager and I was pleased.
Light gold color, small head. A light bodied lager, some malts and hops. Good flavor. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter

This is a backlog rating from 2013 from a bottle picked up in Asheville, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time, work and/or family. Words to describe this beer are toasted malts, grainy, tart fruit, strange beer.
Deep brown color with a roasted malt aroma. Flavor is roasted malt sweetness, slight toffee, earthy, almost like a slight whisky taste. Nice and rich.

Opaque, black-brown with a thin khahi head and very good lacing that quickly slides back down. Aroma of roasted malt, dark toast, cocoa, caramel and some dark fruit. Taste of toasted/roasted malt, plums, cocoa, raisins, and roasted coffee. Medium body and high/medium carbonation. A rather roasty dobbelbock, but not bad.
Brown with small head. Nose light caramel and some malts. Taste sweet and creamy with caramel notes. Palate rather short but still sweet.
Pours dark, dark brown with thin head. Aroma is caramel and spice. Taste is dried fruit and roast. A decent doppelbock.

Bottle from Liquor Express. It poured a dark brown with an off-white head. It has a roasted malt aroma with some dark fruit notes. The taste is lightly bitter. The mouth feel is a bit oily. A6 A4 T5 P4 O14.

On tap at The J Clyde, Birmingham, AL, 2.5.16. Very dark brown. Roasty and a little alcoholic aroma, raisins and some plum. Sweet, roasty, dried sugary fruit taste and very mild bitterness. Medium-to-full body, smooth, fairly fizzy, caramel finish.
Bottle in Fl. Pleasant aroma- but of toasted fruit. Toasted cocoa flavor. Bit of lingering flavor can’t place, likely just malts. Pretty good
Pours a nice dark brown. Aroma of malt, nuts, hops. Tastes malty, with some hops and roasty hints.
Dark reddish brown color pour with a beige head. Aroma is dark fruit, raisins, caramel and roasted malt. Taste is roasted malt, some fruity hops, caramel, bread. Good stuff.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: What a refreshing wheat beer! With a light lemongrass taste and the wheat makes this a favorite for those hot summer days!

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Poured a hazy gold with a slight head which disappeared quickly.........aroma of lemon and poppy bread, wet grass, lemon jolly rancher.....taste is dandelion leaf, mild lemon zest, soda cracker at the end. I've never tasted anything like it but it's a very simple taste of nature. The taste of weeds we chewed on as kids. It shows some fortitude by the brewer. Glad for it.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: This has a full flavour profile that really shows off the wheatgrass. It’s probably an acquired taste for some. But it’s worth trying once. I wish I had access to more this I would buy by the case for summer.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Can: Poured a clear golden color ale with a medium size foamy head with light retention and minimal lacing. Aroma of lemongrass with sweet wheat malt is enjoyable and refreshing. Taste is a nice mix of sweet wheat malt notes with some lemongrass notes clearly distinguishable. Body is full with medium carbonation. Well-made wheat beer with nice balanced notes of lemongrass.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: a lot of lemongrass aroma. cloudy yellow. taste is light on the wheat side with slightly overwhelming grass flavor. a citrus flavor shows up. can.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Can. Hazy gold pour with white head. Nose is wheaty malt, lemongrass, mild hops, spice. Tastes hoppy, citric, spicy, lighter body.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Can. Golden with white fluffy head. All lemongrass. Nose and palate. Sweet and twangy. A good beach beer.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: On tap at brewery. Pours light golden wirh white head. Aroma is lemongrass . Flavor is light malt rig lemongrass a a fruity herbal finish.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft. Opaque straw color with white head and lacing. Bright lemon aroma dominates. Lemon and fresh cut grass. Effervescent mouthfeel. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours clear yellow with a small white head. The aroma has a nice lemon zest, a bit of yeasty esters. The taste has a touch of tartness before the creaminess of the ale comes through. The flavor is fairly typical of the style but this is refreshing.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: A thick tan head that just won't quit atop a jet body. The aroma is fairly typical of the style, except for a few notes of sweetness from the molasses. This is quite possibly the smoothest, creamiest beer I've come across this side of something that has been N2 dispensed. The flavor was nice, without the espresso notes that some brewers feel compelled to insert, with a surprisingly buttery finish. Overall, this is on of the better porters I've had recently.

column2: Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina, United States
column5: Starts off with a huge, everlasting tan head. Nice creamy, velvety mouthfeel. Average porter malt but interesting butter flavor that I'm assuming comes from the molasses.

column1: Blue Ridge (SC) XXX Total Eclipse Stout
column5: Draft at the source in Greer. Dark brown nearly black pour with a large tan head and good lacing. Roasty malt nose and flavors, with coffee, cocoa, smoke and a touch of char. LIght carb, medium body. Lightly sweet, roasty finish. Nice.

column1: Blue Ridge (SC) XXX Total Eclipse Stout
column5: Draft. Poured black color with a large frothy brown head that was mostly lasting and produced very good lacing. Moderate sweet roast chocolate aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium roasted sweet flavor with a sweet finish of moderate duration. Good beer.

column1: Blue Ridge (SC) XXX Total Eclipse Stout
column5: Enjoyed a pint of this at the brew-pub in Greenville SC. I was very impressed with this brew, and despite not usually being a fan of stouts i declared this to be a newfound local favorite. Other than the initial impression of a weak roasty aroma, this beer was phenomenal. Had a great strong flavor intensity of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, etc. I suppose a relatively standard flavor profile for a stout, but it was the fullness of the flavor that distinguished this beer. Finished smooth with an aftertaste of coffee. Had a pitch black color with off white head. Strongly recommended! Also paired incredibly well with smoked gouda and bleu cheese of my entree that evening. ---Rated via Beer Buddy

column1: Blue Ridge (SC) XXX Total Eclipse Stout
column5: On tap at the Blue Ridge Brew Pub in Greenville, SC. Poured a dark brown, almost black color with an off white head. Roast, some coffee, chocolate and earthiness.

column1: Blue Ridge (SC) XXX Total Eclipse Stout
column5: On draft at brewery, poured a dark brown color, aromas of light roasted malt, feint hint of coffee. Flavors are coffee, roasted malt, and a touch of bitterness from the hops. Decent beer overall.

column1: Blue Ridge (SC) XXX Total Eclipse Stout
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Pours a very dark brown color with a thin creamy tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of sweet roasted malts with earthy notes. The taste is roasted malts, caramel with a bitter hop finish. Medium bodied.

column1: Blue Ridge (SC) XXX Total Eclipse Stout
column5: Pours nearly black. Strong aroma of coffee & roasted malt. Full-bodied flavors of smoke & roasted grain. Falls a little flat mid-palate, but not bad overall.

column1: Blue Ridge (SC) XXX Total Eclipse Stout
column5: Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a dark brown almost black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty chocolate aroma. Roasted malty chocolate and caramel flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish.

column1: Blue Ridge (SC) XXX Total Eclipse Stout
column5: Dark black-brown, dark tan head. Aroma is roasty, dry astringent, coffee. Taste is slight roast, chocolate, lightly smoky.

column1: Blue Ridge (SC) XXX Total Eclipse Stout
column5: Tastes weak, needs more body. What flavor is present is good. A combination of light chocolate and coffe, both toasty and a little nutty. Faint carbonation.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale
column5: Medium appearance and light head. Smooth taste and pumpkin aroma. Good taste for the fall.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale
column5: Tastes more like a pumpkin spice cake than a beer. That being said it tastes like a good pumpkin spice cake haha. A bit of yeasty breafiness but not Mich else besides the pumpkin. Succeed s at least in that regard

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale
column5: Draft: This is good, but nothing spectacular... lots spices like cinnamon and nutmeg, very pumpkin pie-like. Body is lacking a bit, it’s a bit thin.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale
column5: Spicy cinnamon type flavor...but after that its pretty watery...spices are good but nothing besides that

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale
column5: From 12oz bottle. Pours a dark amber with little head. Cinnamon and slight nutmeg aroma. Touch-o-hops basically waters down the spiciness of the beer. Kinda weak. Dogfish Head Punkin Ale is a much better example of a spiced pumpkin ale.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale
column5: Poured from the bottle. Aroma is full of nutmeg, with some hints of clove. No real sweetness or hop presence to speak of. Color is a nice orange-amber hue, with small white head. Flavor is strong clove, with just enough malt sweetness to balance the spices. Again, not much from the hops. Overall, this is not my favorite style, but this is a nice pumpkin beer.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale
column5: Usually the one I reach for at a party, when it’s down to this or non-local pumpkins. Like most, this one’s basically a perfunctory amber ale with just enough hop bite in there to provide some relief from the overwhelmingly sweet additions. Just never a style I’ve warmed to, but this one’s better than some.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale
column5: Bottle. Pours an amber color with almost no head. A fair amount of clove smell to this. Not as heavy on the spices as many other pumpkin beers, but still not great.

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale
column5: Bottle from foothills. Copper with head that vanishes quickly. Tastes is spice and pumpkin. Nutmeg is prevalent over any cinnamon. Not bad but I like more cinnamon. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column1: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale
column5: Originally reviewed: 10/27/10. This is the old version, pre-Foothills takeover. 12oz bottle, part of an autumn-themed mixed sixer. Poured into a pint glass. Pours a very thick, cloudy dark rusty amber. The thinnest of heads rests atop. Disappears quickly. Not even a ring around the edge. No lace. The nose is weak and underwhelming. The spices are muted, pumpkin is absent. I’m finding sour fruits, and syrup. Not what I expected. The mouth is decent. Good carbonation play, and a slightly heavy finish. I don’t know. This has some mild pumpkin in the flavor, but it’s pretty weak. It’s more cider-y, with notes of apples and light spices. I’m not sure I would or could have another one of these. I expected more, but it was found lacking. Too bad. I wanted to like this.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Clear straw, ample white lacy head. Honey, herbaceous, some citrus. Light bitterness, some sweetness. Light body, light carbonation. Fine. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Good fresh brew. Organic and clean tasting. Very much of a lager taste. I would drink it again.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: 500 ml bottle in Garmisch, Germany. Pours a deep gold color and a nice head. Grainy and malty. Watery aftertaste, Palate is smooth with few hop characters.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: (Bottle 33 cl) Fully golden with a decent head. Soft, malty and slightly sweet with an almost absent bitterness. Rather low in carbonation. 240602

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: The aroma is sweet, malty, and yeasty - good for a lager. It is slightly hazy dark orange and has a fine bubbly fast disappearing white head. The flavor is rather malt sweet with strong notes of caramel, straws, and yeast. It ends on a slight bitterness - but it seems that the primary hop is aroma.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Bottled: Golden coloured. Huge white quickly diminishing head. Aroma is malty and grainy. Flavour is light malty and sweet with a touch of bitterness in the end. I get a fruity aftertaste.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Nice golden color. Nice lager taste but kind of bitter. Not their finest brew.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Deep golden colour and a nice head. Grainy and malty. Watery aftertaste, with few hop characters.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Sweet flowery, grain also malt aroma. Golden with a little layer of a head. Sweet corn taste. Thin and watery.

column2: Neumarkt in der Oberpfalz, Bavaria, Germany
column5: Smells exactly like canned corn. Deep gold color is attractive. The head is quick and fizzy, but stuck around low and tight on the brew through the glass. Delicate toasted malt with tastes of apples in the middle. little hop character and almost no bitter. Medium body and an OK balance.

Bottle thanks to @minutemat and European Local Swap 3/2019. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aroma has nutty malt, plum and alcohol. Taste is sweetish with dried fruit, nutty flavors and yeasty bitterness. Really nice ale!

330ml bottle in 2012. Dark brown with a thin beige head. Aroma of booze soaked fruit, dates, cinnamon, nutmeg and prunes. Alcohol is quite prominent and the flavour rather sweet, like those British Barley Wine’s of old. The linger is dried fruit and rum.
Nice and dark, alcohol on the nose. Instant bitterness and flavours of the heavily roasted grains. I’d definitely have another, but at 8.5% ABV maybe not tonight!
Pours a dark brown colour with thin white head. Aroma is malt spice clove cinnamon . Taste is malty sweetish spicy bit bitterness. Overall a very nice old ale.
Tall, heavy, beige head. Dark, almost black, colour. Opaque. Aroma of roasted malts, caramels. Taste is heavy too, licorice - coffee. It's not bad. Expected bit more, but it's bit older bottle too.
Todella tumma, mutta ei liian tuhti. Karamellia ja maltainen, ei kitkerä. Miellyttävä kokemus.
Brown color with almost creamy tanned head. Aroma has caramel, dark malt, dark fruits. Taste is malty sweet with long sweet aftertaste. Flavors of caramel, dark malt, dark fruits, wood and vanilla.

2016 06 28 Butelka 0,33 l. Piana beżowa, obfita, beżowa, bardzo gęsta i pozostająca do końca, piękny lacing. Kolor głęboki, ciemnobrązowy, pod światło rubinowy, lekko zamglone. W aromacie nuty opiekane, razowca, karmelowe, winne, dzikiej róży oraz alkoholowe na sposób lekko gorzelniany. W smaku dość wytrawne i alkoholowe, wyczuwalne nuty ciemnych słodów, karmelowe, razowca, ziemisto-ziolowe, przyprawowe. Pełnia średnia w kierunku średnio wysokiej, wysycenie średnio niskie, goryczka na średnim poziomie intensywności, ziołowo-herbacniano-ziemista i trochę alkoholowa. Piwo przeleżakowałem do końca daty ważności, było przyzwoicie ułożone, ale grzaniu w gardło towarzyszyła dość wyraźna niezbyt przyjemna alkoholowość. Spodziewałem się innego rodzaju trunku, dlatego trochę się rozczarowałem, mimo to piwo jest smaczne i prezentuje dość wysoki poziom. 3,7/5
Wonderfully complex. Dark toastiness, molasses, fruits galore, lots of warmth. Each sip a work of art.
Bottle from Sainsbury’s. Very deep brown with a reddish hue, white foam. Strong warming malty goodness with a hint of treacle and a robust bitter finish. Very nice.

0,5 l bottle. Murky brown orange with a nearly three finger pale beige head in the glass. Banana an clove smell with some yeast. Taste starts short orange fruity, than more the typical banana chewing gum mix with clove background Low wheat and yeast. Getting a little bit more dry in the second part. Wheat and fruity ending. Nice.

Eher würzig / herb, süffig, ausgewogen und erfrischend. Angenehm malzige Noten dominieren ab dem Mittelteil, leicht säuerliche folgen. Relativ weich. Wirklich gut. Schlägt die helle Variante und das Fips-Weizen aus gleichem Haus deutlich. Anmerkung am Rande: Arcobräu in Moos und Graf Arco in Eichendorf / Adldorf sind zwei verschiedenen Brauerein, die nichts miteinander zu tun haben. Wird sehr oft verwechselt.
Hazy murky brown. Aroma is light ripe banana with some caramel and yeasty base. Taste is sweet yeasty caramel. Hazy on the tongue. Nothing wrong here.

Das dunkle Weißbier aus dem Hause Arco sieht im Glas top aus! Schöne dunkelbraune, trübe Farbgebung mit ordentlicher Schaumkrone. Geruch: dunkelmalzig. Der Antrunk ist schön erfrischend, mild, süffig, dunkel- und röstmalzig und leicht fruchtig. Auch bei diesem Bier, wie schon beim hellen HW, versucht es kurzzeitig den Vollmundigkeitsstatus zu erlangen. Es zeigen sich verschiedene Malzaromen, ist leicht würzig und eine süße-Säuerlichkeit erscheint im Background. Im Abgang bleiben, wie erwartet, ein hefiger Geschmack gepaart mit röst-dunkelmalzigen Aromen im Mundraum liegen. Ein sehr leckeres dunkles Weißbier!
Marron trouble, légère mousse. Nez léger malté pain. Gout malté pain noir avec du fruité sur ananas et paille. Bon corps. Fin sur le malté sucré.
Light brown color with medium head. Aroma is yeast, wheat. Flavor is malt, wheat, sweet. Medium body, lively carbonation. Banana aftertaste. In a way special Weizen. Watery.
10.06.2018 -- 0.5l bottle from marktkauf, 1€. pours a murky brown with a medium creamy head. aroma of dates, banana, and caramel. flavour of bread, wheat, herbs. a bit thin and light body.

Hazy brown color with off-white head. Aroma has toasted malt, caramel, brown sugar and candied banana. Taste follows with toasted malt, burnt sugar and some overripe banana. Medium body with medium minus carbonation. Quite nice, well made dunkelweizen.
Bottle from Waitrose. (Brief tasting notes and rating from old records) - Dark, rich, malty, creamy, sweet, spicy, fruity wheat beer. (Backlog)
Bottle. brown color. caramel, yeast and banana in the aroma and flavor. Citrus, pear. Decent.

emacgee again... dark brown with a very light tan head, nice ring forms... light bitter chocolate, a little roast but more sweet than anything... the taste is pretty light, not a ton going on, sweet coffee, very bitter on the finish... average

Growler from TJs Carrboro. Dark black pour with two fingers chestnut brown head and copper edges. Nose is very rich and chocolaty with notes of sweet java and light hints of grain. Flavor has a mild acidic character with notes of bitter chocolate and coffee grounds, not as smooth as the bouquet but still nice. Lost some carbonation from the growler-ing.
Dark brown pour with thin tan head and minimal lace. Rich roasty aroma. Thin bodied. Chocolate malts, light coffee and a bitter finish

Tap. Pours a nice deep dark brown near black with a thick head. some lace. Aroma is chocolate malts, good roast, and hints of anise seed. Leather and earth flavor sharp licorice some tar and big chocolate malts, lots of dry roast and nuts, toffee sweetness in the middle and dries out in the end. Nice overall.

A dark brown with hints of red on the edges. An aroma of chocolate and coffee. Toasted maltiness with just a hint of sweet before it fades to a very nice finishing dry bitter. Good carbonation and mouthfeel make this a pretty nice stout.
On draft at Barley’s in Asheville. Black pour, small tan head. Very roasty aromas. Good coffee and chocolate flavors, roast malt. Something missing, but not bad.

Draft at Mellow Mushroom, Asheville, NC.Big coffee and roast malt aroma. Dark brown to full black with a rapidly diminishing head. Bitter roast coffee and dark chocolate flavor. A little thin and without any real flavor range, but mostly pretty nice.

Draught at Barley’s in Asheville. Pours a nice black with amber edges and rocky, lacy tan head. The aroma is chocolatey with some roasty notes and some vanilla. The flavor is somewhat oat-like at first, then some sweet chocolate notes. The finish dries a little into some ashiness. Mild leafy hops bounce around throughout. Not great, a very typical dry stout.

On tap at Mellow Mushroom in Asheville, NC on 9/21/07. Pours black with a small tan head and good lacing retained. Nose is sweet and lactic and slightly nutty and chocolately. Flavor is dry and roasty with a little weird funkiness thrown in.

Draft sample at Knoxville Brew Jam. Poured a dark brown color with an average frothy brown head that mostly diminished with fair lacing. Moderate roasted coffee and chocolate malt aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Medium roasted bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Flavorful soft brew.
Some rust and a little caramel. Rusty red pour with good head and lacing. Slight tang in finish but pretty clean. Tap at brewery.

My Bottom Line: Underhopped or very sweet, it doesn’t matter. Dust covers this brew’s toasted cereals and the creamy sugars get unpalatable quickly. Further Personal Perceptions: -A slice of foam stays atop the dark amber. -The hefty body reduces drinkability considerably. -Fruity caramel flavors reach dominance soon enough. -Yet another Mexican artisanal brew that over-the-top sugary... On tap at Fiebre de Malta, Mexico City.

Draught at Fiebre de Malta, Mexico City. Clear nut brown, mid sized head. Fruity nose with some grass. Medium bodied with rounded mouthfeel. Firm, bready buttery malt, slight grassy hops. Low bitterness, Quite pleasant.
Amber colour. No head nor retention (poor service?) Sweet malt flavor and aroma, vienna malt. Hop presence just for bitterness, slightly and subtle dry finish, very nice.

Rich amber pour. White head. The aroma is softly sweet and malty. Fairly clean with a nice light vienna flavour. Lightly hopped, but clean. Pretty fresh and tasty actually. Light toasted malt with a little bit of sweetness on the finish. Well attenuated.
Amber color, aroma and taste are moderately sweet, caramel, bready, not bad.
[eyes] Good amber color with good start head. [nouse] NICE malty hoppy aroma [mouth] Fresh, the flavor is smooth and little bitter

Had it at the Santa Fe shopping mall in Mexico city. I felt a very artificial taste in this, watered down with a caramel and smokey taste. Its better than other Mexican Viennas but maybe i dont like the style too much. I dont know why there are so many viennas in Mexico.

I went to the Beer Factory in Puebla and ordered this while watching a baseball game. The appearance is typical of a vienna-style beer, and the flavor and aroma are very pleasing. No bitterness, and in my opinion a better alternative to the stout they also offer. If you are in Mexico City or Puebla, make it a point to go to a Beer Factory.

Bottle courtesy of Nekronos. A nice reddish amber lager with a thick big bubbled light moka head, lacing. Light caramel aroma, bready. In mouth, a light caramel malt, light roasted notes, very light bodied, with some reisdual nutty notes. Muchas gracias Raul.
@ Fiebre de Malta. Golden, thin head. Lightish body, malts are doughy, not much bitterness, and overall too sweet, unbalanced.

My Bottom Line: Stale hops and wet biscuits try to muster the courage to build a Pils together. Further Personal Perceptions: -A veil of foam covers the honeyed golden. -There is no crispness, no hop zip, no clarity at all in this one. -Carbonation is low, which doesn’t work with this particular profile. -This is quite fruity for a lager... -Dusty edges bore quickly. On tap at Fiebre de Malta, Mexico City.

A hazed golden pils with a thin white head. In aroma, German malt, light mineral notes, grassy German hops. In mouth, light grassy hops, light mineral notes, faint bodied, so-so. On tap at Fiebre de Malta.

Draught at Fiebre de Malta, Mexico City. Clear golden, small head. Fruity nose. Mid sweet with mediu body and cleanm rounded mouthfeel. Mostly fruity or neutral, with faint notes of boiled vegetables. Low bitterness.
Pale golden pour. The aroma is very light but there is a decent malt profile. The hops are quite faded, but the beer is decent. A simple macro-esque pilsner. Okay.
Im not big fan of pilsner style, but i have to admit this one was good, one of the best beer factory have made.
[eyes] Fresh, brillant, transparent. The head is white but poor. [Nouse] Kindly cereal aroma [Mouth] The bitter flavor is light medium for this Pilsner, Good election in this kind of Mexican Beer.
Corn nose, amber, pours a small off-white head. Meatalic taste, some malt no hops, light bodied, grainy, sweet unispired.. Thank You Nekronos.
Crystal clear apple juice body, minimal head. Aroma is non-existent. Taste is medium sweet, some grainy, nothing else. Watery light body, no crispness.
Good beer, I am impressed by this Mexicanbeers, fortunately there have been some improvings in owr brewing.
Spicy, it has an arma of spices and maybe chilli. The tatse is normal, but if you swallow, the aroma helps your taste to detect something hot in it.
Pine and citrus peel. Decent malt. No faults other than boring. Golden amber pour with good head and carpet lacing. Light tang in finish. Tap at brewery.

Draught at Beer Factory, Mundo E, Tlalnepantla. Clear amber, small head. Rich grapefruit aroma. Mid dry with clean mouthfeel and somewhat rounded mouthfeel. Slightly caramelly with mid intensity grapefruit hops. Mid bitter finish. A refreshing clean APA.

Para se una ipa me dejo muy insatisfecho, me gusto mas una que hizo el amigo de un primo y que era su primera chela, no tiene ese característico sabor amargo como a limón o naranja y muy poca carbonización.

Pours deep amber with a one finger head with regular retention, it hasva weak aroma with notes of caramel and roasted malts, it tastes like an average amber ale, it is not a pale ale, medium to light body, the flavor has notes of caramel, roasted malts and some citrus hops, slightly above macro

Pale amber pour with a tight white head. The aroma is of faded us hops - principally cascade, but the punchiness is gone and they are just there as a touch of light fruitiness. Soft and lightly hoppy/bitter. There is a bit of diacetyl on the finish. I suspect this started out as a good brew - but it’s definitely showing some age.

On tap. Pours a clear amber colour with a modest offwhite head. Aroma is faint, but has some malt character and pleasant hoppiness. Taste is disappointing, very watery. Some hoppiness with no malt character at all. Poor beer.

500 ml on tap, Puebla. Pours a nice dark amber color, minimal head. Aroma is sweet and malty with a little bit of hoppy freshness to offset it. Taste reflcts the aroma and is sweet and caramelly with some bitterness. Well balanced and easy to drink, and should match up well with most meals at the restaurant. Palate is smooth and body is full. Better than I expected.
Amber dark color, hoppy aroma, a little bit wattery, smooth flavour, not bad.

[eyes] Ambar darky color the head is medium creamy color,trasparent. [nouse] Medium malty aroma, a little floral and citric. [Mouth] Smooth bitterness, the large is better than the first tonge touch, very fressh and crispy

On tap at the Tjbeer fest. Mild watery and very thin body. Otherwise it has a nice backround to it citrusy hops and light bitterness... very little malts... maybe it was being served too cold, i should try it again sometime im in the Capital and let it sit for a while. Feb 2008, I tried this in Mexico City and its the same thing... pretty bland and comercial tasting.
Some coffee and roast. Black pour with good head and lacing. Ligh bitter end. Watery. Tap at brewery.
una tristeza. Empezó siendo una muy buena cerveza pero con el paso del tiempo y el cambio de dueños a esta cerveza la han aguadado brutalmente
Un sabor a malta tostado y de chocolate amargo pero no en gran intencidad. Una opcion para introducirse en la gama, pero para cualquiera en busqueda de una buena experiencia stout queda debiendo.

Pint glass poured at Graciela, Taller de Cerveza in Mexico City. Deep reddish brown Poured with moderate tan head. Foam retains fullness for quite a long time. Coffee roast without bitterness in initial taste, but not sustained. Mouthfeel is moderate to thin. Neutral aftertaste but easily encourages your next sip.

De Tipo irlandés, de color castaño-oscuro, proveniente de maltas negras y chocolate utilizadas en su elaboración. Esta cerveza presenta un gran cuerpo y una espuma consistente que se encuentran perfectamente balanceados con los lúpulos ingleses utilizados.
This beer has the right proportion of classic stout beers! When you come to Mexico, please taste it!-- rated via 'Find A Beer' for Blackberry 10

Draught at Beer Factory, Mundo E, Tlalnepantla. Near black, mid sized head. Fruity nose with some coffee. Medium bodied with clean, somewhat rounded mouthfeel. Mid sweet and fruity with some cocoa powder and mid bitter finish. Rather lifeless stout.

Pours a black brew with a small beige head with poor retention, aroma is moderate bitter and moderate to low sweet witj coffe, chocolate and rosated malt, médium bodied, flavor is moderate bitter and moderate sweet with chocolate, coffe and roasted malt, creamy textutre, slightly bitter finish.

Tenia mas expectativas de esta cerveza, es una stout muy rica pero por lo que había oído de ella me imagine que era grandiosa, no ayuda el elevado costo, ni el vaso en el que lo sirven, la comida en el lugar es buena pero en cuanto a cervezas, se me hace como un starbucks del café y no necesariamente en el buen sentido
Fantastic beer, enjoy in Mexico City and Puebla. Fantastica cerveza mexicana,oscura.. Caramel

From a growler fresh from the brewpub. Pours cloudy copper-amber with head and lace. Aroma of brown malts and old fruit juice. Medium carbonation and mouthfeel. Flavors of amber malts, minerals, grains, wet rag, caramel. Overall rich and flavorful but a tad more sweet with malts than BJCP guidelines, not clean, bready, or with a dry finish and not something I totally crave after a glass. Here's the overall BJCP guidelines: "An elegant, malty German amber lager with a clean, rich, toasty and bready malt flavor, restrained bitterness, and a dry finish that encourages another drink. The overall malt impression is soft, elegant, and complex, with a rich aftertaste that is never cloying or heavy."
Amber with a tall tan head. Sweet dough malts, earth, toast, and slightly sour in the finish. Medium bodied. Nice fest brew but a little too much caramel for me. Still, I’d drink it twice.
Draft. Small off-white head atop clear dark amber body. Aroma is moderately sweet, bread, orange, light caramel. Taste is moderately sweet, orange/earthy, some bread.
Draught at brewpub Hazy red-amber color with compact head. Very simple malt and caramel profile, off-dry, ordinary bitterness. Light yeasty aroma. Not similar to a Festbier. Simple beer.
Bottle. Pours an amber brown with big off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts and spices. Flavor is much the same. Very smooth, I could drink a lot of these.
Clear amber orange, thin beige head. Aroma of buttery dough, toast, nutty malt. Taste of sweet fruit, burnt bitterness.
pours a slightly dark amber and off white head. has a very distinct smell of caramel and a very malty aroma, overall decent october for a local brewer

Pint (or two) @ 74th St. Ale House. Part of their Oktoberfest lineup. Much tastier than the Alpine I had right before it. Big and malty marzen perfect for the season. Only issue is that it looked a little muddy, but damn tasty.

Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--Harvest Moon Festbier Style Ale--2001 22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV--24 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) Oktoberfest--Clear rich copper red color. Creamy malty lacy head. Toasted fruit malt mild floral hop front. Creamy lager smooth crisp mild roasted sweet cherry caramel body. Mild hop creamy malt spice end. Sampled 9/9/2001. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--Harvest Moon Festbier Style Ale--2002--22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV. (3.75 / 5.0) Oktoberfest--Hazy rich amber color. Rich white lacy head. Light sediment. Mild hop malty front. Smooth crisp thick sweet caramel malty ale ester fruit body. Dry clean mild hop citrus end. More of a light hop amber. Sampled 9/29/2002. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--Harvest Moon Festbier Style Ale--2003 22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV--24 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) Oktoberfest--Clear rich dark amber red color. Light toasted malty mild hop front. Light sediment. Rich clean light sweet toasted caramel fruit body. Smooth mild hop end. A touch bland but smoothly drinkable. Sampled 9/13/2003. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--Harvest Moon Festbier Style Ale--New Unique Logo--2004-B 22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV--24 IBU’s Oktoberfest--Sighted at Fremont Oktoberfest 9/17/2004. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--Harvest Moon Festbier Style Ale--Original Logo--2004-A 22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV--24 IBU’s. (4.25 / 5.0) Oktoberfest--Rich foamy lacy head. Hazy bright dark amber color. Floral malty mild hop front. Smooth rich creamy malty crusty sweet mild toasted caramel toffee body with Ale ester tang. Doughy base. Smooth mild hop end. Sampled 9/10/2004. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--SNOQUALMIE Harvest Moon Festbier Style Ale--2005 22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV--24 IBU’s. (4.25 / 5.0) Oktoberfest--Creamy stable rich lacy head. Bright Bottle Conditioned hazy pretty amber red color. Mild hop floral malt front. Malty smooth crisp caramel mellow sweet fruit ester doughy mild tangy Fest Ale body. Smooth mild hop end. Sampled 9/24/2005. SNOQUALMIE Harvest Moon Festbier-Style Ale--2006 22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV--24 IBU’s. (4.25 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Fest--Rich lacy head. Hazy deep amber red rich bright color. Malty mild fruit hop front. Rich mild sweet creamy caramel fruit malty body. Smooth clean crisp mild hop end. Tasty Malty Fest Ale. Richer in 2005? Sampled 9/9/2006. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--SNOQUALMIE Harvest Moon Festbier-Style Ale--2007 22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV--24 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Fest--Rich mild lace foamy copper head. Clear dark amber bronze color. Mild hop malt front fruit ester front. Creamy mild crusty toasted biscuit caramel fruity malty body. Smooth malty mild hop clean toasted end. Sampled 9/29/2007. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--SNOQUALMIE--Harvest Moon Ale--German Style Festbier--A smooth, Oktoberfest-inspired Festbier--New Label Style--2008 22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV--24 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0 ) Amber Ale--Fest--Dense lacy off white head . Sediment hint. Clear cold hazed rich bright amber gold color. Mild malt hop front. Malty smooth mild fruit caramel tangy refreshing Fest Ale mild ester body. Mild tangy malt spice hop hint smooth crisp end. Mellow Amber Festbier Ale. Sampled 9/19/2008. 4 @ $3.49 Each. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--SNOQUALMIE--Harvest Moon Ale--German Style Festbier--A smooth, Oktoberfest-inspired Festbier--New Label Style--2009 22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV--24 IBU’s. (4.25 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Fest--Rich dense lacy off white head. Clear bright dark rich amber color. Light unfiltered sediment. Rich malty mild hop toasted fruit hint front. Smooth mild creamy malty rich toasted caramel mild doughy biscuit fruit hint body. Clean satisfying mild hop smooth end. Sampled 11/1/2009. 2 @ $3.49 Each. Snoqualmie Falls Brewing Company--SNOQUALMIE Perfectly Balanced Hand Crafted Ales--Harvest Moon Ale--German Style Festbier--A smooth, Oktoberfest-inspired Festbier--2010 22 oz. Bottle. 5.30% ABV. 24 IBU’s. (4.0 / 5.0) Amber Ale--Festbier. Lacy rocky dense lasting rust orange head. Fizz hazed dark bright amber red color. Toasted dark malt ester mild hop front. Creamy smooth mellow sweet cloying frothy malty toasted doughy caramel toffee black cherry hint body. Satisfying mild hop Fest end. A favorite highly anticipated Seasonal release that seems a little overly sweet malty this year. Sampled 9/12/200. 2 @ $3.99 Each Purchased at The Ballard Market, Seattle, WA 9/12/2010.

Date: September 11, 2009 Mode: Draft Source: Brewpub Appearance: clear dark amber, wispy off white head, streaks of lace Aroma: sweet caramel malt aroma, touch of bready character, light earthyness Flavor: sweet caramel malt flavor, touch of sticky candy, light bread, light balancing earthyness Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Drinkability: 7/10 Score: ** /4
Not as good as negra modelo, but a decent beer to drink on tap on almost every bar in México.
Draft: ultra sweet you can taste the sugar cane. Not their best work! Eat lots of tacos.

En fût au Los Tabernacos à Playa Del Carmen. Je pensais que c’était la Modelo Obscura mais ça l’air que non. Couleur ambrée assez foncé, mousse mince. Arôme de malt caramel. En bouche, caramel, malt et une finale douce et maltée. Bonne beer.

From tap at San Jose del Cabo airport. Pours slight hazy dark brown with a small off-white and creamy head. Aroma is dark roasted malty and vague yeasty. Bitter, dark roasted malty and vague yeasty fruity. Medium dry and bitter finish.
Dark reddish brown pour, white head, aroma is some vinegar, dark malt, roast. Taste is some biscuit, black roast, slightly vinegary finish.
dark cristal color, little head, little malty aroma strong steel aroma, no flavor but is fresh and smooth, no taste,

Draft while on honeymoon in Cancun. Now after having read the reviews, i agree with DuffMan - This reminded me of Negra Modelo, except not as good. Poured dark amber with good clarity and a thin light-tan head. Caramel, and weak malt flavor. A bit grainy in the aftertaste. Not all that great, but for mexico, this was a treat.

Draught @ Applebee’s in Mexico. Average creamy off-white head that mostly lasted. Good display of lacework. Clear sparkling body with a light dark amber color. Aroma of toasted malt, caramel, hint of grass and hay. Over the palate came more toasted malt, hint of butter and again grassy notes. Light bodied with an average carbonation and hint of dry texture. Light sweet flavor with a hint of bitterness. Sweet caramel and toasted malty finish. Quit ok beer in the Mexican sun.

This is available in bottles now for a limited time, marketed as "Edition Especial" with a fancy plastic label. Purchased in the mini-market in the plaza near the convention center. Truthfully, I found this identical to Negra Modelo in every respect (I had one right after the other, so I’m pretty set on this). Here is my rating for Negra Modelo: Dark amber, brown sugary aroma. Sweeter palate than the pale lager, a little metallic though. Not bad considering its origins. Ditto for Modelo Obscura.

While staying at Barcelo Premium Colonial Resort in the Mayan Riviera this was one of two beers available on draft. The other being Corona. Iced tea appearance, caramel flavor, and the only game in town if you wanted a beer with some color.
250 ml bottle at Naples airport. Clear light golden with white head. Light grain, light corn. Dry with low bitterness and medium carbonation.
bottle dorata limpida ferro cereale niente aroma astringenze amaro poco poco corpo

330ml bottle from the shop in Rome, drunk at the hotel. Pours clear with a frothy head that lasted a bit, medium lacing and a brief bead. Mid straw in colour. Bread and caramel on the nose with some floral notes. Lively in the mouth with mid carbonation, releasing soft malty biscuit flavours with a gentle hop presence, mild bitterness, quite a bit of sugar, but with a crisp finish. Overall, a pretty decent lager.
Una lager color giallo paglierino. Gusto secco e rinfrescante, con un giusto bilanciamento di malto e mais. Leggera e dissetante, dal gusto pieno, dall’aroma di puro malto.
Bottle shared by Inoven. Clear a bit pale golden color, average sized white head. Smell and taste malts, hay, a bit sweetish malts, slightly wort. Average to decent body and carbonation. Not bad.
Flesje gedeeld met Benzai. Helder goudgeel bier. Schuim is snel weg. Aroma van hooi en wort. In de smaak komt een vleugje sinaasappel naar boven met een vleugje hop. Smaak ebt snel weg.
bottle @ eataly (rome) nothing special lager beer, pale colour, light body, medium carbonated

from supermarket Conad, Alba Adriatica - translucid golden beer with no foam left; oily grassy and papery aroma; subtle carbonation, tart, medium-bodied, astringent bitterness and aftertaste of cardboard
Rating #1064, flaske fra café i Rom. Aroma af grøntsager og våd hund. Smag af lidt karamel, alkohol og ren humlebitterhed til sidst. Medium tyk. Standard udseende for en tynd pilsner.

Butelka 0,25, niespecjalnie zachęcająca etykieta. Zwykłe P, zobaczymy co jest w środku. Piwo żółte, piana o małych bombelkach niemniej szybko schodzi, zostawiając malutki leasing. Aromat słaby trochę bananowy. Średnio gazowane. Niestety w ustach wyczuwalny aromat alkoholu. Mdły finisz. Niezły aromat jak na koncerniak no i też fajnie że nie tak nagazowane jak reszta Peroni. Ze względu na brązową butelkę nadaje się na małe wypady za miasto itp.
Draft. Pours brown with a beige head. Light toasted malts, medium sweetness, faint roast, and light earthy notes. Pretty good.

[4669-20120817] Tap. Sweetened caramel brûlée and roasted grains aroma. Clear, dark red brown body with a quick foamy off-white head. Lightly boozy malt and grains and beer-soaked bread flavour. Medium body. Average. (6/3/6/3/13) 3.1 (@ brewpub, Selinsgrove, PA)

Hand pump at Brewpub. Pours brown with an inch of khaki foam that leaves little lacing. Slight caramel note on the nose. A bit thin on the tongue. Bigger caramel on the tongue. Solid but not spectacular.

Growler, Campground Brewdown. Medium beige head that mostly disappears atop clear garnet body. Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee/roast, some honey, light cherry. Taste is moderately sweet, roast, some earthy, cherry, milk chocolate, honey. Medium body, light stickiness.

On tap at Selin’s Grove. Pours a clear cola brown with a thin white head. Sweet chocolate and roast. Nutty, roast, chocolate and cocoa. Medium bodied, smooth, very drinkable. Roasty and sweet, light bitterness into the finish.
Medium nutty brown, tan head. Nose is faint roast, chocolate & cola. Flavor is cola, nutty malt, chocolate, english hoppiness. Nice, but the molasses imparts an overwhelming cola character.

2012-08-17. Very dark brown black body with very small tan head. Flavour is pretty sweet malt, very light roast, mild dark fruity undertones. Lingering sweet fruity malt in the aftertaste. Mild notes of molasses as per the menu description if you look. 6+ Similar aroma is sweet malt, sugary mild molasses if you look, muted roast. Smooth average plus palate us very lightly carbonated. Okay. On tap at Selins Grove, Pennsylvania

Tap at the brewpub. Pours a clear cola. Huge tan lace. Sticky. Nose is muted with milk chocolate. Taste is big milk chocolate, raisin and walnut bread. Bitter finish. Very nice. Some light dairy character. Similar viscosity to the stout. No roast. Still quite nice.
Light molasses and cola nose. Light to moderately sweet, soft and creamy palate, touch of brown sugar, some dark chocolate. Very quaffable.

Draft. Pours cloudy, reddish-brown with faint off-white head; short retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is toasted malt, caramel, earthy notes, and light oak. Flavor is average toasted malt, light earthy hops, and light dark fruit esters; smooth with a hint of vanilla. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

column1: Selins Grove St. Fillans Wee Heavy
column5: New England Bucket List Trip #230. Cask at the brewpub. Pours a clear copper with a large creamy off-white head. Good head retention. Aroma of dark fruit, brown sugar, toffee. The taste is toffee, toasted malt, raisin, vanilla, spicy hops. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness.

column1: Selins Grove St. Fillans Wee Heavy
column5: Cask. Pours amber with a thin head. Malty, with medium sweetness, faint dark fruity notes, and a hint of floral hops. Good stuff, and very chuggable for 9%.

column1: Selins Grove St. Fillans Wee Heavy
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear amber brown with a thin white head. Warn spicy malt with some plum and caramel. Big malt with some tangy plum notes. King spicy malt, warming toast.

column1: Selins Grove St. Fillans Wee Heavy
column5: Cask at brewpub. pours brown with a thick khaki head. I didn’t get a ton on the nose except for a bit of alcohol. Fairly sweet on the tongue. Hides it’s alcohol well and finishes clean. Not as complex as I felt it should have been.

column1: Selins Grove St. Fillans Wee Heavy
column5: Had this on cask at the Selin’s Grove 14th anniversary party. It was the ’09 and it was served into a goblet. A - Pours deep dark brown with a strong one finger white head, dissipating to a light film, leaving minimal lacing down the glass. S - Lots of toffee and caramel sweetness up front. Some dark fruits, most noticeably raisins and figs, begin to come out as it warms up a bit. It looks like the extra cellar time has killed most of the boozy aroma’s giving this one a sweet roasty nose. T - Plenty of sweet toffee and caramel up front giving way quickly to a mixture of dark fruits, raisins and figs, and bit of earthy hops. Finish has some strong sweetness that lingers for some time after consumption. Booze is ever present offering a light warming feeling but it is hidden well. Very sweet but not to the point of being overpowering. Very nice wee heavy. M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Quite the creamy feel with a lingering sweet finish. Not too much heat from the booze in this one. D - Good not great. I really liked this one but I liked the barrel aged version better. I am not sure I could have more than one of these at a time. Definitely a sipper at 12% ABV.

column1: Selins Grove St. Fillans Wee Heavy
column5: On cask at the brewpub. Reviewed from notes. I was told this was a wee heavy, but given the taste of it and the reviews from here, I’m sure it’s the same beer. I believe this was the 2009 edition. Pours dark brown with a thin off white head with some staying power, leaving a bit of lace as it does recede. The nose brings dark fruits, caramel, a touch of booze, and some sweetened malt. The taste adds in a bit of chocolate and brown sugar. A bit more alcohol. Definitely a dark, earthy version of the style. I suppose this really is more like a wee heavy. Good caramel and toffee throughout. The feel is fairly heavy though not overly so. Drinks quite well and was a nice sipper. Serving type: cask Reviewed on: 10-24-2010

column1: Selins Grove St. Fillans Wee Heavy
column5: 2009 on cask at the brewpub. Arrived at the table a deep clear ruby with a moderate linen white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left partial lace. Pleasant aroma of rich sweet malt with toffee along with a few vapors of alcohol. The flavor is superb; rich and malty, toffee sweetness, molasses, a bit of earthy peat, bourbon, vanilla, its all there. Mild bitterness at the finish. Rich and full bodied. Smooth on the palate. This is delicious!

column1: Selins Grove St. Fillans Wee Heavy
column5: 2008, Cask. Pours a dark brown with a small tan head. Funky, sour, malty aroma. Quite sour, and tasty; warming finish. A find.

column1: Selins Grove St. Fillans Wee Heavy
column5: Sample platter Sweet raisin and dark fruit aroma. Very malty and syrupy with a sweet dried cherry flavor. Finished boozy, nearly a spiced rum. Clingy aftertaste, warm in the mouth.

column1: Selins Grove St. Fillans Wee Heavy
column5: On cask at the brewpub. Pours a dark, yet clear coppery color with almost no head. Aroma of candied sugar and light malt. Taste of malt, dark fruit and candied sugar.

Nitro draft at brewery that poured inky black with tan head. Aroma is roast, dark chocolate, coffee and smoke. Taste is moderate bitters and a touch of sweetness. Medium bodied, silky smooth and another excellent beer.
Draft Sample at Brewpub. Pours brown/black with red hues. Sweet and caramel-esque with mild roast, something odd, like eating spent grain. Delicious grainy, grainness.

Taster glass at Selin's Grove, with ML. Pours opaque dark brown/black. Tan head. Aroma is campfire smoke, roasted malts, toffee, and dark chocolate. Flavour is drier than the nose would suggest. Notes of almonds, bread, toffee, expresso, and chocolate. Surprisingly light body.

A: Dark Brown Hue, Passes Very Little Light, Off White Head Ring, Some Lacing S: Dark Roasted Malts, Mild Coffee, Mild Chocolate T: Dark Roasted Chocolate Malts, Coffee, Mild Nutty, Oatmeal M: Decent Carbonation, Medium to Full Bodied, Smokey Overall, a pretty solid Oatmeal Stout with lots of flavors.
Nitro pour. Pours deep brown with a beige nitro head. Medium roasted malts, some nutty and chocolate sweetness, and faint earthy notes. Nice.
On tap, Pours clean brownish black, cream head, aroma is roast, taste is nice sweet and roast, a little thin on the palate.

[4670-20120817] Tap. Roasted smoky grains and dry wood aroma. Murky, dark brown black body with a long-lasting creamy light tan head. Smoky roasted grains flavour has a long aftertaste of burnt cigarette ashes and smoky kindling. Full body. Overpowering! (7/3/6/3/13) 3.2 (@ brewpub, Selinsgrove, PA)
Nitro pour(black) with tan head. Roasted and bitter malts with some light earthy and smokey tones of aroma. Texture is creamy. Flavor is smokey, bitter and still with roasted tones.

On tap at Selin’s Grove. Pours a dark caramel cola color with a medium sized dense creamy head. Cocoa, chocolate, sweet roast and malt, caramel. Creamy and smooth, roast and cocoa. Chocolate and roast. Nice coffee notes, sweet and creamy finish, roast and caramel.
Black, tan head. Nose is sweet, toasty & burnt malt, dark fruit, some oxidation. Flavor is roast, light burnt character, dark sweet fruits, honey. Sweet but nice.

Pours dark amber with a beige head. Has a citrus smell and has a delightful balance of hops, coriander, and citrus flavor with the right amount of bitterness to finish. One of the better IPAs I’ve had.

Tap. ON my visit to SG, this was listed as 1.078 OG and 9% abv, so a bit stronger. Deep copper with a lacing beige head. Nose again beautifully mellow, melon, musky, snappy. Medium-bitter, very dry, lightly soapy and cleansing, touch of rye character, straight melon with some citrus and very light pine. Also has a minty note that I’ve only found in the Hüll varieties, a nice surprise. Medium-full, very soft (almost flat) but refreshing and very attractive!

Draft. Murky dark amber body with small beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, grapefruit, some orange, spicy. Taste is moderately sweet, grapefruit, some spicy, light coriander. Medium body, light acidity, resin.

Draft sample at brewpub. Cloudy yellow orange, no head. Nose of pine and orange, grapefruit. Caramel backbone, semi sweet and mildly bitter, lingering, lots of citrus and floral notes, grapefruit, lemon, orange, flower pedal. Some herbal quality. Solid.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours a hazy orange-gold with thin white head aroma is caramel, citrus, lemon, fruit. Medium to full body, creamy mouthfeel. Solid but balanced bitterness with a bit of sweetness on the finish
Golden orange hue, floral and citrus notes in flavor and aroma, well balanced, perfect carbonation.

12oz pour at the brewery. Pours a translucent orange with some sudsy white head. Nose is spot on, soapy, piney, orange, lemon, light malt. Flavor is the same, lightly malty, lightly lemony, a little tea, a little stone fruit, unripened plum. Clean finish.
draft at Selin’s Grove. orangish pour & medium bodied. fruit forward with solid caramel malt backbone. orange & tangerine notes, medium biterness
Draft. Pours golden orange with a white head. Big citric hops, grass, and mint, with a clean malty base. Great big hoppy flavor with only medium bitterness. Good stuff.

Growler from the brewery. Pours turbid orangy copper with 1-finger of lacy off-white head. Nose is very fruity, with tangerine, mango, caramel malt. Tastes caramel malty, smooth, complex, with mid-palate fruity notes of mango,pineapple, tangerine, and some berry notes. More fruity than piney or resiny, this one is very good.

New England Bucket List Trip #229. Keg at the brewpub. Pours a clear amber with a large creamy tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of caramel malt and floral hops. The taste is caramel, toffee, dark fruit, brown sugar. Medium bodied, mild lingering fruit.
Draft sample at Brewpub. Pours red and clear. Sweet sugar nose, bread and biscuit. Nice caramel flavor, mild bitter, some bread, rather sweet. Clean and tasty.

Sampled at the brewery. Light neutral fruity notes, cherry wood. Sweet caramel malt. Coppery amber clear with thin head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Starts moderately sweet with apple skin, grape must, caramel and neutral fruity character. Mild nutty bitter notes with muted hop bitterness. Nutty smooth Altbier after.

16oz pour is a clear brown with some thin beige head. Nose is nice, vinous, malty, cracker, mild booze, almost like processed mead. Flavor is solid, malty, vinous, a little tannic, lemon tea, honey, dried grass. Clean finish. Complex but drinkable.

The Scottish ale is a tried and true ale, and it's one if those beers where it's hard to mess up, which means almost anyone's is usually drinkable. The downside here is that when a beer is "common" or hard to really mess up that folks stop trying to make a beer interesting or unique and you rarely taste a Scottish ale that makes you stop and say... mmmm. Well Selins Grove you made me stop to say... mmmm. Soft, Carmely, smooth, with absolutely no bitterness. This is the kind of Scottish ale that sets standards.

A: Ambery Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Mild Lacing S: Malty, Light Caramel T: Malty, Light Caramel, Light Toffee M: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Sweet, Mildly Bitter Overall, an average Scotch ale with lots of malt character.
Draft. Brown hazy pour with some light head. Aromas has some full malt tones. Flavor is woody and malt heavy with a smooth finish. Not my favorite style but still a nice beer.

The aroma is chocolate, caramel, bready, malty. The appearance is deep red/brown, small white head. The flavor is chocolate, caramel, biscuit, like the aroma. The finish is light pine bitterness. Medium in body. Decent.

Draft. Pours hazy, dark gold with thin, creamy white head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is cloves, bread malt, straw, and light citrus. Flavor is heavy caramel and toasted malts, faint hops, and average fruit esters; smooth with a slightly sweet finish. Medium body, low carbonation, and low warmth.

Tap. Pours hazy amber with a small, creamy off-white head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is light caramel and cookie malt, light fruity esters and faint hops. Flavor is malt dominant, light hops, fruity esters and a sweet finish. Light body and warmth with medium carbonation.
On tap at Selin’s Grove brewpub. Powerful, spicy aroma. I’m not really an expert on farmhouse saisons, but this was light and very drinkable. A lot better than Weyerbacher’s Muse.
Tap at the source. Mostly clear deep golden color with a smallish white head. Rich honey maltiness with plenty of pepper and clove to counter. Smooth deceivingly easy to drink, great triple.

Growler from brewery that poured hazy gold with a small white head. Soft carbonation leads to smooth mouth feel. Aroma is yeast, candied sugar, earthy and pear. Taste is sweet with some acidic tartness. Nice.

New England Bucket List Trip #236. Keg at the brewpub. Pours a clear golden with a thin creamy off-white head. Good head retention. Aroma of herbal hops, bread,y malt, dry stone fruit. The taste is candi sugar, bready malt, yeast, stone fruits. Medium bodied, mild booze, lingering fruit.

Tap at SG, this on 1.078 OG and 9% abv. Hazy yellow golden with a white head. Medium body, sugary with Belgian yeast character, esters, some spice and mineral spirit; off-dry, low bitterness, meringue, orange peel, dries with time and "spices out." Alcohol masterfully hidden.
Draft at the source. This is a sweetish, lightly spiced triple that is easy drinking despite its strength. Tasty.

[5665-20130817] Tap. Mild cold-cut hammy meat aroma. Hazy, pale yellow brown body with a long-lasting creamy white head and thick lacing. Ham roast and cloves flavour has a light floor cleaner aftertaste. Medium-full body is quite boozy. Interesting, great to sample. (7/3/7/3/14) 3.4

Clear yellow pour from the brewery. White head. Aroma of candied orange peel, slight vanilla, golden raisin. Taste is sweet but clean. Not really even a hint of alcohol like the style usually presents. Very well done.

This one poured a hazy golden color with a white head. Aroma was of candy sugar oranges, light fruit and esters. Flavor was sweet bread, candy sugar, apple skins, oranges and yeast. Tasty tripel for sure

transparent gold, fizzes out with oily wisp white head. Honey and bubblegum nose, huge esters whacking with sweetness. Light vomit and sugar at front palate, hot and sticky mid brings plastics, gravel, dirty banana and burnt sugars through the boozy, thick end. Way more bitterness for balance, up attenuation, esters should be less sweet with more floral or pepper to nuance.
Draft sample at Brewpub. Pours yellow with white head. Floral nose, bubblegum, some herbs. Herbs, thyme and coriander with floral notes. Nice and dry, mild bitter with little hop flavor. Done well.
Growler thanks to Toby pours out dark red topped with a small head. Nose is big sweet cherries some toffee notes. Tatse is more of the nice sweet cherries a touch of tartness to balance it out.

Very old rating found on a loose page while cleaning, possibly from 2010. Notes are from a tasting, possibly RB gathering in Grand Rapids - Reddish pour. It smells of cherries and spice (cinnamon, I think). The flavor is full of tart cherries along with some cinnamon. Very good.

Growler brought back by a friend. This one has been on my list for many years. Pours a clear cherry red with a thin beige head. Aroma of sweet cherry, sweet malt, very light caramel and slight Belgian esters. Sweet cherry and sweet malt flavor with slight tartness before a sweet and estery cherry finish.

On tap at the source, I liked it so much in my sampler that I ordered a glass afterwards. Deep red with a pink tinged head. Huge tart cherry aroma and flavor. Reminds me a lot of New Glarus Belgian Red, very tasty.

At the July DC tasting. Poured a dark brown color with an off-white head. Aroma was light cherry, light toffee, caramel malts. Flavor was very light tart cherry juice. Cherry skins on the finish. A pretty tasty beer, refreshing surprisingly!
From a bottle at the DC tasting July 10, 2016. Pours a clear deep amber with an off white head. Caramel aroma. Flavors of cherry and toffee. Sweet finish.

Growler shared 6/10/16. Definitely a very unexpected surprise, as I never ended up trying this stuff back in the day (that I remember). Good clarity to this black cherry liquid with some brighter hues on the edges. Pink-flecked, off-white head is initially large but fully falls to cover/ring rather quickly. Huge cherry nose has light glue, medicines, all sorts of phenols and definitely some wood/vegetal-like cherryskin notes. Despite the slight medicinal/phenolic character, which I believe is actually quite natural/authentic, it’s bursting with huge aromatics and bright fruit flavors but yet retains a funky, fermented/macerated feel to it as well. Honey and vanilla show through, from the malts, packing the aroma even more full. No alcohol or flaw. Just like the 2 Roads Framboise Noir was ultra jammy, this thing is super medicinal, but in a mostly good way. Lots of cherry pit, cherry flesh and light cellar qualities, with huge black pepper phenols and a sweet, lightly syrupy at times (but for the engaging carbonation which helps clear it) texture. Definitely on the sweeter side of things, relative to Belgian fruit beers, much like New Glarus. But just like them, the fruit is done so well that it’s easy to forgive a lot.

4 oz pour on draft at City Tap House during the SAVOR Week event. Dark ruby red with light pinkish white head. Aromas of cherries, light tart notes. Tastes of cherries, spice, tart cherry juice, cherry pie filling. Medium body with a dry finish. Pretty tasty, like a tart and juicy cherry pie without the crust.

Wonderfully executed. Ruby red pour with great head and lacing. Well executed cherry with light cutrus bretta. Sweet and tangy finish. Awesome drinkability here. You can taste the cherry skins and fruit of the berry here. Tap at city tap house.

Aroma - tart cherry, cherry pie like filling and associated sugary nature, some crumb and sugar. Appearance - body is a hazy garnet. The head is a soft pink, and around 3/4" of an inch and settles slowly. Scattered lacing. Taste - has a rich black cherry - you can taste the skin and flesh of the cherry - at the same time you can taste a rich pie filling like flavor. There is a tart quality to the cherries, some sugary crumb like flavor. This is essentially a cherry pie in a glass. Quite incredible. Palate - medium bodied, sticky and slightly slick texture, average carbonation, tart and slightly alcoholic finish.

This is more a fruit-accented saison with some funkiness than a fruit wheat. The apricot is front and center and provides a tartness that complements the slight musty funk and turns this into more of a dessert-like treat than a beer. It isn’t super-complex, and it’s definitely a ’girly’ fruit beer, but damn it’s fresh and tasty.
Very nice, had a slight amount of sourness that brought out the fruit well.
Interbrew sends this stuff in major cities in Poland under various names . Slightly metalic , thin watery , some hop at the end .
What's there to say? Just another pale grainy pilsener by Oranjeboom. Boring, unintersting, couldn't finish a whole bottle.

Clear yellow color. Head is initially large, frothy, but diminishes real quickly. Aroma of bitter hops, typical pilsener. Taste is not that bad actually. Dry bitter finish ofcourse. I was expecting a lot worse.

Yuk, malty, stinky aroma. Typical for a german pilsener. taste is like some dirty vegetable, long past its date. No this is crap. Okay better than normal Oranjeboom, butI guess this beer will give you an exquisite headache too.

Appearance is very clear, with rapidly disappearing head. Almost no aroma. Typical pilsener taste. Bitter finish. Not the best pilsener i've ever had, but definitely better than Oranjeboom's own brew.
This wasn't too bad. It poured a typical pale orange color with a nice white head. The flavor was hoppy yet balanced and I would try this again.
Very average pale ale, nice hoppy aroma, decent hoppiness in the body & flavors, ok balance, wasn't enough of a malt profile to throughly balance the beer, a decent pale ale
Hopy nose. Good hop flavor. Light malt, but proper for style. This is a good APA example and a hop lovers beer.
Wonderful aroma, almost cidery, which was weird for this style. Kinda bland taste again, some bitterness with a bad aftertaste that left my mouth tasting like a pine tree.
Awesome brown ale, dark amber in color, kept a very nice soft head, full nutty flavors, well balanced, roasted malt & nut undertones, excellent ale
Unfortunately this brewpub is no longer open. What a shame. This was a decent porter, nothing spectacular, but a nice drink nonetheless. Ah well, what can you do.
Japan Takamatsu in een Tapas bar in het winkelcentrum bij ons hotel. Smaakt best wel goed na de Koreaanse biertjes

Bottle that I have picked up, in one Japanese grocery, in Paris. Trying and rating this beer, today, at Epalinges, in our flat. In my point of view, it is an average lager, not bad at all. Firstly, you get a gold body, clear, average carbonation, thin and white foam. The taste is decently malty, round, bready, rather dry, normal dosis of hop, perfect for these hot days.
Best Japanese beer around, bro! Was blown away when I first tasted it at a spanish joint in Kyoto.Nice in both large and small bottle. Find it at Izumiya supermarket or Yamaya. Kampai!
Draught @ Mount Takao Beer Mount, Tokyo. Sweetish, grainy and earthy bulk lager with hints of hops.
Multiple paper cups of this at some insane grocery store with the famous Kyoto man himself, Mark. Pours a clear golden hue with a medium white head. Toast, bready, semi-sweet. Soft perfume. Decent.
Just an average beer but it is delicious. Great with food and it never becomes boring or a chore to drink.
Fat. Klar guldfärgad med ett vitt skum. Dofter och smaker av säd, vitt bröd och malt. En i mängden av lageröl om än inte en av de sämre.
Om tap at gonpachi. Pale Golden color creamy White head disappearing bit lacing. Mild grainy aroma adjuncts and light hops. Average pilsener
Bottle, 500 ml at Red Hill Bar, Takayama. Pours golden, white head. Malty, grainy, sweetish with light bitterness in finish. Light to medium bodied. Had worse.
500mL bottle pour from Neon Forest Museum Bar in Kyoto. Light golden yellow with white head. Cereal malt, light hops, a little corn and skunk.

Traveling drank this @ Beaver Street Brewery and Restaurant Flagstaff,AZ - Poured light yellow color - I had to really stick my nose in to smell any hop presence! Very watery and lacking real taste? Almost tasted like a commercial grade mexican brew? Overall very unsatisfying! Not recommended!

On draft at Beaver Street. Pour was full amber colored body with some copper hues. Head was nice off-white, provided excellent almost continuous lacing all the way down with some ring patterns in there. The aroma was caramel, toffee, some piney-citrusey notes, but certainly not strong. Flavor followed the aroma, nice bitter resinous bite at the end of each sip, only gentle floral and citrusey touches behind it all, more bittering hops than any flavors. The mouthfeel was quite nice, slightly creamy for the style, a decent sipper (in a somewhat unimpressive style for me) on a beautiful sunny afternoon in Flagstaff.
Smell is citrus, hops, and malts. Look is clear straw colored with a nice white head. Taste is sweet, caramel, smooth, with a good balance of malts and hops. Good overall.

Medium gold color. Nicely malty, and smooth. Milder flavor. Nice hop balance. Mouthfeel is smooth and full. Smooth taste and flavor, reminiscent of English Ales (DUH!) Finish is smooth. Aftertaste is slightly malty.
Not all that pleasing. Golden color pour with a decent sized head. Aroma was slightly fruity. Smooth but slightly off flavor.

I’m assuming this is the one I had? 12oz bottle labeled Organic Blonde Ale (but why are the ratings from so long ago, hmm). Poured a deeper and cloudy golden color with a huge sized head. Aromas of earthy mustiness, citrus, and grapes. Tastes of citrus, grains, and a light tart finish.
cloudy golden with small head, the aroma is of citrus and the flavor is crisp and slightly sweet with a mildly bitter finish.
A crisp, straw colored beer. While it was somewhat lacking in flavor its pleasant crispness more than made up for it. Pretty good.

Poured from a bottle, lasting head, little lacing. More aroma than flavor (and not much of either). Nothing objectionable about this one, kind of pleasant. Very smooth, but disappointing lack of full flavor.
Crisp clean and a tad spicy. A very nice summer time beer. Extremely smooth and easy to drink.
had this a couple of tymes. and both tymes it was a fresh batch. sweet with a tad spicy flavor. smells like a summer afternoon.

Medium straw color, very large head. A medium bodied Kolsch style ale. Subtle malts, mild and somewhat sweet. Mild hops with a slight spiciness. Good flavor. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. Nice refreshing ‘summer’ beer.

column1: Gem of the Sea Solomons Ale
column5: Big thanks to Hairofthedog for sending this one my way, doesn’t look like many more people will ever have the chance! Medium orange amber, slight head, faint bread aroma. Some hop bitterness mixed with an odd roasted note and some slight sour flavors. Odd. Not bad, just strange. In the end, the sourness just doesn’t hang.

column1: Gem of the Sea Solomons Ale
column5: (12 oz bottle: Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, CA) This is one bizarre smelling AND tasting beer. It’s both pleasant and unpleasant at the same time, testament to the fact that I like some aspects of this beer and hate others. It tastes very vegetal to me, but also very sweet and malty like "raw", yet-to-be-boiled wort for a dark beer. Mild bitterness adds very little to this beer. I think it’s the finish that is very vegetal, and unfortunately that finish really hangs on the palate. The nose is also very malty and "raw". Medium bodied with a slightly sticky mouthfeel. Medium amber in color, fully clear in appearance, with a small off-white head that recedes to a rim around the edge of the glass. Some patchy lacing. In summation, this is yet another oddball beer from Gem Of The Sea, a beer that certainly falls outside the boundaries of the style, just like their other beers. Maybe it’s like their pilsner and is better on tap? Who knows, and now they’re out of business? No real loss there in my opinion.(12 oz bottle: Hi-Time Wine Cellars in Costa Mesa, CA) Okay, so I saw another bottle in the beer cooler at Hi-Time Wine Cellars and figured I should give this another try. This is a totally different beer this time around, and obviously a fresher bottle. The nose is pleasant, mostly sweet caramel, and minimally hoppy. I get a moderate amount of sugary sweet caramel in the flavor too, well, more sugary than caramel. Fairly mild on the hops, even in the finish. But it’s not vegetal and it’s definitely not like raw wort like the first bottle. This is just a simple, pleasant, easy drinking amber.

column1: Gem of the Sea Solomons Ale
column5: Marketed as "Jarhead Red", but there wasn’t any red in the pour. Poured clear and gold with a chunky white head. Sweet aroma. Not much going on. Light hop spice, balanced with light malt. Nothing stands out. Short aftertaste was mellow and sweet.

column1: Gem of the Sea Solomons Ale
column5: Cloudy peach color with a small quickly subsiding off white head. Aroma is flowery, yeasty, spicy. Flavor starts with a hint of sweetness abruptly put aside by a sharp grassy, spicy bitterness. Light on the palate with a long dry bitter aftertaste. Not consistant with most other ratings; bad batch??? Guess I'll never know, I won't buy it again.

column1: Gem of the Sea Solomons Ale
column5: Orange amber with smallish head, malty sweet aroma, hint of spice. Begins with a sweet caramel maltiness, slightly thin body and finishes with hops that have a spiced taint. I found this to be somewhat interesting with the spiced hops being it’s distinctive characteristic, though not overdone. No too bad, but I had this one after a Red Nectar which was much better.

column1: Gem of the Sea Solomons Ale
column5: Weird peanut shell color to it with maybe a touch of sunset and a salt water wash on the top. Has a very sweet, malty molasses maybe aroma backed up with some hopiness. Starts off watery then shows some malt body and then goes back to watery hops. Nothing special.

column1: Gem of the Sea Solomons Ale
column5: Clear amber color, decent head formation. Light malty caramel aroma. Bitterness from start to finish, caramel flavor is light, slightly grainy, finishes with a nice bitter bite.

column1: Gem of the Sea Solomons Ale
column5: This ale pours with an amber orange body topped by a thin white head with a decent amount of lacing. The aroma is sweet and rich with malt with a very slight hoppy bitterness. Smells a lot like a dopplebock. The flavor is very similar however the hops step forward and show themselves more. Not a real prominent flavor but not bad. Medium bodied and relatively smooth.

column1: Gem of the Sea Solomons Ale
column5: Red amber color with a thin head. Oddly sweet aroma, honey, oatmeal and brown sugar. Flavor was also oddly sweet, rich malts, a little hoppiness and a citrus finish - somewhat unbalanced. Smooth, medium body, lightly carbonated and easy drinking.

column1: Gem of the Sea Solomons Ale
column5: (bottle) A light amber color. A nice pleasent aroma. The first taste of it didn't appeal to me at all, but after that it became a nice red ale.
Tap @ Brewekrz, Riverside Point. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are sweet malt, grass, fruits and hops. Nice bitter finish.
Draft - Bready malts. Clear gold with a decent white head. Bready notes and a little carb kick in the finish

Tasted 10/1/2017. Draught at Brewerkz, Clarke Quay, Singapore; $S13. Poured a clouded murky honey-brown amber with 5mm of white open foam that diminished quickly to a collar that laced very poorly. Carbonation low, slow with medium sized bubbles. Aroma of sweet light malt with hints of citrus. Taste of citrus with low strength grapefruit bitterness. Light body. Crisp with a lingering low level nice bitterness. Very expensive for an average beer.
Heller, spritzig herber Antrunk. Geringe Bitterkeit, süffig, knackig herb zum Ende. Lang anhaltender Nachgeschmack. 9/8/8/9//8
On tap at the Brewpub at Clark Quay. Golden with white head. Soft and easy to drink with citrus, bread and some light malt.
Tap at Brewerkz Clarke Quay. Pours clear golden with minimal white head which soon disappears. Aroma is herbal. Taste is grassy bitter, herbal taste, slight corn sweet.
Goldgelb schaum ok Geruch getreidig heller honig, Geschmack getreidig leichte frucht kaum herb, diese Brauerei hat weit aus besseres zu bieten
Vom Fass. Goldene, leicht trübe Farbe, weisser feinporiger Schaum. Wenig Aroma. Getreide. Antrunk getreidig. Sanfte Säure. Süffig.
*On tap at Brewerkz Clarke Quay. Golden fresh brew. Easy to drink with round and fresh grainy hints. Not much bitterness. Nice.
Draught at Brewerkz Singapore. Amber color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, malts, grass and a bit of hops. Bitter finish with citrus, grass and malts. Decent golden ale.
Beer tasting brewekz singapore Aroma is hoppy and grassy. Prefer golden ale to this
Tap @ Brewekrz, Riverside Point. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are grass, straw, hops and malt. Nice bitter finish.

Butelka prosto z Singapuru, dzięki Andrzej i Wojtek. Kolor złoty, zamglony, piana słaba ale zostawia ślady na szkle. Zapach lekko cytrusowy, trochę stęchlizny. Smak lekko kwaskowy, trochę wodnisty, nic specjalnego tylko jako ciekawostka.
Draft - Lots of grainy notes. Pale clear gold with a rich white head. Grains, light citrus and a dry finish. A touch of bitterness and this would be really nice.
Mild bitterer, deutlich getreidiger Antrunk. Spritzig, angenehme Würzigkeit. Die Trockenheit in Verbindung mit dem moderat grasigen Hopfen passt gut. Vollmundig, spritzig, gut. 9/11/11/11//11
On tap at the Brewpub at Clarke Quay. Hazy golden/yellow with a small head. Quite hoppy with bread, citrus and grass. Not that exciting.
Helles trübes gelb schwacher schaum, Geruch hopfen leicht citrus, Geschmack leichte frucjt citrus leicht wässrig wenig herb leicht honig, hab schon um einiges schlechtere Pilsener getrunken
Vom Fass. Strohgelbes naturtrübes Bier mit weissem Schaum. Zitrone in der Nase und imAntrunk. Schön frisch.
*On tap at Brewerkz Clarke Quay. Bitter grainy brew with a crisp body. Easy to drink, grainy fresh, not too bad.
