Draught at Brewerkz Singapore. Golden color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, a bit of toast, soapy aroma and grass. Bitter finish with citrus, a bit of toast and grass. Pretty horrible stuff.

Keg at Brewerkz Riverside Point, Singapore. Cloudy pale golden, small head. Huge phenolic bandaid and banana aroma. Light bodied with spritzy carbonation and clean, rounded mouthfeel. Bandaid and grain. Low bitterness. Very heavy on phenols, but quite refreshing.
Tap @ Brewekrz, Riverside Point. Nice head with good duration. Color is hazy golden. Aroma and taste are yeast, fruits, wheat malt and hops. Light bitter and sweet finish.
Draft - Soft wheat and banana notes.clear gold with a decent white heat. Soft wheat and some Cooke carmalized banana. Bit too much banana and nothing else for me.
Tap at Brewerkz Clarke Quay. Pours clear golden with a large white head. Aroma is coriander and lemon zest. Taste is coriander and lemon zest and peach sweet.
Trübes helles gelb schwacher schaum hefe und Banane im geruch, im Geschmack säure Banane hefe leicht wässriger Abgang
Vom Fass. Hellgelb trübes Weizen mit feinem Schaum. Typischer Duft. Weiten, Hefe und Banane. Sehr viel Banane auch im Geschmack. Leider etwas langweilig.
On tap at Brewerkz Clarke Quay. Fresh yeasty beginning with a nice smooth body. Not too much clove or banana, but round and smooth. Nice though.

Tap at Brewerkz,Orchard Parade. Poured a hazy straw colour with a thin white head and plenty of clingy lace. The aroma is grainy wheat, banana. The flavour is light acid citrus with a smooth, fruity yeast, light hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. As far as wheat beers go this is actually rather good.

(On Tap) Very cloudy golden amber with slight white head. Modest aroma - citrus, bananas and a hint of spice. Light body with very nice carbonation - soft with some bright sparkle. Pleasant refreshing taste - lemon, bananas, some light malty sweetness and hints of peppery spice. Nice easy drinking wheat beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pint on tap. Solid wheat nose. Cloudy amber with thin head. Excellent mineral water texture. Finish is hoppy, spicy, floral. Great example of the style.

A bit too much carbonation. Very hoppy and quite bitter. The malt integrity is there thankfully. A medium bodied beer. Doesn’t make or leave much of an impresssion. A tad dry for warm days or, when you are hot and bothered.

Finally found this rating from a year ago. After so many ho hum lagers this is a good respite. The fact that well hopped beers are popular in hotter climates seems to be lost to most, but this is a welcome departure from the mould. A good orange/amber colour with fine head, the fuggles become evident quite quickly. Good body and mouthfeel and a fine finish in this beer makes it a solid and honest beer
Tap. This should be "S'pore Pale Ale" to shorten Singapore. A gold color with a frothy white head. Hoppy dry and bitter.
Tap @ Brewekrz, Riverside Point. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are bitter hops, fruits, flowers and malt. Nice bitter finish.
Draft - Citrus and some apricot. Clearish gold with a decent white head. Light fruity citrus and a touch of mango. Light bitterness in the finish.

Deutlich hopfiger Antrunk, dieser ist aber eher dumpf und wenig grasig. Spritzig, der Hopfen steigt an und wird frischer, getreidig, rund. Langer hopfiger Nachhall, trocken werdend, was das Aroma konserviert. Nicht schlecht, wenn auch steigerungsfähig im Antrunk. 8/7/8/11//10
On tap at the Brewpub at Clarke Quay. Hazy orange with a small head. Quite hoppy with grapefruit, hay, some caramel and mango. The body was medium as was the bitterness. A decent one.

Draft at Brewerkz Riverside Point, Singapore. Very hazy dull orange with a white head. Aroma of orange peel, citrus, very fresh green hops and light malt. Flavour is above light sweet and above moderate bitter. Light medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Tap at Brewerkz Clarke Quay. Pours unclear orange with a minimal white head which soon recedes. Aroma is marmalade and orange bon bons. Taste is marmalade sweet, hint of bitterness, slight vanilla.
Klares dunkles gelb, schwacher schaum, Geruch fruchtig trocken so auch im Geschmack mit angenehm herbem Abgang schön rund
Vom Fass. Orange-goldenesBier mit flachem Schaum. Klassische Grapefruit Noten. Schöner Kräuter Antrunk. Dann sanft bitter.
On tap at Brewerkz Clarke Quay. Great intense bitterness with not too much floralness. Easy to drink but too much bitterness without too much other aroma. Interesting.
Draught at Brewerkz Singapore. Amber color, white head. Bitter taste with grapefruit, hops, resin, peach and grass. Bitter finish with grapefruit, hops, resin, peach and grass. Very nice IPA.
Draught at the brewpub, Spring 2006 (found in my notes). Hazy amber pour with a thin creamy white head. Nice and drinkable.

Draught @ the brewpub. Dark copper color, smells nice, a little grainy. Well balanced flavor, fruits and roasted malt play well, albeit a little short and slightly watery finish. Quite good, and probably the best on the menu.

Suffice to say, when I compare an Erdinger Dunkel or a Paulaner Dunkel to this brew, its pales utterly in comparison. In all fairness though, it’s an alright interpretation of a dark wheat beer. Well, it’s been a fair amount of time since I last drank it and, I am rating from memory. Maybe it has improved.

Draught at the brewpub, January 2007 Muddy dark-amber color; thin creamy head. The aroma, with some cereals, and the taste, with some cereals as well, let me think the ingredients were quite good, but they have not been worked well. Drinkable but simple, mild. The final is too short. Not enough body/malt, but bitter enough.

This will be interesting as I have an Erdinger Dunkel to compare this with. Good colour and head when poured, the latter actually lasting for a good while. There is a typical estery presence of apple which seems to be caramelised by the presence of the malt and chocolate. Good dry finish and a refreshing beer for the climate
Copper coloured (the only Brewerkz beer that I found that doesn't suffer from colour problems). Fruity/toasted cocoa aroma. Dry chocolate flavour. Decent.

Tap. Of the eight beers I had this was one of the best. Brown color with a little hazy laced head. Wheat lightness with a malty character and full body. Some spice in the aroma. This is a seasonal beer available in June, but I had it in September.

28/7/2018. Bottle at Højbjerg tasting. Pours very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of liquorice, chocolate, roasted coffee, malt, oats, dark fruit and toffee. Medium sweetness and medium roasted bitterness. Medium body, slight slickness to texture, but quite fizzy to go with it. Pretty decent apart from that.smoke,

Bottle @ Højbjerg tasting 28 July. Pours hazy dark brown / ruby with airy gray tan head. Clear aroma of malt and oats, with notes of yeast and hints of fruit. Bitter, roasty flavour, with notes of hops and touches of yeast and hints of spice. Roasty and mildly acidic aftertaste.

Bottle @ Saxo tasting. Gusher. Clear very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. Very high carbonation. 280718
Bottle. Frothy off-white good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate.
Bottle @Højbjerg Tasting. Gusher. Black with airy, fluffy light beige head. Aroma has roast and light licorice. Fizzy, fluffy mouthfeel. Flavour has light roast, caramel and some licorice and coffee.
Beertasting at brewerkz Cabination is nice and lasting, oily on glass Aromachocolate, appearance brown, black, taste medium sweet and butter with lightnumami
On tap at Brewerkz Riverside Point. Pours black. Coffee, toast, chocolate, tobacco. Quite dry. Nice.
Tap @ Brewekrz, Riverside Point. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, chocolate, coffee, hops and has a nice bitter finish.
Draft - Dark roast, chocolate and oatmeal. Jet black brown with a nice light brown head. Dark roast, oatmeal and some light chocolate. Silky smooth oatmeal mouthfeel.
Cremig malziger Beginn mit Noten von Kaffee und Schokolade. Dabei wenig süß mit trocken bitterem Stich, Noten von Getreide. Vielschichtig, vollmundig. 10/12/11/12//12

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: 12oz bottle. Pours a clear orange with a thinnish head of white cream and lacing. Nice sweet honey malt and bitter hops are actually smooth. Delicious and smooth blend of flavors. Really nice and drinkable IPA.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Can. Cloudy orange with large foamy off-white head, faint malt aroma, medium carbonation, medium bitter malty taste with a hint of orange peel, smooth body, long finish. Decent IPA.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Poured into a becher pint glass, the appearance was a dark copper color with a finger’s worth of white foamy head that dissipated within several seconds. The aroma had a fairly big malt character to it with some earthiness, grass and butterscotch. The flavor blended lightly between the malts and the earthy and grassy hops. Cues a nicely blended aftertaste rolling into the finish. On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. ABV felt fine. Overall, decent as an English styled IPA as the brewer suggests or brewers as I see this is brewed at Shipyard. Do-able.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: English style, and they invented the IPA, I enjoyed this, thanks for sharing Ron! Malt heavy, caramel, toffee. I don’t recall the notes added by the hops, but they were muted.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: The low reviews seem to be from this being rated as an American IPA when it is definitely an English IPA. Pours Dark copper with a thin white head. Aroma is dominated by malt: caramel and some butterscotch. The flavor is also very malt driven. Caramel, butterscotch, and it finishes off with an earthy, bitter bite. A decent English IPA. Quite drinkable, but definitely a shock if you want an aggressive hop-forward American IPA.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Bottle. Pours a golden amber with a thin white head. Light pine and citrus notes. Thin to medium bodied with flavors of honey, citrus and pine. Ends a little bit sweet, but with a nice grapefruit bitterness.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: On tap at Timberwolf Pub (Schroon Lake, NY). Limpid, amber body with an average off-white frothy head. Fair malty/hoppy aroma with weirs leather hints. Taste is slightly dominated by hoppy flavors. It also carries malty, woody, and grainy notes. Ends with a decent bitter/woody finish. Drinkable.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: I’m an IPA guy love the aroma and that taste is something completely different then most other ipas so I teed to enjoy this ale very much way to change the game Davidson brothers.

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: Tap at Johnny Rockets in Queensbury on my Topper trip to Vermont. Man this is not really good at all tasted like dish soap. Very malty and off balance. Would never try this again if I had a gun to my head. Bluhhhh

column2: Glens Falls, New York, United States
column5: At the brewpub for quick lunch stop. pours orange with nose of piney yet slightly stale hops. Tastes of pine, grapefruit, honey, florals, light caramel, and earth. standard brewpub ipa but well done enough to get by

column1: French Broad Flanders Field Brown Ale
column5: My first dissapointment is that despite the name this wasn't a Flanders brown ale. Instead it was more of the typical brown ale most micros have. It was thin for style and bigger than typical hops. I like my browns to have low hop and heavy malt, but this was reversed. I could have forgiven it if it had just had more malt, but it didn't.

On tap at the brewery, Asheville NC, 7 July 2006 at 5.0%. Fairly pale colour with a modest haze. Mainly citric with less of the banana ester and spice feel than usual. Quite fizzy with a sort of soda water / Alka-Seltzer feel. In common with the Pilsner and the Marzen, this was a clean and easy drinking effort, if a bit lacking in character.

Date: 08/13/2005 Mode: Draft Source: Brewery pale yellow, thin fine white head, nice spicy aroma with bits of citrus and coriander, big body for a wit, light slightly sweet malt flavor, nice balancing spices, a bit of out-of-place tartness in the background, Aroma: 9/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 10/20 Rating: 3/5.0 Score: **/4 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
i was not a big fan of this beer. a growler from the brewery. has a sweet some what perfume aroma. tasted very floral to me. don’t think i will have it again.
poured into tulip. pours a cloudy golden yellow, flat sour aroma, flat and sour on taste like dead yeast....

Draught at the brewpub. Pours hazy yellow with almost non-existant white head. The aroma is banana, zest, and, erm, meadow. The flavor is more zesty than anything. The malts manifest themselves as crackers, and the finish is kinda dry. Definitely nothing special.

Draught. Pours light gold, just ever so slightly cloudy with no real head. The aroma is pretty sweet with hints of pear, banana, and perfume. It’s quite weak in the mouth, but has faint suggestions of banana, cereal, cork, and apple peels. Even given the warm weather, this wasn’t even that refreshing. One should expect just a bit more flavor and complexity from this style.

Pale yellow, no head. Aroma of orange (they put a twist of range peel in the glass before pouring, which may explain that) and a slight herbal note. Flavor is orange again, with coriander and um, cedar, maybe?Has a funky lambic character, as well. Sampled at 2005 Knoxville Brewer’s Jam.
A pale yellow color with a light spicy nose. Good mellow flavor that goes down smooth. Otherwise, not much interesting about this.
This Witbier is right down the middle. Nothing wrong here - nothing complelling. It is sweeter, fruitier than its dry and spicy cousins, but only slightly.

The appearance was only average, being the good cloudy yellow but lacking the glow of some. It was a bit low on the coriander and couldn't compete with the spicier wits like Wittekerke or even Allagash's. More orange than coriander. Otherwise a nice mild take on the style.

On tap at the brewpub. Hey, this is a nice place for Johnson City! Outdoor beer garden in East Tennessee? Maybe there’s hope for civilization yet! This is not a bad porter. Dark black in appearance, with great head retention. Subtle roasted malt flavor, but mostly chocholate and black patent I suspect. Good hop balance and a less-than-stout body. Great when it warms up. Don’t start with this one at the Otter, finish with it.

This was a surprisingly bold beer for a brewpub. Brewpubs on the average seem to be a bit timid on the flavor front. Nice black appearance with good brown, big-bubbled head. Big coffee flavor, some chocolate. Very stoutish porter.

On tap at the brewpub. This would be the ale they make for the UN-sophisticated otters. Mine arrived flat. Kind of a dark-gold to amber color. Body was a little thin for me and the hops were very absent for the style. I think the brewer can do better.
Fairly citric beer with surprisingly low bitterness. A bit thin, but not too much so for style. This beer can't quite compare to the boldness of their porter, but it's not a bad beer, either.
Bottle. Pours a hazy orange gold with some carb and no head. The aroma is strong funk, rubber, floral, oak. Medium body, strong funk, nice tartness, glad to finally try this.

750 ml bottle shared at the original Chez Moeder Lambic’s cellar (A Day To Sink All Sea Shepherds tasting). Hazy orange color with off white head. Malty and yeasty aroma, toasted bread, funky barnyard notes, grass, citrusy fruity, stone fruits, wood. Light sweet and moderate acidic taste. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

Bottle shared at A Day To Sink All Sea Shepards tasting. Very hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma of deep dank cellar funk, basement, cobwebs, light mushroom, citric notes, mineral and slight mint notes. Flavour is light moderate sour. Light medium bodied with soft carbonation. So soft, refined and easy drinking. A great experience to be able to try this beer.

@ A day to sink all seasheppards, Thnx for sharing !!! Pours unclear blonde, very small ring of white foam. Smell is super intense on funk and oak. taste is intense, funk, oak, brett. Typical cantillon, in all the foog ways. Funky grainyness, but in a super-complex balance. Good MF . Has gotten soft carbo at this time. Very nice !

Pours a nice golden straw color and most bottles I’ve had have been nicely carbonated. It’s an interesting beer and is quite different from a regular gueuze. Worth tracking this one down but there is definitely some bottle variation at this point.

Bottle @ Pat’s. Thanks, Jer! Hazed golden-orange pour with a white head. Really citric and lemony. Funky mushroom and library books. Some damp straw, orange peel, and golden apple. Nice sourness to the flavor. A slight sweetness of orange marmalade and apple. Sour lemon and green grapes. A sort of musty funkiness and slight earthy quality. Sort of zesty.
Bottle thanks to Lulu, Shelton label. A very elegant beer. Nose is complex although a little oxidized. Beer the same.

This beer is so moderately acidic, and i dont find that in old lambic if it is not Cantillon. Perhaps above all on should speak of the elegance in the sourness that only comes with old Cantillon! An oxidation that makes one think of dusty cellar! The taste of green apple peel but a flavor the meat from red apples, complex is the least one can say!

Danke Lulu. Musky aroma with nice sourness. Slight oxidation which gives depth and keeps aromas of citrus and hay. Really an aroma you want to come back to and sit and smell for a while. Lovely complex flavor, simple but wow what a mouthfeel, in the beginning. Apples, citrus and lots of murky barnyard cellars. Long finish with a sour almost bitter finish. Although there is something in the after taste I dont really dig.

Considering Cantillon’s quality, it would be a shame to throw away geuze bottles that show a fermentation going to slowly, so those bottles were cleverly marketed as ’Loerik’, meaning something like ’lazybones’. A geuze Cantillon "in development", so to speak. Due to the slower than expected refermentation, this one stays softer and ’flatter’ than the fully developed geuze Cantillon, but otherwise the main character is the same. Great, in other words. Which probably partially explains why this has become something of a ’white whale’ now that it is no longer produced, I suppose.

Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a beige head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of metal and light notes of caramel and sulphur. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of straw and caramel, leading to a dry metallic and straw finish. Thanks Pinball for sharing.

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of Pinball. Slightly hazy golden with a nice, white head. weird, chemical aroma. Medium body, oxidized maltiness and overripe fruit and a littel sulphur. No bitterness. Clearly not fresh. 190209

Botella. Bit hazy deep golden. Nice white medium head. Bit sweet malty bit spiced/herby aroma. Good mouthfeel. The flavour has a sweet maltiness with herbs/spice, bitter hops and a dry bitter finish. Good pils.
swingtop bottle clear yellow, thick white head. faint spritty aroma, also sweet stuff , but not nice slightly roasted, spicy flavor, malts, toffee. not my kind of beer.

Woody stuff, cloudy appearance, lingering malty aroma and taste, excellent smooth texture with long lasting spongy froth on the top. Good amount og hops so as not overpower the malt. Very easy to drink and enjoy.

Darker gold than a standerd pils, with a small head. Rich malty aroma, which is peppery and herbal. Crisp and herbal flavour with a gentle bitterness that gains strength towards its dry finish. This is a very nice, flavourful, and also very distinctive pilsener.

50 cL bottle (5.3%, Spain). Pours golden and clear yellow with a quickly gone white head. Spiced and slight herbal malt aroma. Sweet malty and delicately spiced/herbalness. Finish holds slight bitterness breaking the otherwise also slight herbal malt flavours in the finish. Complex and delicate brew.

swing top bottle (500ml). -Clear golden coloured, small white head, cardboard nose. Sweet malty, mild hoppy and caramel taste with notes of cardboard and alcohol. One dimensional brew with rather bitter herbal finish. 5.3%ABV

swing-top-bottle bought in Cham. Golden yellow colour, large head, impressiveley nice aroma of herbs, hop and malt. Very intensive flavour, malty, hoppy with pleasant hints of fruit and herbs, apple mainly. Pleasantl carbonation.
Bottled (5.3%). Clear golden, brief head. Papery malt and peach. Sweet and oxidized with evident cardboard flavour Medium bodied. Low bitterness.
Dunkelbraun, leicht trüb. Geruch fruchtig nach Erdbeere. Im Geschmack leicht restsüß, dazu wässrig. Im Abgang seicht, nur wenig Hopfen.
~This review was made some time ago via another application, and thus the specific details (beyond numerical scores) are no longer available~

Dark brown with a red hue and a nice head. The aroma is malty with notes of caramel and a bit of alcohol. The flavour has notes of roasted malt, light sweetness, a bit of alcohol and it’s actually quite OK... 1753
Can. Clear amber/orange colour with medium creamy off-white mostly diminishing head. Malty aroma with hints of grain. Sweet malty flavor.
bottle. Dark amber colour with an average head. Sweet caramel and malty aroma, bit grainy. Flavour is malty, slightly roasted, with caramel, notes of alcohol and bit nutty.
Beautiful dark amber/red color with fine head. Watery even if this is a very strong beer. Some burnt malt and some sweetness but definitely a cheep beer.

33 cl can. No yeast at the bottom. Dark reddish brown colour with a nice head. Sweet aroma of malt, caramel and little alcoholic. Nice flavour of sweet caramel, maltness and ends up someway light and have a warm finish from the noteable alcohol.
This is actually a good harboe-beer. Brownish colour with a light brown mostly lasting head. Taste of caramel and malts.
Can. This is one of the best Harboe!!!!!! Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Brown colour. Week but ok aroma. Very nice flavor with hoints of caramel and smoke. Oily palate.
Clear deep reddish colour with a creamy tan head. Sweet malty and grainy aroma with hints of caramel and nuts. Sweet malty flavor with a faintly roasted bitterness. Dry finish.
Bijna zwart van kleur, kraag verdwijnt snel tot een randje. Ruikt melkachtig, licht koffie, smaakt idem. Vrij zoet, bittere nasmaak. Vrij vlak van smaak.

Black beer with a decent head. All the typical teastes like coffee, chocolate caramel and some raisins.Unfortunaltely the tastes do last but not very long. I've had (much) better examples of this style but all of them were (much) higher in alcohol and (much) higher in price. I'll have this again.
Gusto caramello e liquiriziq, poco dolce con coda acidula. Schiuma persistente, colore nero.
Dark brown with an off white head that doesn’t las long enough. Aroma of roasted grain. Taste has elements of coffee and liquorice with a hint of salt. Bitter finish.

Very dark brown body with a nice, everlasting, frothy and creamy-like beige head. Aroma is licorice, dark bread, soy sauce. Taste starts somehow sweet, with fruity notes (plums), roasted malts, milk chocolate and some licorice. Medium malty (roasted) notes. Medium to full body, soft to lively carbonation, oily texture.

From the bottle. Brown with a thin, frothy head that fades completely. Aroma is roasted grains, toast, licorice. Taste is mildly sweet up front with plum jam and caramel overtones. Goes down with an increasing tartness but ends up mildly bitter and a touch salty. Medium body with a light and fading carbonation. Okay.

Bottle. Clear dark brown color, fine, thick, beige lasting head. Nice aroma, bread, toffee, roasted barley. Dry taste, medium bitter, maybe a hint acrid. Chocolate, toffee, coffee aftertaste, is there a whisper of salt, I'm not sure. Medium carbonation, full body. Nice stout, just as I like it.

Copenhagen 13/12 2018. 33 cl bottle from Den Gamle Købmand, Kbh K. Cartoon trying to make a point about Oyster Stouts and Mermaids. I am not sure if the succeed. Pours clear dark brown with a red hue. Head is medium-sized and off-white. Settles as 1 cm thick layer of foam managing to cover the surface of the beer. Very moderate lacing. Aroma is rich, sweet and nutty. Sweet caramel, fermented plums and figs. Sugary sweetness. Nuts and alcohol rummaging in the background. Medium carbonation. Slightly thick, oily texture. Lightly tingling. Flavor is heavy sweet and on the verge of being cloying. Very moderate bitterness. Aftertaste is sweet with a light alcoholic burn. Too sweet for my taste buds but it carries a solid kick.
Bottled, shared by my neighbor. Dark brown colored. Sweet and pretty straightforward, some roasted malts, hint of chocolate.
Onder een beige kleurige schuimkraag schuilt een krachtig bier, vol van smaak en rijk van geur.

Cask-Conditioned. Light brown colour, sour flavour. In previous years Benskins was a large local brewery, Benskins Bitter developed a reputation locally of being unpleasantly sour. Now the beer is brewed hundreds of miles away, but it still retains the sour flavour.
Cask-Conditioned. Much like many of the other Rebellion brews, slightly bitter and rather sweet. Rebellion could probably use making more beers which are distinctly different from each other.

Cask (handpump). Old notes from circa 2002. Not sure where I had this. Mid copper colour. Signature Rebellion fruity malt profile with a touch of sweetness. There’s a little late earthy hoppiness but the malt dominates.
Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 23/09/2002 Amber coloured and slightly sweet on the palate. Some sour fruit flavour. Lasting malt finish.
Cask-Conditioned. Didn't seem as sweet as Lion Pride tasted the same evening. Standard Rebellion, certainly good but undistinctive.

column1: Headford Ridge Bin 5 Medium Dry Cider
column5: Bottle. Clear amber colour, light visible carbonation. Aroma of dry apples and a touch of barnyard. Flavours are apples, sweet/tart well balanced, quite sweet at first, dryish at the end. Low carbonation. Very nice.

column1: Headford Ridge Bin 5 Medium Dry Cider
column5: One of the best bottled ciders I have tasted since discovering Weston’s Organic.

column1: Headford Ridge Bin 5 Medium Dry Cider
column5: [bottle] Pours a clear amber with lots of carbonation and no head. Musty and dry aroma of apples, other citrus and toffee with a certain comfortable home smell. Initial sweet and apple taste that dries out and fades into a slightly bitter, tart finish with a dry mouthfeel and a lingering taste of apples and sugar. The first true cider I’ve ever had and I definitely enjoyed it.

column1: Headford Ridge Bin 5 Medium Dry Cider
column5: Bottled. This has to be one of the worst things i have tasted. NEver again!

500ml bottle (Ales By Mail) (6:4:7:3:13=3.3) Sweet watery lemony malty aroma. Lovely resiny toffee malts and nuts in the taste. Watery palate, a bit dead, but a pleasant sweetening heft, some roast, chocolate hints. Finish of resiny strong English ale, some nuttiness and wood. Seems like a great 8% beer that's been watered down to 6%. Decent enough, though.
Old note. The aroma has light toasted malts, herbal tones. Brown coloured beer with a thin, off-white head. The taste is sweet, has toasted malts, cookie, yeast tones. Medium bodied.
Bottle from Alesbymail. Clear brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and dark fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. 060617

Bottle shared with the missus at Bukowski @ Boxpark - Shoreditch, London. Pours clear, red-brown with a small, off-white foam topping. Toasty toffee in the nose, some leafy hops. Medium sweet flavour with more toffee and toasted malts, dried leaves, faint dark fruits, leather. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Lightly sweet on the finish, with lots of leaves, moderate bitterness, moss, leathery fruits, mellow toffee sugars. Not bad overall.
Backlog, early amateur rating! Sample @ Malmö Öl & Whisky Festival 20130420. Fruity, malty and caramely.

Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Amber colour. Heavy malty aroma. Powerfull caramellic notes. Moderate bitter nice caramelli flavor. Some coffee notes. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.

Bottle. Looks very dark brown, ruby tinge, no head at all- ends up looking like a pint of coke. Aroma- malty, slight red wine, raisin, hop hints. Taste- full and malty, raisin hints, a little bit of roastiness, chocolatey finish. Really nice, unexpectedly so given the appearance.
Bottle. Amber colour. Frothy head quickly disappates. Note of lemon. English Bitter. Pleasant
Bottle 0.5l at home. BBE MAR14. Colour is brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, sweetness, caramel and malts.

Flaska på Nya Tröls. En riktigt malttung pjäs, Mahognyfärgad med drag åt rött, i princip inget skum och bara en månad till bäst föredatumet och serverad alldeles för kall. Mycket söta maltsmaker. Russin, honung, mörkt bröd, treacle. Fina smaknyanser men också lite platt, aningen syrlig. Trevligt öl som nog drack under fel omständigheter. En höstkväll hade den nog fått högrre betyg.

column1: Tyranena Ya Hey Der Honey Wheat
column5: On tap at the brewery. Honey aroma with some citrus. Golden color with a thin, white head. Sweet, honey, floral, slight grass in the finish. Water and thin. Had some flavor, just not my favorite style at all.

column1: Tyranena Ya Hey Der Honey Wheat
column5: Clear yellow with thin white head. No aroma of malt or honey. Taste is pure malt, no wheat character or honey flavor. Overall a nice refreshing beer for a summer’s day but not for fans of wheat beer.

column1: Tyranena Ya Hey Der Honey Wheat
column5: On tap at the brewery. Clear orange-golden body with a minimal white bubbly head. Cream of wheat-grainy aroma with a touch fo watermelon and banana. The flavor has wet papery cardboard notes, orange, and a dry papery finish. Wasn’t a big fan of this stuff.

column1: Tyranena Ya Hey Der Honey Wheat
column5: Straw color with a smaller white head. Dry wheat flakes aroma. Bland malt and wood flavors. Another american wheat ale. Egad!

column1: Tyranena Ya Hey Der Honey Wheat
column5: Nose is very citric/bananas. Flavor is sweet and a bit "wheaty". Filtered. A middle of the road american wheat.
Probably the best pumpkin ale ever created. Has a great taste and it's not too overpowering. Good light aftermath and easy smooth feel to it.
Golden orange color, small off white head. Caramel malt, spice aroma. Light body. Mildly sweet, yeast, spices, pretty straightforward pumpkin beer.

Huge thanks to Erzengel for sharing. Bottle looks good. Beer in the glass zippy, small head. Malty-fruity aroma. Starts mild, a lot of herbal notes, some spekulatius, some peaches. Finish a bit washy. Okay.
Shared with Erzengel! A clear deep golden beer with a small white lacing. Aroma of pumpkin spices, cinnamon, soft hoppy reddish malt. Taste of mild sweet pumpkin spices, cinnamon, reddish malt.

Many thanks to Peter for this bottle. Great fantastic smooth pumpkin-spice beginning. The beer is soft in the back, the spices and the pumpkin are fantastically on top. Nice smooth with a moderate bitterness, refreshing and soft in aftertaste. Very nice.
Pours clear orange with a white head. Aroma is pumpkin spice. Taste is candy sugar, cinnamon and pumpkin, moving to nutmeg. Finish is spice and light pumpkin.

10/31/18 Had just before midnight on Halloween with A after a date night. Poured from bottle. Very clear with only a slight head. Label is awesome! Nose is a bit subdued but caramel malt and nice pumpkin spice come through. Taste is crisp with nutmeg and pumpkin spice dominating an almost lager-like malt profile. Very spicy with some good sweetness and no discernible bitterness. Palate is crisp and light but decently full with better carbonation than I expected from the anemic head on the pour. Leaves behind some nice nutmeg/pumpkin spice flavors. Overall, a crisp and enjoyable beer that's tasty but definitely unremarkable for arguably my favorite style of beer.
This is probably the best beer I've had with pumpkin in it. A perfect beverage for the fall. Always reminds me of growing up in Maine too!

Pours a clear amber with little head. Aroma reminiscent of pumpkin pie. Taste is initially like a wheat beer, gradually fades to the palate. Palate is very similar to pumpkin pie, gradually fades to some light hops influences on the back of the tongue. Drinkable.
Pumpkin pie spice aroma light amber color. Taste ofvpumpkin pie spice with a hop bitterness finish.

Usually producers of fine bottled ales, Harviestoun have let themselves down with this rather run of the mill bitter. The picture on the label is a moon behind a church spire which gives the impression of a slightly risque "moon". Sigh! Is it true that the quality of a beer is in inverse proportion to the rudeness of the label? The hops are Willamette, a rather soft, gentle breed, and Liberty, typically found in German lagers. The mildness of these hops may account for the lack of character in the beer.
Bottled, pasteurised, 275ml, courtesy of Derek. Amber, carbonated white head. Sweet and thin beer, pasteurised beyond reason into a drab cardboardy, malty affair. Really not too good.

Subtitled "a truly flatulent brew" this is surprisingly good. Ken Brooker, founder and owner of Harviestoun, seems to enjoy producing ales with a range of hops and this is no exception. The hops used in the brew are Hersbrucker and Challenger, then Styrian Goldings are added for aroma. The result is a very clean, refreshing and citric beer with a subtle play of the citric fruits. An ideal summer session beer.

column1: Kelham Island Fat Cat Pale Ale
column5: I was given this by one of my clients - it has no brewery name on the label, but he also gave me Pale Rider and told me it was the same brewery. This is a 20th birthday ale, and appears to be one of a series of anniversary ales that the Kelham Island Brewery in Sheffield produces. As the brewery started in the back room of The Fat Cat pub they have a number of beers with this title. The brewery itself was founded in 1990. Slightly hoppy nose, and the light hops continue into the taste. Thin body, but clean and refreshing. The hops becoming more pronounced into the aftertaste. A light and agreeable drink.
Very excellent IPA, amber in color, great soft lacy head, lots of floral tones in the aroma, lots of hop bitterness in the flavors, great balance, spicy aftertaste, all-around excellent IPA

Pours turbid deep golden with a strawberry blonde thing going on. Super aroma of raspberries, wheat, yeast, citrus, and hops. Has a delicious, full raspberry flavor, with citrus, yeast, hops, and wheat overtones. Finishes sweet, with raspberries, malt, yeast, and some citrus at the finish. I'm not a huge fruit beer guy, but this one is masterfully complex, super tasty, and extraordinarily refreshing. Bravo!
Lots of rasberries in the aroma, cloudy & hazy appearance, the rasberry flavors were way too overpowering, way too much rasberries in this brew all together
Draft at the brewpub. Solid copper, with malt, caramel, toffee. Smooth finish with a brown sugar element at culmination.
On tap at the Valley Forge Brew Pub. Poured a medium to dark orange/amber color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas and tastes of malts and caramel. Lightly sweet. Light hops.

Like many other VFBC beers, there's nothing wrong with this brew - it's just that there's nothing remarkable about it either. Classic Oktoberfest burnt orange color, mildly sweet malt flavor with a nice nut finish. Hop profile was present, but, subtle. IMHO, they need to crank up the "flavor" volume on this brew.
Deep copper in color, didn't keep all that great of a head, a bit bland & watery, I've certainly had better marzen-style brews
A nice malt whiskey aroma but the body is thin, sour and slightly redolent of vomit.
A fairly run of the mill pale beer with some nice orange fruit, but an imbalance of hops and malt leading to a feeling that this is too bitter. Quite freshing though, and the orange fruit is juicy.
Cask Handpump at the Penny Black, Northwich (JDW) 09/06/2002 Clear golden coloured and slightly pale. Some bitterness in a dry hop finish.

The 15/50 of the name refers to Hop Back's 15th and the Queen's 50th anniversaries. This is a very pale summer ale with a refreshing and very fruity flavour. There's plenty of light tang from the soft but aromatic hops. The fruits keep returning in different combinations of citric flavours, and there's enough sweetness to stop the fruits from becoming sharp. A very good bottle-conditioned beer. 'Hoppy Anniversary' indeed!
Van tap. Hopbittertje, vlak, koriander, witbiertonen, korte nadronk, fris. (6-2017).
Keg at the Beerbox. Malty nose, clean and lightly biscuity. Pale gold, fine white head, dry-sweet and clean, light leafy hoppiness.

Keg at the London Brewers Market. At 5% ABV. Pours mostly clear yellow, lightly effervescent, with a creamy, white head. Crispy cereal in the nose, some biscuit and lemon peel. Light sweet flavour with grainy malts, more lemon peel, straw, cereal. Light bodied with average carbonation. Finishes with touches of grassy bitterness, more citrus rind, cereal, biscuits. Not bad.
Not bad, nothing to write home about really. A standard lager really, a bit of hops, but lacks any real bite - I prefer Meantime’s Wheat Beer.
Bottle (from Sainsburys, BBE Aug 06). Grassy hops and sweetish malt aromas with an unusual but not unpleasant sellotape aroma. Fairly sweet but quite freshly refreshing. Not bad.

(draft) Clear apple juice body with white head. Aroma is medium sweet, mild, grassy. Taste is medium sweet, some grassy, cereal/grain, slight astringency in the finish. Watery light body with no crispness.
Draught at Greenwich Union as Meantime Lager. Golden coloured. Quite metallic aroma and flavour. Slightly malty. Thin.
Bottle 660ml.Straw in colour and nearly in taste,no head fair malt.Too bland and sharp for a starter,but ok when you have had a few.
From Sainsburys. Malt in the aroma. Sweet malty taste, faint hops. It’s sweet and unrefined but completely pleasant to taste and very refreshing. There is far worse.
Sainsbury’s bottle. Thin white head, soon gone. Yellow colour. Malty and slightly sweet aroma, malty and sweet taste. Thin bodied. Slightly bitter finish. Bog standard lager, I was expecting better.
Keg at the Old Brewery, Greenwich in 2015. Clear amber with a white head. Aroma of lager malt, berries, bread and light herbal notes. Caramel and biscuity malt flavours, with some citrus rind notes.
Cervesa suau, amb aroma afruitat i en gust toc a galeta amb un toc amarg. Cerveza suave, con un aroma frutado y en sabor toque a galleta con un toque amargo.

Keg at the Beer House, Paddington station, 05/03/15. Clear golden with a moderate off white covering. Nose is bready, pale malt, light citric rinds, straw. Taste comprises sweet elements, bready malt, caramel, light floral notes. Medium bodied, prickly carbonation, semi drying close. Ok lager, refreshing after a 3 mile run!

Âmbar, límpida, de espuma média e de curta duração. Aroma de ameixas com toque de café e um leve toque cítrico. Sabor de ameixas e um pouco de café, levemente adocicado. Retrogosto curto com final amargo. Média carbonatação, corpo médio.
Cerveja leve, muito fácil de beber. Aroma frutado e suave. Pouca carbonatação.
Bottle @ joes. Amber colour, small off-white head. Smells malty, caramel, some hops, sweetish. Tastes sweet, caramel, slightly iron. Thin to medium body, soft to medium carbo.
Bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch leicht röstmalzig, Karamell, fruchtig. Geschmack röstmalzig süß, fruchtig, Karamell.

Cor âmbar, cristalina, com espuma quase branca de média formação e baixa persistência; sem lacing. Aroma de malte (pão); Sabor de início de biscoito evoluindo para um final de leve amargor e picardia ainda mais leve; retrogosto de adstringência leve; Corpo leve e média carbonatação; Tb um lixo! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap @ Drink Baar as Union Lager. Pours copper with white head. The head stays. Aroma is caramel, malt, metallic, and cherries. Taste is malt, caramel, metallic, watery, mild bitterness and sweetness. Taste gets better as it warms up. Overall: this must be one of the most non-offending beers I have ever tasted, it is very easy to drink.

Tap. Clear redish amber color. Medium size, thick white head, stays. Looks fizzy, but I suspect dirty glass. Hops, malty, sweet and faint iron, jam and apples in aroma. Caramel, apples, hops, hay, strudel, sweetish taste. Short buttery bitterness in aftertaste. I like it.

First tasted this in the Fat Cat, Norwich in June 2002. Cask, handpump dispense. Ruby black in colour with a thin creamy white head. Strong fruit dumpling flavours present in the long intense aroma. Thin but lovely creamy texture to the mouthfeel and good lacing. Dark malts give a rich moist maltloaf base with molasses, plum jam, dates and sultanas. There is a slight earthy note in the brief aftertaste but sweetness returns rather quickly. The finish is malty and fruity with strong vinous cask notes and alcoholic sherry flavours evident in the throat. This is a cracking Old Ale does not taste like a stout though? Highly recommended.

1. Cask Stillage at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, Oldham 23/03/2002 Black and strong in alcohol with some fruit aroma. Hint of rum flavour. Smooth slightly hoppy finish. 2. Cask Handpump at the Ship & Mitre, Liverpool 13/06/2002 Dark red coloure with big roast aroma. Bitter lasting finish. 3. Cask Handpump at Wilkie’s Tavern, Warrington 21/04/2003 Dark red coloured with some alcohol present. Fruity aroma. Slightly bitter hop finish.

(pretty aged sample) Colour of extremely strong, nearly black tea; light brown, creamy head. Whiff of vinegar over grain, scorched grain and coffee. Again preserving vinegar in the taste, short lived but unmistakably, and returning with every sip. Coffee, but restrained; corn flakes and something faint cheesy - smoked cheese rookkaas . Well bodied, slick, slightly oily MF, thinner because of age & acidity. Thanks for this forgotten beer, MatW. As our mutual friend Ian Garrett would say, "Interesting" rather than really great.

Bottle conditioned. Deep red colour almost black, good cream coloured rocky head but slightly overcarbonated. Peppery aromas with hints of coffee powder, more coffee in the mouth with a fruity sour note developing but keeping itself in check without detracting from the flavour. Finish is dry and tinged with roast barley. More of a porter than a stout.Website suggests brewery is no more but beers being produced elsewhere.

Nursery Brewing is a new venture by Malcolm Shipp the owner of Shipping Beer who specialise in importing Irish Ales and various stouts, so it's no surprise that this bottle conditioned beer is a handome stout. The head brewer is Steve Cheeseright who won Supreme Champion with Knickadroppa Glory whilst brewing for the Sutton Brewing Co in Plymouth. This is a warm and smooth stout with bags of soft dark fruit and licorice malt flavours with sufficent fizz to make the whole thing taste quite light and refreshing. As a lover of well made dark beers I rate this quite highly. Strongly recommended.

yeah is some brew fellar! all we can get up here in top end apart from xxxx but that rubbish to dam expensive. you can dilute blacksmith with some paint thinner and you won’t tell the difference fellar. Great drink fellar i strongly recomend it if you want a life changing hangover you will never forget if you survive it.

This would have to be one of the top 3 beers I have ever had the pleasure of drinking. Along with Regal, and Tooheys Red, this beer offers a wide variety of sensations to the palette along with a crisp array of fresh tastes and flavours. Both going down, and coming up. I couldn’t think of a reason why I wouldn’t buy this beer. Why you poofs are whining is a mystery to me. TWO THUMBS UP!

Despite the ’bitter’ name it looks like a lager, smells like a lager and tastes... of not very much. Golden syrup in colour. English-style lager nose, light and hoppy. Malty notes in the mouth but it lacks body. Something floral but chemical and a bit nasty in the middle. Keep walking. (Can - doesn’t help with the flavour)
not to bad. a bit watery, but better than I expected. is everybody sure this is a pale lager?

Bought a carton of this when me and a mate were hitting the piss (At 25bux a carton of 440ml cans). Its not good at all but its just like any other mainstream aussie shit, so my mate can pertend his other aussie mainstream beers rip it up, but they just dont. You could tell this was made of poor quality hops and malt - poor, poor, poor. cheers

Independent Breweries eh? From what? Craftsmanship? A cheap swilling beer that has the positive going for it that it should never be skunked, simply because it is only in a can. Typical taste of thin Aussie macro swill.
Thought this one was a bit thin ,slight bitterness with no flavour to go with it and couldn't tell the colour as I had it straight from the can.
Virtually no aroma. Sweetish and only mildly bitter taste. It is very watery. The only thing separating this from other Aussie standard lagers is a slightly darker colour.

i couldn't be too critical of this, it's like an aussie version of german supermarket beer, dirt cheap and bigger cans than normal. and even tastes okay, some bitterness, the sweetness is never overwhelming, not too metallic
dark in appearance, watery with a sort of malty taste, good for the price (24 bucks for a carton of 440ml cans)
Nez:malte et parfume.Oeil une blonde tres trouble.Au gout malte et parfume.Pas si mal pour une petit lager.

Crisp, very hoppy, ok body, little in the malt department; seemed more like an IPA than a pils to me, and I didn't get much of the traditional lager/pils aroma, of course the pub IS super-smoky what the hell can you do in a smoky atmosphere about tasting beer I ask you?
I had the cask conditioned version which was extremely smooth and easy to drink. Great session beer and a well made ESB.

Cask at The Rock, Chiddingfold. Malty slghtly sou edged funky aroma. Thin frothy head. Light brown. Medium bitter with a hint of sour. Actually quite spicy. Thin. Light. Flat. A tad astringent finish. Decent bitter. Got a bit of character, as advertised.

Cask at Ragged Trousers, Tunbridge Wells. - Earthy, even slightly cheesy green tealeaf and cracker, some sweet lemon in the nose. Dry zesty lemonade with a sweetish stonefruit ring and again some cheesy hop and/or slightly earthy yeast character not at odds with the mineral palate. Maybe this is basic for a bitter, but i could drink this kind of pumped up earthy goodness all day like Zoigl...

Draught at the Gallipot Inn. Slightly citrusy but not overly coming through in the taste. Classic cask ale task yet gentle on the palate. Very light / watery. Could go the distance for a good session (but not sure you’d want to..)

Sipped at a pub in Groombridge, food was utterly forgettable but this beer saved the evening. Taste of utterly pure ingredients with a subtle Kentish hop that lingers but does not overstay its welcome like some of these new fangled dolly-Parton beers.

An excellent session beer due to the sensible strength,smooth flavour and easy drinkability. Hop and malt are well balanced with no overall dominance of either so the second will go down as easily as the first (and so on). It is refreshing for a hot afternoon and there is little danger of a sore head even after several. It is unspectacular but that is entirely the point, it doesn’t aim to be. This is a good one to introduce people to traditional English beers.

Tapped (@The Flower Pot, Maidstone, Kent, U.K.): Deep golden to light amber coloured, a bit unclear, creamy and lacy off-white head, slightly caramelly, but mainly fruity nose with a bready touch; dryish bitter-sweet flavour, light to medium bodied, soft; slightly lingering caramelly-bitter finish with an illusion of dried fruits. O.K. ......
Cask at The Bottle House Inn. Pale amber. The aroma is lightly spicy with a bit of soft leafiness. Very light palate with only a hint of bitterness. Fairly watery - meh, okay.

Cask (handpump) @ GBBF 09, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England. Light light unclear medium amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, nutty, light hoppy. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090805]

Cask @ "The Man Of Kent" Rochester. Simple eazy to sink old man type of beer, this 28 year old digged it too. Dusty hops are spicy and floral. Toffee malts ..some fruity orange..earth ..pine and lemon zest. This beer ,despite being floral-does taste a bit like its got cobwebs all over it. Dusty yeast or something. Nice brew anyway bozo.
A Mes rate. Cask at GBBF. Copper colour with thin off white head. Slightly oaky, some toffee, dull and slightly astringent citric bitterness. Boring.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at the Phoenixville location, clear amber in a tulip glass. Sweet bready malt and yeast aroma. Bread then hops taste, very bitter finish.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle poured into a glass. Hazy with small white head. Aroma is yeasty, medium body, medium carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is yeasty and some tart.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Draft at brewery.Bready, yeasty, honey aroma. Taste is sweet, fell is sleek. Nice flavors throughout, savory, grassy. Decent Saison.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Transferring from old system. The color was golden, but there wasn’t any haze to it. The aroma was light, but did have some yeast to it. The flavor was missing some of the standard spices. bottle

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Bottle split 3 ways. Saison Vos pours a lightly hazygolden, with a small one finger head. Notes of crisp german pils malt, hay, bread, spice, and lemon skin. Spicy as it warms up with a thin to medium feel in the mouth. Decent saison.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Bottle; pours gold with a white head; aroma of yeast, malt, some fruits, and hints of spice; taste is slightly sweet with yeast, fruits, malt, and hints of grass; finish is dry with some spice and fruit notes

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Bottle from Pivoteka, Zagreb. Shared with Marko. Clear, very light colored. Lasting frothy white head. Wine-like aromas, quite aromatic. Dry, Champagne, watery. Very light with some alcohol in the finish, quite warming in the end. Has good and bad sides.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Light florals and bubblegum. Golden pour with ok head. Light citrus and soft malt aroma. Light sweet finish. Tap at Sehkraft.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: Bottle, 750 ml, courtesy of JFK10000, shared with him and Miro B. Pours cloudy yellow, large white head. Bit yeasty, spicy, fruit notes, light bitterness. Medium bodied. Decent saison.

column2: Pottstown and Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States
column5: On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear pale yellow with a thin white head. Aromas of fruity yeast and light light banana. Like a slightly tangy pils. Quite refreshing.
Cask Conditioned. Mid brown beer with thin disappearing head. Overwheming tea, ash flavours, dry but thin and watery, little mouthfeel.

Kent's newest brewery, Old Kent, opened in 2000 in Borough Green with a range of five beers; their names based on cricket: Fine Edge, Full Pitch, etc. The blurb on the bottles puts an emphasis on the traditional and hopes to evoke a long past country atmosphere. All the beers are bottle conditioned. The Opener is a disappointing start - thin and lifeless, this is like a weedy old man in stained and faded cardigan shuffling up to the wicket to be bowled out for a duck.

The name on this bottle refers to a record-breaking test match score by Brian Lara in 1994. This is the best of the Old Kent beers I've tried, but is perhaps impressionist rather than traditional in style. The flavours are dotted around, and sometimes seem out of place - it's interesting and tasty enough, but doesn't quite work as a team. Worth another innings though.
on holiday in kenya 0.50 bottle gold blond colored sparkling body with a white head and a malt hoppy aroma a malt wattery hoppy taste with a bitter finish

Bottle. Clear light golden liquid with medium white head. Aroma of corn, cereal, butter, cooked vegetables and bread. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of cereal, butter and bread. Medium bodied with medium to high carbonation. Yuck, bad stuff. Kenya tick though, yeah!
500 ml bottle in Kenya. Pours a pale yellow with a fast to go bubbly head. Armoa is weak and uninteresting, Taste is much the same a weak watered down beer. Palate is much like the taste.

Bottle: Poured a super pale yellow color lager with a small pure white foamy head. Aroma of light adjunct is quite light. Taste is quite bland with limited adjunct notes and a semi-sweet finish. Body is thin with good carbonation. Another bland offering with limited taste.

500ml bottle. Pale golden body with a white head. Weak malt aroma. Light malty and sweet grainy flavor. Watery with almost no bitterness. Short aftertaste. Quite refreshing, but identical to so many other of its kind.
pale yellow, thick white head with some lacing. Malty aroma with some hints of cooked vegetables. Sweet, sugary plastic flavour with a touch of lemon. Watery and thin. No bitterness whatsoever.
Bottled. Pours a pale golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet malty, slightly metalic. Taste is sweet grainy.
Bottle. Clear golden colour with a big white head. Metallic malty aroma and taste. Watery body and a thin finish.

(Bottle 50 cl) Very pale golden with a fine, creamy head. High in carbonation. Lightly perfumy, malty aroma. Rather thin body with some sweetish malt. No real trace of hops. Good malternative if your well is polluted I guess....Thanks to Dorthe for bringing this over a long, long distance. 221005
A yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet with primary notes of straw - and so is the flavor, with a dry end. The body is quite thin.

Bottle from Hops and Crafts Exeter. Pours clear deep amber with an off white head. Aroma of nuts, ,grass, chocolate ,lemon & brown bread. Taste of light chocolate,a little treacle,brown bread,hay & a little pepper. On the light side of medium bodied with a smooth nicely carbonated mouthfeel. The finish is dry and sweet with more brown bread, treacle,ligh chocolate, hay,pepper,lemon & rye cracker.
Keg at the hanging bat. Pours clear amber, nose is musty, grass, herbs, taste is grassy, vegetative.

Aroma; roasted malts, dark syrup, dark bread, grass, nuts, grain, caramel, raisin. Look; pale beige head, clear brown body. Taste; dark syrup, prune, roasted malts, dark bread, grass, nuts, grain, caramel, and finishes lingering fruity malted. Feel; good body, juicy, gentle co². Overall; good dunkel. [btl @im hauslicher Umgebung] 7484'15

500ml bottle from Corks of North Street, Bristol (BB 28/12/19). Typical Dunkel appearance - clear copper brown, beige head, foamy, decent lace. Malty aromas of toast, caramel, subtle dark chocolate are reflected on the tongue which is sweet and toasty. Palate is smooth, light carbonation, medium bodied, sweetish finish. Quaffable.

Bottle at home. It pours clear medium brown with a decent foamy beige head. The aroma is earthy roast, rye bread, toasted nut, woody and some dried fruits. The taste is dry, earthy, toasted nut, wood, quite savoury feeling, rivita, brown bread and dried fruits with a drying finish. Medium body and moderate, foamy carbonation. Decent enough dunkel.
At the Bräustüberl Tegernseer, with a view on the lake. the foam stability is medium. The body dark brown. The Aroma is darkmalty, the taste is darkmalty, maybe a bit bitter, roasty. Easy but ok.
Beer with brown color, clear aspect, soft bitterness, low volume of foam on top, flat carbonized, (drunk a 33cl tap beer at "Little Italy", Tutzing, DE #955)(#121 DE)(#55 Bavaria).

Glass bottle 500ml from Seven Seasons, Hoxton. Poured into a pint glass, fridge cold. Best before 01/08/19. The beer pours a deep dark amber with cherry red tinting where the light bleeds through. A slight haze with two fingers of uniform compact head. The colour of the head resembles the yellowness that a heavy smoker with a greyed moustache might experience(my roundabout way of saying yellow tinged white). The aroma is sweet and malty, reminisced of a bock. Caramel and cereal grains. A hint of corn. Simple but inviting. The taste follows exactly. Sweet, caramel, malt, grains. Clean and very tasty. All lager-pilsner-dortmuner-hells beers should be like this. Medium-low carbonation in the mouth. Clean, slightly sweet aftertaste. A very simple, very well made, very tasty beer. I think you’d have trouble finding a better beer in the style. I’d love to try this one on tap.
AR: malzig, nussig AP: klares rotbraun, kastanienbraun TA: malzig, karamell

Aroma of caramel malts, and grainy bread. Pours deep reddish amber with thin tan lace . Taste is medium sweet with a sweet malts edge and light bitter finish. Palate is medium bodied oily texture average carbonation and a long mellow finish. I bought it for the style and I can imagine that if I could frequent the brauhaus, this would be a regular choice.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Christmas Ale
column5: 15th December 2012 Clear bright brown beer, good off white head. Palate is smooth and quite dry. Semi sweet malts with a little lactose. Whisper of toffee. Trace of bubblegum ester. Mild minerals. Trace of blackcurrant and spice. Finishes very dry and medium bitter. Not bad, fairly well joined up. Over dry though!

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Christmas Ale
column5: Bottle. Red amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma is roasted malt, hop, caramel, grain. Flavour is roasted malt, fruit, hop, spices, caramel. Medium body. Ordinary beer.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Christmas Ale
column5: Bottle. Pours amber with a tiny off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, roasted grains, nuts and red fruits. Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, nuts, red fruits and fruitiness. medium body, average carbonation.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Christmas Ale
column5: Bottle 500ml @ Geokkjer Pours clear brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, spices and floral hops. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Christmas Ale
column5: Bottle. It’s a clear, dark amber beer topped by a dense, light beige head. The aroma is lightly roasted, with caramel and some fruityness. Quite simple, but far from bad. It’s quite dry on the palate, medium bodied and with a nice carbonation level. Caramel, roasted notes, some bitterness and a little fruityness in the flavor. Lasting bitter and caramel roasted finish. A rather boring one, but sure drinkable. 130119

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Christmas Ale
column5: Clear amber of color with a small off white head. An aroma of bread, caramel, bisquit and weak fruity. A flavor of bread, bisquit, hops, grass, caramel and fruity.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Christmas Ale
column5: 50cl bottle from Appellation Wines. Pours like a really dark honey to chestnut colour. The nose has honey and barrabrith bread. The taste has sharp spicey hops, with a honey and malt backbone. The palate has a medium body with a round sweet texture and a finish that is a little cloying with some alcohol too. Overall, rich but a little unbalanced.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Christmas Ale
column5: 0,5 l shared bottle cortesy of Odland. Hazy hazelnut with a light brown big bubbled film leaving a good lacing. Toffee, malt on the nose. Sweet malty bitter light acidic light toasted mouth. Fully bodied and rich. Long bitter finish. Light hint of chlorine.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Christmas Ale
column5: Bottle from Odland, thanks.Pours dark golden with a small white head. Aroma of light roasted caramel, bitter coffee. Taste is sweet malty,light roasted with some spicy notes, lingering dry and moderate bitter. Ok to be a christmas beer.

column1: Wye Valley Dorothy Goodbody's Christmas Ale
column5: 500 ml bottle, kindly shared by abemorsten, thanks to Odland.. ABV is 6.0%. Amber colour, moderate head, slightly off-white. Very moderate aroma, some dusty malts, a hint of toffee. The flavour has a nice balance between the malts and hops (Bramling Cross and Fuggles), a slight roastiness in the dry finish. Nothing particularly "christmasy" about it though, but decent to drink..

Brewed by an unspecified brewery in Warwick trading under the name the Han Red Ginseng Beer Co Ltd, this is a light tasting lager flavoured with ginger and ginseng. There is another beer flavoured with ginseng called Cupid Ale by the Robert Cain brewery, so this is not especially unique. The flavour is very much that of a ginger beer shandy. Light and resonably refreshing, though the sweet ginger flavour can stick to the mouth a bit. One to give a miss really.

column2: Ocean Township, New Jersey, United States
column5: Bottle courtesy of maniac, thank you sir! Clear amber color. Aroma of rusty caramel. Taste is sweet and sticky caramel.

column2: Ocean Township, New Jersey, United States
column5: Bottle @ The WWGT2D? Tasting. I hope travlr doesn’t rate this. Amber with a small head. The nose is oxidized, as you’d expect. SOme sherry and rotting cherry. Cardboard sprinkled with cocoa powder. The taste is a great advertisement for the benefits of cellaring. Nasty cardboard. Mildly soured cherries. Bear claw donut. Light body, soft carbonation.

column2: Ocean Township, New Jersey, United States
column5: Bottle shared by Alan at his house. Pours brown with no head. Nose and taste of oxidation, sherry, caramel and bready malt. Lighter medium body.

column2: Ocean Township, New Jersey, United States
column5: Join me, as I enjoy a Taste of History! Appearance: Cautiously poured a deep amber-hued body, quite clear, due to the yeast packed into the bottom of the bottle due to years of quiet solitude. No head beyond a few, large stray bottles. Smell: Toasted breadcrusts, some cooked honey, and aged-derived notes of cardboard and a hint of metal. Some dark fruitiness, some dirty socks. Taste: Toasted breadcrusts, forgotten grains, and a low, supporting honeyesque sweetness. Raisins, loose change, and some water-logged cardboard. Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. No remaining carbonation. Overall: This had been another installment of... a Taste of History!

column2: Ocean Township, New Jersey, United States
column5: 12 ounce bottled shared by maniac at the 12th Richmond Ratebeer Gathering on 9/18/10. Pours a clear amber color with nearly no head. Aroma of toffee, raisins, daint leafy hops and light toasty notes. The taste is citrus and leafy hops with tart-cherry like notes. Medium-full bodied.

column2: Ocean Township, New Jersey, United States
column5: Buttered toast, honey, and almond aroma. Clear copper, headless. Tart tea and elderberry flavor. Superb honey finish. Fantastic!

column2: Ocean Township, New Jersey, United States
column5: (Sample Date: 9/18/2010 Source:Other) Malty with dark fruit notes and some wine in the aroma. Clear copper with little head. Malty with some nice oxidation and a slight sour twang. Dark fruit notes. Finish is lightly sour and fruity with light bitterness.

column2: Ocean Township, New Jersey, United States
column5: Sampled at the Richmond Gathering XII. Pours a dull amber with ring of near white head. Nose is sweet caramel, biscuit, and some oxidation. Flavor is a little cardboard, sweet apples. Medium palate. Decent for the style i suppose? Easy drinker.

column2: Ocean Township, New Jersey, United States
column5: Bottle from kp. Served into a snifter. Pour is hazy nut brown with a small ring of sticky white head. Aromas of rasins, caramel, faded hops, and sweet fruit. Flavor is mellow and smooth with caramel, rasin, and plum. Past its prime but still enjoyable.

column2: Ocean Township, New Jersey, United States
column5: Bottle (3 years old?), courtesy GodOfThunder. Pours a hazy, reddish amber color with a dense, foamy, khaki colored head. Minimal, spotty lacing. The aroma is mostly sweet, light caramel and bready yeast dominating lesser notes of toffee, floral hops, and peppery spice. Flavors follow suit, sweet biscuit and toasted bread showing in the forefront, with staunch floral hops following through. Dark fruits emerge at the mid point, mostly figgy, but reaching as far as sweet-tart strawberry. Medium-plus bodied and well carbonated, the mouthfeel doesn’t impress, but doesn’t disappoint either. As others have noted, it’s certainly not at its best, but it is still solid even at this age.
Bottle. Darker golden in color with a whitish head. Sweet fruity banana and wheat in aroma. Ripe banana and notes of wheat in taste. Quite sweet.

Bottle. Clear dark yellow color, small head. Fruity aroma, reminds me of ice bonbons. Sweet taste, low bitterness. Malty, somewhat estery aftertaste, but tastes light. Low carbonation, decent mouthfeel. As a light Weißbier to drink from the bottle ok, but not a fully fledged one.
Heller, kaum aromatischer Antrunk. Im Mittelteil trocken und weiter laff aromatisch. Geringe Herbe, wässrig. 8/6/5/5/8/5

Ein schnelles Flaschenweizen was auch aus der Flasche wohl genossen werden kann. Das gehört sich einfach nicht für Weizen... wie ein Pils aus einem Masskrug. Dieses Bier riecht nur bedingt nach Weizen. Es sieht noch einigermassen aus wie ein Weissbier aber schon im Einstieg wird deutlich es handelt sich um eine geschmackliche lite Version von Weizenbier. Es ist recht Süss und geschmacklich uneinheitlich. Zwar ist der Weizengeschmack erkennbar aber zu Schwach und zu Süß. Fazit: Vielleicht in der Gattung Flaschenweizen noch standard, im Bieruniversum mangelhaft.

33cl. Mild-weich im Antrunk. Leicht hefig-bananig. Frisch, aber recht süß. Der Hauptteil ist süßlich-weizig, mild und süffig, aber recht süß. Im Nachgeschmack sehr bananig-süß, mild-weich. Mäßiges und sehr süßliches Weizen. Ganz leicht herb im Nachgeschmack. --> 10/12/9/9
Trübes goldgelbes Bier mit schöner Schaumkrone. Geruch hefig, fruchtig. Geschmack hefig, fruchtig nach Banane, leicht würzig.
Bisschen Banane und Nelke, aber nicht zu viel. Erfrischend gute Restsüße. Ein bisschen Eisbonbon, könnte aber auch unterbewusst sein.

It’s unclear golden with a creamy white head. The aroma has notes of yeast, wheat, banana and a VERY light touch of meat. The flavor is sweet with notes of mild yeast, banana (mostly banana peal), fruit, wheat and the finish is slightly spicy.

Bottle: Golden, white and stable lacy head, wheaty-dusty nose, supported by a yeasty-fruity touch; sweet-sourish flavour, light bodied and quite soft; some citrussy traces in the sweetish-wheaty finish, some yeast is detectable.Quite a decent Weizen...

Bottle 330ml. Unclear medium yellow colour with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, wheat, light to moderate hoppy, grass, light to moderate yeasty. Flavour is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration, yeasty, grainy notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120817]
Dark orange brown pour. Thin head. Pumpkin and pie spice nose. Initial taste of pumpkin with barley palate. Sweet and sour.
clear amber colour, large, dense and stable off-white head; aroma and taste of pumpkins, some cinnamon, slight clove, nutmeg and biscuity-caramel notes; not bad

12-ounce bottle pours copper with a tiny beige head and some lacing. Aroma: brown sugar, pumpkin pie spice. Flavor: cinnamon, nutmeg, brown sugar, raisins, pecans. Mouthfeel: medium-bodied, slick finish.
Orangey bronze color, white head. Pumpkin pie aroma. Sweet pumpkin pie flavored beer, caramel, spices. I love pumpkin pie, but why in a beer? It doesn't taste neceasarily bad I just don't see why.
12 oz bottle, pours clear orange amber. Nutmeg and pumpkin dominate the aroma. Strongly spiced taste and finish, with pumpkin overpowered. Finish is somewhat unpleasant.

12 oz bottle from Trader Joe's in Short Pump, VA The ale poured an almost clear rich amber color with and off-white head and lacing. A good looking ale. Your nose is attacked by clove, cinnamon, and hints of vanilla. Your taste buds are assaulted as well with more cinnamon and earthy chocolate. The pumpkin taste is very muted by the other spices. The ale has a medium body and average carbonation. Not bad for a seasonal ale. I like the ABV at 7%.
Bottle. Pours brown. Vanilla, clove, cinnamon, biscuit, little earthy, touch of milk chocolate, dryish finish. Medium body. Not bad.
Nice juicy medium body, mild sweetness without any sour or off notes. Pure pumpkin moderate flavor without intrusive spice notes which is so refreshing!

Pint, draft at Winking Lizard in Copley . Smell the pumpkin and the spices. Amber in color with light white head. Taste soft cinnamon and nutmeg. Pumpkin also. Spice aftertaste. Delightful pumpkin and really drinkable. Cheers!

Pours up a clear dark amber color in the glass, with a tan head. Pumpkin flavor is detectable amidst a cocktail of spices, including cinnamon, nutmeg, and vanilla. Where this ale excels the most is it's body as a brown ale, which creates a naturally rich platform for pumpkin without the overbearing muddiness of some. A little heavy on the spices, but good.

column1: Great Dane Verruckte Stadt German Pils
column5: On tap in Fitchburg, WI The third of four regulars that I tried on this particular visit provided another benchmark experience for the Great Dane's line up of regular and seasonal drafts. Much like Crop Circle Wheat it will not challenge your assumptions about the state of pilsners but will be easy to finish. AROMA / APPEARANCE Lemon crisp, buttered toast, and a tease of cereal grains compose the core of this balanced session driven bouquet. A clear golden body lightens the mood as it reflects back much of the active light. FLAVOR / PALATE Wheat, lemon crisps, and semisweet hay packed down by dozens of feet enrich the tongue with a fluid texture. The refreshing profile is otherwise unremarkable though not without its strengths. For those times when you just want a basic pils it does everything one would expect. This is another fine choice for any starter flight to calibrate your own preferences.

column1: Great Dane Verruckte Stadt German Pils
column5: This pours a clear, dark yellow color with a slight white head. The aroma is slightly malty. The flavor is mild and good for a pils. Lots of grain and hints of citrus.

column1: Great Dane Verruckte Stadt German Pils
column5: Sample at the downtown brewpub. Clear pale yellow-gold color with a thin white head that evaporates quickly to a sparse film. Spotty lacing. Grassy hops and bready malt in the nose. LIght body with flavors of herbal hops, yeast and malt. The finish is mildly bitter with a short spiced hops aftertaste. Barely average overall.

column1: Great Dane Verruckte Stadt German Pils
column5: On tap at the brewpub. Comes a clear light gold with a nice white head. Aroma of malt, grain, and grass. Taste is malt, grain, grass, and florals. Decent enough.

column1: Great Dane Verruckte Stadt German Pils
column5: Tap at the brewpub in Wausau. Clear pale golden pour with a smaller spotty white head. Nose is very faint. Crisp palate but just mild cream / grain here. Dull.

column1: Great Dane Verruckte Stadt German Pils
column5: draft. clear, sparkling yellow. buttered popcorn and sweetish candycorn nose. sourish mint leaf grassy hops. egg shells and sulfur are quite high. fizzy and rough; coarse and brash acids. poorly made

column1: Great Dane Verruckte Stadt German Pils
column5: A snappy pils with more hoppy bitterness than malty sweetness. A bit of caramel and, hmmmm, maybe lemon on the aroma. Enjoyed on tap with the kick-butt meatloaf at the original Great Dane.

column1: Great Dane Verruckte Stadt German Pils
column5: Thirsty Troll Brew Fest. Pour is gold with a white head. Aroma shows pale malt and grassy hops. Flavor shows pretty much the same with maybe a touch of citrus hiding in the background. Overall body is light, crisp, and finishes with light bitterness. Nothing offensive, just not very interesting.

column1: Great Dane Verruckte Stadt German Pils
column5: A golden lager with a thin lacing white head. In aroma, a light acidic malt with light German hops. In mouth, a nice crisp malt with German hopping, boring. On tap at Madison airport location, Jan 22 2012.

column1: Great Dane Verruckte Stadt German Pils
column5: On tap at the Wausau GD. Served a mid gold with a nice frothy head that faded slowly to a nice lacing. Aroma was of malt and hops. Taste was similar with Pilsner-like hop predominance but mild, not bitter, in nature. The mouth was decent. Overall, a decent pilsner.

2/9/19. On tap at the brewpub. Clear amber red pour with a small khaki head that fades to a ring. Light fruity aroma, biscuit and caramel. Sweet malty entry, caramel, a touch of fruitiness, some bitterness and chalkiness. Eh.

[Tap] On tap at the brewpub in Wausau. Pour is amber/orange in color. NOt much head on top. Cocoa powder and grain are the only things I could pick out of the aroma. Sweet toffee, caramel, noticeable alcohol and biscuity notes. A tad syrupy, with a sweet finish. An OK beer, but wish there was some better balance.

On tap at downtown location. Pours a clear reddish color. Nose is of light fruit and sweet malt with some floral notes. This beer tastes nice and sweet, hints if molasses, caramel, roasted malt, and floral hops. The hops have more presence and flavor in this beer than the typical bock, but still in a subdued way. Very, very smooth and drinkable. Slightly warming. Medium body. Very well balanced with a hint of fizz in the tongue. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at downtown location, pours a clear dark amberish red with a thin white head, the aroma has a little bit of fruit that comes through with just a little bit of malt as well, the flavor has a lot of malt with a little bit of caramel and some spices as well, the abv burns just a little, mouthfeel is decent, not terrible by any means.

On tap at brewpub Sitting in the quiet basement area I started out with a well made bock. Balanced, inviting, and a good deal at $3.00 during Happy Hour it was one of many good choices available on a cold winter evening. Aroma / Appearance - Soft ruby red and radiant the body looked like a warm hearth after a long fire. A radiant ebony head graced the top like a layer of packing foam. Butterscotch, caramel, and a primarily malt driven experience drives home a sweet experience from start to finish. Flavor / Palate - Caramel, cotton candy, powdered sugar, and peanut butter were not the combination I was expecting. Even so it seemed to be satisfying and reasonably gentle on the palate. While perhaps not a great release it is well enough done that I don’t feel like my time was wasted.
good medium bodied and colored beer. nothing outstanding but good and solid performer overall lightly bitter,
Sampler. It poured a deep reddish caramel color and had a huge malty aroma. There was a small amount of hops and tons of caramelized malt with some fruity flavors. Not a bad bock brew.

Caramel-amber pour with a dense, creamy off-white head that leaves a sticky lacing. Faintish aroma, honey and alcohol. Initial flavor is sweet malts, cream soda and caramel, vanilla sweetness, offset by a minty spiciness and a sharp alcohol bite. Becomes significantly more bready towards the finish, becoming almost crusty on the linger. Full bodied, thick and quite smooth on the palate.

Poured with a light tan head and a little lace. Nice brown color with red highlights. Malty, slightly caramel and a hint smokey. Nice beer. Very drinkable. Easy. Not too sweet. Good body. Satisfying. Not boozy. Good session beer.

On tap at the downtown Dane. Poured clear coppery-brown with a tall, creamy cap of beige head.. beautiful! The aroma was very strong with aged caramel and chocolatey notes present.. singed the nose hairs a bit on the back. The flavor found sweeter caramel at the core with strong peppery, boozy notes around and through the finish.. some nice earthy and fruity character joined in as well.. grainy and strong on the finish. Medium-plus bodied and spicy on the palate with a decent flow.
Aroma malt, karamell. Utseende Klar mørk brun med offwhite skum. Smak malt, karamell. Maltpreg, middels fyldig, grei øl. Boks smakt September 2012, 50cl 4,5%
This is not my kin dof beer. Way too much honey, and where there’s a lack of bitterness, there’s too much sweetness and overripe malts.

500ml can from Rune and Finn from Tromso. Now I have never really looked at a map of Norway, and bugger me they live a long way away from just about anywhere. It’s only really when you look at these guys who live on an island in the arctic circle who have terrific numbers of rates especially as the price of beer there is so astronomical and then they come to London and must have the best time ever. Especially now. Anyway, this rating is dedicated to 2 beer lovers from a wintery island that is Tromso and for the great hour or so I spent with them in The Pakenham Arms on an autumnal Thursday late afternoon. This beer is clear orange gold with a lasting cream coloured head. The aroma I can say is not great. The flavour too isn’t the best in the world. It’s an ok, slightly cardboardy lager. It’s not terrible nor is it particularly good. But as I say the fact this comes from the edge of northern europe fills my heart with a sense of well being. Cheers guys and hope to see you next time you are in the UK.

Can at home. The colour is clear light amber with a small white head. Aromas of pale malt, grass, berries and gooseberry, and hints of spices. The flavour follows with apricot and grassy hops in addition. Light and slick mouth feel, and light bitterness. A surprisingly okay beer.
