The last can of the northern Norwegian macro collection provided to me by Foffern, thanks a lot for these missing ticks man! :-) Pours a deep, near-brown golden orange with a medium, foamy white retention. Nose is light caramel and pale malt tones with hints of red berries and wet paper. Taste is pale malts, hints of caramel and some quite hideous metallic hints in the finish. Watery palate. Not good, I know Mack can to much better than this.

(Can, 0.5 l, courtesy of Rune - thanks) The beer poured pale copper coloured and clear. Its head was medium sized, fizzy and white and it disappeared quickly. Aroma had caramell, toffee and mildly grass. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were sweetness, toffee, caramell, malts, mildly grass at the background and lowish bitterness. Aftertaste had caramell and bitterness. A bit unbalanced beer: flavours left the middle of my tongue completely deserted.
Light brown and clear. Has a white head, mostly diminishing. Moderate malty aroma, toasted. Flavor is moderate sweet and finish light bitter. Lively carbonation.
0.5l can at Craig’s house. light golden colour and transparent. Not my can of beer.
can at home ... amber ... big bubbly white head ... sweet juicy lager nose ... light grassy lager hop ... little hunny ... really not up to much ...but there again i dont like lagers
03.01.2004. 0,5l Can. Ølet er mørkt og gyllent. Smaken er god men ølet er litt pregløst og kommer dessverre til å gå i glemmeboken.

column1: Oskar Blues G'Knight Imperial Red IPA
column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: 355ml can from LCBO.Pours an opaque red ale with two fingers of off white head. Layered lacing clinging to the side of glass. Delicious sweet fruity aroma with a whiff of grapefruit bitterness. Taste matches the aroma. Sweet honey and toffee notes. Little bit of pumpkin?? Not as dry and bitter as your usual IPA. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Sticky mouthfeel. Loving it.

column1: Oskar Blues G'Knight Imperial Red IPA
column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Tight creamy off white head stayed on a hazy reddish brown still body. Tangerine, raspberry, sweet citrus & resin aroma. Medium bodied, creamy & aerous in the mouth with a cloying back. Red berries, pine, resin, sugar, syrup & spices with malt undercurrent.

column1: Oskar Blues G'Knight Imperial Red IPA
column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Can from BrewDog Bottlebox. Hazy reddish brown with a large foamy off white head. Toffee, currants and berry aroma. Fairly thick mouthfeel, chocolate, chewy berries, caramel and rye with a bitter aftertaste.

column1: Oskar Blues G'Knight Imperial Red IPA
column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Found out of can. Pours reddish. Nice red haze, with strong hop flavor. Great Fall option.

column1: Oskar Blues G'Knight Imperial Red IPA
column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Not much aroma, but there is booze and dark fruit sugar upon close sniff. Smooth, caramel, candied, dark fruit, resinous boozy bitterness in the flavor. Finishes astringent. Nicely balanced; reminds me of Dogfish Head's legendary 90 Minute. Very good DIPA and certainly one of Oskar Blues' best beers. Easily the best stuff I've had from them along with their legendary Dale's Pale Ale.

column1: Oskar Blues G'Knight Imperial Red IPA
column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Deep orange brown, small off-white head. Caramel-forward character, with some piney notes. Alright.

column1: Oskar Blues G'Knight Imperial Red IPA
column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Can from Coppers, Newcastle. Amber-red coloured with a large white head of foam. It has a bitter orange and pine flavour with citrus and liquorice on the smooth warming finish. Excellent!

column1: Oskar Blues G'Knight Imperial Red IPA
column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: 12 oz can. Smells of coffee and citrus. Amber brown in color. Taste sweet, malt , hops, a touch of citrus and pine. Sweet roasted malt finish with a touch of hops. The booze is well hidden. Nice balance. Quite enjoyable.

column1: Oskar Blues G'Knight Imperial Red IPA
column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: This can is coming from the sterk, in Amsterdam, drinking and enjoying this can, two days ago, at home, in Epalinges. You get a copper body, clear, ordinary carbonation, white foam. In my point of view, it is a generous IPA, delicious. You smell at the nose, a side of fresh pine tree and malt and I waa thinking of a typical resinous IPA, when you drink it, you a discreet side of pine tree, this IPA is well balanced, malty, smooth, pine tree and round, perfect bitterness and a beautiful harmony in the mouth.

column1: Oskar Blues G'Knight Imperial Red IPA
column4: Oskar Blues Brewery (CANarchy Craft Brewery Collective)
column5: Can: Aroma is malt, candy, dark fruits, caramel and resin. Reddish color, medium head. Flavor is malty, caramelic, candies, pine, resin, dark fruits, herbs, bitter citrus peel. Ends dry, bitter, astringent. Nice.
Far from impressive. This has a tangy and sour feel but is watery more than anything. Not worth it.

A beer that lacks character and is rather plain.In other words, nothing special stood out about this beer.It formed virtually no head and there were fine-sized bubbles observed.The body had some lively carbonation to it and it was just a bit cloudy.The hue was pale yellow and there was no lacing.The nose was malty and the flavor was slightly hoppy.The mouthfeel was tingly, smooth, watery and light bodied.

This brew poured a small head of quickly disappearing medium sized white bubbles that left very little lacing and a transparent softly carbonated orange colored body behind. Its aroma is a plesant malty one and its mouthfeel is quite bubbly. The flavor is a tad off and thin though. Otherwise, I was starting to like this one. That is until I tasted it.
Relies on its light diacetyl for most of its flavor. Really not that bad for a lite beer. Not really unlike their basic lager.
Nice light beer with good flavor. A tad fizzy and aggressive in the mouth but a nice clean and refreshing beer. Somewhat watery but what do you expect from a light beer?

This light beer is all malt and very clean. Body is light but not as light as the macros. This one is more in the category of Amstel Light in terms of body and flavor but it''s much better than Amstel. I find it clean, refreshing and very enjoyable. A good trade-up for macro and import light beer drinkers. Is this going to lure craft beer drinkers into drinking light beer? No, but it isn''t intended to. After all, what self-respecting craft beer drinker is going to buy light beer on a regular basis? This is a great beer for craft drinkers to keep in the fridge for their non-beer geek friends.
light straw color. Palate was fizzy and "mushy". A very small step above most macros. This was very disappointing, knowing how much better this brewer can do.
Almost approaching Coors light in the "taste" category, but not quite that bad. A weak attempt.
From the backlog, draft & bottle. Pours deep amber, offwhite head. Caramel, roasty malts, pine, citrus.

09.03.2013, 0,35l bottle @ home: Lett fyldig og s�dmerik fruktig lukt med preg av malt, humle, v�te blad, jord, gras, karamell, litt barskog. S�dmerik smak med preg av malt, humle, jord, v�te blad, karamell, gras, litt barn�ler. Middels bitterhet som set litt. Grei.

From Jul 2007 Purchased as part of a mixed 6pack at Wilbur's Liquors in Ft Collins. This pours from 12oz bottle a nice clear deep amber with a large head of foam that recedes slowly leaving a few small islands near the center and it has some lacing. The smell is hoppy. I get a lot of grapefruit but I also get some caramel malt. The taste on first sip is kind of strange. The initial flavour is rather empty of flavour, kind of watery but then, thankfully, the grapefruit hoppy goodness moves in near and through the finish though it's at a subdued level. Hey, this is only 4.4%abv so I expected some kind of reduction in what was going to hit my taste buds and it sure makes this Ale a good for sessioning candidate *if* the flavour that's there is enough to please. Imho, it passes that test. I'd buy it again.
A very solid amber ale. Plenty of malty body, typical of an easy drinking amber, but it has a nice grassy hop punch as well.

Draft Third of a Pint at GBBF 2009 (Day 1), Earl’s Court, London Aug 2009 - And Bottle - Deep Amber in colour. Malty base/backbone; roasty malts, caramel. Hoppy; big grapefruit citrus hop flavours; grassy hops. Nice malt/hops balance. Dry hoppy finish. Much hoppier than expected. Surprisingly flavoursome for a low-ABV beer. Very drinkable. Nice beer! (2009-08)

Punaisenruskea kirkas olut paksulla, höttöisellä ja pitsiä jättävällä vaahdolla. Kaunis olut. Tuoksu humalaa ja hedelmää. Maku hieman greippinen, mutta varsinkin jälkimaultaan enemmänkin greippisen katkera. Ulkonäkö tässä oluessa toimii ja maitokauppavahvuiseksi tietysti hieno tekele, mutta omaan makuuni turhan greippinen.

darker amber colour, moderate sized yellowish head; aroma of toast, resins, floral and biscuity notes, some roasted nuts, too. taste is the same- mild roasted toasty and malty; easily drinkable good amber ale

0.355l bottle. Clear amber body, lasting off-white head. Aroma of caramel, toast, reisins and citruses. Taste of caramel, toast, citruses and even some roasted malts. Light medium bodied. Easy to drink. Quite nice.

Thanks Lagzibacsi! Light brown. Very sweet flaky malty aroma. Sweet syrup on the nose. Long sweet malts and mild bitterness. Really sessionable. Balanced nice a bit sweet for me, but a good 12 pack beer.

Où, Quand, Comment : Bouteille, dégustée au Mondial de la Bière 2007. Visuel : Couleur : ambrée foncée. Apparence : claire. Arôme : Houblon résineux, citrique, légèrement floral et fruité (agrumes, abricots), caramel sucré. Goût : Entrée de bouche : Moyenne amertume de houblon floral, moyennement citrique, fruitée (agrumes, notes d’abricots) et aux notes herbeuse, présente toute la gorgée. Un support malté de caramel sucré aux notes rôties est également présent des notes de pain. En bouche : Corps : moyen. Effervescence : moyen. Texture : légèrement crémeuse. Finale : moyenne-longue et un peu sèche, moyennement amère de houblon résineux, légèrement herbeux et citrique aux notes florales et terreuses.
ausome beer send more. good arfter taste has a efifesence like no other local beer here leaves vb and xxxx at the starting gate good hops and 440ml is a good size can.

There’s nothing better than a slab of these to make you forget you’re with your family on Christmas day. Come to think of it, if you forget it’s even Christmas, then you’ve done well. Very nice and pleasant aftertaste and a full, rich body. This rivals the best beers out there. Regal indeed. Fit for a King.
Strike 3 for this brewery. If something is regal it should be fit for a Queen. Hmmm, come to think of it perhaps we should export this to England.
Again almost no aroma. Very sweet and chemical tasting. Faintly bitter at the end. Just shows how desperate I am for ratings these days.
i guess not all small brewery stuff is good. this stuff was pretty rank, gassy, composty, miscellaneous industrial waste thrown in for good measure

Pale gold clear colour under a medium size and lasting off-white head and some random blobby lace. Very faint light hops and laundromat lint aroma. Light thin body with mild bitter flavoured start plus a fainter sweeter malt after that. One of thousands but probably OK for a lager.

I like when brewers do something unusual. It even nicer when it works. Light gold color. A light bodied wheat beer, flavored with mint and wheat grass. Smooth taste. Mild malts and hops. Very different taste. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet. A very interesting beer, the mint flavor is very prevalent yet it adds to the flavor of the wheat beer.
amber coloured weiss, cloudy in appearance, citrus hop, none of the banana flavour found in most german hefeweizen
Draught. Cloudy dark yellow with firm white head. Acidic aroma with tones of lemon. Smooth, round flavour with tones of wheat, spices. High acidity.
Sampled draught at Stockholm Beer Festival. Yellow coloured, hazy. Acidic citrusy nose. Yeasty and light bodied with lemony finish.
golden lager, nothing special, served too cold in the brewpub to detect any real flavour, but on cask has a bit more hop flavour and aroma
Cask Handpump at the Smithfield Hotel, Manchester 07/03/2002 Straw golden coloured and smooth on the palate. Slightly pale aroma. Hoppy finish.
[Draft at Stockholm Beer Festival 2003] A golden beer with a fine head. The aroma is very lightly malty. The flavor is malty sweet and it ends on a rather bitter note. A pretty simple beer.
Sampled draught at Stockholm Beer Festival. Golden with a decent head. Soapy malty nose. Flavour with notes of citrus and butterscotch.
Sample draught at Stockholm Beer Festival 2003. Light golden with a steady white head. Fresh aroma with hop and malt. Almost a bit ale-ish flavour with citrus and maybe butterscotch.
(Stockholm Beer Festival 2003) Light golden, not much head. A little thin and there could have been more aroma and flavor. A little dry, and has a bitter finish
Sampled draught at Stockholm Beer Festival. Pale amber. Grassy nose. Druity, firm and dry with bitter finish. A pleasant and well made pilsener.
another mis-named Dwan beer - not unpleasant, but not really a bitter, more of a brown ale. Malt dominates, though slight hoppy aftertaste
Yellow brown with firm white head. Aroma of citrusy hops, probably Cascade. Malty flavour with tones of tea. Dry bitter finish.
Sampled cask conditioned at Stockholm Beer Festival. Reddish amber. Strange sea water aroma. Lightly chocolatey sweet nose. Reasonably malty with dryish finish. Not very complex though.
cask in Great Western, Exeter. a reasonable attempt at a Belgian style ale, reddish in colour and with a sweetish crystal malt flavour
Cask Handpump at the Crescent, Salford 26/09/2002 Mid brown coloured with a sour fruit aroma and flavour. Lasting hop finish.
Orange-brown with firm white head. Grassy aroma with fruit and spice notes. Acidic flavour with tones of banana and alcohol. Dry finish.
Very interesting. A beer which is more easy-drinkable than Rodenbach. Very. very noce.
Sampled draught at Gulliver''s Pub in Copenhagen. Nice red colour. Reminds you of a Flanders Red Ale. Quite acidic and sweet-sour. Very refreshing and interesting.

Sampled draught at Stockholm Beer Festival. Very red, not much head. Peculiar aroma, with hints of lemon and rhubarb. Roasty, lightly acidic and surprisingly light bodied. Very complex and confusing beer. Like mixing all the beer styles of the world into one glass.
easy-drinking, fruity red ale. once again better cask than keg. caramel and crystal malt flavours nicely ballanced by hoppy finish
Aroma is fresh and fruity, some floural hops. Taste is carmel fruity malts with a decent amount of bitterness, not a bad wee ale.
Cask Stillage at the Pacific Road Arts Centre, Birkenhead 23/10/2003 Amber coloured with some alcohol present. Slight fruit aroma. Hint of bitterness in a crisp and creamy malt finish.

Keg Nice amber color; creamy head. Strange acid aroma. The taste is very strange for an Irish brew, being a bit sour, but it's pleasant and refreshing (a mix of British Ale and Flemish Sour Ale). It turns to be more like a Winter Warmer.
(Stockholm Beer Festival 2003) Amber with a very nice head. This is a fruity one, both in aroma and flavor. Some malt.
Dark amber. Creamy head, well creamy in all meanings. Juniper berry aroma. Fruity fresh aroma, still roasty. Nice one!
An everlasting head, like a dancefloor! Smooth, creamy palate with some fruit in the flavour.
A dark amber beer with a creamy head. The aroma is slight but of malt sweetness. The flavor is very smooth - with a good sweetness and a great bitterness and a really a good palate.

On tap: Beautiful dark amber coloured. Imressive head, that last till the end of the beer. Aroma is spicy and has notes of hops. Flavour is spicy and hoppy as well (I find some coriander notes). Very bitter in the end. Last very long on the palate. Nice beer.
Bitter watery typical English beer. ........................................
Bottle at Seven Seas Side, Turkey. Golden, clear with a medium white head. Aroma of malt, citrus and hops. Medium bitter with a soft malt and corn end. Ok at 40+
0,33 l bottle. Better than average pilsener from Gotland island, worth to drink
Flaska 330 ml från Systembolaget. Guldfärgad med fint vitt skum. Maltig och ganska fruktig doft. Maltig och brödig smak med inslag av citrus och frukt. Rejäl beska i eftersmaken.
From backlog. Bottle from Systembolaget Charlottenberg. Golden with white head. Malt, hops, herbs. Some bitterness.

330ml brown bottle poured into a pint glass. Appearance is clear pale golden with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma of grass, herbs and bread. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter. Palate is meidum bodied, smooth texture and average carbonation. Wisby Pils is a decent beer for the style, nice for a change to have a well hopped beer with German hops.
Pours clear darker golden, topped with a smaller and nonlasting white foam. Grainy, cardboard, corn nose. Sweet corn syrupy start. Hint of bitterness. Very vague. Watery body. Metallic finish.
Ordentliche Perlung, schönes Gold im Glas. In der Nase hopfig wie ein Pils sein muss. Im Trunk erst etwas wässrig, dann Getreide mittig bitterer werdend bis in dem Abgang. Passt.
Hygglig beska, men inte mycket eftersmak eller djup. Det känns som ett tvunget tillskott hos Wisby bryggeri, lite halvhjärtat
Tap at Bishops Arms Östersund. A pilsner true to form but it didn't do it for me again
Ljusgul med fint vitt skum. Doftar fruktigt och lite brödigt. Smaken fyllig, besk, tämligen torr. Eftersmaken lång med markant beska.
Bottle (part of a Federation selection pack). Biscuity malt, toffee, spices and fruit. Full mouthgell but an unusual flavour I couldnt place.

Bottled. Amber colour, moderate white head but strangely lumpy like semolina or frog spawn, low condition. Not bottle conditioned but had a fine grey sludge coating the bottle bottom (not an old bottle though). Low peppery hop aroma, sweet and malty in the mouth with some caramel and toffee. Biscuits in the finish and a slight hop bitterness.
Amber coloured. Sweet with some chewy malt. Medium bodied and dry with lingering salty finish. One-dimensional but balanced.

Orange colour with yellow tones. Malty aroma with hoppy tones. Stony, dry flavour. I have never understood this pseudo-beerstyle, Smooth. Both John Smith and this is very weak and just uses the nitro-carbonation as an excuse for brewing quite lousy beers.
This is really more of a brown ale. Cloudy brown color. Grassy nose. Pale malt flavor is predominant. I didn't like this as much as the Angel Ale.
This beer has a amber body - hue with a sweet initial flavor and a light body.
Sampled draught (nitro) at Stockholm Beer Festival. Amber coloured with creamy head. No aroma. Unclean mellow body, very sweet and lacking in just about everything.

Aroma; dark malt, dark tart, coffee, mocca, dark fruit. Look; tan good head, dark brown body. Taste; dark malt, dark caramel, dark tart, coffee, mocca chocolate, plums n prunes, and finishes lingering, good. Feel; good body, alright co². Overall; very good dunkel. [btl @im hauslicher Umgebung] 7484'16
On tap in Frankfurt, Germany. Dark red-brown, slightly hazy with a decent off-white head. Malty aroma. Taste is malt, roast, dark chocolate - just all of it not very intense. Easy to drink.
1l mug in Munich. Dark brown color with off white head. Fresh malty, caramel, biscuits, hints of coffee aroma and flavor. Crispy, caramel palate, light to medium body.
Keg at Paulaner Nockherberger, Munich in 2017. Deep ruby with an offwhite head. Aroma of caramel, roasted nuts and berries. Bready malt flavour with chewy grains and burnt sugar.

Eingetrübte dunkelbraune Farbe mit weißer Schaumkrone. Malziger, getreidiger Geruch. Geschmacklich malzig, getreidig, leicht rauchig mit Karamell. Mittlere Süße mit leichter Bitterkeit, leichter bis mittlerer Körper mit sanfter Kohlensäure.

Tap at Drink Baar as "Ur-Dunkel Naturtrüb / Original Münchner Dunkel" (according to untappd menu). Pours dark amber brown. Aroma and flavor are sweet, caramel, malt, grains. Feels bit watery and macro. Overall: ok.
500ml bottle (as Ur- Dunkel). Hazy brown color. Medium size, off-white head, stays. Caramel, sweet, malty in aroma and in taste. Fizzy carbonation. Drinkable brew.
Keg at bavaria brauhaus. Pours deep reddish Amber, nose is nutty, burnt cereal, toffee, taste is sweet, nutty, roasted, caramel.

On tap @ Münchner Stubn. Deep brownish body with a tall, foamy and persistent off-white head. Aroma is caramel, some chestnuts and cherries. Malt forward taste with lots of caramel again, dark bread, dried red fruits. Some mineral in finish. Medium body, lively carbonation, thin texture.

TAp at Paulaner am Dom, Frankfurt. Hazy dark brown with orange tints and a thick, medium head. Malty nose, chocolate, caramel, raisins. Sweet and rich malt flavor, dark chocolate, raisins, smooth and decent enough.

Draught version. Orange yellow with brown tones. Aroma of oranges, dust and amin. Citrusy flavour with tones of ethanol and a decent bitterness. I haven´t seen it since SBF 2002 so I guess it didn´t became an instant hit.
Sampled draught at Stockholm Beer Festival. Amber coloured. Big pear aroma. Full bodied and sweet, a slight hint of citrusd. Complex with soft mouthfeel and nicely bitter finish.

Nitro draught version. Orange brown with firm white head. Buttery aroma. A bit smoked flavour with firm bitterness and dry finish. Yet another prototype brew from Swedens most productive brewery. As Per says this is probably the prototype for what later became Dublin red. Yet another beer style I never have understood.
Sampled draught (nitro) at Stockholm Beer Festival. Dark ruby, creamy appearance. Peaty, roasty aroma. Light to medium body. Salty, flowery and bitterish finish.
0,5l bottle. Pours clear amber with off-white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, hops. Taste is malty, caramel, british kind of bitter hops. Light overall, but quite bitter also.
bursztynowe z ladna piana. Aromat slodowo, zbozowo, karmel. W smaku podobnie. Na finiszu minimalna goryczka

Pours foggy copper with a moderate beige-coloured head. Aroma: caramel malts, biscuit, herbal, interesting fruitiness, spicy Czech hop. Similar taste. Hoppy ending. Light bitterness. Medium minus body. Decent stuff. Aroma
500ml bottle from Beru Vykhodnoy in Moscow. Pours clear amber with a tall off-white head. Aroma is burnt caramel, herbs, bread. Taste is dry and slightly bitter, nuts, caramel, herbs.
tap @ cseh sörfesztivál (budapest) amber-red colour, normal body, average carbonated, caramel, malty, herbs, rather sweet than bitter, easy to drink
Bitvu dvou "polotmavých třináctek" z tohoto pivovaru vyhrál nad tímto pivem Vídeňský ležák, který není tak sladký a není cítit spáleným karamelem jako toto pivo - což pokládám za mínus.
Bottle. Malty aroma, caramel, herbal notes. Tastes the same as aroma, light to medium sweet and bitter. Medium body, malty bitter sweet finish. Average.
Bottle from Kaufland. Very beautiful appearance! Big head. Herbal aroma which I can't decipher. Very decent beer!

Eigentlich bin ich kein Freund halbdunkler Biere, aber bei diesem Bier hat man es geschafft, auch durch Zugabe von Kräutern, ein gutes volles Aroma zu etablieren, das nicht zu süß wird. Kann ich nur empfehlen.
V skupinovej terapii. Prijemna horko sladka vona. Jantarova farba, pena pekne drzi. Chut sladkasta karamelova jemne s kavou. Na konci ostava.
Very much despite it's name pale yellow, and slightly hazy. Some hay aroma. Clean and sweet, light bodied with low bitterness. Unremarkable not not at all unpleasant.

I had this beer many years ago at one time when I was only giving ratings to the beers but was too lazy and stupid to write down my thoughts. I will update this as soon as I get my hands on this beer again.
Deep amber. Slightly citrusy. Medium bodied, clean with quite bitter finish.
Bottle pours still and dark brown. Aroma and flavour are all malt. It's more ESB than IPA.

Bottle from Malt Traders Southbank on 3 December 2017. This is not your standard IPA as it looks, smells and tastes different from the many IPA’s that I have had in the past. More malty than hoppy and there is a copper red colour to it. Fresh and clean in the mouth with a sweetish malt aftertaste. Enjoyable beer from this brewery.
Bottle. Backlog rating from bottle collection and historic scoring. Source not recorded. No tasting notes kept, just rating.

Bottle, from Morrisons, Fort William. Dirty golden brown, thin but well sustained white head and good condition. Slightly fruity nose with hints of sweet caramel, quite full in the mouth with a little yeast bitternes, some earthy hop notes and a muted caramel sweetness. There is also a low citrus note and a suggestion of coconut. Finish has a little citrus hoppiness and a touch of yeast and more coconut.

* Bottle. Pours chestnut red, with an off-white head. * Aroma is medium, malt, toffee, hops & apple. * Palate is medium, high carbonation, large bubbles, moist. * Taste sweet malt, toffee, apple & slight hop. * Finish is sweet & moist. * Overall good taste, malty & moist but carbonation too high. A bitter not an IPA.
Bottle from morrisons. Quite dark in colour. Nutty, malty aroma and taste. Not like an IPA.

Bottle, part of a gift pack, no best-before or bottled-on date, blue and black label. This pours a hazy dark brown that is more chestnut than copper. The head is rather thin and retains poorly. Peaty caramel profile, tea-like hop character, more dry than bitter. Not undrinkable, but completely off the map for an "IPA".

I really enjoyed this beer. In glass is a dark red beer with a beige head, and adequate carbonation. The aroma has caramel, bread, and strong coffee notes, the taste is clear, with a medium body, not too much of the malt is felt, and that is the only bad thing. At the end the hops flavor is strong, and persistent, like an IPA should be.

Bottle from Tesco, Edinburgh. This is an amber-red coloured beer with a rich malty and red fruity flavour, roasted notes and a slight fruity finish. This tastes very much like an 80 shilling rather than an IPA.
500ml bottle at home. Pours copper brown with little to no head. Aromas are all malt, toffee, caramel, biscuit. Very light floral note. Sweet taste, thin on the palate. Pretty dull.

Creamy tan head left a decent cover on a jet black, thin looking body. Dark chocolate, coal, nutty & roast aroma. Medium bodied, smooth over the tongue with a sharper clean back. Bitter berry, chocolate, coal, nutty & roasted tastes with a fruity light citrus finish.
Not spectacular BB it a good solid dark beer. Malty, a little toasty, some chocolate. Simple but decent.
Cask @ NWAF 2017. Reddish brown with a tiny tan head. Fruity and acidic tones. Fruit, malt, acidity and hops. Medium body with a bitter / sour finish.

Gravity cask at National Winter Ales Festival. Black with a thick off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, licorice and raisin, with a phenolic, yeasty touch. Sweetish fruity and roasted flavour. Full body, easy drinking
From cask. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is roaste malty, dark breadish and roasted malty. Dry, dark roasted, bitter and mild chocolate note. Roasted dark breadish finish.
Drunk from 50cl bottle given as present by parents from their Scotland trip. Enjoyable dark, rich porter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Cask at SRAF. Pours brown. Nose is sweet dark malts, light roast. Taste is dryish, bitterish, dark malts.

Cask handpull at the Sulwath Brewery Tap. Dark brown with a creamy tan head. Coffee and liquorice dominate the nose. Sweet taste which turns to a malty Guinness-esque sourness. Solid and very tasty, an enjoyable beer.

Cask at the standing order. Pours clear dark brown, red chinks, thin beige head. Aromas of treacle scones. Taste is treacle too. Very thin and watery, like diluted treacle I guess. Some coffee notes sneak past the treacle, but it’s pretty poor overall.
pours dark brown with white head Aroma is grain with chocolate taste is sweet with dry tones not the best stout but very drinkable
Sampled draught at Stockholm Beer Festival. Golde colour, brief head. Grassy aroma. Dry and medium bodied with sharp mouthfeel. Salty finish.
Golden yellow. The is quite absent. Buttery flavour with nut tones and a dry finish.
Sampled draught at Stockholm Beer Festival. Spicy aroma. Malty and rather sweet with less sharp mouthfeel than most of the brewery's beers. Medium bitterness. Not overly complex.
2002 edition. The aroma is tangy with aromas of caramel and malt. The flavor is tangy and sweet with notes of brown sugar, malt and something tart, possibly orange. Strange beer!

(Bottle 33 cl) Very dark brown, almost mahogany with an underlying, warm reddish tone. Filtered, not much head. Very malty and lightly burned notes. Pretty close to the brewery’s Christmas beer. 100304
Dense dark lager with intense buttery aroma and palate. Oily and malty with hints of smoke, burnt rubber and chestnuts...

Red-brown. Buttery aroma. Malty flavour with tones of butter and rubber. Dry woody finish. A decent attempt to brew a dark lager. It has gotten better over the last year. The acidity has been replaced with more chocolate and coffee tones.
Dark amber color, with a nice head. Nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is roasted, some cocoa. Has a smokey flavor, some cocoa. A really nice one.
Dark rubybrown with good head. Nice lacing. Burnt and roasted aroma with some sour notes. dry, roasty and sligtly smokey flavour. Thin body with a short, unclean finish.
Smokey, sweet, salty, dark. Swine drink. Cardboard, soy sauce, rotting vegetables.
Dark ruby with a steday head. A lot of tar and smoke, almost like a rauchbier. Flavour from some smoked sausage.
Dark brown. Burnt nose. Some flavor of coffee with slight artificial taste. A little acidic.

A deep red beer with a fine but fast disappearing head. The aroma is sweet and fruity. The flavor is very sweet, slightly smoked and somewhat thin for a dark lager. It ends on an OK bitterness. Nothing special.

Õlle on selline jook, et iga uus kord kui klaasi või pudeli suule tõstad, siis leiad midagi uut, sõltuvalt tuhandest-miljonist pisiasjast, mis hetke olukorda mõjutavad. Seega piirdun iga õlle juures selle tekstiga.
Archives: 10 years ago it was a good beer to have. One of the best black lagers I had in from local manufacturers.
500ml bottle. Dark brown color. Sweet, caramel, some dark berries in aroma. Sweet, caramel, fruity in taste. Tastes like they have mixed some extract into it.
Dark beer, delicate aroma. Sweet, not very strong. Good.....................
Dark brown with creamy head. Sweet, medium bodied and lightly roasty. Low bitterness.

Aroma; bread, brown malts, syrup, a fruit. Look; big offwhite head, clear amber body. Taste; malts, caramel, tart, bread, fruit, citric hops, and finishes balanced. Feel; good body n fine co². Overall; good balance. Good drinkability. [btl SB @im hauslicher Umgebung] 5474'15
Bottle. Golden color. Floral maltaroma with a hint of caramel. Malty yet dryish flavor, floral, bready with a hint of caramel. Full bodied. Slightly perfumed. Decent.
Bottled as Weltenburger Kloster Festbier. Clear deep gold. Decent white head. Aroma: cereals, straw, bread, spicy hop. Medium body. Taste: grain, hay, bread, hop. Pleasant hoppy ending. Quite OK.
Tap at man in the moon. Clear amber with creamy, white head. Grassy and grainy with some caramel and crackers. Easy drinking.

I had this on tap at a Ocktoberfest in Japan. It was clearly at the Weltenburger booth labeled as an Octkoberfest beer and first time in Japan. I hope/assume its the same beer. GOlden amber color with a fair amount of malty sweetness, but really lacked much depth or character with a touch of buscuitiness. Mediocre at best.

Appearance Clear amber, small white head, sparse lacing. Aroma Roasted malts, caramel notes, nasty lager sulphur, wet cardboard, grass, grain, and skunky notes. Taste Bitter and dry, with a slightly harsh finish Palate Light, "crisp", sparkling, aftertaste of dark bread Overall Bland, dull, uninspired, I’m guessing it was made to replace the regular "chugging pilsner" in October.
SB Oskarshamn, flaska. Bra att SB tog in många i Oskarshamn. Utsökt oktoberfestbier. Dock inget för knut i nacken och skyglappar till brillor. Måste drickas i mass vad trodde ni....
En klassisk öl i linje med traditionen - gjorde för att bälgas snarare än att njutas..

500ml bottle from Systembolaget. Clear golden large white head, some lacing. Sweet and grassy aroma, sugar, biscuits. Thin and light mouthfeel, medium carbonated with gentle bubbles. Malt-sweet taste, caramel, biscuits, bread. Dry finish.
Luktar lite halmigt. Bra skum som ligger kvar. Smakar ganska neutralt, men lite alkoholantydan på slutet. Skulle ha varit 4,3 procent i stället...

Poured a rich amber with little head. Slight hops in the nose with a light malt as well. I was surprised to pick up some fruit and a little nuttiness too, making this a very interesting example of an amber ale. Overall very tasty and refreshing.

Bottle from the BevMo in Folsom, CA. Pours amber with a foamy off-white head. Smells malty. Maybe a little hop. Med body, or close. It has a certain nuttiness. If this were blind tasting, I’d consider it a brown. Even seems to have a hint of chocolate. Ok ale, just not my preference.
pours a nice amber with little to no head. This beer is sweet then bitter lightly bready and earthy!!
Bottle. Fruity caramel malt aroma. Slightly hazy amber with a small white head. Vegetal caramel malt and herbal hops flavor. Medium body and carbonation.
Bottle. Apple, berry and caramel malt aroma. Amber with nice tan head. Sweet caramel malt flavor. Bitter vegetal finish. Smelled good but not a fan of the finish.

At a tasting in Nimrod Rosenblatt house in Haifa during a blind tasting, bottle, pours cloudy dark orange amber color with off-white head that dissipates quickly, slowly to medium sparkling, hoppy and slightly sour bad aroma, slightly bitter taste, light body, too lively carbonation in the mouth, flows, overall a reasonably and not more beer.

Clear amber with an off-white head and decent lacing. Grassy and earthy hops aromas with a subtle caramel malt in the background. Flavors match, and include some clean pekoe tea notes. Medium body and carbonation and a clean hoppy finish.
Clear dark amber color/ beige head. Soapy, leafy hop aromas. medium bodied. Caramel, marshmallow sweet flavors with tea leaf hoppage. "Hermitage Amber Ale"
(12oz bottle thanks to Cavie) clear rich copper, film of white bubbles. Nose of candied oranges, rye, and caramel. Taste of light smoke, rye, umami, toasty grains of paradise.
orangish amber pour. Aroma of oranges, soap, honey and caramel malt. Flavor is a bit skunky, cardboard, honeycomb, wheat breat, perfumey flavor. Meh.
Bottled. dark brown color wit small beige head. Aroma, caramel, roasted malt. Taste, coffee, caramel, spices. Sweet aftertaste.

A beautiful dark clear brown beer with reddish hues, and a thick moka head. A pleasant sweet chocolate malt aroma. In mouth, sweet chocolate malt balls, cold coffee, very smooth. A nice schwarzbier. Oktoberfest evening at Marc Gratton’s, taste on April 20 2007

Bottled, 330ml with pull ring cap. From Pivovarsky Klub, Prague. Black, red hue, explosive brown head. Sweet and fruity dunkel, a little powdery in texture, but nicely set up with a blackcurrant, loganberry type flavour and a slightly cloying sweetness. Some carbonation, but not intrusive, a little chocolate, dark malt. Reasonably straight forward, uncomplicated beer.
Very good black beer. not very bitter a bit dry and sweet. I bought it last summer in the Czech Republic and storde it until Christmasday.

Clear very dark amber with a large frothy light brown head. Good lacing. Aroma of chocolate and caramel, quite sweet too. Oily feel in the mouth, more chocolate and caramel come through the sweet body. The beer also has a late fruity kick to it, with blueberry and wildfruits in the finish. Interesting and enjoyable.

330 ml bottle. Dark brown, almost black, with a deep ruby hue. Melanoidan round malty aroma. Dark sweet roasted, but at the same time, soft, malts. Medium-bodied. Some carbonation that sticks to the tongue. Soft and lightly souris mouthfeel. Gentle bitterness. Easy-drinking and not particularly complex, perhaps for other than the mentioned sourness.

Bottle at Luna Hotel in Prague. Nice amber color, quite fluffy offwhite head. Malty aroma with figs, cocoa, notes of ash and some apples. Malty flavor with toffee notes, some hops that grow stronger in the finish.

Creamy light beige head with larger bubbles. Deep dark red translucent body. Vague burnt sweetish malt aroma. Taste is sweetish licorice with some roasty malts. Somewhat watery. Faint aftertaste. Decent, nothing special. (0.33l bottle.)

Bottle at Arena Restaurant Pizzerie in Prague. Very dark brown color, big beige lasting creamy head. Malty sweet scent, not burnt but more to the bayern and münchener side. Fresh scent when the glass is swirled. Very rich mouthfeel. Sweet taste, low bitterness. Sweet aftertaste.

Bottle. Black beer with ruby edges and dark beige head. Some very nice velvety molasses, coffee and charcoal on aroma with some dark toffee too. Fullish in mouth, with more coffee/toffee. Finish is dryish. Not too sweet and just a feeling of juicy velvet. Nice beer.

I am admittedly biased , having hailed from the Black Country. However this beer, as many on here know is something of a phenomenon. I have read many negative reviews regarding the bottled Bathams...and I couldn’t agree more! The bottles are in no way a proper representation of a well kept, well poured pint of the real stuff. On a good day it is a perfectly smooth, delicately hopped brew with a refreshingly sweet and malty finish. It is by far one of the areas best kept secrets and it is both a blessing and a curse that often the only stuff that reaches the outside world is the bottled version which is, in that particular format, a very average beer.

This beer is my personal favourite. The comments regarding quality depending on location are correct. Bull and Bladder is the best place to drink it. The furthest I have found it on draft was Shrewsbury. The Great Weston in Wolverhampton serves a very good pint and worth a visit if you don’t know the place. Oh and the Unicorn in Wollaston.. I could go on. Basically anywhere that serves Bathams is worth a visit!
This is a hell of a bitter. It is best drunk on draught. In a bottle it is unremarkable. But at the Bull and Bladder it is fantasit. Smooth, creamy, I sank 5 pints in an hour. Beutiful pint.
Only drink on draught. It is a just such a wonderfully smooth beer. An afternoon drinking this in the Bull and Bladder is heaven.

Batham's is a beer that tastes best when drunk as close to the brewery as possible. Beers from the bull and bladder are fantastic, and the exchange in Wollaston is possibly the best place to get it. Unfortunately the bottles are not representative of how it tastes draught and are best avoided, being too gassy and bland.

Very easy drinking session beer. Amber colour with a hint of caramel Lovely smooth ale its my personal favorite I am very lucky that my local The Nags Head in Malvern has this as a permanent choice on tap.
I was wrong the first time I had this - I didn't think that much of it. It's pretty much a perfect bitter.

Many thanks to Erzengel for sharing! A clear golden beer with a mid-sized most good lasting off-white head. Aroma of mild grainy malt, soft sweet malt with hints of straw. Taste of grainy malt, toasted malt, flowery hops, soft grassy bitterness, okay!
Many thanks to Minutemat for this bottle. Smooth grainy nose. The beer starts grainy round, full bodied, grainy. Round and smooth, mild and moderate bitter. Great.
Bottle @ Cotteridge Wines. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity and light grainy. Flavor is medium sweet. Sweet finish. Watery. 270717

Keg @ Golden Calley. Medium Gold pour with a small white head. Aroma of toasted grain. Light caramel. Mild earthy hop. Flavor has some supple, sweet malt accent. Crisp toasted bread. Some candy corn. A bit boozy. Medium body, oily.

On tap at golden Valley brewing. Pours out golden topped with a white head. Nose is sweet malts toffee plenty of grain and some fruit. Taste is more of the sweet malts toffee rich fruit and a nice end.

Super hazy peachy orange colored beer with a good white head. The nose is mild and sweet while in the mouth it is very flavorsome. Smooth, doughy and grassy flavors coming from a seamless mingling of hip and barley. Hints of light orange and mango. Not much of a finish to it.

355ml bottle pours dark amber in color with a finger of off-white head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma is bready malts and caramel with mild hops. Taste is big malty sweetness with a little hop bitterness in the finish. Lacking a little in the balance of flavors, but still a drinkable brew, just not as good as it could be.

Bottle: &nbsp Amberish, slight haze, a little fiery and dark, thin sudsy off-white head, dies quickly, sparce lacing. &nbsp Sweet mealy nose, slight breadiness, a bit of unripened melon. &nbsp Really mealy on the tongue. &nbsp Some biscuit and breadiness, pale fruitiness. &nbsp Seems a little heavy in its sweetness, but not really in body. &nbsp As it warms I get some alcohol coming out. &nbsp Somewhat sticky. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate, albeit its a bit sugary and clingy. &nbsp Its okay, but seems a little unrefined. &nbsp Not all that smooth, and certainly wouldnt reach for another after finishing this 22oz. &nbsp A little too sweet in my opinion.
Draft @ the Brewpub. Pours a clear golden color with a small off-white head. Has a sweetish grainy malty aroma. Sweetish malty grainy caramel flavor. Has a sweetish malty caramel finish.
Hazy amber with minimal head and good lacings. Interesting flavors. Sweet malts with a slightly bitter hop profile. A bit of sweet and sour going on here. A refreshing brew that was quite enjoyable.

From a 12 oz. bottle--a distinctive burnt sienna/copper colored lager with an outstanding malt taste and pleasing hop undertones. Though it is debatable whether this bock is a "true lager" as noted by the brewery, the hint of apple in this beer is far from overbearing. This bock finishes quite smooth though a little dull.
12oz bottle. Poured a medium and hazy golden color with a small sized head. Aromas of grains, some caramel, toasted malts, and lightly nutty. Tastes of caramel, honey sweetness, bready, and citrus.

Bottle Malty aroma with citrus tones. Poured pale brown with white head. Malty flavour, with an unpleasant big swath of molasses in the middle of it. Bready finish, with more molasses. I admit I’m not familiar with the Heiliges Geist bock style, but I would not seek this out. It could be I just don’t like the style.

column1: Rio Salado Autumn Deluge Alt Bier Amber Ale
column5: Aroma was like walking into a musty old bar. You can smell the fermantation. Beer held to light has a dark red tint to it. Decent head to the beer. Sweet malts gave it a licorice gave it a licorice flavor. Hops came though to. At the end I thought this beer was simular to a port wine.

column1: Rio Salado Autumn Deluge Alt Bier Amber Ale
column5: Bottle poured a nice dark brown with a good lasting head. A brisk Aroma of fruits and malt. Nice east drinking beer with a lot of taste.. tangy smoke with a bit of a kick on the finish. I like it .. I like it a lot.

column1: Rio Salado Autumn Deluge Alt Bier Amber Ale
column5: Dark Rust. Tame, barely existant aroma with mild fruit, heavy malt and subtle German hops. Fruity, mainly plums, but also a variety of German malt notes (chocolate, coffee, roased malts, bread). Noble hops. An odd range of flavors that worked, but isn’t really intune with the best of the style.

column1: Rio Salado Autumn Deluge Alt Bier Amber Ale
column5: bottle-pours a crimson amber hue with a nice off-white head. big malts, spice, german hops and sage on the aroma. slightly smokey? Nice big vienna style flavors here. I would have thought this was a lager. nice malts and a noble hop backbone. slightly fizzy body, but nothing really that detracting. Very good brew!!!

column1: Rio Salado Autumn Deluge Alt Bier Amber Ale
column5: A little dark for the style but was a hell of a lot better than last years version. Rio Salado appears to be back on track after a couple of years of declining quality due to the origional brewer making the beer again. I even bought a 6 pack to go.

column1: Rio Salado Autumn Deluge Alt Bier Amber Ale
column5: Appearance: lovely ruby red color, with a fine, fluffy, creamy head that fast fizzles down. Aroma: sweet and fruity, but largely clean and dry. Taste is clear and smooth, with a medium body, and great balance. Delicious hoppiness right up at first, followed by solid malt. All in all, this was a decent and quite drinkable ale!

column1: Rio Salado Autumn Deluge Alt Bier Amber Ale
column5: A really nice brown ale (though it's labeled altbier)! I was annoyed that I couldn't get much of a head out of it. It's sort of like a light Porter with lots of malt and medium roastiness. Not overpowering with nuttiness or anything to differentiate it from a full-bodied English Brown Ale. Fairly sweet, too, but don't look here for hops.

column1: Rio Salado Autumn Deluge Alt Bier Amber Ale
column5: Deep dark roasted coffee color. Sweet malty aroma, a little nutty. The initial taste is sweet a little watery. Soft in the flavor, medium bodied. Has many different aspects to it. Brown, regular ale. Of a porter, stout even a dunkel. An interesting beer that requires more tastings.

column1: Rio Salado Autumn Deluge Alt Bier Amber Ale
column5: Pours a dark brown, with some deep red notes when held up to the light. A thin brown head with roasted aromas in the nose. Lightly fruity but predominantly roasted in character, like a roast porter actually. Taste is not quite so roasty as the aroma, but it is definitely there and a bit out of place in something called an Alt. This beer is lightly hoppy and finishes with some bitterness. If you take a step back from this beer and view it as something other than an Alt bier then it has some merit to it. Quite a tasty brown ale with interesting roasted notes. This is not what I expected from an Alt, it pushes the boundaries a bit much, but it is tasty. The roasted notes and the deep brown color are not really typical. It seems as though the recipe has been change recently. Still a good beer though, no longer the Alt that I remember and was hoping for.

column1: Rio Salado Autumn Deluge Alt Bier Amber Ale
column5: Big head from bottle pour. Awesome dark amber color. Nice sweet aroma to it. Nice balace of flavor to it, I even found a little sweet grape bubble gum taste to it when it finished.

Draft sample @ Back Road festival. Hazy golden with a small white head. Sweet banana orange, clove, and bready wheat malt flavor. Orange wheat malt, clove, and grassy herbal hops flavor. Medium body, soft carbonation.
Draft. Banana, orange, clove and wheat malt aroma. Hazy golden yellow with moderate head. Sweet orange/banana, wheat malt, and moderately bitter hay flavor. Very good - very hoppy for a hefeweizen.
Light amber pour with no head at all. Aroma is heavy in citrus and malts. Medium body. The bitter flavor brings this beer down. Light on hops but a bitter palate.
Orange pour. No head. Aroma of citrus. Flavor is bland with a weird bitterness. Dry finish.
12 oz bottle. nothing too surprising. banana, orange body. i agree that flooding this beer with hops could be a nice addition.

The appearance was a small sized white head with fine-small bubbles that completely dissipated during my rating. The body was uncarbonated, clear with a orange hue. The nose was malty, fruity, some spice with banana notes and the flavor was fruity and spicy. The mouthfeel was smooth and fruity. The lacing was very sparse.

This brew poured a small head of fine to medium sized white colored mostly diminishing bubbles that left behind a softly carbonated yellow orange colored body. The aroma was a mild malt hop one and the mouthfeel was smooth with a lingering fruity finish. The flavor was a mild malt hop one with a balance of fruit.

Woo Doggy; I’m the 7th rater of the Back Road Weiss, thanks to the BigBadBear63 for the hook up! I should have gone with the straight pour into my Erdinger wizen glass for the frothy head effect. The body is a pale orange / bronzy color, little head due to my crappy pouring job. The aroma and flavor are very much in conjunction, BIG orange and tangerine peals, and coriander, absolute notes of banana, as well as a yeasty soft doughy sensation. If the palate were more abundant, maybe creamier or oilier it would certainly be getting higher marks. Thanks for the brew Mike; I enjoyed it!

Clear yellow gold with no head (I could only get big bubbles even with a hard pour). Spicey banana yeast nose. Thin body with initial apricot,apple and banana fruit flavors. Lemon and spice try to come to the fore but fall short. Back Road has some much better beers.
Orange smell, orange color and no head. Very thin even at the pour, hints of what could have been spice but not enough to make a differance.

Bottle from Tim. This was poured into a mug. The appearance was a soft pale yellow transparent color with a quickly dissipating foamy to fizzy head. No lace. The aroma had some sweet lemon pulp, light wheat, some white pepper, sweet grassiness, light citrus glossing and then a touch of coriander and light orange peel. The flavor had a crisp sweetness about it coming from the prior mentioned aromas. White pepper hit slightly and dissipated to allow a light tart nip right before the aftertaste which was somewhat citrusy and had the coriander. Finish was quick and had the orange peel with the white pepper. The palate was between light and medium bodied with a fair sessionability about it. Carbonation felt fine. ABV felt fine. Overall, decent little Americanized witbier that I wouldnt mind having again, maybe not one to seek out, but it does the trick in the warmer weather.

12oz, no date. Opened with only the faintest hiss. Clear golden orange with a 1/2 finger white head, quickly fading to a thin ring. Lots of orange in the aroma. Spicy coriander and light lemon are in the background with some sweet pale malts. Flavor is a little bit papery and adds some sour lemon pulp tang, stronger yeasty elements, and soft wheat. Minimal bitterness in the crisp wheaty finish. Low carbonation with a heavier body that what I usually get for the style--maybe the carbonation kept it from being lightened much. I also picked this up from Pat’s Liquors.
Orange, coriander, yeasty spiciness, some wheat grassiness, but all undercut by a faint, but persistent, off-tasting sour tartness that always makes me think of bottling-line problems...

Nice looking pour, a hazy pale straw body with a tall fizzy white head. It’s got an aroma of tart wheat, oranges, and bitter lemon grass. According to the commercial description, it has a "delicious taste described as citrus/celery like." Thankfully, I perceived no unwanted (from a Wit’s style viewpoint) vegetables in the flavor. Wheat, a tart citric taste (orange with a squirt of lemon), and some coriander was what I encountered. Actually, not too bad. Pat’s Liquors, Porter, IN

Bottle from BBB63. Hazy yellow beer with a substantial foamy white head. The aroma has tangerine, apricot and some yeast in it. Fruity orange and apricot flavors with subtle corriander spice and a tangy yeastiness. Spices and pepper take over in the finish. It is hot on the tongue with an almost distracting carbonation. I can hear the bubbles breaking in the glass.

Pours bright and yellow. Nice wheaty aroma. Mellow banana flavor with the corriander and orange nicely showcased. Great refreshing body. All flavors mellow and balanced. I would like to see this brew kicked up a notch. Nice refreshing taste, just not as bold as it could be.

Bottle. Strong banana and clove aroma. Cloudy amber color with no head. Slightly sweet banana/clove malt flavor - no carbonation. Very nice aroma and good taste but flatness may turn some off this beer.

2006 bottle from BBB63, drunk on 8/20/06. Low-to-moderate haziness in this more traditionally colored copper colored beer with deep peachy-gold tints. White head shows very poor retention, and little/no lacing. Large bubbles rise listlessly in the liquid.... Wheat and spices collide in the nose, with moderate acidity being drawn from the yeast and perhaps the coriander. Strong, nutty wheat notes downplay the moderate phenolic character (white and black pepper, some clove-like notes), while the soft pils-malt seems ample, though certainly not assertive. I do get a good deal of fruitiness, mainly citric (lemons and oranges) with some softer fruits produced from the yeast. Aroma is medium strength, no alcohol apparent. Wet, somewhat slick texture immediately highlights the low carbonation. And what is there, is rather fizzy and large/loose-bubbled. Some wateriness on the end as well, but other than carbonation issues, a very simple, but well-done wit. Honey/dough from the pils malt, with light coriander bitterness, some touches of spicy phenols and an almost biscuity note through the middle. High attenuation, varied fruitiness; citric and mellower fruits. Moderate acidity helps keep interest. No alcohol/flaws, but a tighter carbonation would provide much more expressiveness for the flavors.

Dirty gold haze. Dusty white head. Some foot was in first aroma. Some spicy orange follows. Not too bad, but typical aroma. "Do I have to drink it?" I asked BBB63. Its kind of odd tasting… like sour orange with some wheat. Its okay but not my thing.

Pale blond grapefruit color with bubble cloisters adhering to the sides of the glass, rising to the top and popping at the surface to form a tiny head. Lemons shaved and smashed on honey dough introduce the aroma, with spiced nodes of cardamom and referencing cola traits, and coriander, to foot the rest of the bill. Sweet honey and biscuit flavor characteristics are congealed with a searing lemon and coriander twangs. Wishy washy skew of a French bakery with exploding spice canisters. Wholesome kneaded dough with bitter orange peel makes a final attempt to keep this one in purgatory and halt the decent into hell. Lighter-bodied, semi-effervescent and keeling to broaching acidity. Green cardamom reverberations hug like fresh ginger cola in the finish. Thanks for the Indiana treat, BBB63!

Cask at the Station Hotel, Ipswich. Pours clear bright golden with a small white head leaving good lacing. Aroma of citrus, hop, grass and flowers. Medium sweetness, light bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation.
Cask at GBBF 2012. (Backlog / historic rating from old records. NO tasting notes taken / kept) (Backlog)
Cask. A very rich and smooth golden ale. There was plenty of malt and this was balanced by good bitter hops. It’s not one to session because of the richness, but a good place to start the evening
Cask at the Riverside, Pennal. Pours light gold with a small head. Aroma is mango and papaya jelly. Taste has mango, papaya and lime jelly.

Sampled on draft at the John Baird in Muswell Hill. Golden colour with a white head. The taste is dominated by spruce and citrus with a grapefruity finish. Full bodied and low carbonation. Very pleasant and highly drinkable.

Cask, JDW, Hamilton Hall, 20/2/2016. White lacing. Golden appearance. Straw, hey and spruce and garden dew on aroma. Taste is hey, straw, herbs, mint tea like texture and oranges. An odd but well made and definitely underhopped golden ale.

Cask at the Prince Arthur (JDW), Fleet. Straw in colour with a ring of white froth; lemon citrus aroma; a crisp lemony citrus taste with a grainy, medium body; then a grapefruit bitterness with lingering honey. Rather good.
Cask at the Stockbridge tap. Pours clear golden, nose is sweet toffee, floral, peach, taste is similar, dry finish.

It seems like buses, good beers for the Friday after work session come along in two’s. Having recently enjoyed Naylors 5% Snowstorm, this one kept me and Mai in the Tilley Stone Friday gone. Bright gold, white head grapefruit aroma, lovely tropical and grapefruit flavours, Pleasing floral hops. Lovely bitter-sweet balance, and a kind of perfect storm of the best elements of a blond, a quality pilsner, and a golden Belgian ale. Of the four hand pulls on in the pub, I would say a good 70% of quaffers were enjoying this. Salopian yet to put a foot wrong for me.

Cask at Crown Rivers, Heathrow. Clear golden liquid with small white head. Aroma of earth, floral hops, bread, light citrus, very light butter and light grain. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of bread, light butter, earth, red berries and floral hops. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Bit buttery, but very true to style.

column4: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
column5: 473ml can. Had this one ages ago back in my dorm days. I don’t really remember it all that well, but I do recall only buying one. Mind you, if it had been horrible that would probably stand out, so there we are. Overall, it was unhorrible.

column4: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
column5: Je ne l’ai bu qu’une fois à Ottawa, elle est meilleur que la plus connu. Arome légèrement riche, saveur de caramel et de malt un peu roti et un peu amère.

column4: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
column5: On tap at Highlander Pub, Ottawa. Dark copper body topped with a thin off-white creamy head. Good malty aroma with notes of roasted cereals and toffee. Decent and well-balanced malty/hoppy taste that ends with a quite short bitter finish.

column4: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
column5: Can... Surprisingly unhorrible. I really don’t know what to celebrate with a 5% ABV ale, but not at all bad. Pretty darn malty without being too sweet. I wouldn’t buy it again, but I’m glad I did this once. Found the can at a corner market while in Montreal. I didn’t know I could even get this stuff in Quebec.

column4: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
column5: I have to go against the group here. I was really surprised how much I liked this ale. Beautiful copper colour and thick creamy head. Flavourful at the first impression, nice feel in the mouth and a good finish. Awfully good and amazingly better than the (OK) Keith’s regular product.

column4: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
column5: Somewhat thick, off white head. Darker golden colour body. Smells of ale yeast, malt and some kind of metalish scent. The can that I had this beer out of was probably guilty of this. Some sugary corn notes too. The flavour of this was much better than the smell. Slightly watery with hints of maple sugar and more malt. The palate was a little bitter to start and watery to finish. The malts saved it!

column4: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
column5: Amber in colour. Slight aroma of malts and tin. Flavour was really light, with a watery sweetness. Not to bad coming from this brewery.

column4: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
column5: Not bad for a Keiths. Nice foamy head. A little bit of hops and a nice malty taste, a bit roasted. Better than Rickard's Dreg!

column4: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
column5: This one has a little more hop in the mouth and in the nose. Not a great beer, but the best from this producer.

column4: Alexander Keith's Nova Scotia Brewery / Oland Brewery (AB InBev)
column5: Not much of a head, but not all that bad. Not that good, either, however. Easy drinking, with a good hop nose and taste, but its a bit light on the finish. Not enough oomph. Had at the brewery, on the tour.
12 oz bottle pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of caramel, earthy and toast. Taste is caramel and some nutty notes

Draft from notes. Pours a clear amber color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have toasted malts, caramel, earthy and floral hops, grass, dry, decent enough for an amber, but...

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a pint glass. Off-white 3 finger head. The color is a rich amber. Grapefruit and sweet malt on the nose. In the taste the mouthfeel is creamy, smooth and superbly balanced between malts and hops. Notes of biscuit, toast, honey, pine, grapefruit. The finish is grapefruit, pine and honey.
Poured from a bomber in Portland....dark red with moderate head..little lacing. Nose is sweet - caramel and toffee - with moderately bitter taste...good bitter aftertaste lingers a bit. Tasty.

Draft nitro. Poured a clear dark copper color with an average fizzy off-white head that was mostly lasting and had good lacing. Good earthy hop & toasted sweet malt aroma. Medium body with smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Good brew.
From a bomber. Pours a hazy deep amber with a thick ecru head. Nutty aroma. Jammy flavors with a bitter hop finish.

Pours a deep reddish brown on nitro tap with thick tan head that dissipates slowly to leave good lace. Aroma and taste of sweet caramel and bready malt, nutty notes, and earthy ending. This is a really nice balanced amber with great mouth and finish from the nitro.
Brick red with a tall tan head. Aroma is sweet, lightly toasted malts, spivey hop bite. Medium bodied. Flavor has nice caramel malts, a bit of hop spice, light fruit. Full flavored and quite tasty.

Amber-copper color with a soft nitro off-white head. Light malty aroma with hint of floral hops. Smooth malty milky with touch of dry floral hop character. Notes: On nitro tap. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a finger and half of head on a dark straw body. The aroma is sharp citrus and pine. The taste has a nice moderate pine and citrus bitterness, then mellows to a mild sweet finish. The texture is crisp. It smells great and tastes good.

column4: Paulaner Bräuhaus Singapore (Brau Holding Int. - Heineken)
column5: Keg at Paulaner Bräuhaus, Singapore. Hazy deep amber, creamy head. Fruity, nutty nose. Mid sweet with medium body and rounded mouthfeel. Nutty, toasty and fruity. Mild grassy hops leads to a mid bitter finish.

column4: Paulaner Bräuhaus Singapore (Brau Holding Int. - Heineken)
column5: Tap @ the brewpub. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are caramel, roasted malt, notes of chocolate, little toffee and hops. Sweet malty finish.

column4: Paulaner Bräuhaus Singapore (Brau Holding Int. - Heineken)
column5: Draft - Dark sugars and malts. Cloudy light brown with a beige head. Light raisin and some mellow Cinnamon with a ligh dark malt finish.

column4: Paulaner Bräuhaus Singapore (Brau Holding Int. - Heineken)
column5: Wässrig malziger Antrunk. Keine Herbe, geringe Würzigkeit, die zum Mittelteil ansteigt. Leider bleibt das Bier auch nach steigender Intensität laff und langweilig. Mild bitter-malziger Nachhall. 8/7/8/7//7

column4: Paulaner Bräuhaus Singapore (Brau Holding Int. - Heineken)
column5: Draft at the brewpub. Cloudy brown with an off white head. Aroma of caramel, malt, light hops and candy notes. Flavour is light to moderate sweet and bitter. Light to medium bodied with soft carbonation.

column4: Paulaner Bräuhaus Singapore (Brau Holding Int. - Heineken)
column5: Tap at the Suntec City, brewpub, Singapore. Poured a murky medium brown with a frothy white head and some broken lace. The aroma is dry creamy malt, yeast. The flavour is grainy yeast, crushed banana, light roasty notes, dry earthy grain. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

column4: Paulaner Bräuhaus Singapore (Brau Holding Int. - Heineken)
column5: Draught @ microbrewery in Singapore on 30/6/16. One of three brewed on site. I thought this was the best of the bunch with a clean toasty sweet malty palate and a lowish bitterness made for a session. Nice presentation with a copper brown body and lasting off-white head. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

column4: Paulaner Bräuhaus Singapore (Brau Holding Int. - Heineken)
column5: Draught pint at the Mad Poet, Singapore on 19/03/15. Staff really didn’t know what they were selling - calling it ’dark lager’ - should have taken that as an omen. Appearance was fine. Aroma of liquorice and malt. Taste of caramel, chocolate malt. Fizzy, sweet and watery at the same time. Pretty poor.

column4: Paulaner Bräuhaus Singapore (Brau Holding Int. - Heineken)
column5: Not really a Munchener or a dunkel. Wimpy nose, a bit caramel sugary, nothing much resembling a hop around the place. Disappointing but harmless.

column4: Paulaner Bräuhaus Singapore (Brau Holding Int. - Heineken)
column5: Draught at the brewpub. Hazy brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, carame, hops and bitterness.
